00:06:13.510 --> 00:06:17.972
I want to say that the treatments we have
for depression are appalling.

00:06:17.996 --> 00:06:19.599
They're not very effective.

00:06:19.916 --> 00:06:21.686
They're extremely costly.

00:06:21.710 --> 00:06:24.207
They come with innumerable side effects.

00:06:24.231 --> 00:06:25.668
They're a disaster.

00:06:25.985 --> 00:06:30.652
But I am so grateful that I live now
and not 50 years ago,

00:06:30.676 --> 00:06:33.596
when there would have been
almost nothing to be done.

00:06:33.620 --> 00:06:36.003
I hope that 50 years hence,

00:06:36.027 --> 00:06:38.049
people will hear about my treatments

00:06:38.073 --> 00:06:41.741
and be appalled that anyone endured
such primitive science.

00:06:42.843 --> 00:06:46.085
Depression is the flaw in love.

00:06:47.399 --> 00:06:50.516
If you were married
to someone and thought,

00:06:50.540 --> 00:06:54.250
"Well, if my wife dies,
I'll find another one,"

00:06:54.274 --> 00:06:56.523
it wouldn't be love as we know it.

00:06:57.322 --> 00:07:01.889
There's no such thing as love
without the anticipation of loss,

00:07:01.913 --> 00:07:07.469
and that specter of despair
can be the engine of intimacy.

00:07:08.162 --> 00:07:10.993
There are three things
people tend to confuse:

00:07:11.017 --> 00:07:14.106
depression, grief and sadness.

00:07:14.924 --> 00:07:18.263
Grief is explicitly reactive.

00:07:18.287 --> 00:07:21.168
If you have a loss
and you feel incredibly unhappy,

00:07:21.192 --> 00:07:22.867
and then, six months later,

00:07:22.891 --> 00:07:25.976
you are still deeply sad,
but you're functioning a little better,

00:07:26.000 --> 00:07:27.785
it's probably grief,

00:07:27.809 --> 00:07:31.544
and it will probably ultimately
resolve itself in some measure.

00:07:31.568 --> 00:07:34.373
If you experience a catastrophic loss,

00:07:34.397 --> 00:07:35.699
and you feel terrible,

00:07:35.723 --> 00:07:38.512
and six months later
you can barely function at all,

00:07:38.536 --> 00:07:41.050
then it's probably a depression
that was triggered

00:07:41.074 --> 00:07:43.257
by the catastrophic circumstances.

00:07:43.606 --> 00:07:46.776
The trajectory tells us a great deal.

00:07:47.154 --> 00:07:50.514
People think of depression
as being just sadness.

00:07:50.538 --> 00:07:52.709
It's much, much too much sadness,

00:07:52.733 --> 00:07:54.484
much too much grief

00:07:54.508 --> 00:07:56.617
at far too slight a cause.

00:07:57.428 --> 00:08:00.213
As I set out to understand depression,

00:08:00.237 --> 00:08:02.884
and to interview people
who had experienced it,

00:08:02.908 --> 00:08:06.701
I found that there were people
who seemed, on the surface,

00:08:06.725 --> 00:08:09.938
to have what sounded like
relatively mild depression

00:08:09.962 --> 00:08:12.700
who were nonetheless
utterly disabled by it.

00:08:13.255 --> 00:08:15.668
And there were other people
who had what sounded

00:08:15.692 --> 00:08:18.754
as they described it
like terribly severe depression

00:08:18.778 --> 00:08:20.518
who nonetheless had good lives

00:08:20.542 --> 00:08:23.248
in the interstices
between their depressive episodes.

00:08:23.843 --> 00:08:27.808
And I set out to find out
what it is that causes some people

00:08:27.832 --> 00:08:30.061
to be more resilient than other people.

00:08:30.085 --> 00:08:33.301
What are the mechanisms
that allow people to survive?

00:08:33.610 --> 00:08:36.808
And I went out and I interviewed
person after person

00:08:36.832 --> 00:08:38.808
who was suffering with depression.

00:08:38.832 --> 00:08:41.023
One of the first people I interviewed

00:08:41.047 --> 00:08:45.901
described depression
as a slower way of being dead,

00:08:45.925 --> 00:08:48.259
and that was a good thing
for me to hear early on

00:08:48.283 --> 00:08:51.390
because it reminded me
that that slow way of being dead

00:08:51.414 --> 00:08:53.694
can lead to actual deadness,

00:08:53.718 --> 00:08:55.675
that this is a serious business.

00:08:55.699 --> 00:08:58.088
It's the leading disability worldwide,

00:08:58.112 --> 00:09:00.194
and people die of it every day.

00:09:01.142 --> 00:09:04.861
One of the people I talked to
when I was trying to understand this

00:09:04.885 --> 00:09:08.746
was a beloved friend
who I had known for many years,

00:09:08.770 --> 00:09:13.223
and who had had a psychotic episode
in her freshman year of college,

00:09:13.247 --> 00:09:16.049
and then plummeted
into a horrific depression.

00:09:16.073 --> 00:09:17.712
She had bipolar illness,

00:09:17.736 --> 00:09:20.223
or manic depression, as it was then known.

00:09:20.247 --> 00:09:24.032
And then she did very well
for many years on lithium,

00:09:24.056 --> 00:09:27.205
and then eventually,
she was taken off her lithium

00:09:27.229 --> 00:09:29.040
to see how she would do without it,

00:09:29.064 --> 00:09:31.015
and she had another psychosis,

00:09:31.039 --> 00:09:35.399
and then plunged into the worst depression
that I had ever seen

00:09:35.423 --> 00:09:38.240
in which she sat
in her parents' apartment,

00:09:38.264 --> 00:09:41.536
more or less catatonic,
essentially without moving,

00:09:41.560 --> 00:09:43.473
day after day after day.

00:09:43.901 --> 00:09:47.385
And when I interviewed her
about that experience some years later --

00:09:47.409 --> 00:09:50.510
she's a poet and psychotherapist
named Maggie Robbins --

00:09:50.534 --> 00:09:53.580
when I interviewed her, she said,

00:09:53.604 --> 00:09:57.123
"I was singing 'Where Have
All The Flowers Gone,'

00:09:57.147 --> 00:10:00.044
over and over, to occupy my mind.

00:10:00.513 --> 00:10:03.309
I was singing to blot out
the things my mind was saying,

00:10:03.333 --> 00:10:08.093
which were, 'You are nothing.
You are nobody.

00:10:08.117 --> 00:10:10.048
You don't even deserve to live.'

00:10:10.649 --> 00:10:13.055
And that was
when I really started thinking

00:10:13.079 --> 00:10:14.433
about killing myself."

00:10:15.151 --> 00:10:19.061
You don't think in depression
that you've put on a gray veil

00:10:19.085 --> 00:10:22.449
and are seeing the world
through the haze of a bad mood.

00:10:22.959 --> 00:10:25.949
You think that the veil
has been taken away,

00:10:25.973 --> 00:10:27.577
the veil of happiness,

00:10:27.601 --> 00:10:29.538
and that now you're seeing truly.

00:10:30.205 --> 00:10:32.965
It's easier to help
schizophrenics who perceive

00:10:32.989 --> 00:10:36.963
that there's something foreign
inside of them that needs to be exorcised,

00:10:36.987 --> 00:10:39.313
but it's difficult with depressives,

00:10:39.337 --> 00:10:42.139
because we believe
we are seeing the truth.

00:10:42.998 --> 00:10:44.543
But the truth lies.

00:10:45.945 --> 00:10:47.919
I became obsessed with that sentence:

00:10:47.943 --> 00:10:50.075
"But the truth lies."

00:10:50.393 --> 00:10:52.833
And I discovered,
as I talked to depressive people,

00:10:52.857 --> 00:10:55.429
that they have
many delusional perceptions.

00:10:55.773 --> 00:10:57.511
People will say, "No one loves me."

00:10:57.535 --> 00:10:58.747
And you say, "I love you,

00:10:58.771 --> 00:11:01.269
your wife loves you,
your mother loves you."

00:11:01.293 --> 00:11:04.654
You can answer that one pretty readily,
at least for most people.

00:11:05.082 --> 00:11:07.248
But people who are depressed
will also say,

00:11:07.272 --> 00:11:11.319
"No matter what we do,
we're all just going to die in the end."

00:11:11.343 --> 00:11:13.572
Or they'll say,
"There can be no true communion

00:11:13.596 --> 00:11:14.958
between two human beings.

00:11:14.982 --> 00:11:17.366
Each of us is trapped in his own body."

00:11:17.763 --> 00:11:19.383
To which you have to say,

00:11:19.407 --> 00:11:20.886
"That's true,

00:11:20.910 --> 00:11:24.418
but I think we should focus right now
on what to have for breakfast."

00:11:24.442 --> 00:11:26.603
(Laughter)

00:11:26.627 --> 00:11:28.272
A lot of the time,

00:11:28.296 --> 00:11:31.270
what they are expressing
is not illness, but insight,

00:11:31.294 --> 00:11:33.825
and one comes to think
what's really extraordinary

00:11:33.849 --> 00:11:36.981
is that most of us know
about those existential questions

00:11:37.005 --> 00:11:39.049
and they don't distract us very much.

00:11:39.386 --> 00:11:41.208
There was a study I particularly liked

00:11:41.232 --> 00:11:44.975
in which a group of depressed
and a group of non-depressed people

00:11:44.999 --> 00:11:47.723
were asked to play a video
game for an hour,

00:11:47.747 --> 00:11:49.367
and at the end of the hour,

00:11:49.391 --> 00:11:53.001
they were asked how many little monsters
they thought they had killed.

00:11:53.025 --> 00:11:57.010
The depressive group was usually accurate
to within about 10 percent,

00:11:57.034 --> 00:11:58.605
and the non-depressed people

00:11:58.629 --> 00:12:03.083
guessed between 15 and 20 times
as many little monsters --

00:12:03.107 --> 00:12:04.258
(Laughter)

00:12:04.282 --> 00:12:06.034
as they had actually killed.

00:12:07.903 --> 00:12:11.119
A lot of people said, when I chose
to write about my depression,

00:12:11.143 --> 00:12:14.608
that it must be very difficult
to be out of that closet,

00:12:14.632 --> 00:12:15.941
to have people know.

00:12:15.965 --> 00:12:18.234
They said, "Do people
talk to you differently?"

00:12:18.258 --> 00:12:20.337
I said, "Yes, people
talk to me differently.

00:12:20.361 --> 00:12:22.123
They talk to me differently insofar

00:12:22.147 --> 00:12:24.814
as they start telling me
about their experience,

00:12:24.838 --> 00:12:26.649
or their sister's experience,

00:12:26.673 --> 00:12:28.314
or their friend's experience.

00:12:28.687 --> 00:12:30.885
Things are different because now I know

00:12:30.909 --> 00:12:35.014
that depression is the family secret
that everyone has.

00:12:35.673 --> 00:12:39.299
I went a few years ago to a conference,

00:12:39.323 --> 00:12:41.754
and on Friday of the three-day conference,

00:12:41.778 --> 00:12:44.783
one of the participants
took me aside, and she said,

00:12:44.807 --> 00:12:51.056
"I suffer from depression
and I'm a little embarrassed about it,

00:12:51.080 --> 00:12:52.922
but I've been taking this medication,

00:12:52.946 --> 00:12:56.060
and I just wanted to ask you
what you think?"

00:12:56.084 --> 00:12:58.704
And so I did my best to give her
such advice as I could.

00:12:58.728 --> 00:13:03.215
And then she said, "You know,
my husband would never understand this.

00:13:03.239 --> 00:13:06.507
He's really the kind of guy to whom
this wouldn't make any sense,

00:13:06.531 --> 00:13:08.655
so, you know, it's just between us."

00:13:08.679 --> 00:13:10.231
And I said, "Yes, that's fine."

00:13:10.691 --> 00:13:12.550
On Sunday of the same conference,

00:13:12.574 --> 00:13:14.450
her husband took me aside,

00:13:14.474 --> 00:13:15.788
(Laughter)

00:13:15.812 --> 00:13:17.573
and he said, "My wife wouldn't think

00:13:17.597 --> 00:13:19.908
that I was really much
of a guy if she knew this,

00:13:19.932 --> 00:13:23.690
but I've been dealing with this depression
and I'm taking some medication,

00:13:23.714 --> 00:13:26.139
and I wondered what you think?"

00:13:26.163 --> 00:13:28.453
They were hiding the same medication

00:13:28.477 --> 00:13:31.852
in two different places
in the same bedroom.

00:13:31.876 --> 00:13:33.074
(Laughter)

00:13:33.098 --> 00:13:36.036
And I said that I thought
communication within the marriage

00:13:36.060 --> 00:13:38.108
might be triggering
some of their problems.

00:13:38.132 --> 00:13:40.624
(Laughter)

00:13:42.551 --> 00:13:44.114
But I was also struck

00:13:44.138 --> 00:13:47.656
by the burdensome nature
of such mutual secrecy.

00:13:48.099 --> 00:13:49.960
Depression is so exhausting.

00:13:49.984 --> 00:13:52.930
It takes up so much
of your time and energy,

00:13:52.954 --> 00:13:54.485
and silence about it,

00:13:54.509 --> 00:13:56.766
it really does make the depression worse.

00:13:57.234 --> 00:13:58.443
And then I began thinking

00:13:58.467 --> 00:14:00.790
about all the ways
people make themselves better.

00:14:00.814 --> 00:14:03.275
I'd started off as a medical conservative.

00:14:03.299 --> 00:14:05.933
I thought there were a few
kinds of therapy that worked,

00:14:05.957 --> 00:14:07.402
it was clear what they were --

00:14:07.426 --> 00:14:08.926
there was medication,

00:14:08.950 --> 00:14:10.617
there were certain psychotherapies,

00:14:10.641 --> 00:14:13.062
there was possibly
electroconvulsive treatment,

00:14:13.086 --> 00:14:15.675
and that everything else was nonsense.

00:14:15.699 --> 00:14:17.627
But then I discovered something.

00:14:17.651 --> 00:14:19.284
If you have brain cancer,

00:14:19.308 --> 00:14:22.496
and you say that standing on your head
for 20 minutes every morning

00:14:22.520 --> 00:14:23.673
makes you feel better,

00:14:23.697 --> 00:14:26.675
it may make you feel better,
but you still have brain cancer,

00:14:26.699 --> 00:14:28.772
and you'll still probably die from it.

00:14:29.345 --> 00:14:31.631
But if you say that you have depression,

00:14:31.655 --> 00:14:33.995
and standing on your head
for 20 minutes every day

00:14:34.019 --> 00:14:36.215
makes you feel better, then it's worked,

00:14:36.239 --> 00:14:38.680
because depression
is an illness of how you feel,

00:14:38.704 --> 00:14:40.034
and if you feel better,

00:14:40.058 --> 00:14:42.617
then you are effectively
not depressed anymore.

00:14:43.070 --> 00:14:45.157
So I became much more tolerant

00:14:45.181 --> 00:14:47.569
of the vast world
of alternative treatments.

00:14:47.894 --> 00:14:50.206
And I get letters,
I get hundreds of letters

00:14:50.230 --> 00:14:53.040
from people writing to tell me
about what's worked for them.

00:14:53.064 --> 00:14:56.629
Someone was asking me
backstage today about meditation.

00:14:56.653 --> 00:15:00.325
My favorite of the letters that I got
was the one that came from a woman

00:15:00.349 --> 00:15:03.270
who wrote and said
that she had tried therapy, medication,

00:15:03.294 --> 00:15:05.124
she had tried pretty much everything,

00:15:05.148 --> 00:15:08.054
and she had found a solution
and hoped I would tell the world,

00:15:08.078 --> 00:15:11.650
and that was making
little things from yarn.

00:15:11.674 --> 00:15:14.567
(Laughter)

00:15:14.591 --> 00:15:16.127
She sent me some of them.

00:15:16.151 --> 00:15:18.181
(Laughter)

00:15:18.205 --> 00:15:20.070
And I'm not wearing them right now.

00:15:20.094 --> 00:15:21.244
(Laughter)

00:15:21.803 --> 00:15:24.294
I suggested to her
that she also should look up

00:15:24.318 --> 00:15:27.724
obsessive compulsive disorder in the DSM.

00:15:28.937 --> 00:15:31.627
And yet, when I went to look
at alternative treatments,

00:15:31.651 --> 00:15:34.079
I also gained perspective
on other treatments.

00:15:34.563 --> 00:15:37.281
I went through
a tribal exorcism in Senegal

00:15:37.305 --> 00:15:39.294
that involved a great deal of ram's blood

00:15:39.318 --> 00:15:41.356
and that I'm not going
to detail right now,

00:15:41.380 --> 00:15:43.380
but a few years afterwards
I was in Rwanda,

00:15:43.404 --> 00:15:45.301
working on a different project,

00:15:45.325 --> 00:15:47.910
and I happened to describe
my experience to someone,

00:15:47.934 --> 00:15:49.093
and he said,

00:15:49.117 --> 00:15:51.575
"Well, that's West Africa,
and we're in East Africa,

00:15:51.599 --> 00:15:53.856
and our rituals are
in some ways very different,

00:15:53.880 --> 00:15:55.181
but we do have some rituals

00:15:55.205 --> 00:15:58.005
that have something in common
with what you're describing."

00:15:58.029 --> 00:15:59.196
And he said,

00:15:59.220 --> 00:16:02.431
"But we've had a lot of trouble
with Western mental health workers,

00:16:02.455 --> 00:16:05.073
especially the ones who came
right after the genocide."

00:16:05.097 --> 00:16:07.147
I said, "What kind
of trouble did you have?"

00:16:07.171 --> 00:16:10.923
And he said, "Well,
they would do this bizarre thing.

00:16:10.947 --> 00:16:12.995
They didn't take people out
in the sunshine

00:16:13.019 --> 00:16:14.508
where you begin to feel better.

00:16:14.532 --> 00:16:17.684
They didn't include drumming
or music to get people's blood going.

00:16:17.708 --> 00:16:19.614
They didn't involve the whole community.

00:16:19.638 --> 00:16:22.874
They didn't externalize
the depression as an invasive spirit.

00:16:22.898 --> 00:16:27.911
Instead what they did was they took people
one at a time into dingy little rooms

00:16:27.935 --> 00:16:29.316
and had them talk for an hour

00:16:29.340 --> 00:16:31.484
about bad things
that had happened to them."

00:16:31.508 --> 00:16:33.551
(Laughter)

00:16:33.575 --> 00:16:36.944
(Applause)

00:16:36.968 --> 00:16:39.397
He said, "We had to ask them
to leave the country."

00:16:39.421 --> 00:16:42.363
(Laughter)

00:16:42.387 --> 00:16:44.965
Now at the other end
of alternative treatments,

00:16:44.989 --> 00:16:47.084
let me tell you about Frank Russakoff.

00:16:47.108 --> 00:16:52.810
Frank Russakoff had the worst depression
perhaps that I've ever seen in a man.

00:16:52.834 --> 00:16:54.803
He was constantly depressed.

00:16:54.827 --> 00:16:56.272
He was, when I met him,

00:16:56.296 --> 00:17:00.102
at a point at which every month,
he would have electroshock treatment.

00:17:00.126 --> 00:17:02.677
Then he would feel
sort of disoriented for a week.

00:17:02.701 --> 00:17:04.480
Then he would feel okay for a week.

00:17:04.504 --> 00:17:06.598
Then he would have a week
of going downhill.

00:17:06.622 --> 00:17:09.212
And then he would have another
electroshock treatment.

00:17:09.236 --> 00:17:10.809
And he said to me when I met him,

00:17:10.833 --> 00:17:13.198
"It's unbearable to go
through my weeks this way.

00:17:13.222 --> 00:17:14.669
I can't go on this way,

00:17:14.693 --> 00:17:16.803
and I've figured out
how I'm going to end it

00:17:16.827 --> 00:17:18.160
if I don't get better."

00:17:18.184 --> 00:17:22.286
"But," he said to me,
"I heard about a protocol at Mass General

00:17:22.310 --> 00:17:25.532
for a procedure called a cingulotomy,
which is a brain surgery,

00:17:25.556 --> 00:17:27.825
and I think I'm going to give that a try."

00:17:27.849 --> 00:17:31.142
And I remember being amazed
at that point to think that someone

00:17:31.166 --> 00:17:34.163
who clearly had so many bad experiences

00:17:34.187 --> 00:17:36.323
with so many different treatments

00:17:36.347 --> 00:17:39.387
still had buried in him,
somewhere, enough optimism

00:17:39.411 --> 00:17:41.196
to reach out for one more.

00:17:41.718 --> 00:17:45.915
And he had the cingulotomy,
and it was incredibly successful.

00:17:45.939 --> 00:17:47.551
He's now a friend of mine.

00:17:47.575 --> 00:17:50.900
He has a lovely wife
and two beautiful children.

00:17:50.924 --> 00:17:53.849
He wrote me a letter
the Christmas after the surgery,

00:17:53.873 --> 00:17:55.038
and he said,

00:17:55.062 --> 00:17:57.665
"My father sent me two presents this year,

00:17:57.689 --> 00:18:00.216
First, a motorized CD rack
from The Sharper Image

00:18:00.240 --> 00:18:01.638
that I didn't really need,

00:18:01.662 --> 00:18:03.899
but I knew he was giving it
to me to celebrate

00:18:03.923 --> 00:18:07.172
the fact that I'm living on my own
and have a job I seem to love.

00:18:07.593 --> 00:18:10.834
And the other present
was a photo of my grandmother,

00:18:10.858 --> 00:18:12.334
who committed suicide.

00:18:12.913 --> 00:18:15.818
As I unwrapped it, I began to cry,

00:18:15.842 --> 00:18:17.699
and my mother came over and said,

00:18:17.723 --> 00:18:20.715
'Are you crying because
of the relatives you never knew?'

00:18:21.120 --> 00:18:24.668
And I said, 'She had
the same disease I have.'

00:18:25.200 --> 00:18:27.812
I'm crying now as I write to you.

00:18:27.836 --> 00:18:31.123
It's not that I'm so sad,
but I get overwhelmed,

00:18:31.147 --> 00:18:33.344
I think, because I could
have killed myself,

00:18:33.368 --> 00:18:36.796
but my parents kept me going,
and so did the doctors,

00:18:36.820 --> 00:18:38.650
and I had the surgery.

00:18:38.674 --> 00:18:40.756
I'm alive and grateful.

00:18:41.489 --> 00:18:46.090
We live in the right time,
even if it doesn't always feel like it."

00:18:47.814 --> 00:18:49.733
I was struck by the fact that depression

00:18:49.757 --> 00:18:54.763
is broadly perceived to be
a modern, Western, middle-class thing,

00:18:54.787 --> 00:18:58.918
and I went to look at how it operated
in a variety of other contexts,

00:18:58.942 --> 00:19:01.133
and one of the things
I was most interested in

00:19:01.157 --> 00:19:03.072
was depression among the indigent.

00:19:03.096 --> 00:19:04.644
And so I went out to try to look

00:19:04.668 --> 00:19:07.421
at what was being done
for poor people with depression.

00:19:07.445 --> 00:19:09.572
And what I discovered is that poor people

00:19:09.596 --> 00:19:12.124
are mostly not being
treated for depression.

00:19:12.148 --> 00:19:14.822
Depression is the result
of a genetic vulnerability,

00:19:14.846 --> 00:19:18.196
which is presumably
evenly distributed in the population,

00:19:18.220 --> 00:19:19.933
and triggering circumstances,

00:19:19.957 --> 00:19:23.711
which are likely to be more severe
for people who are impoverished.

00:19:23.735 --> 00:19:27.238
And yet it turns out that if you have
a really lovely life

00:19:27.262 --> 00:19:28.844
but feel miserable all the time,

00:19:28.868 --> 00:19:30.654
you think, "Why do I feel like this?

00:19:30.678 --> 00:19:31.947
I must have depression."

00:19:31.971 --> 00:19:34.107
And you set out to find treatment for it.

00:19:34.131 --> 00:19:36.063
But if you have a perfectly awful life,

00:19:36.087 --> 00:19:37.830
and you feel miserable all the time,

00:19:37.854 --> 00:19:40.864
the way you feel
is commensurate with your life,

00:19:40.888 --> 00:19:42.743
and it doesn't occur to you to think,

00:19:42.767 --> 00:19:44.304
"Maybe this is treatable."

00:19:44.328 --> 00:19:47.530
And so we have an epidemic in this country

00:19:47.554 --> 00:19:50.212
of depression among impoverished people

00:19:50.236 --> 00:19:52.808
that's not being picked up
and that's not being treated

00:19:52.832 --> 00:19:54.780
and that's not being addressed,

00:19:54.804 --> 00:19:56.875
and it's a tragedy of a grand order.

00:19:57.177 --> 00:19:58.777
And so I found an academic

00:19:58.801 --> 00:20:02.026
who was doing a research project
in slums outside of D.C.,

00:20:02.050 --> 00:20:05.193
where she picked up women
who had come in for other health problems

00:20:05.217 --> 00:20:06.972
and diagnosed them with depression,

00:20:06.996 --> 00:20:10.068
and then provided six months
of the experimental protocol.

00:20:10.092 --> 00:20:12.397
One of them, Lolly, came in,

00:20:12.421 --> 00:20:14.694
and this is what she said
the day she came in.

00:20:15.027 --> 00:20:19.592
She said, and she was a woman,
by the way, who had seven children.

00:20:19.616 --> 00:20:22.401
She said, "I used to have a job
but I had to give it up

00:20:22.425 --> 00:20:24.640
because I couldn't go out of the house.

00:20:25.092 --> 00:20:27.032
I have nothing to say to my children.

00:20:27.405 --> 00:20:29.887
In the morning,
I can't wait for them to leave,

00:20:29.911 --> 00:20:33.113
and then I climb in bed
and pull the covers over my head,

00:20:33.137 --> 00:20:35.012
and three o'clock when they come home,

00:20:35.036 --> 00:20:36.478
it just comes so fast."

00:20:36.502 --> 00:20:38.796
She said, "I've been taking
a lot of Tylenol,

00:20:38.820 --> 00:20:41.323
anything I can take
so that I can sleep more.

00:20:41.347 --> 00:20:45.344
My husband has been telling me
I'm stupid, I'm ugly.

00:20:45.368 --> 00:20:48.122
I wish I could stop the pain."

00:20:48.893 --> 00:20:51.489
Well, she was brought
into this experimental protocol,

00:20:51.513 --> 00:20:53.704
and when I interviewed her
six months later,

00:20:53.728 --> 00:20:57.953
she had taken a job working in childcare

00:20:57.977 --> 00:21:02.027
for the U.S. Navy,
she had left the abusive husband,

00:21:02.051 --> 00:21:04.074
and she said to me,

00:21:04.098 --> 00:21:06.353
"My kids are so much happier now."

00:21:06.377 --> 00:21:09.059
She said, "There's one room
in my new place for the boys

00:21:09.083 --> 00:21:10.970
and one room for the girls,

00:21:10.994 --> 00:21:13.333
but at night, they're just
all up on my bed,

00:21:13.357 --> 00:21:15.945
and we're doing homework
all together and everything.

00:21:15.969 --> 00:21:17.643
One of them wants to be a preacher,

00:21:17.667 --> 00:21:19.560
one of them wants to be a firefighter,

00:21:19.584 --> 00:21:22.284
and one of the girls says
she's going to be a lawyer.

00:21:22.308 --> 00:21:24.512
They don't cry like they used to,

00:21:24.536 --> 00:21:26.346
and they don't fight like they did.

00:21:27.102 --> 00:21:29.927
That's all I need now, is my kids.

00:21:30.784 --> 00:21:32.729
Things keep on changing,

00:21:32.753 --> 00:21:37.129
the way I dress,
the way I feel, the way I act.

00:21:37.867 --> 00:21:41.668
I can go outside not being afraid anymore,

00:21:41.692 --> 00:21:45.180
and I don't think
those bad feelings are coming back,

00:21:45.204 --> 00:21:48.140
and if it weren't
for Dr. Miranda and that,

00:21:48.164 --> 00:21:51.686
I would still be at home
with the covers pulled over my head,

00:21:51.710 --> 00:21:53.563
if I were still alive at all.

00:21:54.055 --> 00:21:57.561
I asked the Lord to send me an angel,

00:21:57.585 --> 00:21:59.362
and He heard my prayers."

00:22:02.266 --> 00:22:05.246
I was really moved by these experiences,

00:22:05.270 --> 00:22:07.785
and I decided that I wanted
to write about them

00:22:07.809 --> 00:22:10.626
not only in a book I was working on,
but also in an article,

00:22:10.650 --> 00:22:13.229
and I got a commission
from The New York Times Magazine

00:22:13.253 --> 00:22:15.372
to write about depression
among the indigent.

00:22:15.396 --> 00:22:16.633
And I turned in my story,

00:22:16.657 --> 00:22:20.117
and my editor called me and said,
"We really can't publish this."

00:22:20.626 --> 00:22:21.785
And I said, "Why not?"

00:22:21.809 --> 00:22:23.880
And she said, "It just is too far-fetched.

00:22:23.904 --> 00:22:27.567
These people who are sort of
at the very bottom rung of society

00:22:27.591 --> 00:22:29.606
and then they get
a few months of treatment

00:22:29.630 --> 00:22:32.003
and they're virtually ready
to run Morgan Stanley?

00:22:32.027 --> 00:22:33.543
It's just too implausible."

00:22:33.971 --> 00:22:36.552
She said, "I've never even heard
of anything like it."

00:22:36.576 --> 00:22:39.029
And I said, "The fact
that you've never heard of it

00:22:39.053 --> 00:22:41.156
is an indication that it is news."

00:22:41.865 --> 00:22:45.888
(Laughter)

00:22:45.912 --> 00:22:49.251
(Applause)

00:22:49.275 --> 00:22:51.392
"And you are a news magazine."

00:22:51.908 --> 00:22:54.968
So after a certain amount of negotiation,
they agreed to it.

00:22:54.992 --> 00:22:58.878
But I think a lot of what they said
was connected in some strange way

00:22:58.902 --> 00:23:02.483
to this distaste that people still have
for the idea of treatment,

00:23:02.507 --> 00:23:04.365
the notion that somehow if we went out

00:23:04.389 --> 00:23:07.212
and treated a lot of people
in indigent communities,

00:23:07.236 --> 00:23:09.092
that would be exploitative,

00:23:09.116 --> 00:23:10.814
because we would be changing them.

00:23:10.838 --> 00:23:14.645
There is this false moral imperative
that seems to be all around us,

00:23:14.669 --> 00:23:16.777
that treatment of depression,

00:23:16.801 --> 00:23:19.076
the medications and so on,
are an artifice,

00:23:19.100 --> 00:23:21.423
and that it's not natural.

00:23:21.447 --> 00:23:24.390
And I think that's very misguided.

00:23:24.414 --> 00:23:27.747
It would be natural
for people's teeth to fall out,

00:23:27.771 --> 00:23:30.959
but there is nobody militating
against toothpaste,

00:23:30.983 --> 00:23:32.453
at least not in my circles.

00:23:33.873 --> 00:23:35.117
People then say,

00:23:35.141 --> 00:23:38.402
"But isn't depression part of what people
are supposed to experience?

00:23:38.426 --> 00:23:40.158
Didn't we evolve to have depression?

00:23:40.182 --> 00:23:41.933
Isn't it part of your personality?"

00:23:41.957 --> 00:23:44.396
To which I would say, mood is adaptive.

00:23:44.420 --> 00:23:47.497
Being able to have sadness and fear

00:23:47.521 --> 00:23:49.427
and joy and pleasure

00:23:49.451 --> 00:23:53.206
and all of the other moods that we have,
that's incredibly valuable.

00:23:53.230 --> 00:23:55.144
And major depression

00:23:55.168 --> 00:23:58.530
is something that happens
when that system gets broken.

00:23:58.554 --> 00:24:00.158
It's maladaptive.

00:24:00.182 --> 00:24:01.797
People will come to me and say,

00:24:01.821 --> 00:24:04.623
"I think, though, if I just
stick it out for another year,

00:24:04.647 --> 00:24:06.500
I think I can just get through this."

00:24:06.524 --> 00:24:09.048
And I always say to them,
"You may get through it,

00:24:09.072 --> 00:24:11.262
but you'll never be 37 again.

00:24:11.691 --> 00:24:15.400
Life is short, and that's a whole year
you're talking about giving up.

00:24:15.940 --> 00:24:17.091
Think it through."

00:24:17.652 --> 00:24:20.300
It's a strange poverty
of the English language,

00:24:20.324 --> 00:24:22.408
and indeed of many other languages,

00:24:22.432 --> 00:24:24.802
that we use this same word, depression,

00:24:24.826 --> 00:24:28.540
to describe how a kid feels
when it rains on his birthday,

00:24:28.564 --> 00:24:32.923
and to describe how somebody feels
the minute before they commit suicide.

00:24:33.453 --> 00:24:36.459
People say to me, "Well, is it
continuous with normal sadness?"

00:24:36.483 --> 00:24:39.590
And I say, in a way it's continuous
with normal sadness.

00:24:39.614 --> 00:24:41.788
There is a certain amount of continuity,

00:24:41.812 --> 00:24:43.749
but it's the same way there's continuity

00:24:43.773 --> 00:24:45.979
between having an iron fence
outside your house

00:24:46.003 --> 00:24:47.423
that gets a little rust spot

00:24:47.447 --> 00:24:50.045
that you have to sand off
and do a little repainting,

00:24:50.069 --> 00:24:52.897
and what happens if you leave
the house for 100 years

00:24:52.921 --> 00:24:56.720
and it rusts through
until it's only a pile of orange dust.

00:24:57.040 --> 00:24:58.893
And it's that orange dust spot,

00:24:58.917 --> 00:25:00.682
that orange dust problem,

00:25:00.706 --> 00:25:03.292
that's the one
we're setting out to address.

00:25:03.998 --> 00:25:06.212
So now people say,

00:25:06.236 --> 00:25:08.915
"You take these happy pills,
and do you feel happy?"

00:25:08.939 --> 00:25:10.129
And I don't.

00:25:10.552 --> 00:25:13.520
But I don't feel sad
about having to eat lunch,

00:25:13.544 --> 00:25:16.385
and I don't feel sad
about my answering machine,

00:25:16.409 --> 00:25:18.607
and I don't feel sad
about taking a shower.

00:25:19.282 --> 00:25:21.885
I feel more, in fact, I think,

00:25:21.909 --> 00:25:24.315
because I can feel
sadness without nullity.

00:25:24.662 --> 00:25:28.868
I feel sad about professional
disappointments,

00:25:28.892 --> 00:25:31.176
about damaged relationships,

00:25:31.200 --> 00:25:32.717
about global warming.

00:25:33.072 --> 00:25:35.773
Those are the things
that I feel sad about now.

00:25:35.797 --> 00:25:38.507
And I said to myself, well,
what is the conclusion?

00:25:38.531 --> 00:25:41.068
How did those people who have better lives

00:25:41.092 --> 00:25:43.622
even with bigger depression
manage to get through?

00:25:43.922 --> 00:25:46.073
What is the mechanism of resilience?

00:25:46.541 --> 00:25:48.503
And what I came up with over time

00:25:48.527 --> 00:25:51.353
was that the people
who deny their experience,

00:25:51.377 --> 00:25:53.393
and say, "I was depressed a long time ago,

00:25:53.417 --> 00:25:55.188
I never want to think about it again,

00:25:55.212 --> 00:25:56.506
I'm not going to look at it

00:25:56.530 --> 00:25:58.553
and I'm just going
to get on with my life,"

00:25:58.577 --> 00:26:03.175
ironically, those are the people
who are most enslaved by what they have.

00:26:03.199 --> 00:26:05.397
Shutting out the depression
strengthens it.

00:26:05.738 --> 00:26:08.428
While you hide from it, it grows.

00:26:09.143 --> 00:26:11.681
And the people who do better

00:26:11.705 --> 00:26:16.258
are the ones who are able to tolerate
the fact that they have this condition.

00:26:16.282 --> 00:26:20.154
Those who can tolerate their depression
are the ones who achieve resilience.

00:26:20.474 --> 00:26:22.086
So Frank Russakoff said to me,

00:26:22.110 --> 00:26:25.832
"If I had a do-over,
I suppose I wouldn't do it this way,

00:26:25.856 --> 00:26:29.324
but in a strange way,
I'm grateful for what I've experienced.

00:26:29.348 --> 00:26:32.672
I'm glad to have been
in the hospital 40 times.

00:26:32.981 --> 00:26:35.592
It taught me so much about love,

00:26:35.616 --> 00:26:38.537
and my relationship
with my parents and my doctors

00:26:38.561 --> 00:26:42.107
has been so precious to me,
and will be always."

00:26:42.730 --> 00:26:44.632
And Maggie Robbins said,

00:26:44.656 --> 00:26:47.621
"I used to volunteer in an AIDS clinic,

00:26:47.645 --> 00:26:50.635
and I would just talk and talk and talk,

00:26:50.659 --> 00:26:54.692
and the people I was dealing with
weren't very responsive, and I thought,

00:26:54.716 --> 00:26:57.212
'That's not very friendly
or helpful of them.'"

00:26:57.236 --> 00:26:58.476
(Laughter)

00:26:58.500 --> 00:27:00.118
"And then I realized,

00:27:00.142 --> 00:27:02.285
I realized that
they weren't going to do more

00:27:02.309 --> 00:27:04.792
than make those first
few minutes of small talk.

00:27:04.816 --> 00:27:06.855
It was simply going to be an occasion

00:27:06.879 --> 00:27:09.828
where I didn't have AIDS
and I wasn't dying,

00:27:09.852 --> 00:27:12.730
but could tolerate the fact that they did

00:27:12.754 --> 00:27:13.969
and they were.

00:27:14.461 --> 00:27:17.604
Our needs are our greatest assets.

00:27:18.160 --> 00:27:22.325
It turns out I've learned to give
all the things I need."

00:27:24.118 --> 00:27:27.979
Valuing one's depression
does not prevent a relapse,

00:27:28.003 --> 00:27:30.640
but it may make the prospect of relapse

00:27:30.664 --> 00:27:34.177
and even relapse itself
easier to tolerate.

00:27:34.962 --> 00:27:38.620
The question is not so much
of finding great meaning

00:27:38.644 --> 00:27:41.215
and deciding your depression
has been very meaningful.

00:27:41.239 --> 00:27:45.230
It's of seeking that meaning
and thinking, when it comes again,

00:27:45.254 --> 00:27:48.571
"This will be hellish,
but I will learn something from it."

00:27:49.445 --> 00:27:51.685
I have learned in my own depression

00:27:51.709 --> 00:27:53.907
how big an emotion can be,

00:27:53.931 --> 00:27:56.991
how it can be more real than facts,

00:27:57.015 --> 00:27:59.744
and I have found that that experience

00:27:59.768 --> 00:28:02.636
has allowed me to experience
positive emotion

00:28:02.660 --> 00:28:05.559
in a more intense and more focused way.

00:28:06.180 --> 00:28:09.763
The opposite of depression
is not happiness,

00:28:09.787 --> 00:28:11.097
but vitality,

00:28:11.121 --> 00:28:14.076
and these days, my life is vital,

00:28:14.100 --> 00:28:16.392
even on the days when I'm sad.

00:28:16.781 --> 00:28:19.896
I felt that funeral in my brain,

00:28:19.920 --> 00:28:24.460
and I sat next to the colossus
at the edge of the world,

00:28:24.484 --> 00:28:28.371
and I have discovered
something inside of myself

00:28:28.395 --> 00:28:30.459
that I would have to call a soul

00:28:30.483 --> 00:28:33.996
that I had never formulated
until that day 20 years ago

00:28:34.020 --> 00:28:37.321
when hell came to pay me a surprise visit.

00:28:38.799 --> 00:28:42.612
I think that while I hated being depressed

00:28:42.636 --> 00:28:45.138
and would hate to be depressed again,

00:28:45.162 --> 00:28:47.225
I've found a way to love my depression.

00:28:47.852 --> 00:28:52.035
I love it because it has forced me
to find and cling to joy.

00:28:52.639 --> 00:28:56.228
I love it because each day I decide,

00:28:56.252 --> 00:28:57.641
sometimes gamely,

00:28:57.665 --> 00:29:00.210
and sometimes against the moment's reason,

00:29:00.234 --> 00:29:02.373
to cleave to the reasons for living.

00:29:02.936 --> 00:29:06.613
And that, I think,
is a highly privileged rapture.

00:29:07.034 --> 00:29:08.290
Thank you.

00:29:08.314 --> 00:29:12.315
(Applause)

00:29:12.339 --> 00:29:13.490
Thank you.

00:29:13.514 --> 00:29:15.886
(Applause)

title: The $80 prosthetic knee that's changing lives
transcript: Nine years ago, I worked for the U.S. government in Iraq, helping rebuild the electricity infrastructure. And I was there, and I worked in that job because I believe that technology can improve people's lives. One afternoon, I had tea with a storekeeper at the Al Rasheed Hotel in Baghdad, and he said to me, "You Americans, you can put a man on the moon, but when I get home tonight, I won't be able to turn on my lights." At the time, the U.S. government had spent more than two billion dollars on electricity reconstruction. How do you ensure technology reaches users? How do you put it in their hands so that it is useful?So those are the questions that my colleagues and I at D-Rev ask ourselves. And D-Rev is short for Design Revolution. And I took over the organization four years ago and really focused it on developing products that actually reach users, and not just any users, but customers who live on less than four dollars a day. One of the key areas we've been working on recently is medical devices, and while it may not be obvious that medical devices have something in common with Iraq's electricity grid then, there are some commonalities. Despite the advanced technology, it's not reaching the people who need it most.So I'm going to tell you about one of the projects we've been working on, the ReMotion Knee, and it's a prosthetic knee for above-knee amputees. And this project started when the Jaipur Foot Organization, the largest fitter of prosthetic limbs in the world, came to the Bay Area and they said, "We need a better knee." Chances are, if you're living on less than four dollars a day, and you're an amputee, you've lost your limb in a vehicle accident. Most people think it's land mines, but it's a vehicle accident. You're walking by the side of the road and you're hit by a truck, or you're trying to to jump on a moving train, you're late for work, and your pant leg gets caught. And the reality is that if you don't have much money, like this young named Kamal right here, the option you really have is a bamboo staff to get around. And how big a problem is this? There's over three million amputees every year who need a new or replacement knee.And what are their options? This is a high-end. This is what we'd call a "smart knee." It's got a microprocessor inside. It can pretty much do anything, but it's 20,000 dollars, and to give you a sense of who wears this, veterans, American veterans coming back from Afghanistan or Iraq would be fit with something like this. This is a low-end titanium knee. It's a polycentric knee, and all that that means is the mechanism, is a four-bar mechanism, that mimics a natural human knee. But at 1,400 dollars, it's still too expensive for people like Kamal. And lastly, here you see a low-end knee. This is a knee that's been designed specifically for poor people. And while you have affordability, you've lost on functionality. The mechanism here is a single axis, and a single axis is like a door hinge. So you can think about how unstable that would be. And this is the type of mechanismthat the Jaipur Foot Organization was using when they were looking for a better knee, and I just wanted to give you a sense of what a leg system looks like, because I'm showing you all these knees and I imagine it's hard to think  how it all fits together. So at the top you have a socket, and this fits over someone's residual limb, and everyone's residual limb is a little bit different. And then you have the knee, and here I've got a single axis on the knee so you can see how it rotates, and then a pylon, and then a foot. And we've been able to develop a knee, a polycentric knee, so that type of knee that acts like a human knee, mimics human gait, for 80 dollars retail.(Applause)But the key is, you can have this great invention, you can have this great design, but how do you get it to the people who most need it? How do you ensure it gets to them and it improves their lives?So at D-Rev, we've done some other projects, and we looked at three things that we really believe gets technologies to customers, to users, to people who need it.And the first thing is that the product  needs to be world class. It needs to perform on par or better than the best products on the market. Regardless of your income level, you want the most beautiful, the best product that there is. I'm going to show you a video now of a man named Ash. You can see him walking. He's wearing the same knee system here with a single axis knee. And he's doing a 10-meter walk test. And you'll notice that he's struggling  with stability as he's walking. And something that's not obvious, that you can't see, is that it's psychologically draining to walk and to be preventing yourself from falling. Now this is a video of Kamal. You remember Kamal earlier, holding the bamboo staff. He's wearing one of the earlier versions of our knee, and he's doing that same 10-meter walk test. And you can see his stability is much better.So world class isn't just about technical performance. It's also about human performance. And most medical devices, we've learned, as we've dug in, are really designed for Westerners, for wealthier economies. But the reality is our users, our customers, they do different things. They sit cross-legged more. We see that they squat. They kneel in prayer. And we designed our knee to have the greatest range of motion of almost any other knee on the market.So the second thing we learned, and this leads into my second point, which is that we believe that products need to be designed to be user-centric. And at D-Rev, we go one step further and we say you need to be user-obsessed. So it's not just the end user that you're thinking about, but everyone who interacts with the product, so, for example, the prosthetist who fits the knee, but also the context in which the knee is being fit. What is the local market like? How do all these components get to the clinic? Do they all get there on time? The supply chain. Everything that goes into ensuring that this product gets to the end user, and it goes in as part of the system, and it's used.So I wanted to show you some of the iterations we did between the first version, the Jaipur Knee, so this is it right here. (Clicking) Notice anything about it? It clicks. We'd seen that users had actually modified it. So do you see that black strip right there? That's a homemade noise dampener. We also saw that our users had modified it in other ways. You can see there that that particular amputee, he had wrapped bandages around the knee. He'd made a cosmesis. And if you look at the knee, it's got those pointy edges, right? So if you're wearing it under pants or a skirt or a sari, it's really obvious that you're wearing a prosthetic limb, and in societies where there's social stigma around being disabled, people are particularly acute about this.So I'm going to show you some of the modifications we did. We did a lot of iterations, not just  around this, but some other things. But here we have the version three,  the ReMotion Knee, but if you look in here, you can see the noise dampener. It's quieter. The other thing we did is that we smoothed the profile. We made it thinner. And something that's not obvious is that we designed it for mass production.And this goes into my last point. We really, truly believe that if a product is going to reach users at the scale that it's needed, it needs to be market-driven, and market-driven means that products are sold. They're not donated. They're not heavily subsidized. Our product needs to be designed to offer value to the end user. It also has to be designed to be very affordable. But a product that is valued by a customer is used by a customer, and use is what creates impact. And we believe that as designers, it holds us accountable to our customers. And with centralized manufacturing, you can control the quality control, and you can hit that $80 price point with profit margins built in. And now, those profit margins are critical, because if you want to scale, if you want to reach all the people in the world who possibly need a knee, it needs to be economically sustainable.So I want to give you a sense of where we are at. We have fit over 5,000 amputees, and one of the big indicators we're looking at, of course, is, does it improve lives? Well, the standard is, is someone still wearing their knee six months later? The industry average is about 65 percent. Ours is 79 percent, and we're hoping to get that higher. Right now, our knees are worn in 12 countries. This is where we want to get, though, in the next three years. We'll double the impact in 2015, and we'll double it each of the following years after that. But then we hit a new challenge, and that's the number of skilled prosthetists who are able to fit knees.So I want to end with a story of Pournima. Pournima was 18 years old when she was in a car accident where she lost her leg, and she traveled 12 hours by train to come to the clinic to be fit with a knee, and while all of the amputees who wear our knees affect us as the designers, she's particularly meaningful to me  as an engineer and as a woman, because she was in school, she had just started school to study engineering. And she said, "Well, now that I can walk again, I can go back and complete my studies." And to me she represents the next generation of engineers solving problems and ensuring meaningful technologies reach their users.So thank you.(Applause)

Nine years ago, I worked
