00:00:16.757 --> 00:00:19.886
helping rebuild the electricity infrastructure.

00:00:19.886 --> 00:00:22.523
And I was there, and I worked in that job

00:00:22.523 --> 00:00:24.373
because I believe that technology

00:00:24.373 --> 00:00:27.022
can improve people's lives.

00:00:27.022 --> 00:00:29.957
One afternoon, I had tea with a storekeeper

00:00:29.957 --> 00:00:32.777
at the Al Rasheed Hotel in Baghdad,

00:00:32.777 --> 00:00:35.516
and he said to me, "You Americans,

00:00:35.516 --> 00:00:36.867
you can put a man on the moon,

00:00:36.867 --> 00:00:38.412
but when I get home tonight,

00:00:38.412 --> 00:00:41.268
I won't be able to turn on my lights."

00:00:41.268 --> 00:00:42.925
At the time, the U.S. government had spent

00:00:42.925 --> 00:00:45.285
more than two billion dollars

00:00:45.285 --> 00:00:47.642
on electricity reconstruction.

00:00:47.642 --> 00:00:50.814
How do you ensure technology reaches users?

00:00:50.814 --> 00:00:52.794
How do you put it in their hands

00:00:52.794 --> 00:00:55.030
so that it is useful?

00:00:55.030 --> 00:00:58.074
So those are the questions that my colleagues and I

00:00:58.074 --> 00:01:00.187
at D-Rev ask ourselves.

00:01:00.187 --> 00:01:03.335
And D-Rev is short for Design Revolution.

00:01:03.335 --> 00:01:05.929
And I took over the organization four years ago

00:01:05.929 --> 00:01:08.230
and really focused it on developing products

00:01:08.230 --> 00:01:10.418
that actually reach users,

00:01:10.418 --> 00:01:11.904
and not just any users,

00:01:11.904 --> 00:01:15.959
but customers who live on
less than four dollars a day.

00:01:15.959 --> 00:01:17.867
One of the key areas we've been working on recently

00:01:17.867 --> 00:01:20.380
is medical devices, and while it may not be obvious

00:01:20.380 --> 00:01:22.512
that medical devices have something in common

00:01:22.512 --> 00:01:25.078
with Iraq's electricity grid then,

00:01:25.078 --> 00:01:27.207
there are some commonalities.

00:01:27.207 --> 00:01:29.916
Despite the advanced technology,

00:01:29.916 --> 00:01:32.684
it's not reaching the people who need it most.

00:01:32.684 --> 00:01:35.092
So I'm going to tell you about one of
the projects we've been working on,

00:01:35.092 --> 00:01:37.999
the ReMotion Knee, and it's a prosthetic knee

00:01:37.999 --> 00:01:40.155
for above-knee amputees.

00:01:40.155 --> 00:01:43.455
And this project started when
the Jaipur Foot Organization,

00:01:43.455 --> 00:01:46.049
the largest fitter of prosthetic limbs in the world,

00:01:46.049 --> 00:01:47.518
came to the Bay Area and they said,

00:01:47.518 --> 00:01:50.488
"We need a better knee."

00:01:50.488 --> 00:01:53.636
Chances are, if you're living on
less than four dollars a day,

00:01:53.636 --> 00:01:55.513
and you're an amputee,

00:01:55.513 --> 00:01:57.687
you've lost your limb in a vehicle accident.

00:01:57.687 --> 00:01:59.100
Most people think it's land mines,

00:01:59.100 --> 00:02:00.706
but it's a vehicle accident.

00:02:00.706 --> 00:02:02.562
You're walking by the side of the road

00:02:02.562 --> 00:02:03.986
and you're hit by a truck,

00:02:03.986 --> 00:02:05.847
or you're trying to to jump on a moving train,

00:02:05.847 --> 00:02:09.831
you're late for work, and your pant leg gets caught.

00:02:09.831 --> 00:02:12.996
And the reality is that if
you don't have much money,

00:02:12.996 --> 00:02:14.996
like this young named Kamal right here,

00:02:14.996 --> 00:02:17.200
the option you really have

00:02:17.200 --> 00:02:19.764
is a bamboo staff to get around.

00:02:19.764 --> 00:02:22.247
And how big a problem is this?

00:02:22.247 --> 00:02:25.173
There's over three million amputees every year

00:02:25.173 --> 00:02:28.462
who need a new or replacement knee.

00:02:28.462 --> 00:02:30.331
And what are their options?

00:02:30.331 --> 00:02:32.930
This is a high-end. This is
what we'd call a "smart knee."

00:02:32.930 --> 00:02:34.948
It's got a microprocessor inside.

00:02:34.948 --> 00:02:37.033
It can pretty much do anything,

00:02:37.033 --> 00:02:38.730
but it's 20,000 dollars,

00:02:38.730 --> 00:02:40.936
and to give you a sense of who wears this,

00:02:40.936 --> 00:02:44.179
veterans, American veterans coming
back from Afghanistan or Iraq

00:02:44.179 --> 00:02:46.505
would be fit with something like this.

00:02:46.505 --> 00:02:49.022
This is a low-end titanium knee.

00:02:49.022 --> 00:02:51.499
It's a polycentric knee, and all that that means

00:02:51.499 --> 00:02:53.708
is the mechanism, is a four-bar mechanism,

00:02:53.708 --> 00:02:56.258
that mimics a natural human knee.

00:02:56.258 --> 00:02:58.661
But at 1,400 dollars, it's still too expensive

00:02:58.661 --> 00:03:01.045
for people like Kamal.

00:03:01.045 --> 00:03:03.638
And lastly, here you see a low-end knee.

00:03:03.638 --> 00:03:05.469
This is a knee that's been designed specifically

00:03:05.469 --> 00:03:07.145
for poor people.

00:03:07.145 --> 00:03:08.978
And while you have affordability,

00:03:08.978 --> 00:03:10.873
you've lost on functionality.

00:03:10.873 --> 00:03:13.524
The mechanism here is a single axis,

00:03:13.524 --> 00:03:15.773
and a single axis is like a door hinge.

00:03:15.773 --> 00:03:18.058
So you can think about how unstable that would be.

00:03:17.968 --> 00:03:19.963
And this is the type of mechanism

00:03:19.963 --> 00:03:23.852
that the Jaipur Foot Organization was using
when they were looking for a better knee,

00:03:23.852 --> 00:03:26.209
and I just wanted to give you a sense
of what a leg system looks like,

00:03:26.209 --> 00:03:27.548
because I'm showing you all these knees

00:03:27.548 --> 00:03:29.924
and I imagine it's hard to think 
how it all fits together.

00:03:29.924 --> 00:03:31.966
So at the top you have a socket,

00:03:31.966 --> 00:03:33.912
and this fits over someone's residual limb,

00:03:33.912 --> 00:03:36.472
and everyone's residual limb is a little bit different.

00:03:36.472 --> 00:03:37.656
And then you have the knee,

00:03:37.656 --> 00:03:39.374
and here I've got a single axis on the knee

00:03:39.374 --> 00:03:41.086
so you can see how it rotates,

00:03:41.086 --> 00:03:45.049
and then a pylon, and then a foot.

00:03:45.049 --> 00:03:47.592
And we've been able to develop a knee,

00:03:47.592 --> 00:03:49.954
a polycentric knee, so that type of knee

00:03:49.954 --> 00:03:52.529
that acts like a human knee, mimics human gait,

00:03:52.529 --> 00:03:55.272
for 80 dollars retail.

00:03:55.272 --> 00:03:58.836
(Applause)

00:03:58.836 --> 00:04:01.390
But the key is, you can have this great invention,

00:04:01.390 --> 00:04:03.376
you can have this great design, but how do you get it

00:04:03.376 --> 00:04:05.148
to the people who most need it?

00:04:05.148 --> 00:04:08.454
How do you ensure it gets to them
and it improves their lives?

00:04:08.454 --> 00:04:11.390
So at D-Rev, we've done some other projects,

00:04:11.390 --> 00:04:13.774
and we looked at three things that we really believe

00:04:13.774 --> 00:04:17.746
gets technologies to customers, to users,

00:04:17.746 --> 00:04:19.122
to people who need it.

00:04:19.122 --> 00:04:21.843
And the first thing is that the product 
needs to be world class.

00:04:21.843 --> 00:04:23.494
It needs to perform on par

00:04:23.494 --> 00:04:26.339
or better than the best products on the market.

00:04:26.339 --> 00:04:28.485
Regardless of your income level,

00:04:28.485 --> 00:04:30.023
you want the most beautiful,

00:04:30.023 --> 00:04:32.711
the best product that there is.

00:04:32.711 --> 00:04:36.200
I'm going to show you a video now

00:04:36.200 --> 00:04:37.846
of a man named Ash. You can see him walking.

00:04:37.846 --> 00:04:39.758
He's wearing the same knee system here

00:04:39.758 --> 00:04:41.364
with a single axis knee.

00:04:41.364 --> 00:04:43.456
And he's doing a 10-meter walk test.

00:04:43.456 --> 00:04:47.271
And you'll notice that he's struggling 
with stability as he's walking.

00:04:47.271 --> 00:04:49.926
And something that's not obvious, that you can't see,

00:04:49.926 --> 00:04:52.513
is that it's psychologically draining

00:04:52.513 --> 00:04:56.295
to walk and to be preventing yourself from falling.

00:04:56.295 --> 00:04:57.999
Now this is a video of Kamal.

00:04:57.999 --> 00:05:00.732
You remember Kamal earlier,
holding the bamboo staff.

00:05:00.732 --> 00:05:03.440
He's wearing one of the earlier versions of our knee,

00:05:03.440 --> 00:05:06.540
and he's doing that same 10-meter walk test.

00:05:06.540 --> 00:05:09.956
And you can see his stability is much better.

00:05:11.807 --> 00:05:14.926
So world class isn't just about
technical performance.

00:05:14.926 --> 00:05:18.266
It's also about human performance.

00:05:18.266 --> 00:05:20.124
And most medical devices, we've learned,

00:05:20.124 --> 00:05:22.652
as we've dug in, are really designed for Westerners,

00:05:22.652 --> 00:05:24.315
for wealthier economies.

00:05:24.315 --> 00:05:27.577
But the reality is our users, our customers,

00:05:27.577 --> 00:05:30.130
they do different things. They sit cross-legged more.

00:05:30.130 --> 00:05:32.972
We see that they squat. They kneel in prayer.

00:05:32.972 --> 00:05:35.720
And we designed our knee to have
the greatest range of motion

00:05:35.720 --> 00:05:39.804
of almost any other knee on the market.

00:05:39.804 --> 00:05:41.534
So the second thing we learned, and this leads

00:05:41.534 --> 00:05:43.794
into my second point, which is that we believe

00:05:43.794 --> 00:05:46.511
that products need to be
designed to be user-centric.

00:05:46.511 --> 00:05:49.111
And at D-Rev, we go one step further and we say

00:05:49.111 --> 00:05:51.011
you need to be user-obsessed.

00:05:51.011 --> 00:05:53.731
So it's not just the end user
that you're thinking about,

00:05:53.731 --> 00:05:55.707
but everyone who interacts with the product,

00:05:55.707 --> 00:05:58.421
so, for example, the prosthetist who fits the knee,

00:05:58.421 --> 00:06:01.589
but also the context in which the knee is being fit.

00:06:01.589 --> 00:06:03.173
What is the local market like?

00:06:03.173 --> 00:06:05.091
How do all these components get to the clinic?

00:06:05.091 --> 00:06:07.413
Do they all get there on time? The supply chain.

00:06:07.413 --> 00:06:09.516
Everything that goes into ensuring

00:06:09.516 --> 00:06:11.499
that this product gets to the end user,

00:06:11.499 --> 00:06:15.920
and it goes in as part of the system, and it's used.

00:06:15.920 --> 00:06:17.786
So I wanted to show you some of the iterations

00:06:17.786 --> 00:06:22.379
we did between the first version, the Jaipur Knee,

00:06:22.379 --> 00:06:24.200
so this is it right here.

00:06:24.200 --> 00:06:25.926
(Clicking)

00:06:25.926 --> 00:06:28.144
Notice anything about it?

00:06:28.144 --> 00:06:30.705
It clicks.

00:06:30.705 --> 00:06:33.571
We'd seen that users had actually modified it.

00:06:33.571 --> 00:06:37.083
So do you see that black strip right there?

00:06:37.083 --> 00:06:40.075
That's a homemade noise dampener.

00:06:40.075 --> 00:06:42.293
We also saw that our users had modified it

00:06:42.293 --> 00:06:43.727
in other ways.

00:06:43.727 --> 00:06:45.517
You can see there that that particular amputee,

00:06:45.517 --> 00:06:47.746
he had wrapped bandages around the knee.

00:06:47.746 --> 00:06:49.470
He'd made a cosmesis.

00:06:49.470 --> 00:06:51.666
And if you look at the knee,

00:06:51.666 --> 00:06:55.120
it's got those pointy edges, right?

00:06:55.120 --> 00:06:57.323
So if you're wearing it under pants or a skirt

00:06:57.323 --> 00:06:59.583
or a sari, it's really obvious

00:06:59.583 --> 00:07:01.179
that you're wearing a prosthetic limb,

00:07:01.179 --> 00:07:05.371
and in societies where there's social
stigma around being disabled,

00:07:05.371 --> 00:07:08.328
people are particularly acute about this.

00:07:08.328 --> 00:07:10.644
So I'm going to show you some
of the modifications we did.

00:07:10.644 --> 00:07:13.559
We did a lot of iterations, not just 
around this, but some other things.

00:07:13.559 --> 00:07:15.987
But here we have the version three, 
the ReMotion Knee,

00:07:15.987 --> 00:07:17.806
but if you look in here, you can see

00:07:17.806 --> 00:07:22.524
the noise dampener. It's quieter.

00:07:22.524 --> 00:07:26.177
The other thing we did is that
we smoothed the profile.

00:07:26.177 --> 00:07:27.609
We made it thinner.

00:07:27.609 --> 00:07:29.317
And something that's not obvious is that we

00:07:29.317 --> 00:07:32.518
designed it for mass production.

00:07:32.518 --> 00:07:34.214
And this goes into my last point.

00:07:34.214 --> 00:07:36.185
We really, truly believe that if a product

00:07:36.185 --> 00:07:38.522
is going to reach users at the scale that it's needed,

00:07:38.522 --> 00:07:40.357
it needs to be market-driven,

00:07:40.357 --> 00:07:43.602
and market-driven means that products are sold.

00:07:43.602 --> 00:07:46.725
They're not donated. They're not heavily subsidized.

00:07:46.725 --> 00:07:48.938
Our product needs to be designed to offer value

00:07:48.938 --> 00:07:50.239
to the end user.

00:07:50.239 --> 00:07:52.418
It also has to be designed to be very affordable.

00:07:52.418 --> 00:07:54.592
But a product that is valued by a customer

00:07:54.592 --> 00:07:56.303
is used by a customer,

00:07:56.303 --> 00:07:58.476
and use is what creates impact.

00:07:58.476 --> 00:08:00.235
And we believe that as designers,

00:08:00.235 --> 00:08:03.465
it holds us accountable to our customers.

00:08:03.465 --> 00:08:06.081
And with centralized manufacturing,

00:08:06.081 --> 00:08:08.108
you can control the quality control,

00:08:08.108 --> 00:08:09.836
and you can hit that $80 price point

00:08:09.836 --> 00:08:12.326
with profit margins built in.

00:08:12.326 --> 00:08:14.482
And now, those profit margins are critical,

00:08:14.482 --> 00:08:16.151
because if you want to scale, if you want to reach

00:08:16.151 --> 00:08:18.410
all the people in the world who possibly need a knee,

00:08:18.410 --> 00:08:21.567
it needs to be economically sustainable.

00:08:21.567 --> 00:08:24.163
So I want to give you a sense of where we are at.

00:08:24.163 --> 00:08:27.739
We have fit over 5,000 amputees,

00:08:27.739 --> 00:08:29.958
and one of the big indicators
we're looking at, of course,

00:08:29.958 --> 00:08:31.871
is, does it improve lives?

00:08:31.871 --> 00:08:33.607
Well, the standard is, is someone

00:08:33.607 --> 00:08:36.132
still wearing their knee six months later?

00:08:36.132 --> 00:08:38.835
The industry average is about 65 percent.

00:08:38.835 --> 00:08:41.127
Ours is 79 percent,

00:08:41.127 --> 00:08:44.071
and we're hoping to get that higher.

00:08:44.071 --> 00:08:47.084
Right now, our knees are worn in 12 countries.

00:08:47.084 --> 00:08:48.694
This is where we want to get, though,

00:08:48.694 --> 00:08:50.212
in the next three years.

00:08:50.212 --> 00:08:52.712
We'll double the impact in 2015,

00:08:52.712 --> 00:08:55.830
and we'll double it each of
the following years after that.

00:08:55.830 --> 00:08:57.663
But then we hit a new challenge,

00:08:57.663 --> 00:08:59.682
and that's the number of skilled prosthetists

00:08:59.682 --> 00:09:02.790
who are able to fit knees.

00:09:02.790 --> 00:09:05.471
So I want to end with a story of Pournima.

00:09:05.471 --> 00:09:07.118
Pournima was 18 years old

00:09:07.118 --> 00:09:09.986
when she was in a car accident
where she lost her leg,

00:09:09.986 --> 00:09:13.427
and she traveled 12 hours by train

00:09:13.427 --> 00:09:15.854
to come to the clinic to be fit with a knee,

00:09:15.854 --> 00:09:18.447
and while all of the amputees who wear our knees

00:09:18.447 --> 00:09:20.623
affect us as the designers,

00:09:20.623 --> 00:09:24.890
she's particularly meaningful to me 
as an engineer and as a woman,

00:09:24.890 --> 00:09:26.454
because she was in school,

00:09:26.454 --> 00:09:29.178
she had just started school to study engineering.

00:09:29.178 --> 00:09:31.333
And she said, "Well, now that I can walk again,

00:09:31.333 --> 00:09:33.741
I can go back and complete my studies."

00:09:33.741 --> 00:09:36.911
And to me she represents the next generation

00:09:36.911 --> 00:09:39.943
of engineers solving problems

00:09:39.943 --> 00:09:42.388
and ensuring meaningful technologies

00:09:42.388 --> 00:09:44.172
reach their users.

00:09:44.172 --> 00:09:46.210
So thank you.

00:09:46.210 --> 00:09:50.014
(Applause)

title: Does money make you mean?
transcript: I want you to, for a moment, think about playing a game of Monopoly. Except in this game, that combination of skill, talent and luck that helped earn you success in games, as in life, has been rendered irrelevant, because this game's been rigged, and you've got the upper hand. You've got more money, more opportunities to move around the board, and more access to resources. And as you think about that experience, I want you to ask yourself: How might that experience of being a privileged player in a rigged game change the way you think about yourself and regard that other player?So, we ran a study on the UC Berkeley campus to look at exactly that question. We brought in more than 100 pairs of strangers into the lab, and with the flip of a coin, randomly assigned one of the two to be a rich player in a rigged game. They got two times as much money; when they passed Go, they collected twice the salary; and they got to roll both dice instead of one, so they got to move around the board a lot more.(Laughter)And over the course of 15 minutes, we watched through hidden cameras what happened. What I want to do today, for the first time, is show you a little bit of what we saw. You'll to have to pardon the sound quality, because again, these were hidden cameras. So we've provided subtitles.[Video] Rich Player: How many 500s did you have?Poor Player: Just one.RP: Are you serious? PP: Yeah.RP: I have three. (Laughs) I don't know why they gave me so much.Paul Piff: So it was quickly apparent to players that something was up. One person clearly has a lot more money than the other person, and yet, as the game unfolded, we saw very notable differences, dramatic differences begin to emerge between the two players. The rich player started to move around the board louder, literally smacking the board with the piece as he went around.(Game piece smacks board)We were more likely to see signs of dominance and nonverbal signs, displays of power and celebration among the rich players.We had a bowl of pretzels positioned off to the side. It's on the bottom right corner. That allowed us to watch participants' consummatory behavior. So we're just tracking how many pretzels participants eat.[Video] RP: Are those pretzels a trick?PP: I don't know.Paul Piff: OK, so no surprises, people are on to us. They wonder what that bowl of pretzels is doing there in the first place. One even asks, like you just saw, "Is that bowl of pretzels there as a trick?" And yet, despite that, the power of the situation seems to inevitably dominate, and those rich players start to eat more pretzels.(Laughter)[Video] RP: I love pretzels.(Laughter)Paul Piff: And as the game went on, one of the really interesting and dramatic patterns that we observed begin to emerge was that the rich players actually started to become ruder toward the other person — less and less sensitive to the plight of those poor, poor players, and more and more demonstrative of their material success, more likely to showcase how well they're doing.[Video] RP: I have money ...(Laughs) I have money for everything.PP: How much is that?RP: You owe me 24 dollars. You're going to lose all your money soon. I'll buy it. I have so much money. I have so much money, it takes me forever.RP 2: I'm going to buy out this whole board.RP 3: You're going to run out of money soon. I'm pretty much untouchable at this point.(Laughter)Paul Piff: And here's what I think was really, really interesting: it's that, at the end of the 15 minutes, we asked the players to talk about their experience during the game. And when the rich players talked about why they had inevitably won in this rigged game of Monopoly ...(Laughter)They talked about what they'd done to buy those different properties and earn their success in the game.(Laughter)And they became far less attuned to all those different features of the situation — including that flip of a coin — that had randomly gotten them into that privileged position in the first place. And that's a really, really incredible insight into how the mind makes sense of advantage.Now, this game of Monopoly can be used as a metaphor for understanding society and its hierarchical structure, wherein some people have a lot of wealth and a lot of status, and a lot of people don't; they have a lot less wealth and a lot less status and a lot less access to valued resources. And what my colleagues and I for the last seven years have been doing is studying the effects of these kinds of hierarchies. What we've been finding across dozens of studies and thousands of participants across this country is that as a person's levels of wealth increase, their feelings of compassion and empathy go down, and their feelings of entitlement, of deservingness, and their ideology of self-interest increase. In surveys, we've found that it's actually wealthier individuals who are more likely to moralize greed being good, and that the pursuit of self-interest is favorable and moral. Now, what I want to do today is talk about some of the implications of this ideology self-interest, talk about why we should care about those implications, and end with what might be done.Some of the first studies that we ran in this area looked at helping behavior, something social psychologists call "pro-social behavior." And we were really interested in who's more likely to offer help to another person: someone who's rich or someone who's poor. In one of the studies, we bring rich and poor members of the community into the lab, and give each of them the equivalent of 10 dollars. We told the participants they could keep these 10 dollars for themselves, or they could share a portion of it, if they wanted to, with a stranger, who's totally anonymous. They'll never meet that stranger; the stranger will never meet them. And we just monitor how much people give. Individuals who made 25,000, sometimes under 15,000 dollars a year, gave 44 percent more of their money to the stranger than did individuals making 150,000, 200,000 dollars a year.We've had people play games to see who's more or less likely to cheat to increase their chances of winning a prize. In one of the games, we actually rigged a computer so that die rolls over a certain score were impossible — You couldn't get above 12 in this game, and yet ... the richer you were, the more likely you were to cheat in this game to earn credits toward a $50 cash prize — sometimes by three to four times as much.We ran another study where we looked at whether people would be inclined to take candy from a jar of candy that we explicitly identified as being reserved for children —(Laughter)I'm not kidding — I know it sounds like I'm making a joke. We explicitly told participants: "This candy is for children participating in a developmental lab nearby. They're in studies. This is for them." And we just monitored how much candy participants took. Participants who felt rich took two times as much candy as participants who felt poor.We've even studied cars. Not just any cars, but whether drivers of different kinds of cars are more or less inclined to break the law. In one of these studies, we looked at whether drivers would stop for a pedestrian that we had posed waiting to cross at a crosswalk. Now in California, as you all know, because I'm sure we all do this, it's the law to stop for a pedestrian who's waiting to cross. So here's an example of how we did it. That's our confederate off to the left, posing as a pedestrian. He approaches as the red truck successfully stops. In typical California fashion, it's overtaken by the bus who almost runs our pedestrian over.(Laughter)Now here's an example of a more expensive car, a Prius, driving through, and a BMW doing the same. So we did this for hundreds of vehicles on several days, just tracking who stops and who doesn't. What we found was as the expensiveness of a car increased ...(Laughter)the drivers' tendencies to break the law increased as well. None of the cars — none of the cars — in our least expensive car category broke the law. Close to 50 percent of the cars in our most expensive vehicle category broke the law. We've run other studies, finding that wealthier individuals are more likely to lie in negotiations, to endorse unethical behavior at work, like stealing cash from the cash register, taking bribes, lying to customers.Now, I don't mean to suggest that it's only wealthy people who show these patterns of behavior. Not at all — in fact, I think that we all, in our day-to-day, minute-by-minute lives, struggle with these competing motivations of when or if to put our own interests above the interests of other people. And that's understandable, because the American dream is an idea in which we all have an equal opportunity to succeed and prosper, as long as we apply ourselves and work hard. And a piece of that means that sometimes, you need to put your own interests above the interests and well-being of other people around you. But what we're finding is that the wealthier you are, the more likely you are to pursue a vision of personal success, of achievement and accomplishment, to the detriment of others around you.Here I've plotted for you the mean household income received by each fifth and top five percent of the population over the last 20 years. In 1993, the differences between the different quintiles of the population, in terms of income, are fairly egregious. It's not difficult to discern that there are differences. But over the last 20 years, that significant difference has become a Grand Canyon of sorts between those at the top and everyone else. In fact, the top 20 percent of our population own close to 90 percent of the total wealth in this country.We're at unprecedented levels of economic inequality. What that means is that wealth is not only becoming increasingly concentrated in the hands of a select group of individuals, but the American dream is becoming increasingly unattainable for an increasing majority of us. And if it's the case, as we've been finding, that the wealthier you are, the more entitled you feel to that wealth, and the more likely you are to prioritize your own interests above the interests of other people, and be willing to do things to serve that self-interest, well, then, there's no reason to think that those patterns will change. In fact, there's every reason to think that they'll only get worse, and that's what it would look like if things just stayed the same, at the same linear rate, over the next 20 years.Now inequality — economic inequality — is something we should all be concerned about, and not just because of those at the bottom of the social hierarchy, but because individuals and groups with lots of economic inequality do worse ... not just the people at the bottom, everyone. There's a lot of really compelling research coming out from top labs all over the world, showcasing the range of things that are undermined as economic inequality gets worse. Social mobility, things we really care about, physical health, social trust, all go down as inequality goes up. Similarly, negative things in social collectives and societies, things like obesity, and violence, imprisonment, and punishment, are exacerbated as economic inequality increases. Again, these are outcomes not just experienced by a few, but that resound across all strata of society. Even people at the top experience these outcomes.So what do we do? This cascade of self-perpetuating, pernicious, negative effects could seem like something that's spun out of control, and there's nothing we can do about it, certainly nothing we as individuals could do. But in fact, we've been finding in our own laboratory research that small psychological interventions, small changes to people's values, small nudges in certain directions, can restore levels of egalitarianism and empathy. For instance, reminding people of the benefits of cooperation or the advantages of community, cause wealthier individuals to be just as egalitarian as poor people.In one study, we had people watch a brief video, just 46 seconds long, about childhood poverty that served as a reminder of the needs of others in the world around them. And after watching that, we looked at how willing people were to offer up their own time to a stranger presented to them in the lab, who was in distress. After watching this video, an hour later, rich people became just as generous of their own time to help out this other person, a stranger, as someone who's poor, suggesting that these differences are not innate or categorical, but are so malleable to slight changes in people's values, and little nudges of compassion and bumps of empathy.And beyond the walls of our lab, we're even beginning to see signs of change in society. Bill Gates, one of our nation's wealthiest individuals, in his Harvard commencement speech, talked about the problem of inequality facing society as being the most daunting challenge, and talked about what must be done to combat it, saying, "Humanity's greatest advances are not in its discoveries — but in how those discoveries are applied to reduce inequity." And there's the Giving Pledge, in which more than 100 of our nation's wealthiest individuals are pledging half of their fortunes to charity. And there's the emergence of dozens of grassroots movements, like "We are the 1 percent," "Resource Generation," or "Wealth for Common Good," in which the most privileged members of the population, members of the one percent and elsewhere, people who are wealthy, are using their own economic resources, adults and youth alike — that's what's most striking to me — leveraging their own privilege, their own economic resources, to combat inequality by advocating for social policies, changes in social values and changes in people's behavior that work against their own economic interests, but that may ultimately restore the American dream.Thank you.(Applause)
subtitle:
WEBVTT
X-TIMESTAMP-MAP=MPEGTS:900000,LOCAL:00:00:00.000

00:00:12.862 --> 00:00:15.386
I want you to, for a moment,

00:00:15.410 --> 00:00:18.480
think about playing a game of Monopoly.

00:00:19.045 --> 00:00:24.466
Except in this game,
that combination of skill, talent and luck

00:00:24.490 --> 00:00:27.245
that helped earn you success
in games, as in life,

00:00:27.269 --> 00:00:28.670
has been rendered irrelevant,

00:00:28.694 --> 00:00:30.850
because this game's been rigged,

00:00:30.874 --> 00:00:32.349
and you've got the upper hand.

00:00:32.753 --> 00:00:34.537
You've got more money,

00:00:34.561 --> 00:00:37.098
more opportunities to move
around the board,

00:00:37.122 --> 00:00:38.864
and more access to resources.

00:00:39.356 --> 00:00:41.226
And as you think about that experience,

00:00:41.250 --> 00:00:42.676
I want you to ask yourself:

00:00:43.063 --> 00:00:48.110
How might that experience of being
a privileged player in a rigged game

00:00:48.134 --> 00:00:50.428
change the way you think about yourself

00:00:51.126 --> 00:00:53.538
and regard that other player?

00:00:54.872 --> 00:00:57.953
So, we ran a study
on the UC Berkeley campus

00:00:57.977 --> 00:01:00.217
to look at exactly that question.

00:01:00.241 --> 00:01:03.934
We brought in more than 100 pairs
of strangers into the lab,

00:01:04.815 --> 00:01:06.529
and with the flip of a coin,

00:01:06.553 --> 00:01:10.594
randomly assigned one of the two
to be a rich player in a rigged game.

00:01:10.618 --> 00:01:12.364
They got two times as much money;

00:01:13.467 --> 00:01:16.519
when they passed Go,
they collected twice the salary;

00:01:17.297 --> 00:01:19.578
and they got to roll
both dice instead of one,

00:01:19.602 --> 00:01:21.896
so they got to move
around the board a lot more.

00:01:21.920 --> 00:01:23.526
(Laughter)

00:01:23.976 --> 00:01:25.684
And over the course of 15 minutes,

00:01:25.708 --> 00:01:28.199
we watched through
hidden cameras what happened.

00:01:29.215 --> 00:01:31.311
What I want to do today,
for the first time,

00:01:31.335 --> 00:01:33.483
is show you a little bit of what we saw.

00:01:33.507 --> 00:01:35.808
You'll to have to pardon
the sound quality,

00:01:35.832 --> 00:01:37.805
because again, these were hidden cameras.

00:01:37.829 --> 00:01:39.514
So we've provided subtitles.

00:01:39.909 --> 00:01:42.224
[Video] Rich Player: How many
500s did you have?

00:01:42.248 --> 00:01:43.399
Poor Player: Just one.

00:01:43.423 --> 00:01:44.843
RP: Are you serious?
PP: Yeah.

00:01:44.867 --> 00:01:47.998
RP: I have three. (Laughs)
I don't know why they gave me so much.

00:01:48.022 --> 00:01:51.387
Paul Piff: So it was quickly apparent
to players that something was up.

00:01:51.411 --> 00:01:54.538
One person clearly has
a lot more money than the other person,

00:01:54.562 --> 00:01:57.118
and yet, as the game unfolded,

00:01:57.142 --> 00:02:01.672
we saw very notable differences,
dramatic differences begin to emerge

00:02:01.696 --> 00:02:03.105
between the two players.

00:02:03.446 --> 00:02:07.765
The rich player started to move
around the board louder,

00:02:07.789 --> 00:02:10.813
literally smacking the board
with the piece as he went around.

00:02:10.837 --> 00:02:12.544
(Game piece smacks board)

00:02:12.568 --> 00:02:15.517
We were more likely
to see signs of dominance

00:02:15.541 --> 00:02:19.554
and nonverbal signs, displays of power

00:02:19.578 --> 00:02:22.252
and celebration among the rich players.

00:02:23.458 --> 00:02:26.143
We had a bowl of pretzels
positioned off to the side.

00:02:26.167 --> 00:02:27.709
It's on the bottom right corner.

00:02:27.733 --> 00:02:31.192
That allowed us to watch
participants' consummatory behavior.

00:02:31.216 --> 00:02:34.194
So we're just tracking
how many pretzels participants eat.

00:02:35.740 --> 00:02:37.687
[Video] RP: Are those pretzels a trick?

00:02:37.711 --> 00:02:39.255
PP: I don't know.

00:02:39.671 --> 00:02:42.786
Paul Piff: OK, so no surprises,
people are on to us.

00:02:42.810 --> 00:02:46.302
They wonder what that bowl of pretzels
is doing there in the first place.

00:02:46.326 --> 00:02:47.960
One even asks, like you just saw,

00:02:47.984 --> 00:02:50.642
"Is that bowl of pretzels
there as a trick?"

00:02:50.993 --> 00:02:54.037
And yet, despite that,
the power of the situation

00:02:54.061 --> 00:02:56.271
seems to inevitably dominate,

00:02:56.295 --> 00:02:59.330
and those rich players
start to eat more pretzels.

00:02:59.354 --> 00:03:00.740
(Laughter)

00:03:04.248 --> 00:03:05.660
[Video] RP: I love pretzels.

00:03:05.684 --> 00:03:07.354
(Laughter)

00:03:10.272 --> 00:03:12.274
Paul Piff: And as the game went on,

00:03:12.406 --> 00:03:14.881
one of the really interesting
and dramatic patterns

00:03:14.905 --> 00:03:17.557
that we observed begin to emerge

00:03:18.212 --> 00:03:21.014
was that the rich players
actually started to become ruder

00:03:21.038 --> 00:03:22.450
toward the other person --

00:03:23.061 --> 00:03:26.663
less and less sensitive to the plight
of those poor, poor players,

00:03:26.687 --> 00:03:30.693
and more and more demonstrative
of their material success,

00:03:31.246 --> 00:03:33.699
more likely to showcase
how well they're doing.

00:03:36.042 --> 00:03:37.675
[Video] RP: I have money ...

00:03:37.699 --> 00:03:39.595
(Laughs) I have money for everything.

00:03:39.971 --> 00:03:41.444
PP: How much is that?

00:03:41.468 --> 00:03:43.695
RP: You owe me 24 dollars.

00:03:45.362 --> 00:03:48.069
You're going to lose all your money soon.

00:03:48.093 --> 00:03:50.229
I'll buy it. I have so much money.

00:03:50.253 --> 00:03:52.279
I have so much money, it takes me forever.

00:03:52.303 --> 00:03:54.392
RP 2: I'm going
to buy out this whole board.

00:03:54.416 --> 00:03:56.497
RP 3: You're going
to run out of money soon.

00:03:56.521 --> 00:03:58.569
I'm pretty much untouchable at this point.

00:03:58.593 --> 00:04:00.181
(Laughter)

00:04:00.205 --> 00:04:03.390
Paul Piff: And here's what I think
was really, really interesting:

00:04:03.414 --> 00:04:05.604
it's that, at the end of the 15 minutes,

00:04:06.256 --> 00:04:09.630
we asked the players to talk
about their experience during the game.

00:04:10.605 --> 00:04:14.691
And when the rich players talked
about why they had inevitably won

00:04:14.715 --> 00:04:16.387
in this rigged game of Monopoly ...

00:04:16.411 --> 00:04:20.485
(Laughter)

00:04:21.426 --> 00:04:27.774
They talked about what they'd done
to buy those different properties

00:04:27.798 --> 00:04:29.763
and earn their success in the game.

00:04:29.787 --> 00:04:30.821
(Laughter)

00:04:30.845 --> 00:04:33.245
And they became far less attuned

00:04:33.269 --> 00:04:35.781
to all those different
features of the situation --

00:04:35.805 --> 00:04:37.818
including that flip of a coin --

00:04:38.461 --> 00:04:42.460
that had randomly gotten them
into that privileged position

00:04:42.484 --> 00:04:43.787
in the first place.

00:04:43.811 --> 00:04:46.644
And that's a really,
really incredible insight

00:04:46.668 --> 00:04:50.329
into how the mind
makes sense of advantage.

00:04:52.059 --> 00:04:54.237
Now, this game of Monopoly can be used

00:04:54.261 --> 00:04:59.220
as a metaphor for understanding society
and its hierarchical structure,

00:04:59.244 --> 00:05:02.861
wherein some people
have a lot of wealth and a lot of status,

00:05:02.885 --> 00:05:04.369
and a lot of people don't;

00:05:04.393 --> 00:05:07.282
they have a lot less wealth
and a lot less status

00:05:07.306 --> 00:05:10.354
and a lot less access to valued resources.

00:05:10.378 --> 00:05:13.760
And what my colleagues and I
for the last seven years have been doing

00:05:13.784 --> 00:05:16.624
is studying the effects
of these kinds of hierarchies.

00:05:17.664 --> 00:05:21.043
What we've been finding
across dozens of studies

00:05:21.067 --> 00:05:24.343
and thousands of participants
across this country

00:05:24.443 --> 00:05:28.324
is that as a person's levels
of wealth increase,

00:05:29.046 --> 00:05:32.821
their feelings of compassion
and empathy go down,

00:05:34.996 --> 00:05:38.722
and their feelings of entitlement,
of deservingness,

00:05:38.746 --> 00:05:42.306
and their ideology
of self-interest increase.

00:05:43.242 --> 00:05:44.835
In surveys, we've found

00:05:44.859 --> 00:05:48.722
that it's actually wealthier individuals
who are more likely to moralize

00:05:48.746 --> 00:05:50.453
greed being good,

00:05:50.477 --> 00:05:54.445
and that the pursuit of self-interest
is favorable and moral.

00:05:55.021 --> 00:05:58.651
Now, what I want to do today
is talk about some of the implications

00:05:58.675 --> 00:06:00.570
of this ideology self-interest,

00:06:01.626 --> 00:06:04.270
talk about why we should
care about those implications,

00:06:04.294 --> 00:06:05.893
and end with what might be done.

00:06:07.523 --> 00:06:09.940
Some of the first studies
that we ran in this area

00:06:09.964 --> 00:06:11.300
looked at helping behavior,

00:06:11.324 --> 00:06:14.531
something social psychologists
call "pro-social behavior."

00:06:15.411 --> 00:06:16.860
And we were really interested

00:06:16.884 --> 00:06:20.285
in who's more likely
to offer help to another person:

00:06:20.402 --> 00:06:22.632
someone who's rich or someone who's poor.

00:06:23.513 --> 00:06:24.781
In one of the studies,

00:06:24.805 --> 00:06:30.235
we bring rich and poor members
of the community into the lab,

00:06:30.347 --> 00:06:33.171
and give each of them
the equivalent of 10 dollars.

00:06:33.743 --> 00:06:37.955
We told the participants they could keep
these 10 dollars for themselves,

00:06:37.979 --> 00:06:40.867
or they could share
a portion of it, if they wanted to,

00:06:40.891 --> 00:06:43.235
with a stranger, who's totally anonymous.

00:06:43.259 --> 00:06:46.516
They'll never meet that stranger;
the stranger will never meet them.

00:06:46.540 --> 00:06:48.790
And we just monitor how much people give.

00:06:49.512 --> 00:06:54.161
Individuals who made 25,000,
sometimes under 15,000 dollars a year,

00:06:54.185 --> 00:06:57.502
gave 44 percent more
of their money to the stranger

00:06:57.526 --> 00:07:01.231
than did individuals making
150,000, 200,000 dollars a year.

00:07:02.941 --> 00:07:04.978
We've had people play games

00:07:05.767 --> 00:07:08.433
to see who's more or less likely to cheat

00:07:08.457 --> 00:07:10.811
to increase their chances
of winning a prize.

00:07:10.835 --> 00:07:13.584
In one of the games,
we actually rigged a computer

00:07:13.608 --> 00:07:17.288
so that die rolls over a certain score
were impossible --

00:07:17.312 --> 00:07:21.404
You couldn't get above 12
in this game, and yet ...

00:07:22.522 --> 00:07:25.711
the richer you were, the more likely
you were to cheat in this game

00:07:25.735 --> 00:07:28.460
to earn credits toward a $50 cash prize --

00:07:29.104 --> 00:07:31.342
sometimes by three to four times as much.

00:07:33.064 --> 00:07:34.228
We ran another study

00:07:34.252 --> 00:07:38.043
where we looked at whether people
would be inclined to take candy

00:07:38.432 --> 00:07:41.072
from a jar of candy
that we explicitly identified

00:07:41.096 --> 00:07:42.976
as being reserved for children --

00:07:43.000 --> 00:07:46.596
(Laughter)

00:07:46.620 --> 00:07:50.774
I'm not kidding -- I know it sounds
like I'm making a joke.

00:07:51.179 --> 00:07:53.409
We explicitly told participants:

00:07:53.433 --> 00:07:57.766
"This candy is for children participating
in a developmental lab nearby.

00:07:57.790 --> 00:07:59.919
They're in studies. This is for them."

00:07:59.943 --> 00:08:02.867
And we just monitored
how much candy participants took.

00:08:03.525 --> 00:08:06.440
Participants who felt rich
took two times as much candy

00:08:06.464 --> 00:08:08.117
as participants who felt poor.

00:08:09.633 --> 00:08:11.590
We've even studied cars.

00:08:12.273 --> 00:08:13.942
Not just any cars,

00:08:13.966 --> 00:08:17.230
but whether drivers
of different kinds of cars

00:08:17.254 --> 00:08:20.272
are more or less inclined
to break the law.

00:08:20.296 --> 00:08:21.808
In one of these studies,

00:08:22.516 --> 00:08:27.243
we looked at whether drivers
would stop for a pedestrian

00:08:27.267 --> 00:08:30.127
that we had posed waiting
to cross at a crosswalk.

00:08:30.151 --> 00:08:31.999
Now in California, as you all know,

00:08:32.023 --> 00:08:34.427
because I'm sure we all do this,

00:08:34.451 --> 00:08:37.972
it's the law to stop for a pedestrian
who's waiting to cross.

00:08:38.392 --> 00:08:40.234
So here's an example of how we did it.

00:08:40.258 --> 00:08:43.801
That's our confederate off to the left,
posing as a pedestrian.

00:08:43.825 --> 00:08:47.807
He approaches as the red truck
successfully stops.

00:08:48.177 --> 00:08:49.956
In typical California fashion,

00:08:49.980 --> 00:08:52.949
it's overtaken by the bus
who almost runs our pedestrian over.

00:08:52.973 --> 00:08:54.326
(Laughter)

00:08:54.350 --> 00:08:56.555
Now here's an example
of a more expensive car,

00:08:56.579 --> 00:09:00.826
a Prius, driving through,
and a BMW doing the same.

00:09:03.548 --> 00:09:05.963
So we did this for hundreds of vehicles

00:09:05.987 --> 00:09:08.446
on several days,

00:09:08.470 --> 00:09:10.894
just tracking who stops and who doesn't.

00:09:12.545 --> 00:09:16.798
What we found was as the expensiveness
of a car increased ...

00:09:16.822 --> 00:09:18.894
(Laughter)

00:09:18.918 --> 00:09:22.149
the drivers' tendencies
to break the law increased as well.

00:09:22.173 --> 00:09:24.974
None of the cars -- none of the cars --

00:09:24.998 --> 00:09:28.069
in our least expensive car category

00:09:28.093 --> 00:09:29.251
broke the law.

00:09:29.751 --> 00:09:34.594
Close to 50 percent of the cars
in our most expensive vehicle category

00:09:34.618 --> 00:09:35.817
broke the law.

00:09:37.508 --> 00:09:38.756
We've run other studies,

00:09:38.780 --> 00:09:42.667
finding that wealthier individuals
are more likely to lie in negotiations,

00:09:42.691 --> 00:09:44.882
to endorse unethical behavior at work,

00:09:44.906 --> 00:09:47.506
like stealing cash from the cash register,

00:09:47.620 --> 00:09:50.409
taking bribes, lying to customers.

00:09:52.655 --> 00:09:54.248
Now, I don't mean to suggest

00:09:54.272 --> 00:09:57.846
that it's only wealthy people
who show these patterns of behavior.

00:09:57.870 --> 00:10:00.676
Not at all -- in fact,
I think that we all,

00:10:00.700 --> 00:10:03.619
in our day-to-day, minute-by-minute lives,

00:10:03.643 --> 00:10:06.492
struggle with these competing motivations

00:10:06.516 --> 00:10:12.207
of when or if to put our own interests
above the interests of other people.

00:10:12.231 --> 00:10:14.507
And that's understandable,

00:10:14.531 --> 00:10:17.428
because the American dream is an idea

00:10:17.452 --> 00:10:22.287
in which we all have an equal opportunity
to succeed and prosper,

00:10:22.311 --> 00:10:24.867
as long as we apply
ourselves and work hard.

00:10:24.891 --> 00:10:27.600
And a piece of that means that sometimes,

00:10:27.624 --> 00:10:30.553
you need to put your own interests

00:10:30.577 --> 00:10:34.086
above the interests and well-being
of other people around you.

00:10:34.110 --> 00:10:37.481
But what we're finding
is that the wealthier you are,

00:10:37.505 --> 00:10:41.345
the more likely you are to pursue
a vision of personal success,

00:10:41.369 --> 00:10:43.694
of achievement and accomplishment,

00:10:43.718 --> 00:10:45.906
to the detriment of others around you.

00:10:46.885 --> 00:10:50.158
Here I've plotted for you
the mean household income

00:10:50.182 --> 00:10:53.418
received by each fifth
and top five percent of the population

00:10:53.442 --> 00:10:54.870
over the last 20 years.

00:10:55.537 --> 00:10:56.771
In 1993,

00:10:56.795 --> 00:10:59.921
the differences between the different
quintiles of the population,

00:10:59.945 --> 00:11:01.133
in terms of income,

00:11:01.157 --> 00:11:03.229
are fairly egregious.

00:11:03.690 --> 00:11:06.380
It's not difficult to discern
that there are differences.

00:11:06.404 --> 00:11:09.233
But over the last 20 years,
that significant difference

00:11:09.257 --> 00:11:11.549
has become a Grand Canyon of sorts

00:11:11.573 --> 00:11:14.597
between those at the top
and everyone else.

00:11:14.621 --> 00:11:18.255
In fact, the top 20 percent
of our population

00:11:18.279 --> 00:11:21.378
own close to 90 percent
of the total wealth in this country.

00:11:21.402 --> 00:11:25.081
We're at unprecedented levels
of economic inequality.

00:11:27.816 --> 00:11:31.657
What that means is that wealth is not only
becoming increasingly concentrated

00:11:31.681 --> 00:11:34.615
in the hands of a select group
of individuals,

00:11:34.639 --> 00:11:38.967
but the American dream
is becoming increasingly unattainable

00:11:38.991 --> 00:11:41.333
for an increasing majority of us.

00:11:42.185 --> 00:11:44.984
And if it's the case,
as we've been finding,

00:11:45.008 --> 00:11:46.457
that the wealthier you are,

00:11:46.481 --> 00:11:49.000
the more entitled you feel to that wealth,

00:11:49.024 --> 00:11:52.022
and the more likely you are
to prioritize your own interests

00:11:52.046 --> 00:11:53.802
above the interests of other people,

00:11:53.826 --> 00:11:57.351
and be willing to do things
to serve that self-interest,

00:11:57.375 --> 00:12:01.042
well, then, there's no reason to think
that those patterns will change.

00:12:01.066 --> 00:12:04.598
In fact, there's every reason
to think that they'll only get worse,

00:12:04.622 --> 00:12:07.808
and that's what it would look like
if things just stayed the same,

00:12:07.832 --> 00:12:10.890
at the same linear rate,
over the next 20 years.

00:12:12.120 --> 00:12:14.860
Now inequality -- economic inequality --

00:12:14.884 --> 00:12:17.083
is something we should
all be concerned about,

00:12:17.107 --> 00:12:20.710
and not just because of those
at the bottom of the social hierarchy,

00:12:20.734 --> 00:12:23.078
but because individuals and groups

00:12:23.102 --> 00:12:27.575
with lots of economic
inequality do worse ...

00:12:28.307 --> 00:12:30.601
not just the people
at the bottom, everyone.

00:12:31.164 --> 00:12:33.231
There's a lot of really
compelling research

00:12:33.255 --> 00:12:35.915
coming out from top labs
all over the world,

00:12:35.939 --> 00:12:40.589
showcasing the range of things
that are undermined

00:12:40.613 --> 00:12:43.129
as economic inequality gets worse.

00:12:43.153 --> 00:12:45.982
Social mobility,
things we really care about,

00:12:46.006 --> 00:12:48.464
physical health, social trust,

00:12:48.488 --> 00:12:51.420
all go down as inequality goes up.

00:12:51.444 --> 00:12:55.969
Similarly, negative things
in social collectives and societies,

00:12:55.993 --> 00:12:58.073
things like obesity, and violence,

00:12:58.097 --> 00:12:59.695
imprisonment, and punishment,

00:12:59.719 --> 00:13:03.845
are exacerbated as economic
inequality increases.

00:13:03.869 --> 00:13:07.412
Again, these are outcomes
not just experienced by a few,

00:13:07.436 --> 00:13:10.874
but that resound
across all strata of society.

00:13:10.898 --> 00:13:13.558
Even people at the top
experience these outcomes.

00:13:14.177 --> 00:13:16.114
So what do we do?

00:13:17.265 --> 00:13:20.847
This cascade of self-perpetuating,

00:13:20.871 --> 00:13:23.356
pernicious, negative effects

00:13:23.380 --> 00:13:26.776
could seem like something
that's spun out of control,

00:13:26.800 --> 00:13:28.688
and there's nothing we can do about it,

00:13:28.712 --> 00:13:30.967
certainly nothing
we as individuals could do.

00:13:31.516 --> 00:13:37.605
But in fact, we've been finding
in our own laboratory research

00:13:38.478 --> 00:13:43.058
that small psychological interventions,

00:13:43.653 --> 00:13:46.672
small changes to people's values,

00:13:46.789 --> 00:13:50.146
small nudges in certain directions,

00:13:50.170 --> 00:13:53.304
can restore levels
of egalitarianism and empathy.

00:13:53.717 --> 00:13:57.990
For instance, reminding people
of the benefits of cooperation

00:13:58.014 --> 00:13:59.909
or the advantages of community,

00:14:00.919 --> 00:14:04.731
cause wealthier individuals
to be just as egalitarian

00:14:04.755 --> 00:14:06.080
as poor people.

00:14:07.327 --> 00:14:12.852
In one study, we had people watch
a brief video, just 46 seconds long,

00:14:12.876 --> 00:14:14.294
about childhood poverty

00:14:15.102 --> 00:14:19.303
that served as a reminder of the needs
of others in the world around them.

00:14:20.215 --> 00:14:22.110
And after watching that,

00:14:22.134 --> 00:14:25.590
we looked at how willing people
were to offer up their own time

00:14:26.200 --> 00:14:30.231
to a stranger presented to them
in the lab, who was in distress.

00:14:30.984 --> 00:14:34.204
After watching this video, an hour later,

00:14:34.228 --> 00:14:37.608
rich people became
just as generous of their own time

00:14:37.632 --> 00:14:39.778
to help out this other person, a stranger,

00:14:39.802 --> 00:14:41.247
as someone who's poor,

00:14:41.271 --> 00:14:45.529
suggesting that these differences
are not innate or categorical,

00:14:45.553 --> 00:14:49.309
but are so malleable
to slight changes in people's values,

00:14:49.333 --> 00:14:52.741
and little nudges of compassion
and bumps of empathy.

00:14:53.130 --> 00:14:54.707
And beyond the walls of our lab,

00:14:54.731 --> 00:14:58.010
we're even beginning to see
signs of change in society.

00:14:58.851 --> 00:15:01.999
Bill Gates, one of our nation's
wealthiest individuals,

00:15:02.023 --> 00:15:03.951
in his Harvard commencement speech,

00:15:03.975 --> 00:15:06.836
talked about the problem
of inequality facing society

00:15:06.860 --> 00:15:09.523
as being the most daunting challenge,

00:15:09.547 --> 00:15:12.381
and talked about what must
be done to combat it,

00:15:12.405 --> 00:15:17.423
saying, "Humanity's greatest advances
are not in its discoveries --

00:15:17.447 --> 00:15:20.479
but in how those discoveries are applied

00:15:20.503 --> 00:15:22.291
to reduce inequity."

00:15:23.314 --> 00:15:25.243
And there's the Giving Pledge,

00:15:25.267 --> 00:15:29.194
in which more than 100
of our nation's wealthiest individuals

00:15:30.035 --> 00:15:33.217
are pledging half
of their fortunes to charity.

00:15:33.844 --> 00:15:38.316
And there's the emergence of dozens
of grassroots movements,

00:15:39.094 --> 00:15:40.847
like "We are the 1 percent,"

00:15:41.466 --> 00:15:42.949
"Resource Generation,"

00:15:43.514 --> 00:15:45.403
or "Wealth for Common Good,"

00:15:45.427 --> 00:15:49.766
in which the most privileged
members of the population,

00:15:49.790 --> 00:15:52.734
members of the one percent and elsewhere,

00:15:52.758 --> 00:15:54.497
people who are wealthy,

00:15:54.620 --> 00:15:58.073
are using their own economic resources,

00:15:58.097 --> 00:16:02.330
adults and youth alike --
that's what's most striking to me --

00:16:02.354 --> 00:16:05.915
leveraging their own privilege,
their own economic resources,

00:16:05.939 --> 00:16:08.780
to combat inequality

00:16:08.804 --> 00:16:11.246
by advocating for social policies,

00:16:11.824 --> 00:16:13.682
changes in social values

00:16:13.706 --> 00:16:15.964
and changes in people's behavior

00:16:16.101 --> 00:16:19.141
that work against
their own economic interests,

00:16:19.165 --> 00:16:22.343
but that may ultimately
restore the American dream.

00:16:23.378 --> 00:16:24.598
Thank you.

00:16:24.622 --> 00:16:29.957
(Applause)

title: Never, ever give up
transcript: It's the fifth time I stand on this shore, the Cuban shore, looking out at that distant horizon, believing, again, that I'm going to make it all the way across that vast, dangerous wilderness of an ocean. Not only have I tried four times, but the greatest swimmers in the world have been trying since 1950, and it's still never been done.The team is proud of our four attempts. It's an expedition of some 30 people. Bonnie is my best friend and head handler, who somehow summons will, that last drop of will within me, when I think it's gone, after many, many hours and days out there. The shark experts are the best in the world — large predators below. The box jellyfish, the deadliest venom in all of the ocean, is in these waters, and I have come close to dying from them on a previous attempt. The conditions themselves, besides the sheer distance of over 100 miles in the open ocean — the currents and whirling eddies and the Gulf Stream itself, the most unpredictable of all of the planet Earth.And by the way — it's amusing to me that journalists and people, before these attempts, often ask me, "Well, are you going to go with any boats or any people or anything?"(Laughter)And I'm thinking, what are they imagining? That I'll just sort of do some celestial navigation —(Laughter)And carry a bowie knife in my mouth, and I'll hunt fish and skin them alive and eat them, and maybe drag a desalinization plant behind me for fresh water.(Laughter)Yes, I have a team.(Laughter)And the team is expert, and the team is courageous, and brimming with innovation and scientific discovery, as is true of any major expedition on the planet.And we've been on a journey. And the debate has raged, hasn't it, since the Greeks, of isn't it what it's all about? Isn't life about the journey, not really the destination? And here we've been on this journey, and the truth is, it's been thrilling. We haven't reached that other shore, and still, our sense of pride and commitment, unwavering commitment. When I turned 60, the dream was still alive from having tried this in my 20s — dreamed it and imagined it. The most famous body of water on the Earth today, I imagine, Cuba to Florida. And it was deep. It was deep in my soul.When I turned 60, it wasn't so much about the athletic accomplishment, it wasn't the ego of "I want to be the first." That's always there and it's undeniable. But it was deeper. It was "how much life is there left?" Let's face it — we're all on a one-way street, aren't we? And what are we going to do? What are we going to do as we go forward, to have no regrets looking back? And all this past year in training, I had that Teddy Roosevelt quote to paraphrase it, floating around in my brain. It says, "You go ahead. You go ahead and sit back in your comfortable chair and you be the critic, you be the observer, while the brave one gets in the ring and engages and gets bloody and gets dirty and fails over and over and over again, but yet isn't afraid and isn't timid and lives life in a bold way."And so of course I want to make it across. It is the goal, and I should be so shallow to say that this year, the destination was even sweeter than the journey.(Laughter)(Applause)But the journey itself was worthwhile taking. And at this point, by this summer, everybody — scientists, sports scientists, endurance experts, neurologists, my own team, Bonnie — said it's impossible. It just simply can't be done, and Bonnie said to me, "But if you're going to take the journey, I'm going to see you through to the end of it, so I'll be there."And now we're there. As we're looking out, kind of a surreal moment before the first stroke, standing on the rocks at Marina Hemingway, the Cuban flag is flying above, all my team is out in their boats, hands up in the air, "We're here! We're here for you!" Bonnie and I look at each other and say, this year, the mantra is — and I've been using it in training — Find a way. You have a dream and you have obstacles in front of you, as we all do. None of us ever get through this life without heartache, without turmoil, and if you believe and you have faith and you can get knocked down and get back up again and you believe in perseverance as a great human quality, you find your way. And Bonnie grabbed my shoulders, and she said, "Let's find our way to Florida."And we started, and for the next 53 hours, it was an intense, unforgettable life experience. The highs were high, the awe — I'm not a religious person, but I'll tell you, to be in the azure blue of the Gulf Stream as if, as you're breathing, you're looking down miles and miles and miles, to feel the majesty of this blue planet we live on — it's awe-inspiring. I have a playlist of about 85 songs, and especially in the middle of the night ... That night, because we use no lights — lights attract jellyfish, lights attract sharks, lights attract baitfish that attract sharks, so we go in the pitch black of the night. You've never seen black this black. You can't see the front of your hand, and the people on the boat, Bonnie and my team on the boat — they just hear the slapping of the arms, and they know where I am, because there's no visual at all. And I'm out there kind of tripping out on my little playlist.(Laughter)I've got tight rubber caps, I don't hear a thing. I've got goggles and I'm turning my head 50 times a minute, and I'm singing ...(Singing) Imagine there's no heaven(Laughter)doo doo doo doo doo It's easy if you try doo doo doo doo dooAnd I can sing that song a thousand times in a row.(Laughter)Now there's a talent unto itself.(Laughter)(Applause)And each time I get done with,(Singing) Oh, you may say I'm a dreamer but I'm not the only one222.(Singing) Imagine there's no heaven(Laughter)And when I get through the end of a thousand of John Lennon's "Imagine," I have swum nine hours and 45 minutes ... exactly.(Laughter)And then there are the crises. Of course there are. And the vomiting starts, the seawater — you're not well. You're wearing a jellyfish mask for the ultimate protection. It's difficult to swim in. It's causing abrasions on the inside of the mouth, but the tentacles can't get you. And the hypothermia sets in. The water's 85 degrees, and yet you're losing weight and using calories. And as you come over toward the side of the boat — not allowed to touch it, not allowed to get out, but Bonnie and her team hand me nutrition and ask me how I'm doing, am I all right. I am seeing the Taj Mahal —(Laughter)Over here. I'm in a very different state —(Laughter)And I'm thinking, "Wow! I never thought I'd be running into the Taj Mahal out here. It's gorgeous! I mean, how long did it take them to build that? It's just ... So, uh — wooo — you know?(Laughter)We kind of have a cardinal rule that I'm never told how far it is, because we don't know how far it is. What's going to happen to you between this point and that point? What's going to happen to the weather and the currents and, God forbid, you're stung, when you don't think you could be stung in all this armor. Bonnie made a decision coming into that third morning that I was suffering, and I was hanging on by a thread. And she said, "Come here," and I came close to the boat, and she said, "Look, look out there." And I saw light, because the day is easier than the night, and I thought we were coming into day. I saw a stream of white light along the horizon, and I said, "It's going to be morning soon." And she said, "No, those are the lights of Key West." It was 15 more hours, which for most swimmers would be a long time.(Laughter)(Applause)You have no idea how many 15-hour training swims I had done.So here we go, and I somehow, without a decision, went into no counting of strokes and no singing and no quoting Stephen Hawking on the parameters of the universe. I just went into thinking about this dream, and why and how. As I said, when I turned 60, it wasn't about that concrete "Can you do it?" That's the everyday machinations. That's the discipline, and it's the preparation, and there's a pride in that. But I decided to think, as I went along, about — you know, the phrase usually is, "reaching for the stars." And in my case, it's reaching for the horizon. And when you reach for the horizon, as I've proven, you may not get there. But what a tremendous build of character and spirit that you lay down; what a foundation you lay down in reaching for those horizons.And now, the shore is coming. And there's just a little part of me that's sad. The epic journey is going to be over.So many people come up to me now and say, "What's next?"(Laughter)"We love that!"(Laughter)"That little tracker on the computer? When are you going to do the next one? We can't wait to follow the next one." Well, they were just there for 53 hours, and I was there for years. And so there won't be another epic journey in the ocean.But the point is, and the point was, that every day of our lives is epic. And I'll tell you, when I walked up onto that beach, staggered up onto that beach ... I had so many times, in a very puffed-up ego way, rehearsed what I would say ...(Laughter)on the beach. When Bonnie thought the back of my throat was swelling up, she brought the medical team over to our boat to say, "She's really beginning to have trouble breathing; another 12, 24 hours in the saltwater ..." — the whole thing — I just thought, in my hallucinatory moment, that I heard the word "tracheotomy."(Laughter)Bonnie said to the doctor, "I'm not worried about her not breathing. If she can't talk when she gets to the shore, she's going to be pissed off."(Laughter)But the truth is, all those orations that I had practiced, just to get myself through some training swims as motivation — it wasn't like that. It was a very real moment, with that crowd, with my team. We did it. I didn't do it. We did it. And we'll never forget it. It'll always be part of us.The three things I did sort of blurt out when we got there, was first: Never, ever give up. I live it. What's the phrase from today from Socrates?Audience: To be is to do.Diana Nyad: To be is to do. So I don't stand up and say, "Don't ever give up." I didn't give up. There was action behind these words.The second is: You can chase your dreams at any age; you're never too old. Sixty-four; a thing no one, at any age, any gender, could ever do has done it. And there's no doubt in my mind that I am at the prime of my life today.(Applause)Yeah.(Applause)Thank you.And the third thing I said on that beach was, it looks like the most solitary endeavor in the world, and in many ways, of course, it is. And in other ways, and the most important ways, it's a team. And if you think I'm a badass, you want to meet Bonnie.(Laughter)Bonnie, where are you? Where are you? There's Bonnie Stoll.(Applause)My buddy.(Applause)The Henry David Thoreau quote goes, "When you achieve your dreams, it's not so much what you get as who you have become in achieving them." And yeah, I stand before you now. In the three months since that swim ended, I've sat down with Oprah, and I've been in President Obama's Oval Office; I've been invited to speak in front of esteemed groups such as yourselves; I've signed a wonderful major book contract. All of that's great, and I don't denigrate it. I'm proud of it all, but the truth is, I'm walking around tall because I am that bold, fearless person, and I will be, every day, until it's time for these days to be done.Thank you very much and enjoy the conference.Thank you. Thank you!(Applause)Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you! Thank you.(Applause)Find a way!(Applause)
