but yet isn't afraid and isn't timid
and lives life in a bold way."

00:04:22.902 --> 00:04:25.335
And so of course I want to make it across.

00:04:25.359 --> 00:04:30.202
It is the goal, and I should
be so shallow to say that this year,

00:04:30.631 --> 00:04:34.132
the destination was even sweeter
than the journey.

00:04:34.156 --> 00:04:36.059
(Laughter)

00:04:36.083 --> 00:04:39.491
(Applause)

00:04:39.515 --> 00:04:41.892
But the journey itself
was worthwhile taking.

00:04:42.797 --> 00:04:45.215
And at this point, by this summer,

00:04:45.239 --> 00:04:48.371
everybody -- scientists,
sports scientists,

00:04:48.974 --> 00:04:52.028
endurance experts, neurologists,

00:04:53.277 --> 00:04:55.671
my own team, Bonnie --

00:04:57.713 --> 00:04:58.965
said it's impossible.

00:04:59.540 --> 00:05:02.088
It just simply can't be done,
and Bonnie said to me,

00:05:02.112 --> 00:05:04.098
"But if you're going to take the journey,

00:05:04.122 --> 00:05:06.313
I'm going to see you
through to the end of it,

00:05:06.337 --> 00:05:07.500
so I'll be there."

00:05:07.524 --> 00:05:08.965
And now we're there.

00:05:12.090 --> 00:05:14.963
As we're looking out,
kind of a surreal moment

00:05:14.987 --> 00:05:16.291
before the first stroke,

00:05:16.315 --> 00:05:18.817
standing on the rocks at Marina Hemingway,

00:05:18.841 --> 00:05:21.510
the Cuban flag is flying above,

00:05:21.534 --> 00:05:25.784
all my team is out in their boats,
hands up in the air,

00:05:25.808 --> 00:05:27.126
"We're here!

00:05:27.872 --> 00:05:29.051
We're here for you!"

00:05:30.975 --> 00:05:33.064
Bonnie and I look at each other and say,

00:05:33.088 --> 00:05:36.337
this year, the mantra is --
and I've been using it in training --

00:05:37.174 --> 00:05:38.330
Find a way.

00:05:39.095 --> 00:05:40.296
You have a dream

00:05:41.829 --> 00:05:44.820
and you have obstacles
in front of you, as we all do.

00:05:44.844 --> 00:05:47.258
None of us ever get through this life

00:05:48.496 --> 00:05:49.818
without heartache,

00:05:52.016 --> 00:05:53.281
without turmoil,

00:05:54.337 --> 00:05:57.131
and if you believe and you have faith

00:05:57.155 --> 00:05:59.527
and you can get knocked down
and get back up again

00:05:59.551 --> 00:06:02.452
and you believe in perseverance

00:06:02.476 --> 00:06:06.094
as a great human quality,

00:06:06.118 --> 00:06:07.407
you find your way.

00:06:07.431 --> 00:06:09.052
And Bonnie grabbed my shoulders,

00:06:09.076 --> 00:06:12.196
and she said, "Let's find
our way to Florida."

00:06:13.332 --> 00:06:15.881
And we started, and for the next 53 hours,

00:06:15.905 --> 00:06:20.331
it was an intense,
unforgettable life experience.

00:06:21.605 --> 00:06:23.822
The highs were high, the awe --

00:06:23.846 --> 00:06:26.171
I'm not a religious person,
but I'll tell you,

00:06:26.195 --> 00:06:29.620
to be in the azure blue of the Gulf Stream

00:06:29.644 --> 00:06:31.524
as if, as you're breathing,

00:06:31.548 --> 00:06:35.567
you're looking down miles
and miles and miles,

00:06:36.211 --> 00:06:41.120
to feel the majesty
of this blue planet we live on --

00:06:41.144 --> 00:06:44.534
it's awe-inspiring.

00:06:45.013 --> 00:06:47.491
I have a playlist of about 85 songs,

00:06:47.515 --> 00:06:49.628
and especially in the middle
of the night ...

00:06:49.652 --> 00:06:52.768
That night, because we use
no lights -- lights attract jellyfish,

00:06:52.792 --> 00:06:53.988
lights attract sharks,

00:06:54.012 --> 00:06:56.373
lights attract baitfish
that attract sharks,

00:06:56.397 --> 00:06:58.874
so we go in the pitch black of the night.

00:06:58.898 --> 00:07:01.361
You've never seen black this black.

00:07:02.229 --> 00:07:04.291
You can't see the front of your hand,

00:07:04.315 --> 00:07:07.304
and the people on the boat,
Bonnie and my team on the boat --

00:07:07.328 --> 00:07:09.361
they just hear the slapping of the arms,

00:07:09.385 --> 00:07:10.576
and they know where I am,

00:07:10.600 --> 00:07:12.518
because there's no visual at all.

00:07:12.542 --> 00:07:16.655
And I'm out there kind of tripping out
on my little playlist.

00:07:16.679 --> 00:07:19.183
(Laughter)

00:07:19.207 --> 00:07:22.251
I've got tight rubber caps,
I don't hear a thing.

00:07:22.275 --> 00:07:25.392
I've got goggles and I'm turning
my head 50 times a minute,

00:07:25.416 --> 00:07:26.691
and I'm singing ...

00:07:27.458 --> 00:07:30.057
(Singing) Imagine there's no heaven

00:07:30.081 --> 00:07:31.668
(Laughter)

00:07:31.692 --> 00:07:33.374
doo doo doo doo doo

00:07:33.398 --> 00:07:36.218
It's easy if you try

00:07:36.242 --> 00:07:37.446
doo doo doo doo doo

00:07:37.470 --> 00:07:40.004
And I can sing that song
a thousand times in a row.

00:07:40.028 --> 00:07:42.263
(Laughter)

00:07:42.287 --> 00:07:44.913
Now there's a talent unto itself.

00:07:44.937 --> 00:07:46.741
(Laughter)

00:07:46.765 --> 00:07:49.345
(Applause)

00:07:49.369 --> 00:07:51.743
And each time I get done with,

00:07:51.767 --> 00:07:56.587
(Singing) Oh, you may say I'm a dreamer
but I'm not the only one

00:07:58.585 --> 00:08:00.115
222.

00:08:01.528 --> 00:08:03.964
(Singing) Imagine there's no heaven

00:08:03.988 --> 00:08:06.070
(Laughter)

00:08:06.094 --> 00:08:07.609
And when I get through the end

00:08:07.633 --> 00:08:09.689
of a thousand of John Lennon's "Imagine,"

00:08:09.713 --> 00:08:11.961
I have swum nine hours and 45 minutes ...

00:08:12.741 --> 00:08:13.916
exactly.

00:08:13.940 --> 00:08:16.337
(Laughter)

00:08:16.361 --> 00:08:18.313
And then there are the crises.

00:08:18.337 --> 00:08:19.487
Of course there are.

00:08:20.915 --> 00:08:24.233
And the vomiting starts,
the seawater -- you're not well.

00:08:24.257 --> 00:08:27.866
You're wearing a jellyfish mask
for the ultimate protection.

00:08:27.890 --> 00:08:29.349
It's difficult to swim in.

00:08:29.373 --> 00:08:32.007
It's causing abrasions
on the inside of the mouth,

00:08:32.031 --> 00:08:33.839
but the tentacles can't get you.

00:08:34.665 --> 00:08:37.226
And the hypothermia sets in.

00:08:37.250 --> 00:08:40.635
The water's 85 degrees,
and yet you're losing weight

00:08:40.659 --> 00:08:41.978
and using calories.

00:08:42.002 --> 00:08:44.440
And as you come over
toward the side of the boat --

00:08:44.464 --> 00:08:46.804
not allowed to touch it,
not allowed to get out,

00:08:46.828 --> 00:08:48.958
but Bonnie and her team hand me nutrition

00:08:48.982 --> 00:08:52.311
and ask me how I'm doing, am I all right.

00:08:52.335 --> 00:08:55.194
I am seeing the Taj Mahal --

00:08:55.218 --> 00:08:56.439
(Laughter)

00:08:56.463 --> 00:08:57.746
Over here.

00:08:57.770 --> 00:09:01.533
I'm in a very different state --

00:09:01.557 --> 00:09:02.929
(Laughter)

00:09:02.953 --> 00:09:05.715
And I'm thinking, "Wow!

00:09:05.739 --> 00:09:09.328
I never thought I'd be running
into the Taj Mahal out here.

00:09:09.621 --> 00:09:11.382
It's gorgeous!

00:09:11.406 --> 00:09:13.995
I mean, how long
did it take them to build that?

00:09:14.019 --> 00:09:15.706
It's just ...

00:09:16.273 --> 00:09:18.373
So, uh -- wooo -- you know?

00:09:18.397 --> 00:09:21.576
(Laughter)

00:09:22.584 --> 00:09:24.452
We kind of have a cardinal rule

00:09:24.476 --> 00:09:27.945
that I'm never told how far it is,
because we don't know how far it is.

00:09:27.969 --> 00:09:31.146
What's going to happen to you
between this point and that point?

00:09:31.170 --> 00:09:33.774
What's going to happen
to the weather and the currents

00:09:33.798 --> 00:09:35.758
and, God forbid, you're stung,

00:09:35.782 --> 00:09:39.676
when you don't think you could
be stung in all this armor.

00:09:40.351 --> 00:09:43.581
Bonnie made a decision
coming into that third morning

00:09:44.730 --> 00:09:46.501
that I was suffering,

00:09:46.525 --> 00:09:49.838
and I was hanging on by a thread.

00:09:50.417 --> 00:09:51.662
And she said, "Come here,"

00:09:51.686 --> 00:09:53.773
and I came close
to the boat, and she said,

00:09:53.797 --> 00:09:54.995
"Look, look out there."

00:09:55.019 --> 00:09:56.172
And I saw light,

00:09:56.196 --> 00:09:58.198
because the day is easier than the night,

00:09:58.222 --> 00:10:00.052
and I thought we were coming into day.

00:10:00.076 --> 00:10:03.734
I saw a stream of white light
along the horizon,

00:10:03.758 --> 00:10:06.036
and I said, "It's going
to be morning soon."

00:10:06.060 --> 00:10:09.324
And she said, "No, those
are the lights of Key West."

00:10:11.608 --> 00:10:13.450
It was 15 more hours,

00:10:13.474 --> 00:10:15.683
which for most swimmers
would be a long time.

00:10:15.707 --> 00:10:18.833
(Laughter)

00:10:18.857 --> 00:10:22.174
(Applause)

00:10:22.198 --> 00:10:26.202
You have no idea how many
15-hour training swims I had done.

00:10:26.743 --> 00:10:30.560
So here we go, and I somehow,
without a decision,

00:10:30.584 --> 00:10:32.902
went into no counting of strokes

00:10:32.926 --> 00:10:34.235
and no singing

00:10:34.259 --> 00:10:39.450
and no quoting Stephen Hawking
on the parameters of the universe.

00:10:39.474 --> 00:10:45.701
I just went into thinking
about this dream, and why and how.

00:10:46.146 --> 00:10:48.288
As I said, when I turned 60,

00:10:48.312 --> 00:10:52.316
it wasn't about that concrete
"Can you do it?"

00:10:52.340 --> 00:10:55.276
That's the everyday machinations.

00:10:55.300 --> 00:10:58.047
That's the discipline,
and it's the preparation,

00:10:58.071 --> 00:10:59.776
and there's a pride in that.

00:10:59.800 --> 00:11:03.690
But I decided to think, as I went along,

00:11:04.349 --> 00:11:08.214
about -- you know, the phrase usually is,
"reaching for the stars."

00:11:08.238 --> 00:11:10.801
And in my case,
it's reaching for the horizon.

00:11:11.396 --> 00:11:13.267
And when you reach for the horizon,

00:11:13.291 --> 00:11:15.409
as I've proven, you may not get there.

00:11:15.994 --> 00:11:21.421
But what a tremendous build
of character and spirit

00:11:22.350 --> 00:11:24.343
that you lay down;

00:11:24.367 --> 00:11:28.257
what a foundation you lay down
in reaching for those horizons.

00:11:29.847 --> 00:11:31.700
And now, the shore is coming.

00:11:32.390 --> 00:11:34.934
And there's just a little part
of me that's sad.

00:11:35.537 --> 00:11:37.754
The epic journey is going to be over.

00:11:37.778 --> 00:11:39.844
So many people come up to me now and say,

00:11:39.868 --> 00:11:41.061
"What's next?"

00:11:41.085 --> 00:11:42.507
(Laughter)

00:11:42.531 --> 00:11:43.836
"We love that!"

00:11:43.860 --> 00:11:44.947
(Laughter)

00:11:44.971 --> 00:11:46.851
"That little tracker on the computer?

00:11:46.875 --> 00:11:48.716
When are you going to do the next one?

00:11:48.740 --> 00:11:50.572
We can't wait to follow the next one."

00:11:50.596 --> 00:11:52.776
Well, they were just there for 53 hours,

00:11:52.800 --> 00:11:54.745
and I was there for years.

00:11:55.187 --> 00:11:58.592
And so there won't be another
epic journey in the ocean.

00:11:58.616 --> 00:12:02.167
But the point is, and the point was,

00:12:02.191 --> 00:12:06.444
that every day of our lives is epic.

00:12:07.375 --> 00:12:09.847
And I'll tell you,
when I walked up onto that beach,

00:12:09.871 --> 00:12:11.709
staggered up onto that beach ...

00:12:11.866 --> 00:12:18.293
I had so many times,
in a very puffed-up ego way,

00:12:18.317 --> 00:12:20.352
rehearsed what I would say ...

00:12:20.376 --> 00:12:22.023
(Laughter)

00:12:22.047 --> 00:12:23.297
on the beach.

00:12:23.321 --> 00:12:26.261
When Bonnie thought the back
of my throat was swelling up,

00:12:26.285 --> 00:12:28.454
she brought the medical team
over to our boat

00:12:28.478 --> 00:12:32.686
to say, "She's really beginning
to have trouble breathing;

00:12:32.710 --> 00:12:35.765
another 12, 24 hours
in the saltwater ..." --

00:12:35.789 --> 00:12:39.534
the whole thing -- I just thought,
in my hallucinatory moment,

00:12:39.558 --> 00:12:41.944
that I heard the word "tracheotomy."

00:12:41.968 --> 00:12:44.298
(Laughter)

00:12:44.829 --> 00:12:48.099
Bonnie said to the doctor,
"I'm not worried about her not breathing.

00:12:48.123 --> 00:12:50.264
If she can't talk
when she gets to the shore,

00:12:50.288 --> 00:12:51.815
she's going to be pissed off."

00:12:51.839 --> 00:12:57.046
(Laughter)

00:12:57.070 --> 00:13:00.975
But the truth is, all those orations
that I had practiced,

00:13:00.999 --> 00:13:04.875
just to get myself through some
training swims as motivation --

00:13:04.899 --> 00:13:06.367
it wasn't like that.

00:13:06.391 --> 00:13:08.839
It was a very real moment,

00:13:08.863 --> 00:13:10.887
with that crowd, with my team.

00:13:11.326 --> 00:13:13.811
We did it. I didn't do it. We did it.

00:13:13.835 --> 00:13:16.612
And we'll never forget it.
It'll always be part of us.

00:13:17.139 --> 00:13:21.157
The three things I did sort of blurt out
when we got there, was first:

00:13:21.181 --> 00:13:23.344
Never, ever give up.

00:13:24.508 --> 00:13:25.910
I live it.

00:13:25.934 --> 00:13:28.233
What's the phrase
from today from Socrates?

00:13:28.825 --> 00:13:30.021
Audience: To be is to do.

00:13:30.045 --> 00:13:31.353
Diana Nyad: To be is to do.

00:13:31.377 --> 00:13:34.366
So I don't stand up and say,
"Don't ever give up."

00:13:34.390 --> 00:13:35.742
I didn't give up.

00:13:36.299 --> 00:13:38.226
There was action behind these words.

00:13:38.250 --> 00:13:39.944
The second is:

00:13:39.968 --> 00:13:43.244
You can chase your dreams
at any age; you're never too old.

00:13:43.268 --> 00:13:48.347
Sixty-four; a thing no one,
at any age, any gender, could ever do

00:13:48.371 --> 00:13:49.527
has done it.

00:13:49.551 --> 00:13:51.090
And there's no doubt in my mind

00:13:51.114 --> 00:13:53.782
that I am at the prime of my life today.

00:13:53.806 --> 00:13:56.610
(Applause)

00:13:56.634 --> 00:13:57.882
Yeah.

00:13:57.906 --> 00:14:02.192
(Applause)

00:14:02.216 --> 00:14:03.392
Thank you.

00:14:04.039 --> 00:14:06.182
And the third thing
I said on that beach was,

00:14:06.206 --> 00:14:08.858
it looks like the most solitary
endeavor in the world,

00:14:08.882 --> 00:14:10.985
and in many ways, of course, it is.

00:14:11.009 --> 00:14:14.658
And in other ways,
and the most important ways,

00:14:14.682 --> 00:14:15.870
it's a team.

00:14:15.894 --> 00:14:18.603
And if you think I'm a badass,
you want to meet Bonnie.

00:14:18.627 --> 00:14:20.079
(Laughter)

00:14:20.103 --> 00:14:21.361
Bonnie, where are you?

00:14:22.699 --> 00:14:23.972
Where are you?

00:14:25.194 --> 00:14:26.573
There's Bonnie Stoll.

00:14:26.597 --> 00:14:28.984
(Applause)

00:14:29.008 --> 00:14:30.302
My buddy.

00:14:30.326 --> 00:14:33.331
(Applause)

00:14:33.355 --> 00:14:35.675
The Henry David Thoreau quote goes,

00:14:35.699 --> 00:14:38.969
"When you achieve your dreams,
it's not so much what you get

00:14:38.993 --> 00:14:41.291
as who you have become in achieving them."

00:14:41.862 --> 00:14:43.773
And yeah, I stand before you now.

00:14:43.797 --> 00:14:45.797
In the three months since that swim ended,

00:14:45.821 --> 00:14:47.625
I've sat down with Oprah,

00:14:47.649 --> 00:14:51.407
and I've been in
President Obama's Oval Office;

00:14:51.431 --> 00:14:53.982
I've been invited to speak
in front of esteemed groups

00:14:54.006 --> 00:14:55.157
such as yourselves;

00:14:55.181 --> 00:14:57.432
I've signed a wonderful
major book contract.

00:14:57.456 --> 00:15:00.167
All of that's great,
and I don't denigrate it.

00:15:00.191 --> 00:15:02.082
I'm proud of it all, but the truth is,

00:15:02.106 --> 00:15:03.399
I'm walking around tall

00:15:03.423 --> 00:15:09.366
because I am that bold, fearless person,
and I will be, every day,

00:15:09.390 --> 00:15:13.539
until it's time for these days to be done.

00:15:13.563 --> 00:15:15.721
Thank you very much
and enjoy the conference.

00:15:15.745 --> 00:15:17.852
Thank you. Thank you!

00:15:17.876 --> 00:15:20.615
(Applause)

00:15:20.639 --> 00:15:24.400
Thank you. Thank you. Thank you.
Thank you! Thank you.

00:15:24.424 --> 00:15:27.129
(Applause)

00:15:27.153 --> 00:15:28.570
Find a way!

00:15:28.594 --> 00:15:30.579
(Applause)

title: How an obese town lost a million pounds
transcript: How many of you have been to Oklahoma City?Raise your hand. Yeah?How many of you have not been to Oklahoma City and have no idea who I am? (Laughter)Most of you. Let me give you a little bit of background.Oklahoma City started in the most unique way imaginable. Back on a spring day in 1889, the federal government held what they called a land run. They literally lined up the settlers along an imaginary line, and they fired off a gun, and the settlers roared across the countryside and put down a stake, and wherever they put down that stake, that was their new home. And at the end of the very first day, the population of Oklahoma City had gone from zero to 10,000, and our planning department is still paying for that. The citizens got together on that first day and elected a mayor. And then they shot him. (Laughter) That's not really all that funny — (Laughter) — but it allows me to see what type of audience I'm dealing with, so I appreciate the feedback.The 20th century was fairly kind to Oklahoma City. Our economy was based on commodities, so the price of cotton or the price of wheat, and ultimately the price of oil and natural gas. And along the way, we became a city of innovation. The shopping cart was invented in Oklahoma City. (Applause) The parking meter, invented in Oklahoma City. You're welcome.Having an economy, though, that relates to commodities can give you some ups and some downs, and that was certainly the case in Oklahoma City's history. In the 1970s, when it appeared that the price of energy would never retreat, our economy was soaring, and then in the early 1980s, it cratered quickly. The price of energy dropped. Our banks began to fail. Before the end of the decade, 100 banks had failed in the state of Oklahoma. There was no bailout on the horizon. Our banking industry, our oil and gas industry, our commercial real estate industry, were all at the bottom of the economic scale. Young people were leaving Oklahoma City in droves for Washington and Dallas and Houston and New York and Tokyo, anywhere where they could  find a job that measured up to their educational attainment, because in Oklahoma City, the good jobs just weren't there.But along at the end of the '80s came an enterprising businessman who became mayor named Ron Norick. Ron Norick eventually figured out that the secret to economic development wasn't incentivizing companies up front, it was about creating a place where businesses wanted to locate, and so he pushed an initiative called MAPS that basically was a penny-on-the-dollar sales tax to build a bunch of stuff. It built a new sports arena, a new canal downtown, it fixed up our performing arts center, a new baseball stadium downtown, a lot of things to improve the quality of life. And the economy indeed seemed to start showing some signs of life.The next mayor came along. He started MAPS for Kids, rebuilt the entire inner city school system, all 75 buildings either built anew or refurbished.And then, in 2004, in this rare collective lack of judgment bordering on civil disobedience, the citizens elected me mayor.Now the city I inherited was just on the verge of coming out of its slumbering economy, and for the very first time, we started showing up on the lists. Now you know the lists I'm talking about. The media and the Internet love to rank cities. And in Oklahoma City, we'd never really been on lists before. So I thought it was kind of cool when they came out with these positive lists and we were on there. We weren't anywhere close to the top, but we were on the list, we were somebody. Best city to get a job, best city to start a business, best downtown — Oklahoma City.And then came the list of the most obese cities in the country. And there we were.Now I like to point out that we were on that list with a lot of really cool places. (Laughter) Dallas and Houston and New Orleans and Atlanta and Miami. You know, these are cities that, typically, you're not embarrassed to be associated with. But nonetheless, I didn't like being on the list.And about that time, I got on the scales. And I weighed 220 pounds. And then I went to this website sponsored by the federal government, and I typed in my height, I typed in my weight, and I pushed Enter, and it came back and said "obese."I thought, "What a stupid website." (Laughter) "I'm not obese. I would know if I was obese."And then I started getting honest with myself about what had become my lifelong struggle with obesity, and I noticed this pattern, that I was gaining about two or three pounds a year, and then about every 10 years, I'd drop 20 or 30 pounds. And then I'd do it again. And I had this huge closet full of clothes, and I could only wear a third of it at any one time, and only I knew which part of the closet I could wear. But it all seemed fairly normal, going through it.Well, I finally decided I needed to lose weight, and I knew I could because I'd done it so many times before, so I simply stopped eating as much. I had always exercised. That really wasn't the part of the equation that I needed to work on. But I had been eating 3,000 calories a day, and I cut it to 2,000 calories a day, and the weight came off. I lost about a pound a week for about 40 weeks.Along the way, though, I started examining my city, its culture, its infrastructure, trying to figure out why our specific city seemed to have a problem with obesity. And I came to the conclusion that we had built an incredible quality of life if you happen to be a car. (Laughter) But if you happen to be a person, you are combatting the car seemingly at every turn. Our city is very spread out. We have a great intersection of highways, I mean, literally no traffic congestion in Oklahoma City to speak of. And so people live far, far away. Our city limits are enormous, 620 square miles, but 15 miles is less than 15 minutes. You literally can get a speeding ticket during rush hour in Oklahoma City. And as a result, people tend to spread out. Land's cheap. We had also not required developers to build sidewalks on new developments  for a long, long time. We had fixed that, but it had been relatively recently, and there were literally 100,000 or more homes into our inventory in neighborhoods that had  virtually no level of walkability.And as I tried to examine how we might deal with obesity, and was taking all of these elements into my mind, I decided that the first thing we need to do was have a conversation. You see, in Oklahoma City, we weren't talking about obesity. And so, on New Year's Eve of 2007, I went to the zoo, and I stood in front of the elephants, and I said, "This city is going on a diet, and we're going to lose a million pounds."Well, that's when all hell broke loose.(Laughter)The national media gravitated toward this story immediately, and they really could have  gone with it one of two ways. They could have said, "This city is so fat that the mayor had to put them on a diet." But fortunately, the consensus was, "Look, this is a problem in a lot of places. This is a city that's wanting to do something about it." And so they started helping us drive traffic to the website. Now, the web address was thiscityisgoingonadiet.com. And I appeared on "The Ellen DeGeneres Show" one weekday morning to talk about the initiative, and on that day, 150,000 visits were placed to our website. People were signing up, and so the pounds started to add up, and the conversation that I thought was so important to have was starting to take place. It was taking place inside the homes, mothers and fathers talking about it with their kids. It was taking place in churches. Churches were starting their own running groups and their own support groups for people who were dealing with obesity. Suddenly, it was a topic worth discussing at schools and in the workplace. And the large companies, they typically have wonderful wellness programs, but the medium-sized companies that typically fall between the cracks on issues like this, they started to get engaged and used our program as a model for their own employees to try and have contests to see who might be able to deal with their obesity situation in a way that could be proactively beneficial to others.And then came the next stage of the equation. It was time to push what I called MAPS 3. Now MAPS 3, like the other two programs, had had an economic development motive behind it, but along with the traditional economic development tasks like building a new convention center, we added some health-related infrastructure to the process. We added a new central park, 70 acres in size, to be right downtown in Oklahoma City. We're building a downtown streetcar to try and help the walkability formula for people who choose to live in the inner city and help us create the density there. We're building senior health and wellness centers throughout the community. We put some investments on the river that had originally been invested upon in the original MAPS, and now we are currently in the final stages of developing the finest venue in the world for the sports of canoe, kayak and rowing. We hosted the Olympic trials last spring. We have Olympic-caliber events coming to Oklahoma City, and athletes from all over the world moving in, along with inner city programs to get kids more engaged in these types of recreational activities that are a little bit nontraditional. We also, with another initiative that was passed, are building hundreds of miles of new sidewalks throughout the metro area. We're even going back into some inner city situations where we had built neighborhoods and we had built schools but we had not connected the two. We had built libraries and we had built neighborhoods, but we had never really connected the two with any sort of walkability. Through yet another funding source, we're redesigning all of our inner city streets to be more pedestrian-friendly. Our streets were really wide, and you'd push the button to allow you to walk across, and you had to run in order to get there in time. But now we've narrowed the streets, highly landscaped them, making them more pedestrian-friendly, really a redesign, rethinking the way we build our infrastructure, designing a city around people and not cars. We're completing our bicycle trail master plan. We'll have over 100 miles when we're through building it out.And so you see this culture starting to shift in Oklahoma City. And lo and behold, the demographic changes that are coming with it are very inspiring. Highly educated twentysomethings are moving to Oklahoma City from all over the region and, indeed, even from further away, in California.When we reached a million pounds, in January of 2012, I flew to New York with some our participants who had lost over 100 pounds, whose lives had been changed, and we appeared on the Rachael Ray show, and then that afternoon, I did a round of media in New York pushing the same messages that you're accustomed to hearing about obesity and the dangers of it. And I went into the lobby of Men's Fitness magazine, the same magazine that had put us on that list five years before. And as I'm sitting in the lobby waiting to talk to the reporter, I notice there's a magazine copy of the current issue right there on the table, and I pick it up, and I look at the headline across the top, and it says, "America's Fattest Cities: Do You Live in One?" Well, I knew I did, so I picked up the magazine and I began to look, and we weren't on it.(Applause)Then I looked on the list of fittest cities, and we were on that list. We were on the list as the 22nd fittest city in the United States. Our state health statistics are doing better. Granted, we have a long way to go. Health is still not something that we should be proud of in Oklahoma City, but we seem to have turned the cultural shift of making health a greater priority. And we love the idea of the demographics of highly educated twentysomethings, people with choices, choosing Oklahoma City in large numbers. We have the lowest unemployment in the United States, probably the strongest economy in the United States. And if you're like me, at some point in your educational career, you were asked to read a book called "The Grapes of Wrath." Oklahomans leaving for California in large numbers for a better future. When we look at the demographic shifts of people coming from the west, it appears that what we're seeing now is the wrath of grapes. (Laughter) (Applause) The grandchildren are coming home.You've been a great audience and very attentive. Thank you very much for having me here.(Applause)

WEBVTT

00:00:12.270 --> 00:00:14.443
How many of you have been to Oklahoma City?

00:00:14.443 --> 00:00:15.733
Raise your hand. Yeah?

00:00:15.733 --> 00:00:17.882
How many of you have not been to Oklahoma City

00:00:17.882 --> 00:00:21.891
and have no idea who I am? (Laughter)

00:00:21.891 --> 00:00:24.689
Most of you. Let me give you
a little bit of background.

00:00:24.689 --> 00:00:27.131
Oklahoma City started in the most

00:00:27.131 --> 00:00:28.899
unique way imaginable.

00:00:28.899 --> 00:00:31.721
Back on a spring day in 1889,

00:00:31.721 --> 00:00:33.308
the federal government held what they called

00:00:33.308 --> 00:00:35.067
a land run.

00:00:35.067 --> 00:00:36.761
They literally lined up the settlers

00:00:36.761 --> 00:00:38.384
along an imaginary line,

00:00:38.384 --> 00:00:39.809
and they fired off a gun,

00:00:39.809 --> 00:00:41.594
and the settlers roared across the countryside

00:00:41.594 --> 00:00:43.710
and put down a stake,

00:00:43.710 --> 00:00:45.246
and wherever they put down that stake,

00:00:45.246 --> 00:00:46.954
that was their new home.

00:00:46.954 --> 00:00:49.324
And at the end of the very first day,

00:00:49.324 --> 00:00:51.074
the population of Oklahoma City

00:00:51.074 --> 00:00:54.980
had gone from zero to 10,000,

00:00:54.980 --> 00:00:56.321
and our planning department

00:00:56.321 --> 00:01:00.241
is still paying for that.

00:01:00.241 --> 00:01:02.738
The citizens got together on that first day

00:01:02.738 --> 00:01:04.990
and elected a mayor.

00:01:04.990 --> 00:01:06.797
And then they shot him.

00:01:06.797 --> 00:01:11.446
(Laughter)

00:01:11.905 --> 00:01:14.388
That's not really all that funny

00:01:14.388 --> 00:01:15.892
-- (Laughter) --

00:01:15.892 --> 00:01:17.812
but it allows me to see what type of audience

00:01:17.812 --> 00:01:22.174
I'm dealing with, so I appreciate the feedback.

00:01:22.174 --> 00:01:24.951
The 20th century was fairly kind to Oklahoma City.

00:01:24.951 --> 00:01:27.412
Our economy was based on commodities,

00:01:27.412 --> 00:01:30.211
so the price of cotton or the price of wheat,

00:01:30.211 --> 00:01:33.524
and ultimately the price of oil and natural gas.

00:01:33.524 --> 00:01:35.636
And along the way, we became a city

00:01:35.636 --> 00:01:37.682
of innovation.

00:01:37.682 --> 00:01:41.555
The shopping cart was invented in Oklahoma City.

00:01:41.555 --> 00:01:46.695
(Applause)

00:01:46.695 --> 00:01:51.995
The parking meter, invented in Oklahoma City.

00:01:51.995 --> 00:01:55.741
You're welcome.

00:01:55.741 --> 00:01:57.437
Having an economy, though,

00:01:57.437 --> 00:02:00.584
that relates to commodities
can give you some ups and some downs,

00:02:00.584 --> 00:02:03.181
and that was certainly the case
in Oklahoma City's history.

00:02:03.181 --> 00:02:05.538
In the 1970s, when it appeared

00:02:05.538 --> 00:02:07.361
that the price of energy would never retreat,

00:02:07.361 --> 00:02:09.095
our economy was soaring,

00:02:09.095 --> 00:02:12.677
and then in the early 1980s, it cratered quickly.

00:02:12.677 --> 00:02:15.148
The price of energy dropped.

00:02:15.148 --> 00:02:16.900
Our banks began to fail.

00:02:16.900 --> 00:02:18.458
Before the end of the decade,

00:02:18.458 --> 00:02:22.345
100 banks had failed in the state of Oklahoma.

00:02:22.345 --> 00:02:24.896
There was no bailout on the horizon.

00:02:24.896 --> 00:02:27.201
Our banking industry, our oil and gas industry,

00:02:27.201 --> 00:02:29.237
our commercial real estate industry,

00:02:29.237 --> 00:02:32.440
were all at the bottom of the economic scale.

00:02:32.440 --> 00:02:35.085
Young people were leaving Oklahoma City in droves

00:02:35.085 --> 00:02:38.000
for Washington and Dallas and Houston
and New York and Tokyo,

00:02:38.000 --> 00:02:40.107
anywhere where they could 
find a job that measured up

00:02:40.107 --> 00:02:41.778
to their educational attainment,

00:02:41.778 --> 00:02:45.009
because in Oklahoma City,
the good jobs just weren't there.

00:02:45.009 --> 00:02:46.725
But along at the end of the '80s

00:02:46.725 --> 00:02:49.553
came an enterprising businessman

00:02:49.553 --> 00:02:51.562
who became mayor named Ron Norick.

00:02:51.562 --> 00:02:53.309
Ron Norick eventually figured out

00:02:53.309 --> 00:02:55.246
that the secret to economic development

00:02:55.246 --> 00:02:57.407
wasn't incentivizing companies up front,

00:02:57.407 --> 00:03:00.461
it was about creating a place
where businesses wanted to locate,

00:03:00.461 --> 00:03:03.473
and so he pushed an initiative called MAPS

00:03:03.473 --> 00:03:05.878
that basically was a penny-on-the-dollar sales tax

00:03:05.878 --> 00:03:08.190
to build a bunch of stuff.

00:03:08.190 --> 00:03:10.165
It built a new sports arena,

00:03:10.165 --> 00:03:12.344
a new canal downtown,

00:03:12.344 --> 00:03:14.705
it fixed up our performing arts center,

00:03:14.705 --> 00:03:17.372
a new baseball stadium downtown,

00:03:17.372 --> 00:03:19.216
a lot of things to improve the quality of life.

00:03:19.216 --> 00:03:21.629
And the economy indeed seemed to start

00:03:21.629 --> 00:03:23.661
showing some signs of life.

00:03:23.661 --> 00:03:26.019
The next mayor came along.

00:03:26.019 --> 00:03:27.796
He started MAPS for Kids,

00:03:27.796 --> 00:03:30.523
rebuilt the entire inner city school system,

00:03:30.523 --> 00:03:35.277
all 75 buildings either built anew or refurbished.

00:03:35.277 --> 00:03:38.498
And then, in 2004,

00:03:38.498 --> 00:03:43.202
in this rare collective lack of judgment

00:03:43.202 --> 00:03:45.830
bordering on civil disobedience,

00:03:45.830 --> 00:03:49.798
the citizens elected me mayor.

00:03:49.798 --> 00:03:52.002
Now the city I inherited

00:03:52.002 --> 00:03:53.846
was just on the verge

00:03:53.846 --> 00:03:57.247
of coming out of its slumbering economy,

00:03:57.247 --> 00:03:58.938
and for the very first time,

00:03:58.938 --> 00:04:02.077
we started showing up on the lists.

00:04:02.077 --> 00:04:04.094
Now you know the lists I'm talking about.

00:04:04.094 --> 00:04:05.877
The media and the Internet

00:04:05.877 --> 00:04:08.423
love to rank cities.

00:04:08.423 --> 00:04:10.498
And in Oklahoma City,

00:04:10.498 --> 00:04:13.179
we'd never really been on lists before.

00:04:13.179 --> 00:04:14.885
So I thought it was kind of cool

00:04:14.885 --> 00:04:17.581
when they came out with these
positive lists and we were on there.

00:04:17.581 --> 00:04:19.279
We weren't anywhere close to the top,

00:04:19.279 --> 00:04:22.776
but we were on the list, we were somebody.

00:04:22.776 --> 00:04:24.606
Best city to get a job,

00:04:24.606 --> 00:04:26.621
best city to start a business,

00:04:26.621 --> 00:04:28.414
best downtown --

00:04:28.414 --> 00:04:30.888
Oklahoma City.

00:04:30.888 --> 00:04:34.193
And then came the list

00:04:34.193 --> 00:04:39.739
of the most obese cities in the country.

00:04:39.739 --> 00:04:42.842
And there we were.

00:04:42.842 --> 00:04:44.986
Now I like to point out that we were on that list

00:04:44.986 --> 00:04:47.484
with a lot of really cool places.

00:04:47.484 --> 00:04:48.707
(Laughter)

00:04:48.707 --> 00:04:51.963
Dallas and Houston and New Orleans

00:04:51.963 --> 00:04:53.673
and Atlanta and Miami.

00:04:53.673 --> 00:04:55.170
You know, these are cities that, typically,

00:04:55.170 --> 00:04:57.818
you're not embarrassed to be associated with.

00:04:57.818 --> 00:05:02.086
But nonetheless, I didn't like being on the list.

00:05:02.086 --> 00:05:06.431
And about that time, I got on the scales.

00:05:06.431 --> 00:05:08.557
And I weighed 220 pounds.

00:05:08.557 --> 00:05:10.060
And then I went to this website

00:05:10.060 --> 00:05:11.910
sponsored by the federal government,

00:05:11.910 --> 00:05:15.583
and I typed in my height, I typed in my weight,

00:05:15.583 --> 00:05:16.912
and I pushed Enter,

00:05:16.912 --> 00:05:20.962
and it came back and said "obese."

00:05:20.962 --> 00:05:23.215
I thought, "What a stupid website."

00:05:23.215 --> 00:05:26.090
(Laughter)

00:05:26.090 --> 00:05:32.335
"I'm not obese. I would know if I was obese."

00:05:32.335 --> 00:05:34.826
And then I started getting honest with myself

00:05:34.826 --> 00:05:39.752
about what had become
my lifelong struggle with obesity,

00:05:39.752 --> 00:05:41.632
and I noticed this pattern,

00:05:41.632 --> 00:05:44.323
that I was gaining about two or three pounds a year,

00:05:44.323 --> 00:05:47.629
and then about every 10 years,
I'd drop 20 or 30 pounds.

00:05:47.629 --> 00:05:49.191
And then I'd do it again.

00:05:49.191 --> 00:05:51.524
And I had this huge closet full of clothes,

00:05:51.524 --> 00:05:54.891
and I could only wear a third of it at any one time,

00:05:54.891 --> 00:05:59.003
and only I knew which part of the closet I could wear.

00:05:59.003 --> 00:06:04.553
But it all seemed fairly normal, going through it.

00:06:04.553 --> 00:06:07.635
Well, I finally decided I needed to lose weight,

00:06:07.635 --> 00:06:10.052
and I knew I could because
I'd done it so many times before,

00:06:10.052 --> 00:06:12.290
so I simply stopped eating as much.

00:06:12.290 --> 00:06:13.545
I had always exercised.

00:06:13.545 --> 00:06:15.420
That really wasn't the part of the equation

00:06:15.420 --> 00:06:17.333
that I needed to work on.

00:06:17.333 --> 00:06:20.162
But I had been eating 3,000 calories a day,

00:06:20.162 --> 00:06:22.444
and I cut it to 2,000 calories a day,

00:06:22.444 --> 00:06:25.335
and the weight came off. I lost about a pound a week

00:06:25.335 --> 00:06:29.241
for about 40 weeks.

00:06:29.241 --> 00:06:30.786
Along the way, though,

00:06:30.786 --> 00:06:34.806
I started examining my city,

00:06:34.806 --> 00:06:38.302
its culture, its infrastructure,

00:06:38.302 --> 00:06:41.194
trying to figure out why our specific city

00:06:41.194 --> 00:06:45.593
seemed to have a problem with obesity.

00:06:45.593 --> 00:06:47.769
And I came to the conclusion

00:06:47.769 --> 00:06:51.627
that we had built an incredible quality of life

00:06:51.627 --> 00:06:55.047
if you happen to be a car.

00:06:55.047 --> 00:06:58.282
(Laughter)

00:06:58.282 --> 00:07:01.822
But if you happen to be a person,

00:07:01.822 --> 00:07:06.391
you are combatting the car seemingly at every turn.

00:07:06.391 --> 00:07:08.664
Our city is very spread out.

00:07:08.664 --> 00:07:12.219
We have a great intersection of highways,

00:07:12.219 --> 00:07:15.833
I mean, literally no traffic congestion
in Oklahoma City to speak of.

00:07:15.833 --> 00:07:18.044
And so people live far, far away.

00:07:18.044 --> 00:07:21.629
Our city limits are enormous, 620 square miles,

00:07:21.629 --> 00:07:25.174
but 15 miles is less than 15 minutes.

00:07:25.174 --> 00:07:27.109
You literally can get a speeding ticket

00:07:27.109 --> 00:07:30.706
during rush hour in Oklahoma City.

00:07:30.706 --> 00:07:33.203
And as a result, people tend to spread out.

00:07:33.203 --> 00:07:36.896
Land's cheap.

00:07:36.896 --> 00:07:39.462
We had also not required developers

00:07:39.462 --> 00:07:41.957
to build sidewalks on new developments 
for a long, long time.

00:07:41.957 --> 00:07:44.370
We had fixed that, but it had been relatively recently,

00:07:44.370 --> 00:07:46.764
and there were literally 100,000

00:07:46.764 --> 00:07:49.440
or more homes into our inventory

00:07:49.440 --> 00:07:55.518
in neighborhoods that had 
virtually no level of walkability.

00:07:57.822 --> 00:08:00.076
And as I tried to examine

00:08:00.076 --> 00:08:02.049
how we might deal with obesity,

00:08:02.049 --> 00:08:03.933
and was taking all of these elements into my mind,

00:08:03.933 --> 00:08:07.347
I decided that the first thing we need to do

00:08:07.347 --> 00:08:09.467
was have a conversation.

00:08:09.467 --> 00:08:11.426
You see, in Oklahoma City,

00:08:11.426 --> 00:08:14.207
we weren't talking about obesity.

00:08:14.207 --> 00:08:19.218
And so, on New Year's Eve of 2007,

00:08:19.218 --> 00:08:21.257
I went to the zoo,

00:08:21.257 --> 00:08:23.678
and I stood in front of the elephants,

00:08:23.678 --> 00:08:27.541
and I said, "This city is going on a diet,

00:08:27.541 --> 00:08:31.160
and we're going to lose a million pounds."

00:08:31.160 --> 00:08:32.933
Well, that's when all hell broke loose.

00:08:32.933 --> 00:08:35.711
(Laughter)

00:08:35.711 --> 00:08:37.594
The national media

00:08:37.594 --> 00:08:42.111
gravitated toward this story immediately,

00:08:42.111 --> 00:08:44.970
and they really could have 
gone with it one of two ways.

00:08:44.970 --> 00:08:46.501
They could have said,

00:08:46.501 --> 00:08:48.643
"This city is so fat

00:08:48.643 --> 00:08:51.959
that the mayor had to put them on a diet."

00:08:51.959 --> 00:08:54.462
But fortunately, the consensus was,

00:08:54.462 --> 00:08:56.809
"Look, this is a problem in a lot of places.

00:08:56.809 --> 00:09:00.668
This is a city that's wanting
to do something about it."

00:09:00.668 --> 00:09:02.638
And so they started helping us

00:09:02.638 --> 00:09:04.788
drive traffic to the website.

00:09:04.788 --> 00:09:06.306
Now, the web address was

00:09:06.306 --> 00:09:11.287
thiscityisgoingonadiet.com.

00:09:11.287 --> 00:09:14.706
And I appeared on "The Ellen DeGeneres Show"

00:09:14.706 --> 00:09:18.126
one weekday morning to talk about the initiative,

00:09:18.126 --> 00:09:21.646
and on that day, 150,000 visits

00:09:21.646 --> 00:09:23.466
were placed to our website.

00:09:23.466 --> 00:09:25.040
People were signing up,

00:09:25.040 --> 00:09:27.886
and so the pounds started to add up,

00:09:27.886 --> 00:09:29.493
and the conversation that I thought

00:09:29.493 --> 00:09:33.257
was so important to have was starting to take place.

00:09:33.257 --> 00:09:35.806
It was taking place inside the homes,

00:09:35.806 --> 00:09:38.383
mothers and fathers talking about it with their kids.

00:09:38.383 --> 00:09:41.044
It was taking place in churches.

00:09:41.044 --> 00:09:43.040
Churches were starting their own running groups

00:09:43.040 --> 00:09:44.328
and their own support groups

00:09:44.328 --> 00:09:47.060
for people who were dealing with obesity.

00:09:47.060 --> 00:09:50.472
Suddenly, it was a topic worth discussing at schools

00:09:50.472 --> 00:09:52.104
and in the workplace.

00:09:52.104 --> 00:09:54.265
And the large companies, they typically have

00:09:54.265 --> 00:09:55.861
wonderful wellness programs,

00:09:55.861 --> 00:09:57.184
but the medium-sized companies

00:09:57.184 --> 00:10:00.269
that typically fall between the cracks
on issues like this,

00:10:00.269 --> 00:10:02.970
they started to get engaged and used our program

00:10:02.970 --> 00:10:04.826
as a model for their own employees

00:10:04.826 --> 00:10:06.772
to try and have contests to see

00:10:06.772 --> 00:10:10.587
who might be able to deal with their obesity situation

00:10:10.587 --> 00:10:15.554
in a way that could be proactively
beneficial to others.

00:10:15.554 --> 00:10:20.175
And then came the next stage of the equation.

00:10:20.175 --> 00:10:24.187
It was time to push what I called MAPS 3.

00:10:24.187 --> 00:10:26.387
Now MAPS 3, like the other two programs,

00:10:26.387 --> 00:10:29.051
had had an economic development motive behind it,

00:10:29.051 --> 00:10:31.871
but along with the traditional
economic development tasks

00:10:31.871 --> 00:10:33.633
like building a new convention center,

00:10:33.633 --> 00:10:36.397
we added some health-related infrastructure

00:10:36.397 --> 00:10:38.289
to the process.

00:10:38.289 --> 00:10:41.034
We added a new central park, 70 acres in size,

00:10:41.034 --> 00:10:43.424
to be right downtown in Oklahoma City.

00:10:43.424 --> 00:10:45.203
We're building a downtown streetcar

00:10:45.203 --> 00:10:47.451
to try and help the walkability formula

00:10:47.451 --> 00:10:49.503
for people who choose to live in the inner city

00:10:49.503 --> 00:10:52.880
and help us create the density there.

00:10:52.880 --> 00:10:56.235
We're building senior health and wellness centers

00:10:56.235 --> 00:10:57.933
throughout the community.

00:10:57.933 --> 00:10:59.621
We put some investments on the river

00:10:59.621 --> 00:11:02.157
that had originally been invested upon

00:11:02.157 --> 00:11:03.837
in the original MAPS,

00:11:03.837 --> 00:11:05.781
and now we are currently in the final stages

00:11:05.781 --> 00:11:08.432
of developing the finest venue in the world

00:11:08.432 --> 00:11:11.248
for the sports of canoe, kayak and rowing.

00:11:11.248 --> 00:11:13.140
We hosted the Olympic trials last spring.

00:11:13.140 --> 00:11:15.544
We have Olympic-caliber events
coming to Oklahoma City,

00:11:15.544 --> 00:11:18.100
and athletes from all over the world moving in,

00:11:18.100 --> 00:11:19.702
along with inner city programs

00:11:19.702 --> 00:11:23.652
to get kids more engaged in these
types of recreational activities

00:11:23.652 --> 00:11:26.452
that are a little bit nontraditional.

00:11:26.452 --> 00:11:30.178
We also, with another initiative that was passed,

00:11:30.178 --> 00:11:34.021
are building hundreds of miles of new sidewalks

00:11:34.021 --> 00:11:36.420
throughout the metro area.

00:11:36.420 --> 00:11:38.265
We're even going back into some

00:11:38.265 --> 00:11:39.760
inner city situations

00:11:39.760 --> 00:11:41.474
where we had built neighborhoods

00:11:41.474 --> 00:11:43.155
and we had built schools

00:11:43.155 --> 00:11:45.081
but we had not connected the two.

00:11:45.081 --> 00:11:47.799
We had built libraries and
we had built neighborhoods,

00:11:47.799 --> 00:11:49.404
but we had never really connected the two

00:11:49.404 --> 00:11:51.828
with any sort of walkability.

00:11:51.828 --> 00:11:53.927
Through yet another funding source,

00:11:53.927 --> 00:11:57.262
we're redesigning all of our inner city streets

00:11:57.262 --> 00:11:58.772
to be more pedestrian-friendly.

00:11:58.772 --> 00:12:00.649
Our streets were really wide,

00:12:00.649 --> 00:12:03.076
and you'd push the button
to allow you to walk across,

00:12:03.076 --> 00:12:06.624
and you had to run in order to get there in time.

00:12:06.624 --> 00:12:08.532
But now we've narrowed the streets,

00:12:08.532 --> 00:12:11.440
highly landscaped them, making them
more pedestrian-friendly,

00:12:11.440 --> 00:12:13.907
really a redesign, rethinking the way

00:12:13.907 --> 00:12:15.455
we build our infrastructure,

00:12:15.455 --> 00:12:20.702
designing a city around people and not cars.

00:12:20.702 --> 00:12:22.823
We're completing our bicycle trail master plan.

00:12:22.823 --> 00:12:24.641
We'll have over 100 miles

00:12:24.641 --> 00:12:27.433
when we're through building it out.

00:12:27.433 --> 00:12:30.694
And so you see this culture starting to shift

00:12:30.694 --> 00:12:32.198
in Oklahoma City.

00:12:32.198 --> 00:12:34.875
And lo and behold, the demographic changes

00:12:34.875 --> 00:12:37.855
that are coming with it are very inspiring.

00:12:37.855 --> 00:12:39.438
Highly educated twentysomethings

00:12:39.438 --> 00:12:41.498
are moving to Oklahoma City from all over the region

00:12:41.498 --> 00:12:45.598
and, indeed, even from further away, in California.

00:12:48.673 --> 00:12:51.009
When we reached a million pounds,

00:12:51.009 --> 00:12:53.310
in January of 2012,

00:12:53.310 --> 00:12:55.753
I flew to New York with some our participants

00:12:55.753 --> 00:12:57.283
who had lost over 100 pounds,

00:12:57.283 --> 00:12:59.568
whose lives had been changed,

00:12:59.568 --> 00:13:01.739
and we appeared on the Rachael Ray show,

00:13:01.739 --> 00:13:05.146
and then that afternoon,
I did a round of media in New York

00:13:05.146 --> 00:13:07.587
pushing the same messages

00:13:07.587 --> 00:13:11.683
that you're accustomed to hearing
about obesity and the dangers of it.

00:13:11.683 --> 00:13:16.664
And I went into the lobby of Men's Fitness magazine,

00:13:16.664 --> 00:13:21.040
the same magazine that had put us on that list

00:13:21.040 --> 00:13:23.403
five years before.

00:13:23.403 --> 00:13:26.350
And as I'm sitting in the lobby
waiting to talk to the reporter,

00:13:26.360 --> 00:13:28.744
I notice there's a magazine copy

00:13:28.744 --> 00:13:31.363
of the current issue right there on the table,

00:13:31.363 --> 00:13:33.019
and I pick it up, and I look at the headline

00:13:33.019 --> 00:13:34.784
across the top, and it says,

00:13:34.784 --> 00:13:39.465
"America's Fattest Cities: Do You Live in One?"

00:13:39.465 --> 00:13:41.610
Well, I knew I did,

00:13:41.610 --> 00:13:43.762
so I picked up the magazine

00:13:43.762 --> 00:13:46.773
and I began to look,

00:13:46.773 --> 00:13:49.519
and we weren't on it.

00:13:49.519 --> 00:13:53.937
(Applause)

00:13:55.942 --> 00:13:58.867
Then I looked on the list of fittest cities,

00:13:58.867 --> 00:14:01.030
and we were on that list.

00:14:01.030 --> 00:14:04.408
We were on the list as the 22nd
fittest city in the United States.

00:14:04.408 --> 00:14:07.595
Our state health statistics are doing better.

00:14:07.595 --> 00:14:09.707
Granted, we have a long way to go.

00:14:09.707 --> 00:14:10.846
Health is still not something

00:14:10.846 --> 00:14:12.383
that we should be proud of in Oklahoma City,

00:14:12.383 --> 00:14:16.166
but we seem to have turned the cultural shift

00:14:16.166 --> 00:14:19.247
of making health a greater priority.

00:14:19.247 --> 00:14:22.090
And we love the idea of the demographics

00:14:22.090 --> 00:14:23.900
of highly educated twentysomethings,

00:14:23.900 --> 00:14:25.669
people with choices, choosing Oklahoma City

00:14:25.669 --> 00:14:27.118
in large numbers.

00:14:27.118 --> 00:14:29.411
We have the lowest unemployment
in the United States,

00:14:29.411 --> 00:14:32.283
probably the strongest economy in the United States.

00:14:32.283 --> 00:14:33.913
And if you're like me, at some point

00:14:33.913 --> 00:14:36.285
in your educational career,

00:14:36.285 --> 00:14:38.502
you were asked to read a book called

00:14:38.502 --> 00:14:41.347
"The Grapes of Wrath."

00:14:41.347 --> 00:14:44.381
Oklahomans leaving for California

00:14:44.381 --> 00:14:46.824
in large numbers for a better future.

00:14:46.824 --> 00:14:48.613
When we look at the demographic shifts

00:14:48.613 --> 00:14:49.773
of people coming from the west,

00:14:49.773 --> 00:14:51.401
it appears that what we're seeing now

00:14:51.401 --> 00:14:54.249
is the wrath of grapes.

00:14:54.249 --> 00:14:56.062
(Laughter)

00:14:56.062 --> 00:14:59.127
(Applause)

00:14:59.127 --> 00:15:03.672
The grandchildren are coming home.

00:15:03.672 --> 00:15:05.460
You've been a great audience and very attentive.

00:15:05.460 --> 00:15:07.911
Thank you very much for having me here.

00:15:07.911 --> 00:15:10.454
(Applause)

title: I got 99 problems ... palsy is just one
transcript: Hello, TEDWomen, what's up.(Cheering)Not good enough. Hello, TEDWomen, what is up?(Loud cheering)My name is Maysoon Zayid, and I am not drunk, but the doctor who delivered me was. He cut my mom six different times in six different directions, suffocating poor little me in the process. As a result, I have cerebral palsy, which means I shake all the time. Look. It's exhausting. I'm like Shakira, Shakira meets Muhammad Ali.(Laughter)CP is not genetic. It's not a birth defect. You can't catch it. No one put a curse on my mother's uterus, and I didn't get it because my parents are first cousins, which they are.(Laughter)It only happens from accidents, like what happened to me on my birth day.Now, I must warn you, I'm not inspirational.(Laughter)And I don't want anyone in this room to feel bad for me, because at some point in your life, you have dreamt of being disabled. Come on a journey with me. It's Christmas Eve, you're at the mall, you're driving around in circles looking for parking, and what do you see? Sixteen empty handicapped spaces.(Laughter)And you're like, "God, can't I just be a little disabled?"(Laughter)Also, I've got to tell you, I've got 99 problems, and palsy is just one.(Laughter)If there was an Oppression Olympics, I would win the gold medal. I'm Palestinian, Muslim, I'm female, I'm disabled, and I live in New Jersey.(Laughter)(Applause)If you don't feel better about yourself, maybe you should.(Laughter)Cliffside Park, New Jersey is my hometown. I have always loved the fact that my hood and my affliction share the same initials. I also love the fact that if I wanted to walk from my house to New York City, I could.A lot of people with CP don't walk, but my parents didn't believe in "can't." My father's mantra was, "You can do it, yes you can can."(Laughter) So, if my three older sisters were mopping, I was mopping. If my three older sisters went to public school, my parents would sue the school system and guarantee that I went too, and if we didn't all get A's, we all got my mother's slipper.(Laughter)My father taught me how to walk when I was five years old by placing my heels on his feet and just walking. Another tactic that he used is he would dangle a dollar bill in front of me and have me chase it.(Laughter)My inner stripper was very strong.(Laughter)Yeah. No, by the first day of kindergarten, I was walking like a champ who had been punched one too many times.(Laughter)Growing up, there were only six Arabs in my town, and they were all my family.(Laughter)Now there are 20 Arabs in town, and they are still all my family.(Laughter)I don't think anyone even noticed we weren't Italian.(Laughter)(Applause)This was before 9/11 and before politicians thought it was appropriate to use "I hate Muslims" as a campaign slogan. The people that I grew up with had no problem with my faith. They did, however, seem very concerned that I would starve to death during Ramadan. I would explain to them that I have enough fat to live off of for three whole months, so fasting from sunrise to sunset is a piece of cake.(Laughter)I have tap-danced on Broadway. Yeah, on Broadway. It's crazy.(Applause)My parents couldn't afford physical therapy, so they sent me to dancing school. I learned how to dance in heels, which means I can walk in heels. And I'm from Jersey, and we are really concerned with being chic, so if my friends wore heels, so did I.And when my friends went and spent their summer vacations on the Jersey Shore, I did not. I spent my summers in a war zone, because my parents were afraid that if we didn't go back to Palestine every single summer, we'd grow up to be Madonna.(Laughter)Summer vacations often consisted of my father trying to heal me, so I drank deer's milk, I had hot cups on my back, I was dunked in the Dead Sea, and I remember the water burning my eyes and thinking, "It's working! It's working!"(Laughter)But one miracle cure we did find was yoga. I have to tell you, it's very boring, but before I did yoga, I was a stand-up comedian who can't stand up. And now I can stand on my head. My parents reinforced this notion that I could do anything, that no dream was impossible, and my dream was to be on the daytime soap opera "General Hospital."(Laughter)I went to college during affirmative action and got a sweet scholarship to ASU, Arizona State University, because I fit every single quota.(Laughter)I was like the pet lemur of the theater department. Everybody loved me. I did all the less-than-intelligent kids' homework, I got A's in all of my classes, A's in all of their classes.(Laughter)Every time I did a scene from "The Glass Menagerie," my professors would weep. But I never got cast. Finally, my senior year, ASU decided to do a show called "They Dance Real Slow in Jackson." It's a play about a girl with CP. I was a girl with CP. So I start shouting from the rooftops, "I'm finally going to get a part! I have cerebral palsy! Free at last! Free at last! Thank God almighty, I'm free at last!" I didn't get the part.(Laughter)Sherry Brown got the part. I went racing to the head of the theater department crying hysterically, like someone shot my cat, to ask her why, and she said it was because they didn't think I could do the stunts. I said, "Excuse me, if I can't do the stunts, neither can the character."(Laughter)(Applause)This was a part that I was literally born to play they gave it to a non-palsy actress. College was imitating life. Hollywood has a sordid history of casting able-bodied actors to play disabled onscreen.Upon graduating, I moved back home, and my first acting gig was as an extra on a daytime soap opera. My dream was coming true. And I knew that I would be promoted from "Diner Diner" to "Wacky Best Friend" in no time.(Laughter)But instead, I remained a glorified piece of furniture that you could only recognize from the back of my head, and it became clear to me that casting directors didn't hire fluffy, ethnic, disabled actors. They only hired perfect people. But there were exceptions to the rule. I grew up watching Whoopi Goldberg, Roseanne Barr, Ellen, and all of these women had one thing in common: they were comedians. So I became a comic.(Laughter)(Applause)My first gig was driving famous comics from New York City to shows in New Jersey, and I'll never forget the face of the first comic I ever drove when he realized that he was speeding down the New Jersey Turnpike with a chick with CP driving him.(Laughter)I've performed in clubs all over America, and I've also performed in Arabic in the Middle East, uncensored and uncovered.(Laughter)Some people say I'm the first stand-up comic in the Arab world. I never like to claim first, but I do know that they never heard that nasty little rumor that women aren't funny, and they find us hysterical.(Laughter)In 2003, my brother from another mother and father Dean Obeidallah and I started the New York Arab-American Comedy Festival, now in its 10th year. Our goal was to change the negative image of Arab-Americans in media, while also reminding casting directors that South Asian and Arab are not synonymous.(Laughter)Mainstreaming Arabs was much, much easier than conquering the challenge against the stigma against disability.My big break came in 2010. I was invited to be a guest on the cable news show "Countdown with Keith Olbermann." I walked in looking like I was going to the prom, and they shuffle me into a studio and seat me on a spinning, rolling chair.(Laughter)So I looked at the stage manager and I'm like, "Excuse me, can I have another chair?" And she looked at me and she went, "Five, four, three, two ..." And we were live, right? So I had to grip onto the anchor's desk so that I wouldn't roll off the screen during the segment, and when the interview was over, I was livid. I had finally gotten my chance and I blew it, and I knew I would never get invited back. But not only did Mr. Olbermann invite me back, he made me a full-time contributor, and he taped down my chair.(Laughter)(Applause)One fun fact I learned while on the air with Keith Olbermann was that humans on the Internet are scumbags.(Laughter) People say children are cruel, but I was never made fun of as a child or an adult. Suddenly, my disability on the world wide web is fair game. I would look at clips online and see comments like, "Yo, why's she tweakin'?" "Yo, is she retarded?" And my favorite, "Poor Gumby-mouth terrorist. What does she suffer from? We should really pray for her." One commenter even suggested that I add my disability to my credits: screenwriter, comedian, palsy.Disability is as visual as race. If a wheelchair user can't play Beyoncé, then Beyoncé can't play a wheelchair user. The disabled are the largest — Yeah, clap for that, man. Come on.(Applause)People with disabilities are the largest minority in the world, and we are the most underrepresented in entertainment.The doctors said that I wouldn't walk, but I am here in front of you. However, if I grew up with social media, I don't think I would be. I hope that together, we can create more positive images of disability in the media and in everyday life. Perhaps if there were more positive images, it would foster less hate on the Internet. Or maybe not. Maybe it still takes a village to teach our children well.My crooked journey has taken me to some very spectacular places. I got to walk the red carpet flanked by soap diva Susan Lucci and the iconic Loreen Arbus. I got to act in a movie with Adam Sandler and work with my idol, the amazing Dave Matthews. I toured the world as a headliner on Arabs Gone Wild. I was a delegate representing the great state of New Jersey at the 2008 DNC. And I founded Maysoon's Kids, a charity that hopes to give Palestinian refugee children a sliver of the chance my parents gave me. But the one moment that stands out the most was when I got — before this moment —(Laughter)(Applause)But the one moment that stands out the most was when I got to perform for the man who floats like a butterfly and stings like a bee, has Parkinson's and shakes just like me, Muhammad Ali.(Applause)(Applause ends)It was the only time that my father ever saw me perform live, and I dedicate this talk to his memory.(Arabic) Allah yerhamak yaba.(English) My name is Maysoon Zayid, and if I can can, you can can.(Cheering)(Applause)
