00:00:51.318 --> 00:00:54.325
and we asked them, let's see the effectiveness

00:00:54.325 --> 00:00:56.916
of your leadership development programs.

00:00:56.916 --> 00:00:59.104
Fifty-eight percent of the companies

00:00:59.104 --> 00:01:01.472
cited significant talent gaps

00:01:01.472 --> 00:01:03.827
for critical leadership roles.

00:01:03.827 --> 00:01:07.266
That means that despite
corporate training programs,

00:01:07.266 --> 00:01:11.703
off-sites, assessments, coaching, all of these things,

00:01:11.703 --> 00:01:13.644
more than half the companies

00:01:13.644 --> 00:01:18.501
had failed to grow enough great leaders.

00:01:18.501 --> 00:01:20.524
You may be asking yourself,

00:01:20.524 --> 00:01:23.255
is my company helping me to prepare

00:01:23.255 --> 00:01:26.498
to be a great 21st-century leader?

00:01:26.498 --> 00:01:29.910
The odds are, probably not.

00:01:29.910 --> 00:01:33.973
Now, I've spent 25 years of my professional life

00:01:33.973 --> 00:01:37.478
observing what makes great leaders.

00:01:37.478 --> 00:01:39.943
I've worked inside Fortune 500 companies,

00:01:39.943 --> 00:01:42.012
I've advised over 200 CEOs,

00:01:42.012 --> 00:01:44.771
and I've cultivated more leadership pipelines

00:01:44.771 --> 00:01:47.781
than you can imagine.

00:01:47.781 --> 00:01:51.506
But a few years ago, I noticed a disturbing trend

00:01:51.506 --> 00:01:54.721
in leadership preparation.

00:01:54.721 --> 00:01:58.547
I noticed that, despite all the efforts,

00:01:58.547 --> 00:02:01.086
there were familiar stories that kept resurfacing

00:02:01.086 --> 00:02:03.210
about individuals.

00:02:03.210 --> 00:02:06.844
One story was about Chris,

00:02:06.844 --> 00:02:09.188
a high-potential, superstar leader

00:02:09.188 --> 00:02:12.790
who moves to a new unit and fails,

00:02:12.790 --> 00:02:15.526
destroying unrecoverable value.

00:02:15.526 --> 00:02:19.119
And then there were stories like Sidney, the CEO,

00:02:19.119 --> 00:02:20.821
who was so frustrated

00:02:20.821 --> 00:02:22.888
because her company is cited

00:02:22.888 --> 00:02:25.217
as a best company for leaders,

00:02:25.217 --> 00:02:29.054
but only one of the top 50 leaders is equipped

00:02:29.054 --> 00:02:31.639
to lead their crucial initiatives.

00:02:31.639 --> 00:02:33.596
And then there were stories

00:02:33.596 --> 00:02:36.126
like the senior leadership team

00:02:36.126 --> 00:02:38.206
of a once-thriving business

00:02:38.206 --> 00:02:41.662
that's surprised by a market shift,

00:02:41.662 --> 00:02:44.393
finds itself having to force the company

00:02:44.393 --> 00:02:46.721
to reduce its size in half

00:02:46.721 --> 00:02:49.534
or go out of business.

00:02:49.534 --> 00:02:52.252
Now, these recurring stories

00:02:52.252 --> 00:02:54.819
cause me to ask two questions.

00:02:54.819 --> 00:02:57.290
Why are the leadership gaps widening

00:02:57.290 --> 00:02:59.223
when there's so much more investment

00:02:59.223 --> 00:03:01.447
in leadership development?

00:03:01.447 --> 00:03:04.744
And what are the great leaders doing

00:03:04.744 --> 00:03:08.619
distinctly different to thrive and grow?

00:03:08.619 --> 00:03:10.988
One of the things that I did,

00:03:10.988 --> 00:03:13.664
I was so consumed by these questions

00:03:13.664 --> 00:03:16.608
and also frustrated by those stories,

00:03:16.608 --> 00:03:19.016
that I left my job

00:03:19.016 --> 00:03:21.596
so that I could study this full time,

00:03:21.596 --> 00:03:24.541
and I took a year to travel

00:03:24.541 --> 00:03:26.561
to different parts of the world

00:03:26.561 --> 00:03:28.947
to learn about effective and ineffective

00:03:28.947 --> 00:03:31.332
leadership practices in companies,

00:03:31.332 --> 00:03:34.835
countries and nonprofit organizations.

00:03:34.835 --> 00:03:38.162
And so I did things like travel to South Africa,

00:03:38.162 --> 00:03:41.088
where I had an opportunity to understand

00:03:41.088 --> 00:03:43.562
how Nelson Mandela was ahead of his time

00:03:43.562 --> 00:03:45.453
in anticipating and navigating

00:03:45.453 --> 00:03:48.870
his political, social and economic context.

00:03:48.870 --> 00:03:51.893
I also met a number of nonprofit leaders

00:03:51.893 --> 00:03:55.863
who, despite very limited financial resources,

00:03:55.863 --> 00:03:58.806
were making a huge impact in the world,

00:03:58.806 --> 00:04:02.668
often bringing together seeming adversaries.

00:04:02.668 --> 00:04:07.723
And I spent countless hours in presidential libraries

00:04:07.723 --> 00:04:10.055
trying to understand how the environment

00:04:10.055 --> 00:04:11.213
had shaped the leaders,

00:04:11.213 --> 00:04:12.816
the moves that they made,

00:04:12.816 --> 00:04:14.342
and then the impact of those moves

00:04:14.342 --> 00:04:17.269
beyond their tenure.

00:04:17.269 --> 00:04:20.270
And then, when I returned to work full time,

00:04:20.270 --> 00:04:23.559
in this role, I joined with wonderful colleagues

00:04:23.559 --> 00:04:27.051
who were also interested in these questions.

00:04:27.051 --> 00:04:29.996
Now, from all this, I distilled

00:04:29.996 --> 00:04:34.000
the characteristics of leaders who are thriving

00:04:34.000 --> 00:04:35.826
and what they do differently,

00:04:35.826 --> 00:04:38.279
and then I also distilled

00:04:38.279 --> 00:04:41.221
the preparation practices that enable people

00:04:41.221 --> 00:04:43.862
to grow to their potential.

00:04:43.877 --> 00:04:45.810
I want to share some of those with you now.

00:04:45.810 --> 00:04:47.885
("What makes a great leader in the 21st century?")

00:04:47.885 --> 00:04:51.250
In a 21st-century world, which is more global,

00:04:51.250 --> 00:04:53.701
digitally enabled and transparent,

00:04:53.701 --> 00:04:57.114
with faster speeds of information 
flow and innovation,

00:04:57.114 --> 00:04:59.409
and where nothing big gets done

00:04:59.409 --> 00:05:02.645
without some kind of a complex matrix,

00:05:02.645 --> 00:05:06.305
relying on traditional development practices

00:05:06.305 --> 00:05:08.963
will stunt your growth as a leader.

00:05:08.963 --> 00:05:11.810
In fact, traditional assessments

00:05:11.810 --> 00:05:16.153
like narrow 360 surveys or
outdated performance criteria

00:05:16.153 --> 00:05:18.191
will give you false positives,

00:05:18.191 --> 00:05:21.617
lulling you into thinking that you are more prepared

00:05:21.617 --> 00:05:23.757
than you really are.

00:05:23.757 --> 00:05:27.650
Leadership in the 21st century is defined

00:05:27.650 --> 00:05:30.804
and evidenced by three questions.

00:05:30.804 --> 00:05:32.138
Where are you looking

00:05:32.138 --> 00:05:35.214
to anticipate the next change

00:05:35.214 --> 00:05:38.687
to your business model or your life?

00:05:38.687 --> 00:05:43.537
The answer to this question is on your calendar.

00:05:43.537 --> 00:05:47.478
Who are you spending time with? On what topics?

00:05:47.478 --> 00:05:50.026
Where are you traveling? What are you reading?

00:05:50.026 --> 00:05:51.773
And then how are you distilling this

00:05:51.773 --> 00:05:55.480
into understanding potential discontinuities,

00:05:55.480 --> 00:05:57.732
and then making a decision to do something

00:05:57.732 --> 00:06:02.146
right now so that you're prepared and ready?

00:06:02.146 --> 00:06:05.148
There's a leadership team that does a practice

00:06:05.148 --> 00:06:08.120
where they bring together each member

00:06:08.120 --> 00:06:10.927
collecting, here are trends that impact me,

00:06:10.927 --> 00:06:13.212
here are trends that impact another team member,

00:06:13.212 --> 00:06:14.611
and they share these,

00:06:14.611 --> 00:06:17.407
and then make decisions,
to course-correct a strategy

00:06:17.407 --> 00:06:20.664
or to anticipate a new move.

00:06:20.664 --> 00:06:23.717
Great leaders are not head-down.

00:06:23.717 --> 00:06:25.962
They see around corners,

00:06:25.962 --> 00:06:29.871
shaping their future, not just reacting to it.

00:06:29.871 --> 00:06:31.826
The second question is,

00:06:31.826 --> 00:06:33.845
what is the diversity measure

00:06:33.845 --> 00:06:37.464
of your personal and professional
stakeholder network?

00:06:37.464 --> 00:06:40.466
You know, we hear often about 
good ol' boy networks

00:06:40.466 --> 00:06:44.374
and they're certainly alive and 
well in many institutions.

00:06:44.382 --> 00:06:46.925
But to some extent, we all have a network

00:06:46.925 --> 00:06:48.854
of people that we're comfortable with.

00:06:48.854 --> 00:06:51.766
So this question is about your capacity

00:06:51.766 --> 00:06:54.265
to develop relationships with people

00:06:54.265 --> 00:06:55.788
that are very different than you.

00:06:55.788 --> 00:06:58.781
And those differences can be biological,

00:06:58.781 --> 00:07:03.565
physical, functional, political, 
cultural, socioeconomic.

00:07:03.565 --> 00:07:07.008
And yet, despite all these differences,

00:07:07.008 --> 00:07:08.765
they connect with you

00:07:08.765 --> 00:07:10.019
and they trust you enough

00:07:10.019 --> 00:07:11.301
to cooperate with you

00:07:11.301 --> 00:07:14.439
in achieving a shared goal.

00:07:14.439 --> 00:07:16.774
Great leaders understand

00:07:16.774 --> 00:07:19.703
that having a more diverse network

00:07:19.703 --> 00:07:23.244
is a source of pattern identification

00:07:23.244 --> 00:07:26.029
at greater levels and also of solutions,

00:07:26.029 --> 00:07:27.853
because you have people that are thinking

00:07:27.853 --> 00:07:30.538
differently than you are.

00:07:30.538 --> 00:07:33.888
Third question: are you courageous enough

00:07:33.888 --> 00:07:39.790
to abandon a practice that has 
made you successful in the past?

00:07:39.790 --> 00:07:43.939
There's an expression: Go along to get along.

00:07:43.939 --> 00:07:46.857
But if you follow this advice,

00:07:46.857 --> 00:07:49.249
chances are as a leader,

00:07:49.249 --> 00:07:53.764
you're going to keep doing
what's familiar and comfortable.

00:07:53.764 --> 00:07:56.617
Great leaders dare to be different.

00:07:56.617 --> 00:07:58.262
They don't just talk about risk-taking,

00:07:58.262 --> 00:08:00.080
they actually do it.

00:08:00.080 --> 00:08:02.992
And one of the leaders shared with me the fact that

00:08:02.992 --> 00:08:05.569
the most impactful development comes

00:08:05.569 --> 00:08:08.873
when you are able to build the emotional stamina

00:08:08.873 --> 00:08:13.033
to withstand people telling you that your new idea

00:08:13.033 --> 00:08:17.751
is naïve or reckless or just plain stupid.

00:08:17.751 --> 00:08:21.613
Now interestingly, the people who will join you

00:08:21.613 --> 00:08:25.068
are not your usual suspects in your network.

00:08:25.068 --> 00:08:28.719
They're often people that think differently

00:08:28.719 --> 00:08:31.591
and therefore are willing to join you

00:08:31.591 --> 00:08:33.950
in taking a courageous leap.

00:08:33.950 --> 00:08:37.201
And it's a leap, not a step.

00:08:37.201 --> 00:08:40.110
More than traditional leadership programs,

00:08:40.110 --> 00:08:41.992
answering these three questions

00:08:41.992 --> 00:08:43.375
will determine your effectiveness

00:08:43.375 --> 00:08:46.844
as a 21st-century leader.

00:08:46.844 --> 00:08:51.265
So what makes a great leader in the 21st century?

00:08:51.265 --> 00:08:54.814
I've met many, and they stand out.

00:08:54.814 --> 00:08:56.465
They are women and men

00:08:56.465 --> 00:08:58.231
who are preparing themselves

00:08:58.231 --> 00:09:01.350
not for the comfortable predictability of yesterday

00:09:01.350 --> 00:09:05.126
but also for the realities of today

00:09:05.126 --> 00:09:09.387
and all of those unknown possibilities of tomorrow.

00:09:09.387 --> 00:09:11.814
Thank you.

00:09:11.814 --> 00:09:14.492
(Applause)

title: Are we designed to be sexual omnivores?
transcript: I'm going to go off script and make Chris quite nervous here by making this audience participation. All right. Are you with me? Yeah. Yeah. All right.So what I'd like to do is have you raise your hand if you've ever heard a heterosexual couple having sex. Could be the neighbors, hotel room, your parents. Sorry. Okay. Pretty much everybody. Now raise your hand if the man was making more noise than the woman. I see one guy there. It doesn't count if it was you, sir. (Laughter) So his hand's down. And one woman. Okay. Sitting next to a loud guy.Now what does this tell us? It tells us that human beings make noise when they have sex, and it's generally the woman who makes more noise. This is known as female copulatory vocalization to the clipboard crowd. I wasn't even going to mention this, but somebody told me that Meg Ryan might be here, and she is the world's most famous female copulatory vocalizer. So I thought, got to talk about that. We'll get back to that a little bit later.Let me start by saying human beings are not descended from apes, despite what you may have heard. We are apes. We are more closely related to the chimp and the bonobo than the African elephant is to the Indian elephant, as Jared Diamond pointed out in one of his early books. We're more closely related to chimps and bonobos than chimps and bonobos are related to any other primate — gorillas, orangutans, what have you. So we're extremely closely related to them, and as you'll see in terms of our behavior, we've got some relationship as well. So what I'm asking today, the question I want to explore with you today is, what kind of ape are we in terms of our sexuality? Now, since Darwin's day there's been what Cacilda and I have called the standard narrative of human sexual evolution, and you're all familiar with it, even if you haven't read this stuff. The idea is that, as part of human nature, from the beginning of our species' time, men have sort of leased women's reproductive potential by providing them with certain goods and services. Generally we're talking about meat, shelter, status, protection, things like that. And in exchange, women have offered fidelity, or at least a promise of fidelity. Now this sets men and women up in an oppositional relationship. The war between the sexes is built right into our DNA, according to this vision. Right? What Cacilda and I have argued is that no, this economic relationship, this oppositional relationship, is actually an artifact of agriculture, which only arose about 10,000 years ago at the earliest. Anatomically modern human beings have been around for about 200,000 years, so we're talking about five percent, at most, of our time as a modern, distinct species. So before agriculture, before the agricultural revolution, it's important to understand that human beings lived in hunter-gatherer groups that are characterized wherever they're found in the world by what anthropologists called fierce egalitarianism. They not only share things, they demand that things be shared: meat, shelter, protection, all these things that were supposedly being traded to women for their sexual fidelity, it turns out, are shared widely among these societies. Now I'm not saying that our ancestors were noble savages, and I'm not saying modern day hunter-gatherers are noble savages either. What I'm saying is that this is simply the best way to mitigate risk in a foraging context. And there's really no argument about this among anthropologists. All Cacilda and I have done is extend this sharing behavior to sexuality. So we've argued that human sexuality has essentially evolved, until agriculture, as a way of establishing and maintaining the complex, flexible social systems, networks, that our ancestors were very good at, and that's why our species has survived so well.Now, this makes some people uncomfortable, and so I always need to take  a moment in these talks to say, listen, I'm saying our ancestors were promiscuous, but I'm not saying they were having sex with strangers. There were no strangers. Right? In a hunter-gatherer band, there are no strangers. You've known these people your entire life. So I'm saying, yes, there were overlapping sexual relationships, that our ancestors probably had several different sexual relationships going on at any given moment in their adult lives. But I'm not saying they were having sex with strangers. I'm not saying that they didn't love the people they were having sex with. And I'm not saying there was no pair-bonding going on. I'm just saying it wasn't sexually exclusive.And those of us who have chosen to be monogamous — my parents, for example, have been married for 52 years monogamously, and if it wasn't monogamously, Mom and Dad, I don't want to hear about it— I'm not criticizing this and I'm not saying there's anything wrong with this. What I'm saying is that to argue that our ancestors were sexual omnivores is no more a criticism of monogamy than to argue that our ancestors were dietary omnivores is a criticism of vegetarianism. You can choose to be a vegetarian, but don't think that just because you've made that decision, bacon suddenly stops smelling good. Okay? So this is my point. (Laughter) That one took a minute to sink in, huh?Now, in addition to being a great genius, a wonderful man, a wonderful husband, a wonderful father, Charles Darwin was also a world-class Victorian prude. All right? He was perplexed by the sexual swellings of certain primates, including chimps and bonobos, because these sexual swellings tend to provoke many males to mate with the females. So he couldn't understand why on Earth would the female have developed this thing if all they were supposed to be doing is forming their pair bond, right? Chimps and bonobos, Darwin didn't really know this, but chimps and bonobos mate one to four times per hour with up to a dozen males per day when they have their sexual swellings. Interestingly, chimps have sexual swellings through 40 percent, roughly, of their menstrual cycle, bonobos 90 percent, and humans are among the only species on the planet where the female is available for sex throughout the menstrual cycle, whether she's menstruating, whether she's post-menopausal, whether she's already pregnant. This is vanishingly rare among mammals. So it's a very interesting aspect of human sexuality. Now, Darwin ignored the reflections of the sexual swelling in his own day, as scientists tend to do sometimes.So what we're talking about is sperm competition. Now the average human ejaculate has about 300 million sperm cells, so it's already a competitive environment. The question is whether these sperm are  competing against other men's sperm or just their own. There's a lot to talk about in this chart. The one thing I'll call your attention to right away is the little musical note above the female chimp and bonobo and human. That indicates female copulatory vocalization. Just look at the numbers. The average human has sex about 1,000 times per birth. If that number seems high for some of you, I assure you it seems low for others in the room. We share that ratio with chimps and bonobos. We don't share it with the other three apes, the gorilla, the orangutan and the gibbon, who are more typical of mammals, having sex only about a dozen times per birth. Humans and bonobos are the only  animals that have sex face-to-face when both of them are alive. (Laughter) And you'll see that the human, chimp and bonobo all have external testicles, which in our book we equate to a special fridge you have in the garage just for beer. If you're the kind of guy who has a beer fridge in the garage, you expect a party to happen at any moment, and you need to be ready. That's what the external testicles are. They keep the sperm cells cool so you can have frequent ejaculations. I'm sorry. It's true. The human, some of you will be happy to hear, has the largest, thickest penis of any primate.Now, this evidence goes way beyond anatomy. It goes into anthropology as well. Historical records are full of accounts of people around the world who have sexual practices that should be impossible given what we have assumed about human sexual evolution. These women are the Mosuo from southwestern China. In their society, everyone, men and women, are completely sexually autonomous. There's no shame associated with sexual behavior. Women have hundreds of partners. It doesn't matter. Nobody cares. Nobody gossips. It's not an issue. When the woman becomes pregnant, the child is cared for by her,  her sisters, and her brothers. The biological father is a nonissue. On the other side of the planet, in the Amazon, we've got many tribes which practice what anthropologists call partible paternity. These people actually believe — and they have no contact among them, no common language or anything, so it's not an idea that spread, it's an idea that's arisen around the world — they believe that a fetus is literally made of accumulated semen. So a woman who wants to have a child who's smart and funny and strong makes sure she has lots of sex with the smart guy, the funny guy and the strong guy, to get the essence of each of these men into the baby, and then when the child is born, these different men will come forward and acknowledge their paternity of the child. So paternity is actually sort of a team endeavor in this society. So there are all sorts of examples like this that we go through in the book.Now, why does this matter? Edward Wilson says we need to understand that human sexuality is first a bonding device and only secondarily procreation. I think that's true. This matters because our evolved sexuality is in direct conflict with many aspects of the modern world. The contradictions between what we're told we should feel and what we actually do feel generates a huge amount of unnecessary suffering. My hope is that a more accurate, updated understanding of human sexuality will lead us to have greater tolerance for ourselves, for each other, greater respect for unconventional relationship configurations like same-sex marriage or polyamorous unions, and that we'll finally put to rest the idea that men have some innate, instinctive right to monitor and control women's sexual behavior. (Applause) Thank you. And we'll see that it's not only gay people that have to come out of the closet. We all have closets we have to come out of. Right? And when we do come out of those closets, we'll recognize that our fight is not with each other, our fight is with an outdated,  Victorian sense of human sexuality that conflates desire with property rights, generates shame and confusion in place of understanding and empathy. It's time we moved beyond Mars and Venus, because the truth is that men are from Africa and women are from Africa.Thank you.(Applause)Chris Anderson: Thank you. Christopher Ryan: Thank you.CA: So a question. It's so perplexing, trying to use arguments about evolutionary history to turn that into what we ought to do today. Someone could give a talk and say, look at us, we've got these really sharp teeth and muscles and a brain that's really good at throwing weapons, and if you look at lots of societies around the world, you'll see very high rates of violence. Nonviolence is a choice like vegetarianism, but it's not who you are. How is that different from the talk you gave?CR: Well first of all, the evidence for high levels of violence in prehistory is very debatable. But that's just an example. Certainly, you know, lots of people say to me, just because we lived a certain way in the past doesn't mean we should live that  way now, and I agree with that. Everyone has to respond to the modern world. But the body does have its inherent evolved trajectories. And so you could live on McDonald's and milkshakes, but your body will rebel against  that. We have appetites. I think it was Schopenhauer who said, a person can do what they want but not want what they want. And so what I'm arguing against is the shame that's associated with desires. It's the idea that if you love your husband or wife but you still are attracted to other people, there's something wrong with you, there's something wrong with your marriage, something wrong with your partner. I think a lot of families are fractured by unrealistic expectations that are based upon this false vision of human sexuality. That's what I'm trying to get at.CA: Thank you. Communicated powerfully. Thanks a lot.CR: Thank you, Chris. (Applause)

00:00:57.446 --> 00:01:00.500
This is known as female copulatory vocalization

00:01:00.500 --> 00:01:01.923
to the clipboard crowd.

00:01:01.923 --> 00:01:03.554
I wasn't even going to mention this,

00:01:03.554 --> 00:01:06.495
but somebody told me that Meg Ryan might be here,

00:01:06.495 --> 00:01:09.099
and she is the world's most famous

00:01:09.099 --> 00:01:11.048
female copulatory vocalizer.

00:01:11.048 --> 00:01:13.448
So I thought, got to talk about that.

00:01:13.448 --> 00:01:16.161
We'll get back to that a little bit later.

00:01:16.161 --> 00:01:18.126
Let me start by saying human beings

00:01:18.126 --> 00:01:20.227
are not descended from apes,

00:01:20.227 --> 00:01:22.459
despite what you may have heard. We are apes.

00:01:22.459 --> 00:01:25.295
We are more closely related
to the chimp and the bonobo

00:01:25.295 --> 00:01:28.675
than the African elephant is to the Indian elephant,

00:01:28.675 --> 00:01:31.873
as Jared Diamond pointed
out in one of his early books.

00:01:31.873 --> 00:01:36.068
We're more closely related to chimps and bonobos

00:01:36.068 --> 00:01:37.569
than chimps and bonobos are related

00:01:37.569 --> 00:01:39.231
to any other primate --

00:01:39.231 --> 00:01:41.507
gorillas, orangutans, what have you.

00:01:41.507 --> 00:01:44.754
So we're extremely closely related to them,

00:01:44.754 --> 00:01:47.180
and as you'll see in terms of our behavior,

00:01:47.180 --> 00:01:49.547
we've got some relationship as well.

00:01:49.547 --> 00:01:51.466
So what I'm asking today, the question

00:01:51.466 --> 00:01:54.528
I want to explore with you today is,

00:01:54.528 --> 00:01:58.696
what kind of ape are we in terms of our sexuality?

00:01:58.696 --> 00:02:00.914
Now, since Darwin's day there's been

00:02:00.914 --> 00:02:02.416
what Cacilda and I have called

00:02:02.416 --> 00:02:05.102
the standard narrative of human sexual evolution,

00:02:05.102 --> 00:02:06.656
and you're all familiar with it,

00:02:06.656 --> 00:02:09.219
even if you haven't read this stuff.

00:02:09.219 --> 00:02:12.287
The idea is that, as part of human nature,

00:02:12.287 --> 00:02:14.276
from the beginning of our species' time,

00:02:14.276 --> 00:02:18.770
men have sort of leased
women's reproductive potential

00:02:18.770 --> 00:02:22.165
by providing them with certain goods and services.

00:02:22.165 --> 00:02:25.835
Generally we're talking about meat, shelter, status,

00:02:25.835 --> 00:02:28.466
protection, things like that.

00:02:28.466 --> 00:02:30.801
And in exchange, women have offered fidelity,

00:02:30.801 --> 00:02:33.179
or at least a promise of fidelity.

00:02:33.179 --> 00:02:37.449
Now this sets men and women up
in an oppositional relationship.

00:02:37.449 --> 00:02:43.392
The war between the sexes is built right into
our DNA, according to this vision. Right?

00:02:43.392 --> 00:02:47.329
What Cacilda and I have argued is that no,

00:02:47.329 --> 00:02:49.770
this economic relationship,

00:02:49.770 --> 00:02:51.595
this oppositional relationship,

00:02:51.595 --> 00:02:54.220
is actually an artifact of agriculture,

00:02:54.220 --> 00:02:57.896
which only arose about 10,000
years ago at the earliest.

00:02:57.896 --> 00:03:00.063
Anatomically modern human beings

00:03:00.063 --> 00:03:03.062
have been around for about 200,000 years,

00:03:03.062 --> 00:03:06.684
so we're talking about five percent, at most,

00:03:06.684 --> 00:03:10.372
of our time as a modern, distinct species.

00:03:10.372 --> 00:03:13.906
So before agriculture,

00:03:13.906 --> 00:03:15.911
before the agricultural revolution,

00:03:15.911 --> 00:03:18.022
it's important to understand that human beings

00:03:18.022 --> 00:03:21.356
lived in hunter-gatherer groups that are

00:03:21.356 --> 00:03:24.372
characterized wherever they're found in the world

00:03:24.372 --> 00:03:28.963
by what anthropologists called fierce egalitarianism.

00:03:28.963 --> 00:03:30.831
They not only share things,

00:03:30.831 --> 00:03:33.340
they demand that things be shared:

00:03:33.340 --> 00:03:35.599
meat, shelter, protection, all these things

00:03:35.599 --> 00:03:38.608
that were supposedly being traded to women

00:03:38.608 --> 00:03:41.438
for their sexual fidelity, it turns out,

00:03:41.438 --> 00:03:44.168
are shared widely among these societies.

00:03:44.168 --> 00:03:46.356
Now I'm not saying that our ancestors

00:03:46.356 --> 00:03:48.317
were noble savages, and I'm not saying

00:03:48.317 --> 00:03:51.113
modern day hunter-gatherers
are noble savages either.

00:03:51.113 --> 00:03:53.124
What I'm saying is that this is simply

00:03:53.124 --> 00:03:55.564
the best way to mitigate risk

00:03:55.564 --> 00:03:57.494
in a foraging context.

00:03:57.494 --> 00:04:00.610
And there's really no argument
about this among anthropologists.

00:04:00.610 --> 00:04:05.174
All Cacilda and I have done is extend
this sharing behavior to sexuality.

00:04:05.174 --> 00:04:07.609
So we've argued that human sexuality

00:04:07.609 --> 00:04:12.093
has essentially evolved, until agriculture,

00:04:12.093 --> 00:04:15.239
as a way of establishing and maintaining

00:04:15.239 --> 00:04:18.965
the complex, flexible social systems, networks,

00:04:18.965 --> 00:04:21.876
that our ancestors were very good at,

00:04:21.876 --> 00:04:26.492
and that's why our species has survived so well.

00:04:26.492 --> 00:04:28.709
Now, this makes some people uncomfortable,

00:04:28.709 --> 00:04:31.094
and so I always need to take 
a moment in these talks

00:04:31.094 --> 00:04:32.938
to say, listen,

00:04:32.938 --> 00:04:35.581
I'm saying our ancestors were promiscuous,

00:04:35.581 --> 00:04:37.916
but I'm not saying they were
having sex with strangers.

00:04:37.916 --> 00:04:39.942
There were no strangers. Right?

00:04:39.942 --> 00:04:41.786
In a hunter-gatherer band, there are no strangers.

00:04:41.786 --> 00:04:43.775
You've known these people your entire life.

00:04:43.775 --> 00:04:47.234
So I'm saying, yes, there were
overlapping sexual relationships,

00:04:47.234 --> 00:04:51.541
that our ancestors probably had
several different sexual relationships

00:04:51.541 --> 00:04:54.928
going on at any given moment in their adult lives.

00:04:54.928 --> 00:04:57.331
But I'm not saying they were
having sex with strangers.

00:04:57.331 --> 00:05:00.442
I'm not saying that they didn't love the
people they were having sex with.

00:05:00.442 --> 00:05:03.347
And I'm not saying there was
no pair-bonding going on.

00:05:03.347 --> 00:05:06.433
I'm just saying it wasn't sexually exclusive.

00:05:06.433 --> 00:05:10.117
And those of us who have
chosen to be monogamous --

00:05:10.117 --> 00:05:12.455
my parents, for example, have been married

00:05:12.455 --> 00:05:14.963
for 52 years monogamously,

00:05:14.963 --> 00:05:17.325
and if it wasn't monogamously, Mom and Dad,

00:05:17.325 --> 00:05:19.672
I don't want to hear about it—

00:05:19.672 --> 00:05:22.064
I'm not criticizing this and I'm not saying

00:05:22.064 --> 00:05:23.620
there's anything wrong with this.

00:05:23.620 --> 00:05:25.779
What I'm saying is that to argue

00:05:25.779 --> 00:05:30.453
that our ancestors were sexual omnivores

00:05:30.453 --> 00:05:32.740
is no more a criticism of monogamy

00:05:32.740 --> 00:05:36.208
than to argue that our ancestors
were dietary omnivores

00:05:36.208 --> 00:05:39.531
is a criticism of vegetarianism.

00:05:39.531 --> 00:05:41.412
You can choose to be a vegetarian,

00:05:41.412 --> 00:05:44.156
but don't think that just because
you've made that decision,

00:05:44.156 --> 00:05:46.948
bacon suddenly stops smelling good.

00:05:46.948 --> 00:05:49.635
Okay? So this is my point.

00:05:49.635 --> 00:05:51.986
(Laughter)

00:05:51.986 --> 00:05:55.607
That one took a minute to sink in, huh?

00:05:55.607 --> 00:05:57.937
Now, in addition to being a great genius,

00:05:57.937 --> 00:06:00.002
a wonderful man, a wonderful husband,

00:06:00.002 --> 00:06:01.782
a wonderful father, Charles Darwin

00:06:01.782 --> 00:06:05.894
was also a world-class Victorian prude.

00:06:05.894 --> 00:06:07.834
All right? He was perplexed

00:06:07.834 --> 00:06:10.444
by the sexual swellings of certain primates,

00:06:10.444 --> 00:06:11.987
including chimps and bonobos,

00:06:11.987 --> 00:06:14.525
because these sexual swellings tend to provoke

00:06:14.525 --> 00:06:17.117
many males to mate with the females.

00:06:17.117 --> 00:06:20.288
So he couldn't understand why on Earth would
the female have developed this thing

00:06:20.288 --> 00:06:24.217
if all they were supposed to be doing
is forming their pair bond, right?

00:06:24.217 --> 00:06:26.656
Chimps and bonobos, Darwin didn't really know this,

00:06:26.656 --> 00:06:28.604
but chimps and bonobos mate

00:06:28.604 --> 00:06:30.258
one to four times per hour

00:06:30.258 --> 00:06:33.674
with up to a dozen males per day

00:06:33.674 --> 00:06:36.290
when they have their sexual swellings.

00:06:36.290 --> 00:06:38.945
Interestingly, chimps have sexual swellings

00:06:38.945 --> 00:06:40.747
through 40 percent, roughly,

00:06:40.747 --> 00:06:42.632
of their menstrual cycle,

00:06:42.632 --> 00:06:45.332
bonobos 90 percent,

00:06:45.332 --> 00:06:48.754
and humans are among the
only species on the planet

00:06:48.754 --> 00:06:50.856
where the female is available for sex

00:06:50.856 --> 00:06:52.844
throughout the menstrual cycle,

00:06:52.844 --> 00:06:55.588
whether she's menstruating,
whether she's post-menopausal,

00:06:55.588 --> 00:06:56.899
whether she's already pregnant.

00:06:56.899 --> 00:07:00.743
This is vanishingly rare among mammals.

00:07:00.743 --> 00:07:04.536
So it's a very interesting aspect of human sexuality.

00:07:04.536 --> 00:07:07.211
Now, Darwin ignored the reflections

00:07:07.211 --> 00:07:10.779
of the sexual swelling in his own day,

00:07:10.779 --> 00:07:14.410
as scientists tend to do sometimes.

00:07:14.410 --> 00:07:16.915
So what we're talking about is sperm competition.

00:07:16.915 --> 00:07:20.325
Now the average human ejaculate
has about 300 million sperm cells,

00:07:20.325 --> 00:07:22.755
so it's already a competitive environment.

00:07:22.755 --> 00:07:25.968
The question is whether these sperm are 
competing against other men's sperm

00:07:25.988 --> 00:07:27.773
or just their own.

00:07:27.773 --> 00:07:29.879
There's a lot to talk about in this chart.

00:07:29.879 --> 00:07:32.054
The one thing I'll call your attention to right away

00:07:32.054 --> 00:07:36.096
is the little musical note above the
female chimp and bonobo and human.

00:07:36.096 --> 00:07:39.397
That indicates female copulatory vocalization.

00:07:39.397 --> 00:07:40.999
Just look at the numbers.

00:07:40.999 --> 00:07:43.195
The average human has sex

00:07:43.195 --> 00:07:46.837
about 1,000 times per birth.

00:07:46.837 --> 00:07:49.010
If that number seems high for some of you,

00:07:49.010 --> 00:07:52.223
I assure you it seems low for others in the room.

00:07:52.223 --> 00:07:55.173
We share that ratio with chimps and bonobos.

00:07:55.173 --> 00:07:57.475
We don't share it with the other three apes,

00:07:57.475 --> 00:07:59.731
the gorilla, the orangutan and the gibbon,

00:07:59.731 --> 00:08:01.392
who are more typical of mammals,

00:08:01.392 --> 00:08:04.584
having sex only about a dozen times per birth.

00:08:04.584 --> 00:08:08.797
Humans and bonobos are the only 
animals that have sex face-to-face

00:08:08.805 --> 00:08:11.211
when both of them are alive.

00:08:11.211 --> 00:08:15.116
(Laughter)

00:08:15.853 --> 00:08:19.024
And you'll see that the human, chimp and bonobo

00:08:19.024 --> 00:08:21.420
all have external testicles, which in our book

00:08:21.420 --> 00:08:25.408
we equate to a special fridge you have in the garage

00:08:25.408 --> 00:08:27.668
just for beer.

00:08:27.668 --> 00:08:30.394
If you're the kind of guy who has a beer fridge

00:08:30.394 --> 00:08:32.736
in the garage, you expect a party to happen

00:08:32.736 --> 00:08:34.525
at any moment, and you need to be ready.

00:08:34.525 --> 00:08:36.680
That's what the external testicles are.

00:08:36.680 --> 00:08:39.090
They keep the sperm cells cool

00:08:39.090 --> 00:08:41.308
so you can have frequent ejaculations.

00:08:41.308 --> 00:08:45.047
I'm sorry. It's true.

00:08:45.047 --> 00:08:48.136
The human, some of you will be happy to hear,

00:08:48.136 --> 00:08:50.947
has the largest, thickest penis of any primate.

00:08:50.947 --> 00:08:53.457
Now, this evidence goes way beyond anatomy.

00:08:53.457 --> 00:08:56.018
It goes into anthropology as well.

00:08:56.018 --> 00:08:58.635
Historical records are full of accounts of people

00:08:58.635 --> 00:09:00.444
around the world who have sexual practices

00:09:00.444 --> 00:09:02.074
that should be impossible

00:09:02.074 --> 00:09:06.000
given what we have assumed
about human sexual evolution.

00:09:06.000 --> 00:09:08.700
These women are the Mosuo
from southwestern China.

00:09:08.700 --> 00:09:11.267
In their society, everyone, men and women,

00:09:11.267 --> 00:09:13.008
are completely sexually autonomous.

00:09:13.008 --> 00:09:15.967
There's no shame associated with sexual behavior.

00:09:15.967 --> 00:09:18.213
Women have hundreds of partners.

00:09:18.213 --> 00:09:21.395
It doesn't matter. Nobody cares.
Nobody gossips. It's not an issue.

00:09:21.395 --> 00:09:23.191
When the woman becomes pregnant,

00:09:23.191 --> 00:09:26.049
the child is cared for by her, 
her sisters, and her brothers.

00:09:26.049 --> 00:09:28.888
The biological father is a nonissue.

00:09:28.888 --> 00:09:31.294
On the other side of the planet, in the Amazon,

00:09:31.294 --> 00:09:34.163
we've got many tribes which practice

00:09:34.163 --> 00:09:36.895
what anthropologists call partible paternity.

00:09:36.895 --> 00:09:39.492
These people actually believe --

00:09:39.492 --> 00:09:41.207
and they have no contact among them,

00:09:41.207 --> 00:09:42.863
no common language or anything,

00:09:42.863 --> 00:09:44.600
so it's not an idea that spread,

00:09:44.600 --> 00:09:46.737
it's an idea that's arisen around the world --

00:09:46.737 --> 00:09:48.894
they believe that a fetus is literally made

00:09:48.894 --> 00:09:51.170
of accumulated semen.

00:09:51.170 --> 00:09:53.158
So a woman who wants to have a child

00:09:53.158 --> 00:09:54.990
who's smart and funny and strong

00:09:54.990 --> 00:09:57.121
makes sure she has lots of sex with the smart guy,

00:09:57.121 --> 00:09:59.065
the funny guy and the strong guy,

00:09:59.065 --> 00:10:01.289
to get the essence of each of
these men into the baby,

00:10:01.289 --> 00:10:03.801
and then when the child is born,

00:10:03.801 --> 00:10:05.943
these different men will come forward

00:10:05.943 --> 00:10:08.813
and acknowledge their paternity of the child.

00:10:08.813 --> 00:10:11.651
So paternity is actually sort of a team endeavor

00:10:11.651 --> 00:10:13.267
in this society.

00:10:13.267 --> 00:10:15.255
So there are all sorts of examples like this

00:10:15.255 --> 00:10:17.705
that we go through in the book.

00:10:17.705 --> 00:10:21.165
Now, why does this matter?

00:10:21.165 --> 00:10:23.725
Edward Wilson says we need to understand

00:10:23.725 --> 00:10:26.771
that human sexuality is first a bonding device

00:10:26.771 --> 00:10:29.606
and only secondarily procreation.

00:10:29.606 --> 00:10:31.790
I think that's true. This matters because

00:10:31.790 --> 00:10:34.828
our evolved sexuality is in direct conflict

00:10:34.828 --> 00:10:37.415
with many aspects of the modern world.

00:10:37.415 --> 00:10:39.553
The contradictions between what we're told

00:10:39.553 --> 00:10:42.980
we should feel and what we actually do feel

00:10:42.980 --> 00:10:48.117
generates a huge amount of unnecessary suffering.

00:10:48.117 --> 00:10:50.533
My hope is that a more accurate,

00:10:50.533 --> 00:10:52.908
updated understanding of human sexuality

00:10:52.908 --> 00:10:55.928
will lead us to have greater tolerance for ourselves,

00:10:55.928 --> 00:10:57.525
for each other,

00:10:57.525 --> 00:11:01.148
greater respect for unconventional
relationship configurations

00:11:01.148 --> 00:11:06.429
like same-sex marriage or polyamorous unions,

00:11:06.429 --> 00:11:09.777
and that we'll finally put to rest the idea

00:11:09.777 --> 00:11:12.351
that men have some innate, instinctive right

00:11:12.351 --> 00:11:16.579
to monitor and control women's sexual behavior.

00:11:16.579 --> 00:11:19.571
(Applause)

00:11:19.571 --> 00:11:21.725
Thank you.

00:11:21.725 --> 00:11:23.981
And we'll see that it's not only gay people

00:11:23.981 --> 00:11:25.650
that have to come out of the closet.

00:11:25.650 --> 00:11:29.179
We all have closets we have to come out of. Right?

00:11:29.179 --> 00:11:30.940
And when we do come out of those closets,

00:11:30.940 --> 00:11:34.499
we'll recognize that our fight is not with each other,

00:11:34.499 --> 00:11:39.003
our fight is with an outdated, 
Victorian sense of human sexuality

00:11:39.003 --> 00:11:42.558
that conflates desire with property rights,

00:11:42.558 --> 00:11:45.323
generates shame and confusion

00:11:45.323 --> 00:11:48.158
in place of understanding and empathy.

00:11:48.158 --> 00:11:50.874
It's time we moved beyond Mars and Venus,

00:11:50.874 --> 00:11:52.604
because the truth is

00:11:52.604 --> 00:11:53.941
that men are from Africa

00:11:53.941 --> 00:11:55.937
and women are from Africa.

00:11:55.937 --> 00:11:57.882
Thank you.

00:11:57.882 --> 00:12:03.341
(Applause)

00:12:06.488 --> 00:12:08.982
Chris Anderson: Thank you.
Christopher Ryan: Thank you.

00:12:08.982 --> 00:12:10.724
CA: So a question.

00:12:10.724 --> 00:12:14.623
It's so perplexing, trying to use arguments

00:12:14.623 --> 00:12:17.690
about evolutionary history

00:12:17.690 --> 00:12:20.274
to turn that into what we ought to do today.

00:12:20.274 --> 00:12:22.680
Someone could give a talk and say,

00:12:22.680 --> 00:12:25.425
look at us, we've got these really sharp teeth

00:12:25.425 --> 00:12:27.152
and muscles and a brain that's really good

00:12:27.152 --> 00:12:28.713
at throwing weapons,

00:12:28.713 --> 00:12:31.777
and if you look at lots of societies around the world,

00:12:31.777 --> 00:12:34.063
you'll see very high rates of violence.

00:12:34.063 --> 00:12:37.232
Nonviolence is a choice like vegetarianism,

00:12:37.232 --> 00:12:39.376
but it's not who you are.

00:12:39.376 --> 00:12:41.426
How is that different

00:12:41.426 --> 00:12:44.791
from the talk you gave?

00:12:44.791 --> 00:12:47.975
CR: Well first of all, the evidence

00:12:47.975 --> 00:12:50.750
for high levels of violence in prehistory

00:12:50.750 --> 00:12:53.356
is very debatable.

00:12:53.356 --> 00:12:55.557
But that's just an example.

00:12:55.557 --> 00:12:59.161
Certainly, you know, lots of people say to me,

00:12:59.161 --> 00:13:01.701
just because we lived a certain way in the past

00:13:01.701 --> 00:13:04.900
doesn't mean we should live that 
way now, and I agree with that.

00:13:04.900 --> 00:13:07.427
Everyone has to respond to the modern world.

00:13:07.427 --> 00:13:11.849
But the body does have its inherent

00:13:11.849 --> 00:13:14.706
evolved trajectories.

00:13:14.706 --> 00:13:18.186
And so you could live on
McDonald's and milkshakes,

00:13:18.186 --> 00:13:21.642
but your body will rebel against 
that. We have appetites.

00:13:21.660 --> 00:13:23.348
I think it was Schopenhauer who said,

00:13:23.348 --> 00:13:26.212
a person can do what they want

00:13:26.212 --> 00:13:28.269
but not want what they want.

00:13:28.269 --> 00:13:29.992
And so what I'm arguing against

00:13:29.992 --> 00:13:32.456
is the shame that's associated with desires.

00:13:32.456 --> 00:13:35.815
It's the idea that if you love your husband or wife

00:13:35.815 --> 00:13:38.025
but you still are attracted to other people,

00:13:38.025 --> 00:13:39.524
there's something wrong with you,

00:13:39.524 --> 00:13:41.461
there's something wrong with your marriage,

00:13:41.461 --> 00:13:42.921
something wrong with your partner.

00:13:42.921 --> 00:13:44.944
I think a lot of families are fractured

00:13:44.944 --> 00:13:46.929
by unrealistic expectations

00:13:46.929 --> 00:13:49.974
that are based upon this false

I'd clench my jaw a little tighter, hold my coffee pot with a little more vengeance. The dad would awkwardly shuffle his newspaper and the mom would shoot a chilling stare at her kid. But I would say nothing, and I would seethe inside. And it got to the point where every time I walked up to a table that had a kid anywhere between three and 10 years old, I was ready to fight. I would have that hard conversation.So within a matter of weeks, it happens again."Are you a boy or are you a girl?"Familiar silence, but this time I'm ready, and I am about to go all Women's Studies 101 on this table. (Laughter) I've got my Betty Friedan quotes. I've got my Gloria Steinem quotes. I've even got this little bit from "Vagina Monologues" I'm going to do. My hair is short like a boy's, and I wear boy's clothes, but I'm a girl, and you know how sometimes you like to wear a pink dress, and sometimes you like to wear your comfy jammies? title: Can the damaged brain repair itself?
transcript: I'm very pleased to be here today to talk to you all about how we might repair the damaged brain, and I'm particularly excited by this field, because as a neurologist myself, I believe that this offers one of the great ways that we might be able to offer hope for patients who today live with devastating and yet untreatable diseases of the brain.So here's the problem. You can see here the picture of somebody's brain with Alzheimer's disease next to a healthy brain, and what's obvious is, in the Alzheimer's brain, ringed red, there's obvious damage — atrophy, scarring. And I could show you equivalent pictures from other disease: multiple sclerosis, motor neuron disease, Parkinson's disease, even Huntington's disease, and they would all tell a similar story. And collectively these brain disorders represent one of the major public health threats of our time. And the numbers here are really rather staggering. At any one time, there are 35 million people today living with one of these brain diseases, and the annual cost globally is 700 billion dollars. I mean, just think about that. That's greater than one percent of the global GDP. And it gets worse, because all these numbers are rising because these are by and large age-related diseases, and we're living longer. So the question we really need to ask ourselves is, why, given the devastating impact of these diseases to the individual, never mind the scale of the societal problem, why are there no effective treatments?Now in order to consider this, I first need to give you a crash course in how the brain works. So in other words, I need to tell you everything I learned at medical school. (Laughter) But believe me, this isn't going to take very long. Okay? (Laughter) So the brain is terribly simple: it's made up of four cells, and two of them are shown here. There's the nerve cell, and then there's the myelinating cell, or the insulating cell. It's called oligodendrocyte. And when these four cells work together in health and harmony, they create an extraordinary symphony of electrical activity, and it is this electrical activity that underpins our ability to think, to emote, to remember, to learn, move, feel and so on. But equally, each of these individual four cells alone or together, can go rogue or die, and when that happens, you get damage. You get damaged wiring. You get disrupted connections. And that's evident here with the slower conduction. But ultimately, this damage will manifest as disease, clearly. And if the starting dying nerve cell is a motor nerve, for example, you'll get motor neuron disease.So I'd like to give you a real-life illustration of what happens with motor neuron disease. So this is a patient of mine called John. John I saw just last week in the clinic. And I've asked John to tell us something  about what were his problems that led to the initial diagnosis of motor neuron disease.John: I was diagnosed in October in 2011, and the main problem was a breathing problem, difficulty breathing.Siddharthan Chandran: I don't know if you caught all of that, but what John was telling us was that difficulty with breathing led eventually to the diagnosis of motor neuron disease.So John's now 18 months further down in that journey, and I've now asked him to tell us something about his current predicament.John: What I've got now is  the breathing's gotten worse. I've got weakness in my hands,  my arms and my legs. So basically I'm in a wheelchair most of the time.SC: John's just told us he's in a wheelchair most of the time.So what these two clips show is not just the devastating consequence of the disease, but they also tell us something about the shocking pace of the disease, because in just 18 months, a fit adult man has been rendered wheelchair- and respirator-dependent. And let's face it, John could be anybody's father, brother or friend.So that's what happens when the motor nerve dies. But what happens when that myelin cell dies? You get multiple sclerosis. So the scan on your left is an illustration of the brain, and it's a map of the connections of the brain, and superimposed upon which are areas of damage. We call them lesions of demyelination. But they're damage, and they're white.So I know what you're thinking here. You're thinking, "My God, this bloke came up and said he's going to talk about hope, and all he's done is give a really rather bleak and depressing tale." I've told you these diseases are terrible. They're devastating, numbers are rising, the costs are ridiculous, and worst of all, we have no treatment. Where's the hope?Well, you know what? I think there is hope. And there's hope in this next section, of this brain section of somebody else with M.S., because what it illustrates is, amazingly, the brain can repair itself. It just doesn't do it well enough. And so again, there are two things I want to show you. First of all is the damage of this patient with M.S. And again, it's another one of these white masses. But crucially, the area that's ringed red highlights an area that is pale blue. But that area that is pale blue was once white. So it was damaged. It's now repaired. Just to be clear: It's not because of doctors. It's in spite of doctors, not because of doctors. This is spontaneous repair. It's amazing and it's occurred because there are stem cells in the brain, even, which can enable new myelin, new insulation, to be laid down over the damaged nerves. And this observation is important for two reasons. The first is it challenges one of the orthodoxies that we learnt at medical school, or at least I did, admittedly last century, which is that the brain doesn't repair itself, unlike, say, the bone or the liver. But actually it does, but it just doesn't do it well enough. And the second thing it does, and it gives us a very clear direction  of travel for new therapies — I mean, you don't need to be a rocket scientist to know what to do here. You simply need to find ways of promoting the endogenous, spontaneous repair that occurs anyway.So the question is, why, if we've known that for some time, as we have, why do we not have those treatments? And that in part reflects the complexity of drug development. Now, drug development you might think of as a rather expensive but risky bet, and the odds of this bet are roughly this: they're 10,000 to one against, because you need to screen about 10,000 compounds to find that one potential winner. And then you need to spend 15 years and spend over a billion dollars, and even then, you may not have a winner.So the question for us is, can you change the rules of the game and can you shorten the odds? And in order to do that, you have to think, where is the bottleneck in this drug discovery? And one of the bottlenecks is  early in drug discovery. All that screening occurs in animal models. But we know that the proper  study of mankind is man, to borrow from Alexander Pope. So the question is, can we study these diseases using human material? And of course, absolutely we can. We can use stem cells, and specifically we can use human stem cells. And human stem cells are these extraordinary but simple cells that can do two things: they can self-renew or make more of themselves, but they can also become specialized to make bone, liver or, crucially, nerve cells, maybe even the motor nerve cell or the myelin cell. And the challenge has long been, can we harness the power, the undoubted power of these stem cells in order to realize their promise for regenerative neurology?And I think we can now, and the reason we can is because there have been several major discoveries in the last 10, 20 years. One of them was here in Edinburgh, and it must be the only celebrity sheep, Dolly. So Dolly was made in Edinburgh, and Dolly was an example of the first cloning of a mammal from an adult cell. But I think the even more significant breakthrough for the purposes of our discussion today was made in 2006 by a Japanese scientist called Yamanaka. And what Yamaka did, in a fantastic form of scientific cookery, was he showed that four ingredients, just four ingredients, could effectively convert any cell, adult cell, into a master stem cell. And the significance of this is difficult to exaggerate, because what it means that from anybody in this room, but particularly patients, you could now generate a bespoke, personalized tissue repair kit. Take a skin cell, make it a master pluripotent cell, so you could then make those cells that are relevant to their disease, both to study but potentially to treat. Now, the idea of that at medical school — this is a recurring theme, isn't  it, me and medical school? — would have been ridiculous, but it's an absolute reality today. And I see this as the cornerstone of regeneration, repair and hope.And whilst we're on the theme of hope, for those of you who might have failed at school, there's hope for you as well, because this is the school report of John Gerdon. ["I believe he has ideas about becoming a scientist; on his present showing this is quite ridiculous."] So they didn't think much of him then. But what you may not know is that he  got the Nobel Prize for medicine just three months ago.So to return to the original problem, what is the opportunity of these stem cells, or this disruptive technology, for repairing the damaged brain, which we call regenerative neurology? I think there are two ways you can think about this: as a fantastic 21st-century drug discovery tool, and/or as a form of therapy. So I want to tell you a little bit about both of those in the next few moments.Drug discovery in a dish is how people often talk about this. It's very simple: You take a patient with a disease, let's say motor neuron disease, you take a skin sample, you do the pluripotent reprogramming, as I've already told you, and you generate live motor nerve cells. That's straightforward, because that's what pluripotent cells can do. But crucially, you can then compare their behavior to their equivalent but healthy counterparts, ideally from an unaffected relative. That way, you're matching for genetic variation.And that's exactly what we did here. This was a collaboration with colleagues: in London, Chris Shaw; in the U.S.,  Steve Finkbeiner and Tom Maniatis. And what you're looking at, and this is amazing, these are living, growing, motor nerve cells from a patient with motor neuron disease. It happens to be an inherited form. I mean, just imagine that. This would have been unimaginable 10 years ago. So apart from seeing them grow and put out processes, we can also engineer them so that they fluoresce, but crucially, we can then track their individual health and compare the diseased motor nerve cells to the healthy ones. And when you do all that and put it together, you realize that the diseased ones, which is represented in the red line, are two and a half times more likely to die than the healthy counterpart. And the crucial point about this is that you then have a fantastic assay to discover drugs, because what would you ask of the drugs, and you could do this through a high-throughput automated screening system, you'd ask the drugs, give me one thing: find me a drug that will bring the red line closer to the blue line, because that drug will be a high-value candidate that you could probably take direct to human trial and almost bypass that bottleneck that I've told you about in drug discovery with the animal models, if that makes sense. It's fantastic.But I want to come back to how you might use stem cells directly to repair damage. And again there are two ways to think about this, and they're not mutually exclusive. The first, and I think in the long run the one that will give us the biggest dividend, but it's not thought of that way just yet, is to think about those stem cells that are already in your brain, and I've told you that. All of us have stem cells in the brain, even the diseased brain, and surely the smart way forward is to find ways that you can promote and activate those stem cells in your brain already to react and respond appropriately to damage to repair it. That will be the future. There will be drugs that will do that.But the other way is to effectively parachute in cells, transplant them in, to replace dying or lost cells, even in the brain. And I want to tell you now an experiment, it's a clinical trial that we did, which recently completed, which is with colleagues in UCL, David Miller in particular. So this study was very simple. We took patients with multiple sclerosis and asked a simple question: Would stem cells from the bone marrow be protective of their nerves? So what we did was we took this bone marrow, grew up the stem cells in the lab, and then injected them back into the vein. I'm making this sound really simple. It took five years off a lot of people, okay? And it put gray hair on me and caused all kinds of issues. But conceptually, it's essentially simple. So we've given them into the vein, right? So in order to measure whether this was successful or not, we measured the optic nerve as our outcome measure. And that's a good thing to measure in M.S., because patients with M.S. sadly suffer with problems with vision — loss of vision, unclear vision. And so we measured the size of the optic nerve using the scans with David Miller three times — 12 months, six months, and before the infusion — and you can see the gently declining red line. And that's telling you that the optic nerve is shrinking, which makes sense, because their nerves are dying. We then gave the stem cell infusion and repeated the measurement twice — three months and six months — and to our surprise, almost, the line's gone up. That suggests that the intervention has been protective. I don't think myself that what's happened is that those stem cells have made new myelin or new nerves. What I think they've done is they've promoted the endogenous stem cells, or precursor cells, to do their job, wake up, lay down new myelin. So this is a proof of concept. I'm very excited about that.So I just want to end with the theme I began on, which was regeneration and hope. So here I've asked John what his hopes are for the future.John: I would hope that sometime in the future through the research that you people are doing, we can come up with a cure so that people like me can lead a normal life.SC: I mean, that speaks volumes.But I'd like to close by first of all thanking John — thanking John for allowing me to share his insights and these clips with you all. But I'd also like to add to John and to others that my own view is, I'm hopeful for the future. I do believe that the disruptive technologies like stem cells that I've tried to explain to you do offer very real hope. And I do think that the day that we might be able to repair the damaged brain is sooner than we think. Thank you. (Applause)
