about 10,000 compounds

00:07:17.438 --> 00:07:19.509
to find that one potential winner.

00:07:19.509 --> 00:07:21.426
And then you need to spend 15 years

00:07:21.426 --> 00:07:22.924
and spend over a billion dollars,

00:07:22.924 --> 00:07:26.067
and even then, you may not have a winner.

00:07:26.067 --> 00:07:27.746
So the question for us is,

00:07:27.746 --> 00:07:29.337
can you change the rules of the game

00:07:29.337 --> 00:07:31.886
and can you shorten the odds?

00:07:31.886 --> 00:07:33.930
And in order to do that, you have to think,

00:07:33.930 --> 00:07:36.760
where is the bottleneck in this drug discovery?

00:07:36.760 --> 00:07:39.873
And one of the bottlenecks is 
early in drug discovery.

00:07:39.873 --> 00:07:43.835
All that screening occurs in animal models.

00:07:43.835 --> 00:07:47.294
But we know that the proper 
study of mankind is man,

00:07:47.294 --> 00:07:49.398
to borrow from Alexander Pope.

00:07:49.398 --> 00:07:51.769
So the question is, can we study these diseases

00:07:51.769 --> 00:07:54.157
using human material?

00:07:54.157 --> 00:07:56.220
And of course, absolutely we can.

00:07:56.220 --> 00:07:57.749
We can use stem cells,

00:07:57.749 --> 00:08:00.549
and specifically we can use human stem cells.

00:08:00.549 --> 00:08:02.653
And human stem cells are these extraordinary

00:08:02.653 --> 00:08:05.055
but simple cells that can do two things:

00:08:05.055 --> 00:08:07.849
they can self-renew or make more of themselves,

00:08:07.849 --> 00:08:09.907
but they can also become specialized

00:08:09.907 --> 00:08:12.506
to make bone, liver or, crucially, nerve cells,

00:08:12.506 --> 00:08:14.346
maybe even the motor nerve cell

00:08:14.346 --> 00:08:16.506
or the myelin cell.

00:08:16.506 --> 00:08:18.027
And the challenge has long been,

00:08:18.027 --> 00:08:19.999
can we harness the power,

00:08:19.999 --> 00:08:22.284
the undoubted power of these stem cells

00:08:22.284 --> 00:08:24.302
in order to realize their promise

00:08:24.302 --> 00:08:25.929
for regenerative neurology?

00:08:25.929 --> 00:08:28.858
And I think we can now, and the reason we can

00:08:28.858 --> 00:08:31.766
is because there have been
several major discoveries

00:08:31.766 --> 00:08:33.503
in the last 10, 20 years.

00:08:33.503 --> 00:08:35.115
One of them was here in Edinburgh,

00:08:35.115 --> 00:08:39.227
and it must be the only celebrity sheep, Dolly.

00:08:39.227 --> 00:08:40.852
So Dolly was made in Edinburgh,

00:08:40.852 --> 00:08:42.535
and Dolly was an example

00:08:42.535 --> 00:08:45.749
of the first cloning of a mammal

00:08:45.749 --> 00:08:47.697
from an adult cell.

00:08:47.697 --> 00:08:50.502
But I think the even more significant breakthrough

00:08:50.502 --> 00:08:53.424
for the purposes of our discussion today

00:08:53.424 --> 00:08:55.913
was made in 2006 by a Japanese scientist

00:08:55.913 --> 00:08:57.510
called Yamanaka.

00:08:57.510 --> 00:08:58.814
And what Yamaka did,

00:08:58.814 --> 00:09:01.246
in a fantastic form of scientific cookery,

00:09:01.246 --> 00:09:03.284
was he showed that four ingredients,

00:09:03.284 --> 00:09:05.147
just four ingredients,

00:09:05.147 --> 00:09:08.334
could effectively convert any cell, adult cell,

00:09:08.334 --> 00:09:10.576
into a master stem cell.

00:09:10.576 --> 00:09:13.560
And the significance of this is difficult to exaggerate,

00:09:13.560 --> 00:09:15.800
because what it means that
from anybody in this room,

00:09:15.800 --> 00:09:17.604
but particularly patients,

00:09:17.604 --> 00:09:18.935
you could now generate

00:09:18.935 --> 00:09:21.661
a bespoke, personalized tissue repair kit.

00:09:21.661 --> 00:09:24.609
Take a skin cell, make it a master pluripotent cell,

00:09:24.609 --> 00:09:26.348
so you could then make those cells

00:09:26.348 --> 00:09:28.787
that are relevant to their disease,

00:09:28.787 --> 00:09:31.429
both to study but potentially to treat.

00:09:31.429 --> 00:09:33.491
Now, the idea of that at medical school --

00:09:33.491 --> 00:09:36.116
this is a recurring theme, isn't 
it, me and medical school? —

00:09:36.116 --> 00:09:37.934
would have been ridiculous,

00:09:37.934 --> 00:09:39.993
but it's an absolute reality today.

00:09:39.993 --> 00:09:42.127
And I see this as the cornerstone

00:09:42.127 --> 00:09:45.304
of regeneration, repair and hope.

00:09:45.304 --> 00:09:47.254
And whilst we're on the theme of hope,

00:09:47.254 --> 00:09:49.395
for those of you who might have failed at school,

00:09:49.395 --> 00:09:51.620
there's hope for you as well,

00:09:51.620 --> 00:09:54.116
because this is the school report of John Gerdon.

00:09:54.116 --> 00:09:55.328
["I believe he has ideas about becoming a scientist;
on his present showing this is quite ridiculous."]

00:09:55.328 --> 00:09:56.764
So they didn't think much of him then.

00:09:56.764 --> 00:09:59.622
But what you may not know is that he 
got the Nobel Prize for medicine

00:09:59.622 --> 00:10:02.174
just three months ago.

00:10:02.174 --> 00:10:04.740
So to return to the original problem,

00:10:04.740 --> 00:10:06.883
what is the opportunity of these stem cells,

00:10:06.883 --> 00:10:08.544
or this disruptive technology,

00:10:08.544 --> 00:10:10.098
for repairing the damaged brain,

00:10:10.098 --> 00:10:12.229
which we call regenerative neurology?

00:10:12.229 --> 00:10:14.656
I think there are two ways you can think about this:

00:10:14.656 --> 00:10:18.104
as a fantastic 21st-century drug discovery tool,

00:10:18.104 --> 00:10:20.921
and/or as a form of therapy.

00:10:20.921 --> 00:10:22.948
So I want to tell you a little bit about both of those

00:10:22.948 --> 00:10:25.397
in the next few moments.

00:10:25.397 --> 00:10:27.428
Drug discovery in a dish is how people often

00:10:27.428 --> 00:10:28.658
talk about this.

00:10:28.658 --> 00:10:31.585
It's very simple: You take a patient with a disease,

00:10:31.585 --> 00:10:33.404
let's say motor neuron disease,

00:10:33.404 --> 00:10:35.161
you take a skin sample,

00:10:35.161 --> 00:10:38.219
you do the pluripotent reprogramming,

00:10:38.219 --> 00:10:40.310
as I've already told you,

00:10:40.310 --> 00:10:42.827
and you generate live motor nerve cells.

00:10:42.827 --> 00:10:44.561
That's straightforward, because that's what

00:10:44.561 --> 00:10:46.298
pluripotent cells can do.

00:10:46.298 --> 00:10:49.254
But crucially, you can then compare their behavior

00:10:49.254 --> 00:10:51.677
to their equivalent but healthy counterparts,

00:10:51.677 --> 00:10:53.707
ideally from an unaffected relative.

00:10:53.707 --> 00:10:56.949
That way, you're matching for genetic variation.

00:10:56.949 --> 00:10:59.296
And that's exactly what we did here.

00:10:59.296 --> 00:11:01.219
This was a collaboration with colleagues:

00:11:01.219 --> 00:11:04.742
in London, Chris Shaw; in the U.S., 
Steve Finkbeiner and Tom Maniatis.

00:11:04.742 --> 00:11:07.264
And what you're looking at, and this is amazing,

00:11:07.264 --> 00:11:10.064
these are living, growing, motor nerve cells

00:11:10.064 --> 00:11:12.307
from a patient with motor neuron disease.

00:11:12.307 --> 00:11:14.232
It happens to be an inherited form.

00:11:14.232 --> 00:11:15.931
I mean, just imagine that.

00:11:15.931 --> 00:11:18.412
This would have been unimaginable 10 years ago.

00:11:18.412 --> 00:11:21.766
So apart from seeing them
grow and put out processes,

00:11:21.766 --> 00:11:24.208
we can also engineer them so that they fluoresce,

00:11:24.208 --> 00:11:27.267
but crucially, we can then
track their individual health

00:11:27.267 --> 00:11:29.787
and compare the diseased motor nerve cells

00:11:29.787 --> 00:11:31.659
to the healthy ones.

00:11:31.659 --> 00:11:35.146
And when you do all that and put it together,

00:11:35.146 --> 00:11:37.245
you realize that the diseased ones,

00:11:37.245 --> 00:11:39.033
which is represented in the red line,

00:11:39.033 --> 00:11:42.654
are two and a half times more likely to die

00:11:42.654 --> 00:11:45.359
than the healthy counterpart.

00:11:45.359 --> 00:11:48.002
And the crucial point about this is that you then have

00:11:48.002 --> 00:11:51.591
a fantastic assay to discover drugs,

00:11:51.591 --> 00:11:53.500
because what would you ask of the drugs,

00:11:53.500 --> 00:11:55.261
and you could do this through a high-throughput

00:11:55.261 --> 00:11:57.670
automated screening system,

00:11:57.670 --> 00:12:00.116
you'd ask the drugs, give me one thing:

00:12:00.116 --> 00:12:02.941
find me a drug that will bring the red line

00:12:02.941 --> 00:12:04.831
closer to the blue line,

00:12:04.831 --> 00:12:08.050
because that drug will be a high-value candidate

00:12:08.050 --> 00:12:10.950
that you could probably take direct to human trial

00:12:10.950 --> 00:12:13.537
and almost bypass that bottleneck

00:12:13.537 --> 00:12:15.938
that I've told you about in drug discovery

00:12:15.938 --> 00:12:17.751
with the animal models,

00:12:17.751 --> 00:12:20.404
if that makes sense. It's fantastic.

00:12:20.404 --> 00:12:21.968
But I want to come back

00:12:21.968 --> 00:12:24.017
to how you might use stem cells directly

00:12:24.017 --> 00:12:25.792
to repair damage.

00:12:25.792 --> 00:12:27.617
And again there are two ways to think about this,

00:12:27.617 --> 00:12:29.632
and they're not mutually exclusive.

00:12:29.632 --> 00:12:31.922
The first, and I think in the long run

00:12:31.922 --> 00:12:34.151
the one that will give us the biggest dividend,

00:12:34.151 --> 00:12:36.755
but it's not thought of that way just yet,

00:12:36.755 --> 00:12:40.011
is to think about those stem cells that are already

00:12:40.011 --> 00:12:41.851
in your brain, and I've told you that.

00:12:41.851 --> 00:12:43.705
All of us have stem cells in the brain,

00:12:43.705 --> 00:12:45.340
even the diseased brain,

00:12:45.340 --> 00:12:46.958
and surely the smart way forward

00:12:46.958 --> 00:12:49.455
is to find ways that you can promote and activate

00:12:49.455 --> 00:12:51.491
those stem cells in your brain already

00:12:51.491 --> 00:12:54.678
to react and respond appropriately to damage

00:12:54.678 --> 00:12:55.962
to repair it.

00:12:55.962 --> 00:12:57.394
That will be the future.

00:12:57.394 --> 00:13:00.267
There will be drugs that will do that.

00:13:00.267 --> 00:13:04.530
But the other way is to effectively parachute in cells,

00:13:04.530 --> 00:13:06.334
transplant them in,

00:13:06.334 --> 00:13:10.812
to replace dying or lost cells, even in the brain.

00:13:10.812 --> 00:13:12.900
And I want to tell you now an experiment,

00:13:12.900 --> 00:13:14.794
it's a clinical trial that we did,

00:13:14.794 --> 00:13:16.650
which recently completed,

00:13:16.650 --> 00:13:19.167
which is with colleagues in UCL,

00:13:19.167 --> 00:13:21.922
David Miller in particular.

00:13:21.922 --> 00:13:23.835
So this study was very simple.

00:13:23.835 --> 00:13:26.937
We took patients with multiple sclerosis

00:13:26.937 --> 00:13:28.475
and asked a simple question:

00:13:28.475 --> 00:13:30.149
Would stem cells from the bone marrow

00:13:30.149 --> 00:13:31.872
be protective of their nerves?

00:13:31.872 --> 00:13:35.717
So what we did was we took this bone marrow,

00:13:35.717 --> 00:13:37.934
grew up the stem cells in the lab,

00:13:37.934 --> 00:13:40.273
and then injected them back into the vein.

00:13:40.273 --> 00:13:42.073
I'm making this sound really simple.

00:13:42.073 --> 00:13:45.180
It took five years off a lot of people, okay?

00:13:45.180 --> 00:13:46.868
And it put gray hair on me

00:13:46.868 --> 00:13:48.349
and caused all kinds of issues.

00:13:48.349 --> 00:13:52.372
But conceptually, it's essentially simple.

00:13:52.372 --> 00:13:55.679
So we've given them into the vein, right?

00:13:55.679 --> 00:13:59.312
So in order to measure whether
this was successful or not,

00:13:59.312 --> 00:14:01.060
we measured the optic nerve

00:14:01.060 --> 00:14:02.746
as our outcome measure.

00:14:02.746 --> 00:14:04.511
And that's a good thing to measure in M.S.,

00:14:04.511 --> 00:14:06.584
because patients with M.S. sadly suffer

00:14:06.584 --> 00:14:08.056
with problems with vision --

00:14:08.056 --> 00:14:10.246
loss of vision, unclear vision.

00:14:10.246 --> 00:14:12.329
And so we measured the size of the optic nerve

00:14:12.329 --> 00:14:14.383
using the scans with David Miller

00:14:14.383 --> 00:14:16.481
three times -- 12 months, six months,

00:14:16.481 --> 00:14:18.097
and before the infusion --

00:14:18.097 --> 00:14:21.223
and you can see the gently declining red line.

00:14:21.223 --> 00:14:23.451
And that's telling you that
the optic nerve is shrinking,

00:14:23.451 --> 00:14:25.794
which makes sense, because their nerves are dying.

00:14:25.794 --> 00:14:28.100
We then gave the stem cell infusion

00:14:28.100 --> 00:14:30.201
and repeated the measurement twice --

00:14:30.201 --> 00:14:31.840
three months and six months --

00:14:31.840 --> 00:14:33.813
and to our surprise, almost,

00:14:33.813 --> 00:14:35.969
the line's gone up.

00:14:35.969 --> 00:14:38.500
That suggests that the intervention

00:14:38.500 --> 00:14:40.397
has been protective.

00:14:40.397 --> 00:14:42.314
I don't think myself that what's happened

00:14:42.314 --> 00:14:44.350
is that those stem cells have made new myelin

00:14:44.350 --> 00:14:45.814
or new nerves.

00:14:45.814 --> 00:14:47.959
What I think they've done is they've promoted

00:14:47.959 --> 00:14:50.568
the endogenous stem cells, or precursor cells,

00:14:50.568 --> 00:14:54.019
to do their job, wake up, lay down new myelin.

00:14:54.019 --> 00:14:56.318
So this is a proof of concept.

00:14:56.318 --> 00:14:58.943
I'm very excited about that.

00:14:58.943 --> 00:15:01.432
So I just want to end with the theme I began on,

00:15:01.432 --> 00:15:03.422
which was regeneration and hope.

00:15:03.422 --> 00:15:05.192
So here I've asked John

00:15:05.192 --> 00:15:07.490
what his hopes are for the future.

00:15:07.490 --> 00:15:09.244
John: I would hope that

00:15:09.244 --> 00:15:11.044
sometime in the future

00:15:11.044 --> 00:15:13.484
through the research that you people are doing,

00:15:13.484 --> 00:15:15.693
we can come up with a cure

00:15:15.693 --> 00:15:19.517
so that people like me can lead a normal life.

00:15:19.517 --> 00:15:22.112
SC: I mean, that speaks volumes.

00:15:22.112 --> 00:15:24.651
But I'd like to close by first of all thanking John --

00:15:24.651 --> 00:15:26.380
thanking John for allowing me to share

00:15:26.380 --> 00:15:29.550
his insights and these clips with you all.

00:15:29.550 --> 00:15:32.085
But I'd also like to add to John and to others

00:15:32.085 --> 00:15:34.662
that my own view is, I'm hopeful for the future.

00:15:34.662 --> 00:15:37.014
I do believe that the disruptive technologies

00:15:37.014 --> 00:15:39.072
like stem cells that I've tried to explain to you

00:15:39.072 --> 00:15:40.893
do offer very real hope.

00:15:40.893 --> 00:15:42.656
And I do think that the day that we might be able

00:15:42.656 --> 00:15:44.092
to repair the damaged brain

00:15:44.092 --> 00:15:45.381
is sooner than we think.

00:15:45.381 --> 00:15:47.184
Thank you.

00:15:47.184 --> 00:15:51.877
(Applause)

title: Why good hackers make good citizens
transcript: I'm going to talk about hackers. And the image that comes to your mind when I say that word is probably not of Benjamin Franklin, but I'm going to explain to you why it should be.The image that comes to your mind is probably more likely of a pasty kid sitting in a basement doing something mischievous, or of a shady criminal who is trying to steal your identity, or of an international rogue with a political agenda. And mainstream culture has kind of fed this idea that hackers are people that we should be afraid of.But like most things in technology and the technology world, hacking has equal power for good as it has for evil. For every hacker that's trying to steal your identity there's one that's building a tool that will help you find your loved ones after a disaster or to monitor environmental quality after an oil spill. Hacking is really just any amateur innovation on an existing system, and it is a deeply democratic activity. It's about critical thinking. It's about questioning existing ways of doing things. It's the idea that if you see a  problem, you work to fix it, and not just complain about it. And in many ways, hacking is what built America. Betsy Ross was a hacker. The Underground Railroad was a brilliant hack. And from the Wright brothers to Steve Jobs, hacking has always been at the foundation of American democracy.So if there's one thing I want to leave you here with today, it's that the next time you think about who a hacker is, you think not of this guy but of this guy, Benjamin Franklin, who was one of the greatest hackers of all time. He was one of America's most prolific inventors, though he famously never filed a patent, because he thought that all human knowledge should be freely available. He brought us bifocals and the lightning rod, and of course there was his collaboration on the invention of American democracy.And in Code For America, we really try to embody the spirit of Ben Franklin. He was a tinkerer and a statesman whose conception of citizenship was always predicated on action. He believed that government could be built by the people, and we call those people civic hackers.So it's no wonder that the values that underly a healthy democracy, like collaboration and empowerment and participation and enterprise, are the same values that underly the Internet. And so it's no surprise that many hackers are turning their attention to the problem of government.But before I give you a few examples of what civic hacking looks like, I want to make clear that you don't have to be a programmer to be a civic hacker. You just have to believe that you can bring a 21st-century tool set to bear on the problems that government faces. And we hear all the time from our community of civic hackers at Code for America that they didn't understand how much nontechnical work actually went into civic hacking projects. So keep that in mind. All of you are potential civic hackers.So what does civic hacking look like? Our team last year in Honolulu, which in this case was three full-time fellows who were doing a year of public service, were asked by the city to rebuild the website. And it's a massive thing of tens of thousands of pages which just wasn't going to be possible in the few months that they had. So instead, they decided to build a parallel site that better conformed to how citizens actually want to interact with information on a city website. They're looking for answers to questions, and they want to take action when they're done, which is really hard to do from a site that looks like this. So our team built Honolulu Answers, which is a super-simple search interface where you enter a search term or a question and get back plain language answers that drive a user towards action. Now the site itself was easy enough to build, but the team was faced with the challenge of how they populate all of the content. It would have taken the three of them a very long time, especially given that none of  them are actually from Honolulu. And so they did something that's really radical, when you think about how government is used to working. They asked citizens to write the content. So you've heard of a hack-a-thon. They held a write-a-thon, where on one Saturday afternoon — ("What do I do about wild pigs  being a nuisance?") (Laughter) — Wild pigs are a huge problem  in Honolulu, apparently. In one Saturday afternoon, they were able to populate most of the content for most of the frequently asked questions, but more importantly than that, they created a new way for citizens  to participate in their government.Now, I think this is a really cool story in and of itself, but it gets more awesome. On the National Day of Civic Hacking this past June in Oakland, where I live, the Code For America team in Oakland took the open source code base of Honolulu Answers and turned it into Oakland Answers, and again we held a write-a-thon where we took the most frequently asked questions and had citizens write the answers to them, and I got into the act. I authored this answer, and a few others. And I'm trying to this day to articulate the sense of empowerment and responsibility that I feel for the place that I live based simply on this small act of participation. And by stitching together my small act with the thousands of other small acts of participation that we're enabling through civic hacking, we think we can reenergize citizenship and restore trust in government.At this point, you may be wondering what city officials think of all this. They actually love it. As most of you guys know, cities are being asked every day to do more with less, and they're always looking for innovative solutions to entrenched problems. So when you give citizens a way to participate beyond attending a town hall meeting, cities can actually capture the capacity in their communities to do the business of government.Now I don't want to leave the impression that civic hacking is just an American phenomenon. It's happening across the globe, and one of my favorite examples is from Mexico City, where earlier this year, the Mexico House of Representatives entered into a contract with a software development firm to build an app that legislators would use to track bills. So this was just for the handful of legislators in the House. And the contract was a two-year contract for 9.3 million dollars. Now a lot of people were really angry about this, especially geeks who knew that 9.3 million dollars was an absolutely outrageous amount of money for what was a very simple app. But instead of taking to the streets, they issued a challenge. They asked programmers in Mexico to build something better and cheaper, and they offered a prize of 9,300 dollars — 10,000 times cheaper than the government contract, and they gave the entrants 10 days. And in those 10 days, they submitted 173 apps, five of which were presented to Congress and are still in the app store today. And because of this action, that contract was vacated, and now this has sparked a movement in Mexico City which is home to one of our partners, Code for Mexico City.And so what you see in all three of these places, in Honolulu and in Oakland and in Mexico City, are the elements that are at the core of civic hacking. It's citizens who saw things that could be working better and they decided to fix them, and through that work, they're creating a 21st-century ecosystem of participation. They're creating a whole new set of ways for citizens to be involved, besides voting or signing a petition or protesting. They can actually build government.So back to our friend Ben Franklin, who, one of his lesser-known accomplishments was that in 1736 he founded the first volunteer firefighting company in Philadelphia, called a brigade. And it's because he and his friends noticed that the city was having trouble keeping up with all the fires that were happening in the city, so in true civic hacker fashion, they built a solution.And we have our own brigades at Code for America working on the projects that I've just described, and we want to ask you to follow in Ben Franklin's footsteps and come join us. We have 31 brigades in the U.S. We are pleased to announce today that we're opening up the  brigade to international cities for the first time, starting with cities in Poland and Japan and Ireland. You can find out if there's a brigade where you live at brigade.codeforamerica.org, and if there's not a brigade where you live, we will help you. We've created a tool kit which also lives at brigade.codeforamerica.org, and we will support you along the way. Our goal is to create a global network of civic hackers who are innovating on the existing system in order to build tools that will solve entrenched problems, that will support local government, and that will empower citizens.So please come hack with us.Thank you.(Applause)
subtitle:
WEBVTT
X-TIMESTAMP-MAP=MPEGTS:900000,LOCAL:00:00:00.000

00:00:12.243 --> 00:00:14.317
I'm going to talk about hackers.

00:00:14.317 --> 00:00:16.237
And the image that comes to your mind

00:00:16.237 --> 00:00:18.696
when I say that word is probably not

00:00:18.696 --> 00:00:20.213
of Benjamin Franklin,

00:00:20.213 --> 00:00:23.401
but I'm going to explain to you why it should be.

00:00:23.401 --> 00:00:24.878
The image that comes to your mind

00:00:24.878 --> 00:00:27.564
is probably more likely of a pasty kid

00:00:27.564 --> 00:00:30.080
sitting in a basement doing something mischievous,

00:00:30.080 --> 00:00:34.215
or of a shady criminal who is
trying to steal your identity,

00:00:34.215 --> 00:00:37.238
or of an international rogue

00:00:37.238 --> 00:00:39.949
with a political agenda.

00:00:39.949 --> 00:00:44.482
And mainstream culture has kind of fed this idea

00:00:44.482 --> 00:00:48.991
that hackers are people that we should be afraid of.

00:00:48.991 --> 00:00:50.623
But like most things in technology

00:00:50.623 --> 00:00:52.072
and the technology world,

00:00:52.072 --> 00:00:55.247
hacking has equal power for good as it has for evil.

00:00:55.247 --> 00:00:57.681
For every hacker that's trying to steal your identity

00:00:57.681 --> 00:00:59.919
there's one that's building a tool

00:00:59.919 --> 00:01:03.050
that will help you find your
loved ones after a disaster

00:01:03.050 --> 00:01:06.529
or to monitor environmental quality

00:01:06.529 --> 00:01:09.266
after an oil spill.

00:01:09.266 --> 00:01:13.138
Hacking is really just any amateur innovation

00:01:13.138 --> 00:01:14.534
on an existing system,

00:01:14.534 --> 00:01:17.364
and it is a deeply democratic activity.

00:01:17.364 --> 00:01:18.763
It's about critical thinking.

00:01:18.763 --> 00:01:21.797
It's about questioning existing ways of doing things.

00:01:21.797 --> 00:01:25.185
It's the idea that if you see a 
problem, you work to fix it,

00:01:25.185 --> 00:01:27.216
and not just complain about it.

00:01:27.216 --> 00:01:31.126
And in many ways, hacking is what built America.

00:01:31.126 --> 00:01:33.271
Betsy Ross was a hacker.

00:01:33.271 --> 00:01:36.466
The Underground Railroad was a brilliant hack.

00:01:36.466 --> 00:01:39.342
And from the Wright brothers to Steve Jobs,

00:01:39.342 --> 00:01:41.881
hacking has always been at the foundation

00:01:41.881 --> 00:01:44.933
of American democracy.

00:01:44.933 --> 00:01:49.234
So if there's one thing I want
to leave you here with today,

00:01:49.234 --> 00:01:51.805
it's that the next time you
think about who a hacker is,

00:01:51.805 --> 00:01:55.827
you think not of this guy

00:01:55.827 --> 00:01:58.407
but of this guy, Benjamin Franklin,

00:01:58.407 --> 00:02:01.365
who was one of the greatest hackers of all time.

00:02:01.365 --> 00:02:03.506
He was one of America's most prolific inventors,

00:02:03.506 --> 00:02:05.688
though he famously never filed a patent,

00:02:05.688 --> 00:02:07.282
because he thought that all human knowledge

00:02:07.282 --> 00:02:09.910
should be freely available.

00:02:09.910 --> 00:02:12.942
He brought us bifocals and the lightning rod,

00:02:12.942 --> 00:02:15.139
and of course there was his collaboration

00:02:15.139 --> 00:02:18.104
on the invention of American democracy.

00:02:18.104 --> 00:02:20.427
And in Code For America, we really try to embody

00:02:20.427 --> 00:02:22.445
the spirit of Ben Franklin.

00:02:22.445 --> 00:02:25.887
He was a tinkerer and a statesman

00:02:25.887 --> 00:02:27.747
whose conception of citizenship

00:02:27.747 --> 00:02:29.834
was always predicated on action.

00:02:29.834 --> 00:02:32.619
He believed that government could be built

00:02:32.619 --> 00:02:34.259
by the people,

00:02:34.259 --> 00:02:38.808
and we call those people civic hackers.

00:02:38.808 --> 00:02:41.263
So it's no wonder that the values

00:02:41.263 --> 00:02:43.931
that underly a healthy democracy,

00:02:43.931 --> 00:02:46.924
like collaboration and empowerment

00:02:46.924 --> 00:02:48.987
and participation and enterprise,

00:02:48.987 --> 00:02:52.473
are the same values that underly the Internet.

00:02:52.473 --> 00:02:54.569
And so it's no surprise that many hackers

00:02:54.569 --> 00:02:57.926
are turning their attention to
the problem of government.

00:02:57.926 --> 00:02:59.979
But before I give you a few examples

00:02:59.979 --> 00:03:01.801
of what civic hacking looks like,

00:03:01.801 --> 00:03:03.317
I want to make clear that you don't have

00:03:03.317 --> 00:03:05.411
to be a programmer to be a civic hacker.

00:03:05.411 --> 00:03:07.166
You just have to believe that you can bring

00:03:07.166 --> 00:03:09.433
a 21st-century tool set to bear

00:03:09.433 --> 00:03:11.872
on the problems that government faces.

00:03:11.872 --> 00:03:13.917
And we hear all the time from our community

00:03:13.917 --> 00:03:16.205
of civic hackers at Code for America

00:03:16.205 --> 00:03:18.813
that they didn't understand
how much nontechnical work

00:03:18.813 --> 00:03:20.839
actually went into civic hacking projects.

00:03:20.839 --> 00:03:22.330
So keep that in mind.

00:03:22.330 --> 00:03:26.420
All of you are potential civic hackers.

00:03:26.420 --> 00:03:28.440
So what does civic hacking look like?

00:03:28.440 --> 00:03:30.704
Our team last year in Honolulu,

00:03:30.704 --> 00:03:33.319
which in this case was three full-time fellows

00:03:33.319 --> 00:03:35.471
who were doing a year of public service,

00:03:35.471 --> 00:03:39.436
were asked by the city to rebuild the website.

00:03:39.436 --> 00:03:42.515
And it's a massive thing of
tens of thousands of pages

00:03:42.515 --> 00:03:44.631
which just wasn't going to be possible

00:03:44.631 --> 00:03:46.384
in the few months that they had.

00:03:46.384 --> 00:03:48.841
So instead, they decided to build a parallel site

00:03:48.841 --> 00:03:51.303
that better conformed to how citizens actually

00:03:51.303 --> 00:03:54.642
want to interact with information on a city website.

00:03:54.642 --> 00:03:56.579
They're looking for answers to questions,

00:03:56.579 --> 00:03:59.205
and they want to take action when they're done,

00:03:59.205 --> 00:04:01.491
which is really hard to do from a site

00:04:01.491 --> 00:04:03.140
that looks like this.

00:04:03.140 --> 00:04:05.385
So our team built Honolulu Answers,

00:04:05.385 --> 00:04:07.751
which is a super-simple search interface

00:04:07.751 --> 00:04:10.204
where you enter a search term or a question

00:04:10.204 --> 00:04:12.902
and get back plain language answers

00:04:12.902 --> 00:04:15.342
that drive a user towards action.

00:04:15.342 --> 00:04:18.199
Now the site itself was easy enough to build,

00:04:18.199 --> 00:04:20.102
but the team was faced with the challenge

00:04:20.102 --> 00:04:22.812
of how they populate all of the content.

00:04:22.812 --> 00:04:24.488
It would have taken the three of them

00:04:24.488 --> 00:04:25.865
a very long time,

00:04:25.865 --> 00:04:28.864
especially given that none of 
them are actually from Honolulu.

00:04:28.864 --> 00:04:30.939
And so they did something that's really radical,

00:04:30.939 --> 00:04:32.612
when you think about how government

00:04:32.612 --> 00:04:34.653
is used to working.

00:04:34.653 --> 00:04:37.665
They asked citizens to write the content.

00:04:37.665 --> 00:04:39.159
So you've heard of a hack-a-thon.

00:04:39.159 --> 00:04:40.823
They held a write-a-thon,

00:04:40.823 --> 00:04:43.460
where on one Saturday afternoon --

00:04:43.460 --> 00:04:45.501
("What do I do about wild pigs 
being a nuisance?") (Laughter) —

00:04:45.501 --> 00:04:49.547
Wild pigs are a huge problem 
in Honolulu, apparently.

00:04:49.547 --> 00:04:51.590
In one Saturday afternoon,

00:04:51.590 --> 00:04:53.924
they were able to populate most of the content

00:04:53.924 --> 00:04:55.585
for most of the frequently asked questions,

00:04:55.585 --> 00:04:57.818
but more importantly than that,

00:04:57.818 --> 00:05:01.933
they created a new way for citizens 
to participate in their government.

00:05:01.933 --> 00:05:04.978
Now, I think this is a really cool story in and of itself,

00:05:04.978 --> 00:05:07.315
but it gets more awesome.

00:05:07.315 --> 00:05:09.921
On the National Day of Civic Hacking

00:05:09.921 --> 00:05:12.332
this past June in Oakland, where I live,

00:05:12.332 --> 00:05:14.361
the Code For America team in Oakland

00:05:14.361 --> 00:05:16.561
took the open source code base of Honolulu Answers

00:05:16.561 --> 00:05:18.572
and turned it into Oakland Answers,

00:05:18.572 --> 00:05:20.651
and again we held a write-a-thon

00:05:20.651 --> 00:05:23.999
where we took the most frequently asked questions

00:05:23.999 --> 00:05:25.661
and had citizens write the answers to them,

00:05:25.661 --> 00:05:27.130
and I got into the act.

00:05:27.130 --> 00:05:30.731
I authored this answer, and a few others.

00:05:30.731 --> 00:05:33.843
And I'm trying to this day to articulate

00:05:33.843 --> 00:05:36.889
the sense of empowerment and responsibility

00:05:36.889 --> 00:05:40.469
that I feel for the place that I live

00:05:40.469 --> 00:05:44.511
based simply on this small act of participation.

00:05:44.511 --> 00:05:48.236
And by stitching together my small act

00:05:48.236 --> 00:05:51.042
with the thousands of other
small acts of participation

00:05:51.042 --> 00:05:53.623
that we're enabling through civic hacking,

00:05:53.623 --> 00:05:56.407
we think we can reenergize citizenship

00:05:56.407 --> 00:05:59.457
and restore trust in government.

00:05:59.457 --> 00:06:00.794
At this point, you may be wondering

00:06:00.794 --> 00:06:02.520
what city officials think of all this.

00:06:02.520 --> 00:06:04.073
They actually love it.

00:06:04.073 --> 00:06:06.267
As most of you guys know, cities are being asked

00:06:06.267 --> 00:06:08.988
every day to do more with less,

00:06:08.988 --> 00:06:11.186
and they're always looking for innovative solutions

00:06:11.186 --> 00:06:12.920
to entrenched problems.

00:06:12.920 --> 00:06:16.454
So when you give citizens a way to participate

00:06:16.454 --> 00:06:18.292
beyond attending a town hall meeting,

00:06:18.292 --> 00:06:20.244
cities can actually capture

00:06:20.244 --> 00:06:22.998
the capacity in their communities

00:06:22.998 --> 00:06:26.033
to do the business of government.

00:06:26.033 --> 00:06:28.026
Now I don't want to leave the impression

00:06:28.026 --> 00:06:30.138
that civic hacking is just an American phenomenon.

00:06:30.138 --> 00:06:31.841
It's happening across the globe,

00:06:31.841 --> 00:06:33.494
and one of my favorite examples

00:06:33.494 --> 00:06:35.925
is from Mexico City, where earlier this year,

00:06:35.925 --> 00:06:38.035
the Mexico House of Representatives

00:06:38.035 --> 00:06:42.347
entered into a contract with
a software development firm

00:06:42.347 --> 00:06:45.527
to build an app that legislators would use

00:06:45.527 --> 00:06:46.778
to track bills.

00:06:46.778 --> 00:06:49.454
So this was just for the handful of legislators

00:06:49.454 --> 00:06:52.028
in the House.

00:06:52.028 --> 00:06:54.697
And the contract was a two-year contract

00:06:54.697 --> 00:06:58.623
for 9.3 million dollars.

00:06:58.623 --> 00:07:00.975
Now a lot of people were really angry about this,

00:07:00.975 --> 00:07:03.922
especially geeks who knew that 9.3 million dollars

00:07:03.922 --> 00:07:06.226
was an absolutely outrageous amount of money

00:07:06.226 --> 00:07:08.197
for what was a very simple app.

00:07:08.197 --> 00:07:10.626
But instead of taking to the streets,

00:07:10.626 --> 00:07:12.834
they issued a challenge.

00:07:12.834 --> 00:07:15.665
They asked programmers in Mexico

00:07:15.665 --> 00:07:18.868
to build something better and cheaper,

00:07:18.868 --> 00:07:23.319
and they offered a prize of 9,300 dollars --

00:07:23.319 --> 00:07:25.220
10,000 times cheaper

00:07:25.220 --> 00:07:26.868
than the government contract,

00:07:26.868 --> 00:07:29.971
and they gave the entrants 10 days.

00:07:29.971 --> 00:07:31.783
And in those 10 days,

00:07:31.783 --> 00:07:35.844
they submitted 173 apps,

00:07:35.844 --> 00:07:38.478
five of which were presented to Congress

00:07:38.478 --> 00:07:40.579
and are still in the app store today.

00:07:40.579 --> 00:07:42.400
And because of this action,

00:07:42.400 --> 00:07:44.528
that contract was vacated,

00:07:44.528 --> 00:07:46.660
and now this has sparked a movement in Mexico City

00:07:46.660 --> 00:07:48.417
which is home to one of our partners,

00:07:48.417 --> 00:07:50.875
Code for Mexico City.

00:07:50.875 --> 00:07:53.626
And so what you see in all three of these places,

00:07:53.626 --> 00:07:56.443
in Honolulu and in Oakland and in Mexico City,

00:07:56.443 --> 00:07:59.634
are the elements that are
at the core of civic hacking.

00:07:59.634 --> 00:08:02.657
It's citizens who saw things
that could be working better

00:08:02.657 --> 00:08:04.588
and they decided to fix them,

00:08:04.588 --> 00:08:06.247
and through that work, they're creating

00:08:06.247 --> 00:08:09.438
a 21st-century ecosystem of participation.

00:08:09.438 --> 00:08:11.468
They're creating a whole new set of ways

00:08:11.468 --> 00:08:13.474
for citizens to be involved,

00:08:13.474 --> 00:08:17.419
besides voting or signing a petition or protesting.

00:08:17.419 --> 00:08:21.396
They can actually build government.

00:08:21.396 --> 00:08:24.532
So back to our friend Ben Franklin,

00:08:24.532 --> 00:08:27.278
who, one of his lesser-known accomplishments

00:08:27.278 --> 00:08:31.153
was that in 1736 he founded

00:08:31.153 --> 00:08:34.711
the first volunteer firefighting
company in Philadelphia,

00:08:34.711 --> 00:08:36.410
called a brigade.

00:08:36.410 --> 00:08:38.636
And it's because he and his friends noticed

00:08:38.636 --> 00:08:40.335
that the city was having trouble keeping up

00:08:40.335 --> 00:08:42.405
with all the fires that were happening in the city,

00:08:42.405 --> 00:08:45.194
so in true civic hacker fashion,

00:08:45.194 --> 00:08:47.844
they built a solution.

00:08:47.844 --> 00:08:50.354
And we have our own brigades at Code for America

00:08:50.354 --> 00:08:53.500
working on the projects that I've just described,

00:08:53.500 --> 00:08:55.238
and we want to ask you

00:08:55.238 --> 00:08:57.700
to follow in Ben Franklin's footsteps

00:08:57.700 --> 00:08:59.167
and come join us.

00:08:59.167 --> 00:09:01.457
We have 31 brigades in the U.S.

00:09:01.457 --> 00:09:02.725
We are pleased to announce today

00:09:02.725 --> 00:09:05.001
that we're opening up the 
brigade to international cities

00:09:05.001 --> 00:09:06.593
for the first time,

00:09:06.593 --> 00:09:10.574
starting with cities in Poland and Japan and Ireland.

00:09:10.574 --> 00:09:12.673
You can find out if there's a brigade where you live

00:09:12.673 --> 00:09:15.167
at brigade.codeforamerica.org,

00:09:15.167 --> 00:09:17.606
and if there's not a brigade
where you live, we will help you.

00:09:17.606 --> 00:09:19.462
We've created a tool kit which also lives

00:09:19.462 --> 00:09:21.026
at brigade.codeforamerica.org,

00:09:21.026 --> 00:09:23.566
and we will support you along the way.

00:09:23.566 --> 00:09:27.481
Our goal is to create a global
network of civic hackers

00:09:27.481 --> 00:09:30.234
who are innovating on the existing system

00:09:30.234 --> 00:09:33.194
in order to build tools that will solve

00:09:33.194 --> 00:09:35.060
entrenched problems,

00:09:35.060 --> 00:09:37.087
that will support local government,

00:09:37.087 --> 00:09:38.646
and that will empower citizens.

00:09:38.646 --> 00:09:41.021
So please come hack with us.

00:09:41.021 --> 00:09:42.569
Thank you.

00:09:42.569 --> 00:09:45.119
(Applause)

title: We need money for aid. So let’s print it.
transcript: Thirteen years ago, we set ourselves a goal to end poverty. After some success, we've hit a big hurdle. The aftermath of the financial crisis has begun to hit aid payments, which have fallen for two consecutive years. My question is whether the lessons learned from saving the financial system can be used to help us overcome that hurdle and help millions. Can we simply print money for aid?"Surely not." It's a common reaction. (Laughter) It's a quick talk. Others channel John McEnroe. "You cannot be serious!"Now, I can't do the accent, but I am serious, thanks to these two children, who, as you'll learn, are very much at the heart of my talk. On the left, we have Pia. She lives in England. She has two loving parents, one of whom is standing right here. Dorothy, on the right, lives in rural Kenya. She's one of 13,000 orphans and vulnerable children who are assisted by a charity that I support. I do that because I believe that Dorothy, like Pia, deserves the best life chances that we can afford to give her. You'll all agree with me, I'm sure. The U.N. agrees too. Their overriding aim for international aid is to strive for a life of dignity for all.But — and here's that hurdle — can we afford our aid aspirations? History suggests not. In 1970, governments set themselves a target to increase overseas aid payments to 0.7 percent of their national income. As you can see, a big gap opens up between actual aid and that target. But then come the Millennium Development Goals, eight ambitious targets to be met by 2015. If I tell you that just one of those targets is to eradicate extreme hunger and poverty, you get a sense of the ambition. There's also been some success. The number of people living on less than $1.25 a day has halved. But a lot remains to be done in two years. One in eight remain hungry. In the context of this auditorium, the front two rows aren't going to get any food. We can't settle for that, which is why the concern about the eighth goal, which relates to funding, which I said at the beginning is falling, is so troubling.So what can be done? Well, I work in financial markets, not development. I study the behavior of investors, how they react to policy and the economy. It gives me a different angle on the aid issue. But it took an innocent question from my then-four-year-old daughter to make me appreciate that.Pia and I were on the way to a local cafe and we passed a man collecting for charity. I didn't have any change to give him, and she was disappointed. Once in the cafe, Pia takes out her coloring book and starts scribbling. After a little while, I ask her what she's doing, and she shows me a drawing of a £5 note to give to the man outside. It's so sweet, and more generous than Dad would have been. But of course I explained to her, "You can't do that; it's not allowed." To which I get the classic four-year-old response: "Why not?" Now I'm excited, because I actually think I can answer this time. So I launch into an explanation of how an unlimited supply of money chasing a limited number of goods sends prices to the moon.Something about that exchange stuck with me, not because of the look of relief on Pia's face when I finally finished, but because it related to the sanctity of the money supply, a sanctity that had been challenged and questioned by the reaction of central banks to the financial crisis. To reassure investors, central banks began buying assets to try and encourage investors to do the same. They funded these purchases with money they created themselves. The money wasn't actually physically printed. It's still sort of locked away in the banking system today. But the amount created was unprecedented. Together, the central banks of the U.S., U.K and Japan increased the stock of money in their economies by 3.7 trillion dollars. That's three times, in fact that's more than three times, the total physical stock of dollar notes in circulation. Three times!Before the crisis, this would have been utterly unthinkable, yet it was accepted remarkably quickly. The price of gold, an asset thought to protect against inflation, did jump, but investors bought other assets that offered little protection from inflation. They bought fixed income securities, bonds. They bought equities too. For all the scare stories, the actual actions of investors spoke of rapid acceptance and confidence.That confidence was based on two pillars. The first was that, after years of keeping inflation under control, central banks were trusted to take the money-printing away if inflation became a threat. Secondly, inflation simply never became a threat. As you can see, in the United States, inflation for most of this period remained below average. It was the same elsewhere.So how does all this relate to aid? Well, this is where Dorothy and the Mango Tree charity that supports her comes in. I was at one of their fundraising events earlier this year, and I was inspired to give a one-off donation when I remembered that my firm offers to match the charitable contributions its employees make. So think of this: Instead of just being able to help Dorothy and four of her classmates to go through secondary school for a few years, I was able to double my contribution. Brilliant.So following that conversation with my daughter, and seeing the absence of inflation in the face of money-printing, and knowing that international aid payments were falling at just the wrong time, this made me wonder: Could we match but just on a much grander scale? Let's call this scheme "Print Aid." And here's how it might work. Provided it saw little inflation risk from doing so, the central bank would be mandated to match the government's overseas aid payments up to a certain limit. Governments have been aiming to get aid to 0.7 percent for years, so let's set the limit at half of that, 0.35 percent of their income. So it would work like this: If in a given year the government gave 0.2 percent of its income to overseas aid, the central bank would simply top it up with a further 0.2 percent. So far so good.How risky is this? Well, this involves the creation of money to buy goods, not assets. It sounds more inflationary already, doesn't it. But there are two important mitigating factors here. The first is that by definition, this money printed would be spent overseas. So it's not obvious how it leads to inflation in the country doing the actual printing unless it leads to a currency depreciation of that country. That is unlikely for the second reason: the scale of the money that would be printed under this scheme. So let's think of an example where Print Aid was in place in the U.S., U.K. and Japan. To match the aid payments made by those governments over the last four years, Print Aid would have generated 200 billion dollars' worth of extra aid. What would that look like in the context of the increase in the money stock that had already happened in those countries to save the financial system? Are you read for this? You might struggle to see that at the back, because the gap is quite small. So what we're saying here is that we took a $3.7 trillion gamble to save our financial systems, and you know what, it paid off. There was no inflation. Are we really saying that it's not worth the risk to print an extra 200 billion for aid? Would the risks really be that different? To me, it's not that clear. What is clear is the impact on aid. Even though this is the printing of just three central banks, the global aid that's given over this period is up by almost 40 percent. Aid as a proportion of national income all of a sudden is at a 40-year high. Now, we don't get to 0.7 percent. Governments are still incentivized to give. But you know what, that's the  point of a matching scheme.So I think what we've learned is that the risks from this money creation scheme are quite modest, but the benefits are potentially huge. Imagine what we could do with 40 percent more funding. We might be able to feed the front row.The thing that I fear, the only thing that I fear, apart from the fact that I've run out of time, is that the window of opportunity for this idea is a short one. Today, money creation by central banks is an accepted policy tool. That may not always be the case. Today there are universally agreed aims for international aid. That may not always be the case. Today might be the only time that these two things coincide, such that we can afford the aid that we've always aspired to give.So, can we print money for international aid? I seriously believe the question should be, why not?Thank you very much.(Applause)
subtitle:
WEBVTT
X-TIMESTAMP-MAP=MPEGTS:900000,LOCAL:00:00:00.000

00:00:12.861 --> 00:00:15.027
Thirteen years ago,

00:00:15.027 --> 00:00:21.408
we set ourselves a goal to end poverty.

00:00:21.408 --> 00:00:24.027
After some success,

00:00:24.027 --> 00:00:27.081
we've hit a big hurdle.

00:00:27.081 --> 00:00:29.602
The aftermath of the financial crisis

00:00:29.602 --> 00:00:32.327
has begun to hit aid payments,

00:00:32.327 --> 00:00:37.091
which have fallen for two consecutive years.

00:00:37.091 --> 00:00:41.070
My question is whether the lessons learned

00:00:41.070 --> 00:00:44.990
from saving the financial system

00:00:44.990 --> 00:00:48.472
can be used to help us overcome that hurdle

00:00:48.472 --> 00:00:51.677
and help millions.

00:00:51.677 --> 00:00:58.587
Can we simply print money for aid?

00:00:58.587 --> 00:01:00.094
"Surely not."

00:01:00.094 --> 00:01:02.103
It's a common reaction.

00:01:02.103 --> 00:01:03.125
(Laughter)

00:01:03.125 --> 00:01:05.635
It's a quick talk.

00:01:05.635 --> 00:01:10.412
Others channel John McEnroe.

00:01:10.412 --> 00:01:12.384
"You cannot be serious!"

00:01:12.384 --> 00:01:17.315
Now, I can't do the accent, but I am serious,

00:01:17.315 --> 00:01:21.315
thanks to these two children,

00:01:21.315 --> 00:01:24.995
who, as you'll learn, are very much at the heart

00:01:24.995 --> 00:01:27.487
of my talk.

00:01:27.487 --> 00:01:30.453
On the left, we have Pia.

00:01:30.453 --> 00:01:32.043
She lives in England.

00:01:32.043 --> 00:01:35.187
She has two loving parents,

00:01:35.187 --> 00:01:40.087
one of whom is standing right here.

00:01:40.087 --> 00:01:42.479
Dorothy, on the right,

00:01:42.479 --> 00:01:45.378
lives in rural Kenya.

00:01:45.378 --> 00:01:48.017
She's one of 13,000 orphans

00:01:48.017 --> 00:01:49.522
and vulnerable children

00:01:49.522 --> 00:01:54.870
who are assisted by a charity that I support.

00:01:54.870 --> 00:01:57.650
I do that because I believe

00:01:57.650 --> 00:01:59.971
that Dorothy, like Pia,

00:01:59.971 --> 00:02:03.309
deserves the best life chances

00:02:03.309 --> 00:02:05.873
that we can afford to give her.

00:02:05.873 --> 00:02:08.912
You'll all agree with me, I'm sure.

00:02:08.912 --> 00:02:11.522
The U.N. agrees too.

00:02:11.522 --> 00:02:13.574
Their overriding aim

00:02:13.574 --> 00:02:15.650
for international aid

00:02:15.650 --> 00:02:21.788
is to strive for a life of dignity for all.

00:02:21.792 --> 00:02:26.312
But -- and here's that hurdle --

00:02:26.312 --> 00:02:30.862
can we afford our aid aspirations?

00:02:30.862 --> 00:02:34.155
History suggests not.

00:02:34.155 --> 00:02:39.477
In 1970, governments set themselves a target

00:02:39.477 --> 00:02:41.972
to increase overseas aid payments

00:02:41.972 --> 00:02:44.241
to 0.7 percent

00:02:44.241 --> 00:02:45.880
of their national income.

00:02:45.880 --> 00:02:50.157
As you can see, a big gap opens up

00:02:50.157 --> 00:02:54.751
between actual aid and that target.

00:02:54.751 --> 00:02:59.014
But then come the Millennium Development Goals,

00:02:59.014 --> 00:03:01.423
eight ambitious targets

00:03:01.423 --> 00:03:05.331
to be met by 2015.

00:03:05.331 --> 00:03:08.326
If I tell you that just one of those targets

00:03:08.326 --> 00:03:12.509
is to eradicate extreme hunger and poverty,

00:03:12.509 --> 00:03:15.327
you get a sense of the ambition.

00:03:15.327 --> 00:03:18.932
There's also been some success.

00:03:18.932 --> 00:03:20.241
The number of people living

00:03:20.241 --> 00:03:26.217
on less than $1.25 a day has halved.

00:03:26.217 --> 00:03:29.944
But a lot remains to be done in two years.

00:03:29.944 --> 00:03:33.635
One in eight remain hungry.

00:03:33.635 --> 00:03:36.246
In the context of this auditorium,

00:03:36.246 --> 00:03:40.694
the front two rows aren't going to get any food.

00:03:40.694 --> 00:03:42.852
We can't settle for that,

00:03:42.852 --> 00:03:47.356
which is why the concern about the eighth goal,

00:03:47.356 --> 00:03:49.176
which relates to funding,

00:03:49.176 --> 00:03:52.090
which I said at the beginning is falling,

00:03:52.090 --> 00:03:56.550
is so troubling.

00:03:56.550 --> 00:03:58.604
So what can be done?

00:03:58.604 --> 00:04:01.596
Well, I work in financial markets,

00:04:01.596 --> 00:04:04.047
not development.

00:04:04.047 --> 00:04:07.084
I study the behavior of investors,

00:04:07.084 --> 00:04:12.670
how they react to policy and the economy.

00:04:12.670 --> 00:04:17.303
It gives me a different angle on the aid issue.

00:04:17.303 --> 00:04:19.824
But it took an innocent question

00:04:19.824 --> 00:04:22.459
from my then-four-year-old daughter

00:04:22.459 --> 00:04:26.518
to make me appreciate that.

00:04:26.518 --> 00:04:29.713
Pia and I were on the way to a local cafe

00:04:29.713 --> 00:04:34.129
and we passed a man collecting for charity.

00:04:34.129 --> 00:04:35.680
I didn't have any change to give him,

00:04:35.680 --> 00:04:38.181
and she was disappointed.

00:04:38.181 --> 00:04:41.959
Once in the cafe, Pia takes out her coloring book

00:04:41.959 --> 00:04:43.701
and starts scribbling.

00:04:43.701 --> 00:04:47.725
After a little while, I ask her what she's doing,

00:04:47.725 --> 00:04:50.261
and she shows me a drawing

00:04:50.261 --> 00:04:52.473
of a £5 note

00:04:52.473 --> 00:04:54.516
to give to the man outside.

00:04:54.516 --> 00:04:55.769
It's so sweet,

00:04:55.769 --> 00:04:58.869
and more generous than Dad would have been.

00:04:58.869 --> 00:05:00.795
But of course I explained to her,

00:05:00.795 --> 00:05:03.298
"You can't do that; it's not allowed."

00:05:03.298 --> 00:05:07.992
To which I get the classic four-year-old response:

00:05:07.992 --> 00:05:10.540
"Why not?"

00:05:10.540 --> 00:05:12.954
Now I'm excited, because I actually think

00:05:12.954 --> 00:05:14.795
I can answer this time.

00:05:14.795 --> 00:05:17.710
So I launch into an explanation of how

00:05:17.710 --> 00:05:21.025
an unlimited supply of money

00:05:21.025 --> 00:05:24.204
chasing a limited number of goods

00:05:24.204 --> 00:05:29.138
sends prices to the moon.

00:05:30.994 --> 00:05:35.313
Something about that exchange stuck with me,

00:05:35.313 --> 00:05:37.416
not because of the look of relief

00:05:37.416 --> 00:05:39.679
on Pia's face when I finally finished,

00:05:39.679 --> 00:05:44.469
but because it related

00:05:44.469 --> 00:05:49.370
to the sanctity of the money supply,

00:05:49.370 --> 00:05:53.672
a sanctity that had been challenged and questioned

00:05:53.672 --> 00:05:56.591
by the reaction of central banks

00:05:56.591 --> 00:05:59.067
to the financial crisis.

00:05:59.067 --> 00:06:01.634
To reassure investors,

00:06:01.634 --> 00:06:06.531
central banks began buying assets

00:06:06.531 --> 00:06:11.567
to try and encourage investors to do the same.

00:06:11.567 --> 00:06:15.165
They funded these purchases

00:06:15.165 --> 00:06:18.714
with money they created themselves.

00:06:18.714 --> 00:06:22.000
The money wasn't actually physically printed.

00:06:22.000 --> 00:06:25.614
It's still sort of locked away
in the banking system today.

00:06:25.614 --> 00:06:30.815
But the amount created was unprecedented.

00:06:30.815 --> 00:06:34.320
Together, the central banks of the U.S.,

00:06:34.320 --> 00:06:36.190
U.K and Japan

00:06:36.190 --> 00:06:39.580
increased the stock of money in their economies

00:06:39.580 --> 00:06:43.608
by 3.7 trillion dollars.

00:06:43.608 --> 00:06:47.063
That's three times, in fact
that's more than three times,

00:06:47.063 --> 00:06:51.875
the total physical stock of dollar notes in circulation.

00:06:51.875 --> 00:06:56.123
Three times!

00:06:56.123 --> 00:06:58.033
Before the crisis,

00:06:58.033 --> 00:07:02.981
this would have been utterly unthinkable,

00:07:02.981 --> 00:07:10.445
yet it was accepted remarkably quickly.

00:07:10.445 --> 00:07:12.472
The price of gold,

00:07:12.472 --> 00:07:15.220
an asset thought to protect against inflation,

00:07:15.220 --> 00:07:18.046
did jump,

00:07:18.046 --> 00:07:20.844
but investors bought other assets

00:07:20.844 --> 00:07:23.475
that offered little protection from inflation.

00:07:23.475 --> 00:07:27.019
They bought fixed income securities, bonds.

00:07:27.019 --> 00:07:29.786
They bought equities too.

00:07:29.786 --> 00:07:32.445
For all the scare stories,

00:07:32.445 --> 00:07:35.474
the actual actions of investors

00:07:35.474 --> 00:07:41.999
spoke of rapid acceptance and confidence.

00:07:41.999 --> 00:07:47.674
That confidence was based on two pillars.

00:07:47.674 --> 00:07:50.139
The first was that, after years

00:07:50.139 --> 00:07:53.395
of keeping inflation under control,

00:07:53.395 --> 00:07:56.202
central banks were trusted

00:07:56.202 --> 00:07:59.489
to take the money-printing away

00:07:59.489 --> 00:08:03.110
if inflation became a threat.

00:08:03.110 --> 00:08:09.339
Secondly, inflation simply never became a threat.

00:08:09.339 --> 00:08:11.207
As you can see, in the United States,

00:08:11.207 --> 00:08:13.248
inflation for most of this period

00:08:13.248 --> 00:08:16.705
remained below average.

00:08:16.705 --> 00:08:19.977
It was the same elsewhere.

00:08:19.977 --> 00:08:23.394
So how does all this relate to aid?

00:08:23.394 --> 00:08:27.269
Well, this is where Dorothy

00:08:27.269 --> 00:08:29.735
and the Mango Tree charity

00:08:29.735 --> 00:08:32.293
that supports her comes in.

00:08:32.293 --> 00:08:34.390
I was at one of their fundraising events

00:08:34.390 --> 00:08:35.610
earlier this year,

00:08:35.610 --> 00:08:39.359
and I was inspired to give a one-off donation

00:08:39.359 --> 00:08:42.197
when I remembered that my firm

00:08:42.197 --> 00:08:45.456
offers to match the charitable contributions

00:08:45.456 --> 00:08:48.199
its employees make.

00:08:48.199 --> 00:08:50.925
So think of this:

00:08:50.925 --> 00:08:53.212
Instead of just being able to help Dorothy

00:08:53.212 --> 00:08:55.918
and four of her classmates

00:08:55.918 --> 00:08:58.198
to go through secondary school for a few years,

00:08:58.198 --> 00:09:02.502
I was able to double my contribution.

00:09:02.502 --> 00:09:04.915
Brilliant.

00:09:04.915 --> 00:09:10.878
So following that conversation with my daughter,

00:09:10.878 --> 00:09:13.515
and seeing the absence of inflation

00:09:13.515 --> 00:09:15.462
in the face of money-printing,

00:09:15.462 --> 00:09:18.549
and knowing that international aid payments

00:09:18.549 --> 00:09:21.861
were falling at just the wrong time,

00:09:21.861 --> 00:09:25.822
this made me wonder:

00:09:25.822 --> 00:09:27.917
Could we match

00:09:27.917 --> 00:09:33.967
but just on a much grander scale?

00:09:33.967 --> 00:09:38.420
Let's call this scheme "Print Aid."

00:09:38.420 --> 00:09:41.078
And here's how it might work.

00:09:41.078 --> 00:09:46.235
Provided it saw little inflation risk from doing so,

00:09:46.235 --> 00:09:48.545
the central bank would be mandated

00:09:48.545 --> 00:09:51.938
to match the government's overseas aid payments

00:09:51.938 --> 00:09:54.405
up to a certain limit.

00:09:54.405 --> 00:09:56.478
Governments have been aiming to get aid

00:09:56.478 --> 00:09:58.196
to 0.7 percent for years,

00:09:58.196 --> 00:10:01.081
so let's set the limit at half of that,

00:10:01.081 --> 00:10:05.190
0.35 percent of their income.

00:10:05.190 --> 00:10:07.262
So it would work like this: If in a given year

00:10:07.262 --> 00:10:09.948
the government gave 0.2 percent of its income

00:10:09.948 --> 00:10:11.080
to overseas aid,

00:10:11.080 --> 00:10:12.563
the central bank would simply top it up

00:10:12.563 --> 00:10:15.739
with a further 0.2 percent.

00:10:15.739 --> 00:10:19.340
So far so good.

00:10:19.340 --> 00:10:22.020
How risky is this?

00:10:22.020 --> 00:10:26.262
Well, this involves the creation of money

00:10:26.262 --> 00:10:29.070
to buy goods, not assets.

00:10:29.070 --> 00:10:32.623
It sounds more inflationary already, doesn't it.

00:10:32.623 --> 00:10:37.051
But there are two important mitigating factors here.

00:10:37.051 --> 00:10:40.594
The first is that by definition,

00:10:40.594 --> 00:10:45.744
this money printed would be spent overseas.

00:10:45.744 --> 00:10:49.285
So it's not obvious how it leads to inflation

00:10:49.285 --> 00:10:53.694
in the country doing the actual printing

00:10:53.694 --> 00:10:58.628
unless it leads to a currency
depreciation of that country.

00:10:58.628 --> 00:11:01.921
That is unlikely for the second reason:

00:11:01.921 --> 00:11:04.802
the scale of the money that would be printed

00:11:04.802 --> 00:11:07.622
under this scheme.

00:11:07.622 --> 00:11:10.762
So let's think of an example

00:11:10.762 --> 00:11:14.305
where Print Aid was in place

00:11:14.305 --> 00:11:18.647
in the U.S., U.K. and Japan.

00:11:18.647 --> 00:11:20.950
To match the aid payments made

00:11:20.950 --> 00:11:23.686
by those governments over the last four years,

00:11:23.686 --> 00:11:25.913
Print Aid would have generated

00:11:25.913 --> 00:11:30.248
200 billion dollars' worth of extra aid.

00:11:30.248 --> 00:11:32.435
What would that look like

00:11:32.435 --> 00:11:36.037
in the context of the increase in the money stock

00:11:36.037 --> 00:11:38.313
that had already happened in those countries

00:11:38.313 --> 00:11:40.394
to save the financial system?

00:11:40.394 --> 00:11:43.551
Are you read for this?

00:11:43.551 --> 00:11:45.635
You might struggle to see that at the back,

00:11:45.635 --> 00:11:49.205
because the gap is quite small.

00:11:49.205 --> 00:11:51.653
So what we're saying here

00:11:51.653 --> 00:11:55.121
is that we took a $3.7 trillion gamble

00:11:55.121 --> 00:11:57.497
to save our financial systems,

00:11:57.497 --> 00:11:59.552
and you know what, it paid off.

00:11:59.552 --> 00:12:02.125
There was no inflation.

00:12:02.125 --> 00:12:05.431
Are we really saying that it's not worth the risk

00:12:05.431 --> 00:12:10.083
to print an extra 200 billion for aid?

00:12:10.083 --> 00:12:11.992
Would the risks really be that different?

00:12:11.992 --> 00:12:14.535
To me, it's not that clear.

00:12:14.535 --> 00:12:17.893
What is clear is the impact on aid.

00:12:17.893 --> 00:12:20.009
Even though this is the printing

00:12:20.009 --> 00:12:21.845
of just three central banks,

00:12:21.845 --> 00:12:25.466
the global aid that's given

00:12:25.466 --> 00:12:30.387
over this period is up by almost 40 percent.

00:12:30.387 --> 00:12:32.818
Aid as a proportion of national income

00:12:32.818 --> 00:12:36.268
all of a sudden is at a 40-year high.

00:12:36.268 --> 00:12:39.255
Now, we don't get to 0.7 percent.

00:12:39.255 --> 00:12:42.000
Governments are still incentivized to give.

00:12:42.000 --> 00:12:46.493
But you know what, that's the 
point of a matching scheme.

00:12:46.493 --> 00:12:50.308
So I think what we've learned

00:12:50.308 --> 00:12:54.902
is that the risks from this money creation scheme

00:12:54.902 --> 00:12:57.683
are quite modest,

00:12:57.683 --> 00:13:00.483
but the benefits

00:13:00.483 --> 00:13:02.949
are potentially huge.

00:13:02.949 --> 00:13:06.252
Imagine what we could do
with 40 percent more funding.

00:13:06.252 --> 00:13:11.223
We might be able to feed the front row.

00:13:11.223 --> 00:13:13.921
The thing that I fear, the only thing that I fear,

00:13:13.921 --> 00:13:15.645
apart from the fact that I've run out of time,

00:13:15.645 --> 00:13:20.362
is that the window of opportunity for this idea

00:13:20.362 --> 00:13:23.195
is a short one.

00:13:23.195 --> 00:13:27.020
Today, money creation by central banks

00:13:27.020 --> 00:13:29.934
is an accepted policy tool.

00:13:29.934 --> 00:13:32.415
That may not always be the case.

00:13:32.415 --> 00:13:36.778
Today there are universally agreed aims

00:13:36.778 --> 00:13:38.669
for international aid.

00:13:38.669 --> 00:13:42.289
That may not always be the case.

00:13:42.289 --> 00:13:44.927
Today might be the only time

00:13:44.927 --> 00:13:47.810
that these two things coincide,

00:13:47.810 --> 00:13:51.785
such that we can afford the aid

00:13:51.785 --> 00:13:55.428
that we've always aspired to give.

00:13:55.428 --> 00:14:03.858
So, can we print money for international aid?

00:14:03.858 --> 00:14:07.596
I seriously believe the question should be,

00:14:07.596 --> 00:14:09.659
why not?

00:14:09.659 --> 00:14:12.472
Thank you very much.

00:14:12.472 --> 00:14:18.156
(Applause)

title: What we can learn from galaxies far, far away
transcript: Here are some images of clusters of galaxies. They're exactly what they sound like. They are these huge collections of galaxies, bound together by their mutual gravity. So most of the points that you see on the screen are not individual stars, but collections of stars, or galaxies.Now, by showing you some of these images, I hope that you will quickly see that galaxy clusters are these beautiful objects, but more than that, I think galaxy clusters are mysterious, they are surprising, and they're useful. Useful as the universe's most massive laboratories. And as laboratories, to describe galaxy clusters is to describe the experiments that you can do with them.And I think there are four major types, and the first type that I want to describe is probing the very big. So, how big? Well, here is an image of a particular galaxy cluster. It is so massive that the light passing through it is being bent, it's being distorted by the extreme gravity of this cluster. And, in fact, if you look very carefully you'll be able to see rings around this cluster. Now, to give you a number, this particular galaxy cluster has a mass of over one million billion suns. It's just mind-boggling how  massive these systems can get. But more than their mass, they have this additional feature. They are essentially isolated systems, so if we like, we can think of them as a scaled-down version of the entire universe. And many of the questions that we might have about the universe at large scales, such as, how does gravity work? might be answered by studying these systems.So that was very big. The second things is very hot. Okay, if I take an image of a galaxy cluster, and I subtract away all of the starlight, what I'm left with is this big, blue blob. This is in false color. It's actually X-ray light that we're seeing. And the question is, if it's not galaxies, what is emitting this light? The answer is hot gas, million-degree gas — in fact, it's plasma. And the reason why it's so hot goes back to the previous slide. The extreme gravity of these systems is accelerating particles of gas to great speeds, and great speeds means great temperatures. So this is the main idea, but science is a rough draft. There are many basic properties about this plasma that still confuse us, still puzzle us, and still push our understanding of the physics of the very hot.Third thing: probing the very small. Now, to explain this, I need to tell you a very disturbing fact. Most of the universe's matter is not made up of atoms. You were lied to. Most of it is made up of something  very, very mysterious, which we call dark matter. Dark matter is something that  doesn't like to interact very much, except through gravity, and of course we would like to learn more about it. If you're a particle physicist, you want to know what happens  when we smash things together. And dark matter is no exception.Well, how do we do this? To answer that question, I'm going to have to ask another one, which is, what happens when galaxy clusters collide? Here is an image. Since galaxy clusters are representative slices of the universe, scaled-down versions. They are mostly made up of dark matter, and that's what you see in this bluish purple. The red represents the hot gas, and, of course, you can see many galaxies. What's happened is a particle accelerator at a huge, huge scale. And this is very important, because what it means is that very, very small effects that might be difficult to detect in the lab, might be compounded and compounded into something that we could  possibly observe in nature. So, it's very funny. The reason why galaxy clusters can teach us about dark matter, the reason why galaxy clusters can teach us about the physics of the very small, is precisely because they are so very big.Fourth thing: the physics of the very strange. Certainly what I've said so far is crazy. Okay, if there's anything stranger I think it has to be dark energy. If I throw a ball into the air, I expect it to go up. What I don't expect is that it go up at an ever-increasing rate. Similarly, cosmologists understand why the universe is expanding. They don't understand why it's expanding at an ever-increasing rate. title: The 3 agencies with the power to make or break economies
transcript: Almost two years ago, I was driving in my car in Germany, and I turned on the radio. Europe at the time was in the middle of the Euro crisis, and all the headlines were about European countries getting downgraded by rating agencies in the United States. I listened and thought to myself, "What are these rating agencies, and why is everybody so upset about their work?"Well, if you were sitting next to me in the car that day and would have told me that I would devote the next years to trying to reform them, obviously I would have called you crazy. But guess what's really crazy: the way these rating agencies are run. And I would like to explain to you not only why it's time to change this, but also how we can do it.So let me tell you a little bit about what rating agencies really do. As you would read a car magazine before purchasing a new car or taking a look at a product review before deciding which kind of tablet or phone to get, investors are reading ratings before they decide in which kind of product they are investing their money. A rating can range from a so-called AAA, which means it's a top-performing product, and it can go down to the level of the so-called BBB-, which means it's a fairly risky investment. Rating agencies are rating companies. They are rating banks. They are rating even financial products like the infamous mortgage-backed securities. But they can also rate countries, and these ratings are called sovereign ratings, and I would like to focus in particular on these sovereign ratings.And I can tell, as you're listening to me right now, you're thinking, so why should I really care about this, right? Be honest. Well, ratings affect you. They affect all of us. If a rating agency rates a country, it basically assesses and evaluates a country's debt and the ability and willingness of a country to repay its debt. So if a country gets downgraded by a rating agency, the country has to pay more in order to borrow money on the international markets. So it affects you as a citizen and as a taxpayer, because you and your fellow countrymen have to pony up more in order to borrow. But what if a country can't afford to pay more because it's maybe too expensive? Well, then the country has less available for other services, like roads, schools, healthcare. And this is the reason why you should care, because sovereign ratings affect everyone. And that is the reason why I believe they should be defined as public goods. They should be transparent, accessible, and available to everyone at no cost.But here's the situation: the rating agency market is dominated by three players and three players only — Standard & Poor's, Moody's, and Fitch — and we know whenever there is a market concentration, there is really no competition. There is no incentive to improve the quality of your product. And let's face it, the credit rating  agencies have contributed, putting the global economy on the brink, and yet they have to change the way they operate.The second point, would you really buy a car just based on the advice of the dealer? Obviously not, right? That would be irresponsible. But that's actually what's going on in the rating agency sector every single day. The customers of these rating agencies, like countries or companies, they are paying for their own ratings, and obviously this is creating a conflict of interest.The third point is, the rating agencies are not really telling us how they are coming up with their ratings, but in this day and age, you can't even sell a candy bar without listing everything that's inside. But for ratings, a crucial element of our economy, we really do not know what all the different ingredients are. We are allowing the rating agencies to be intransparent about their work, and we need to change this.I think there is no doubt that the sector needs a complete overhaul, not just a trimming at the margins. I think it's time for a bold move. I think it's time to upgrade the system. And this is why we at the Bertelsmann Foundation have invested a lot of time and effort thinking about an alternative for the sector. And we have developed the first model for a nonprofit rating agency for sovereign risk, and we call it by its acronym, INCRA.INCRA would make a difference to the current system by adding another nonprofit player to the mix. It would be based on a nonprofit model that would be based on a sustainable endowment. The endowment would create income that would allow us to run the operation, to run the rating agency, and it would also allow us to make our ratings publicly available. But this is not enough to make a difference, right? INCRA would also be based on a very, very clear governance structure that would avoid any conflict of interest, and it would include many stakeholders from society. INCRA would not only be a European or an American rating agency, it would be a truly international one, in which, in particular, the emerging economies would have an equal interest,  voice and representation.The second big difference that INCRA would make is that would it base its sovereign risk assessment on a broader set of indicators. Think about it that way. If we conduct a sovereign rating, we basically take a look at the economic soil of a country, its macroeconomic fundamentals. But we also have to ask the question, who is cultivating the economic soil of a country, right? Well, a country has many gardeners, and one of them is the government, so we have to ask the question, how is a country governed? How is it managed? And this is the reason why we have developed what we call forward-looking indicators. These are indicators that give you a much better read about the socioeconomic development of a country. I hope you would agree it's important for you to know if your government is willing to invest  in renewable energy and education. It's important for you to know if the government of your country is able to manage a crisis, if the government is finally able to implement the reforms that it's promised. For example, if INCRA would rate South Africa right now, of course we would take a very, very close look at the youth unemployment of the country, the highest in the world. If over 70 percent of a country's population under the age of 35 is unemployed, of course this has a huge impact on the economy today and even more so in the future. Well, our friends at Moody's, Standard & Poor's, and Fitch will tell us we would take this into account as well. But guess what? We do not know exactly how they will take this into account.And this leads me to the third big difference that INCRA would make. INCRA would not only release its ratings but it would also release its indicators and methodology.So in contrast to the current system, INCRA would be fully transparent. So in a nutshell, INCRA would offer an alternative to the current system of the big three rating agencies by adding a new, nonprofit player to the mix that would increase the competition, it would increase the transparency of the sector, and it would also increase the quality.I can tell that sovereign ratings may still look to you like this very small piece of this very complex global financial world, but I tell you it's a very important one, and a very important one to fix, because sovereign ratings affect all of us, and they should be addressed and should be defined as public goods. And this is why we are testing our model right now, and why we are trying to find out if it can bring together a group of able and willing actors to bring INCRA to life. I truly believe building up INCRA is in everyone's interest, and that we have the unique opportunity right now to turn INCRA into a cornerstone of a new, more inclusive financial system. Because for way too long, we have left the big financial players on their own. It's time to give them some company.Thank you.(Applause)
