and the mask-holding stage.

00:03:26.490 --> 00:03:28.362
And there are micro optics at the bottom

00:03:28.362 --> 00:03:31.236
that's actually embedded in the paper itself.

00:03:31.236 --> 00:03:33.740
What you do is, you take it on,

00:03:33.740 --> 00:03:36.516
and just like you are playing like a toy,

00:03:36.516 --> 00:03:39.603
which it is,

00:03:40.542 --> 00:03:43.572
I tab it off,

00:03:46.997 --> 00:03:49.179
and I break it off.

00:03:49.179 --> 00:03:51.903
This paper has no instructions and no languages.

00:03:51.903 --> 00:03:54.222
There is a code, a color code embedded,

00:03:54.222 --> 00:03:58.833
that tells you exactly how to
fold that specific microscope.

00:03:58.833 --> 00:04:01.482
When it's done, it looks something like this,

00:04:01.482 --> 00:04:04.213
has all the functionalities of a standard microscope,

00:04:04.213 --> 00:04:06.094
just like an XY stage,

00:04:06.094 --> 00:04:10.515
a place where a sample slide could go,

00:04:10.515 --> 00:04:13.055
for example right here.

00:04:13.055 --> 00:04:14.567
We didn't want to change this,

00:04:14.567 --> 00:04:15.939
because this is the standard

00:04:15.939 --> 00:04:17.792
that's been optimized for over the years,

00:04:17.792 --> 00:04:20.488
and many health workers are actually used to this.

00:04:20.488 --> 00:04:21.949
So this is what changes,

00:04:21.949 --> 00:04:24.116
but the standard stains all remain the same

00:04:24.116 --> 00:04:25.891
for many different diseases.

00:04:25.891 --> 00:04:28.823
You pop this in.

00:04:28.823 --> 00:04:32.709
There is an XY stage,

00:04:32.709 --> 00:04:34.682
and then there is a focusing stage,

00:04:34.682 --> 00:04:36.548
which is a flexure mechanism

00:04:36.548 --> 00:04:39.101
that's built in paper itself that allows us to move

00:04:39.101 --> 00:04:42.082
and focus the lenses by micron steps.

00:04:42.082 --> 00:04:44.215
So what's really interesting about this object,

00:04:44.215 --> 00:04:46.098
and my students hate when I do this,

00:04:46.098 --> 00:04:47.859
but I'm going to do this anyway,

00:04:47.859 --> 00:04:49.815
is these are rugged devices.

00:04:49.815 --> 00:04:54.392
I can turn it on and throw it on the floor

00:04:54.392 --> 00:04:57.344
and really try to stomp on it.

00:04:57.344 --> 00:04:59.719
And they last, even though they're designed

00:04:59.719 --> 00:05:03.182
from a very flexible material, like paper.

00:05:03.182 --> 00:05:06.034
Another fun fact is, this is what we actually

00:05:06.034 --> 00:05:10.089
send out there as a standard diagnostic tool,

00:05:10.089 --> 00:05:11.858
but here in this envelope

00:05:11.858 --> 00:05:14.249
I have 30 different foldscopes

00:05:14.249 --> 00:05:19.980
of different configurations all in a single folder.

00:05:19.980 --> 00:05:21.792
And I'm going to pick one randomly.

00:05:21.792 --> 00:05:23.874
This one, it turns out, is actually designed

00:05:23.874 --> 00:05:25.437
specifically for malaria,

00:05:25.437 --> 00:05:27.748
because it has the fluorescent filters built

00:05:27.748 --> 00:05:29.845
specifically for diagnosing malaria.

00:05:29.845 --> 00:05:33.773
So the idea of very specific diagnostic microscopes

00:05:33.773 --> 00:05:35.539
comes out of this.

00:05:35.539 --> 00:05:38.478
So up till now, you didn't actually see

00:05:38.478 --> 00:05:41.435
what I would see from one of these setups.

00:05:41.435 --> 00:05:43.116
So what I would like to do is,

00:05:43.116 --> 00:05:44.742
if we could dim the lights, please,

00:05:44.742 --> 00:05:48.407
it turns out foldscopes are
also projection microscopes.

00:05:48.407 --> 00:05:50.941
I have these two microscopes that I'm going to turn --

00:05:50.941 --> 00:05:52.694
go to the back of the wall --

00:05:52.694 --> 00:05:54.402
and just project, and this way you will see

00:05:54.402 --> 00:05:56.522
exactly what I would see.

00:05:56.522 --> 00:05:58.308
What you're looking at --

00:05:58.308 --> 00:06:00.691
(Applause) —

00:06:00.691 --> 00:06:03.327
This is a cross-section of a compound eye,

00:06:03.327 --> 00:06:05.678
and when I'm going to zoom in closer, right there,

00:06:05.678 --> 00:06:07.922
I am going through the z-axis.

00:06:07.922 --> 00:06:10.946
You actually see how the lenses are cut together

00:06:10.946 --> 00:06:12.519
in the cross-section pattern.

00:06:12.519 --> 00:06:15.075
Another example, one of my favorite insects,

00:06:15.075 --> 00:06:17.052
I love to hate this one,

00:06:17.052 --> 00:06:18.833
is a mosquito,

00:06:18.833 --> 00:06:22.595
and you're seeing the antenna of a culex pipiens.

00:06:22.595 --> 00:06:25.958
Right there.

00:06:25.958 --> 00:06:30.171
All from the simple setup that I actually described.

00:06:30.171 --> 00:06:31.944
So my wife has been field testing

00:06:31.944 --> 00:06:33.944
some of our microscopes

00:06:33.944 --> 00:06:36.425
by washing my clothes whenever I forget them

00:06:36.425 --> 00:06:38.454
in the dryer.

00:06:38.454 --> 00:06:41.254
So it turns out they're waterproof, and --

00:06:41.254 --> 00:06:43.042
(Laughter) —

00:06:43.042 --> 00:06:45.540
right here is just fluorescent water,

00:06:45.540 --> 00:06:47.090
and I don't know if you can actually see this.

00:06:47.090 --> 00:06:49.479
This also shows you how 
the projection scope works.

00:06:49.479 --> 00:06:53.132
You get to see the beam the 
way it's projected and bent.

00:06:56.157 --> 00:06:59.097
Can we get the lights back on again?

00:06:59.097 --> 00:07:00.884
So I'm quickly going to show you,

00:07:00.884 --> 00:07:02.933
since I'm running out of time,

00:07:02.933 --> 00:07:05.359
in terms of how much it costs for us to manufacture,

00:07:05.359 --> 00:07:08.439
the biggest idea was roll-to-roll manufacturing,

00:07:08.439 --> 00:07:11.561
so we built this out of 50 cents of parts and costs.

00:07:11.561 --> 00:07:14.420
(Applause)

00:07:14.420 --> 00:07:16.515
And what this allows us to do

00:07:16.515 --> 00:07:18.851
is to think about a new paradigm in microscopy,

00:07:18.851 --> 00:07:20.868
which we call use-and-throw microscopy.

00:07:20.868 --> 00:07:22.957
I'm going to give you a quick snapshot

00:07:22.957 --> 00:07:24.720
of some of the parts that go in.

00:07:24.720 --> 00:07:26.179
Here is a sheet of paper.

00:07:26.179 --> 00:07:28.268
This is when we were thinking about the idea.

00:07:28.268 --> 00:07:29.623
This is an A4 sheet of paper.

00:07:29.623 --> 00:07:31.604
These are the three stages that you actually see.

00:07:31.604 --> 00:07:35.034
And the optical components, if you
look at the inset up on the right,

00:07:35.034 --> 00:07:37.461
we had to figure out a way to manufacture lenses

00:07:37.461 --> 00:07:39.773
in paper itself at really high throughputs,

00:07:39.773 --> 00:07:41.632
so it uses a process of self-assembly

00:07:41.632 --> 00:07:42.744
and surface tension

00:07:42.744 --> 00:07:46.280
to build achromatic lenses in the paper itself.

00:07:46.280 --> 00:07:47.725
So that's where the lenses go.

00:07:47.725 --> 00:07:49.337
There are some light sources.

00:07:49.337 --> 00:07:50.722
And essentially, in the end,

00:07:50.722 --> 00:07:53.900
all the parts line up because of origami,

00:07:53.900 --> 00:07:57.171
because of the fact that origami allows us

00:07:57.171 --> 00:08:00.151
micron-scale precision of optical alignment.

00:08:00.151 --> 00:08:02.780
So even though this looks like a simple toy,

00:08:02.780 --> 00:08:04.694
the aspects of engineering that go in

00:08:04.694 --> 00:08:07.380
something like this are fairly sophisticated.

00:08:07.380 --> 00:08:10.615
So here is another obvious thing that we would do,

00:08:10.615 --> 00:08:12.208
typically, if I was going to show

00:08:12.208 --> 00:08:13.713
that these microscopes are robust,

00:08:13.713 --> 00:08:17.551
is go to the third floor and
drop it from the floor itself.

00:08:17.551 --> 00:08:20.874
There it is, and it survives.

00:08:20.874 --> 00:08:23.051
So for us, the next step actually

00:08:23.051 --> 00:08:24.890
is really finishing our field trials.

00:08:24.890 --> 00:08:26.995
We are starting at the end of the summer.

00:08:26.995 --> 00:08:29.922
We are at a stage where we'll be 
making thousands of microscopes.

00:08:29.922 --> 00:08:32.066
That would be the first time where we would be

00:08:32.066 --> 00:08:34.151
doing field trials with the highest density

00:08:34.151 --> 00:08:36.706
of microscopes ever at a given place.

00:08:36.706 --> 00:08:38.786
We've started collecting data for malaria,

00:08:38.786 --> 00:08:42.582
Chagas disease and giardia from patients themselves.

00:08:42.582 --> 00:08:44.676
And I want to leave you with this picture.

00:08:44.676 --> 00:08:46.601
I had not anticipated this before,

00:08:46.601 --> 00:08:48.288
but a really interesting link

00:08:48.288 --> 00:08:50.183
between hands-on science education

00:08:50.183 --> 00:08:51.441
and global health.

00:08:51.441 --> 00:08:54.367
What are the tools that we're actually providing

00:08:54.367 --> 00:08:56.547
the kids who are going to fight

00:08:56.547 --> 00:08:58.465
this monster soup for tomorrow?

00:08:58.465 --> 00:09:00.823
I would love for them to be able to just print out

00:09:00.823 --> 00:09:02.952
a Foldscope and carry them around in their pockets.

00:09:02.952 --> 00:09:05.858
Thank you.

00:09:05.858 --> 00:09:10.301
(Applause)

title: A word game to communicate in any language
transcript: I work with children with autism. Specifically, I make technologies to help them communicate.Now, many of the problems that children with autism face, they have a common source, and that source is that they find it difficult to understand abstraction, symbolism. And because of this, they have  a lot of difficulty with language.Let me tell you a little bit about why this is. You see that this is a picture of a bowl of soup. All of us can see it. All of us understand this. These are two other pictures of soup, but you can see that these are more abstract These are not quite as concrete. And when you get to language, you see that it becomes a word whose look, the way it looks and the way it sounds, has absolutely nothing to do  with what it started with, or what it represents, which is the bowl of soup. So it's essentially a completely abstract, a completely arbitrary representation of something which is in the real world, and this is something that children with autism have an incredible amount of difficulty with. Now that's why most of the people  that work with children with autism — speech therapists, educators — what they do is, they try to help children with autism communicate not with words, but with pictures. So if a child with autism wanted to say, "I want soup," that child would pick three different pictures, "I," "want," and "soup," and they would put these together, and then the therapist or the parent would understand that this is what the kid wants to say. And this has been incredibly effective; for the last 30, 40 years people have been doing this. In fact, a few years back, I developed an app for the iPad which does exactly this. It's called Avaz, and the way it works is that kids select different pictures. These pictures are sequenced together to form sentences, and these sentences are spoken out. So Avaz is essentially converting pictures, it's a translator, it converts pictures into speech.Now, this was very effective. There are thousands of children using this, you know, all over the world, and I started thinking about what it does and what it doesn't do. And I realized something interesting: Avaz helps children with autism learn words. What it doesn't help them do is to learn word patterns. Let me explain this in a little more detail. Take this sentence: "I want soup tonight." Now it's not just the words here that convey the meaning. It's also the way in which these words are arranged, the way these words are modified and arranged. And that's why a sentence like "I want soup tonight" is different from a sentence like "Soup want I tonight," which  is completely meaningless. So there is another hidden abstraction here which children with autism find a lot of difficulty coping with, and that's the fact that you can modify words and you can arrange them to have different meanings, to convey different ideas. Now, this is what we call grammar. And grammar is incredibly powerful, because grammar is this one component of language which takes this finite vocabulary that all of us have and allows us to convey an infinite amount of information, an infinite amount of ideas. It's the way in which you can put things together in order to convey anything you want to.And so after I developed Avaz, I worried for a very long time about how I could give grammar  to children with autism. The solution came to me from a very interesting perspective. I happened to chance upon a child with autism conversing with her mom, and this is what happened. Completely out of the blue, very spontaneously, the child got up and said, "Eat." Now what was interesting was the way in which the mom was trying to tease out the meaning of what the child wanted to say by talking to her in questions. So she asked, "Eat what? Do  you want to eat ice cream? You want to eat? Somebody else wants to eat? You want to eat cream now? You want to eat ice cream in the evening?" And then it struck me that what the mother had done was something incredible. She had been able to get that child to communicate an idea to her without grammar. And it struck me that maybe this is what I was looking for. Instead of arranging words in an order, in sequence, as a sentence, you arrange them in this map, where they're all linked together not by placing them one after the other but in questions, in question-answer pairs. And so if you do this, then what you're conveying is not a sentence in English, but what you're conveying is really a meaning, the meaning of a sentence in English. Now, meaning is really the underbelly, in some sense, of language. It's what comes after thought but before language. And the idea was that this particular representation might convey meaning in its raw form.So I was very excited by this, you know, hopping around all over the place, trying to figure out if I can convert all possible sentences that I hear into this. And I found that this is not enough. Why is this not enough? This is not enough because if you wanted to convey something like negation, you want to say, "I don't want soup," then you can't do that by asking a question. You do that by changing the word "want." Again, if you wanted to say, "I wanted soup yesterday," you do that by converting the word "want" into "wanted." It's a past tense. So this is a flourish which I added to make the system complete. This is a map of words joined together as questions and answers, and with these filters applied on top of them in order to modify them to represent certain nuances. Let me show you this with a different example.Let's take this sentence: "I told the carpenter I could not pay him." It's a fairly complicated sentence. The way that this particular system works, you can start with any part of this sentence. I'm going to start with the word "tell." So this is the word "tell." Now this happened in the past, so I'm going to make that "told." Now, what I'm going to do is, I'm going to ask questions. So, who told? I told. I told whom? I told the carpenter. Now we start with a different part of the sentence. We start with the word "pay," and we add the ability filter to it to make it "can pay." Then we make it "can't pay," and we can make it "couldn't pay" by making it the past tense. So who couldn't pay? I couldn't pay. Couldn't pay whom? I couldn't pay the carpenter. And then you join these two together by asking this question: What did I tell the carpenter? I told the carpenter I could not pay him.Now think about this. This is —(Applause)— this is a representation of this sentence without language. And there are two or three interesting things about this. First of all, I could have started anywhere. I didn't have to start with the word "tell." I could have started anywhere in the sentence, and I could have made this entire thing. The second thing is, if I wasn't an English speaker, if I was speaking in some other language, this map would actually hold true in any language. So long as the questions are standardized, the map is actually independent of language. So I call this FreeSpeech, and I was playing with this for many, many months. I was trying out so many different combinations of this.And then I noticed something very interesting about FreeSpeech. I was trying to convert language, convert sentences in English into sentences in FreeSpeech, and vice versa, and back and forth. And I realized that this particular configuration, this particular way of representing language, it allowed me to actually create very concise rules that go between FreeSpeech on one side and English on the other. So I could actually write this set of rules that translates from this particular representation into English. And so I developed this thing. I developed this thing called  the FreeSpeech Engine which takes any FreeSpeech sentence as the input and gives out perfectly grammatical English text. And by putting these two pieces together, the representation and the engine, I was able to create an app, a technology for children with autism, that not only gives them words but also gives them grammar.So I tried this out with kids with autism, and I found that there was an  incredible amount of identification. They were able to create sentences in FreeSpeech which were much more complicated but much more effective than equivalent sentences in English, and I started thinking about why that might be the case. And I had an idea, and I want to  talk to you about this idea next. In about 1997, about 15 years back, there were a group of scientists that were trying to understand how the brain processes language, and they found something very interesting. They found that when you learn a language as a child, as a two-year-old, you learn it with a certain part of your brain, and when you learn a language as an adult — for example, if I wanted to learn Japanese right now — a completely different part of my brain is used. Now I don't know why that's the case, but my guess is that that's because when you learn a language as an adult, you almost invariably learn it through your native language, or through your first language. So what's interesting about FreeSpeech is that when you create a sentence or when you create language, a child with autism creates language with FreeSpeech, they're not using this support language, they're not using this bridge language. They're directly constructing the sentence.And so this gave me this idea. Is it possible to use FreeSpeech not for children with autism but to teach language to people without disabilities? And so I tried a number of experiments. The first thing I did was I built a jigsaw puzzle in which these questions and answers are coded in the form of shapes, in the form of colors, and you have people putting these together and trying to understand how this works. And I built an app out of it, a game out of it, in which children can play with words and with a reinforcement, a sound reinforcement of visual structures, they're able to learn language. And this, this has a lot of potential, a lot of promise, and the government of India recently licensed this technology from us, and they're going to try it out with millions of different children trying to teach them English. And the dream, the hope, the vision, really, is that when they learn English this way, they learn it with the same proficiency as their mother tongue.All right, let's talk about something else. Let's talk about speech. This is speech. So speech is the primary mode of communication delivered between all of us. Now what's interesting about speech is that speech is one-dimensional. Why is it one-dimensional? It's one-dimensional because it's sound. It's also one-dimensional because our mouths are built that way. Our mouths are built to create one-dimensional sound. But if you think about the brain, the thoughts that we have in our heads are not one-dimensional. I mean, we have these rich, complicated, multi-dimensional ideas. Now, it seems to me that language is really the brain's invention to convert this rich, multi-dimensional thought on one hand into speech on the other hand. Now what's interesting is that we do a lot of work in information nowadays, and almost all of that is done in the language domain. Take Google, for example. Google trawls all these countless billions of websites, all of which are in English, and when you want to use Google, you go into Google search, and you type in English, and it matches the English with the English. What if we could do this in FreeSpeech instead? I have a suspicion that if we did this, we'd find that algorithms like searching, like retrieval, all of these things, are much simpler and also more effective, because they don't process the data structure of speech. Instead they're processing the data structure of thought. The data structure of thought. That's a provocative idea.But let's look at this in a little more detail. So this is the FreeSpeech ecosystem. We have the Free Speech representation on one side, and we have the FreeSpeech  Engine, which generates English. Now if you think about it, FreeSpeech, I told you, is completely  language-independent. It doesn't have any specific information in it which is about English. So everything that this system knows about English is actually encoded into the engine. That's a pretty interesting concept in itself. You've encoded an entire human language into a software program. But if you look at what's inside the engine, it's actually not very complicated. It's not very complicated code. And what's more interesting is the fact that the vast majority of the code in that engine is not really English-specific. And that gives this interesting idea. It might be very easy for us to actually create these engines in many, many different languages, in Hindi, in French, in German, in Swahili. And that gives another interesting idea. For example, supposing I was a writer, say, for a newspaper or for a magazine. I could create content in one language, FreeSpeech, and the person who's consuming that content, the person who's reading that particular information could choose any engine, and they could read it in their own mother tongue, in their native language. I mean, this is an incredibly attractive idea, especially for India. We have so many different languages. There's a song about India, and there's a description of the country as, it says, (in Sanskrit). That means "ever-smiling speaker of beautiful languages."Language is beautiful. I think it's the most beautiful of human creations. I think it's the loveliest thing that our brains have invented. It entertains, it educates, it enlightens, but what I like the most about language is that it empowers.I want to leave you with this. This is a photograph of my collaborators, my earliest collaborators when I started working on language and autism and various other things. The girl's name is Pavna, and that's her mother, Kalpana. And Pavna's an entrepreneur, but her story is much more remarkable than mine, because Pavna is about 23. She has quadriplegic cerebral palsy, so ever since she was born, she could neither move nor talk. And everything that she's accomplished so far, finishing school, going to college, starting a company, collaborating with me to develop Avaz, all of these things she's done with nothing more than moving her eyes.Daniel Webster said this: He said, "If all of my possessions were taken from me with one exception, I would choose to keep the power of communication, for with it, I would regain all the rest." And that's why, of all of these incredible  applications of FreeSpeech, the one that's closest to my heart still remains the ability for this to empower children with disabilities to be able to communicate, the power of communication, to get back all the rest.Thank you. (Applause) Thank you. (Applause) Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. (Applause) Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. (Applause)

00:01:29.471 --> 00:01:31.929
"I want soup," that child would pick

00:01:31.929 --> 00:01:34.189
three different pictures, "I," "want," and "soup,"

00:01:34.189 --> 00:01:35.798
and they would put these together,

00:01:35.798 --> 00:01:37.665
and then the therapist or the parent would

00:01:37.665 --> 00:01:39.552
understand that this is what the kid wants to say.

00:01:39.552 --> 00:01:41.330
And this has been incredibly effective;

00:01:41.330 --> 00:01:43.471
for the last 30, 40 years

00:01:43.471 --> 00:01:45.084
people have been doing this.

00:01:45.084 --> 00:01:46.433
In fact, a few years back,

00:01:46.433 --> 00:01:49.108
I developed an app for the iPad

00:01:49.108 --> 00:01:51.363
which does exactly this. It's called Avaz,

00:01:51.363 --> 00:01:53.642
and the way it works is that kids select

00:01:53.642 --> 00:01:54.963
different pictures.

00:01:54.963 --> 00:01:57.533
These pictures are sequenced
together to form sentences,

00:01:57.533 --> 00:01:59.252
and these sentences are spoken out.

00:01:59.252 --> 00:02:02.277
So Avaz is essentially converting pictures,

00:02:02.277 --> 00:02:06.237
it's a translator, it converts pictures into speech.

00:02:06.237 --> 00:02:07.955
Now, this was very effective.

00:02:07.955 --> 00:02:09.339
There are thousands of children using this,

00:02:09.339 --> 00:02:10.769
you know, all over the world,

00:02:10.769 --> 00:02:12.944
and I started thinking about

00:02:12.944 --> 00:02:15.598
what it does and what it doesn't do.

00:02:15.598 --> 00:02:17.282
And I realized something interesting:

00:02:17.282 --> 00:02:21.485
Avaz helps children with autism learn words.

00:02:21.485 --> 00:02:23.890
What it doesn't help them do is to learn

00:02:23.890 --> 00:02:26.638
word patterns.

00:02:26.638 --> 00:02:29.110
Let me explain this in a little more detail.

00:02:29.110 --> 00:02:32.167
Take this sentence: "I want soup tonight."

00:02:32.167 --> 00:02:36.247
Now it's not just the words
here that convey the meaning.

00:02:36.247 --> 00:02:39.387
It's also the way in which these words are arranged,

00:02:39.387 --> 00:02:41.902
the way these words are modified and arranged.

00:02:41.917 --> 00:02:44.223
And that's why a sentence like "I want soup tonight"

00:02:44.223 --> 00:02:46.207
is different from a sentence like

00:02:46.207 --> 00:02:49.519
"Soup want I tonight," which 
is completely meaningless.

00:02:49.519 --> 00:02:52.138
So there is another hidden abstraction here

00:02:52.138 --> 00:02:55.695
which children with autism find
a lot of difficulty coping with,

00:02:55.695 --> 00:02:58.535
and that's the fact that you can modify words

00:02:58.535 --> 00:03:00.636
and you can arrange them to have

00:03:00.636 --> 00:03:03.531
different meanings, to convey different ideas.

00:03:03.531 --> 00:03:06.990
Now, this is what we call grammar.

00:03:06.990 --> 00:03:09.026
And grammar is incredibly powerful,

00:03:09.026 --> 00:03:12.183
because grammar is this one component of language

00:03:12.183 --> 00:03:15.672
which takes this finite vocabulary that all of us have

00:03:15.672 --> 00:03:20.203
and allows us to convey an
infinite amount of information,

00:03:20.203 --> 00:03:22.337
an infinite amount of ideas.

00:03:22.337 --> 00:03:24.339
It's the way in which you can put things together

00:03:24.339 --> 00:03:26.507
in order to convey anything you want to.

00:03:26.507 --> 00:03:28.634
And so after I developed Avaz,

00:03:28.634 --> 00:03:30.202
I worried for a very long time

00:03:30.202 --> 00:03:34.112
about how I could give grammar 
to children with autism.

00:03:34.112 --> 00:03:36.387
The solution came to me from
a very interesting perspective.

00:03:36.387 --> 00:03:39.836
I happened to chance upon a child with autism

00:03:39.836 --> 00:03:41.945
conversing with her mom,

00:03:41.945 --> 00:03:44.039
and this is what happened.

00:03:44.039 --> 00:03:46.225
Completely out of the blue, very spontaneously,

00:03:46.225 --> 00:03:48.688
the child got up and said, "Eat."

00:03:48.688 --> 00:03:50.458
Now what was interesting was

00:03:50.458 --> 00:03:54.702
the way in which the mom was trying to tease out

00:03:54.702 --> 00:03:56.915
the meaning of what the child wanted to say

00:03:56.915 --> 00:03:59.175
by talking to her in questions.

00:03:59.175 --> 00:04:01.768
So she asked, "Eat what? Do 
you want to eat ice cream?

00:04:01.768 --> 00:04:03.880
You want to eat? Somebody else wants to eat?

00:04:03.880 --> 00:04:07.193
You want to eat cream now? You
want to eat ice cream in the evening?"

00:04:07.193 --> 00:04:08.707
And then it struck me that

00:04:08.707 --> 00:04:10.735
what the mother had done was something incredible.

00:04:10.735 --> 00:04:12.729
She had been able to get that child to communicate

00:04:12.729 --> 00:04:16.867
an idea to her without grammar.

00:04:16.867 --> 00:04:19.563
And it struck me that maybe this is what

00:04:19.563 --> 00:04:20.948
I was looking for.

00:04:20.948 --> 00:04:25.090
Instead of arranging words in an order, in sequence,

00:04:25.090 --> 00:04:27.262
as a sentence, you arrange them

00:04:27.262 --> 00:04:31.073
in this map, where they're all linked together

00:04:31.073 --> 00:04:33.216
not by placing them one after the other

00:04:33.216 --> 00:04:36.500
but in questions, in question-answer pairs.

00:04:36.500 --> 00:04:38.858
And so if you do this, then what you're conveying

00:04:38.858 --> 00:04:40.844
is not a sentence in English,

00:04:40.844 --> 00:04:43.810
but what you're conveying is really a meaning,

00:04:43.810 --> 00:04:45.321
the meaning of a sentence in English.

00:04:45.321 --> 00:04:48.253
Now, meaning is really the underbelly,
in some sense, of language.

00:04:48.253 --> 00:04:52.074
It's what comes after thought but before language.

00:04:52.074 --> 00:04:54.577
And the idea was that this particular representation

00:04:54.577 --> 00:04:57.838
might convey meaning in its raw form.

00:04:57.838 --> 00:04:59.609
So I was very excited by this, you know,

00:04:59.609 --> 00:05:01.102
hopping around all over the place,

00:05:01.102 --> 00:05:02.873
trying to figure out if I can convert

00:05:02.873 --> 00:05:05.397
all possible sentences that I hear into this.

00:05:05.397 --> 00:05:07.170
And I found that this is not enough.

00:05:07.170 --> 00:05:08.555
Why is this not enough?

00:05:08.555 --> 00:05:10.266
This is not enough because if you wanted to convey

00:05:10.266 --> 00:05:12.516
something like negation,

00:05:12.516 --> 00:05:14.252
you want to say, "I don't want soup,"

00:05:14.252 --> 00:05:16.472
then you can't do that by asking a question.

00:05:16.472 --> 00:05:18.757
You do that by changing the word "want."

00:05:18.757 --> 00:05:20.394
Again, if you wanted to say,

00:05:20.394 --> 00:05:22.374
"I wanted soup yesterday,"

00:05:22.374 --> 00:05:25.111
you do that by converting
the word "want" into "wanted."

00:05:25.111 --> 00:05:26.777
It's a past tense.

00:05:26.777 --> 00:05:28.880
So this is a flourish which I added

00:05:28.880 --> 00:05:30.456
to make the system complete.

00:05:30.456 --> 00:05:32.433
This is a map of words joined together

00:05:32.433 --> 00:05:34.089
as questions and answers,

00:05:34.089 --> 00:05:36.353
and with these filters applied on top of them

00:05:36.353 --> 00:05:38.170
in order to modify them to represent

00:05:38.170 --> 00:05:39.879
certain nuances.

00:05:39.879 --> 00:05:41.830
Let me show you this with a different example.

00:05:41.830 --> 00:05:43.084
Let's take this sentence:

00:05:43.084 --> 00:05:45.064
"I told the carpenter I could not pay him."

00:05:45.064 --> 00:05:46.856
It's a fairly complicated sentence.

00:05:46.856 --> 00:05:48.749
The way that this particular system works,

00:05:48.749 --> 00:05:51.327
you can start with any part of this sentence.

00:05:51.327 --> 00:05:53.025
I'm going to start with the word "tell."

00:05:53.025 --> 00:05:54.487
So this is the word "tell."

00:05:54.487 --> 00:05:56.087
Now this happened in the past,

00:05:56.087 --> 00:05:58.310
so I'm going to make that "told."

00:05:58.310 --> 00:06:00.018
Now, what I'm going to do is,

00:06:00.018 --> 00:06:01.774
I'm going to ask questions.

00:06:01.774 --> 00:06:04.138
So, who told? I told.

00:06:04.138 --> 00:06:06.065
I told whom? I told the carpenter.

00:06:06.065 --> 00:06:07.816
Now we start with a different part of the sentence.

00:06:07.816 --> 00:06:09.683
We start with the word "pay,"

00:06:09.683 --> 00:06:14.260
and we add the ability filter to it to make it "can pay."

00:06:14.260 --> 00:06:16.361
Then we make it "can't pay,"

00:06:16.361 --> 00:06:17.960
and we can make it "couldn't pay"

00:06:17.960 --> 00:06:19.623
by making it the past tense.

00:06:19.623 --> 00:06:21.546
So who couldn't pay? I couldn't pay.

00:06:21.546 --> 00:06:24.222
Couldn't pay whom? I couldn't pay the carpenter.

00:06:24.222 --> 00:06:25.953
And then you join these two together

00:06:25.953 --> 00:06:27.303
by asking this question:

00:06:27.303 --> 00:06:29.040
What did I tell the carpenter?

00:06:29.040 --> 00:06:33.089
I told the carpenter I could not pay him.

00:06:33.089 --> 00:06:35.026
Now think about this. This is

00:06:35.026 --> 00:06:38.568
—(Applause)—

00:06:38.568 --> 00:06:42.240
this is a representation of this sentence

00:06:42.240 --> 00:06:44.675
without language.

00:06:44.675 --> 00:06:46.867
And there are two or three
interesting things about this.

00:06:46.867 --> 00:06:49.998
First of all, I could have started anywhere.

00:06:49.998 --> 00:06:52.241
I didn't have to start with the word "tell."

00:06:52.241 --> 00:06:53.657
I could have started anywhere in the sentence,

00:06:53.657 --> 00:06:55.164
and I could have made this entire thing.

00:06:55.164 --> 00:06:57.940
The second thing is, if I wasn't an English speaker,

00:06:57.940 --> 00:07:00.115
if I was speaking in some other language,

00:07:00.115 --> 00:07:03.271
this map would actually hold true in any language.

00:07:03.271 --> 00:07:05.261
So long as the questions are standardized,

00:07:05.261 --> 00:07:09.548
the map is actually independent of language.

00:07:09.548 --> 00:07:11.663
So I call this FreeSpeech,

00:07:11.663 --> 00:07:14.598
and I was playing with this for many, many months.

00:07:14.598 --> 00:07:17.324
I was trying out so many
different combinations of this.

00:07:17.324 --> 00:07:19.613
And then I noticed something very
interesting about FreeSpeech.

00:07:19.613 --> 00:07:22.856
I was trying to convert language,

00:07:22.856 --> 00:07:25.240
convert sentences in English
into sentences in FreeSpeech,

00:07:25.240 --> 00:07:26.992
and vice versa, and back and forth.

00:07:26.992 --> 00:07:29.247
And I realized that this particular configuration,

00:07:29.247 --> 00:07:31.273
this particular way of representing language,

00:07:31.273 --> 00:07:35.668
it allowed me to actually create very concise rules

00:07:35.668 --> 00:07:38.402
that go between FreeSpeech on one side

00:07:38.402 --> 00:07:39.890
and English on the other.

00:07:39.890 --> 00:07:42.070
So I could actually write this set of rules

00:07:42.070 --> 00:07:45.465
that translates from this particular
representation into English.

00:07:45.465 --> 00:07:47.296
And so I developed this thing.

00:07:47.296 --> 00:07:49.528
I developed this thing called 
the FreeSpeech Engine

00:07:49.528 --> 00:07:52.089
which takes any FreeSpeech sentence as the input

00:07:52.089 --> 00:07:56.019
and gives out perfectly grammatical English text.

00:07:56.019 --> 00:07:57.624
And by putting these two pieces together,

00:07:57.624 --> 00:07:59.505
the representation and the engine,

00:07:59.505 --> 00:08:03.301
I was able to create an app, a
technology for children with autism,

00:08:03.301 --> 00:08:05.800
that not only gives them words

00:08:05.800 --> 00:08:09.741
but also gives them grammar.

00:08:09.741 --> 00:08:12.101
So I tried this out with kids with autism,

00:08:12.101 --> 00:08:17.114
and I found that there was an 
incredible amount of identification.

00:08:17.114 --> 00:08:19.834
They were able to create sentences in FreeSpeech

00:08:19.834 --> 00:08:22.392
which were much more complicated
but much more effective

00:08:22.392 --> 00:08:25.291
than equivalent sentences in English,

00:08:25.291 --> 00:08:26.973
and I started thinking about

00:08:26.973 --> 00:08:28.942
why that might be the case.

00:08:28.942 --> 00:08:33.229
And I had an idea, and I want to 
talk to you about this idea next.

00:08:33.229 --> 00:08:36.371
In about 1997, about 15 years back,

00:08:36.371 --> 00:08:38.382
there were a group of scientists that were trying

00:08:38.382 --> 00:08:40.771
to understand how the brain processes language,

00:08:40.771 --> 00:08:42.550
and they found something very interesting.

00:08:42.550 --> 00:08:44.422
They found that when you learn a language

00:08:44.422 --> 00:08:47.334
as a child, as a two-year-old,

00:08:47.334 --> 00:08:49.700
you learn it with a certain part of your brain,

00:08:49.700 --> 00:08:51.300
and when you learn a language as an adult --

00:08:51.300 --> 00:08:55.211
for example, if I wanted to
learn Japanese right now —

00:08:55.211 --> 00:08:57.918
a completely different part of my brain is used.

00:08:57.918 --> 00:08:59.749
Now I don't know why that's the case,

00:08:59.749 --> 00:09:01.740
but my guess is that that's because

00:09:01.740 --> 00:09:04.177
when you learn a language as an adult,

00:09:04.177 --> 00:09:05.793
you almost invariably learn it

00:09:05.793 --> 00:09:10.059
through your native language, or
through your first language.

00:09:10.059 --> 00:09:13.311
So what's interesting about FreeSpeech

00:09:13.311 --> 00:09:15.113
is that when you create a sentence

00:09:15.113 --> 00:09:16.808
or when you create language,

00:09:16.808 --> 00:09:19.878
a child with autism creates
language with FreeSpeech,

00:09:19.878 --> 00:09:21.711
they're not using this support language,

00:09:21.711 --> 00:09:23.922
they're not using this bridge language.

00:09:23.922 --> 00:09:26.579
They're directly constructing the sentence.

00:09:26.579 --> 00:09:28.772
And so this gave me this idea.

00:09:28.772 --> 00:09:30.796
Is it possible to use FreeSpeech

00:09:30.796 --> 00:09:33.306
not for children with autism

00:09:33.306 --> 00:09:39.568
but to teach language to people without disabilities?

00:09:39.568 --> 00:09:41.546
And so I tried a number of experiments.

00:09:41.546 --> 00:09:44.494
The first thing I did was I built a jigsaw puzzle

00:09:44.494 --> 00:09:46.464
in which these questions and answers

00:09:46.464 --> 00:09:48.299
are coded in the form of shapes,

00:09:48.299 --> 00:09:49.437
in the form of colors,

00:09:49.437 --> 00:09:51.286
and you have people putting these together

00:09:51.286 --> 00:09:53.059
and trying to understand how this works.

00:09:53.059 --> 00:09:55.435
And I built an app out of it, a game out of it,

00:09:55.435 --> 00:09:58.096
in which children can play with words

00:09:58.096 --> 00:09:59.800
and with a reinforcement,

00:09:59.800 --> 00:10:02.385
a sound reinforcement of visual structures,

00:10:02.385 --> 00:10:04.398
they're able to learn language.

00:10:04.398 --> 00:10:07.134
And this, this has a lot of potential, a lot of promise,

00:10:07.134 --> 00:10:09.109
and the government of India recently

00:10:09.109 --> 00:10:10.513
licensed this technology from us,

00:10:10.513 --> 00:10:12.587
and they're going to try it out
with millions of different children

00:10:12.587 --> 00:10:15.192
trying to teach them English.

00:10:15.192 --> 00:10:17.806
And the dream, the hope, the vision, really,

00:10:17.806 --> 00:10:20.888
is that when they learn English this way,

00:10:20.888 --> 00:10:23.531
they learn it with the same proficiency

00:10:23.531 --> 00:10:27.249
as their mother tongue.

00:10:27.249 --> 00:10:31.065
All right, let's talk about something else.

00:10:31.065 --> 00:10:33.062
Let's talk about speech.

00:10:33.062 --> 00:10:34.333
This is speech.

00:10:34.333 --> 00:10:36.295
So speech is the primary mode of communication

00:10:36.295 --> 00:10:37.908
delivered between all of us.

00:10:37.908 --> 00:10:39.763
Now what's interesting about speech is that

00:10:39.763 --> 00:10:41.008
speech is one-dimensional.

00:10:41.008 --> 00:10:42.367
Why is it one-dimensional?

00:10:42.367 --> 00:10:43.935
It's one-dimensional because it's sound.

00:10:43.935 --> 00:10:45.474
It's also one-dimensional because

00:10:45.474 --> 00:10:46.679
our mouths are built that way.

00:10:46.679 --> 00:10:50.191
Our mouths are built to create
one-dimensional sound.

00:10:50.191 --> 00:10:53.057
But if you think about the brain,

00:10:53.057 --> 00:10:54.821
the thoughts that we have in our heads

00:10:54.821 --> 00:10:56.923
are not one-dimensional.

00:10:56.923 --> 00:10:58.382
I mean, we have these rich,

00:10:58.382 --> 00:11:01.410
complicated, multi-dimensional ideas.

00:11:01.410 --> 00:11:03.100
Now, it seems to me that language

00:11:03.100 --> 00:11:05.432
is really the brain's invention

00:11:05.432 --> 00:11:08.528
to convert this rich, multi-dimensional thought

00:11:08.528 --> 00:11:10.115
on one hand

00:11:10.115 --> 00:11:12.038
into speech on the other hand.

00:11:12.038 --> 00:11:13.800
Now what's interesting is that

00:11:13.800 --> 00:11:16.368
we do a lot of work in information nowadays,

00:11:16.368 --> 00:11:19.447
and almost all of that is done
in the language domain.

00:11:19.447 --> 00:11:21.386
Take Google, for example.

00:11:21.386 --> 00:11:24.063
Google trawls all these
countless billions of websites,

00:11:24.063 --> 00:11:26.788
all of which are in English,
and when you want to use Google,

00:11:26.788 --> 00:11:29.238
you go into Google search, and you type in English,

00:11:29.238 --> 00:11:33.401
and it matches the English with the English.

00:11:33.401 --> 00:11:36.984
What if we could do this in FreeSpeech instead?

00:11:36.984 --> 00:11:39.285
I have a suspicion that if we did this,

00:11:39.285 --> 00:11:41.353
we'd find that algorithms like searching,

00:11:41.353 --> 00:11:43.678
like retrieval, all of these things,

00:11:43.678 --> 00:11:46.753
are much simpler and also more effective,

00:11:46.753 --> 00:11:51.170
because they don't process
the data structure of speech.

00:11:51.170 --> 00:11:57.146
Instead they're processing
the data structure of thought.

00:11:57.146 --> 00:11:59.954
The data structure of thought.

00:11:59.954 --> 00:12:02.030
That's a provocative idea.

00:12:02.030 --> 00:12:04.172
But let's look at this in a little more detail.

00:12:04.172 --> 00:12:06.538
So this is the FreeSpeech ecosystem.

00:12:06.538 --> 00:12:09.422
We have the Free Speech
representation on one side,

00:12:09.422 --> 00:12:11.650
and we have the FreeSpeech 
Engine, which generates English.

00:12:11.652 --> 00:12:13.377
Now if you think about it,

00:12:13.377 --> 00:12:15.921
FreeSpeech, I told you, is completely 
language-independent.

00:12:15.921 --> 00:12:18.008
It doesn't have any specific information in it

00:12:18.008 --> 00:12:19.236
which is about English.

00:12:19.236 --> 00:12:22.036
So everything that this system knows about English

00:12:22.036 --> 00:12:26.656
is actually encoded into the engine.

00:12:26.656 --> 00:12:28.893
That's a pretty interesting concept in itself.

00:12:28.893 --> 00:12:32.497
You've encoded an entire human language

00:12:32.497 --> 00:12:35.142
into a software program.

00:12:35.142 --> 00:12:37.673
But if you look at what's inside the engine,

00:12:37.673 --> 00:12:40.031
it's actually not very complicated.

00:12:40.031 --> 00:12:42.136
It's not very complicated code.

00:12:42.136 --> 00:12:44.808
And what's more interesting is the fact that

00:12:44.808 --> 00:12:47.011
the vast majority of the code in that engine

00:12:47.011 --> 00:12:49.423
is not really English-specific.

00:12:49.423 --> 00:12:51.318
And that gives this interesting idea.

00:12:51.318 --> 00:12:53.356
It might be very easy for us to actually

00:12:53.356 --> 00:12:57.182
create these engines in many,
many different languages,

00:12:57.182 --> 00:13:03.536
in Hindi, in French, in German, in Swahili.

00:13:03.536 --> 00:13:06.335
And that gives another interesting idea.

00:13:06.335 --> 00:13:08.989
For example, supposing I was a writer,

00:13:08.989 --> 00:13:11.111
say, for a newspaper or for a magazine.

00:13:11.111 --> 00:13:16.122
I could create content in one language, FreeSpeech,

00:13:16.122 --> 00:13:18.178
and the person who's consuming that content,

00:13:18.178 --> 00:13:21.239

in their native language.

00:13:33.131 --> 00:13:35.130
especially for India.

We have so many different languages.

of the country as, it says,

(in Sanskrit).

of beautiful languages."

00:13:50.958 --> 00:13:52.922
Language is beautiful.

00:13:52.922 --> 00:13:55.376
I think it's the most beautiful of human creations.

00:13:55.376 --> 00:13:59.354
I think it's the loveliest thing
that our brains have invented.

It entertains, it educates, it enlightens,

is that it empowers.

and autism and various other things.

The girl's name is Pavna,

00:14:16.083 --> 00:14:17.985
and that's her mother, Kalpana.

00:14:17.985 --> 00:14:20.123
And Pavna's an entrepreneur,

00:14:20.123 --> 00:14:22.494
but her story is much more remarkable than mine,

00:14:22.494 --> 00:14:24.894
because Pavna is about 23.

00:14:24.894 --> 00:14:27.446
She has quadriplegic cerebral palsy,

00:14:27.446 --> 00:14:29.086
so ever since she was born,

00:14:29.086 --> 00:14:32.686
she could neither move nor talk.

00:14:32.686 --> 00:14:35.089

00:14:35.089 --> 00:14:37.316
finishing school, going to college,

00:14:37.316 --> 00:14:38.732
starting a company,

collaborating with me to develop Avaz,

all of these things she's done

with nothing more than moving her eyes.

00:14:48.287 --> 00:14:50.976
Daniel Webster said this:

00:14:50.976 --> 00:14:53.916
He said, "If all of my possessions were taken

00:14:53.916 --> 00:14:56.904
from me with one exception,

00:14:56.904 --> 00:14:59.885

00:14:59.885 --> 00:15:03.788
for with it, I would regain all the rest."

applications of FreeSpeech,

to empower children with disabilities

to be able to communicate,

title: Can we all "have it all"?
transcript: So my moment of truth did not come all at once. In 2010, I had the chance to be considered for promotion from my job as director of policy planning at the U.S. State Department. This was my moment to lean in, to push myself forward for what are really only a handful of the very top foreign policy jobs, and I had just finished a big, 18-month project for Secretary Clinton, successfully, and I knew I could handle a bigger job.The woman I thought I was would have said yes. But I had been commuting for two years between Washington and Princeton, New Jersey, where my husband and my two teenage sons lived, and it was not going well. I tried on the idea of eking out another two years in Washington, or maybe uprooting my sons from their school and my husband from his work and asking them to join me. But deep down, I knew that the right decision was to go home, even if I didn't fully recognize the woman who was making that choice.That was a decision based on love and responsibility. I couldn't keep watching my oldest son make bad choices without being able to be there for him when and if he needed me. But the real change came more gradually. Over the next year, while my family was righting itself, I started to realize that even if I could go back into government, I didn't want to. I didn't want to miss the last five years that my sons were at home. I finally allowed myself to accept what was really most important to me, not what I was conditioned to want or maybe what I conditioned myself to want, and that decision led to a reassessment of the feminist narrative that I grew up with and have always championed.I am still completely committed to the cause of male-female equality, but let's think about what that equality really means, and how best to achieve it. I always accepted the idea that the most respected and powerful people in our society are men at the top of their careers, so that the measure of male-female equality ought to be how many women are in those positions: prime ministers, presidents, CEOs, directors, managers, Nobel laureates, leaders. I still think we should do everything we possibly can to achieve that goal. But that's only half of real equality, and I now think we're never going to get there unless we recognize the other half. I suggest that real equality, full equality, does not just mean valuing women on male terms. It means creating a much wider range of equally respected choices for women and for men. And to get there, we have to change our workplaces, our policies and our culture.In the workplace, real equality means valuing family just as much as work, and understanding that the two reinforce each other. As a leader and as a manager, I have always acted on the mantra, if family comes first, work does not come second — life comes together. If you work for me, and you have a family issue, I expect you to attend to it, and I am confident, and my confidence has always been borne out, that the work will get done, and done better. Workers who have a reason to get home to care for their children or their family members are more focused, more efficient, more results-focused. And breadwinners who are also caregivers have a much wider range of experiences and contacts. Think about a lawyer who spends part of his time at school events for his kids talking to other parents. He's much more likely to bring in new clients for his firm than a lawyer who never leaves his office. And caregiving itself develops patience — a lot of patience — and empathy, creativity, resilience, adaptability. Those are all attributes that are ever more important in a high-speed, horizontal, networked global economy.The best companies actually know this. The companies that win awards for workplace flexibility in the United States include some of our most successful corporations, and a 2008 national study on the changing workforce showed that employees in flexible and effective workplaces are more engaged with their work, they're more satisfied and more loyal, they have lower levels of stress and higher levels of mental health. And a 2012 study of employers showed that deep, flexible practices actually lowered operating costs and increased adaptability in a global service economy.So you may think that the privileging of work over family is only an American problem. Sadly, though, the obsession with work is no longer a uniquely American disease. Twenty years ago, when my family first started going to Italy, we used to luxuriate in the culture of siesta. Siesta is not just about avoiding the heat of the day. It's actually just as much about embracing the warmth of a family lunch. Now, when we go, fewer and fewer businesses close for siesta, reflecting the advance of global corporations and 24-hour competition. So making a place for those we love is actually a global imperative.In policy terms, real equality means recognizing that the work that women have traditionally done is just as important as the work that men have traditionally done, no matter who does it. Think about it: Breadwinning and caregiving are equally necessary for human survival. At least if we get beyond a barter economy, somebody has to earn an income and someone else has to convert that income to care and sustenance for loved ones.Now most of you, when you hear me talk about breadwinning and caregiving, instinctively translate those categories into men's work and women's work. And we don't typically challenge why men's work is advantaged. But consider a same-sex couple like my friends Sarah and Emily. They're psychiatrists. They got married five years ago, and now they have two-year-old twins. They love being mothers, but they also love their work, and they're really good at what they do. So how are they going to divide up breadwinning and caregiving responsibilities? Should one of them stop working or reduce hours to be home? Or should they both change their practices so they can have much more flexible schedules? And what criteria should they use to make that decision? Is it who makes the most money or who is most committed to her career? Or who has the most flexible boss?The same-sex perspective helps us see that juggling work and family are not women's problems, they're family problems. And Sarah and Emily are the lucky ones, because they have a choice about how much they want to work. Millions of men and women have to be both breadwinners and caregivers just to earn the income they need, and many of those workers are scrambling. They're patching together care arrangements that are inadequate and often actually unsafe. If breadwinning and caregiving are really equal, then why shouldn't a government invest as much in an infrastructure of care as the foundation of a healthy society as it invests in physical infrastructure as the backbone of a successful economy?The governments that get it — no surprises here — the governments that get it, Norway, Sweden, Denmark, the Netherlands, provide universal child care, support for caregivers at home, school and early childhood education, protections for pregnant women, and care for the elderly and the disabled. Those governments invest in that infrastructure the same way they invest in roads and bridges and tunnels and trains. Those societies also show you that breadwinning and caregiving reinforce each other. They routinely rank among the top 15 countries of the most globally competitive economies, but at the same time, they rank very high on the OECD Better Life Index. In fact, they rank higher than other governments, like my own, the U.S., or Switzerland, that have higher average levels of income but lower rankings on work-life balance.So changing our workplaces and building infrastructures of care would make a big difference, but we're not going to get equally valued choices unless we change our culture, and the kind of cultural change required means re-socializing men. (Applause) Increasingly in developed countries, women are socialized to believe that our place is no longer only in the home, but men are actually still where they always were. Men are still socialized to believe that they have to be breadwinners, that to derive their self-worth from how high they can climb over other men on a career ladder. The feminist revolution still has a long way to go. It's certainly not complete. But 60 years after "The Feminine Mystique" was published, many women actually have more choices than men do. We can decide to be a breadwinner, a caregiver, or any combination of the two. When a man, on the other hand, decides to be a caregiver, he puts his manhood on the line. His friends may praise his decision, but underneath, they're scratching their heads. Isn't the measure of a man his willingness to compete with other men for power and prestige? And as many women hold that view as men do. We know that lots of women still judge the attractiveness of a man based in large part on how successful he is in his career. A woman can drop out of the work force and still be an attractive partner. For a man, that's a risky proposition. So as parents and partners, we should be socializing our sons and our husbands to be whatever they want to be, either caregivers or breadwinners. We should be socializing them to make caregiving cool for guys. (Applause)I can almost hear lots of you thinking, "No way." But in fact, the change is  actually already happening. At least in the United States, lots of men take pride in cooking, and frankly obsess over stoves. They are in the birthing rooms. They take paternity leave when they can. They can walk a baby or soothe a toddler just as well as their wives can, and they are increasingly doing much more of the housework. Indeed, there are male college students now who are starting to say, "I want to be a stay-at-home dad." That was completely unthinkable 50 or even 30 years ago. And in Norway, where men have an automatic three month's paternity leave, but they lose it if they decide not to take it, a high government official told me that companies are starting to look at prospective male employees and raise an eyebrow if they didn't in fact take their leave when they had kids. That means that it's starting to seem like a character defect not to want to be a fully engaged father.So I was raised to believe that championing women's rights meant doing everything we could to get women to the top. And I still hope that I live long enough to see men and women equally represented at all levels of the work force. But I've come to believe that we have to value family every bit as much as we value work, and that we should entertain the idea that doing right by those we love will make all of us better at everything we do.Thirty years ago, Carol Gilligan, a wonderful psychologist, studied adolescent girls and identified an ethic of care, an element of human nature every bit as important as the ethic of justice. It turns out that "you don't care" is just as much a part of who we are as "that's not fair." Bill Gates agrees. He argues that the two great forces of human nature are self-interest and caring for others. Let's bring them both together. Let's make the feminist revolution a humanist revolution. As whole human beings, we will be better caregivers and breadwinners. You may think that can't happen, but I grew up in a society where my mother put out small vases of cigarettes for dinner parties, where blacks and whites used separate bathrooms, and where everybody claimed to be heterosexual. Today, not so much. The revolution for human equality can happen. It is happening. It will happen. How far and how fast is up to us.Thank you.(Applause)

00:08:00.050 --> 00:08:02.188
Now most of you, when you hear me

00:08:02.188 --> 00:08:04.913
talk about breadwinning and caregiving,

00:08:04.913 --> 00:08:08.354
instinctively translate those categories

00:08:08.354 --> 00:08:12.085
into men's work and women's work.

00:08:12.085 --> 00:08:14.921
And we don't typically challenge

00:08:14.921 --> 00:08:18.819
why men's work is advantaged.

00:08:18.819 --> 00:08:21.409
But consider a same-sex couple

00:08:21.409 --> 00:08:23.428
like my friends Sarah and Emily.

00:08:23.428 --> 00:08:25.296
They're psychiatrists.

00:08:25.296 --> 00:08:27.125
They got married five years ago,

00:08:27.125 --> 00:08:30.406
and now they have two-year-old twins.

00:08:30.406 --> 00:08:32.478
They love being mothers,

00:08:32.478 --> 00:08:34.046
but they also love their work,

00:08:34.046 --> 00:08:36.256
and they're really good at what they do.

00:08:36.256 --> 00:08:38.277
So how are they going to divide up

00:08:38.277 --> 00:08:40.754
breadwinning and caregiving responsibilities?

00:08:40.754 --> 00:08:42.839
Should one of them stop working

00:08:42.839 --> 00:08:45.531
or reduce hours to be home?

00:08:45.531 --> 00:08:48.210
Or should they both change their practices

00:08:48.210 --> 00:08:51.493
so they can have much more flexible schedules?

00:08:51.493 --> 00:08:53.464
And what criteria should they use

00:08:53.464 --> 00:08:54.758
to make that decision?

00:08:54.758 --> 00:08:56.532
Is it who makes the most money

00:08:56.532 --> 00:09:00.309
or who is most committed to her career?

00:09:00.309 --> 00:09:04.870
Or who has the most flexible boss?

00:09:04.870 --> 00:09:08.195
The same-sex perspective helps us see

00:09:08.195 --> 00:09:10.659
that juggling work and family

00:09:10.659 --> 00:09:12.770
are not women's problems,

00:09:12.770 --> 00:09:15.408
they're family problems.

00:09:15.408 --> 00:09:18.431
And Sarah and Emily are the lucky ones,

00:09:18.431 --> 00:09:20.200
because they have a choice

00:09:20.200 --> 00:09:22.737
about how much they want to work.

00:09:22.737 --> 00:09:25.566
Millions of men and women

00:09:25.566 --> 00:09:28.903
have to be both breadwinners and caregivers

00:09:28.903 --> 00:09:32.443
just to earn the income they need,

00:09:32.443 --> 00:09:34.991
and many of those workers are scrambling.

00:09:34.991 --> 00:09:37.875
They're patching together care arrangements

00:09:37.875 --> 00:09:39.048
that are inadequate

00:09:39.048 --> 00:09:41.459
and often actually unsafe.

00:09:41.459 --> 00:09:46.149
If breadwinning and caregiving are really equal,

00:09:46.149 --> 00:09:47.737
then why shouldn't a government

00:09:47.737 --> 00:09:51.553
invest as much in an infrastructure of care

00:09:51.553 --> 00:09:55.412
as the foundation of a healthy society

00:09:55.412 --> 00:09:58.524
as it invests in physical infrastructure

00:09:58.524 --> 00:10:02.400
as the backbone of a successful economy?

00:10:02.400 --> 00:10:04.736
The governments that get it --

00:10:04.736 --> 00:10:06.583
no surprises here --

00:10:06.583 --> 00:10:08.423
the governments that get it,

00:10:08.423 --> 00:10:13.128
Norway, Sweden, Denmark, the Netherlands,

00:10:13.128 --> 00:10:16.058
provide universal child care,

00:10:16.058 --> 00:10:18.177
support for caregivers at home,

00:10:18.177 --> 00:10:21.344
school and early childhood education,

00:10:21.344 --> 00:10:23.554
protections for pregnant women,

00:10:23.554 --> 00:10:27.939
and care for the elderly and the disabled.

00:10:27.939 --> 00:10:31.620
Those governments invest in that infrastructure

00:10:31.620 --> 00:10:34.949
the same way they invest in roads and bridges

00:10:34.949 --> 00:10:38.084
and tunnels and trains.

00:10:38.084 --> 00:10:40.492
Those societies also show you

00:10:40.492 --> 00:10:42.782
that breadwinning and caregiving

00:10:42.782 --> 00:10:45.166
reinforce each other.

00:10:45.166 --> 00:10:51.005
They routinely rank among the top 15 countries

00:10:51.005 --> 00:10:54.338
of the most globally competitive economies,

00:10:54.338 --> 00:10:55.990
but at the same time,

00:10:55.990 --> 00:11:00.681
they rank very high on the OECD Better Life Index.

00:11:00.681 --> 00:11:04.217
In fact, they rank higher than other governments,

00:11:04.217 --> 00:11:06.886
like my own, the U.S., or Switzerland,

00:11:06.886 --> 00:11:09.815
that have higher average levels of income

00:11:09.815 --> 00:11:15.578
but lower rankings on work-life balance.

00:11:15.578 --> 00:11:18.254
So changing our workplaces

00:11:18.254 --> 00:11:21.550
and building infrastructures of care

00:11:21.550 --> 00:11:23.025
would make a big difference,

00:11:23.025 --> 00:11:27.509
but we're not going to get equally valued choices

00:11:27.509 --> 00:11:30.014
unless we change our culture,

00:11:30.014 --> 00:11:33.155
and the kind of cultural change required

00:11:33.155 --> 00:11:35.910
means re-socializing men.

00:11:35.910 --> 00:11:39.584
(Applause)

00:11:39.584 --> 00:11:41.319
Increasingly in developed countries,

00:11:41.319 --> 00:11:44.401
women are socialized to believe that our place

00:11:44.401 --> 00:11:48.061
is no longer only in the home,

00:11:48.061 --> 00:11:52.957
but men are actually still where they always were.

00:11:52.957 --> 00:11:56.355
Men are still socialized to believe

00:11:56.355 --> 00:11:58.610
that they have to be breadwinners,

00:11:58.610 --> 00:12:01.485
that to derive their self-worth

00:12:01.485 --> 00:12:04.364
from how high they can climb over other men

00:12:04.364 --> 00:12:06.709
on a career ladder.

00:12:06.709 --> 00:12:09.492
The feminist revolution still has a long way to go.

00:12:09.492 --> 00:12:11.394
It's certainly not complete.

00:12:11.394 --> 00:12:13.050
But 60 years after

00:12:13.050 --> 00:12:15.360
"The Feminine
Mystique" was published,

00:12:15.360 --> 00:12:17.661
many women actually have

00:12:17.661 --> 00:12:20.639
more choices than men do.

00:12:20.639 --> 00:12:23.367
We can decide to be a breadwinner,

00:12:23.367 --> 00:12:27.514
a caregiver, or any combination of the two.

00:12:27.514 --> 00:12:30.040
When a man, on the other hand,

00:12:30.040 --> 00:12:32.929
decides to be a caregiver,

00:12:32.929 --> 00:12:36.233
he puts his manhood on the line.

00:12:36.233 --> 00:12:39.453
His friends may praise his decision,

00:12:39.453 --> 00:12:43.325
but underneath, they're scratching their heads.

00:12:43.325 --> 00:12:46.426
Isn't the measure of a man

00:12:46.426 --> 00:12:49.357
his willingness to compete with other men

00:12:49.357 --> 00:12:51.737
for power and prestige?

00:12:51.737 --> 00:12:55.833
And as many women hold that view as men do.

00:12:55.833 --> 00:12:58.799
We know that lots of women

00:12:58.799 --> 00:13:02.118
still judge the attractiveness of a man

00:13:02.118 --> 00:13:04.843
based in large part on how successful he is

00:13:04.843 --> 00:13:06.340
in his career.

00:13:06.340 --> 00:13:08.691
A woman can drop out of the work force

00:13:08.691 --> 00:13:10.851
and still be an attractive partner.

00:13:10.851 --> 00:13:15.390
For a man, that's a risky proposition.

00:13:15.390 --> 00:13:17.631
So as parents and partners,

00:13:17.631 --> 00:13:20.818
we should be socializing our sons

00:13:20.818 --> 00:13:23.269
and our husbands

00:13:23.269 --> 00:13:26.593
to be whatever they want to be,

00:13:26.593 --> 00:13:30.212
either caregivers or breadwinners.

00:13:30.212 --> 00:13:33.568
We should be socializing them to make caregiving

00:13:33.568 --> 00:13:35.555
cool for guys.

00:13:35.555 --> 00:13:39.320
(Applause)

00:13:39.320 --> 00:13:45.632
I can almost hear lots of you thinking, "No way."

00:13:45.632 --> 00:13:50.279
But in fact, the change is 
actually already happening.

00:13:50.279 --> 00:13:52.236
At least in the United States,

00:13:52.236 --> 00:13:54.460
lots of men take pride in cooking,

00:13:54.460 --> 00:13:57.776
and frankly obsess over stoves.

00:13:57.776 --> 00:14:00.763
They are in the birthing rooms.

00:14:00.763 --> 00:14:03.407
They take paternity leave when they can.

00:14:03.407 --> 00:14:05.869
They can walk a baby or soothe a toddler

00:14:05.869 --> 00:14:08.511
just as well as their wives can,

00:14:08.511 --> 00:14:10.260
and they are increasingly

00:14:10.260 --> 00:14:12.827
doing much more of the housework.

00:14:12.827 --> 00:14:14.915
Indeed, there are male college students now

00:14:14.915 --> 00:14:16.442
who are starting to say,

00:14:16.442 --> 00:14:18.318
"I want to be a stay-at-home dad."

00:14:18.318 --> 00:14:20.569
That was completely unthinkable

00:14:20.569 --> 00:14:23.436
50 or even 30 years ago.

00:14:23.436 --> 00:14:26.327
And in Norway, where men have

00:14:26.327 --> 00:14:29.116
an automatic three month's paternity leave,

00:14:29.116 --> 00:14:32.453
but they lose it if they decide not to take it,

00:14:32.453 --> 00:14:34.378
a high government official told me

00:14:34.378 --> 00:14:36.610
that companies are starting to look

00:14:36.610 --> 00:14:38.695
at prospective male employees

00:14:38.695 --> 00:14:42.673
and raise an eyebrow if they didn't in fact

00:14:42.673 --> 00:14:45.069
take their leave when they had kids.

00:14:45.069 --> 00:14:47.898
That means that it's starting to seem

00:14:47.898 --> 00:14:50.100
like a character defect

00:14:50.100 --> 00:14:54.320
not to want to be a fully engaged father.

00:14:57.379 --> 00:15:02.901
So I was raised

00:15:02.901 --> 00:15:06.550
to believe that championing women's rights

00:15:06.550 --> 00:15:08.669
meant doing everything we could

00:15:08.669 --> 00:15:10.443
to get women to the top.

00:15:10.443 --> 00:15:13.162
And I still hope that I live long enough

00:15:13.162 --> 00:15:16.425
to see men and women equally represented

00:15:16.425 --> 00:15:19.472
at all levels of the work force.

00:15:19.472 --> 00:15:23.571
But I've come to believe that we have to value family

00:15:23.571 --> 00:15:26.403
every bit as much as we value work,

00:15:26.403 --> 00:15:28.915
and that we should entertain the idea

00:15:28.915 --> 00:15:32.464
that doing right by those we love

00:15:32.464 --> 00:15:36.380
will make all of us better at everything we do.

00:15:36.380 --> 00:15:38.448
Thirty years ago, Carol Gilligan,

00:15:38.448 --> 00:15:41.405
a wonderful psychologist, studied adolescent girls

00:15:41.405 --> 00:15:44.462
and identified an ethic of care,

00:15:44.462 --> 00:15:47.617
an element of human nature every bit as important

00:15:47.617 --> 00:15:49.604
as the ethic of justice.

00:15:49.604 --> 00:15:52.909
It turns out that "you don't care"

00:15:52.909 --> 00:15:55.830
is just as much a part of who we are

00:15:55.830 --> 00:15:58.110
as "that's not fair."

00:15:58.110 --> 00:15:59.910
Bill Gates agrees.

00:15:59.910 --> 00:16:03.081
He argues that the two great forces of human nature

00:16:03.081 --> 00:16:07.288
are self-interest and caring for others.

00:16:07.288 --> 00:16:09.930
Let's bring them both together.

00:16:09.930 --> 00:16:12.589
Let's make the feminist revolution

00:16:12.589 --> 00:16:15.321
a humanist revolution.

00:16:15.321 --> 00:16:17.065
As whole human beings,

00:16:17.065 --> 00:16:20.909
we will be better caregivers and breadwinners.

00:16:20.909 --> 00:16:23.017
You may think that can't happen,

00:16:23.017 --> 00:16:24.717
but I grew up in a society

00:16:24.717 --> 00:16:27.063
where my mother put out small vases

00:16:27.063 --> 00:16:29.725
of cigarettes for dinner parties,

00:16:29.725 --> 00:16:33.918
where blacks and whites used separate bathrooms,

00:16:33.918 --> 00:16:39.448
and where everybody claimed to be heterosexual.

00:16:40.560 --> 00:16:44.999
Today, not so much.

00:16:44.999 --> 00:16:48.639
The revolution for human equality

00:16:48.639 --> 00:16:50.429
can happen.

00:16:50.429 --> 00:16:52.675
It is happening.

00:16:52.675 --> 00:16:54.957
It will happen.

00:16:54.957 --> 00:16:59.675
How far and how fast is up to us.

00:16:59.675 --> 00:17:01.818
Thank you.

00:17:01.818 --> 00:17:05.818
(Applause)

title: You don't need an app for that
transcript: Let me start by asking you a question, just with a show of hands: Who has an iPhone? Who has an Android phone? Who has a Blackberry? Who will admit in public to having a Blackberry? (Laughter)And let me guess, how many of you, when you arrived here, like me, went and bought a pay-as-you-go SIM card? Yeah? I'll bet you didn't even know you're using African technology. Pay-as-you-go was a technology, or an idea, pioneered in Africa by a company called Vodacom a good 15 years ago, and now, like franchising, pay-as-you-go is one of the most dominant forces of economic activity in the world.So I'm going to talk about innovation in Africa, which I think is the purest form, innovation out of necessity. But first, I'm going to ask you some other questions. You don't have to put your hands up. These are rhetorical.Why did Nikola Tesla have to invent the alternating current that powers the lights in this building or the city that we're in?Why did Henry Ford have to invent the production line to produce these Fords that came in anything as long as they were black?And why did Eric Merrifield have to invent the dolos? Blank stares. That is what a dolos looks like, and in the background, you can see Robben Island. This is a small dolos, and Eric Merrifield is the most famous inventor you've never heard of. In 1963, a storm ripped up the harbor in a small South African town called East London, and while he was watching his kids playing with toys made from oxen bones called dolosse, he had the idea for this. It's a bit like a huge jumping jack, and they have used this in every harbor in the world as a breakwater. The global shipping economy would not be possible without African technology like this.So whenever you talk about Africa, you have to put up this picture of the world from space, and people go, "Look, it's the Dark Continent." Actually, it isn't. What it is is a map of innovation. And it's really easy to see where innovation's going on. All the places with lots of electricity, it isn't. (Laughter) (Applause) And the reason it isn't is because everybody's watching television or playing Angry Birds. (Laughter) (Applause)So where it's happening is in Africa. Now, this is real innovation, not the way people have expropriated the word to talk about launching new products. This is real innovation, and I define it as problem-solving. People are solving real problems in Africa. Why? Because we have to. Because we have real problems. And when we solve real problems for people, we solve them for the rest of the world at the same time.So in California, everybody's really excited about a little square of plastic that you plug into a phone and you can swipe your credit card, and people say, "We've liberated the credit card from the point of sale terminal." Fantastic. Why do you even need a credit card? In Africa, we've been doing that for years, and we've been doing it on phones like this. This is a picture I took at a place called Kitengela, about an hour south of Nairobi, and the thing that's so remarkable about the payment system that's been pioneered in Africa called M-Pesa is that it works on phones like this. It works on every single phone possible, because it uses SMS. You can pay bills with it,  you can buy your groceries, you can pay your kids' school fees, and I'm told you can even bribe customs officials. (Laughter) Something like 25 million dollars a day is transacted through M-Pesa. Forty percent of Kenya's GDP moves through M-Pesa using phones like this.And you think this is just a feature phone. Actually it's the smartphone of Africa. It's also a radio, and it's also a torch, and more than anything else, it has really superb battery life. Why? Because that's what we need. We have really severe energy problems in Africa. By the way, you can update Facebook and send Gmail from a phone like this.So we have found a way to use the available technology to send money via M-Pesa, which is a bit like a check system for the mobile age. I come from Johannesburg, which is a mining town. It's built on gold. This is a picture I Instagrammed earlier. And the difference today is that  the gold of today is mobile. If you think about the railroad system in North America and how that worked, first came the infrastructure, then came the industry around it, the brothels — it's a bit like the Internet today, right? — and everything else that worked with it: bars, saloons, etc. The gold of today is mobile, and mobile is the enabler that makes all of this possible.So what are some of the things that you can do with it? Well, this is by a guy called Bright Simons from Ghana, and what you do is you take medication, something that some people might spend their entire month's salary on, and you scratch off the code, and you send that to an SMS number, and it tells you if that is legitimate or if it's expired. Really simple, really effective, really life-saving. In Kenya, there's a service called iCow, which just sends you really important information about how to look after your dairy. The dairy business in Kenya is a $463 million business, and the difference between a subsistence farmer and an abundance farmer is only a couple of liters of milk a day. And if you can do that, you can rise out of poverty. Really simple, using a basic phone. If you don't have electricity, no problem! We'll just make it out of old bicycle parts using a windmill, as William Kamkwamba did. There's another great African that you've heard that's busy disrupting the automobile industry in the world. He's also finding a way to reinvent solar power and the electricity industry in North America, and if he's lucky, he'll get us to Mars, hopefully in my lifetime. He comes from Pretoria, the capital of [South Africa], about 50 kilometers from where I live. So back to Joburg, which is sometimes called Egoli, which means City of Gold. And not only is mobile the gold of today, I don't believe that the gold is under the ground. I believe we are the gold. Like you've heard the other economists say, we are at the point where China was when its boom years began, and that's where we're going.So, you hear the West talk about innovation at the edge. Well, of course it's happening at the edge, because in the middle, everybody's updating Facebook, or worse still, they're trying to understand Facebook's privacy settings. (Laughter) This is not that catchy catchphrase. This is innovation over the edge.So, people like to call Africa a mobile-first continent, but actually it's mobile-only, so while everybody else is doing all of those things, we're solving the world's problems. So there's only one thing left to say.["You're welcome"] (Laughter)(Applause)
