and as a society, it's costing us dearly.

00:12:35.102 --> 00:12:38.978
We know that the brain is
capable of extraordinary change,

00:12:38.978 --> 00:12:42.017
and the best way to achieve that,

00:12:42.017 --> 00:12:44.429
even in adults, is to change and modulate

00:12:44.429 --> 00:12:46.224
our environment.

00:12:46.224 --> 00:12:49.109
The second thing I have learned

00:12:49.109 --> 00:12:51.735
is that we need to create an alliance

00:12:51.735 --> 00:12:55.236
of people who believe that science is integral

00:12:55.236 --> 00:12:57.518
to bringing about social change.

00:12:57.518 --> 00:13:00.491
It's easy enough for a neuroscientist to place

00:13:00.491 --> 00:13:02.670
a high-security inmate in an MRI scanner.

00:13:02.670 --> 00:13:05.178
Well actually, that turns out not to be so easy,

00:13:05.178 --> 00:13:07.837
but ultimately what we want to show

00:13:07.837 --> 00:13:11.605
is whether we're able to
reduce the reoffending rates.

00:13:11.605 --> 00:13:14.326
In order to answer complex questions like that,

00:13:14.326 --> 00:13:16.977
we need people of different backgrounds --

00:13:16.977 --> 00:13:19.181
lab-based scientists and clinicians,

00:13:19.181 --> 00:13:21.571
social workers and policy makers,

00:13:21.571 --> 00:13:24.194
philanthropists and human rights activists —

00:13:24.194 --> 00:13:26.120
to work together.

00:13:26.120 --> 00:13:27.807
Finally, I believe we need

00:13:27.807 --> 00:13:29.445
to change our own amygdalae,

00:13:29.445 --> 00:13:32.226
because this issue goes to the heart

00:13:32.226 --> 00:13:33.997
not just of who Joe is,

00:13:33.997 --> 00:13:35.909
but who we are.

00:13:35.909 --> 00:13:38.889
We need to change our view of Joe

00:13:38.889 --> 00:13:42.691
as someone wholly irredeemable,

00:13:42.691 --> 00:13:46.201
because if we see Joe as wholly irredeemable,

00:13:46.201 --> 00:13:50.481
how is he going to see himself as any different?

00:13:50.481 --> 00:13:52.352
In another decade, Joe will be released

00:13:52.352 --> 00:13:55.021
from Wormwood Scrubs.

00:13:55.021 --> 00:13:57.938
Will he be among the 70 percent of inmates

00:13:57.938 --> 00:13:59.432
who end up reoffending

00:13:59.432 --> 00:14:02.214
and returning to the prison system?

00:14:02.214 --> 00:14:04.850
Wouldn't it be better if, while serving his sentence,

00:14:04.850 --> 00:14:06.776
Joe was able to train his amygdala,

00:14:06.776 --> 00:14:09.130
which would stimulate the growth of new brain cells

00:14:09.130 --> 00:14:10.411
and connections,

00:14:10.411 --> 00:14:13.007
so that he will be able to face the world

00:14:13.007 --> 00:14:15.127
once he gets released?

00:14:15.127 --> 00:14:19.591
Surely, that would be in the interest of all of us.

00:14:21.507 --> 00:14:24.758
(Applause)

00:14:24.758 --> 00:14:28.760
Thank you. (Applause)

title: Here's how we take back the Internet
transcript: Chris Anderson: The rights of citizens, the future of the Internet. So I would like to welcome to the TED stage the man behind those revelations, Ed Snowden. (Applause) Ed is in a remote location somewhere in Russia controlling this bot from his laptop, so he can see what the bot can see. Ed, welcome to the TED stage. What can you see, as a matter of fact?Edward Snowden: Ha, I can see everyone. This is amazing. (Laughter)CA: Ed, some questions for you. You've been called many things in the last few months. You've been called a whistleblower, a traitor, a hero. What words would you describe yourself with?ES: You know, everybody who is involved with this debate has been struggling over me and my personality and how to describe me. But when I think about it, this isn't the question that we should be struggling with. Who I am really doesn't matter at all. If I'm the worst person in the world, you can hate me and move on. What really matters here are the issues. What really matters here is the kind of government we want, the kind of Internet we want, the kind of relationship between people and societies. And that's what I'm hoping the debate will move towards, and we've seen that increasing over time. If I had to describe myself, I wouldn't use words like "hero." I wouldn't use "patriot," and I wouldn't use "traitor." I'd say I'm an American and I'm a citizen, just like everyone else.CA: So just to give some context for those who don't know the whole story — (Applause) — this time a year ago, you were stationed in Hawaii working as a consultant to the NSA. As a sysadmin, you had access to their systems, and you began revealing certain classified documents to some handpicked journalists leading the way to June's revelations. Now, what propelled you to do this? ES: You know, when I was sitting in Hawaii, and the years before, when I was working in the intelligence community, I saw a lot of things that had disturbed me. We do a lot of good things in the intelligence community, things that need to be done, and things that help everyone. But there are also things that go too far. There are things that shouldn't be done, and decisions that were being made in secret without the public's awareness, without the public's consent, and without even our representatives in government having knowledge of these programs. When I really came to struggle with these issues, I thought to myself, how can I do this in the most responsible way, that maximizes the public benefit while minimizing the risks? And out of all the solutions that I could come up with, out of going to Congress, when there were no laws, there were no legal protections for a private employee, a contractor in intelligence like myself, there was a risk that I would be buried along with the information and the public would never find out. But the First Amendment of the United States Constitution guarantees us a free press for a reason, and that's to enable an adversarial press, to challenge the government, but also to work together with the government, to have a dialogue and debate about how we can inform the public about matters of vital importance without putting our national security at risk. And by working with journalists, by giving all of my information back to the American people, rather than trusting myself to make the decisions about publication, we've had a robust debate with a deep investment by the government that I think has resulted in a benefit for everyone. And the risks that have been threatened, the risks that have been played up by the government have never materialized. We've never seen any evidence of even a single instance of specific harm, and because of that, I'm comfortable with the decisions that I made.CA: So let me show the audience a couple of examples of what you revealed. If we could have a slide up, and Ed, I don't know whether you can see, the slides are here. This is a slide of the PRISM program, and maybe you could tell the audience what that was that was revealed.ES: The best way to understand PRISM, because there's been a little bit of controversy, is to first talk about what PRISM isn't. Much of the debate in the U.S. has been about metadata. They've said it's just metadata, it's just metadata, and they're talking about a specific legal authority called Section 215 of the Patriot Act. That allows sort of a warrantless wiretapping, mass surveillance of the entire country's phone records, things like that — who you're talking to, when you're talking to them, where you traveled. These are all metadata events. PRISM is about content. It's a program through which the government could compel corporate America, it could deputize corporate America to do its dirty work for the NSA. And even though some of these companies did resist, even though some of them — I believe Yahoo was one of them — challenged them in court, they all lost, because it was never tried by an open court. They were only tried by a secret court. And something that we've seen, something about the PRISM program that's very concerning to me is, there's been a talking point in the U.S. government where they've said 15 federal judges have reviewed these programs and found them to be lawful, but what they don't tell you is those are secret judges in a secret court based on secret interpretations of law that's considered 34,000 warrant requests over 33 years, and in 33 years only rejected 11 government requests. These aren't the people that we want deciding what the role of corporate America in a free and open Internet should be.CA: Now, this slide that we're showing here shows the dates in which different technology companies, Internet companies, are alleged to have joined the program, and where data collection began from them. Now, they have denied collaborating with the NSA. How was that data collected by the NSA?ES: Right. So the NSA's own slides refer to it as direct access. What that means to an actual NSA analyst, someone like me who was working as an intelligence analyst targeting, Chinese cyber-hackers, things like that, in Hawaii, is the provenance of that data is directly from their servers. It doesn't mean that there's a group of company representatives sitting in a smoky room with the NSA palling around and making back-room deals about how they're going to give this stuff away. Now each company handles it different ways. Some are responsible. Some are somewhat less responsible. But the bottom line is, when we talk about how this information is given, it's coming from the companies themselves. It's not stolen from the lines. But there's an important thing to remember here: even though companies pushed back, even though companies demanded, hey, let's do this through a warrant process, let's do this where we actually have some sort of legal review, some sort of basis for handing over these users' data, we saw stories in the Washington Post last year that weren't as well reported as the PRISM story that said the NSA broke in to the data center communications between Google to itself and Yahoo to itself. So even these companies that are cooperating in at least a compelled but hopefully lawful manner with the NSA, the NSA isn't satisfied with that, and because of that, we need our companies to work very hard to guarantee that they're going to represent the interests of the user, and also advocate for the rights of the users. And I think over the last year, we've seen the companies that are named on the PRISM slides take great strides to do that, and I encourage them to continue.CA: What more should they do?ES: The biggest thing that an Internet company in America can do today, right now, without consulting with lawyers, to protect the rights of users worldwide, is to enable SSL web encryption on every page you visit. The reason this matters is today, if you go to look at a copy of "1984" on Amazon.com, the NSA can see a record of that, the Russian intelligence service can see a record of that, the Chinese service can see a record of that, the French service, the German service, the services of Andorra. They can all see it because it's unencrypted. The world's library is Amazon.com, but not only do they not support encryption by default, you cannot choose to use encryption when browsing through books. This is something that we need to change, not just for Amazon, I don't mean to single them out, but they're a great example. All companies need to move to an encrypted browsing habit by default for all users who haven't taken any action or picked any special methods on their own. That'll increase the privacy and the rights that people enjoy worldwide.CA: Ed, come with me to this part of the stage. I want to show you the next slide here. (Applause) This is a program called Boundless Informant. What is that?ES: So, I've got to give credit to the NSA for using appropriate names on this. This is one of my favorite NSA cryptonyms. Boundless Informant is a program that the NSA hid from Congress. The NSA was previously asked by Congress, was there any ability that they had to even give a rough ballpark estimate of the amount of American communications that were being intercepted. They said no. They said, we don't track those stats, and we can't track those stats. We can't tell you how many communications we're intercepting around the world, because to tell you that would be to invade your privacy. Now, I really appreciate that sentiment from them, but the reality, when you look at this slide is, not only do they have the capability, the capability already exists. It's already in place. The NSA has its own internal data format that tracks both ends of a communication, and if it says, this communication came from America, they can tell Congress how many of those communications they have today, right now. And what Boundless Informant tells us is more communications are being intercepted in America about Americans than there are in Russia about Russians. I'm not sure that's what an intelligence agency should be aiming for.CA: Ed, there was a story broken in the Washington Post, again from your data. The headline says, "NSA broke privacy rules thousands of times per year." Tell us about that.ES: We also heard in Congressional testimony last year, it was an amazing thing for someone like me who came from the NSA and who's seen the actual internal documents, knows what's in them, to see officials testifying under oath that there had been no abuses, that there had been no violations of the NSA's rules, when we knew this story was coming. But what's especially interesting about this, about the fact that the NSA has violated their own rules, their own laws thousands of times in a single year, including one event by itself, one event out of those 2,776, that affected more than 3,000 people. In another event, they intercepted all the calls in Washington, D.C., by accident. What's amazing about this, this report, that didn't get that much attention, is the fact that not only were there 2,776 abuses, the chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee, Dianne Feinstein, had not seen this report until the Washington Post contacted her asking for comment on the report. And she then requested a copy from the NSA and received it, but had never seen this before that. What does that say about the state of oversight in American intelligence when the chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee has no idea that the rules are being broken thousands of times every year?CA: Ed, one response to this whole debate is this: Why should we care about all this surveillance, honestly? I mean, look, if you've done nothing wrong, you've got nothing to worry about. What's wrong with that point of view? ES: Well, so the first thing is, you're giving up your rights. You're saying hey, you know, I don't think I'm going to need them, so I'm just going to trust that, you know, let's get rid of them, it doesn't really matter, these guys are going to do the right thing. Your rights matter because you never know when you're going to need them. Beyond that, it's a part of our cultural identity, not just in America, but in Western societies and in democratic societies around the world. People should be able to pick up the phone and to call their family, people should be able to send a text message to their loved ones, people should be able to buy a book online, they should be able to travel by train, they should be able to buy an airline ticket without wondering about how these events are going to look to an agent of the government, possibly not even your government years in the future, how they're going to be misinterpreted and what they're going to think your intentions were. We have a right to privacy. We require warrants to be based on probable cause or some kind of individualized suspicion because we recognize that trusting anybody, any government authority, with the entirety of human communications in secret and without oversight is simply too great a temptation to be ignored.CA: Some people are furious at what you've done. I heard a quote recently from Dick Cheney who said that Julian Assange was a flea bite, Edward Snowden is the lion that bit the head off the dog. He thinks you've committed one of the worst acts of betrayal in American history. What would you say to people who think that?ES: Dick Cheney's really something else. (Laughter) (Applause) Thank you. (Laughter) I think it's amazing, because at the time Julian Assange was doing some of his greatest work, Dick Cheney was saying he was going to end governments worldwide, the skies were going to ignite and the seas were going to boil off, and now he's saying it's a flea bite. So we should be suspicious about the same sort of overblown claims of damage to national security from these kind of officials. But let's assume that these people really believe this. I would argue that they have kind of a narrow conception of national security. The prerogatives of people like Dick Cheney do not keep the nation safe. The public interest is not always the same as the national interest. Going to war with people who are not our enemy in places that are not a threat doesn't make us safe, and that applies whether it's in Iraq or on the Internet. The Internet is not the enemy. Our economy is not the enemy. American businesses, Chinese businesses, and any other company out there is a part of our society. It's a part of our interconnected world. There are ties of fraternity that bond us together, and if we destroy these bonds by undermining the standards, the security, the manner of behavior, that nations and citizens all around the world expect us to abide by.CA: But it's alleged that you've stolen 1.7 million documents. It seems only a few hundred of them have been shared with journalists so far. Are there more revelations to come?ES: There are absolutely more revelations to come. I don't think there's any question that some of the most important reporting to be done is yet to come.CA: Come here, because I want to ask you about this particular revelation. Come and take a look at this. I mean, this is a story which I think for a lot of the techies in this room is the single most shocking thing that they have heard in the last few months. It's about a program called "Bullrun." Can you explain what that is?ES: So Bullrun, and this is again where we've got to thank the NSA for their candor, this is a program named after a Civil War battle. The British counterpart is called Edgehill, which is a U.K. civil war battle. And the reason that I believe they're named this way is because they target our own infrastructure. They're programs through which the NSA intentionally misleads corporate partners. They tell corporate partners that these are safe standards. They say hey, we need to work with you to secure your systems, but in reality, they're giving bad advice to these companies that makes them degrade the security of their services. They're building in backdoors that not only the NSA can exploit, but anyone else who has time and money to research and find it can then use to let themselves in to the world's communications. And this is really dangerous, because if we lose a single standard, if we lose the trust of something like SSL, which was specifically targeted by the Bullrun program, we will live a less safe world overall. We won't be able to access our banks and we won't be able to access commerce without worrying about people monitoring those communications or subverting them for their own ends.CA: And do those same decisions also potentially open America up to cyberattacks from other sources?ES: Absolutely. One of the problems, one of the dangerous legacies that we've seen in the post-9/11 era, is that the NSA has traditionally worn two hats. They've been in charge of offensive operations, that is hacking, but they've also been in charge of defensive operations, and traditionally they've always prioritized defense over offense based on the principle that American secrets are simply worth more. If we hack a Chinese business and steal their secrets, if we hack a government office in Berlin and steal their secrets, that has less value to the American people than making sure that the Chinese can't get access to our secrets. So by reducing the security of our communications, they're not only putting the world at risk, they're putting America at risk in a fundamental way, because intellectual property is the basis, the foundation of our economy, and if we put that at risk through weak security, we're going to be paying for it for years.CA: But they've made a calculation that it was worth doing this as part of America's defense against terrorism. Surely that makes it a price worth paying.ES: Well, when you look at the results of these programs in stopping terrorism, you will see that that's unfounded, and you don't have to take my word for it, because we've had the first open court, the first federal court that's reviewed this, outside the secrecy arrangement, called these programs Orwellian and likely unconstitutional. Congress, who has access to be briefed on these things, and now has the desire to be, has produced bills to reform it, and two independent White House panels who reviewed all of the classified evidence said these programs have never stopped a single terrorist attack that was imminent in the United States. So is it really terrorism that we're stopping? Do these programs have any value at all? I say no, and all three branches of the American government say no as well.CA: I mean, do you think there's a deeper motivation for them than the war against terrorism?ES: I'm sorry, I couldn't hear you, say again?CA: Sorry. Do you think there's a deeper motivation for them other than the war against terrorism?ES: Yeah. The bottom line is that terrorism has always been what we in the intelligence world would call a cover for action. Terrorism is something that provokes an emotional response that allows people to rationalize authorizing powers and programs that they wouldn't give otherwise. The Bullrun and Edgehill-type programs, the NSA asked for these authorities back in the 1990s. They asked the FBI to go to Congress and make the case. The FBI went to Congress and did make the case. But Congress and the American people said no. They said, it's not worth the risk to our economy. They said it's worth too much damage to our society to justify the gains. But what we saw is, in the post-9/11 era, they used secrecy and they used the justification of terrorism to start these programs in secret without asking Congress, without asking the American people, and it's that kind of government behind closed doors that we need to guard ourselves against, because it makes us less safe, and it offers no value.CA: Okay, come with me here for a sec, because I've got a more personal question for you. Speaking of terror, most people would find the situation you're in right now in Russia pretty terrifying. You obviously heard what happened, what the treatment that Bradley Manning got, Chelsea Manning as now is, and there was a story in Buzzfeed saying that there are people in the intelligence community who want you dead. How are you coping with this? How are you coping with the fear?ES: It's no mystery that there are governments out there that want to see me dead. I've made clear again and again and again that I go to sleep every morning thinking about what I can do for the American people. I don't want to harm my government. I want to help my government, but the fact that they are willing to completely ignore due process, they're willing to declare guilt without ever seeing a trial, these are things that we need to work against as a society, and say hey, this is not appropriate. We shouldn't be threatening dissidents. We shouldn't be criminalizing journalism. And whatever part I can do to see that end, I'm happy to do despite the risks.CA: So I'd actually like to get some feedback from the audience here, because I know there's widely differing reactions to Edward Snowden. Suppose you had the following two choices, right? You could view what he did as fundamentally a reckless act that has endangered America or you could view it as fundamentally a heroic act that will work towards America and the world's long-term good? Those are the two choices I'll give you. I'm curious to see who's willing to vote with the first of those, that this was a reckless act? There are some hands going up. Some hands going up. It's hard to put your hand up when the man is standing right here, but I see them.ES: I can see you. (Laughter)CA: And who goes with the second choice, the fundamentally heroic act?(Applause) (Cheers)And I think it's true to say that there are a lot of people who didn't show a hand and I think are still thinking this through, because it seems to me that the debate around you doesn't split along traditional political lines. It's not left or right, it's not really about pro-government, libertarian, or not just that. Part of it is almost a generational issue. You're part of a generation that grew up with the Internet, and it seems as if you become offended at almost a visceral level when you see something done that you think will harm the Internet. Is there some truth to that?ES: It is. I think it's very true. This is not a left or right issue. Our basic freedoms, and when I say our, I don't just mean Americans, I mean people around the world, it's not a partisan issue. These are things that all people believe, and it's up to all of us to protect them, and to people who have seen and enjoyed a free and open Internet, it's up to us to preserve that liberty for the next generation to enjoy, and if we don't change things, if we don't stand up to make the changes we need to do to keep the Internet safe, not just for us but for everyone, we're going to lose that, and that would be a tremendous loss, not just for us, but for the world.CA: Well, I have heard similar language recently from the founder of the world wide web, who I actually think is with us, Sir Tim Berners-Lee. Tim, actually, would you like to come up and say, do we have a microphone for Tim?(Applause)Tim, good to see you. Come up there. Which camp are you in, by the way, traitor, hero? I have a theory on this, but —Tim Berners-Lee: I've given much longer answers to that question, but hero, if I have to make the choice between the two.CA: And Ed, I think you've read the proposal that Sir Tim has talked about about a new Magna Carta to take back the Internet. Is that something that makes sense? ES: Absolutely. I mean, my generation, I grew up not just thinking about the Internet, but I grew up in the Internet, and although I never expected to have the chance to defend it in such a direct and practical manner and to embody it in this unusual, almost avatar manner, I think there's something poetic about the fact that one of the sons of the Internet has actually become close to the Internet as a result of their political expression. And I believe that a Magna Carta for the Internet is exactly what we need. We need to encode our values not just in writing but in the structure of the Internet, and it's something that I hope, I invite everyone in the audience, not just here in Vancouver but around the world, to join and participate in.CA: Do you have a question for Ed?TBL: Well, two questions, a general question —CA: Ed, can you still hear us?ES: Yes, I can hear you. CA: Oh, he's back.TBL: The wiretap on your line got a little interfered with for a moment. (Laughter)ES: It's a little bit of an NSA problem.TBL: So, from the 25 years, stepping back and thinking, what would you think would be the best that we could achieve from all the discussions that we have about the web we want?ES: When we think about in terms of how far we can go, I think that's a question that's really only limited by what we're willing to put into it. I think the Internet that we've enjoyed in the past has been exactly what we as not just a nation but as a people around the world need, and by cooperating, by engaging not just the technical parts of society, but as you said, the users, the people around the world who contribute through the Internet, through social media, who just check the weather, who rely on it every day as a part of their life, to champion that. We'll get not just the Internet we've had, but a better Internet, a better now, something that we can use to build a future that'll be better not just than what we hoped for but anything that we could have imagined.CA: It's 30 years ago that TED was founded, 1984. A lot of the conversation since then has been along the lines that actually George Orwell got it wrong. It's not Big Brother watching us. We, through the power of the web, and transparency, are now watching Big Brother. Your revelations kind of drove a stake through the heart of that rather optimistic view, but you still believe there's a way of doing something about that. And you do too.ES: Right, so there is an argument to be made that the powers of Big Brother have increased enormously. There was a recent legal article at Yale that established something called the Bankston-Soltani Principle, which is that our expectation of privacy is violated when the capabilities of government surveillance have become cheaper by an order of magnitude, and each time that occurs, we need to revisit and rebalance our privacy rights. Now, that hasn't happened since the government's surveillance powers have increased by several orders of magnitude, and that's why we're in the problem that we're in today, but there is still hope, because the power of individuals have also been increased by technology. I am living proof that an individual can go head to head against the most powerful adversaries and the most powerful intelligence agencies around the world and win, and I think that's something that we need to take hope from, and we need to build on to make it accessible not just to technical experts but to ordinary citizens around the world. Journalism is not a crime, communication is not a crime, and we should not be monitored in our everyday activities.CA: I'm not quite sure how you shake the hand of a bot, but I imagine it's, this is the hand right here. TBL: That'll come very soon. ES: Nice to meet you, and I hope my beam looks as nice as my view of you guys does.CA: Thank you, Tim.(Applause)I mean, The New York Times recently called for an amnesty for you. Would you welcome the chance to come back to America?ES: Absolutely. There's really no question, the principles that have been the foundation of this project have been the public interest and the principles that underly the journalistic establishment in the United States and around the world, and I think if the press is now saying, we support this, this is something that needed to happen, that's a powerful argument, but it's not the final argument, and I think that's something that public should decide. But at the same time, the government has hinted that they want some kind of deal, that they want me to compromise the journalists with which I've been working, to come back, and I want to make it very clear that I did not do this to be safe. I did this to do what was right, and I'm not going to stop my work in the public interest just to benefit myself. (Applause)CA: In the meantime, courtesy of the Internet and this technology, you're here, back in North America, not quite the U.S., Canada, in this form. I'm curious, how does that feel?ES: Canada is different than what I expected. It's a lot warmer. (Laughter)CA: At TED, the mission is "ideas worth spreading." If you could encapsulate it in a single idea, what is your idea worth spreading right now at this moment? ES: I would say the last year has been a reminder that democracy may die behind closed doors, but we as individuals are born behind those same closed doors, and we don't have to give up our privacy to have good government. We don't have to give up our liberty to have security. And I think by working together we can have both open government and private lives, and I look forward to working with everyone around the world to see that happen.Thank you very much.CA: Ed, thank you.(Applause)
subtitle:
WEBVTT
X-TIMESTAMP-MAP=MPEGTS:900000,LOCAL:00:00:00.000

00:00:13.030 --> 00:00:15.041
Chris Anderson: The rights of citizens,

00:00:15.041 --> 00:00:17.127
the future of the Internet.

00:00:17.127 --> 00:00:20.510
So I would like to welcome to the TED stage

00:00:20.510 --> 00:00:23.336
the man behind those revelations,

00:00:23.336 --> 00:00:25.712
Ed Snowden.

00:00:25.712 --> 00:00:29.279
(Applause)

00:00:29.279 --> 00:00:33.532
Ed is in a remote location somewhere in Russia

00:00:33.532 --> 00:00:36.307
controlling this bot from his laptop,

00:00:36.307 --> 00:00:40.360
so he can see what the bot can see.

00:00:40.360 --> 00:00:42.308
Ed, welcome to the TED stage.

00:00:42.308 --> 00:00:45.919
What can you see, as a matter of fact?

00:00:45.919 --> 00:00:47.657
Edward Snowden: Ha, I can see everyone.

00:00:47.657 --> 00:00:49.907
This is amazing.

00:00:49.907 --> 00:00:53.120
(Laughter)

00:00:53.120 --> 00:00:56.403
CA: Ed, some questions for you.

00:00:56.403 --> 00:00:57.696
You've been called many things

00:00:57.696 --> 00:00:59.261
in the last few months.

00:00:59.261 --> 00:01:04.186
You've been called a whistleblower, a traitor,

00:01:04.186 --> 00:01:05.915
a hero.

00:01:05.915 --> 00:01:09.732
What words would you describe yourself with?

00:01:09.732 --> 00:01:12.394
ES: You know, everybody who is involved

00:01:12.394 --> 00:01:13.890
with this debate

00:01:13.890 --> 00:01:16.632
has been struggling over me and my personality

00:01:16.632 --> 00:01:19.681
and how to describe me.

00:01:19.681 --> 00:01:21.370
But when I think about it,

00:01:21.370 --> 00:01:24.799
this isn't the question that
we should be struggling with.

00:01:24.799 --> 00:01:27.966
Who I am really doesn't matter at all.

00:01:27.966 --> 00:01:30.678
If I'm the worst person in the world,

00:01:30.678 --> 00:01:32.635
you can hate me and move on.

00:01:32.635 --> 00:01:35.170
What really matters here are the issues.

00:01:35.170 --> 00:01:38.005
What really matters here is the
kind of government we want,

00:01:38.005 --> 00:01:39.518
the kind of Internet we want,

00:01:39.518 --> 00:01:42.076
the kind of relationship between people

00:01:42.076 --> 00:01:43.416
and societies.

00:01:43.416 --> 00:01:46.504
And that's what I'm hoping
the debate will move towards,

00:01:46.504 --> 00:01:48.876
and we've seen that increasing over time.

00:01:48.876 --> 00:01:50.786
If I had to describe myself,

00:01:50.786 --> 00:01:52.130
I wouldn't use words like "hero."

00:01:52.130 --> 00:01:54.832
I wouldn't use "patriot," and I wouldn't use "traitor."

00:01:54.832 --> 00:01:57.026
I'd say I'm an American and I'm a citizen,

00:01:57.026 --> 00:01:59.590
just like everyone else.

00:01:59.590 --> 00:02:01.463
CA: So just to give some context

00:02:01.463 --> 00:02:03.659
for those who don't know the whole story --

00:02:03.659 --> 00:02:07.389
(Applause) —

00:02:07.389 --> 00:02:11.952
this time a year ago, you were stationed in Hawaii

00:02:11.952 --> 00:02:14.342
working as a consultant to the NSA.

00:02:14.342 --> 00:02:16.386
As a sysadmin, you had access

00:02:16.386 --> 00:02:18.791
to their systems,

00:02:18.791 --> 00:02:23.045
and you began revealing
certain classified documents

00:02:23.045 --> 00:02:26.245
to some handpicked journalists

00:02:26.245 --> 00:02:27.836
leading the way to June's revelations.

00:02:27.836 --> 00:02:33.212
Now, what propelled you to do this?

00:02:33.212 --> 00:02:35.998
ES: You know,

00:02:35.998 --> 00:02:38.178
when I was sitting in Hawaii,

00:02:38.178 --> 00:02:40.836
and the years before, when I was
working in the intelligence community,

00:02:40.836 --> 00:02:44.558
I saw a lot of things that had disturbed me.

00:02:44.558 --> 00:02:47.835
We do a lot of good things
in the intelligence community,

00:02:47.835 --> 00:02:49.028
things that need to be done,

00:02:49.028 --> 00:02:51.725
and things that help everyone.

00:02:51.725 --> 00:02:53.682
But there are also things that go too far.

00:02:53.682 --> 00:02:54.978
There are things that shouldn't be done,

00:02:54.978 --> 00:02:58.046
and decisions that were being made in secret

00:02:58.046 --> 00:02:59.294
without the public's awareness,

00:02:59.294 --> 00:03:01.806
without the public's consent,

00:03:01.806 --> 00:03:04.658
and without even our representatives in government

00:03:04.658 --> 00:03:08.291
having knowledge of these programs.

00:03:08.291 --> 00:03:12.824
When I really came to struggle with these issues,

00:03:12.824 --> 00:03:14.446
I thought to myself,

00:03:14.446 --> 00:03:17.532
how can I do this in the most responsible way,

00:03:17.532 --> 00:03:20.540
that maximizes the public benefit

00:03:20.540 --> 00:03:23.251
while minimizing the risks?

00:03:23.251 --> 00:03:26.339
And out of all the solutions that I could come up with,

00:03:26.339 --> 00:03:28.581
out of going to Congress,

00:03:28.581 --> 00:03:29.884
when there were no laws,

00:03:29.884 --> 00:03:31.569
there were no legal protections

00:03:31.569 --> 00:03:33.336
for a private employee,

00:03:33.336 --> 00:03:36.669
a contractor in intelligence like myself,

00:03:36.669 --> 00:03:40.316
there was a risk that I would be
buried along with the information

00:03:40.316 --> 00:03:42.223
and the public would never find out.

00:03:42.223 --> 00:03:45.245
But the First Amendment of
the United States Constitution

00:03:45.245 --> 00:03:48.786
guarantees us a free press for a reason,

00:03:48.786 --> 00:03:51.991
and that's to enable an adversarial press,

00:03:51.991 --> 00:03:53.888
to challenge the government,

00:03:53.888 --> 00:03:56.522
but also to work together with the government,

00:03:56.522 --> 00:03:58.840
to have a dialogue and debate about how we can

00:03:58.840 --> 00:04:04.279
inform the public about matters of vital importance

00:04:04.279 --> 00:04:07.409
without putting our national security at risk.

00:04:07.409 --> 00:04:09.085
And by working with journalists,

00:04:09.085 --> 00:04:11.239
by giving all of my information

00:04:11.239 --> 00:04:13.516
back to the American people,

00:04:13.516 --> 00:04:15.287
rather than trusting myself to make

00:04:15.287 --> 00:04:18.021
the decisions about publication,

00:04:18.021 --> 00:04:20.257
we've had a robust debate

00:04:20.257 --> 00:04:23.524
with a deep investment by the government

00:04:23.524 --> 00:04:28.630
that I think has resulted in a benefit for everyone.

00:04:28.630 --> 00:04:32.405
And the risks that have been threatened,

00:04:32.405 --> 00:04:34.538
the risks that have been played up

00:04:34.538 --> 00:04:36.090
by the government

00:04:36.090 --> 00:04:37.516
have never materialized.

00:04:37.516 --> 00:04:39.594
We've never seen any evidence

00:04:39.594 --> 00:04:43.150
of even a single instance of specific harm,

00:04:43.150 --> 00:04:44.619
and because of that,

00:04:44.619 --> 00:04:46.746
I'm comfortable with the decisions that I made.

00:04:46.746 --> 00:04:48.959
CA: So let me show the audience

00:04:48.959 --> 00:04:51.428
a couple of examples of what you revealed.

00:04:51.428 --> 00:04:53.340
If we could have a slide up, and Ed,

00:04:53.340 --> 00:04:55.095
I don't know whether you can see,

00:04:55.095 --> 00:04:56.209
the slides are here.

00:04:56.209 --> 00:04:58.794
This is a slide of the PRISM program,

00:04:58.794 --> 00:05:01.263
and maybe you could tell the audience

00:05:01.263 --> 00:05:03.869
what that was that was revealed.

00:05:03.869 --> 00:05:06.081
ES: The best way to understand PRISM,

00:05:06.081 --> 00:05:07.542
because there's been a little bit of controversy,

00:05:07.542 --> 00:05:11.293
is to first talk about what PRISM isn't.

00:05:11.293 --> 00:05:14.048
Much of the debate in the U.S.
has been about metadata.

00:05:14.048 --> 00:05:16.939
They've said it's just metadata, it's just metadata,

00:05:16.939 --> 00:05:19.680
and they're talking about a specific legal authority

00:05:19.680 --> 00:05:22.385
called Section 215 of the Patriot Act.

00:05:22.385 --> 00:05:25.454
That allows sort of a warrantless wiretapping,

00:05:25.454 --> 00:05:27.817
mass surveillance of the entire country's

00:05:27.817 --> 00:05:29.974
phone records, things like that --

00:05:29.974 --> 00:05:31.336
who you're talking to,

00:05:31.336 --> 00:05:33.364
when you're talking to them,

00:05:33.364 --> 00:05:34.660
where you traveled.

00:05:34.660 --> 00:05:37.161
These are all metadata events.

00:05:37.161 --> 00:05:40.507
PRISM is about content.

00:05:40.507 --> 00:05:42.647
It's a program through which the government could

00:05:42.647 --> 00:05:44.691
compel corporate America,

00:05:44.691 --> 00:05:48.084
it could deputize corporate America

00:05:48.084 --> 00:05:51.948
to do its dirty work for the NSA.

00:05:51.948 --> 00:05:54.944
And even though some of
these companies did resist,

00:05:54.944 --> 00:05:56.367
even though some of them --

00:05:56.367 --> 00:05:57.613
I believe Yahoo was one of them —

00:05:57.613 --> 00:06:00.270
challenged them in court, they all lost,

00:06:00.270 --> 00:06:03.185
because it was never tried by an open court.

00:06:03.185 --> 00:06:06.316
They were only tried by a secret court.

00:06:06.316 --> 00:06:07.683
And something that we've seen,

00:06:07.683 --> 00:06:10.387
something about the PRISM program
that's very concerning to me is,

00:06:10.387 --> 00:06:12.366
there's been a talking point in the U.S. government

00:06:12.366 --> 00:06:16.117
where they've said 15 federal judges

00:06:16.117 --> 00:06:18.815
have reviewed these programs
and found them to be lawful,

00:06:18.815 --> 00:06:21.535
but what they don't tell you

00:06:21.535 --> 00:06:24.165
is those are secret judges

00:06:24.165 --> 00:06:26.167
in a secret court

00:06:26.167 --> 00:06:29.241
based on secret interpretations of law

00:06:29.241 --> 00:06:33.475
that's considered 34,000 warrant requests

00:06:33.475 --> 00:06:35.934
over 33 years,

00:06:35.934 --> 00:06:38.121
and in 33 years only rejected

00:06:38.121 --> 00:06:41.004
11 government requests.

00:06:41.004 --> 00:06:43.751
These aren't the people that we want deciding

00:06:43.751 --> 00:06:45.897
what the role of corporate America

00:06:45.897 --> 00:06:48.353
in a free and open Internet should be.

00:06:48.353 --> 00:06:50.464
CA: Now, this slide that we're showing here

00:06:50.464 --> 00:06:52.676
shows the dates in which

00:06:52.676 --> 00:06:55.091
different technology companies, Internet companies,

00:06:55.091 --> 00:06:57.445
are alleged to have joined the program,

00:06:57.445 --> 00:07:00.403
and where data collection began from them.

00:07:00.403 --> 00:07:05.152
Now, they have denied collaborating with the NSA.

00:07:05.152 --> 00:07:10.256
How was that data collected by the NSA?

00:07:10.256 --> 00:07:13.435
ES: Right. So the NSA's own slides

00:07:13.435 --> 00:07:16.235
refer to it as direct access.

00:07:16.235 --> 00:07:18.985
What that means to an actual NSA analyst,

00:07:18.985 --> 00:07:22.093
someone like me who was working
as an intelligence analyst

00:07:22.093 --> 00:07:24.564
targeting, Chinese cyber-hackers,

00:07:24.564 --> 00:07:26.646
things like that, in Hawaii,

00:07:26.646 --> 00:07:28.615
is the provenance of that data

00:07:28.615 --> 00:07:30.871
is directly from their servers.

00:07:30.871 --> 00:07:32.935
It doesn't mean

00:07:32.935 --> 00:07:35.741
that there's a group of company representatives

00:07:35.741 --> 00:07:38.178
sitting in a smoky room with the NSA

00:07:38.178 --> 00:07:39.968
palling around and making back-room deals

00:07:39.968 --> 00:07:42.511
about how they're going to give this stuff away.

00:07:42.511 --> 00:07:44.904
Now each company handles it different ways.

00:07:44.904 --> 00:07:46.080
Some are responsible.

00:07:46.080 --> 00:07:48.171
Some are somewhat less responsible.

00:07:48.171 --> 00:07:49.939
But the bottom line is, when we talk about

00:07:49.939 --> 00:07:53.318
how this information is given,

00:07:53.318 --> 00:07:55.804
it's coming from the companies themselves.

00:07:55.804 --> 00:07:58.099
It's not stolen from the lines.

00:07:58.099 --> 00:08:00.031
But there's an important thing to remember here:

00:08:00.031 --> 00:08:01.962
even though companies pushed back,

00:08:01.962 --> 00:08:04.015
even though companies demanded,

00:08:04.015 --> 00:08:06.561
hey, let's do this through a warrant process,

00:08:06.561 --> 00:08:08.335
let's do this

00:08:08.335 --> 00:08:11.484
where we actually have some sort of legal review,

00:08:11.484 --> 00:08:13.315
some sort of basis for handing over

00:08:13.315 --> 00:08:15.255
these users' data,

00:08:15.255 --> 00:08:17.646
we saw stories in the Washington Post last year

00:08:17.646 --> 00:08:20.858
that weren't as well reported as the PRISM story

00:08:20.858 --> 00:08:23.457
that said the NSA broke in

00:08:23.457 --> 00:08:25.258
to the data center communications

00:08:25.258 --> 00:08:27.414
between Google to itself

00:08:27.414 --> 00:08:28.992
and Yahoo to itself.

00:08:28.992 --> 00:08:31.824
So even these companies that are cooperating

00:08:31.824 --> 00:08:34.695
in at least a compelled but hopefully lawful manner

00:08:34.695 --> 00:08:36.568
with the NSA,

00:08:36.568 --> 00:08:39.864
the NSA isn't satisfied with that,

00:08:39.864 --> 00:08:41.842
and because of that, we need our companies

00:08:41.842 --> 00:08:44.657
to work very hard

00:08:44.657 --> 00:08:47.129
to guarantee that they're going to represent

00:08:47.129 --> 00:08:49.715
the interests of the user, and also advocate

00:08:49.715 --> 00:08:51.631
for the rights of the users.

00:08:51.631 --> 00:08:52.905
And I think over the last year,

00:08:52.905 --> 00:08:54.488
we've seen the companies that are named

00:08:54.488 --> 00:08:55.906
on the PRISM slides

00:08:55.906 --> 00:08:57.715
take great strides to do that,

00:08:57.715 --> 00:08:59.968
and I encourage them to continue.

00:08:59.968 --> 00:09:02.650
CA: What more should they do?

00:09:02.650 --> 00:09:06.167
ES: The biggest thing that an Internet company

00:09:06.167 --> 00:09:09.393
in America can do today, right now,

00:09:09.393 --> 00:09:10.835
without consulting with lawyers,

00:09:10.835 --> 00:09:14.374
to protect the rights of users worldwide,

00:09:14.374 --> 00:09:19.757
is to enable SSL web encryption

00:09:19.757 --> 00:09:21.762
on every page you visit.

00:09:21.762 --> 00:09:24.704
The reason this matters is today,

00:09:24.704 --> 00:09:29.942
if you go to look at a copy of "1984" on Amazon.com,

00:09:29.942 --> 00:09:32.389
the NSA can see a record of that,

00:09:32.389 --> 00:09:34.608
the Russian intelligence service
can see a record of that,

00:09:34.608 --> 00:09:37.065
the Chinese service can see a record of that,

00:09:37.065 --> 00:09:38.963
the French service, the German service,

00:09:38.963 --> 00:09:40.285
the services of Andorra.

00:09:40.285 --> 00:09:43.563
They can all see it because it's unencrypted.

00:09:43.563 --> 00:09:47.163
The world's library is Amazon.com,

00:09:47.163 --> 00:09:49.818
but not only do they not
support encryption by default,

00:09:49.818 --> 00:09:51.984
you cannot choose to use encryption

00:09:51.984 --> 00:09:53.711
when browsing through books.

00:09:53.711 --> 00:09:55.420
This is something that we need to change,

00:09:55.420 --> 00:09:57.295
not just for Amazon, I don't mean to single them out,

00:09:57.295 --> 00:09:58.787
but they're a great example.

00:09:58.787 --> 00:10:00.455
All companies need to move

00:10:00.455 --> 00:10:03.848
to an encrypted browsing habit by default

00:10:03.848 --> 00:10:06.332
for all users who haven't taken any action

00:10:06.332 --> 00:10:08.593
or picked any special methods on their own.

00:10:08.593 --> 00:10:10.904
That'll increase the privacy and the rights

00:10:10.904 --> 00:10:13.669
that people enjoy worldwide.

00:10:13.669 --> 00:10:16.147
CA: Ed, come with me to this part of the stage.

00:10:16.147 --> 00:10:19.100
I want to show you the next slide here. (Applause)

00:10:19.100 --> 00:10:21.808
This is a program called Boundless Informant.

00:10:21.808 --> 00:10:23.484
What is that?

00:10:23.484 --> 00:10:25.664
ES: So, I've got to give credit to the NSA

00:10:25.664 --> 00:10:28.107
for using appropriate names on this.

00:10:28.107 --> 00:10:31.952
This is one of my favorite NSA cryptonyms.

00:10:31.952 --> 00:10:33.422
Boundless Informant

00:10:33.422 --> 00:10:36.272
is a program that the NSA hid from Congress.

00:10:36.272 --> 00:10:38.681
The NSA was previously asked by Congress,

00:10:38.681 --> 00:10:40.894
was there any ability that they had

00:10:40.894 --> 00:10:44.652
to even give a rough ballpark estimate

00:10:44.652 --> 00:10:46.838
of the amount of American communications

00:10:46.838 --> 00:10:48.972
that were being intercepted.

00:10:48.972 --> 00:10:52.003
They said no. They said, we don't track those stats,

00:10:52.003 --> 00:10:53.552
and we can't track those stats.

00:10:53.552 --> 00:10:56.656
We can't tell you how many communications

00:10:56.656 --> 00:10:58.119
we're intercepting around the world,

00:10:58.119 --> 00:10:59.606
because to tell you that would be

00:10:59.606 --> 00:11:02.913
to invade your privacy.

00:11:02.913 --> 00:11:05.128
Now, I really appreciate that sentiment from them,

00:11:05.128 --> 00:11:07.263
but the reality, when you look at this slide is,

00:11:07.263 --> 00:11:08.916
not only do they have the capability,

00:11:08.916 --> 00:11:11.532
the capability already exists.

00:11:11.532 --> 00:11:13.206
It's already in place.

00:11:13.206 --> 00:11:16.354
The NSA has its own internal data format

00:11:16.354 --> 00:11:20.503
that tracks both ends of a communication,

00:11:20.503 --> 00:11:21.785
and if it says,

00:11:21.785 --> 00:11:23.811
this communication came from America,

00:11:23.811 --> 00:11:26.167
they can tell Congress how
many of those communications

00:11:26.167 --> 00:11:28.683
they have today, right now.

00:11:28.683 --> 00:11:31.654
And what Boundless Informant tells us

00:11:31.654 --> 00:11:34.380
is more communications are being intercepted

00:11:34.380 --> 00:11:37.353
in America about Americans

00:11:37.353 --> 00:11:40.773
than there are in Russia about Russians.

00:11:40.773 --> 00:11:42.638
I'm not sure that's what an intelligence agency

00:11:42.638 --> 00:11:44.957
should be aiming for.

00:11:44.957 --> 00:11:47.363
CA: Ed, there was a story broken
in the Washington Post,

00:11:47.363 --> 00:11:49.085
again from your data.

00:11:49.085 --> 00:11:50.764
The headline says,

00:11:50.764 --> 00:11:52.261
"NSA broke privacy rules

00:11:52.261 --> 00:11:54.291
thousands of times per year."

00:11:54.291 --> 00:11:55.829
Tell us about that.

00:11:55.829 --> 00:11:58.422
ES: We also heard in Congressional
testimony last year,

00:11:58.422 --> 00:12:00.359
it was an amazing thing for someone like me

00:12:00.359 --> 00:12:02.063
who came from the NSA

00:12:02.063 --> 00:12:04.635
and who's seen the actual internal documents,

00:12:04.635 --> 00:12:07.226
knows what's in them,

00:12:07.226 --> 00:12:09.766
to see officials testifying under oath

00:12:09.766 --> 00:12:11.648
that there had been no abuses,

00:12:11.648 --> 00:12:15.281
that there had been no violations of the NSA's rules,

00:12:15.281 --> 00:12:18.222
when we knew this story was coming.

00:12:18.222 --> 00:12:20.310
But what's especially interesting about this,

00:12:20.310 --> 00:12:22.358
about the fact that the NSA has violated

00:12:22.358 --> 00:12:24.726
their own rules, their own laws

00:12:24.726 --> 00:12:27.399
thousands of times in a single year,

00:12:27.399 --> 00:12:30.126
including one event by itself,

00:12:30.126 --> 00:12:35.102
one event out of those 2,776,

00:12:35.102 --> 00:12:37.408
that affected more than 3,000 people.

00:12:37.408 --> 00:12:39.247
In another event, they intercepted

00:12:39.247 --> 00:12:43.459
all the calls in Washington, D.C., by accident.

00:12:43.459 --> 00:12:45.696
What's amazing about this,

00:12:45.696 --> 00:12:47.904
this report, that didn't get that much attention,

00:12:47.904 --> 00:12:52.765
is the fact that not only were there 2,776 abuses,

00:12:52.765 --> 00:12:54.906
the chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee,

00:12:54.906 --> 00:12:58.893
Dianne Feinstein, had not seen this report

00:12:58.893 --> 00:13:02.084
until the Washington Post contacted her

00:13:02.084 --> 00:13:04.532
asking for comment on the report.

00:13:04.532 --> 00:13:06.425
And she then requested a copy from the NSA

00:13:06.425 --> 00:13:08.126
and received it,

00:13:08.126 --> 00:13:10.153
but had never seen this before that.

00:13:10.153 --> 00:13:12.840
What does that say about the state of oversight

00:13:12.840 --> 00:13:14.577
in American intelligence

00:13:14.577 --> 00:13:16.365
when the chairman of the
Senate Intelligence Committee

00:13:16.365 --> 00:13:19.158
has no idea that the rules are being broken

00:13:19.158 --> 00:13:21.318
thousands of times every year?

00:13:21.318 --> 00:13:24.947
CA: Ed, one response to this whole debate is this:

00:13:24.947 --> 00:13:27.612
Why should we care about

00:13:27.612 --> 00:13:29.080
all this surveillance, honestly?

00:13:29.080 --> 00:13:31.232
I mean, look, if you've done nothing wrong,

00:13:31.232 --> 00:13:34.016
you've got nothing to worry about.

00:13:34.016 --> 00:13:36.308
What's wrong with that point of view?

00:13:36.308 --> 00:13:37.956
ES: Well, so the first thing is,

00:13:37.956 --> 00:13:39.669
you're giving up your rights.

00:13:39.669 --> 00:13:41.027
You're saying hey, you know,

00:13:41.027 --> 00:13:43.399
I don't think I'm going to need them,

00:13:43.399 --> 00:13:45.081
so I'm just going to trust that, you know,

00:13:45.081 --> 00:13:48.059
let's get rid of them, it doesn't really matter,

00:13:48.059 --> 00:13:50.033
these guys are going to do the right thing.

00:13:50.033 --> 00:13:51.892
Your rights matter

00:13:51.892 --> 00:13:54.734
because you never know when
you're going to need them.

00:13:54.734 --> 00:13:57.016
Beyond that, it's a part of our cultural identity,

00:13:57.016 --> 00:13:59.148
not just in America,

00:13:59.148 --> 00:14:00.739
but in Western societies

00:14:00.739 --> 00:14:03.701
and in democratic societies around the world.

00:14:03.701 --> 00:14:06.105
People should be able to pick up the phone

00:14:06.105 --> 00:14:07.559
and to call their family,

00:14:07.559 --> 00:14:09.558
people should be able to send a text message

00:14:09.558 --> 00:14:10.686
to their loved ones,

00:14:10.686 --> 00:14:13.140
people should be able to buy a book online,

00:14:13.140 --> 00:14:14.930
they should be able to travel by train,

00:14:14.930 --> 00:14:17.147
they should be able to buy an airline ticket

00:14:17.147 --> 00:14:18.884
without wondering about how these events

00:14:18.884 --> 00:14:22.569
are going to look to an agent of the government,

00:14:22.569 --> 00:14:25.159
possibly not even your government

00:14:25.159 --> 00:14:26.914
years in the future,

00:14:26.914 --> 00:14:28.654
how they're going to be misinterpreted

00:14:28.654 --> 00:14:31.438
and what they're going to think your intentions were.

00:14:31.438 --> 00:14:33.512
We have a right to privacy.

00:14:33.512 --> 00:14:37.130
We require warrants to be based on probable cause

00:14:37.130 --> 00:14:39.594
or some kind of individualized suspicion

00:14:39.594 --> 00:14:44.121
because we recognize that trusting anybody,

00:14:44.121 --> 00:14:45.715
any government authority,

00:14:45.715 --> 00:14:48.799
with the entirety of human communications

00:14:48.799 --> 00:14:51.232
in secret and without oversight

00:14:51.232 --> 00:14:56.076
is simply too great a temptation to be ignored.

00:14:56.076 --> 00:14:58.635
CA: Some people are furious at what you've done.

00:14:58.635 --> 00:15:01.474
I heard a quote recently from Dick Cheney

00:15:01.474 --> 00:15:07.366
who said that Julian Assange was a flea bite,

00:15:07.366 --> 00:15:10.788
Edward Snowden is the lion
that bit the head off the dog.

00:15:10.788 --> 00:15:12.341
He thinks you've committed

00:15:12.341 --> 00:15:14.633
one of the worst acts of betrayal

00:15:14.633 --> 00:15:16.739
in American history.

00:15:16.739 --> 00:15:21.095
What would you say to people who think that?

00:15:22.933 --> 00:15:25.138
ES: Dick Cheney's really something else.

00:15:25.138 --> 00:15:31.935
(Laughter) (Applause)

00:15:32.434 --> 00:15:37.336
Thank you. (Laughter)

00:15:37.336 --> 00:15:39.812
I think it's amazing, because at the time

00:15:39.812 --> 00:15:43.587
Julian Assange was doing some of his greatest work,

00:15:43.587 --> 00:15:45.023
Dick Cheney was saying

00:15:45.023 --> 00:15:47.453
he was going to end governments worldwide,

00:15:47.453 --> 00:15:50.358
the skies were going to ignite

00:15:50.358 --> 00:15:52.494
and the seas were going to boil off,

00:15:52.494 --> 00:15:54.712
and now he's saying it's a flea bite.

00:15:54.712 --> 00:15:57.225
So we should be suspicious about the same sort of

00:15:57.225 --> 00:16:01.418
overblown claims of damage to national security

00:16:01.418 --> 00:16:03.103
from these kind of officials.

00:16:03.103 --> 00:16:09.952
But let's assume that these
people really believe this.

00:16:09.952 --> 00:16:12.182
I would argue that they have kind of

00:16:12.182 --> 00:16:16.552
a narrow conception of national security.

00:16:16.552 --> 00:16:19.768
The prerogatives of people like Dick Cheney

00:16:19.799 --> 00:16:22.780
do not keep the nation safe.

00:16:22.780 --> 00:16:26.813
The public interest is not always the same

00:16:26.813 --> 00:16:29.248
as the national interest.

00:16:29.248 --> 00:16:33.142
Going to war with people who are not our enemy

00:16:33.142 --> 00:16:35.272
in places that are not a threat

00:16:35.272 --> 00:16:37.439
doesn't make us safe,

00:16:37.439 --> 00:16:39.606
and that applies whether it's in Iraq

00:16:39.606 --> 00:16:41.373
or on the Internet.

00:16:41.373 --> 00:16:42.896
The Internet is not the enemy.

00:16:42.896 --> 00:16:44.921
Our economy is not the enemy.

00:16:44.921 --> 00:16:47.207
American businesses, Chinese businesses,

00:16:47.207 --> 00:16:51.778
and any other company out there

00:16:51.778 --> 00:16:54.209
is a part of our society.

00:16:54.209 --> 00:16:56.423
It's a part of our interconnected world.

00:16:56.423 --> 00:17:00.868
There are ties of fraternity that bond us together,

00:17:00.868 --> 00:17:03.536
and if we destroy these bonds

00:17:03.536 --> 00:17:06.691
by undermining the standards, the security,

00:17:06.691 --> 00:17:09.548
the manner of behavior,

00:17:09.548 --> 00:17:12.499
that nations and citizens all around the world

00:17:12.499 --> 00:17:14.876
expect us to abide by.

00:17:14.876 --> 00:17:18.578
CA: But it's alleged that you've stolen

00:17:18.578 --> 00:17:20.477
1.7 million documents.

00:17:20.477 --> 00:17:22.304
It seems only a few hundred of them

00:17:22.304 --> 00:17:25.161
have been shared with journalists so far.

00:17:25.161 --> 00:17:28.206
Are there more revelations to come?

00:17:28.206 --> 00:17:30.648
ES: There are absolutely more revelations to come.

00:17:30.648 --> 00:17:33.449
I don't think there's any question

00:17:33.449 --> 00:17:37.696
that some of the most important reporting

00:17:37.696 --> 00:17:42.436
to be done is yet to come.

00:17:42.436 --> 00:17:44.498
CA: Come here, because I want to ask you

00:17:44.498 --> 00:17:46.025
about this particular revelation.

00:17:46.025 --> 00:17:49.047
Come and take a look at this.

00:17:49.047 --> 00:17:52.295
I mean, this is a story which I think
for a lot of the techies in this room

00:17:52.295 --> 00:17:54.034
is the single most shocking thing

00:17:54.034 --> 00:17:56.394
that they have heard in the last few months.

00:17:56.394 --> 00:17:59.019
It's about a program called "Bullrun."

00:17:59.019 --> 00:18:02.795
Can you explain what that is?

00:18:02.795 --> 00:18:04.503
ES: So Bullrun, and this is again

00:18:04.503 --> 00:18:11.600
where we've got to thank the NSA for their candor,

00:18:11.600 --> 00:18:16.190
this is a program named after a Civil War battle.

00:18:16.190 --> 00:18:17.803
The British counterpart is called Edgehill,

00:18:17.803 --> 00:18:19.278
which is a U.K. civil war battle.

00:18:19.278 --> 00:18:21.485
And the reason that I believe they're named this way

00:18:21.485 --> 00:18:24.974
is because they target our own infrastructure.

00:18:24.974 --> 00:18:27.665
They're programs through which the NSA

00:18:27.665 --> 00:18:31.880
intentionally misleads corporate partners.

00:18:31.880 --> 00:18:33.762
They tell corporate partners that these

00:18:33.762 --> 00:18:35.437
are safe standards.

00:18:35.437 --> 00:18:37.456
They say hey, we need to work with you

00:18:37.456 --> 00:18:41.109
to secure your systems,

00:18:41.109 --> 00:18:44.302
but in reality, they're giving bad advice

00:18:44.302 --> 00:18:45.568
to these companies that makes them

00:18:45.568 --> 00:18:47.863
degrade the security of their services.

00:18:47.863 --> 00:18:50.192
They're building in backdoors that not only

00:18:50.192 --> 00:18:52.550
the NSA can exploit,

00:18:52.550 --> 00:18:55.071
but anyone else who has time and money

00:18:55.071 --> 00:18:57.191
to research and find it

00:18:57.191 --> 00:18:59.325
can then use to let themselves in

00:18:59.325 --> 00:19:01.195
to the world's communications.

00:19:01.195 --> 00:19:02.965
And this is really dangerous,

00:19:02.965 --> 00:19:07.149
because if we lose a single standard,

00:19:07.149 --> 00:19:10.208
if we lose the trust of something like SSL,

00:19:10.208 --> 00:19:11.690
which was specifically targeted

00:19:11.690 --> 00:19:13.813
by the Bullrun program,

00:19:13.813 --> 00:19:16.481
we will live a less safe world overall.

00:19:16.481 --> 00:19:18.588
We won't be able to access our banks

00:19:18.588 --> 00:19:23.841
and we won't be able to access commerce

00:19:23.841 --> 00:19:26.664
without worrying about people
monitoring those communications

00:19:26.664 --> 00:19:28.842
or subverting them for their own ends.

00:19:28.842 --> 00:19:32.911
CA: And do those same decisions also potentially

00:19:32.911 --> 00:19:35.897
open America up to cyberattacks

00:19:35.897 --> 00:19:39.813
from other sources?

00:19:39.813 --> 00:19:41.278
ES: Absolutely.

00:19:41.278 --> 00:19:43.010
One of the problems,

00:19:43.010 --> 00:19:46.460
one of the dangerous legacies

00:19:46.460 --> 00:19:49.952
that we've seen in the post-9/11 era,

00:19:49.952 --> 00:19:54.189
is that the NSA has traditionally worn two hats.

00:19:54.189 --> 00:19:56.115
They've been in charge of offensive operations,

00:19:56.115 --> 00:19:57.236
that is hacking,

00:19:57.236 --> 00:19:59.946
but they've also been in
charge of defensive operations,

00:19:59.946 --> 00:20:02.309
and traditionally they've always prioritized

00:20:02.309 --> 00:20:03.696
defense over offense

00:20:03.696 --> 00:20:05.086
based on the principle

00:20:05.086 --> 00:20:07.902
that American secrets are simply worth more.

00:20:07.902 --> 00:20:10.012
If we hack a Chinese business

00:20:10.012 --> 00:20:11.696
and steal their secrets,

00:20:11.696 --> 00:20:13.779
if we hack a government office in Berlin

00:20:13.779 --> 00:20:15.877
and steal their secrets,

00:20:15.877 --> 00:20:19.484
that has less value to the American people

00:20:19.484 --> 00:20:21.584
than making sure that the Chinese

00:20:21.584 --> 00:20:24.090
can't get access to our secrets.

00:20:24.090 --> 00:20:28.221
So by reducing the security of our communications,

00:20:28.221 --> 00:20:30.249
they're not only putting the world at risk,

00:20:30.249 --> 00:20:32.521
they're putting America at risk in a fundamental way,

00:20:32.521 --> 00:20:35.192
because intellectual property is the basis,

00:20:35.192 --> 00:20:37.119
the foundation of our economy,

00:20:37.119 --> 00:20:39.377
and if we put that at risk through weak security,

00:20:39.377 --> 00:20:41.006
we're going to be paying for it for years.

00:20:41.006 --> 00:20:42.553
CA: But they've made a calculation

00:20:42.553 --> 00:20:44.744
that it was worth doing this

00:20:44.744 --> 00:20:48.283
as part of America's defense against terrorism.

00:20:48.283 --> 00:20:51.895
Surely that makes it a price worth paying.

00:20:51.895 --> 00:20:55.782
ES: Well, when you look at the results

00:20:55.782 --> 00:20:58.089
of these programs in stopping terrorism,

00:20:58.089 --> 00:21:01.839
you will see that that's unfounded,

00:21:01.839 --> 00:21:03.758
and you don't have to take my word for it,

00:21:03.758 --> 00:21:07.530
because we've had the first open court,

00:21:07.530 --> 00:21:09.899
the first federal court that's reviewed this,

00:21:09.899 --> 00:21:12.695
outside the secrecy arrangement,

00:21:12.695 --> 00:21:14.682
called these programs Orwellian

00:21:14.682 --> 00:21:16.916
and likely unconstitutional.

00:21:16.916 --> 00:21:19.655
Congress, who has access

00:21:19.655 --> 00:21:20.966
to be briefed on these things,

00:21:20.966 --> 00:21:23.948
and now has the desire to be,

00:21:23.948 --> 00:21:26.355
has produced bills to reform it,

00:21:26.355 --> 00:21:29.240
and two independent White House panels

00:21:29.240 --> 00:21:31.330
who reviewed all of the classified evidence

00:21:31.330 --> 00:21:33.963
said these programs have never stopped

00:21:33.963 --> 00:21:35.724
a single terrorist attack

00:21:35.724 --> 00:21:39.227
that was imminent in the United States.

00:21:39.227 --> 00:21:42.413
So is it really terrorism that we're stopping?

00:21:42.413 --> 00:21:44.744
Do these programs have any value at all?

00:21:44.744 --> 00:21:46.988
I say no, and all three branches

00:21:46.988 --> 00:21:49.420
of the American government say no as well.

00:21:49.420 --> 00:21:51.233
CA: I mean, do you think there's a deeper motivation

00:21:51.233 --> 00:21:54.518
for them than the war against terrorism?

00:21:54.518 --> 00:21:56.068
ES: I'm sorry, I couldn't hear you, say again?

00:21:56.068 --> 00:21:59.068
CA: Sorry. Do you think there's a deeper motivation

00:21:59.068 --> 00:22:02.947
for them other than the war against terrorism?

00:22:02.947 --> 00:22:05.642
ES: Yeah. The bottom line is that terrorism

00:22:05.642 --> 00:22:07.843
has always been what we in the intelligence world

00:22:07.843 --> 00:22:11.116
would call a cover for action.

00:22:11.116 --> 00:22:13.041
Terrorism is something that provokes

00:22:13.041 --> 00:22:15.271
an emotional response that allows people

00:22:15.271 --> 00:22:19.628
to rationalize authorizing powers and programs

00:22:19.628 --> 00:22:22.072
that they wouldn't give otherwise.

00:22:22.072 --> 00:22:24.558
The Bullrun and Edgehill-type programs,

00:22:24.558 --> 00:22:26.275
the NSA asked for these authorities

00:22:26.275 --> 00:22:28.212
back in the 1990s.

00:22:28.212 --> 00:22:31.202
They asked the FBI to go to
Congress and make the case.

00:22:31.202 --> 00:22:33.376
The FBI went to Congress and did make the case.

00:22:33.376 --> 00:22:35.941
But Congress and the American people said no.

00:22:35.941 --> 00:22:38.352
They said, it's not worth the risk to our economy.

00:22:38.352 --> 00:22:40.271
They said it's worth too much damage

00:22:40.271 --> 00:22:42.958
to our society to justify the gains.

00:22:42.958 --> 00:22:47.233
But what we saw is, in the post-9/11 era,

00:22:47.233 --> 00:22:50.484
they used secrecy and they
used the justification of terrorism

00:22:50.484 --> 00:22:52.418
to start these programs in secret

00:22:52.418 --> 00:22:54.230
without asking Congress,

00:22:54.230 --> 00:22:56.410
without asking the American people,

00:22:56.410 --> 00:22:59.148
and it's that kind of government behind closed doors

00:22:59.148 --> 00:23:01.707
that we need to guard ourselves against,

00:23:01.707 --> 00:23:02.957
because it makes us less safe,

00:23:02.957 --> 00:23:04.849
and it offers no value.

00:23:04.849 --> 00:23:06.715
CA: Okay, come with me here for a sec,

00:23:06.715 --> 00:23:08.897
because I've got a more personal question for you.

00:23:08.897 --> 00:23:11.821
Speaking of terror,

00:23:11.821 --> 00:23:15.778
most people would find the
situation you're in right now

00:23:15.778 --> 00:23:19.074
in Russia pretty terrifying.

00:23:19.074 --> 00:23:22.661
You obviously heard what happened,

00:23:22.661 --> 00:23:24.854
what the treatment that Bradley Manning got,

00:23:24.854 --> 00:23:27.135
Chelsea Manning as now is,

00:23:27.135 --> 00:23:29.622
and there was a story in Buzzfeed saying that

00:23:29.622 --> 00:23:31.280
there are people in the intelligence community

00:23:31.280 --> 00:23:33.559
who want you dead.

00:23:33.559 --> 00:23:35.499
How are you coping with this?

00:23:35.499 --> 00:23:37.448
How are you coping with the fear?

00:23:37.448 --> 00:23:40.452
ES: It's no mystery

00:23:40.452 --> 00:23:46.100
that there are governments out
there that want to see me dead.

00:23:46.100 --> 00:23:49.510
I've made clear again and again and again

00:23:49.510 --> 00:23:52.876
that I go to sleep every morning

00:23:52.876 --> 00:23:57.436
thinking about what I can
do for the American people.

00:23:57.436 --> 00:24:00.468
I don't want to harm my government.

00:24:00.468 --> 00:24:03.731
I want to help my government,

00:24:03.731 --> 00:24:07.539
but the fact that they are willing to

00:24:07.539 --> 00:24:09.859
completely ignore due process,

00:24:09.859 --> 00:24:12.567
they're willing to declare guilt

00:24:12.567 --> 00:24:15.853
without ever seeing a trial,

00:24:15.853 --> 00:24:18.269
these are things that we need to work against

00:24:18.269 --> 00:24:21.847
as a society, and say hey, this is not appropriate.

00:24:21.847 --> 00:24:23.674
We shouldn't be threatening dissidents.

00:24:23.674 --> 00:24:26.688
We shouldn't be criminalizing journalism.

00:24:26.688 --> 00:24:30.007
And whatever part I can do to see that end,

00:24:30.007 --> 00:24:33.160
I'm happy to do despite the risks.

00:24:33.160 --> 00:24:34.684
CA: So I'd actually like to get some feedback

00:24:34.684 --> 00:24:35.903
from the audience here,

00:24:35.903 --> 00:24:38.007
because I know there's widely differing reactions

00:24:38.007 --> 00:24:39.948
to Edward Snowden.

00:24:39.948 --> 00:24:42.236
Suppose you had the following two choices, right?

00:24:42.236 --> 00:24:45.042
You could view what he did

00:24:45.042 --> 00:24:46.936
as fundamentally a reckless act

00:24:46.936 --> 00:24:50.155
that has endangered America

00:24:50.155 --> 00:24:53.718
or you could view it as fundamentally a heroic act

00:24:53.718 --> 00:24:57.193
that will work towards America and the world's

00:24:57.193 --> 00:24:58.580
long-term good?

00:24:58.580 --> 00:25:01.898
Those are the two choices I'll give you.

00:25:01.898 --> 00:25:04.053
I'm curious to see who's willing to vote with

00:25:04.053 --> 00:25:05.470
the first of those,

00:25:05.470 --> 00:25:08.879
that this was a reckless act?

00:25:08.879 --> 00:25:10.534
There are some hands going up.

00:25:10.534 --> 00:25:11.918
Some hands going up.

00:25:11.918 --> 00:25:13.194
It's hard to put your hand up

00:25:13.194 --> 00:25:15.305
when the man is standing right here,

00:25:15.305 --> 00:25:16.870
but I see them.

00:25:16.870 --> 00:25:19.401
ES: I can see you. (Laughter)

00:25:19.401 --> 00:25:21.662
CA: And who goes with the second choice,

00:25:21.662 --> 00:25:23.545
the fundamentally heroic act?

00:25:23.545 --> 00:25:26.192
(Applause) (Cheers)

00:25:26.192 --> 00:25:28.766
And I think it's true to say that
there are a lot of people

00:25:28.766 --> 00:25:30.991
who didn't show a hand and I think

00:25:30.991 --> 00:25:32.701
are still thinking this through,

00:25:32.701 --> 00:25:36.159
because it seems to me that the debate around you

00:25:36.159 --> 00:25:39.268
doesn't split along traditional political lines.

00:25:39.268 --> 00:25:41.522
It's not left or right, it's not really about

00:25:41.522 --> 00:25:45.644
pro-government, libertarian, or not just that.

00:25:45.644 --> 00:25:48.357
Part of it is almost a generational issue.

00:25:48.357 --> 00:25:50.165
You're part of a generation that grew up

00:25:50.165 --> 00:25:53.091
with the Internet, and it seems as if

00:25:53.091 --> 00:25:56.299
you become offended at almost a visceral level

00:25:56.299 --> 00:25:57.595
when you see something done

00:25:57.595 --> 00:25:59.657
that you think will harm the Internet.

00:25:59.657 --> 00:26:03.230
Is there some truth to that?

00:26:03.230 --> 00:26:08.278
ES: It is. I think it's very true.

00:26:08.278 --> 00:26:11.376
This is not a left or right issue.

00:26:11.376 --> 00:26:13.953
Our basic freedoms, and when I say our,

00:26:13.953 --> 00:26:15.500
I don't just mean Americans,

00:26:15.500 --> 00:26:17.513
I mean people around the world,

00:26:17.513 --> 00:26:19.859
it's not a partisan issue.

00:26:19.859 --> 00:26:21.898
These are things that all people believe,

00:26:21.898 --> 00:26:24.423
and it's up to all of us to protect them,

00:26:24.423 --> 00:26:27.255
and to people who have seen and enjoyed

00:26:27.255 --> 00:26:28.916
a free and open Internet,

00:26:28.916 --> 00:26:32.142
it's up to us to preserve that liberty

00:26:32.142 --> 00:26:34.047
for the next generation to enjoy,

00:26:34.047 --> 00:26:35.912
and if we don't change things,

00:26:35.912 --> 00:26:39.045
if we don't stand up to make the changes

00:26:39.045 --> 00:26:42.252
we need to do to keep the Internet safe,

00:26:42.252 --> 00:26:45.020
not just for us but for everyone,

00:26:45.020 --> 00:26:46.485
we're going to lose that,

00:26:46.485 --> 00:26:47.738
and that would be a tremendous loss,

00:26:47.738 --> 00:26:50.085
not just for us, but for the world.

00:26:50.085 --> 00:26:52.158
CA: Well, I have heard similar language recently

00:26:52.158 --> 00:26:54.006
from the founder of the world wide web,

00:26:54.006 --> 00:26:58.523
who I actually think is with us, Sir Tim Berners-Lee.

00:26:58.523 --> 00:27:01.227
Tim, actually, would you like to come up and say,

00:27:01.227 --> 00:27:03.098
do we have a microphone for Tim?

00:27:03.098 --> 00:27:05.465
(Applause)

00:27:05.465 --> 00:27:12.540
Tim, good to see you. Come up there.

00:27:12.540 --> 00:27:14.977
Which camp are you in, by the way,

00:27:14.977 --> 00:27:18.477
traitor, hero? I have a theory on this, but --

00:27:18.477 --> 00:27:21.171
Tim Berners-Lee: I've given much longer

00:27:21.171 --> 00:27:24.226
answers to that question, but hero,

00:27:24.226 --> 00:27:27.628
if I have to make the choice between the two.

00:27:27.628 --> 00:27:30.961
CA: And Ed, I think you've read

00:27:30.961 --> 00:27:33.045
the proposal that Sir Tim has talked about

00:27:33.045 --> 00:27:36.013
about a new Magna Carta to take back the Internet.

00:27:36.013 --> 00:27:38.115
Is that something that makes sense?

00:27:38.115 --> 00:27:41.756
ES: Absolutely. I mean, my generation, I grew up

00:27:41.756 --> 00:27:43.815
not just thinking about the Internet,

00:27:43.815 --> 00:27:46.179
but I grew up in the Internet,

00:27:46.179 --> 00:27:50.839
and although I never expected to have the chance

00:27:50.839 --> 00:27:56.386
to defend it in such a direct and practical manner

00:27:56.386 --> 00:28:00.182
and to embody it in this unusual,

00:28:00.182 --> 00:28:02.311
almost avatar manner,

00:28:02.311 --> 00:28:05.017
I think there's something poetic about the fact that

00:28:05.017 --> 00:28:06.999
one of the sons of the Internet

00:28:06.999 --> 00:28:10.051
has actually become close to the Internet

00:28:10.051 --> 00:28:12.537
as a result of their political expression.

00:28:12.537 --> 00:28:16.248
And I believe that a Magna Carta for the Internet

00:28:16.248 --> 00:28:18.210
is exactly what we need.

00:28:18.210 --> 00:28:21.718
We need to encode our values

00:28:21.718 --> 00:28:25.065
not just in writing but in the structure of the Internet,

00:28:25.065 --> 00:28:27.305
and it's something that I hope,

00:28:27.305 --> 00:28:29.828
I invite everyone in the audience,

00:28:29.828 --> 00:28:33.078
not just here in Vancouver but around the world,

00:28:33.078 --> 00:28:35.434
to join and participate in.

00:28:35.434 --> 00:28:37.748
CA: Do you have a question for Ed?

00:28:37.748 --> 00:28:39.778
TBL: Well, two questions,

00:28:39.778 --> 00:28:40.902
a general question —

00:28:40.902 --> 00:28:42.697
CA: Ed, can you still hear us?

00:28:42.697 --> 00:28:46.213
ES: Yes, I can hear you.
CA: Oh, he's back.


00:28:46.213 --> 00:28:47.808
TBL: The wiretap on your line

00:28:47.808 --> 00:28:49.714
got a little interfered with for a moment.

00:28:49.714 --> 00:28:51.367
(Laughter)

00:28:51.367 --> 00:28:53.569
ES: It's a little bit of an NSA problem.

00:28:53.569 --> 00:28:57.376
TBL: So, from the 25 years,

00:28:57.376 --> 00:29:00.313
stepping back and thinking,

00:29:00.313 --> 00:29:02.059
what would you think would be

00:29:02.059 --> 00:29:04.666
the best that we could achieve

00:29:04.666 --> 00:29:06.526
from all the discussions that we have

00:29:06.526 --> 00:29:09.419
about the web we want?

00:29:09.419 --> 00:29:12.791
ES: When we think about

00:29:12.791 --> 00:29:15.904
in terms of how far we can go,

00:29:15.904 --> 00:29:18.057
I think that's a question that's really only limited

00:29:18.057 --> 00:29:20.594
by what we're willing to put into it.

00:29:20.594 --> 00:29:23.551
I think the Internet that we've enjoyed in the past

00:29:23.551 --> 00:29:29.109
has been exactly what we as not just a nation

00:29:29.109 --> 00:29:32.448
but as a people around the world need,

00:29:32.448 --> 00:29:36.674
and by cooperating, by engaging not just

00:29:36.674 --> 00:29:38.078
the technical parts of society,

00:29:38.078 --> 00:29:40.920
but as you said, the users,

00:29:40.920 --> 00:29:42.984
the people around the world who contribute

00:29:42.984 --> 00:29:45.426
through the Internet, through social media,

00:29:45.426 --> 00:29:47.153
who just check the weather,

00:29:47.153 --> 00:29:49.706
who rely on it every day as a part of their life,

00:29:49.706 --> 00:29:52.646
to champion that.

00:29:52.646 --> 00:29:55.183
We'll get not just the Internet we've had,

00:29:55.183 --> 00:29:58.132
but a better Internet, a better now,

00:29:58.132 --> 00:30:02.175
something that we can use to build a future

00:30:02.175 --> 00:30:05.143
that'll be better not just than what we hoped for

00:30:05.143 --> 00:30:07.528
but anything that we could have imagined.

00:30:07.528 --> 00:30:12.990
CA: It's 30 years ago that TED was founded, 1984.

00:30:12.990 --> 00:30:14.995
A lot of the conversation since then has been

00:30:14.995 --> 00:30:17.049
along the lines that

00:30:17.049 --> 00:30:18.952
actually George Orwell got it wrong.

00:30:18.952 --> 00:30:20.671
It's not Big Brother watching us.

00:30:20.671 --> 00:30:22.285
We, through the power of the web,

00:30:22.285 --> 00:30:24.649
and transparency, are now watching Big Brother.

00:30:24.649 --> 00:30:26.910
Your revelations kind of drove a stake

00:30:26.910 --> 00:30:30.657
through the heart of that rather optimistic view,

00:30:30.657 --> 00:30:34.077
but you still believe there's a way of doing something

00:30:34.077 --> 00:30:35.946
