I mean, first of all, a lot of people who look at risk and look at the numbers don't understand this belief that terrorism is still the number one threat. Apart from September 11, I think the numbers are that in the last 30 or 40 years about 500 Americans have died from terrorism, mostly from homegrown terrorists. The chance in the last few years of being killed by terrorism is far less than the chance of being killed by lightning. I guess you would say that a single nuclear incident or bioterrorism act or something like that would change those numbers. Would that be the point of view?RL: Well, I'd say two things. One is, the reason that there hasn't been a major attack in the United States since 9/11, that is not an accident. That's a lot of hard work that we have done, that other folks in the intelligence community have done, that the military has done, and that our allies around the globe have done. You've heard the numbers about the tip of the iceberg in terms of numbers of terrorist attacks that NSA programs contributed to stopping was 54, 25 of those in Europe, and of those 25, 18 of them occurred in three countries, some of which are our allies, and some of which are beating the heck out of us over the NSA programs, by the way. So that's not an accident that those things happen. That's hard work. That's us finding intelligence on terrorist activities and interdicting them through one way or another, through law enforcement, through cooperative activities with other countries and sometimes through military action. The other thing I would say is that your idea of nuclear or chem-bio-threat is not at all far-fetched and in fact there are a number of groups who have for several years expressed interest and desire in obtaining those capabilities and work towards that.CA: It's also been said that, of those 54 alleged incidents, that as few as zero of them were actually anything to do with these controversial programs that Mr. Snowden revealed, that it was basically through other forms of intelligence, that you're looking for a needle in a haystack, and the effects of these programs, these controversial programs, is just to add hay to the stack, not to really find the needle. The needle was found by other methods. Isn't there something to that?RL: No, there's actually two programs that are typically implicated in that discussion. One is the section 215 program, the U.S. telephony metadata program, and the other one is popularly called the PRISM program, and it's actually section 702  of the FISA Amendment Act. But the 215 program is only relevant to threats that are directed against the United States, and there have been a dozen threats where that was implicated. Now what you'll see people say publicly is there is no "but for" case, and so there is no case where, but for that, the threat would have happened. But that actually indicates a lack of understanding of how terrorist investigations actually work. You think about on television, you watch a murder mystery. What do you start with? You start with a body, and then they work their way from there to solve the crime. We're actually starting well before that, hopefully before there are any bodies, and we're trying to build the case for who the people are, what they're trying to do, and that involves massive amounts of information. Think of it is as mosaic, and it's hard to say that any one piece of a mosaic was necessary to building the mosaic, but to build the complete picture, you need to have all the pieces of information. On the other, the non-U.S.-related threats out of those 54, the other 42 of them, the PRISM program was hugely relevant to that, and in fact was material in contributing to stopping those attacks.CA: Snowden said two days ago that terrorism has always been what is called in the intelligence world "a cover for action," that it's something that, because it invokes such a powerful emotional response in people, it allows the initiation of these programs to achieve powers that an organization like yours couldn't otherwise have. Is there any internal debate about that?RL: Yeah. I mean, we debate these things all the time, and there is discussion that goes on in the executive branch and within NSA itself and the intelligence community about what's right, what's proportionate, what's the correct thing to do. And it's important to note that the programs that we're talking about were all authorized by two different presidents, two different political parties, by Congress twice, and by federal judges 16 different times, and so this is not NSA running off and doing its own thing. This is a legitimate activity of the United States foreign government that was agreed to by all the branches of the United States government, and President Madison would have been proud.CA: And yet, when congressmen discovered what was actually being done  with that authorization, many of them were completely shocked. Or do you think that is not a legitimate reaction, that it's only because it's now come out publicly, that they really knew exactly what you were doing with the powers they had granted you?RL: Congress is a big body. There's 535 of them, and they change out frequently, in the case of the House, every two years, and I think that the NSA provided all the relevant information to our oversight committees, and then the dissemination of that information by the oversight committees throughout Congress is something that they manage. I think I would say that Congress members had the opportunity to make themselves aware, and in fact a significant number of them, the ones who are assigned oversight responsibility, did have the ability to do that. And you've actually had the chairs of those committees say that in public. CA: Now, you mentioned the  threat of cyberattacks, and I don't think anyone in this room would disagree that that is a huge concern, but do you accept that there's a tradeoff between offensive and defensive strategies, and that it's possible that the very measures taken to, "weaken encryption," and allow yourself to find the bad guys, might also open the door to forms of cyberattack?RL: So I think two things. One is, you said weaken encryption. I didn't. And the other one is that the NSA has both of those missions, and we are heavily biased towards defense, and, actually, the vulnerabilities that we find in the overwhelming majority of cases, we disclose to the people who are responsible for manufacturing or developing those products. We have a great track record of that, and we're actually working on a proposal right now to be transparent and to publish transparency reports in the same way that the Internet companies are being allowed to publish transparency reports for them. We want to be more transparent about that. So again, we eat our own dog food. We use the standards, we use the products that we recommend, and so it's in our interest to keep our communications protected in the same way that other people's need to be.CA: Edward Snowden, when, after his talk, was wandering the halls here in the bot, and I heard him say to a couple of people, they asked him about what he thought of the NSA overall, and he was very complimentary about the people who work with you, said that it's a really impassioned group of employees who are seeking to do the right thing, and that the problems have come from just some badly conceived policies. He came over certainly very reasonably and calmly. He didn't come over like a crazy man. Would you accept that at least, even if you disagree with how he did it, that he has opened a debate that matters?RL: So I think that the discussion is an important one to have. I do not like the way that he did it. I think there were a number of other ways that he could have done that that would have not endangered our people and the people of other nations through losing visibility into what our adversaries are doing. But I do think it's an important conversation.CA: It's been reported that there's almost a difference of opinion with you and your colleagues over any scenario in which he might be offered an amnesty deal. I think your boss, General Keith Alexander, has said that that would be a terrible example for others; you can't negotiate with someone who's broken the law in that way. But you've been quoted as saying that, if Snowden could prove that he was surrendering all undisclosed documents, that a deal maybe should be considered. Do you still think that?RL: Yeah, so actually, this is my favorite thing about that "60 Minutes" interview was all the misquotes that came from that. What I actually said, in  response to a question about, would you entertain any discussions of mitigating action against Snowden, I said, yeah, it's worth a conversation. This is something that the attorney general of the United States and the president also actually have both talked about this, and I defer to the attorney general, because this is his lane. But there is a strong tradition in American jurisprudence of having discussions with people who have been charged with crimes in order to, if it benefits the government, to get something out of that, that there's always room for that kind of discussion. So I'm not presupposing any outcome, but there is always room for discussion.CA: To a lay person it seems like he has certain things to offer the U.S., the government, you, others, in terms of putting things right and helping figure out a smarter policy, a smarter way forward for the future. Do you see, has that kind of possibility been entertained at all? RL: So that's out of my lane. That's not an NSA thing. That would be a Department of Justice sort of discussion. I'll defer to them.CA: Rick, when Ed Snowden ended his talk, I offered him the chance to share an idea worth spreading. What would be your idea worth spreading for this group?RL: So I think, learn the facts. This is a really important conversation, and it impacts, it's not just NSA, it's not just the government, it's you, it's the Internet companies. The issue of privacy and personal data is much bigger than just the government, and so learn the facts. Don't rely on headlines, don't rely on sound bites, don't rely on one-sided conversations. So that's the idea, I think, worth spreading. We have a sign, a badge tab, we wear badges at work with lanyards, and if I could make a plug, my badge lanyard at work says, "Dallas Cowboys." Go Dallas. I've just alienated half the audience, I know. So the lanyard that our people who work in the organization that does our crypto-analytic work have a tab that says, "Look at the data." So that's the idea worth spreading. Look at the data.CA: Rick, it took a certain amount of courage, I think, actually, to come and speak openly to this group. It's not something the NSA has done a lot of in the past, and plus the technology has been challenging. We truly appreciate you doing that and sharing in this very important conversation. Thank you so much.RL: Thanks, Chris.(Applause)
subtitle:
WEBVTT
X-TIMESTAMP-MAP=MPEGTS:900000,LOCAL:00:00:00.000

00:00:12.648 --> 00:00:14.818
Chris Anderson: We had Edward Snowden here

00:00:14.818 --> 00:00:16.356
a couple days ago,

00:00:16.356 --> 00:00:18.699
and this is response time.

00:00:18.699 --> 00:00:20.954
And several of you have written to me

00:00:20.954 --> 00:00:25.597
with questions to ask our guest here from the NSA.

00:00:25.597 --> 00:00:27.945
So Richard Ledgett is the 15th deputy director

00:00:27.945 --> 00:00:30.510
of the National Security Agency,

00:00:30.510 --> 00:00:33.796
and he's a senior civilian officer there,

00:00:33.796 --> 00:00:35.781
acts as its chief operating officer,

00:00:35.781 --> 00:00:39.051
guiding strategies, setting internal policies,

00:00:39.051 --> 00:00:43.431
and serving as the principal advisor to the director.

00:00:43.431 --> 00:00:45.307
And all being well,

00:00:45.307 --> 00:00:48.823
welcome, Rick Ledgett, to TED.

00:00:48.823 --> 00:00:54.149
(Applause)

00:00:55.493 --> 00:00:59.241
Richard Ledgett: I'm really thankful for the opportunity to talk to folks here.

00:00:59.241 --> 00:01:01.195
I look forward to the conversation,

00:01:01.195 --> 00:01:04.177
so thanks for arranging for that.

00:01:04.177 --> 00:01:05.715
CA: Thank you, Rick.

00:01:05.715 --> 00:01:08.282
We appreciate you joining us.

00:01:08.282 --> 00:01:10.449
It's certainly quite a strong statement

00:01:10.449 --> 00:01:12.436
that the NSA is willing to reach out

00:01:12.436 --> 00:01:16.433
and show a more open face here.

00:01:16.433 --> 00:01:18.386
You saw, I think,

00:01:18.386 --> 00:01:22.279
the talk and interview that Edward Snowden

00:01:22.279 --> 00:01:23.223
gave here a couple days ago.

00:01:23.223 --> 00:01:25.662
What did you make of it?

00:01:25.662 --> 00:01:28.813
RL: So I think it was interesting.

00:01:28.813 --> 00:01:31.700
We didn't realize that he 
was going to show up there,

00:01:31.700 --> 00:01:34.833
so kudos to you guys for arranging

00:01:34.833 --> 00:01:37.536
a nice surprise like that.

00:01:37.536 --> 00:01:42.909
I think that, like a lot of the things

00:01:42.909 --> 00:01:47.428
that have come out since Mr. Snowden

00:01:47.428 --> 00:01:49.993
started disclosing classified information,

00:01:49.993 --> 00:01:53.459
there were some kernels of truth in there,

00:01:53.459 --> 00:01:56.953
but a lot of extrapolations and half-truths in there,

00:01:56.953 --> 00:01:59.476
and I'm interested in helping to address those.

00:01:59.476 --> 00:02:01.796
I think this is a really important conversation

00:02:01.796 --> 00:02:03.328
that we're having in the United States

00:02:03.328 --> 00:02:04.843
and internationally,

00:02:04.843 --> 00:02:09.252
and I think it is important and of import,

00:02:09.252 --> 00:02:12.712
and so given that, we need to have that be

00:02:12.712 --> 00:02:14.112
a fact-based conversation,

00:02:14.112 --> 00:02:16.564
and we want to help make that happen.

00:02:16.564 --> 00:02:21.181
CA: So the question that a lot 
of people have here is,

00:02:21.181 --> 00:02:24.095
what do you make of Snowden's motivations

00:02:24.095 --> 00:02:26.346
for doing what he did,

00:02:26.346 --> 00:02:30.836
and did he have an alternative
way that he could have gone?

00:02:30.836 --> 00:02:33.175
RL: He absolutely did

00:02:33.175 --> 00:02:37.373
have alternative ways that he could have gone,

00:02:37.373 --> 00:02:42.967
and I actually think that characterizing him

00:02:42.967 --> 00:02:44.957
as a whistleblower

00:02:44.957 --> 00:02:48.485
actually hurts legitimate whistleblowing activities.

00:02:48.485 --> 00:02:52.056
So what if somebody who works in the NSA --

00:02:52.056 --> 00:02:55.060
and there are over 35,000 people who do.

00:02:55.060 --> 00:02:57.413
They're all great citizens.

00:02:57.413 --> 00:02:59.716
They're just like your husbands, fathers, sisters,

00:02:59.716 --> 00:03:03.933
brothers, neighbors, nephews, friends and relatives,

00:03:03.933 --> 00:03:06.103
all of whom are interested in doing the right thing

00:03:06.103 --> 00:03:07.290
for their country

00:03:07.290 --> 00:03:10.324
and for our allies internationally,

00:03:10.324 --> 00:03:14.406
and so there are a variety of venues to address

00:03:14.406 --> 00:03:15.580
if folks have a concern.

00:03:15.580 --> 00:03:17.503
First off, there's their supervisor,

00:03:17.503 --> 00:03:20.195
and up through the supervisory chain

00:03:20.195 --> 00:03:21.937
within their organization.

00:03:21.937 --> 00:03:23.584
If folks aren't comfortable with that,

00:03:23.584 --> 00:03:25.939
there are a number of inspectors general.

00:03:25.939 --> 00:03:29.480
In the case of Mr. Snowden, he had the option

00:03:29.480 --> 00:03:31.405
of the NSA inspector general,

00:03:31.405 --> 00:03:32.725
the Navy inspector general,

00:03:32.725 --> 00:03:34.292
the Pacific Command inspector general,

00:03:34.292 --> 00:03:36.202
the Department of Defense inspector general,

00:03:36.202 --> 00:03:38.308
and the intelligence community inspector general,

00:03:38.308 --> 00:03:42.626
any of whom would have both kept
his concerns in classified channels

00:03:42.626 --> 00:03:45.257
and been happy to address them.

00:03:45.257 --> 00:03:47.534
(CA and RL speaking at once)

00:03:47.534 --> 00:03:50.137
He had the option to go to
congressional committees,

00:03:50.137 --> 00:03:53.256
and there are mechanisms
to do that that are in place,

00:03:53.256 --> 00:03:55.795
and so he didn't do any of those things.

00:03:55.795 --> 00:03:58.785
CA: Now, you had said that

00:03:58.785 --> 00:04:01.014
Ed Snowden had other avenues

00:04:01.014 --> 00:04:03.709
for raising his concerns.

00:04:03.709 --> 00:04:07.035
The comeback on that is a couple of things:

00:04:07.035 --> 00:04:10.845
one, that he certainly believes that as a contractor,

00:04:10.845 --> 00:04:14.606
the avenues that would have been available
to him as an employee weren't available,

00:04:14.606 --> 00:04:18.037
two, there's a track record of other whistleblowers,

00:04:18.037 --> 00:04:20.648
like [Thomas Andrews Drake] being treated

00:04:20.648 --> 00:04:23.795
pretty harshly, by some views,

00:04:23.795 --> 00:04:25.448
and thirdly, what he was taking on

00:04:25.448 --> 00:04:28.785
was not one specific flaw that he'd discovered,

00:04:28.785 --> 00:04:30.756
but programs that had been approved

00:04:30.756 --> 00:04:33.697
by all three branches of government.

00:04:33.697 --> 00:04:36.496
I mean, in that circumstance,

00:04:36.496 --> 00:04:38.899
couldn't you argue that what he did

00:04:38.899 --> 00:04:41.165
was reasonable?

00:04:41.165 --> 00:04:43.478
RL: No, I don't agree with that.

00:04:43.478 --> 00:04:47.215
I think that the —

00:04:47.215 --> 00:04:49.350
sorry, I'm getting feedback

00:04:49.350 --> 00:04:52.907
through the microphone there —

00:04:52.907 --> 00:04:57.734
the actions that he took were inappropriate

00:04:57.734 --> 00:05:02.509
because of the fact that 
he put people's lives at risk,

00:05:02.509 --> 00:05:03.981
basically, in the long run,

00:05:03.981 --> 00:05:05.545
and I know there's been a lot of talk

00:05:05.545 --> 00:05:10.209
in public by Mr. Snowden
and some of the journalists

00:05:10.209 --> 00:05:13.639
that say that the things that have been disclosed

00:05:13.639 --> 00:05:17.834
have not put national security and people at risk,

00:05:17.834 --> 00:05:22.128
and that is categorically not true.

00:05:22.128 --> 00:05:24.035
They actually do.

00:05:24.035 --> 00:05:26.876
I think there's also an amazing arrogance

00:05:26.876 --> 00:05:31.011
to the idea that he knows better than

00:05:31.011 --> 00:05:34.306
the framers of the Constitution

00:05:34.306 --> 00:05:36.685
in how the government should 
be designed and work

00:05:36.685 --> 00:05:38.827
for separation of powers

00:05:38.827 --> 00:05:45.274
and the fact that the executive 
and the legislative branch

00:05:45.274 --> 00:05:47.885
have to work together and they have
checks and balances on each other,

00:05:47.885 --> 00:05:49.419
and then the judicial branch,

00:05:49.419 --> 00:05:50.855
which oversees the entire process.

00:05:50.855 --> 00:05:55.076
I think that's extremely arrogant on his part.

00:05:55.076 --> 00:05:57.382
CA: Can you give a specific example

00:05:57.382 --> 00:06:00.838
of how he put people's lives at risk?

00:06:00.838 --> 00:06:02.835
RL: Yeah, sure.

00:06:02.835 --> 00:06:06.229
So the things that he's disclosed,

00:06:06.229 --> 00:06:07.744
the capabilities,

00:06:07.744 --> 00:06:10.186
and the NSA is a capabilities-based organization,

00:06:10.186 --> 00:06:14.060
so when we have foreign intelligence targets,

00:06:14.060 --> 00:06:15.691
legitimate things of interest --

00:06:15.691 --> 00:06:17.701
like, terrorists is the iconic example,

00:06:17.701 --> 00:06:20.795
but it includes things like human traffickers,

00:06:20.795 --> 00:06:22.657
drug traffickers,

00:06:22.657 --> 00:06:26.621
people who are trying to build
advanced weaponry, nuclear weapons,

00:06:26.621 --> 00:06:28.584
and build delivery systems for those,

00:06:28.584 --> 00:06:32.215
and nation-states who might be executing aggression against their immediate neighbors,

00:06:32.215 --> 00:06:34.809
which you may have some visibility

00:06:34.809 --> 00:06:37.563
into some of that that's going on right now,

00:06:37.563 --> 00:06:41.525
the capabilities are applied

00:06:41.525 --> 00:06:46.526
in very discrete and measured and controlled ways.

00:06:46.526 --> 00:06:49.314
So the unconstrained disclosure 
of those capabilities

00:06:49.314 --> 00:06:51.598
means that as adversaries see them

00:06:51.598 --> 00:06:53.961
and recognize, "Hey, I might be vulnerable to this,"

00:06:53.961 --> 00:06:55.528
they move away from that,

00:06:55.528 --> 00:06:58.737
and we have seen targets in terrorism,

00:06:58.737 --> 00:07:00.869
in the nation-state area,

00:07:00.869 --> 00:07:03.871
in smugglers of various types, and other folks

00:07:03.871 --> 00:07:05.824
who have, because of the disclosures,

00:07:05.824 --> 00:07:08.759
moved away from our ability

00:07:08.759 --> 00:07:10.847
to have insight into what they're doing.

00:07:10.847 --> 00:07:13.811
The net effect of that is that our people

00:07:13.811 --> 00:07:15.704
who are overseas in dangerous places,

00:07:15.704 --> 00:07:17.568
whether they're diplomats or military,

00:07:17.568 --> 00:07:20.159
and our allies who are in similar situations,

00:07:20.159 --> 00:07:23.018
are at greater risk because we don't see

00:07:23.018 --> 00:07:25.969
the threats that are coming their way.

00:07:25.969 --> 00:07:28.028
CA: So that's a general response saying that

00:07:28.028 --> 00:07:30.125
because of his revelations,

00:07:30.125 --> 00:07:32.991
access that you had to certain types of information

00:07:32.991 --> 00:07:36.562
has been shut down, has been closed down.

00:07:36.562 --> 00:07:40.111
But the concern is that the nature of that access

00:07:40.111 --> 00:07:43.815
was not necessarily legitimate in the first place.

00:07:43.815 --> 00:07:46.597
I mean, describe to us this Bullrun program

00:07:46.597 --> 00:07:48.726
where it's alleged that the NSA

00:07:48.726 --> 00:07:51.111
specifically weakened security

00:07:51.111 --> 00:07:55.680
in order to get the type of 
access that you've spoken of.

00:07:55.680 --> 00:08:00.821
RL: So there are, when our

00:08:00.821 --> 00:08:03.533
legitimate foreign intelligence targets
of the type that I described before,

00:08:03.533 --> 00:08:06.569
use the global telecommunications system

00:08:06.569 --> 00:08:08.652
as their communications methodology,

00:08:08.652 --> 00:08:10.066
and they do, because it's a great system,

00:08:10.066 --> 00:08:12.904
it's the most complex system ever devised by man,

00:08:12.904 --> 00:08:14.551
and it is a wonder,

00:08:14.551 --> 00:08:16.155
and lots of folks in the room there

00:08:16.155 --> 00:08:18.506
are responsible for the creation

00:08:18.506 --> 00:08:19.875
and enhancement of that,

00:08:19.875 --> 00:08:22.748
and it's just a wonderful thing.

00:08:22.748 --> 00:08:25.245
But it's also used by people who are

00:08:25.245 --> 00:08:27.276
working against us and our allies.

00:08:27.276 --> 00:08:29.707
And so if I'm going to pursue them,

00:08:29.707 --> 00:08:31.442
I need to have the capability

00:08:31.442 --> 00:08:33.617
to go after them,

00:08:33.617 --> 00:08:36.443
and again, the controls are in

00:08:36.443 --> 00:08:38.964
how I apply that capability,

00:08:38.964 --> 00:08:41.210
not that I have the capability itself.

00:08:41.210 --> 00:08:42.982
Otherwise, if we could make it so that

00:08:42.982 --> 00:08:45.168
all the bad guys used one corner of the Internet,

00:08:45.168 --> 00:08:47.124
we could have a domain, badguy.com.

00:08:47.124 --> 00:08:48.618
That would be awesome,

00:08:48.618 --> 00:08:50.760
and we could just concentrate all our efforts there.

00:08:50.760 --> 00:08:52.092
That's not how it works.

00:08:52.092 --> 00:08:54.303
They're trying to hide

00:08:54.303 --> 00:08:56.108
from the government's ability

00:08:56.108 --> 00:08:59.391
to isolate and interdict their actions,

00:08:59.391 --> 00:09:02.203
and so we have to swim in that same space.

00:09:02.203 --> 00:09:03.805
But I will tell you this.

00:09:03.805 --> 00:09:05.284
So NSA has two missions.

00:09:05.284 --> 00:09:06.734
One is the Signals Intelligence mission

00:09:06.734 --> 00:09:10.361
that we've unfortunately read so
much about in the press.

00:09:10.361 --> 00:09:12.099
The other one is the Information Assurance mission,

00:09:12.099 --> 00:09:15.010
which is to protect the national security
systems of the United States,

00:09:15.010 --> 00:09:16.978
and by that, that's things like

00:09:16.978 --> 00:09:18.994
the communications that the president uses,

00:09:18.994 --> 00:09:21.599
the communications that
control our nuclear weapons,

00:09:21.599 --> 00:09:23.868
the communications that our
military uses around the world,

00:09:23.868 --> 00:09:26.359
and the communications that we use with our allies,

00:09:26.359 --> 00:09:28.083
and that some of our allies themselves use.

00:09:28.083 --> 00:09:33.920
And so we make recommendations
on standards to use,

00:09:33.920 --> 00:09:35.747
and we use those same standards,

00:09:35.747 --> 00:09:37.625
and so we are invested

00:09:37.625 --> 00:09:39.870
in making sure that those communications

00:09:39.870 --> 00:09:43.483
are secure for their intended purposes.

00:09:43.483 --> 00:09:45.432
CA: But it sounds like what you're saying is that

00:09:45.432 --> 00:09:49.177
when it comes to the Internet at large,

00:09:49.177 --> 00:09:51.804
any strategy is fair game

00:09:51.804 --> 00:09:54.720
if it improves America's safety.

00:09:54.720 --> 00:09:56.778
And I think this is partly where there is such

00:09:56.778 --> 00:09:58.163
a divide of opinion,

00:09:58.163 --> 00:09:59.413
that there's a lot of people in this room

00:09:59.413 --> 00:10:00.786
and around the world

00:10:00.786 --> 00:10:02.436
who think very differently about the Internet.

00:10:02.436 --> 00:10:05.423
They think of it as a momentous

00:10:05.423 --> 00:10:07.021
invention of humanity,

00:10:07.021 --> 00:10:10.185
kind of on a par with the
Gutenberg press, for example.

00:10:10.185 --> 00:10:12.640
It's the bringer of knowledge to all.

00:10:12.640 --> 00:10:14.344
It's the connector of all.

00:10:14.344 --> 00:10:17.729
And it's viewed in those sort of idealistic terms.

00:10:17.729 --> 00:10:19.302
And from that lens,

00:10:19.302 --> 00:10:21.899
what the NSA has done is equivalent to

00:10:21.899 --> 00:10:24.059
the authorities back in Germany

00:10:24.059 --> 00:10:26.928
inserting some device into every printing press

00:10:26.928 --> 00:10:30.469
that would reveal which books people bought

00:10:30.469 --> 00:10:32.489
and what they read.

00:10:32.489 --> 00:10:34.720
Can you understand that from that viewpoint,

00:10:34.720 --> 00:10:38.925
it feels outrageous?

00:10:38.925 --> 00:10:42.227
RL: I do understand that, and I actually share
the view of the utility of the Internet,

00:10:42.227 --> 00:10:43.929
and I would argue it's bigger than the Internet.

00:10:43.929 --> 00:10:46.340
It is a global telecommunications system.

00:10:46.340 --> 00:10:48.791
The Internet is a big chunk of 
that, but there is a lot more.

00:10:48.791 --> 00:10:52.134
And I think that people have legitimate concerns

00:10:52.134 --> 00:10:58.440
about the balance between
transparency and secrecy.

00:10:58.440 --> 00:11:00.380
That's sort of been couched as a balance

00:11:00.380 --> 00:11:04.016
between privacy and national security.

00:11:04.016 --> 00:11:05.436
I don't think that's the right framing.

00:11:05.436 --> 00:11:07.801
I think it really is transparency and secrecy.

00:11:07.801 --> 00:11:11.360
And so that's the national and international conversation that we're having,

00:11:11.360 --> 00:11:12.759
and we want to participate in that, and want

00:11:12.759 --> 00:11:15.199
people to participate in it in an informed way.

00:11:15.199 --> 00:11:17.110
So there are things,

00:11:17.110 --> 00:11:18.560
let me talk there a little bit more,

00:11:18.560 --> 00:11:22.329
there are things that we need
to be transparent about:

00:11:22.329 --> 00:11:24.356
our authorities, our processes,

00:11:24.356 --> 00:11:26.410
our oversight, who we are.

00:11:26.410 --> 00:11:28.176
We, NSA, have not done a good job of that,

00:11:28.176 --> 00:11:29.564
and I think that's part of the reason

00:11:29.564 --> 00:11:32.293
that this has been so revelational

00:11:32.293 --> 00:11:34.489
and so sensational in the media.

00:11:34.489 --> 00:11:38.615
Nobody knew who we were. We were the No Such Agency, the Never Say Anything.

00:11:38.615 --> 00:11:41.264
There's takeoffs of our logo

00:11:41.264 --> 00:11:44.283
of an eagle with headphones on around it.

00:11:44.283 --> 00:11:47.906
And so that's the public characterization.

00:11:47.906 --> 00:11:52.242
And so we need to be more
transparent about those things.

00:11:52.242 --> 00:11:53.660
What we don't need to be transparent about,

00:11:53.660 --> 00:11:55.998
because it's bad for the U.S.,

00:11:55.998 --> 00:11:58.581
it's bad for all those other
countries that we work with

00:11:58.581 --> 00:12:00.674
and that we help provide information

00:12:00.674 --> 00:12:02.396
that helps them secure themselves

00:12:02.396 --> 00:12:03.905
and their people,

00:12:03.905 --> 00:12:07.795
it's bad to expose operations and capabilities

00:12:07.795 --> 00:12:13.087
in a way that allows the people
that we're all working against,

00:12:13.087 --> 00:12:18.050
the generally recognized bad guys,

00:12:18.050 --> 00:12:20.350
to counter those.

00:12:20.350 --> 00:12:23.375
CA: But isn't it also bad to deal

00:12:23.375 --> 00:12:26.779
a kind of body blow to the American companies

00:12:26.779 --> 00:12:28.675
that have essentially given the world

00:12:28.675 --> 00:12:33.855
most of the Internet services that matter?

00:12:33.855 --> 00:12:37.247
RL: It is. It's really the companies are

00:12:37.247 --> 00:12:40.635
in a tough position, as are we,

00:12:40.635 --> 00:12:42.576
because the companies,

00:12:42.576 --> 00:12:44.908
we compel them to provide information,

00:12:44.908 --> 00:12:46.891
just like every other nation in the world does.

00:12:46.891 --> 00:12:50.165
Every industrialized nation in the world

00:12:50.165 --> 00:12:52.265
has a lawful intercept program

00:12:52.265 --> 00:12:54.763
where they are requiring companies

00:12:54.763 --> 00:12:56.174
to provide them with information

00:12:56.174 --> 00:12:57.829
that they need for their security,

00:12:57.829 --> 00:13:00.056
and the companies that are involved

00:13:00.056 --> 00:13:01.484
have complied with those programs

00:13:01.484 --> 00:13:03.102
in the same way that they have to do

00:13:03.102 --> 00:13:06.552
when they're operating in Russia or the U.K.

00:13:06.552 --> 00:13:10.838
or China or India or France,

00:13:10.838 --> 00:13:12.856
any country that you choose to name.

00:13:12.856 --> 00:13:17.765
And so the fact that these revelations

00:13:17.765 --> 00:13:20.059
have been broadly characterized as

00:13:20.059 --> 00:13:21.949
"you can't trust company A because

00:13:21.949 --> 00:13:25.464
your privacy is suspect with them"

00:13:25.464 --> 00:13:29.505
is actually only accurate in the sense that

00:13:29.505 --> 00:13:32.241
it's accurate with every other company in the world

00:13:32.241 --> 00:13:34.400
that deals with any of those countries in the world.

00:13:34.400 --> 00:13:36.528
And so it's being picked up by people

00:13:36.528 --> 00:13:38.122
as a marketing advantage,

00:13:38.122 --> 00:13:39.895
and it's being marketed that 
way by several countries,

00:13:39.895 --> 00:13:41.406
including some of our allied countries,

00:13:41.406 --> 00:13:42.908
where they are saying,

00:13:42.908 --> 00:13:44.437
"Hey, you can't trust the U.S.,

00:13:44.437 --> 00:13:47.023
but you can trust our telecom company,

00:13:47.023 --> 00:13:48.377
because we're safe."

00:13:48.377 --> 00:13:50.036
And they're actually using that to counter

00:13:50.036 --> 00:13:52.354
the very large technological edge

00:13:52.354 --> 00:13:54.163
that U.S. companies have

00:13:54.163 --> 00:13:58.069
in areas like the cloud and
Internet-based technologies.

00:13:58.069 --> 00:14:01.076
CA: You're sitting there with the American flag,

00:14:01.076 --> 00:14:04.646
and the American Constitution guarantees

00:14:04.646 --> 00:14:07.493
freedom from unreasonable search and seizure.

00:14:07.493 --> 00:14:09.454
How do you characterize

00:14:09.454 --> 00:14:13.934
the American citizen's right to privacy?

00:14:13.934 --> 00:14:16.215
Is there such a right?

00:14:16.215 --> 00:14:18.951
RL: Yeah, of course there is.

00:14:18.951 --> 00:14:21.994
And we devote an inordinate
amount of time and pressure,

00:14:21.994 --> 00:14:24.278
inordinate and appropriate, actually I should say,

00:14:24.278 --> 00:14:26.486
amount of time and effort in order to ensure

00:14:26.486 --> 00:14:28.818
that we protect that privacy.

00:14:28.818 --> 00:14:31.875
and beyond that, the privacy of citizens

00:14:31.875 --> 00:14:35.524
around the world, it's not just Americans.

00:14:35.524 --> 00:14:37.424
Several things come into play here.

00:14:37.424 --> 00:14:39.172
First, we're all in the same network.

00:14:39.172 --> 00:14:40.746
My communications,

00:14:40.746 --> 00:14:44.893
I'm a user of a particular Internet email service

00:14:44.893 --> 00:14:48.864
that is the number one email service of choice

00:14:48.864 --> 00:14:50.457
by terrorists around the world, number one.

00:14:50.457 --> 00:14:53.182
So I'm there right beside them in email space

00:14:53.182 --> 00:14:55.071
in the Internet.

00:14:55.071 --> 00:14:58.663
And so we need to be able to pick that apart

00:14:58.663 --> 00:15:02.518
and find the information that's relevant.

00:15:05.089 --> 00:15:08.451
In doing so, we're going to necessarily encounter

00:15:08.451 --> 00:15:10.519
Americans and innocent foreign citizens

00:15:10.519 --> 00:15:12.065
who are just going about their business,

00:15:12.065 --> 00:15:14.763
and so we have procedures in
place that shreds that out,

00:15:14.763 --> 00:15:16.978
that says, when you find that,

00:15:16.978 --> 00:15:19.245
not if you find it, when you find it,
because you're certain to find it,

00:15:19.245 --> 00:15:21.028
here's how you protect that.

00:15:21.028 --> 00:15:23.133
These are called minimization procedures.

00:15:23.133 --> 00:15:25.161
They're approved by the attorney general

00:15:25.161 --> 00:15:26.761
and constitutionally based.

00:15:26.761 --> 00:15:29.241
And so we protect those.

00:15:29.241 --> 00:15:33.712
And then, for people, citizens of the world

00:15:33.712 --> 00:15:35.591
who are going about their lawful business

00:15:35.591 --> 00:15:37.298
on a day-to-day basis,

00:15:37.298 --> 00:15:39.594
the president on his January 17 speech,

00:15:39.594 --> 00:15:41.087
laid out some additional protections

00:15:41.087 --> 00:15:43.146
that we are providing to them.

00:15:43.146 --> 00:15:45.018
So I think absolutely,

00:15:45.018 --> 00:15:46.553
folks do have a right to privacy,

00:15:46.553 --> 00:15:49.172
and that we work very hard to make sure

00:15:49.172 --> 00:15:51.978
that that right to privacy is protected.

00:15:51.978 --> 00:15:53.714
CA: What about foreigners using

00:15:53.714 --> 00:15:55.864
American companies' Internet services?

00:15:55.864 --> 00:15:59.709
Do they have any privacy rights?

00:15:59.709 --> 00:16:02.382
RL: They do. They do, in the sense of,

00:16:02.382 --> 00:16:08.122
the only way that we are able to compel

00:16:08.122 --> 00:16:10.448
one of those companies to provide us information

00:16:10.448 --> 00:16:13.910
is when it falls into one of three categories:

00:16:13.910 --> 00:16:17.462
We can identify that this particular person,

00:16:17.462 --> 00:16:19.852
identified by a selector of some kind,

00:16:19.852 --> 00:16:23.208
is associated with counterterrorist

00:16:23.208 --> 00:16:28.457
or proliferation or other foreign intelligence target.

00:16:28.457 --> 00:16:30.239
CA: Much has been made of the fact that

00:16:30.239 --> 00:16:32.705
a lot of the information that you've obtained

00:16:32.705 --> 00:16:34.981
through these programs is essentially metadata.

00:16:34.981 --> 00:16:37.276
It's not necessarily the actual words

00:16:37.276 --> 00:16:38.929
that someone has written in an email

00:16:38.929 --> 00:16:40.278
or given on a phone call.

00:16:40.278 --> 00:16:44.327
It's who they wrote to and when, and so forth.

00:16:44.327 --> 00:16:45.863
But it's been argued,

00:16:45.863 --> 00:16:47.974
and someone here in the audience has talked

00:16:47.974 --> 00:16:50.441
to a former NSA analyst who said

00:16:50.441 --> 00:16:52.828
metadata is actually much more invasive

00:16:52.828 --> 00:16:54.231
than the core data,

00:16:54.231 --> 00:16:55.364
because in the core data

00:16:55.364 --> 00:16:58.591
you present yourself as you want to be presented.

00:16:58.591 --> 00:17:01.297
With metadata, who knows what the conclusions are

00:17:01.297 --> 00:17:02.713
that are drawn?

00:17:02.713 --> 00:17:04.719
Is there anything to that?

00:17:04.719 --> 00:17:06.508
RL: I don't really understand that argument.

00:17:06.508 --> 00:17:09.408
I think that metadata's important
for a couple of reasons.

00:17:09.408 --> 00:17:13.886
Metadata is the information that lets you

00:17:13.886 --> 00:17:17.277
find connections that people are trying to hide.

00:17:17.277 --> 00:17:19.288
So when a terrorist is corresponding

00:17:19.288 --> 00:17:21.133
with somebody else who's not known to us

00:17:21.133 --> 00:17:23.741
but is engaged in doing or
supporting terrorist activity,

00:17:23.741 --> 00:17:26.167
or someone who's violating international sanctions

00:17:26.167 --> 00:17:29.244
by providing nuclear weapons-related material

00:17:29.244 --> 00:17:31.570
to a country like Iran or North Korea,

00:17:31.570 --> 00:17:35.147
is trying to hide that activity
because it's illicit activity.

00:17:35.147 --> 00:17:37.957
What metadata lets you do is connect that.

00:17:37.957 --> 00:17:39.489
The alternative to that

00:17:39.489 --> 00:17:41.108
is one that's much less efficient

00:17:41.108 --> 00:17:42.489
and much more invasive of privacy,

00:17:42.489 --> 00:17:46.325
which is gigantic amounts of content collection.

00:17:46.325 --> 00:17:47.718
So metadata, in that sense,

00:17:47.718 --> 00:17:50.114
actually is privacy-enhancing.

00:17:50.114 --> 00:17:52.219
And we don't, contrary to some of the stuff

00:17:52.219 --> 00:17:53.934
that's been printed,

00:17:53.934 --> 00:17:56.703
we don't sit there and grind out

00:17:56.703 --> 00:17:59.540
metadata profiles of average people.

00:17:59.540 --> 00:18:01.496
If you're not connected

00:18:01.496 --> 00:18:04.548
to one of those valid intelligence targets,

00:18:04.548 --> 00:18:07.961
you are not of interest to us.

00:18:07.961 --> 00:18:11.133
CA: So in terms of the threats

00:18:11.133 --> 00:18:13.445
that face America overall,

00:18:13.445 --> 00:18:16.657
where would you place terrorism?

00:18:16.657 --> 00:18:19.755
RL: I think terrorism is still number one.

00:18:19.755 --> 00:18:23.659
I think that we have never been in a time

00:18:23.659 --> 00:18:25.650
where there are more places

00:18:25.650 --> 00:18:28.503
where things are going badly

00:18:28.503 --> 00:18:32.404
and forming the petri dish in which terrorists

00:18:32.404 --> 00:18:37.714
take advantage of the lack of governance.

00:18:37.714 --> 00:18:41.351
An old boss of mine, Tom Fargo, Admiral Fargo,

00:18:41.351 --> 00:18:43.564
used to describe it as arcs of instability.

00:18:43.564 --> 00:18:45.932
And so you have a lot of those arcs of instability

00:18:45.932 --> 00:18:47.625
in the world right now,

00:18:47.625 --> 00:18:49.462
in places like Syria, where there's a civil war

00:18:49.462 --> 00:18:52.172
going on and you have massive numbers,

00:18:52.172 --> 00:18:53.907
thousands and thousands of foreign fighters

00:18:53.907 --> 00:18:55.640
who are coming into Syria

00:18:55.640 --> 00:18:57.143
to learn how to be terrorists

00:18:57.143 --> 00:18:59.244
and practice that activity,

00:18:59.244 --> 00:19:01.943
and lots of those people are Westerners

00:19:01.943 --> 00:19:05.672
who hold passports to European countries

00:19:05.672 --> 00:19:07.424
or in some cases the United States,

00:19:07.424 --> 00:19:09.825
and so they are basically learning how

00:19:09.825 --> 00:19:13.305
to do jihad and have expressed intent

00:19:13.305 --> 00:19:15.718
to go out and do that later on

00:19:15.718 --> 00:19:17.385
in their home countries.

00:19:17.385 --> 00:19:18.706
You've got places like Iraq,

00:19:18.706 --> 00:19:21.488
which is suffering from a high
level of sectarian violence,

00:19:21.488 --> 00:19:24.139
again a breeding ground for terrorism.

00:19:24.139 --> 00:19:26.645
And you have the activity in the Horn of Africa

00:19:26.645 --> 00:19:29.692
and the Sahel area of Africa.

00:19:29.692 --> 00:19:32.220
Again, lots of weak governance

00:19:32.220 --> 00:19:36.111
which forms a breeding ground for terrorist activity.

00:19:36.111 --> 00:19:38.105
So I think it's very serious. I think it's number one.

00:19:38.105 --> 00:19:40.359
I think number two is cyber threat.

00:19:40.359 --> 00:19:46.123
I think cyber is a threat in three ways:

00:19:46.123 --> 00:19:49.877
One way, and probably the most common way

00:19:49.877 --> 00:19:52.069
that people have heard about it,

00:19:52.069 --> 00:19:54.069
is due to the theft of intellectual property,

00:19:54.069 --> 00:19:58.373
so basically, foreign countries going in,

00:19:58.373 --> 00:20:00.250
stealing companies' secrets,

00:20:00.250 --> 00:20:02.248
and then providing that information

00:20:02.248 --> 00:20:03.985
to state-owned enterprises

00:20:03.985 --> 00:20:06.934
or companies connected to the government

00:20:06.934 --> 00:20:09.437
to help them leapfrog technology

00:20:09.437 --> 00:20:11.512
or to gain business intelligence

00:20:11.512 --> 00:20:14.180
that's then used to win contracts overseas.

00:20:14.180 --> 00:20:17.919
That is a hugely costly set of
activities that's going on right now.

00:20:17.919 --> 00:20:19.386
Several nation-states are doing it.

00:20:19.386 --> 00:20:22.611
Second is the denial-of-service attacks.

00:20:22.611 --> 00:20:23.990
You're probably aware that there have been

00:20:23.990 --> 00:20:25.961
a spate of those directed against

00:20:25.961 --> 00:20:29.549
the U.S. financial sector since 2012.

00:20:29.549 --> 00:20:32.166
Again, that's a nation-state who
is executing those attacks,

00:20:32.166 --> 00:20:33.239
and they're doing that

00:20:33.239 --> 00:20:37.992
as a semi-anonymous way of reprisal.

00:20:37.992 --> 00:20:39.382
And the last one is destructive attacks,

00:20:39.382 --> 00:20:40.908
and those are the ones that concern me the most.

00:20:40.908 --> 00:20:42.308
Those are on the rise.

00:20:42.308 --> 00:20:45.938
You have the attack against Saudi Aramco in 2012,

00:20:45.938 --> 00:20:47.628
August of 2012.

00:20:47.628 --> 00:20:49.913
It took down about 35,000 of their computers

00:20:49.913 --> 00:20:51.705
with a Wiper-style virus.

00:20:51.705 --> 00:20:53.618
You had a follow-on a week later

00:20:53.618 --> 00:20:55.152
to a Qatari company.

00:20:55.152 --> 00:20:57.293
You had March of 2013,

00:20:57.293 --> 00:20:59.964
you had a South Korean attack

00:20:59.964 --> 00:21:02.397
that was attributed in the press to North Korea

00:21:02.397 --> 00:21:04.452
that took out thousands of computers.

00:21:04.452 --> 00:21:05.897
Those are on the rise,

00:21:05.897 --> 00:21:08.631
and we see people expressing interest

00:21:08.631 --> 00:21:09.807
in those capabilities

00:21:09.807 --> 00:21:11.824
and a desire to employ them.

00:21:11.824 --> 00:21:13.390
CA: Okay, so a couple of things here,

00:21:13.390 --> 00:21:15.332
because this is really the core of this, almost.

00:21:15.332 --> 00:21:16.596
I mean, first of all,

00:21:16.596 --> 00:21:18.154
a lot of people who look at risk

00:21:18.154 --> 00:21:19.371
and look at the numbers

00:21:19.371 --> 00:21:21.631
don't understand this belief that terrorism

00:21:21.631 --> 00:21:23.515
is still the number one threat.

00:21:23.515 --> 00:21:25.143
Apart from September 11,

00:21:25.143 --> 00:21:27.498
I think the numbers are that
in the last 30 or 40 years

00:21:27.498 --> 00:21:30.599
about 500 Americans have died from terrorism,

00:21:30.599 --> 00:21:34.582
mostly from homegrown terrorists.

00:21:34.582 --> 00:21:36.169
The chance in the last few years

00:21:36.169 --> 00:21:37.892
of being killed by terrorism

00:21:37.892 --> 00:21:41.876
is far less than the chance
of being killed by lightning.

00:21:41.876 --> 00:21:45.282
I guess you would say that a single nuclear incident

00:21:45.282 --> 00:21:48.608
or bioterrorism act or something like that

00:21:48.608 --> 00:21:50.509
would change those numbers.

00:21:50.509 --> 00:21:52.671
Would that be the point of view?

00:21:52.671 --> 00:21:53.847
RL: Well, I'd say two things.

00:21:53.847 --> 00:21:55.773
One is, the reason that there hasn't been

00:21:55.773 --> 00:21:57.583
a major attack in the United States since 9/11,

00:21:57.583 --> 00:21:59.139
that is not an accident.

00:21:59.139 --> 00:22:01.325
That's a lot of hard work that we have done,

00:22:01.325 --> 00:22:02.706
that other folks

00:22:02.706 --> 00:22:04.089
in the intelligence community have done,

00:22:04.089 --> 00:22:05.270
that the military has done,

00:22:05.270 --> 00:22:07.318
and that our allies around the globe have done.

00:22:07.318 --> 00:22:09.769
You've heard the numbers about

00:22:09.769 --> 00:22:12.301
the tip of the iceberg in terms

00:22:12.301 --> 00:22:14.871
of numbers of terrorist attacks that NSA programs

00:22:14.871 --> 00:22:17.630
contributed to stopping was 54,

00:22:17.630 --> 00:22:19.452
25 of those in Europe,

00:22:19.452 --> 00:22:21.582
and of those 25,

00:22:21.582 --> 00:22:24.187
18 of them occurred in three countries,

00:22:24.187 --> 00:22:26.050
some of which are our allies,

00:22:26.050 --> 00:22:28.249
and some of which are beating the heck out of us

00:22:28.249 --> 00:22:32.726
over the NSA programs, by the way.

00:22:32.726 --> 00:22:35.418
So that's not an accident that those things happen.

00:22:35.418 --> 00:22:37.743
That's hard work. That's us finding intelligence

00:22:37.743 --> 00:22:39.573
on terrorist activities

00:22:39.573 --> 00:22:41.147
and interdicting them through one way or another,

00:22:41.147 --> 00:22:42.478
through law enforcement,

00:22:42.478 --> 00:22:45.308
through cooperative activities with other countries

00:22:45.308 --> 00:22:48.424
and sometimes through military action.

00:22:48.424 --> 00:22:51.317
The other thing I would say is that

00:22:51.317 --> 00:22:56.583
your idea of nuclear or chem-bio-threat

00:22:56.583 --> 00:22:58.099
is not at all far-fetched

00:22:58.099 --> 00:22:59.837
and in fact there are a number of groups

00:22:59.837 --> 00:23:01.724
who have for several years expressed interest

00:23:01.724 --> 00:23:04.264
and desire in obtaining those capabilities

00:23:04.264 --> 00:23:06.024
and work towards that.

00:23:06.024 --> 00:23:07.600
CA: It's also been said that,

00:23:07.600 --> 00:23:10.300
of those 54 alleged incidents,

00:23:10.300 --> 00:23:12.148
that as few as zero of them

00:23:12.148 --> 00:23:13.210
were actually anything to do

00:23:13.210 --> 00:23:15.057
with these controversial programs

00:23:15.057 --> 00:23:18.789
that Mr. Snowden revealed,

00:23:18.789 --> 00:23:22.706
that it was basically through
other forms of intelligence,

00:23:22.706 --> 00:23:25.596
that you're looking for a needle in a haystack,

00:23:25.596 --> 00:23:27.158
and the effects of these programs,

00:23:27.158 --> 00:23:28.189
these controversial programs,

00:23:28.189 --> 00:23:30.261
is just to add hay to the stack,

00:23:30.261 --> 00:23:31.841
not to really find the needle.

00:23:31.841 --> 00:23:33.923
The needle was found by other methods.

00:23:33.923 --> 00:23:38.047
Isn't there something to that?

00:23:38.047 --> 00:23:40.455
RL: No, there's actually two programs

00:23:40.455 --> 00:23:42.872
that are typically implicated in that discussion.

00:23:42.872 --> 00:23:45.350
One is the section 215 program,

00:23:45.350 --> 00:23:48.328
the U.S. telephony metadata program,

00:23:48.328 --> 00:23:50.368
and the other one is

00:23:50.368 --> 00:23:51.962
popularly called the PRISM program,

00:23:51.962 --> 00:23:55.210
and it's actually section 702 
of the FISA Amendment Act.

00:23:55.210 --> 00:23:59.400
But the 215 program

00:23:59.400 --> 00:24:01.127
is only relevant to threats

00:24:01.127 --> 00:24:03.386
that are directed against the United States,

00:24:03.386 --> 00:24:06.286
and there have been a dozen threats

00:24:06.286 --> 00:24:07.601
where that was implicated.

00:24:07.601 --> 00:24:10.790
Now what you'll see people say publicly

00:24:10.790 --> 00:24:12.826
is there is no "but for" case,

00:24:12.826 --> 00:24:16.639
and so there is no case where, but for that,

00:24:16.639 --> 00:24:18.340
the threat would have happened.

00:24:18.340 --> 00:24:22.547
But that actually indicates a lack of understanding

00:24:22.547 --> 00:24:27.664
of how terrorist investigations actually work.

00:24:27.664 --> 00:24:29.142
You think about on television,

00:24:29.142 --> 00:24:30.474
you watch a murder mystery.

00:24:30.474 --> 00:24:32.004
What do you start with? You start with a body,

00:24:32.004 --> 00:24:34.240
and then they work their way
from there to solve the crime.

00:24:34.240 --> 00:24:35.771
We're actually starting well before that,

00:24:35.771 --> 00:24:37.272
hopefully before there are any bodies,

00:24:37.272 --> 00:24:39.705
and we're trying to build the case for

00:24:39.705 --> 00:24:42.135
who the people are, what they're trying to do,

00:24:42.135 --> 00:24:44.985
and that involves massive amounts of information.

00:24:44.985 --> 00:24:46.466
Think of it is as mosaic,

00:24:46.466 --> 00:24:48.628
and it's hard to say that any one piece of a mosaic

00:24:48.628 --> 00:24:51.260
was necessary to building the mosaic,

00:24:51.260 --> 00:24:52.989
but to build the complete picture,

00:24:52.989 --> 00:24:54.954
you need to have all the pieces of information.

00:24:54.954 --> 00:24:58.059
On the other, the non-U.S.-related
threats out of those 54,

00:24:58.059 --> 00:25:01.248
the other 42 of them,

00:25:01.248 --> 00:25:05.878
the PRISM program was hugely relevant to that,

00:25:05.878 --> 00:25:08.864
and in fact was material in contributing

00:25:08.864 --> 00:25:10.746
to stopping those attacks.

00:25:10.746 --> 00:25:12.083
CA: Snowden said two days ago

00:25:12.083 --> 00:25:15.453
that terrorism has always been

00:25:15.453 --> 00:25:17.581
what is called in the intelligence world

00:25:17.581 --> 00:25:19.127
"a cover for action,"

00:25:19.127 --> 00:25:21.064
that it's something that,

00:25:21.064 --> 00:25:22.780
because it invokes such a powerful

00:25:22.780 --> 00:25:24.619
emotional response in people,

00:25:24.619 --> 00:25:27.253
it allows the initiation of these programs

00:25:27.253 --> 00:25:30.814
to achieve powers that an organization like yours

00:25:30.814 --> 00:25:32.381
couldn't otherwise have.

00:25:32.381 --> 00:25:35.833
Is there any internal debate about that?

00:25:35.833 --> 00:25:37.245
RL: Yeah.

00:25:37.245 --> 00:25:39.245
I mean, we debate these things all the time,

00:25:39.245 --> 00:25:42.004
and there is discussion that goes on

00:25:42.004 --> 00:25:43.925
in the executive branch

00:25:43.925 --> 00:25:45.988
and within NSA itself

00:25:45.988 --> 00:25:47.643
and the intelligence community about

00:25:47.643 --> 00:25:49.003
what's right, what's proportionate,

00:25:49.003 --> 00:25:50.264
what's the correct thing to do.

00:25:50.264 --> 00:25:51.842
And it's important to note that the programs

00:25:51.842 --> 00:25:53.189
that we're talking about

00:25:53.189 --> 00:25:56.591
were all authorized by two different presidents,

00:25:56.591 --> 00:25:58.336
two different political parties,

00:25:58.336 --> 00:26:00.471
by Congress twice,

00:26:00.471 --> 00:26:04.307
and by federal judges 16 different times,

00:26:04.307 --> 00:26:09.019
and so this is not NSA running off

00:26:09.019 --> 00:26:10.482
and doing its own thing.

00:26:10.482 --> 00:26:12.930
This is a legitimate activity

00:26:12.930 --> 00:26:15.448
of the United States foreign government

00:26:15.448 --> 00:26:17.623
that was agreed to by all the branches

00:26:17.623 --> 00:26:19.607
of the United States government,

00:26:19.607 --> 00:26:22.656
and President Madison would have been proud.

00:26:22.656 --> 00:26:26.745
CA: And yet, when congressmen discovered

00:26:26.745 --> 00:26:28.975
what was actually being done 
with that authorization,

00:26:28.975 --> 00:26:31.844
many of them were completely shocked.

00:26:31.844 --> 00:26:35.190
Or do you think that is not a legitimate reaction,

00:26:35.190 --> 00:26:37.295
that it's only because it's now come out publicly,

00:26:37.295 --> 00:26:40.397
that they really knew exactly what you were doing

00:26:40.397 --> 00:26:42.733
with the powers they had granted you?

00:26:42.733 --> 00:26:44.407
RL: Congress is a big body.

00:26:44.407 --> 00:26:46.384
There's 535 of them,

00:26:46.384 --> 00:26:48.525
and they change out frequently,

00:26:48.525 --> 00:26:50.383
in the case of the House, every two years,

00:26:50.383 --> 00:26:54.159
and I think that the NSA provided

00:26:54.159 --> 00:26:57.296
all the relevant information
to our oversight committees,

00:26:57.296 --> 00:26:59.574
and then the dissemination of that information

00:26:59.574 --> 00:27:01.473
by the oversight committees throughout Congress

00:27:01.473 --> 00:27:04.107
is something that they manage.

00:27:04.107 --> 00:27:08.963
I think I would say that Congress members

00:27:08.963 --> 00:27:12.794
had the opportunity to make themselves aware,

00:27:12.794 --> 00:27:14.663
and in fact a significant number of them,

00:27:14.663 --> 00:27:18.121
the ones who are assigned oversight responsibility,

00:27:18.121 --> 00:27:19.295
did have the ability to do that.

00:27:19.295 --> 00:27:23.233
And you've actually had the chairs of
those committees say that in public.

00:27:23.233 --> 00:27:24.790
CA: Now, you mentioned the 
threat of cyberattacks,

00:27:24.790 --> 00:27:26.957
and I don't think anyone in this room would disagree

00:27:26.957 --> 00:27:28.847
that that is a huge concern,

00:27:28.847 --> 00:27:30.681
but do you accept that there's a tradeoff

00:27:30.681 --> 00:27:33.092
between offensive and defensive strategies,

00:27:33.092 --> 00:27:35.917
and that it's possible that the very measures taken

00:27:35.917 --> 00:27:38.586
to, "weaken encryption,"

00:27:38.586 --> 00:27:40.739
and allow yourself to find the bad guys,

00:27:40.739 --> 00:27:45.012
might also open the door to forms of cyberattack?

00:27:45.012 --> 00:27:47.855
RL: So I think two things.

00:27:47.855 --> 00:27:51.702
One is, you said weaken encryption. I didn't.

00:27:51.702 --> 00:27:56.828
And the other one is that

00:27:56.828 --> 00:27:59.604
the NSA has both of those missions,

00:27:59.604 --> 00:28:01.885
and we are heavily biased towards defense,

00:28:01.885 --> 00:28:05.402
and, actually, the vulnerabilities that we find

00:28:05.402 --> 00:28:07.503
in the overwhelming majority of cases,

00:28:07.503 --> 00:28:10.276
we disclose to the people who are responsible

00:28:10.276 --> 00:28:13.639
for manufacturing or developing those products.

00:28:13.639 --> 00:28:15.022
We have a great track record of that,

00:28:15.022 --> 00:28:17.008
and we're actually working on a proposal right now

00:28:17.008 --> 00:28:20.178
to be transparent and to
publish transparency reports

00:28:20.178 --> 00:28:23.064
in the same way that the Internet companies

00:28:23.064 --> 00:28:26.931
are being allowed to publish
transparency reports for them.

00:28:26.931 --> 00:28:28.929
We want to be more transparent about that.

00:28:28.929 --> 00:28:32.058
So again, we eat our own dog food.

00:28:32.058 --> 00:28:34.311
We use the standards, we use the products

00:28:34.311 --> 00:28:36.966
that we recommend,

00:28:36.966 --> 00:28:39.261
and so it's in our interest

00:28:39.261 --> 00:28:41.899
to keep our communications protected

00:28:41.899 --> 00:28:45.703
in the same way that other people's need to be.

00:28:45.703 --> 00:28:48.893
CA: Edward Snowden,

00:28:48.893 --> 00:28:53.321
when, after his talk, was wandering the halls here

00:28:53.321 --> 00:28:54.566
in the bot,

00:28:54.566 --> 00:28:56.754
and I heard him say to a couple of people,

00:28:56.754 --> 00:28:58.371
they asked him about what he thought

00:28:58.371 --> 00:28:59.964
of the NSA overall,

00:28:59.964 --> 00:29:02.737
and he was very complimentary about the people

00:29:02.737 --> 00:29:04.758
who work with you,

00:29:04.758 --> 00:29:08.681
said that it's a really

00:29:08.681 --> 00:29:10.641
impassioned group of employees

00:29:10.641 --> 00:29:13.090
who are seeking to do the right thing,

00:29:13.090 --> 00:29:16.044
and that the problems have come from

00:29:16.044 --> 00:29:19.163
just some badly conceived policies.

00:29:19.163 --> 00:29:23.608
He came over certainly very reasonably and calmly.

00:29:23.608 --> 00:29:25.783
He didn't come over like a crazy man.

00:29:25.783 --> 00:29:27.753
Would you accept that at least,

00:29:27.753 --> 00:29:30.769
even if you disagree with how he did it,

00:29:30.769 --> 00:29:34.793
that he has opened a debate that matters?

00:29:34.793 --> 00:29:37.191
RL: So I think that the discussion

00:29:37.191 --> 00:29:39.055
is an important one to have.

00:29:39.055 --> 00:29:42.431
I do not like the way that he did it.

00:29:42.431 --> 00:29:44.436
I think there were a number of other ways

00:29:44.436 --> 00:29:45.898
that he could have done that

00:29:45.898 --> 00:29:49.194
that would have not endangered our people

00:29:49.194 --> 00:29:51.842
and the people of other nations

00:29:51.842 --> 00:29:53.953
through losing visibility

00:29:53.953 --> 00:29:56.684
into what our adversaries are doing.

00:29:56.684 --> 00:29:59.370
But I do think it's an important conversation.

00:29:59.370 --> 00:30:00.909
CA: It's been reported that there's

00:30:00.909 --> 00:30:03.018
almost a difference of opinion

00:30:03.018 --> 00:30:04.489
with you and your colleagues

00:30:04.489 --> 00:30:06.542
over any scenario in which

00:30:06.542 --> 00:30:09.145
he might be offered an amnesty deal.

00:30:09.145 --> 00:30:11.856
I think your boss, General Keith Alexander,

00:30:11.856 --> 00:30:13.842
has said that that would be a terrible example

00:30:13.842 --> 00:30:15.307
for others;

00:30:15.307 --> 00:30:16.964
you can't negotiate with someone

00:30:16.964 --> 00:30:18.972
who's broken the law in that way.

00:30:18.972 --> 00:30:20.981
But you've been quoted as saying that,

00:30:20.981 --> 00:30:24.189
if Snowden could prove that he was surrendering

00:30:24.189 --> 00:30:25.985
all undisclosed documents,

00:30:25.985 --> 00:30:28.224
that a deal maybe should be considered.

00:30:28.224 --> 00:30:31.194
Do you still think that?

00:30:31.194 --> 00:30:32.712
RL: Yeah, so actually,

00:30:32.712 --> 00:30:35.295
this is my favorite thing about
that "60 Minutes" interview

00:30:35.295 --> 00:30:37.007
was all the misquotes that came from that.

00:30:37.007 --> 00:30:39.922
What I actually said, in 
response to a question about,

00:30:39.922 --> 00:30:41.734
would you entertain any discussions

00:30:41.734 --> 00:30:48.119
of mitigating action against Snowden,

00:30:48.119 --> 00:30:49.951
I said, yeah, it's worth a conversation.

00:30:49.951 --> 00:30:51.586
This is something that the attorney general

00:30:51.586 --> 00:30:53.516
of the United States and the president also

00:30:53.516 --> 00:30:55.054
actually have both talked about this,

00:30:55.054 --> 00:30:56.423
and I defer to the attorney general,

00:30:56.423 --> 00:30:57.970
because this is his lane.

00:30:57.970 --> 00:31:00.479
But there is a strong tradition

00:31:00.479 --> 00:31:03.671
in American jurisprudence

00:31:03.671 --> 00:31:08.246
of having discussions with people

00:31:08.246 --> 00:31:10.090
who have been charged with crimes in order to,

00:31:10.090 --> 00:31:11.606
if it benefits the government,

00:31:11.606 --> 00:31:13.984
to get something out of that,

00:31:13.984 --> 00:31:16.618
that there's always room for that kind of discussion.

00:31:16.618 --> 00:31:18.307
So I'm not presupposing any outcome,

00:31:18.307 --> 00:31:22.043
but there is always room for discussion.

00:31:22.043 --> 00:31:23.643
CA: To a lay person it seems like

00:31:23.643 --> 00:31:27.011
he has certain things to offer the U.S.,

00:31:27.011 --> 00:31:28.750
the government, you, others,

00:31:28.750 --> 00:31:30.431
in terms of putting things right

00:31:30.431 --> 00:31:32.489
and helping figure out a smarter policy,

00:31:32.489 --> 00:31:37.695
a smarter way forward for the future.

00:31:38.946 --> 00:31:41.019
Do you see, has that kind of possibility

00:31:41.019 --> 00:31:43.417
been entertained at all?

00:31:43.417 --> 00:31:45.055
RL: So that's out of my lane.

00:31:45.055 --> 00:31:46.584
That's not an NSA thing.

00:31:46.584 --> 00:31:48.791
That would be a Department of Justice

00:31:48.791 --> 00:31:51.288
sort of discussion.

00:31:51.288 --> 00:31:54.584
I'll defer to them.

00:31:54.584 --> 00:31:57.549
CA: Rick, when Ed Snowden ended his talk,

00:31:57.549 --> 00:32:01.294
I offered him the chance to
share an idea worth spreading.

00:32:01.294 --> 00:32:02.947
What would be your idea worth spreading

00:32:02.947 --> 00:32:05.229
for this group?

00:32:05.229 --> 00:32:07.221
RL: So I think, learn the facts.

00:32:07.221 --> 00:32:09.837
This is a really important conversation,

00:32:09.837 --> 00:32:11.913
and it impacts, it's not just NSA,

00:32:11.913 --> 00:32:13.111
it's not just the government,

00:32:13.111 --> 00:32:16.019
it's you, it's the Internet companies.

00:32:16.019 --> 00:32:19.137
The issue of privacy and personal data

00:32:19.137 --> 00:32:20.714
is much bigger than just the government,

00:32:20.714 --> 00:32:22.625
and so learn the facts.

00:32:22.625 --> 00:32:24.221
Don't rely on headlines,

00:32:24.221 --> 00:32:25.897
don't rely on sound bites,

00:32:25.897 --> 00:32:28.377
don't rely on one-sided conversations.

00:32:28.377 --> 00:32:31.526
So that's the idea, I think, worth spreading.

00:32:31.526 --> 00:32:34.919
We have a sign, a badge tab,

00:32:34.919 --> 00:32:36.808
we wear badges at work with lanyards,

00:32:36.808 --> 00:32:38.221
and if I could make a plug,

00:32:38.221 --> 00:32:40.968
my badge lanyard at work says, "Dallas Cowboys."

00:32:40.968 --> 00:32:44.465
Go Dallas.

00:32:44.465 --> 00:32:47.131
I've just alienated half the audience, I know.

00:32:47.131 --> 00:32:51.027
So the lanyard that our people

00:32:51.027 --> 00:32:52.812
who work in the organization

00:32:52.812 --> 00:32:55.232
that does our crypto-analytic work

00:32:55.232 --> 00:32:57.173
have a tab that says, "Look at the data."

00:32:57.173 --> 00:32:58.709
So that's the idea worth spreading.

00:32:58.709 --> 00:33:00.958
Look at the data.

00:33:00.958 --> 00:33:03.950
CA: Rick, it took a certain amount of courage,

00:33:03.950 --> 00:33:06.565
I think, actually, to come and speak openly

00:33:06.565 --> 00:33:07.819
to this group.

00:33:07.819 --> 00:33:10.486
It's not something the NSA
has done a lot of in the past,

00:33:10.486 --> 00:33:13.581
and plus the technology has been challenging.

00:33:13.581 --> 00:33:15.362
We truly appreciate you doing that

00:33:15.362 --> 00:33:17.775
and sharing in this very important conversation.

00:33:17.775 --> 00:33:19.916
Thank you so much.

00:33:19.916 --> 00:33:21.855
RL: Thanks, Chris.

00:33:21.855 --> 00:33:28.926
(Applause)

title: Where’s Google going next?
transcript: Charlie Rose: So Larry sent me an email and he basically said, we've got to make sure that  we don't seem like we're a couple of middle-aged boring men. I said, I'm flattered by that — (Laughter) — because I'm a bit older, and he has a bit more net worth than I do.Larry Page: Well, thank you.CR: So we'll have a conversation about the Internet, and we'll have a conversation Google, and we'll have a conversation about search and privacy, and also about your philosophy and a sense of how you've connected the dots and how this journey that began some time ago has such interesting prospects. Mainly we want to talk about the future. So my first question: Where is Google and where is it going? LP: Well, this is something we think about a lot, and our mission we defined a long time ago is to organize the world's information and make it universally accessible and useful. And people always say, is that really what you guys are still doing? And I always kind of think about that myself, and I'm not quite sure. But actually, when I think about search, it's such a deep thing for all of us, to really understand what you want, to understand the world's information, and we're still very much in the early stages of that, which is totally crazy. We've been at it for 15 years already, but it's not at all done.CR: When it's done, how will it be?LP: Well, I guess, in thinking about where we're going — you know, why is it not done? — a lot of it is just computing's kind of a mess. You know, your computer doesn't know where you are, it doesn't know what you're doing, it doesn't know what you know, and a lot we've been trying to do recently is just make your devices work, make them understand your context. Google Now, you know, knows where you are, knows what you may need. So really having computing  work and understand you and understand that information, we really haven't done that yet. It's still very, very clunky.CR: Tell me, when you look at what Google is doing, where does Deep Mind fit?LP: Yeah, so Deep Mind is a company we just acquired recently. It's in the U.K. First, let me tell you the way we got there, which was looking at search and really understanding, trying to understand everything, and also make the computers not clunky and really understand you — like, voice was really important. So what's the state of the art  on speech recognition? It's not very good. It doesn't really understand you. So we started doing machine learning research to improve that. That helped a lot. And we started just looking at things like YouTube. Can we understand YouTube? But we actually ran machine learning on YouTube and it discovered cats, just by itself. Now, that's an important concept. And we realized there's really something here. If we can learn what cats are, that must be really important. So I think Deep Mind, what's really amazing about Deep Mind is that it can actually — they're learning things in this unsupervised way. They started with video games, and really just, maybe I can show the video, just playing video games, and learning how to do that automatically.CR: Take a look at the video games and how machines are coming to be able to do some remarkable things.LP: The amazing thing about this is this is, I mean, obviously, these are old games, but the system just sees what you see, the pixels, and it has the controls and it has the score, and it's learned to play all of these games, same program. It's learned to play all of these games with superhuman performance. We've not been able to do things like this with computers before. And maybe I'll just narrate this one quickly. This is boxing, and it figures out it can sort of pin the opponent down. The computer's on the left, and it's just racking up points. So imagine if this kind of intelligence were thrown at your schedule, or your information needs, or things like that. We're really just at the beginning of that, and that's what I'm really excited about.CR: When you look at all that's taken place with Deep Mind and the boxing, also a part of where we're going is artificial intelligence. Where are we, when you look at that?LP: Well, I think for me, this is kind of one of the most exciting things I've seen in a long time. The guy who started this company, Demis, has a neuroscience and a computer science background. He went back to school to get his Ph.D. to study the brain. And so I think we're seeing a lot of exciting work going on that sort of crosses computer science and neuroscience in terms of really understanding what it takes to make something smart and do really interesting things.CR: But where's the level of it now? And how fast do you think we are moving?LP: Well, this is the state of the art right now, understanding cats on YouTube and things like that, improving voice recognition. We used a lot of machine learning to improve things incrementally, but I think for me, this example's really exciting, because it's one program that can do a lot of different things.CR: I don't know if we can do this, but we've got the image of the cat. It would be wonderful to see this. This is how machines looked at cats and what they came up with. Can we see that image?LP: Yeah. CR: There it is. Can you see the cat? Designed by machines, seen by machines.LP: That's right. So this is learned from just watching YouTube. And there's no training, no notion of a cat, but this concept of a cat is something important that you would understand, and now that the machines can kind of understand. Maybe just finishing also on the search part, it started with search, really understanding people's context and their information. I did have a video I wanted to show quickly on that that we actually found.(Video) ["Soy, Kenya"]Zack Matere: Not long ago, I planted a crop of potatoes. Then suddenly they started dying one after the other. I checked out the books and  they didn't tell me much. So, I went and I did a search. ["Zack Matere, Farmer"] Potato diseases. One of the websites told me that ants could be the problem. It said, sprinkle wood ash over the plants. Then after a few days the ants disappeared. I got excited about the Internet. I have this friend who really would like to expand his business. So I went with him to the cyber cafe and we checked out several sites. When I met him next, he was going to put a windmill at the local school. I felt proud because something that wasn't there before was suddenly there. I realized that not everybody can be able to access what I was able to access. I thought that I need to have an Internet that my grandmother can use. So I thought about a notice board. A simple wooden notice board. When I get information on my phone, I'm able to post the information on the notice board. So it's basically like a computer. I use the Internet to help people. I think I am searching for a better life for me and my neighbors. So many people have access to information, but there's no follow-up to that. I think the follow-up to that is our knowledge. When people have the knowledge, they can find solutions without having to helped out. Information is powerful, but it is how we use it that will define us.(Applause)LP: Now, the amazing thing about that video, actually, was we just read about it in the news, and we found this gentlemen, and made that little clip.CR: When I talk to people about you, they say to me, people who know you well, say, Larry wants to change the world, and he believes technology can show the way. And that means access to the Internet. It has to do with languages. It also means how people can get access and do things that will affect their community, and this is an example. LP: Yeah, that's right, and I think for me, I have been focusing on access more, if we're talking about the future. We recently released this Loon Project which is using balloons to do it. It sounds totally crazy. We can show the video here. Actually, two out of three people in the world don't have good Internet access now. We actually think this can really help people sort of cost-efficiently.CR: It's a balloon. LP: Yeah, get access to the Internet.CR: And why does this balloon give you access to the Internet? Because there was some interesting things you had to do to figure out how to make balloons possible, they didn't have to be tethered.LP: Yeah, and this is a good example of innovation. Like, we've been thinking about this idea for five years or more before we started working on it, but it was just really, how do we get access points up high, cheaply? You normally have to use satellites and it takes a long time to launch them. But you saw there how easy it is to launch a balloon and get it up, and actually again, it's the power of the Internet, I did a search on it, and I found, 30, 40 years ago, someone had put up a balloon and it had gone around the Earth multiple times. And I thought, why can't we do that today? And that's how this project got going.CR: But are you at the mercy of the wind?LP: Yeah, but it turns out, we did some weather simulations which probably hadn't really been done before, and if you control the altitude of the balloons, which you can do by pumping air into them and other ways, you can actually control roughly where they go, and so I think we can build a worldwide mesh of these balloons that can cover the whole planet.CR: Before I talk about the future and transportation, where you've been a nerd for a while, and this fascination you have with transportation and automated cars and bicycles, let me talk a bit about what's been the subject here earlier with Edward Snowden. It is security and privacy. You have to have been thinking about that.LP: Yeah, absolutely. I saw the picture of Sergey with Edward Snowden yesterday. Some of you may have seen it. But I think, for me, I guess, privacy and security are a really important thing. We think about it in terms of both things, and I think you can't have privacy without security, so let me just talk about security first, because you asked about Snowden and all of that, and then I'll say a little bit about privacy. I think for me, it's tremendously disappointing that the government secretly did all this stuff and didn't tell us. I don't think we can have a democracy if we're having to protect you and our users from the government for stuff that we've never had a conversation about. And I don't mean we have to know what the particular terrorist attack is they're worried about protecting us from, but we do need to know what the parameters of it is, what kind of surveillance the government's going to do and how and why, and I think we haven't had that conversation. So I think the government's actually done itself a tremendous disservice by doing all that in secret.CR: Never coming to Google to ask for anything.LP: Not Google, but the public. I think we need to  have a debate about that, or we can't have a functioning democracy. It's just not possible. So I'm sad that Google's in the position of protecting you and our users from the government doing secret thing that nobody knows about. It doesn't make any sense.CR: Yeah. And then there's a privacy side of it.LP: Yes. The privacy side, I think it's — the world is changing. You carry a phone. It knows where you are. There's so much more information about you, and that's an important thing, and it makes sense why people are asking difficult questions. We spend a lot of time thinking about this and what the issues are. I'm a little bit — I think the main thing that we need to do is just provide people choice, show them what data's being collected — search history, location data. We're excited about incognito mode in Chrome, and doing that in more ways, just giving people more choice and more awareness of what's going on. I also think it's very easy. What I'm worried is that we throw out the baby with the bathwater. And I look at, on your show, actually, I kind of lost my voice, and I haven't gotten it back. I'm hoping that by talking to you I'm going to get it back.CR: If I could do anything, I would do that.LP: All right. So get out your voodoo doll and whatever you need to do. But I think, you know what, I look at that, I made that public, and I got all this information. We got a survey done on medical conditions with people who have similar issues, and I look at medical records, and I say, wouldn't it be amazing if everyone's medical records were available anonymously to research doctors? And when someone accesses your medical record, a research doctor, they could see, you could see which doctor accessed it and why, and you could maybe learn about what conditions you have. I think if we just did that, we'd save 100,000 lives this year.CR: Absolutely. Let me go — (Applause)LP: So I guess I'm just very worried that with Internet privacy, we're doing the same thing we're  doing with medical records, is we're throwing out the baby with the bathwater, and we're not really thinking about the tremendous good that can come from people sharing information with the right people in the right ways.CR: And the necessary condition that people have to have confidence that their information will not be abused.LP: Yeah, and I had this problem with my voice stuff. I was scared to share it. Sergey encouraged me to do that, and it was a great thing to do.CR: And the response has been overwhelming.LP: Yeah, and people are super positive. We got thousands and thousands of people with similar conditions, which there's no data on today. So it was a really good thing.CR: So talking about the future, what is it about you and transportation systems?LP: Yeah. I guess I was just frustrated with this when I was at college in Michigan. I had to get on the bus and take it and wait for it. And it was cold and snowing. I did some research on how much it cost, and I just became a bit obsessed with transportation systems.CR: And that began the idea of an automated car.LP: Yeah, about 18 years ago I learned about people working on automated cars, and I became fascinated by that, and it takes a while to  get these projects going, but I'm super excited about the possibilities of that improving the world. There's 20 million people or more injured per year. It's the leading cause of death for people under 34 in the U.S.CR: So you're talking about saving lives.LP: Yeah, and also saving space and making life better. Los Angeles is half parking lots and roads, half of the area, and most cities are not far behind, actually. It's just crazy that that's what we use our space for.CR: And how soon will we be there?LP: I think we can be there very, very soon. We've driven well over 100,000 miles now totally automated. I'm super excited about getting that out quickly.CR: But it's not only you're talking about automated cars. You also have this idea for bicycles.LP: Well at Google, we got this idea that we should just provide free bikes to everyone, and that's been amazing, most of the trips.
