You see bikes going everywhere, and the bikes wear out. They're getting used 24 hours a day.CR: But you want to put them above the street, too.LP: Well I said, how do we get people using bikes more?CR: We may have a video here.LP: Yeah, let's show the video. I just got excited about this.(Music) So this is actually how you might separate bikes from cars with minimal cost. Anyway, it looks totally crazy, but I was actually thinking about our campus, working with the Zippies and stuff, and just trying to get a lot more bike usage, and I was thinking about, how do you cost-effectively separate the bikes from traffic? And I went and searched, and this is what I found. And we're not actually working on this, that particular thing, but it gets your imagination going.CR: Let me close with this. Give me a sense of the philosophy  of your own mind. You have this idea of [Google X]. You don't simply want to go in some small, measurable arena of progress.LP: Yeah, I think many of the things we just  talked about are like that, where they're really — I almost use the economic concept of additionality, which means that you're doing something that wouldn't happen unless  you were actually doing it. And I think the more you can do things like that, the bigger impact you have, and that's about doing things that people might not think are possible. And I've been amazed, the more I learn about technology, the more I realize I don't know, and that's because this technological horizon, the thing that you can see to do next, the more you learn about technology, the more you learn what's possible. You learn that the balloons are possible because there's some material that will work for them.CR: What's interesting about  you too, though, for me, is that, we have lots of people who are thinking about the future, and they are going and looking and they're coming back, but we never see the implementation. I think of somebody you knew and read about, Tesla. The principle of that for you is what?LP: Well, I think invention is not enough. If you invent something, Tesla invented electric power that we use, but he struggled to get it out to people. That had to be done by other people. It took a long time. And I think if we can actually combine both things, where we have an innovation and invention focus, plus the ability to really — a company that can really commercialize things and get them to people in a way that's positive for the world and to give people hope. You know, I'm amazed with the Loon Project just how excited people were about that, because it gave them hope for the two thirds of the world that doesn't have Internet right now that's any good.CR: Which is a second thing about corporations. You are one of those people who believe that corporations are an agent of change if they are run well.LP: Yeah. I'm really dismayed most people think companies are basically evil. They get a bad rap. And I think that's somewhat correct. Companies are doing the same incremental thing that they did 50 years ago or 20 years ago. That's not really what we need. We need, especially in technology, we need revolutionary change, not incremental change.CR: You once said, actually, as I think I've got this about right, that you might consider, rather than giving your money, if you were leaving it to some cause, just simply giving it to Elon Musk, because you had confidence that he would change the future, and that you would therefore —LP: Yeah, if you want to go Mars, he wants to go to Mars, to back up humanity, that's a worthy goal, but it's a company, and it's philanthropical. So I think we aim to do kind of similar things. And I think, you ask, we have a lot of employees at Google who have become pretty wealthy. People make a lot of money in technology. A lot of people in the room are pretty wealthy. You're working because you want to change the world. You want to make it better. Why isn't the company that you work for worthy not just of your time but your money as well? I mean, but we don't have a concept of that. That's not how we think about companies, and I think it's sad, because companies are most of our effort. They're where most of people's time is, where a lot of the money is, and so I think I'd like for us to help out more than we are.CR: When I close conversations with lots of people, I always ask this question: What state of mind, what quality of mind is it that has served you best? People like Rupert Murdoch have said curiosity, and other people in the media have said that. Bill Gates and Warren Buffett have said focus. What quality of mind, as I leave this audience, has enabled you to think about the future and at the same time change the present?LP: You know, I think the most important thing — I looked at lots of companies and why I thought they don't succeed over time. We've had a more rapid turnover of companies. And I said, what did they fundamentally do wrong? What did those companies all do wrong? And usually it's just that they missed the future. And so I think, for me, I just try to focus on that and say, what is that future really going to be and how do we create it, and how do we cause our organization, to really focus on that and drive that at a really high rate? And so that's been curiosity, it's been looking at things people might not think about, working on things that no one else is working on, because that's where the additionality really is, and be willing to do that, to take that risk. Look at Android. I felt guilty about working on Android when it was starting. It was a little startup we bought. It wasn't really what we were really working on. And I felt guilty about spending time on that. That was stupid. That was the future, right? That was a good thing to be working on.CR: It is great to see you here. It's great to hear from you, and a pleasure to sit at this table with you. Thanks, Larry.LP: Thank you.(Applause)CR: Larry Page.

00:00:13.339 --> 00:00:16.965
Charlie Rose: So Larry sent me an email

00:00:16.965 --> 00:00:18.952
and he basically said,

00:00:18.952 --> 00:00:22.681
we've got to make sure that 
we don't seem like we're

00:00:22.681 --> 00:00:27.172
a couple of middle-aged boring men.

00:00:27.172 --> 00:00:30.214
I said, I'm flattered by that --

00:00:30.214 --> 00:00:32.586
(Laughter) —

00:00:32.586 --> 00:00:36.101
because I'm a bit older,

00:00:36.101 --> 00:00:40.252
and he has a bit more net worth than I do.

00:00:40.252 --> 00:00:42.851
Larry Page: Well, thank you.

00:00:42.851 --> 00:00:45.831
CR: So we'll have a conversation about

00:00:45.831 --> 00:00:48.529
the Internet, and we'll have a conversation Google,

00:00:48.529 --> 00:00:49.963
and we'll have a conversation about search

00:00:49.963 --> 00:00:51.330
and privacy,

00:00:51.330 --> 00:00:52.885
and also about your philosophy

00:00:52.885 --> 00:00:55.341
and a sense of how you've connected the dots

00:00:55.341 --> 00:00:57.432
and how this journey that began

00:00:57.432 --> 00:00:58.716
some time ago

00:00:58.716 --> 00:01:00.611
has such interesting prospects.

00:01:00.611 --> 00:01:03.207
Mainly we want to talk about the future.

00:01:03.207 --> 00:01:04.796
So my first question: Where is Google

00:01:04.796 --> 00:01:06.842
and where is it going?

00:01:06.842 --> 00:01:08.301
LP: Well, this is something we think about a lot,

00:01:08.301 --> 00:01:11.876
and our mission we defined a long time ago

00:01:11.876 --> 00:01:14.139
is to organize the world's information

00:01:14.139 --> 00:01:17.577
and make it universally accessible and useful.

00:01:17.577 --> 00:01:19.619
And people always say,

00:01:19.619 --> 00:01:21.834
is that really what you guys are still doing?

00:01:21.834 --> 00:01:23.952
And I always kind of think about that myself,

00:01:23.952 --> 00:01:26.148
and I'm not quite sure.

00:01:26.148 --> 00:01:30.155
But actually, when I think about search,

00:01:30.155 --> 00:01:32.771
it's such a deep thing for all of us,

00:01:32.771 --> 00:01:35.014
to really understand what you want,

00:01:35.014 --> 00:01:37.382
to understand the world's information,

00:01:37.382 --> 00:01:40.914
and we're still very much in the early stages of that,

00:01:40.914 --> 00:01:42.727
which is totally crazy.

00:01:42.727 --> 00:01:45.245
We've been at it for 15 years already,

00:01:45.245 --> 00:01:48.820
but it's not at all done.

00:01:48.820 --> 00:01:51.496
CR: When it's done, how will it be?

00:01:51.496 --> 00:01:54.213
LP: Well, I guess,

00:01:54.213 --> 00:01:56.613
in thinking about where we're going --

00:01:56.613 --> 00:01:58.900
you know, why is it not done? --

00:01:58.900 --> 00:02:01.336
a lot of it is just computing's kind of a mess.

00:02:01.336 --> 00:02:03.139
You know, your computer
doesn't know where you are,

00:02:03.139 --> 00:02:05.174
it doesn't know what you're doing,

00:02:05.174 --> 00:02:06.856
it doesn't know what you know,

00:02:06.856 --> 00:02:09.432
and a lot we've been trying to do recently

00:02:09.432 --> 00:02:12.727
is just make your devices work,

00:02:12.727 --> 00:02:15.068
make them understand your context.

00:02:15.068 --> 00:02:17.071
Google Now, you know, knows where you are,

00:02:17.071 --> 00:02:19.253
knows what you may need.

00:02:19.253 --> 00:02:23.361
So really having computing 
work and understand you

00:02:23.361 --> 00:02:25.417
and understand that information,

00:02:25.417 --> 00:02:27.727
we really haven't done that yet.

00:02:27.727 --> 00:02:29.276
It's still very, very clunky.

00:02:29.276 --> 00:02:31.642
CR: Tell me, when you look at what Google is doing,

00:02:31.642 --> 00:02:34.611
where does Deep Mind fit?

00:02:34.611 --> 00:02:36.195
LP: Yeah, so Deep Mind is a company

00:02:36.195 --> 00:02:38.726
we just acquired recently.

00:02:38.726 --> 00:02:41.808
It's in the U.K.

00:02:41.808 --> 00:02:44.462
First, let me tell you the way we got there,

00:02:44.462 --> 00:02:46.690
which was looking at search

00:02:46.690 --> 00:02:48.313
and really understanding,

00:02:48.313 --> 00:02:50.546
trying to understand everything,

00:02:50.546 --> 00:02:52.151
and also make the computers not clunky

00:02:52.151 --> 00:02:54.352
and really understand you --

00:02:54.352 --> 00:02:56.464
like, voice was really important.

00:02:56.464 --> 00:02:59.325
So what's the state of the art 
on speech recognition?

00:02:59.325 --> 00:03:00.985
It's not very good.

00:03:00.985 --> 00:03:03.051
It doesn't really understand you.

00:03:03.051 --> 00:03:05.054
So we started doing machine learning research

00:03:05.054 --> 00:03:06.591
to improve that.

00:03:06.591 --> 00:03:08.294
That helped a lot.

00:03:08.294 --> 00:03:10.661
And we started just looking at things like YouTube.

00:03:10.661 --> 00:03:12.629
Can we understand YouTube?

00:03:12.629 --> 00:03:15.315
But we actually ran machine learning on YouTube

00:03:15.315 --> 00:03:19.400
and it discovered cats, just by itself.

00:03:19.400 --> 00:03:21.491
Now, that's an important concept.

00:03:21.491 --> 00:03:24.482
And we realized there's really something here.

00:03:24.482 --> 00:03:26.599
If we can learn what cats are,

00:03:26.599 --> 00:03:28.674
that must be really important.

00:03:28.674 --> 00:03:31.303
So I think Deep Mind,

00:03:31.303 --> 00:03:33.667
what's really amazing about Deep Mind

00:03:33.667 --> 00:03:35.671
is that it can actually --

00:03:35.671 --> 00:03:39.228
they're learning things in this unsupervised way.

00:03:39.228 --> 00:03:41.795
They started with video games,

00:03:41.795 --> 00:03:44.288
and really just, maybe I can show the video,

00:03:44.288 --> 00:03:46.492
just playing video games,

00:03:46.492 --> 00:03:48.507
and learning how to do that automatically.

00:03:48.507 --> 00:03:50.359
CR: Take a look at the video games

00:03:50.359 --> 00:03:52.769
and how machines are coming to be able

00:03:52.769 --> 00:03:55.225
to do some remarkable things.

00:03:55.225 --> 00:03:56.554
LP: The amazing thing about this

00:03:56.554 --> 00:03:58.234
is this is, I mean, obviously,

00:03:58.234 --> 00:03:59.708
these are old games,

00:03:59.708 --> 00:04:04.506
but the system just sees what you see, the pixels,

00:04:04.506 --> 00:04:06.937
and it has the controls and it has the score,

00:04:06.937 --> 00:04:09.148
and it's learned to play all of these games,

00:04:09.148 --> 00:04:10.727
same program.

00:04:10.727 --> 00:04:12.764
It's learned to play all of these games

00:04:12.764 --> 00:04:14.550
with superhuman performance.

00:04:14.550 --> 00:04:16.405
We've not been able to do things like this

00:04:16.405 --> 00:04:17.923
with computers before.

00:04:17.923 --> 00:04:20.218
And maybe I'll just narrate this one quickly.

00:04:20.218 --> 00:04:23.023
This is boxing, and it figures out it can

00:04:23.023 --> 00:04:25.657
sort of pin the opponent down.

00:04:25.657 --> 00:04:27.396
The computer's on the left,

00:04:27.396 --> 00:04:30.481
and it's just racking up points.

00:04:30.481 --> 00:04:32.567
So imagine if this kind

00:04:32.567 --> 00:04:34.694
of intelligence were thrown at your schedule,

00:04:34.694 --> 00:04:39.331
or your information needs, or things like that.

00:04:39.331 --> 00:04:41.949
We're really just at the beginning of that,

00:04:41.949 --> 00:04:44.314
and that's what I'm really excited about.

00:04:44.314 --> 00:04:46.784
CR: When you look at all that's taken place

00:04:46.784 --> 00:04:49.368
with Deep Mind and the boxing,

00:04:49.368 --> 00:04:51.708
also a part of where we're going

00:04:51.708 --> 00:04:54.597
is artificial intelligence.

00:04:54.597 --> 00:04:57.396
Where are we, when you look at that?

00:04:57.396 --> 00:04:59.181
LP: Well, I think for me,

00:04:59.181 --> 00:05:00.684
this is kind of one of the most exciting things

00:05:00.684 --> 00:05:02.596
I've seen in a long time.

00:05:02.596 --> 00:05:05.009
The guy who started this company, Demis,

00:05:05.009 --> 00:05:07.787
has a neuroscience and a
computer science background.

00:05:07.787 --> 00:05:09.417
He went back to school

00:05:09.417 --> 00:05:12.543
to get his Ph.D. to study the brain.

00:05:12.543 --> 00:05:15.163
And so I think we're seeing a lot of exciting work

00:05:15.163 --> 00:05:18.244
going on that sort of crosses computer science

00:05:18.244 --> 00:05:19.994
and neuroscience

00:05:19.994 --> 00:05:22.319
in terms of really understanding

00:05:22.319 --> 00:05:24.773
what it takes to make something smart

00:05:24.773 --> 00:05:26.488
and do really interesting things.

00:05:26.488 --> 00:05:28.626
CR: But where's the level of it now?

00:05:28.626 --> 00:05:31.332
And how fast do you think we are moving?

00:05:31.332 --> 00:05:34.601
LP: Well, this is the state of the art right now,

00:05:34.601 --> 00:05:36.732
understanding cats on YouTube

00:05:36.732 --> 00:05:38.015
and things like that,

00:05:38.015 --> 00:05:40.162
improving voice recognition.

00:05:40.162 --> 00:05:42.580
We used a lot of machine learning

00:05:42.580 --> 00:05:45.059
to improve things incrementally,

00:05:45.059 --> 00:05:48.453
but I think for me, this example's really exciting,

00:05:48.453 --> 00:05:50.696
because it's one program

00:05:50.696 --> 00:05:52.740
that can do a lot of different things.

00:05:52.740 --> 00:05:53.878
CR: I don't know if we can do this,

00:05:53.878 --> 00:05:55.063
but we've got the image of the cat.

00:05:55.063 --> 00:05:56.817
It would be wonderful to see this.

00:05:56.817 --> 00:05:59.326
This is how machines looked at cats

00:05:59.326 --> 00:06:00.441
and what they came up with.

00:06:00.441 --> 00:06:01.496
Can we see that image?

00:06:01.496 --> 00:06:03.898
LP: Yeah.
CR: There it is. Can you see the cat?

00:06:03.898 --> 00:06:05.925
Designed by machines, seen by machines.

00:06:05.925 --> 00:06:07.035
LP: That's right.

00:06:07.035 --> 00:06:09.642
So this is learned from just watching YouTube.

00:06:09.642 --> 00:06:11.509
And there's no training,

00:06:11.509 --> 00:06:12.893
no notion of a cat,

00:06:12.893 --> 00:06:15.454
but this concept of a cat

00:06:15.454 --> 00:06:18.262
is something important that you would understand,

00:06:18.262 --> 00:06:20.785
and now that the machines can kind of understand.

00:06:20.785 --> 00:06:21.957
Maybe just finishing

00:06:21.957 --> 00:06:24.179
also on the search part,

00:06:24.179 --> 00:06:26.965
it started with search, really understanding

00:06:26.965 --> 00:06:29.529
people's context and their information.

00:06:29.529 --> 00:06:31.389
I did have a video

00:06:31.389 --> 00:06:33.399
I wanted to show quickly on that

00:06:33.399 --> 00:06:35.046
that we actually found.

00:06:35.046 --> 00:06:40.158
(Video) ["Soy, Kenya"]

00:06:40.538 --> 00:06:42.410
Zack Matere: Not long ago,

00:06:42.410 --> 00:06:44.996
I planted a crop of potatoes.

00:06:44.996 --> 00:06:48.396
Then suddenly they started
dying one after the other.

00:06:48.396 --> 00:06:51.146
I checked out the books and 
they didn't tell me much.

00:06:51.146 --> 00:06:53.092
So, I went and I did a search.

00:06:53.092 --> 00:06:56.211
["Zack Matere, Farmer"]

00:06:57.567 --> 00:07:00.714
Potato diseases.

00:07:00.714 --> 00:07:02.442
One of the websites told me

00:07:02.442 --> 00:07:04.344
that ants could be the problem.

00:07:04.344 --> 00:07:06.615
It said, sprinkle wood ash over the plants.

00:07:06.615 --> 00:07:08.899
Then after a few days the ants disappeared.

00:07:08.899 --> 00:07:11.493
I got excited about the Internet.

00:07:11.493 --> 00:07:13.158
I have this friend

00:07:13.158 --> 00:07:16.776
who really would like to expand his business.

00:07:16.776 --> 00:07:19.971
So I went with him to the cyber cafe

00:07:19.971 --> 00:07:22.512
and we checked out several sites.

00:07:22.512 --> 00:07:25.053
When I met him next, he was going to put a windmill

00:07:25.053 --> 00:07:27.747
at the local school.

00:07:27.747 --> 00:07:29.351
I felt proud because

00:07:29.351 --> 00:07:31.379
something that wasn't there before

00:07:31.379 --> 00:07:33.266
was suddenly there.

00:07:33.266 --> 00:07:35.956
I realized that not everybody

00:07:35.956 --> 00:07:37.490
can be able to access

00:07:37.490 --> 00:07:38.976
what I was able to access.

00:07:38.976 --> 00:07:40.814
I thought that I need to have an Internet

00:07:40.814 --> 00:07:42.615
that my grandmother can use.

00:07:42.615 --> 00:07:45.072
So I thought about a notice board.

00:07:45.072 --> 00:07:46.988
A simple wooden notice board.

00:07:46.988 --> 00:07:49.303
When I get information on my phone,

00:07:49.303 --> 00:07:51.540
I'm able to post the information

00:07:51.540 --> 00:07:53.262
on the notice board.

00:07:53.262 --> 00:07:56.120
So it's basically like a computer.

00:07:56.120 --> 00:08:00.009
I use the Internet to help people.

00:08:00.009 --> 00:08:03.419
I think I am searching for

00:08:03.419 --> 00:08:04.960
a better life

00:08:04.960 --> 00:08:09.074
for me and my neighbors.

00:08:09.074 --> 00:08:13.058
So many people have access to information,

00:08:13.058 --> 00:08:15.639
but there's no follow-up to that.

00:08:15.639 --> 00:08:18.147
I think the follow-up to that is our knowledge.

00:08:18.147 --> 00:08:19.753
When people have the knowledge,

00:08:19.753 --> 00:08:21.383
they can find solutions

00:08:21.383 --> 00:08:23.367
without having to helped out.

00:08:23.398 --> 00:08:25.519
Information is powerful,

00:08:25.519 --> 00:08:30.121
but it is how we use it that will define us.

00:08:30.121 --> 00:08:34.502
(Applause)

00:08:34.502 --> 00:08:37.048
LP: Now, the amazing thing about that video,

00:08:37.048 --> 00:08:38.514
actually, was we just read about it in the news,

00:08:38.514 --> 00:08:41.019
and we found this gentlemen,

00:08:41.019 --> 00:08:43.334
and made that little clip.

00:08:43.334 --> 00:08:44.725
CR: When I talk to people about you,

00:08:44.725 --> 00:08:47.330
they say to me, people who know you well, say,

00:08:47.330 --> 00:08:49.221
Larry wants to change the world,

00:08:49.221 --> 00:08:53.333
and he believes technology can show the way.

00:08:53.333 --> 00:08:55.191
And that means access to the Internet.

00:08:55.191 --> 00:08:56.922
It has to do with languages.

00:08:56.922 --> 00:08:59.751
It also means how people can get access

00:08:59.751 --> 00:09:02.457
and do things that will affect their community,

00:09:02.457 --> 00:09:04.950
and this is an example.

00:09:04.950 --> 00:09:08.526
LP: Yeah, that's right, and I think for me,

00:09:08.526 --> 00:09:10.908
I have been focusing on access more,

00:09:10.908 --> 00:09:13.106
if we're talking about the future.

00:09:13.106 --> 00:09:15.780
We recently released this Loon Project

00:09:15.780 --> 00:09:18.080
which is using balloons to do it.

00:09:18.080 --> 00:09:19.740
It sounds totally crazy.

00:09:19.740 --> 00:09:22.279
We can show the video here.

00:09:22.279 --> 00:09:23.759
Actually, two out of three people in the world

00:09:23.759 --> 00:09:26.145
don't have good Internet access now.

00:09:26.145 --> 00:09:29.051
We actually think this can really help people

00:09:29.051 --> 00:09:31.108
sort of cost-efficiently.

00:09:31.108 --> 00:09:34.479
CR: It's a balloon.
LP: Yeah, get access to the Internet.

00:09:34.479 --> 00:09:36.622
CR: And why does this balloon give you access

00:09:36.622 --> 00:09:37.835
to the Internet?

00:09:37.835 --> 00:09:39.050
Because there was some interesting things

00:09:39.050 --> 00:09:40.884
you had to do to figure out how

00:09:40.884 --> 00:09:43.015
to make balloons possible,

00:09:43.015 --> 00:09:44.764
they didn't have to be tethered.

00:09:44.764 --> 00:09:46.845
LP: Yeah, and this is a good example of innovation.

00:09:46.845 --> 00:09:49.389
Like, we've been thinking about this idea

00:09:49.389 --> 00:09:51.161
for five years or more

00:09:51.161 --> 00:09:52.762
before we started working on it,

00:09:52.762 --> 00:09:54.081
but it was just really,

00:09:54.081 --> 00:09:57.601
how do we get access points up high, cheaply?

00:09:57.601 --> 00:09:59.393
You normally have to use satellites

00:09:59.393 --> 00:10:02.332
and it takes a long time to launch them.

00:10:02.332 --> 00:10:04.826
But you saw there how easy it is to launch a balloon

00:10:04.826 --> 00:10:06.345
and get it up,

00:10:06.345 --> 00:10:08.346
and actually again, it's the power of the Internet,

00:10:08.346 --> 00:10:10.126
I did a search on it,

00:10:10.126 --> 00:10:12.430
and I found, 30, 40 years ago,

00:10:12.430 --> 00:10:14.319
someone had put up a balloon

00:10:14.319 --> 00:10:17.124
and it had gone around the Earth multiple times.

00:10:17.124 --> 00:10:19.959
And I thought, why can't we do that today?

00:10:19.959 --> 00:10:22.326
And that's how this project got going.

00:10:22.326 --> 00:10:24.656
CR: But are you at the mercy of the wind?

00:10:24.656 --> 00:10:26.778
LP: Yeah, but it turns out,

00:10:26.778 --> 00:10:28.271
we did some weather simulations

00:10:28.271 --> 00:10:30.818
which probably hadn't really been done before,

00:10:30.818 --> 00:10:32.928
and if you control the altitude of the balloons,

00:10:32.928 --> 00:10:35.209
which you can do by pumping air into them

00:10:35.209 --> 00:10:37.031
and other ways,

00:10:37.031 --> 00:10:39.960
you can actually control roughly where they go,

00:10:39.960 --> 00:10:42.165
and so I think we can build a worldwide mesh

00:10:42.165 --> 00:10:45.504
of these balloons that can cover the whole planet.

00:10:45.504 --> 00:10:47.746
CR: Before I talk about the future and transportation,

00:10:47.746 --> 00:10:49.641
where you've been a nerd for a while,

00:10:49.641 --> 00:10:52.065
and this fascination you have with transportation

00:10:52.065 --> 00:10:54.128
and automated cars and bicycles,

00:10:54.128 --> 00:10:55.865
let me talk a bit about what's been the subject here

00:10:55.865 --> 00:10:58.308
earlier with Edward Snowden.

00:10:58.308 --> 00:11:01.414
It is security and privacy.

00:11:01.414 --> 00:11:03.754
You have to have been thinking about that.

00:11:03.754 --> 00:11:05.108
LP: Yeah, absolutely.

00:11:05.108 --> 00:11:07.951
I saw the picture of Sergey with
Edward Snowden yesterday.

00:11:07.951 --> 00:11:10.821
Some of you may have seen it.

00:11:10.821 --> 00:11:13.992
But I think, for me, I guess,

00:11:13.992 --> 00:11:17.654
privacy and security are a really important thing.

00:11:17.654 --> 00:11:19.899
We think about it in terms of both things,

00:11:19.899 --> 00:11:22.802
and I think you can't have privacy without security,

00:11:22.802 --> 00:11:25.173
so let me just talk about security first,

00:11:25.173 --> 00:11:27.769
because you asked about Snowden and all of that,

00:11:27.769 --> 00:11:30.210
and then I'll say a little bit about privacy.

00:11:30.210 --> 00:11:34.010
I think for me, it's tremendously disappointing

00:11:34.010 --> 00:11:35.449
that the government

00:11:35.449 --> 00:11:37.779
secretly did all this stuff and didn't tell us.

00:11:37.779 --> 00:11:41.082
I don't think we can have a democracy

00:11:41.082 --> 00:11:44.512
if we're having to protect you and our users

00:11:44.512 --> 00:11:46.208
from the government

00:11:46.208 --> 00:11:49.011
for stuff that we've never had a conversation about.

00:11:49.011 --> 00:11:50.907
And I don't mean we have to know

00:11:50.907 --> 00:11:52.602
what the particular terrorist attack is they're worried

00:11:52.602 --> 00:11:54.364
about protecting us from,

00:11:54.364 --> 00:11:56.162
but we do need to know

00:11:56.162 --> 00:11:58.572
what the parameters of it is,

00:11:58.572 --> 00:12:00.616
what kind of surveillance the government's

00:12:00.616 --> 00:12:02.784
going to do and how and why,

00:12:02.784 --> 00:12:05.061
and I think we haven't had that conversation.

00:12:05.061 --> 00:12:07.628
So I think the government's actually done

00:12:07.628 --> 00:12:09.796
itself a tremendous disservice

00:12:09.796 --> 00:12:11.957
by doing all that in secret.

00:12:11.957 --> 00:12:13.572
CR: Never coming to Google

00:12:13.572 --> 00:12:15.097
to ask for anything.

00:12:15.097 --> 00:12:17.127
LP: Not Google, but the public.

00:12:17.127 --> 00:12:20.900
I think we need to 
have a debate about that,

00:12:20.900 --> 00:12:23.399
or we can't have a functioning democracy.

00:12:23.399 --> 00:12:24.805
It's just not possible.

00:12:24.805 --> 00:12:27.049
So I'm sad that Google's

00:12:27.049 --> 00:12:29.665
in the position of protecting you and our users

00:12:29.665 --> 00:12:31.199
from the government

00:12:31.199 --> 00:12:33.443
doing secret thing that nobody knows about.

00:12:33.443 --> 00:12:35.190
It doesn't make any sense.

00:12:35.190 --> 00:12:38.180
CR: Yeah. And then there's a privacy side of it.

00:12:38.180 --> 00:12:40.607
LP: Yes. The privacy side,

00:12:40.607 --> 00:12:42.576
I think it's -- the world is changing.

00:12:42.576 --> 00:12:46.481
You carry a phone. It knows where you are.

00:12:46.481 --> 00:12:49.566
There's so much more information about you,

00:12:49.566 --> 00:12:52.412
and that's an important thing,

00:12:52.412 --> 00:12:54.684
and it makes sense why people are asking

00:12:54.684 --> 00:12:56.720
difficult questions.

00:12:56.720 --> 00:13:00.087
We spend a lot of time thinking about this

00:13:00.087 --> 00:13:02.798
and what the issues are.

00:13:02.798 --> 00:13:04.527
I'm a little bit --

00:13:04.527 --> 00:13:05.787
I think the main thing that we need to do

00:13:05.787 --> 00:13:08.149
is just provide people choice,

00:13:08.149 --> 00:13:10.661
show them what data's being collected --

00:13:10.661 --> 00:13:15.412
search history, location data.

00:13:15.412 --> 00:13:18.184
We're excited about incognito mode in Chrome,

00:13:18.184 --> 00:13:20.433
and doing that in more ways,

00:13:20.433 --> 00:13:21.829
just giving people more choice

00:13:21.829 --> 00:13:25.122
and more awareness of what's going on.

00:13:25.122 --> 00:13:27.515
I also think it's very easy.

00:13:27.515 --> 00:13:28.792
What I'm worried is that we throw out

00:13:28.792 --> 00:13:30.882
the baby with the bathwater.

00:13:30.882 --> 00:13:33.796
And I look at, on your show, actually,

00:13:33.796 --> 00:13:35.515
I kind of lost my voice,

00:13:35.515 --> 00:13:36.846
and I haven't gotten it back.

00:13:36.846 --> 00:13:38.490
I'm hoping that by talking to you

00:13:38.490 --> 00:13:40.143
I'm going to get it back.

00:13:40.143 --> 00:13:41.875
CR: If I could do anything, I would do that.

00:13:41.875 --> 00:13:44.055
LP: All right. So get out your voodoo doll

00:13:44.055 --> 00:13:46.474
and whatever you need to do.

00:13:46.474 --> 00:13:48.802
But I think, you know what, I look at that,

00:13:48.802 --> 00:13:50.632
I made that public,

00:13:50.632 --> 00:13:51.849
and I got all this information.

00:13:51.849 --> 00:13:54.578
We got a survey done on medical conditions

00:13:54.578 --> 00:13:57.949
with people who have similar issues,

00:13:57.949 --> 00:14:02.690
and I look at medical records, and I say,

00:14:02.690 --> 00:14:04.095
wouldn't it be amazing

00:14:04.095 --> 00:14:06.145
if everyone's medical records were available

00:14:06.145 --> 00:14:07.828
anonymously

00:14:07.828 --> 00:14:10.464
to research doctors?

00:14:10.464 --> 00:14:13.505
And when someone accesses your medical record,

00:14:13.505 --> 00:14:15.114
a research doctor,

00:14:15.114 --> 00:14:17.748
they could see, you could see which doctor

00:14:17.748 --> 00:14:19.608
accessed it and why,

00:14:19.608 --> 00:14:21.188
and you could maybe learn about

00:14:21.188 --> 00:14:22.818
what conditions you have.

00:14:22.818 --> 00:14:24.320
I think if we just did that,

00:14:24.320 --> 00:14:26.485
we'd save 100,000 lives this year.

00:14:26.485 --> 00:14:29.433
CR: Absolutely. Let me go — (Applause)

00:14:29.433 --> 00:14:32.195
LP: So I guess I'm just very worried that

00:14:32.195 --> 00:14:34.001
with Internet privacy,

00:14:34.001 --> 00:14:36.301
we're doing the same thing we're 
doing with medical records,

00:14:36.305 --> 00:14:38.834
is we're throwing out the baby with the bathwater,

00:14:38.834 --> 00:14:40.662
and we're not really thinking

00:14:40.662 --> 00:14:42.872
about the tremendous good that can come

00:14:42.872 --> 00:14:45.063
from people sharing information

00:14:45.063 --> 00:14:47.640
with the right people in the right ways.

00:14:47.640 --> 00:14:49.877
CR: And the necessary condition

00:14:49.877 --> 00:14:51.579
that people have to have confidence

00:14:51.579 --> 00:14:54.034
that their information will not be abused.

00:14:54.034 --> 00:14:55.811
LP: Yeah, and I had this problem with my voice stuff.

00:14:55.811 --> 00:14:57.319
I was scared to share it.

00:14:57.319 --> 00:14:59.209
Sergey encouraged me to do that,

00:14:59.209 --> 00:15:01.036
and it was a great thing to do.

00:15:01.036 --> 00:15:02.770
CR: And the response has been overwhelming.

00:15:02.770 --> 00:15:04.430
LP: Yeah, and people are super positive.

00:15:04.430 --> 00:15:07.263
We got thousands and thousands of people

00:15:07.263 --> 00:15:08.551
with similar conditions,

00:15:08.551 --> 00:15:11.579
which there's no data on today.

00:15:11.579 --> 00:15:12.935
So it was a really good thing.

00:15:12.935 --> 00:15:15.954
CR: So talking about the future, what is it about you

00:15:15.954 --> 00:15:19.712
and transportation systems?

00:15:19.712 --> 00:15:21.889
LP: Yeah. I guess I was just frustrated

00:15:21.889 --> 00:15:24.428
with this when I was at college in Michigan.

00:15:24.428 --> 00:15:25.878
I had to get on the bus and take it

00:15:25.878 --> 00:15:27.520
and wait for it.

00:15:27.520 --> 00:15:29.699
And it was cold and snowing.

00:15:29.699 --> 00:15:32.354
I did some research on how much it cost,

00:15:32.354 --> 00:15:38.779
and I just became a bit obsessed
with transportation systems.

00:15:38.779 --> 00:15:41.149
CR: And that began the idea of an automated car.

00:15:41.149 --> 00:15:42.843
LP: Yeah, about 18 years ago I learned about

00:15:42.843 --> 00:15:46.025
people working on automated cars,

00:15:46.025 --> 00:15:47.648
and I became fascinated by that,

00:15:47.648 --> 00:15:50.425
and it takes a while to 
get these projects going,

00:15:50.425 --> 00:15:55.522
but I'm super excited about the possibilities of that

00:15:55.522 --> 00:15:57.190
improving the world.

00:15:57.190 --> 00:16:01.716
There's 20 million people or more injured per year.

00:16:01.716 --> 00:16:03.702
It's the leading cause of death

00:16:03.702 --> 00:16:05.832
for people under 34 in the U.S.

00:16:05.832 --> 00:16:07.383
CR: So you're talking about saving lives.

00:16:07.383 --> 00:16:09.738
LP: Yeah, and also saving space

00:16:09.738 --> 00:16:13.653
and making life better.

00:16:13.653 --> 00:16:17.898
Los Angeles is half parking lots and roads,

00:16:17.898 --> 00:16:19.631
half of the area,

00:16:19.631 --> 00:16:22.458
and most cities are not far behind, actually.

00:16:22.458 --> 00:16:24.022
It's just crazy

00:16:24.022 --> 00:16:25.615
that that's what we use our space for.

00:16:25.615 --> 00:16:27.958
CR: And how soon will we be there?

00:16:27.958 --> 00:16:29.884
LP: I think we can be there very, very soon.

00:16:29.884 --> 00:16:33.385
We've driven well over 100,000 miles

00:16:33.385 --> 00:16:37.478
now totally automated.

00:16:37.478 --> 00:16:41.130
I'm super excited about getting that out quickly.

00:16:41.130 --> 00:16:43.535
CR: But it's not only you're
talking about automated cars.

00:16:43.535 --> 00:16:45.921
You also have this idea for bicycles.

00:16:45.921 --> 00:16:48.167
LP: Well at Google, we got this idea

00:16:48.167 --> 00:16:51.618
that we should just provide free bikes to everyone,

00:16:51.618 --> 00:16:54.386
and that's been amazing, most of the trips.

00:16:54.386 --> 00:16:55.972
You see bikes going everywhere,

00:16:55.972 --> 00:16:57.538
and the bikes wear out.

00:16:57.538 --> 00:16:58.992
They're getting used 24 hours a day.

00:16:58.992 --> 00:17:01.152
CR: But you want to put them above the street, too.

00:17:01.152 --> 00:17:02.727
LP: Well I said, how do we get people

00:17:02.727 --> 00:17:04.254
using bikes more?

00:17:04.254 --> 00:17:05.879
CR: We may have a video here.

00:17:05.879 --> 00:17:07.157
LP: Yeah, let's show the video.

00:17:07.157 --> 00:17:10.249
I just got excited about this.

00:17:10.249 --> 00:17:14.291
(Music)

00:17:16.171 --> 00:17:18.596
So this is actually how you might separate

00:17:18.596 --> 00:17:22.225
bikes from cars with minimal cost.

00:17:26.669 --> 00:17:28.424
Anyway, it looks totally crazy,

00:17:28.424 --> 00:17:30.751
but I was actually thinking about our campus,

00:17:30.751 --> 00:17:32.811
working with the Zippies and stuff,

00:17:32.811 --> 00:17:35.109
and just trying to get a lot more bike usage,

00:17:35.109 --> 00:17:36.657
and I was thinking about,

00:17:36.657 --> 00:17:39.488
how do you cost-effectively separate

00:17:39.488 --> 00:17:40.902
the bikes from traffic?

00:17:40.902 --> 00:17:42.052
And I went and searched,

00:17:42.052 --> 00:17:43.423
and this is what I found.

00:17:43.423 --> 00:17:45.268
And we're not actually working on this,

00:17:45.268 --> 00:17:46.560
that particular thing,

00:17:46.560 --> 00:17:48.614
but it gets your imagination going.

00:17:48.614 --> 00:17:50.378
CR: Let me close with this.

00:17:50.378 --> 00:17:52.723
Give me a sense of the philosophy 
of your own mind.

00:17:52.723 --> 00:17:55.211
You have this idea of [Google X].

00:17:55.211 --> 00:17:58.207
You don't simply want

00:17:58.207 --> 00:18:03.803
to go in some small, measurable arena of progress.

00:18:03.803 --> 00:18:05.516
LP: Yeah, I think

00:18:05.516 --> 00:18:07.647
many of the things we just 
talked about are like that,

00:18:07.647 --> 00:18:10.599
where they're really --

00:18:10.599 --> 00:18:14.229
I almost use the economic concept of additionality,

00:18:14.229 --> 00:18:16.419
which means that you're doing something

00:18:16.419 --> 00:18:19.367
that wouldn't happen unless 
you were actually doing it.

00:18:19.367 --> 00:18:22.507
And I think the more you can do things like that,

00:18:22.507 --> 00:18:24.578
the bigger impact you have,

00:18:24.578 --> 00:18:27.568
and that's about doing things

00:18:27.568 --> 00:18:31.175
that people might not think are possible.

00:18:31.175 --> 00:18:33.004
And I've been amazed,

00:18:33.004 --> 00:18:35.233
the more I learn about technology,

00:18:35.233 --> 00:18:37.429
the more I realize I don't know,

00:18:37.429 --> 00:18:40.766
and that's because this technological horizon,

00:18:40.766 --> 00:18:43.663
the thing that you can see to do next,

00:18:43.663 --> 00:18:45.503
the more you learn about technology,

00:18:45.503 --> 00:18:48.105
the more you learn what's possible.

00:18:48.105 --> 00:18:50.351
You learn that the balloons are possible

00:18:50.351 --> 00:18:52.688
because there's some material
that will work for them.

00:18:52.688 --> 00:18:55.067
CR: What's interesting about 
you too, though, for me,

00:18:55.067 --> 00:18:56.778
is that, we have lots of people

00:18:56.778 --> 00:18:58.920
who are thinking about the future,

00:18:58.920 --> 00:19:02.188
and they are going and looking
and they're coming back,

00:19:02.188 --> 00:19:04.315
but we never see the implementation.

00:19:04.315 --> 00:19:05.920
I think of somebody you knew

00:19:05.920 --> 00:19:08.827
and read about, Tesla.

00:19:08.827 --> 00:19:12.631
The principle of that for you is what?

00:19:12.631 --> 00:19:14.416
LP: Well, I think invention is not enough.

00:19:14.416 --> 00:19:15.637
If you invent something,

00:19:15.637 --> 00:19:18.832
Tesla invented electric power that we use,

00:19:18.832 --> 00:19:21.493
but he struggled to get it out to people.

00:19:21.493 --> 00:19:23.177
That had to be done by other people.

00:19:23.177 --> 00:19:24.803
It took a long time.

00:19:24.803 --> 00:19:28.670
And I think if we can actually combine both things,

00:19:28.670 --> 00:19:32.201
where we have an innovation and invention focus,

00:19:32.201 --> 00:19:35.173
plus the ability to really -- a company

00:19:35.173 --> 00:19:37.171
that can really commercialize things

00:19:37.171 --> 00:19:38.801
and get them to people

00:19:38.801 --> 00:19:40.876
in a way that's positive for the world

00:19:40.876 --> 00:19:42.932
and to give people hope.

00:19:42.932 --> 00:19:45.706
You know, I'm amazed with the Loon Project

00:19:45.706 --> 00:19:48.492
just how excited people were about that,

00:19:48.492 --> 00:19:50.306
because it gave them hope

00:19:50.306 --> 00:19:51.927
for the two thirds of the world

00:19:51.927 --> 00:19:54.653
that doesn't have Internet right now that's any good.

00:19:54.653 --> 00:19:56.775
CR: Which is a second thing about corporations.

00:19:56.775 --> 00:19:59.251
You are one of those people who believe

00:19:59.251 --> 00:20:01.568
that corporations are an agent of change

00:20:01.568 --> 00:20:03.039
if they are run well.

00:20:03.039 --> 00:20:04.860
LP: Yeah. I'm really dismayed

00:20:04.860 --> 00:20:08.154
most people think companies are basically evil.

00:20:08.154 --> 00:20:09.920
They get a bad rap.

00:20:09.920 --> 00:20:12.161
And I think that's somewhat correct.

00:20:12.161 --> 00:20:15.031
Companies are doing the same incremental thing

00:20:15.031 --> 00:20:16.794
that they did 50 years ago

00:20:16.794 --> 00:20:18.425
or 20 years ago.

00:20:18.425 --> 00:20:19.795
That's not really what we need.

00:20:19.795 --> 00:20:22.013
We need, especially in technology,

00:20:22.013 --> 00:20:24.130
we need revolutionary change,

00:20:24.130 --> 00:20:25.543
not incremental change.

00:20:25.543 --> 00:20:26.712
CR: You once said, actually,

00:20:26.712 --> 00:20:28.530
as I think I've got this about right,

00:20:28.530 --> 00:20:30.175
that you might consider,

00:20:30.175 --> 00:20:31.928
rather than giving your money,

00:20:31.928 --> 00:20:35.248
if you were leaving it to some cause,

00:20:35.248 --> 00:20:37.254
just simply giving it to Elon Musk,

00:20:37.254 --> 00:20:38.417
because you had confidence

00:20:38.417 --> 00:20:40.259
that he would change the future,

00:20:40.259 --> 00:20:42.036
and that you would therefore —

00:20:42.036 --> 00:20:43.620
LP: Yeah, if you want to go Mars,

00:20:43.620 --> 00:20:45.341
he wants to go to Mars,

00:20:45.341 --> 00:20:47.312
to back up humanity,

00:20:47.312 --> 00:20:48.984
that's a worthy goal, but it's a company,

00:20:48.984 --> 00:20:51.539
and it's philanthropical.

00:20:51.539 --> 00:20:54.491
So I think we aim to do kind of similar things.

00:20:54.491 --> 00:20:57.478
And I think, you ask, we have a lot of employees

00:20:57.478 --> 00:21:00.793
at Google who have become pretty wealthy.

00:21:00.793 --> 00:21:03.313
People make a lot of money in technology.

00:21:03.313 --> 00:21:05.469
A lot of people in the room are pretty wealthy.

00:21:05.469 --> 00:21:07.783
You're working because you
want to change the world.

00:21:07.783 --> 00:21:09.545
You want to make it better.

00:21:09.545 --> 00:21:12.990
Why isn't the company that you work for

00:21:12.990 --> 00:21:14.933
worthy not just of your time

00:21:14.933 --> 00:21:17.084
but your money as well?

00:21:17.084 --> 00:21:18.806
I mean, but we don't have a concept of that.

00:21:18.806 --> 00:21:21.110
That's not how we think about companies,

00:21:21.110 --> 00:21:22.577
and I think it's sad,

00:21:22.577 --> 00:21:26.344
because companies are most of our effort.

00:21:26.344 --> 00:21:28.859
They're where most of people's time is,

00:21:28.859 --> 00:21:30.713
where a lot of the money is,

00:21:30.713 --> 00:21:33.065
and so I think I'd like for us to help out

00:21:33.065 --> 00:21:34.191
more than we are.

00:21:34.191 --> 00:21:35.912
CR: When I close conversations with lots of people,

00:21:35.912 --> 00:21:37.691
I always ask this question:

00:21:37.691 --> 00:21:39.206
What state of mind,

00:21:39.206 --> 00:21:41.015
what quality of mind is it

00:21:41.015 --> 00:21:42.782
that has served you best?

00:21:42.782 --> 00:21:45.303
People like Rupert Murdoch have said curiosity,

00:21:45.303 --> 00:21:47.931
and other people in the media have said that.

00:21:47.931 --> 00:21:50.955
Bill Gates and Warren Buffett have said focus.

00:21:50.955 --> 00:21:52.382
What quality of mind,

00:21:52.382 --> 00:21:53.756
as I leave this audience,

00:21:53.756 --> 00:21:57.286
has enabled you to think about the future

00:21:57.286 --> 00:21:58.933
and at the same time

00:21:58.933 --> 00:22:01.138
change the present?

00:22:01.138 --> 00:22:02.808
LP: You know, I think the most important thing --

00:22:02.808 --> 00:22:04.420
I looked at lots of companies

00:22:04.420 --> 00:22:07.723
and why I thought they don't succeed over time.

00:22:07.723 --> 00:22:10.556
We've had a more rapid turnover of companies.

00:22:10.556 --> 00:22:13.325
And I said, what did they fundamentally do wrong?

00:22:13.325 --> 00:22:15.492
What did those companies all do wrong?

00:22:15.492 --> 00:22:18.764
And usually it's just that they missed the future.

00:22:18.764 --> 00:22:21.208
And so I think, for me,

00:22:21.208 --> 00:22:23.632
I just try to focus on that and say,

00:22:23.632 --> 00:22:25.816
what is that future really going to be

00:22:25.816 --> 00:22:27.603
and how do we create it,

00:22:27.603 --> 00:22:32.270
and how do we cause our organization,

00:22:32.270 --> 00:22:34.710
to really focus on that

00:22:34.710 --> 00:22:38.035
and drive that at a really high rate?

00:22:38.035 --> 00:22:39.395
And so that's been curiosity,

00:22:39.395 --> 00:22:41.128
it's been looking at things

00:22:41.128 --> 00:22:42.846
people might not think about,

00:22:42.846 --> 00:22:45.951
working on things that no one else is working on,

00:22:45.951 --> 00:22:49.257
because that's where the additionality really is,

00:22:49.257 --> 00:22:50.808
and be willing to do that,

00:22:50.808 --> 00:22:52.190
to take that risk.

00:22:52.190 --> 00:22:53.255
Look at Android.

00:22:53.255 --> 00:22:56.040
I felt guilty about working on Android

00:22:56.040 --> 00:22:57.356
when it was starting.

00:22:57.356 --> 00:22:59.314
It was a little startup we bought.

00:22:59.314 --> 00:23:01.984
It wasn't really what we were really working on.

00:23:01.984 --> 00:23:04.479
And I felt guilty about spending time on that.

00:23:04.479 --> 00:23:05.933
That was stupid.

00:23:05.933 --> 00:23:06.984
That was the future, right?

00:23:06.984 --> 00:23:09.269
That was a good thing to be working on.

00:23:09.269 --> 00:23:10.686
CR: It is great to see you here.

00:23:10.686 --> 00:23:12.146
It's great to hear from you,

00:23:12.146 --> 00:23:14.443
and a pleasure to sit at this table with you.

00:23:14.443 --> 00:23:15.371
Thanks, Larry.

00:23:15.371 --> 00:23:17.474
LP: Thank you.

00:23:17.474 --> 00:23:21.406
(Applause)

00:23:21.406 --> 00:23:24.717
CR: Larry Page.

title: My daughter, Malala
transcript: In many patriarchal societies and tribal societies, fathers are usually known by their sons, but I'm one of the few fathers who is known by his daughter, and I am proud of it.(Applause)Malala started her campaign for education and stood for her rights in 2007, and when her efforts were honored in 2011, and she was given the national youth peace prize, and she became a very famous, very popular young girl of her country. Before that, she was my daughter, but now I am her father. Ladies and gentlemen, if we glance to human history, the story of women is the story of injustice, inequality, violence and exploitation. You see, in patriarchal societies, right from the very beginning, when a girl is born, her birth is not celebrated. She is not welcomed, neither by father nor by mother. The neighborhood comes and commiserates with the mother, and nobody congratulates the father. And a mother is very uncomfortable for having a girl child. When she gives birth to the first girl child, first daughter, she is sad. When she gives birth to the second daughter, she is shocked, and in the expectation of a son, when she gives birth to a third daughter, she feels guilty like a criminal.Not only the mother suffers, but the daughter, the newly born daughter, when she grows old, she suffers too. At the age of five, while she should be going to school, she stays at home and her brothers are admitted in a school. Until the age of 12, somehow, she has a good life. She can have fun. She can play with her friends in the streets, and she can move around in the streets like a butterfly. But when she enters her teens, when she becomes 13 years old, she is forbidden to go out of her home without a male escort. She is confined under the four walls of her home. She is no more a free individual. She becomes the so-called honor of her father and of her brothers and of her family, and if she transgresses the code of that so-called honor, she could even be killed.And it is also interesting that this so-called code of honor, it does not only affect the life of a girl, it also affects the life of the male members of the family. I know a family of seven sisters and one brother, and that one brother, he has migrated to the Gulf countries, to earn a living for his seven sisters and parents, because he thinks that it will be humiliating if his seven sisters learn a skill and they go out of the home and earn some livelihood. So this brother, he sacrifices the joys of his life and the happiness of his sisters at the altar of so-called honor.And there is one more norm of the patriarchal societies that is called obedience. A good girl is supposed to be very quiet, very humble and very submissive. It is the criteria. The role model good girl should be very quiet. She is supposed to be silent and she is supposed to accept the decisions of her father and mother and the decisions of elders, even if she does not like them. If she is married to a man she doesn't like or if she is married to an old man, she has to accept, because she does not want to be dubbed as disobedient. If she is married very early, she has to accept. Otherwise, she will be called disobedient. And what happens at the end? In the words of a poetess, she is wedded, bedded, and then she gives birth to more sons and daughters. And it is the irony of the situation that this mother, she teaches the same lesson of obedience to her daughter and the same lesson of honor to her sons. And this vicious cycle goes on, goes on.Ladies and gentlemen, this plight of millions of women could be changed if we think differently, if women and men think differently, if men and women in the tribal and patriarchal societies in the developing countries, if they can break a few norms of family and society, if they can abolish the discriminatory laws of the systems in their states, which go against the basic human rights of the women.Dear brothers and sisters, when Malala was born, and for the first time, believe me, I don't like newborn children, to be honest, but when I went and I looked into her eyes, believe me, I got extremely honored. And long before she was born, I thought about her name, and I was fascinated with a heroic legendary freedom fighter in Afghanistan. Her name was Malalai of Maiwand, and I named my daughter after her. A few days after Malala was born, my daughter was born, my cousin came — and it was a coincidence — he came to my home and he brought a family tree, a family tree of the Yousafzai family, and when I looked at the family tree, it traced back to 300 years of our ancestors. But when I looked, all were men, and I picked my pen, drew a line from my name, and wrote, "Malala."And when she grow old, when she was four and a half years old, I admitted her in my school. You will be asking, then, why should I mention about the admission of a girl in a school? Yes, I must mention it. It may be taken for granted in Canada, in America, in many developed countries, but in poor countries, in patriarchal societies, in tribal societies, it's a big event for the life of girl. Enrollment in a school means recognition of her identity and her name. Admission in a school means that she has entered the world of dreams and aspirations where she can explore her potentials for her future life. I have five sisters, and none of them could go to school, and you will be astonished, two weeks before, when I was filling out the Canadian visa form, and I was filling out the family part of the form, I could not recall the surnames of some of my sisters. And the reason was that I have never, never seen the names of my sisters written on any document. That was the reason that I valued my daughter. What my father could not give to my sisters and to his daughters, I thought I must change it.I used to appreciate the intelligence and the brilliance of my daughter. I encouraged her to sit with me when my friends used to come. I encouraged her to go with me to different meetings. And all these good values, I tried to inculcate in her personality. And this was not only she, only Malala. I imparted all these good values to my school, girl students  and boy students as well. I used education for emancipation. I taught my girls, I taught my girl students, to unlearn the lesson of obedience. I taught my boy students to unlearn the lesson of so-called pseudo-honor.Dear brothers and sisters, we were striving for more rights for women, and we were struggling to have more, more and more space for the women in society. But we came across a new phenomenon. It was lethal to human rights and particularly to women's rights. It was called Talibanization. It means a complete negation of women's participation in all political, economical and social activities. Hundreds of schools were lost. Girls were prohibited from going to school. Women were forced to wear veils and they were stopped from going to the markets. Musicians were silenced, girls were flogged and singers were killed. Millions were suffering, but few spoke, and it was the most scary thing when you have all around such people who kill and who flog, and you speak for your rights. It's really the most scary thing.At the age of 10, Malala stood, and she stood for the right of education. She wrote a diary for the BBC blog, she volunteered herself for the New York Times documentaries, and she spoke from every platform she could. And her voice was the most powerful voice. It spread like a crescendo all around the world. And that was the reason the Taliban could not tolerate her campaign, and on October 9 2012, she was shot in the head at point blank range.It was a doomsday for my family and for me. The world turned into a big black hole. While my daughter was on the verge of life and death, I whispered into the ears of my wife, "Should I be blamed for what happened to my daughter and your daughter?"And she abruptly told me, "Please don't blame yourself. You stood for the right cause. You put your life at stake for the cause of truth, for the cause of peace, and for the cause of education, and your daughter in inspired from you and she joined you. You both were on the right path and God will protect her."These few words meant a lot to me, and I didn't ask this question again.When Malala was in the hospital, and she was going through the severe pains and she had had severe headaches because her facial nerve was cut down, I used to see a dark shadow spreading on the face of my wife. But my daughter never complained. She used to tell us, "I'm fine with my crooked smile and with my numbness in my face. I'll be okay. Please don't worry." She was a solace for us, and she consoled us.Dear brothers and sisters, we learned from her how to be resilient in the most difficult times, and I'm glad to share with you that despite being an icon for the rights of children and women, she is like any 16-year old girl. She cries when her homework is incomplete. She quarrels with her brothers, and I am very happy for that.People ask me, what special is in my mentorship which has made Malala so bold and so courageous and so vocal and poised? I tell them, don't ask me what I did. Ask me what I did not do. I did not clip her wings, and that's all.Thank you very much.(Applause) Thank you. Thank you very much. Thank you. (Applause)

00:03:33.946 --> 00:03:36.634
and if she transgresses

00:03:36.634 --> 00:03:39.845
the code of that so-called honor,

00:03:39.845 --> 00:03:44.209
she could even be killed.

00:03:44.209 --> 00:03:48.210
And it is also interesting that this so-called

00:03:48.210 --> 00:03:49.573
code of honor,

00:03:49.573 --> 00:03:53.263
it does not only affect the life of a girl,

00:03:53.263 --> 00:03:55.389
it also affects the life

00:03:55.389 --> 00:04:00.188
of the male members of the family.

00:04:00.188 --> 00:04:06.781
I know a family of seven sisters and one brother,

00:04:06.781 --> 00:04:08.603
and that one brother,

00:04:08.603 --> 00:04:12.107
he has migrated to the Gulf countries,

00:04:12.107 --> 00:04:14.802
to earn a living for his seven sisters

00:04:14.802 --> 00:04:17.150
and parents,

00:04:17.150 --> 00:04:23.004
because he thinks that it will be humiliating

00:04:23.004 --> 00:04:25.726
if his seven sisters learn a skill

00:04:25.726 --> 00:04:28.106
and they go out of the home

00:04:28.106 --> 00:04:32.257
and earn some livelihood.

00:04:32.257 --> 00:04:33.847
So this brother,

00:04:33.847 --> 00:04:37.200
he sacrifices the joys of his life

00:04:37.200 --> 00:04:40.592
and the happiness of his sisters

00:04:40.592 --> 00:04:45.176
at the altar of so-called honor.

00:04:45.176 --> 00:04:46.710
And there is one more norm

00:04:46.710 --> 00:04:49.068
of the patriarchal societies

00:04:49.068 --> 00:04:53.518
that is called obedience.

00:04:53.518 --> 00:04:57.304
A good girl is supposed to be

00:04:57.304 --> 00:05:02.552
very quiet, very humble

00:05:02.552 --> 00:05:06.523
and very submissive.

00:05:06.523 --> 00:05:07.862
It is the criteria.

00:05:07.862 --> 00:05:11.694
The role model good girl should be very quiet.

00:05:11.694 --> 00:05:13.983
She is supposed to be silent

00:05:13.983 --> 00:05:17.154
and she is supposed to accept the decisions

00:05:17.154 --> 00:05:19.374
of her father and mother

00:05:19.374 --> 00:05:22.599
and the decisions of elders,

00:05:22.599 --> 00:05:25.005
even if she does not like them.

00:05:25.005 --> 00:05:28.334
If she is married to a man she doesn't like

00:05:28.334 --> 00:05:31.076
or if she is married to an old man,

00:05:31.076 --> 00:05:32.636
she has to accept,

00:05:32.636 --> 00:05:35.154
because she does not want to be dubbed

00:05:35.154 --> 00:05:37.777
as disobedient.

00:05:37.777 --> 00:05:39.409
If she is married very early,

00:05:39.409 --> 00:05:40.883
she has to accept.

00:05:40.883 --> 00:05:44.905
Otherwise, she will be called disobedient.

00:05:44.905 --> 00:05:47.708
And what happens at the end?

00:05:47.708 --> 00:05:49.463
In the words of a poetess,

00:05:49.463 --> 00:05:52.250
she is wedded, bedded,

00:05:52.250 --> 00:05:57.421
and then she gives birth
to more sons and daughters.

00:05:57.421 --> 00:06:00.190
And it is the irony of the situation

00:06:00.190 --> 00:06:02.522
that this mother,

00:06:02.522 --> 00:06:05.574
she teaches the same lesson of obedience

00:06:05.574 --> 00:06:06.634
to her daughter

00:06:06.634 --> 00:06:11.067
and the same lesson of honor to her sons.

00:06:11.067 --> 00:06:16.180
And this vicious cycle goes on, goes on.

00:06:17.955 --> 00:06:20.482
Ladies and gentlemen,

00:06:20.482 --> 00:06:23.704
this plight of millions of women

00:06:23.704 --> 00:06:26.536
could be changed

00:06:26.536 --> 00:06:28.911
if we think differently,

00:06:28.911 --> 00:06:32.892
if women and men think differently,

00:06:32.892 --> 00:06:37.110
if men and women in the
tribal and patriarchal societies

00:06:37.110 --> 00:06:39.093
in the developing countries,

00:06:39.093 --> 00:06:42.004
if they can break a few norms

00:06:42.004 --> 00:06:46.608
of family and society,

00:06:46.608 --> 00:06:52.088
if they can abolish the discriminatory laws

00:06:52.088 --> 00:06:54.616
of the systems in their states,

00:06:54.616 --> 00:06:56.907
which go against the basic human rights

00:06:56.907 --> 00:07:00.701
of the women.

00:07:00.701 --> 00:07:05.945
Dear brothers and sisters, when Malala was born,

00:07:05.945 --> 00:07:08.098
and for the first time,

00:07:08.098 --> 00:07:09.372
believe me,

00:07:09.372 --> 00:07:14.349
I don't like newborn children, to be honest,

00:07:14.349 --> 00:07:18.131
but when I went and I looked into her eyes,

00:07:18.131 --> 00:07:20.251
believe me,

00:07:20.251 --> 00:07:24.232
I got extremely honored.

00:07:24.232 --> 00:07:26.402
And long before she was born,

00:07:26.402 --> 00:07:29.438
I thought about her name,

00:07:29.438 --> 00:07:32.723
and I was fascinated with a heroic

00:07:32.723 --> 00:07:36.588
legendary freedom fighter in Afghanistan.

00:07:36.588 --> 00:07:41.597
Her name was Malalai of Maiwand,

00:07:41.597 --> 00:07:45.882
and I named my daughter after her.

00:07:45.882 --> 00:07:48.874
A few days after Malala was born,

00:07:48.874 --> 00:07:50.613
my daughter was born,

00:07:50.613 --> 00:07:52.271
my cousin came --

00:07:52.271 --> 00:07:54.239
and it was a coincidence --

00:07:54.239 --> 00:07:56.954
he came to my home

00:07:56.954 --> 00:07:59.659
and he brought a family tree,

00:07:59.659 --> 00:08:03.327
a family tree of the Yousafzai family,

00:08:03.327 --> 00:08:05.883
and when I looked at the family tree,

00:08:05.883 --> 00:08:11.936
it traced back to 300 years of our ancestors.

00:08:11.936 --> 00:08:16.333
But when I looked, all were men,

00:08:16.333 --> 00:08:18.755
and I picked my pen,

00:08:18.755 --> 00:08:20.759
drew a line from my name,

00:08:20.759 --> 00:08:24.458
and wrote, "Malala."

00:08:25.543 --> 00:08:28.313
And when she grow old,

00:08:28.313 --> 00:08:31.896
when she was four and a half years old,

00:08:31.896 --> 00:08:35.432
I admitted her in my school.

00:08:35.432 --> 00:08:38.338
You will be asking, then, why should I mention about

00:08:38.338 --> 00:08:40.840
the admission of a girl in a school?

00:08:40.840 --> 00:08:42.895
Yes, I must mention it.

00:08:42.895 --> 00:08:45.980
It may be taken for granted in Canada,

00:08:45.980 --> 00:08:49.807
in America, in many developed countries,

00:08:49.807 --> 00:08:52.265
but in poor countries,

00:08:52.265 --> 00:08:55.833
in patriarchal societies, in tribal societies,

00:08:55.833 --> 00:08:59.447
it's a big event for the life of girl.

00:08:59.447 --> 00:09:03.086
Enrollment in a school means

00:09:03.086 --> 00:09:08.835
recognition of her identity and her name.

00:09:08.835 --> 00:09:10.513
Admission in a school means

00:09:10.513 --> 00:09:14.195
that she has entered the world of dreams

00:09:14.195 --> 00:09:15.858
and aspirations

00:09:15.858 --> 00:09:19.370
where she can explore her potentials

00:09:19.370 --> 00:09:22.616
for her future life.

00:09:22.616 --> 00:09:24.695
I have five sisters,

00:09:24.695 --> 00:09:28.009
and none of them could go to school,

00:09:28.009 --> 00:09:29.583
and you will be astonished,

00:09:29.583 --> 00:09:33.677
two weeks before,

00:09:33.693 --> 00:09:37.976
when I was filling out the Canadian visa form,

00:09:37.976 --> 00:09:42.641
and I was filling out the family part of the form,

00:09:42.641 --> 00:09:44.725
I could not recall

00:09:44.725 --> 00:09:48.730
the surnames of some of my sisters.

00:09:48.730 --> 00:09:50.579
And the reason was

00:09:50.579 --> 00:09:53.871
that I have never, never seen the names

00:09:53.871 --> 00:09:59.697
of my sisters written on any document.

00:09:59.697 --> 00:10:02.637
That was the reason that

00:10:02.637 --> 00:10:06.170
I valued my daughter.

00:10:06.170 --> 00:10:10.483
What my father could not give to my sisters

00:10:10.483 --> 00:10:12.238
and to his daughters,

00:10:12.238 --> 00:10:16.479
I thought I must change it.

00:10:16.479 --> 00:10:19.486
I used to appreciate the intelligence

00:10:19.486 --> 00:10:23.158
and the brilliance of my daughter.

00:10:23.158 --> 00:10:25.752
I encouraged her to sit with me

00:10:25.752 --> 00:10:27.411
when my friends used to come.

00:10:27.411 --> 00:10:32.195
I encouraged her to go with
me to different meetings.

00:10:32.195 --> 00:10:33.856
And all these good values,

00:10:33.856 --> 00:10:37.066
I tried to inculcate in her personality.

00:10:37.066 --> 00:10:40.729
And this was not only she, only Malala.

00:10:40.729 --> 00:10:43.465
I imparted all these good values

00:10:43.465 --> 00:10:48.008
to my school, girl students 
and boy students as well.

00:10:48.008 --> 00:10:52.387
I used education for emancipation.

00:10:52.387 --> 00:10:54.252
I taught my girls,

00:10:54.252 --> 00:10:56.207
I taught my girl students,

00:10:56.207 --> 00:11:01.276
to unlearn the lesson of obedience.

00:11:01.276 --> 00:11:04.241
I taught my boy students

00:11:04.241 --> 00:11:09.722
to unlearn the lesson of so-called pseudo-honor.

00:11:13.654 --> 00:11:17.639
Dear brothers and sisters,

00:11:17.639 --> 00:11:22.222
we were striving for more rights for women,

00:11:22.222 --> 00:11:25.844
and we were struggling to have more,

00:11:25.844 --> 00:11:30.071
more and more space for the women in society.

00:11:30.071 --> 00:11:33.284
But we came across a new phenomenon.

00:11:33.284 --> 00:11:35.777
It was lethal to human rights

00:11:35.777 --> 00:11:39.225
and particularly to women's rights.

00:11:39.225 --> 00:11:43.902
It was called Talibanization.

00:11:43.902 --> 00:11:47.590
It means a complete negation

00:11:47.590 --> 00:11:49.800
of women's participation

00:11:49.800 --> 00:11:55.995
in all political, economical and social activities.

00:11:55.995 --> 00:11:59.542
Hundreds of schools were lost.

00:11:59.542 --> 00:12:05.773
Girls were prohibited from going to school.

00:12:05.773 --> 00:12:09.479
Women were forced to wear veils

00:12:09.479 --> 00:12:13.035
and they were stopped from going to the markets.

00:12:13.035 --> 00:12:15.619
Musicians were silenced,

00:12:15.619 --> 00:12:17.576
girls were flogged

00:12:17.576 --> 00:12:21.059
and singers were killed.

00:12:21.059 --> 00:12:22.933
Millions were suffering,

00:12:22.933 --> 00:12:26.178
but few spoke,

00:12:26.178 --> 00:12:28.402
and it was the most scary thing

00:12:28.402 --> 00:12:34.488
when you have all around such people

00:12:34.488 --> 00:12:36.514
who kill and who flog,

00:12:36.514 --> 00:12:37.810
and you speak for your rights.

00:12:37.810 --> 00:12:42.017
It's really the most scary thing.

00:12:42.017 --> 00:12:43.910
At the age of 10,

00:12:43.910 --> 00:12:48.154
Malala stood, and she stood for the right

00:12:48.154 --> 00:12:50.465
of education.

00:12:50.465 --> 00:12:55.237
She wrote a diary for the BBC blog,

00:12:55.237 --> 00:12:57.441
she volunteered herself

00:12:57.441 --> 00:13:01.035
for the New York Times documentaries,

00:13:01.035 --> 00:13:05.951
and she spoke from every platform she could.

00:13:05.951 --> 00:13:10.339
And her voice was the most powerful voice.

00:13:10.339 --> 00:13:16.592
It spread like a crescendo all around the world.

00:13:16.592 --> 00:13:18.444
And that was the reason the Taliban

00:13:18.444 --> 00:13:22.775
could not tolerate her campaign,

00:13:22.775 --> 00:13:25.624
and on October 9 2012,

00:13:25.624 --> 00:13:31.373
she was shot in the head at point blank range.

00:13:31.373 --> 00:13:35.518
It was a doomsday for my family and for me.

00:13:35.518 --> 00:13:41.337
The world turned into a big black hole.

00:13:41.337 --> 00:13:43.003
While my daughter was

00:13:43.003 --> 00:13:46.455
on the verge of life and death,

00:13:46.455 --> 00:13:50.294
I whispered into the ears of my wife,

00:13:50.294 --> 00:13:53.396
"Should I be blamed for what happened

00:13:53.396 --> 00:13:57.072
to my daughter and your daughter?"

00:13:57.072 --> 00:13:59.593
And she abruptly told me,

00:13:59.593 --> 00:14:02.104
"Please don't blame yourself.

00:14:02.104 --> 00:14:05.320
You stood for the right cause.

00:14:05.320 --> 00:14:07.455
You put your life at stake

00:14:07.455 --> 00:14:08.858
for the cause of truth,

00:14:08.858 --> 00:14:10.039
for the cause of peace,

00:14:10.039 --> 00:14:12.147
and for the cause of education,

00:14:12.147 --> 00:14:14.196
and your daughter in inspired from you

00:14:14.196 --> 00:14:16.427
and she joined you.

00:14:16.427 --> 00:14:18.102
You both were on the right path

00:14:18.102 --> 00:14:21.475
and God will protect her."

00:14:21.475 --> 00:14:24.821
These few words meant a lot to me,

00:14:24.821 --> 00:14:28.932
and I didn't ask this question again.

00:14:28.932 --> 00:14:33.052
When Malala was in the hospital,

00:14:33.052 --> 00:14:36.299
and she was going through the severe pains

00:14:36.299 --> 00:14:38.819
and she had had severe headaches

00:14:38.819 --> 00:14:42.007
because her facial nerve was cut down,

00:14:42.007 --> 00:14:44.459
I used to see a dark shadow

00:14:44.459 --> 00:14:49.996
spreading on the face of my wife.

00:14:49.996 --> 00:14:56.097
But my daughter never complained.

00:14:56.097 --> 00:14:58.158
She used to tell us,

00:14:58.158 --> 00:15:00.209
"I'm fine with my crooked smile

00:15:00.209 --> 00:15:02.951
and with my numbness in my face.

00:15:02.951 --> 00:15:05.030
I'll be okay. Please don't worry."

00:15:05.030 --> 00:15:07.159
She was a solace for us,

00:15:07.159 --> 00:15:10.056
and she consoled us.

00:15:12.078 --> 00:15:16.299
Dear brothers and sisters,

00:15:16.299 --> 00:15:18.921
we learned from her how to be resilient

00:15:18.921 --> 00:15:22.226
in the most difficult times,

00:15:22.226 --> 00:15:25.234
and I'm glad to share with you

00:15:25.234 --> 00:15:31.126
that despite being an icon

00:15:31.126 --> 00:15:33.955
for the rights of children and women,

00:15:33.955 --> 00:15:39.248
she is like any 16-year old girl.

00:15:39.248 --> 00:15:44.380
She cries when her homework is incomplete.

00:15:44.380 --> 00:15:46.448
She quarrels with her brothers,

00:15:46.448 --> 00:15:50.171
and I am very happy for that.

00:15:50.171 --> 00:15:52.574
People ask me,

00:15:52.574 --> 00:15:56.066
what special is in my mentorship

00:15:56.066 --> 00:15:58.606
which has made Malala so bold

00:15:58.606 --> 00:16:03.098
and so courageous and so vocal and poised?

00:16:03.098 --> 00:16:09.373
I tell them, don't ask me what I did.

00:16:09.373 --> 00:16:13.234
Ask me what I did not do.

00:16:13.234 --> 00:16:18.491
I did not clip her wings, and that's all.

00:16:18.491 --> 00:16:21.373
Thank you very much.

00:16:21.373 --> 00:16:26.869
(Applause)

00:16:26.869 --> 00:16:30.869
Thank you. Thank you very much. Thank you. (Applause)

title: To create for the ages, let's combine art and engineering
transcript: Good morning. When I was a little boy, I had an experience that changed my life, and is in fact why I'm here today. That one moment profoundly affected how I think about art, design and engineering.As background, I was fortunate enough to grow up in a family of loving and talented artists in one of the world's great cities. My dad, John Ferren, who died when I was 15, was an artist by both passion and profession, as is my mom, Rae. He was one of the New York School abstract expressionists who, together with his contemporaries, invented American modern art, and contributed to moving the American zeitgeist towards modernism in the 20th century. Isn't it remarkable that, after thousands of years of people doing mostly representational art, that modern art, comparatively speaking, is about 15 minutes old, yet now pervasive. As with many other important innovations, those radical ideas required no new technology, just fresh thinking and a willingness to experiment, plus resiliency in the face of near-universal criticism and rejection. In our home, art was everywhere. It was like oxygen, around us and necessary for life. As I watched him paint, Dad taught me that art was not about being decorative, but was a different way of communicating ideas, and in fact one that could bridge the worlds of knowledge and insight.Given this rich artistic environment, you'd assume that I would have been compelled to go into the family business, but no. I followed the path of most kids who are genetically programmed to make their parents crazy. I had no interest in becoming an artist, certainly not a painter. What I did love was electronics and machines — taking them apart, building new ones, and making them work. Fortunately, my family also had engineers in it, and with my parents, these were my first role models. What they all had in common was they worked very, very hard. My grandpa owned and operated a sheet metal kitchen cabinet factory in Brooklyn. On weekends, we would go together to Cortlandt Street, which was New York City's radio row. There we would explore massive piles of surplus electronics, and for a few bucks bring home treasures like Norden bombsights and parts from the first IBM tube-based computers. I found these objects both useful and fascinating. I learned about engineering and how things worked, not at school but by taking apart and studying these fabulously complex devices. I did this for hours every day, apparently avoiding electrocution. Life was good.However, every summer, sadly, the machines got left behind while my parents and I traveled overseas to experience history, art and design. We visited the great museums and historic buildings of both Europe and the Middle East, but to encourage my growing interest in science and technology, they would simply drop me off in places like the London Science Museum, where I would wander endlessly for hours by myself studying the history of science and technology.Then, when I was about nine years old, we went to Rome. On one particularly hot summer day, we visited a drum-shaped building that from the outside was not particularly interesting. My dad said it was called the Pantheon, a temple for all of the gods. It didn't look all that special from the outside, as I said, but when we walked inside, I was immediately struck by three things: First of all, it was pleasantly cool despite the oppressive heat outside. It was very dark, the only source of light being an big open hole in the roof. Dad explained that this wasn't a big open hole, but it was called the oculus, an eye to the heavens. And there was something about this place, I didn't know why, that just felt special. As we walked to the center of the room, I looked up at the heavens through the oculus. This was the first church that I'd been to that provided an unrestricted view between God and man. But I wondered, what about when it rained? Dad may have called this an oculus, but it was, in fact, a big hole in the roof. I looked down and saw floor drains had been cut into the stone floor. As I became more accustomed to the dark, I was able to make out details of the floor and the surrounding walls. No big deal here, just the same statuary stuff that we'd seen all over Rome. In fact, it looked like the Appian Way marble salesman showed up with his sample book, showed it to Hadrian, and Hadrian said, "We'll take all of it." (Laughter)But the ceiling was amazing. It looked like a Buckminster Fuller geodesic dome. I'd seen these before, and Bucky was friends with my dad. It was modern, high-tech, impressive, a huge 142-foot clear span which, not coincidentally, was exactly its height. I loved this place. It was really beautiful and unlike anything I'd ever seen before, so I asked my dad, "When was this built?" He said, "About 2,000 years ago." And I said, "No, I mean, the roof." You see, I assumed that this was a modern roof that had been put on because the original was destroyed in some long-past war. He said, "It's the original roof."That moment changed my life, and I can remember it as if it were yesterday. For the first time, I realized people were smart 2,000 years ago. (Laughter) This had never crossed my mind. I mean, to me, the pyramids at Giza, we visited those the year before, and sure they're impressive, nice enough design, but look, give me an unlimited budget, 20,000 to 40,000 laborers, and about 10 to 20 years to cut and drag stone blocks  across the countryside, and I'll build you pyramids too. But no amount of brute force gets you the dome of the Pantheon, not 2,000 years ago, nor today. And incidentally, it is still the largest unreinforced concrete dome that's ever been built. To build the Pantheon took some miracles. By miracles, I mean things that are technically barely possible, very high-risk, and might not be actually accomplishable at this moment in time, certainly not by you.For example, here are some of the Pantheon's miracles. To make it even structurally possible, they had to invent super-strong concrete, and to control weight, varied the density of the aggregate as they worked their way up the dome. For strength and lightness, the dome structure used five rings of coffers, each of diminishing size, which imparts a dramatic forced perspective to the design. It was wonderfully cool inside because of its huge thermal mass, natural convection of air rising up through the oculus, and a Venturi effect when wind blows across the top of the building. I discovered for the first time that light itself has substance. The shaft of light beaming through the oculus was both beautiful and palpable, and I realized for the first time that light could be designed. Further, that of all of the forms of design, visual design, they were all kind of irrelevant without it, because without light, you can't see any of them. I also realized that I wasn't the first person to think that this place was really special. It survived gravity, barbarians, looters, developers and the ravages of time to become what I believe is the longest continuously occupied building in history.Largely because of that visit, I came to understand that, contrary to what I was being told in school, the worlds of art and design were not, in fact, incompatible with science and engineering. I realized, when combined, you could create things that were amazing that couldn't be done in either domain alone. But in school, with few exceptions, they were treated as separate worlds, and they still are. My teachers told me that I had to get serious and focus on one or the other. However, urging me to specialize only caused me to really  appreciate those polymaths like Michelangelo, Leonardo da Vinci, Benjamin Franklin, people who did exactly the opposite. And this led me to embrace and want to be in both worlds.So then how do these projects of unprecedented creative vision and technical complexity like the Pantheon actually happen? Someone themselves, perhaps Hadrian, needed a brilliant creative vision. They also needed the storytelling and leadership skills necessary to fund and execute it, and a mastery of science and technology with the ability and knowhow to push existing innovations even farther. It is my belief that to create these rare game changers requires you to pull off at least five miracles. The problem is, no matter how talented, rich or smart you are, you only get one to one and a half miracles. That's it. That's the quota. Then you run out of time, money, enthusiasm, whatever. Remember, most people can't even imagine one of these technical miracles, and you need at least five to make a Pantheon. In my experience, these rare visionaries who can think across the worlds of art, design and engineering have the ability to notice when others have provided enough of the miracles to bring the goal within reach. Driven by the clarity of their vision, they summon the courage and determination to deliver the remaining miracles and they often take what other people think to be insurmountable obstacles and turn them into features. Take the oculus of the Pantheon. By insisting that it be in the design, it meant you couldn't use much of the structural technology that had been developed for Roman arches. However, by instead embracing it and rethinking weight and stress distribution, they came up with a design that only works if there's a big hole in the roof. That done, you now get the aesthetic and design benefits of light, cooling and that critical direct connection with the heavens. Not bad. These people not only believed that the impossible can be done, but that it must be done.Enough ancient history. What are some recent examples of innovations that combine creative design and technological advances in a way so profound that they will be remembered a thousand years from now? Well, putting a man on the moon was a good one, and returning him safely to Earth wasn't bad either. Talk about one giant leap: It's hard to imagine a more profound moment in human history than when we first left our world to set foot on another.So what came after the moon? One is tempted to say that today's pantheon is the Internet, but I actually think that's quite wrong, or at least it's only part of the story. The Internet isn't a Pantheon. It's more like the invention of concrete: important, absolutely necessary to build the Pantheon, and enduring, but entirely insufficient by itself. However, just as the technology of concrete was critical in realization of the Pantheon, new designers will use the technologies of the Internet to create novel concepts that will endure.
