The smartphone is a perfect example. Soon the majority of people on the planet will have one, and the idea of connecting everyone to both knowledge and each other will endure.So what's next? What imminent advance will be the equivalent of the Pantheon? Thinking about this, I rejected many very plausible and dramatic breakthroughs to come, such as curing cancer. Why? Because Pantheons are anchored in designed physical objects, ones that inspire by simply seeing and experiencing them, and will continue to do so indefinitely. It is a different kind of language, like art. These other vital contributions that extend life and relieve suffering are, of course, critical, and fantastic, but they're part of the continuum of our overall knowledge and technology, like the Internet.So what is next? Perhaps counterintuitively, I'm guessing it's a visionary idea from the late 1930s that's been revived every decade since: autonomous vehicles. Now you're thinking, give me a break. How can a fancy version of cruise control be profound? Look, much of our world has been designed around  roads and transportation. These were as essential to the success of the Roman Empire as the interstate highway system to the prosperity and development of the United States. Today, these roads that interconnect our world are dominated by cars and trucks that have remained largely unchanged for 100 years. Although perhaps not obvious today, autonomous vehicles will be the key technology that enables us to redesign our cities and, by extension, civilization. Here's why: Once they become ubiquitous, each year, these vehicles will save tens of thousands of lives in the United States alone and a million globally. Automotive energy consumption and air pollution will be cut dramatically. Much of the road congestion in and out of our cities will disappear. They will enable compelling new concepts in how we design cities, work, and the way we live. We will get where we're going faster and society will recapture vast amounts of lost productivity now spent sitting in traffic basically polluting.But why now? Why do we think this is ready? Because over the last 30 years, people from outside the automotive industry have spent countless billions creating the needed miracles, but for entirely different purposes. It took folks like DARPA, universities, and companies completely outside of the automotive industry to notice that if you were clever about it, autonomy could be done now. So what are the five miracles needed for autonomous vehicles? One, you need to know where you are and exactly what time it is. This was solved neatly by the GPS system, Global Positioning System, that the U.S. Government put in place. You need to know where all the roads are, what the rules are, and where you're going. The various needs of personal navigation systems, in-car navigation systems, and web-based maps address this. You must have near-continuous communication with high-performance computing networks and with others nearby to understand their intent. The wireless technologies developed for mobile devices, with some minor modifications, are completely suitable to solve this. You'll probably want some restricted roadways to get started that both society and its lawyers agree are safe to use for this. This will start with the HOV lanes and move from there. But finally, you need to recognize people, signs and objects. Machine vision, special sensors, and high-performance computing can do a lot of this, but it turns out a lot is not good enough when your family is on board. Occasionally, humans will  need to do sense-making. For this, you might actually have to wake up your passenger and ask them what the hell that big lump is in the middle of the road. Not so bad, and it will give us a sense of purpose in this new world. Besides, once the first drivers explain to their confused car that the giant chicken at the fork in the road is actually a restaurant, and it's okay to keep driving, every other car on the surface of the Earth will know that from that point on.Five miracles, mostly delivered, and now you just need a clear vision of a better world filled with autonomous vehicles with seductively beautiful  and new functional designs plus a lot of money and hard work to bring it home. The beginning is now only a handful of years away, and I predict that autonomous vehicles will permanently change our world over the next several decades.In conclusion, I've come to believe that the ingredients for the next Pantheons are all around us, just waiting for visionary people with the broad knowledge, multidisciplinary skills, and intense passion to harness them to make their dreams a reality. But these people don't spontaneously pop into existence. They need to be nurtured and encouraged from when they're little kids. We need to love them and help them discover their passions. We need to encourage them to work hard and help them understand that failure is a necessary ingredient for success, as is perseverance. We need to help them to find their own role models, and give them the confidence to believe in themselves and to believe that anything is possible, and just as my grandpa did when he took me shopping for surplus, and just as my parents did when they took me to science museums, we need to encourage them to find their own path, even if it's very different from our own.But a cautionary note: We also need to periodically pry them away from their modern miracles, the computers, phones, tablets, game machines and TVs, take them out into the sunlight so they can experience both the natural and design wonders of our world, our planet and our civilization. If we don't, they won't understand what these precious things are that someday they will be resopnsible for protecting and improving. We also need them to understand something that doesn't seem adequately appreciated in our increasingly tech-dependent world, that art and design are not luxuries, nor somehow incompatible with science and engineering. They are in fact essential to what makes us special.Someday, if you get the chance, perhaps you can take your kids to the actual Pantheon, as we will our daughter Kira, to experience firsthand the power of that astonishing design, which on one otherwise unremarkable day in Rome, reached 2,000 years into the future to set the course for my life.Thank you.(Applause)
subtitle:
WEBVTT
X-TIMESTAMP-MAP=MPEGTS:900000,LOCAL:00:00:00.000

00:00:13.020 --> 00:00:15.285
Good morning.

00:00:15.285 --> 00:00:17.072
When I was a little boy,

00:00:17.072 --> 00:00:20.149
I had an experience that changed my life,

00:00:20.149 --> 00:00:23.057
and is in fact why I'm here today.

00:00:23.057 --> 00:00:24.998
That one moment

00:00:24.998 --> 00:00:27.260
profoundly affected how I think about

00:00:27.260 --> 00:00:30.481
art, design and engineering.

00:00:30.481 --> 00:00:33.238
As background, I was fortunate enough to grow up

00:00:33.238 --> 00:00:36.951
in a family of loving and talented artists

00:00:36.951 --> 00:00:39.515
in one of the world's great cities.

00:00:39.515 --> 00:00:43.392
My dad, John Ferren, who died when I was 15,

00:00:43.392 --> 00:00:46.922
was an artist by both passion and profession,

00:00:46.922 --> 00:00:49.182
as is my mom, Rae.

00:00:49.182 --> 00:00:50.987
He was one of the New York School

00:00:50.987 --> 00:00:52.748
abstract expressionists who,

00:00:52.748 --> 00:00:55.260
together with his contemporaries,

00:00:55.260 --> 00:00:58.158
invented American modern art,

00:00:58.158 --> 00:01:01.343
and contributed to moving the American zeitgeist

00:01:01.343 --> 00:01:05.886
towards modernism in the 20th century.

00:01:05.886 --> 00:01:08.807
Isn't it remarkable that, after thousands of years

00:01:08.807 --> 00:01:12.448
of people doing mostly representational art,

00:01:12.448 --> 00:01:14.481
that modern art, comparatively speaking,

00:01:14.481 --> 00:01:16.821
is about 15 minutes old,

00:01:16.821 --> 00:01:18.719
yet now pervasive.

00:01:18.719 --> 00:01:20.663
As with many other important innovations,

00:01:20.663 --> 00:01:24.283
those radical ideas required no new technology,

00:01:24.283 --> 00:01:27.176
just fresh thinking and a willingness to experiment,

00:01:27.176 --> 00:01:31.344
plus resiliency in the face of near-universal criticism

00:01:31.344 --> 00:01:32.798
and rejection.

00:01:32.798 --> 00:01:35.315
In our home, art was everywhere.

00:01:35.315 --> 00:01:36.886
It was like oxygen,

00:01:36.886 --> 00:01:40.048
around us and necessary for life.

00:01:40.048 --> 00:01:41.907
As I watched him paint,

00:01:41.907 --> 00:01:44.214
Dad taught me that art

00:01:44.214 --> 00:01:46.423
was not about being decorative,

00:01:46.423 --> 00:01:49.537
but was a different way of communicating ideas,

00:01:49.537 --> 00:01:51.574
and in fact one that could bridge the worlds

00:01:51.574 --> 00:01:54.502
of knowledge and insight.

00:01:54.502 --> 00:01:56.642
Given this rich artistic environment,

00:01:56.642 --> 00:01:58.257
you'd assume that I would have been compelled

00:01:58.257 --> 00:02:00.366
to go into the family business,

00:02:00.366 --> 00:02:02.982
but no.

00:02:02.982 --> 00:02:04.769
I followed the path of most kids

00:02:04.769 --> 00:02:06.119
who are genetically programmed

00:02:06.119 --> 00:02:08.318
to make their parents crazy.

00:02:08.318 --> 00:02:10.941
I had no interest in becoming an artist,

00:02:10.941 --> 00:02:12.501
certainly not a painter.

00:02:12.501 --> 00:02:15.800
What I did love was electronics and machines --

00:02:15.800 --> 00:02:17.420
taking them apart, building new ones,

00:02:17.420 --> 00:02:19.307
and making them work.

00:02:19.307 --> 00:02:23.209
Fortunately, my family also had engineers in it,

00:02:23.209 --> 00:02:24.417
and with my parents,

00:02:24.417 --> 00:02:27.045
these were my first role models.

00:02:27.045 --> 00:02:28.402
What they all had in common

00:02:28.402 --> 00:02:31.110
was they worked very, very hard.

00:02:31.110 --> 00:02:33.480
My grandpa owned and operated a sheet metal

00:02:33.480 --> 00:02:36.180
kitchen cabinet factory in Brooklyn.

00:02:36.180 --> 00:02:39.604
On weekends, we would go
together to Cortlandt Street,

00:02:39.604 --> 00:02:42.279
which was New York City's radio row.

00:02:42.279 --> 00:02:45.082
There we would explore massive piles

00:02:45.082 --> 00:02:46.303
of surplus electronics,

00:02:46.303 --> 00:02:48.605
and for a few bucks bring home treasures

00:02:48.605 --> 00:02:50.037
like Norden bombsights

00:02:50.037 --> 00:02:54.548
and parts from the first IBM tube-based computers.

00:02:54.548 --> 00:02:57.614
I found these objects both useful and fascinating.

00:02:57.614 --> 00:03:00.245
I learned about engineering and how things worked,

00:03:00.245 --> 00:03:01.705
not at school

00:03:01.705 --> 00:03:03.494
but by taking apart and studying

00:03:03.494 --> 00:03:05.971
these fabulously complex devices.

00:03:05.971 --> 00:03:08.555
I did this for hours every day,

00:03:08.555 --> 00:03:11.853
apparently avoiding electrocution.

00:03:11.853 --> 00:03:13.425
Life was good.

00:03:13.425 --> 00:03:15.746
However, every summer, sadly,

00:03:15.746 --> 00:03:17.779
the machines got left behind

00:03:17.779 --> 00:03:19.983
while my parents and I traveled overseas

00:03:19.983 --> 00:03:23.623
to experience history, art and design.

00:03:23.623 --> 00:03:26.017
We visited the great museums and historic buildings

00:03:26.017 --> 00:03:27.877
of both Europe and the Middle East,

00:03:27.877 --> 00:03:30.137
but to encourage my growing interest

00:03:30.137 --> 00:03:31.952
in science and technology,

00:03:31.952 --> 00:03:34.236
they would simply drop me off in places

00:03:34.236 --> 00:03:36.676
like the London Science Museum,

00:03:36.676 --> 00:03:40.394
where I would wander endlessly for hours by myself

00:03:40.394 --> 00:03:44.370
studying the history of science and technology.

00:03:44.370 --> 00:03:47.634
Then, when I was about nine years old,

00:03:47.634 --> 00:03:49.502
we went to Rome.

00:03:49.502 --> 00:03:51.863
On one particularly hot summer day,

00:03:51.863 --> 00:03:54.742
we visited a drum-shaped
building that from the outside

00:03:54.742 --> 00:03:56.986
was not particularly interesting.

00:03:56.986 --> 00:03:59.311
My dad said it was called the Pantheon,

00:03:59.311 --> 00:04:01.779
a temple for all of the gods.

00:04:01.779 --> 00:04:04.053
It didn't look all that special from the outside,

00:04:04.053 --> 00:04:06.492
as I said, but when we walked inside,

00:04:06.492 --> 00:04:09.805
I was immediately struck by three things:

00:04:09.805 --> 00:04:13.035
First of all, it was pleasantly cool

00:04:13.035 --> 00:04:15.113
despite the oppressive heat outside.

00:04:15.113 --> 00:04:17.827
It was very dark, the only source of light

00:04:17.827 --> 00:04:20.300
being an big open hole in the roof.

00:04:20.300 --> 00:04:22.533
Dad explained that this wasn't a big open hole,

00:04:22.533 --> 00:04:24.347
but it was called the oculus,

00:04:24.347 --> 00:04:26.723
an eye to the heavens.

00:04:26.723 --> 00:04:28.868
And there was something about this place,

00:04:28.868 --> 00:04:31.871
I didn't know why, that just felt special.

00:04:31.871 --> 00:04:33.869
As we walked to the center of the room,

00:04:33.869 --> 00:04:36.690
I looked up at the heavens through the oculus.

00:04:36.690 --> 00:04:38.987
This was the first church that I'd been to

00:04:38.987 --> 00:04:41.190
that provided an unrestricted view

00:04:41.190 --> 00:04:44.348
between God and man.

00:04:44.348 --> 00:04:47.778
But I wondered, what about when it rained?

00:04:47.778 --> 00:04:49.635
Dad may have called this an oculus,

00:04:49.635 --> 00:04:52.722
but it was, in fact, a big hole in the roof.

00:04:52.722 --> 00:04:54.551
I looked down and saw floor drains

00:04:54.551 --> 00:04:57.136
had been cut into the stone floor.

00:04:57.136 --> 00:04:59.595
As I became more accustomed to the dark,

00:04:59.595 --> 00:05:01.859
I was able to make out details of the floor

00:05:01.859 --> 00:05:03.589
and the surrounding walls.

00:05:03.589 --> 00:05:06.166
No big deal here, just the same statuary stuff

00:05:06.166 --> 00:05:08.082
that we'd seen all over Rome.

00:05:08.082 --> 00:05:09.754
In fact, it looked like the Appian Way

00:05:09.754 --> 00:05:11.950
marble salesman showed up

00:05:11.950 --> 00:05:14.398
with his sample book, showed it to Hadrian,

00:05:14.398 --> 00:05:17.038
and Hadrian said, "We'll take all of it."

00:05:17.038 --> 00:05:18.744
(Laughter)

00:05:18.744 --> 00:05:21.962
But the ceiling was amazing.

00:05:21.962 --> 00:05:24.798
It looked like a Buckminster Fuller geodesic dome.

00:05:24.798 --> 00:05:26.107
I'd seen these before,

00:05:26.107 --> 00:05:28.351
and Bucky was friends with my dad.

00:05:28.351 --> 00:05:31.842
It was modern, high-tech, impressive,

00:05:31.842 --> 00:05:34.279
a huge 142-foot clear span

00:05:34.279 --> 00:05:37.522
which, not coincidentally, was exactly its height.

00:05:37.522 --> 00:05:38.784
I loved this place.

00:05:38.784 --> 00:05:42.203
It was really beautiful and unlike
anything I'd ever seen before,

00:05:42.203 --> 00:05:45.773
so I asked my dad, "When was this built?"

00:05:45.773 --> 00:05:48.905
He said, "About 2,000 years ago."

00:05:48.905 --> 00:05:51.409
And I said, "No, I mean, the roof."

00:05:51.409 --> 00:05:53.368
You see, I assumed that this was a modern roof

00:05:53.368 --> 00:05:55.286
that had been put on because the original

00:05:55.286 --> 00:05:58.832
was destroyed in some long-past war.

00:05:58.832 --> 00:06:02.294
He said, "It's the original roof."

00:06:02.294 --> 00:06:04.772
That moment changed my life,

00:06:04.772 --> 00:06:07.421
and I can remember it as if it were yesterday.

00:06:07.421 --> 00:06:10.016
For the first time, I realized people were smart

00:06:10.016 --> 00:06:12.156
2,000 years ago. (Laughter)

00:06:12.156 --> 00:06:14.270
This had never crossed my mind.

00:06:14.270 --> 00:06:18.141
I mean, to me, the pyramids at Giza,

00:06:18.141 --> 00:06:20.069
we visited those the year before,

00:06:20.069 --> 00:06:22.989
and sure they're impressive, nice enough design,

00:06:22.989 --> 00:06:25.444
but look, give me an unlimited budget,

00:06:25.444 --> 00:06:29.441
20,000 to 40,000 laborers, and about 10 to 20 years

00:06:29.441 --> 00:06:33.057
to cut and drag stone blocks 
across the countryside,

00:06:33.057 --> 00:06:35.821
and I'll build you pyramids too.

00:06:35.821 --> 00:06:38.624
But no amount of brute force

00:06:38.624 --> 00:06:41.666
gets you the dome of the Pantheon,

00:06:41.666 --> 00:06:44.685
not 2,000 years ago, nor today.

00:06:44.685 --> 00:06:47.425
And incidentally, it is still the largest

00:06:47.425 --> 00:06:51.239
unreinforced concrete dome that's ever been built.

00:06:51.239 --> 00:06:54.234
To build the Pantheon took some miracles.

00:06:54.234 --> 00:06:56.666
By miracles, I mean things that are

00:06:56.666 --> 00:06:59.253
technically barely possible,

00:06:59.253 --> 00:07:02.325
very high-risk, and might not be

00:07:02.325 --> 00:07:04.909
actually accomplishable at this moment in time,

00:07:04.909 --> 00:07:09.161
certainly not by you.

00:07:09.161 --> 00:07:12.286
For example, here are some
of the Pantheon's miracles.

00:07:12.286 --> 00:07:14.979
To make it even structurally possible,

00:07:14.979 --> 00:07:17.546
they had to invent super-strong concrete,

00:07:17.546 --> 00:07:19.495
and to control weight,

00:07:19.495 --> 00:07:21.563
varied the density of the aggregate

00:07:21.563 --> 00:07:24.331
as they worked their way up the dome.

00:07:24.331 --> 00:07:26.632
For strength and lightness, the dome structure

00:07:26.632 --> 00:07:28.669
used five rings of coffers,

00:07:28.669 --> 00:07:30.276
each of diminishing size,

00:07:30.276 --> 00:07:33.012
which imparts a dramatic forced perspective

00:07:33.012 --> 00:07:35.019
to the design.

00:07:35.019 --> 00:07:36.944
It was wonderfully cool inside

00:07:36.944 --> 00:07:39.127
because of its huge thermal mass,

00:07:39.127 --> 00:07:41.212
natural convection of air rising up

00:07:41.212 --> 00:07:42.613
through the oculus,

00:07:42.613 --> 00:07:45.088
and a Venturi effect when wind blows across

00:07:45.088 --> 00:07:47.391
the top of the building.

00:07:47.391 --> 00:07:51.351
I discovered for the first time that light itself

00:07:51.351 --> 00:07:53.318
has substance.

00:07:53.318 --> 00:07:55.995
The shaft of light beaming through the oculus

00:07:55.995 --> 00:07:58.485
was both beautiful and palpable,

00:07:58.485 --> 00:08:00.742
and I realized for the first time

00:08:00.742 --> 00:08:02.643
that light could be designed.

00:08:02.643 --> 00:08:07.517
Further, that of all of the forms of design,

00:08:07.517 --> 00:08:08.893
visual design,

00:08:08.893 --> 00:08:10.724
they were all kind of irrelevant without it,

00:08:10.724 --> 00:08:14.585
because without light, you can't see any of them.

00:08:14.585 --> 00:08:17.037
I also realized that I wasn't the first person

00:08:17.037 --> 00:08:20.296
to think that this place was really special.

00:08:20.296 --> 00:08:24.673
It survived gravity, barbarians, looters, developers

00:08:24.673 --> 00:08:26.572
and the ravages of time to become

00:08:26.572 --> 00:08:27.952
what I believe is the longest

00:08:27.952 --> 00:08:30.909
continuously occupied building in history.

00:08:30.909 --> 00:08:33.125
Largely because of that visit,

00:08:33.125 --> 00:08:34.662
I came to understand that,

00:08:34.662 --> 00:08:37.301
contrary to what I was being told in school,

00:08:37.301 --> 00:08:39.330
the worlds of art and design

00:08:39.330 --> 00:08:41.346
were not, in fact, incompatible

00:08:41.346 --> 00:08:43.022
with science and engineering.

00:08:43.022 --> 00:08:45.115
I realized, when combined,

00:08:45.115 --> 00:08:47.878
you could create things that were amazing

00:08:47.878 --> 00:08:50.724
that couldn't be done in either domain alone.

00:08:50.724 --> 00:08:53.157
But in school, with few exceptions,

00:08:53.157 --> 00:08:55.077
they were treated as separate worlds,

00:08:55.077 --> 00:08:57.220
and they still are.

00:08:57.220 --> 00:08:59.916
My teachers told me that I had to get serious

00:08:59.916 --> 00:09:02.089
and focus on one or the other.

00:09:02.089 --> 00:09:05.184
However, urging me to specialize

00:09:05.184 --> 00:09:08.494
only caused me to really 
appreciate those polymaths

00:09:08.494 --> 00:09:12.644
like Michelangelo, Leonardo da Vinci,

00:09:12.644 --> 00:09:14.069
Benjamin Franklin,

00:09:14.069 --> 00:09:16.779
people who did exactly the opposite.

00:09:16.779 --> 00:09:18.968
And this led me to embrace

00:09:18.968 --> 00:09:21.938
and want to be in both worlds.

00:09:21.938 --> 00:09:27.766
So then how do these projects of unprecedented creative vision and technical complexity

00:09:27.766 --> 00:09:30.260
like the Pantheon actually happen?

00:09:30.260 --> 00:09:34.188
Someone themselves, perhaps Hadrian,

00:09:34.188 --> 00:09:37.379
needed a brilliant creative vision.

00:09:37.379 --> 00:09:40.172
They also needed the storytelling
and leadership skills

00:09:40.172 --> 00:09:42.950
necessary to fund and execute it,

00:09:42.950 --> 00:09:45.812
and a mastery of science and technology

00:09:45.812 --> 00:09:47.895
with the ability and knowhow

00:09:47.895 --> 00:09:51.941
to push existing innovations even farther.

00:09:51.941 --> 00:09:55.861
It is my belief that to create
these rare game changers

00:09:55.861 --> 00:09:59.991
requires you to pull off at least five miracles.

00:09:59.991 --> 00:10:02.684
The problem is, no matter how talented,

00:10:02.684 --> 00:10:04.416
rich or smart you are,

00:10:04.416 --> 00:10:07.442
you only get one to one and a half miracles.

00:10:07.442 --> 00:10:09.224
That's it. That's the quota.

00:10:09.224 --> 00:10:11.837
Then you run out of time, money, enthusiasm,

00:10:11.837 --> 00:10:13.216
whatever.

00:10:13.216 --> 00:10:15.493
Remember, most people can't even imagine

00:10:15.493 --> 00:10:17.400
one of these technical miracles,

00:10:17.400 --> 00:10:20.509
and you need at least five to make a Pantheon.

00:10:20.509 --> 00:10:23.010
In my experience, these rare visionaries

00:10:23.010 --> 00:10:24.847
who can think across the worlds of art,

00:10:24.847 --> 00:10:26.674
design and engineering

00:10:26.674 --> 00:10:28.876
have the ability to notice

00:10:28.876 --> 00:10:31.593
when others have provided enough of the miracles

00:10:31.593 --> 00:10:34.149
to bring the goal within reach.

00:10:34.149 --> 00:10:36.786
Driven by the clarity of their vision,

00:10:36.786 --> 00:10:39.096
they summon the courage and determination

00:10:39.096 --> 00:10:41.193
to deliver the remaining miracles

00:10:41.193 --> 00:10:44.743
and they often take what other people think to be

00:10:44.743 --> 00:10:46.789
insurmountable obstacles

00:10:46.789 --> 00:10:48.574
and turn them into features.

00:10:48.574 --> 00:10:51.501
Take the oculus of the Pantheon.

00:10:51.501 --> 00:10:53.399
By insisting that it be in the design,

00:10:53.399 --> 00:10:56.272
it meant you couldn't use much
of the structural technology

00:10:56.272 --> 00:10:59.246
that had been developed for Roman arches.

00:10:59.246 --> 00:11:02.144
However, by instead embracing it

00:11:02.144 --> 00:11:04.732
and rethinking weight and stress distribution,

00:11:04.732 --> 00:11:07.214
they came up with a design that only works

00:11:07.214 --> 00:11:09.118
if there's a big hole in the roof.

00:11:09.118 --> 00:11:12.125
That done, you now get the aesthetic

00:11:12.125 --> 00:11:16.506
and design benefits of light, cooling

00:11:16.506 --> 00:11:19.806
and that critical direct connection with the heavens.

00:11:19.806 --> 00:11:21.850
Not bad.

00:11:21.850 --> 00:11:23.911
These people not only believed

00:11:23.911 --> 00:11:25.967
that the impossible can be done,

00:11:25.967 --> 00:11:28.793
but that it must be done.

00:11:28.793 --> 00:11:30.894
Enough ancient history.

00:11:30.894 --> 00:11:34.027
What are some recent examples of innovations

00:11:34.027 --> 00:11:35.906
that combine creative design

00:11:35.906 --> 00:11:39.149
and technological advances in a way so profound

00:11:39.149 --> 00:11:40.478
that they will be remembered

00:11:40.478 --> 00:11:42.311
a thousand years from now?

00:11:42.311 --> 00:11:45.407
Well, putting a man on the moon was a good one,

00:11:45.407 --> 00:11:48.424
and returning him safely to Earth wasn't bad either.

00:11:48.424 --> 00:11:50.916
Talk about one giant leap:

00:11:50.916 --> 00:11:53.364
It's hard to imagine a more profound moment

00:11:53.364 --> 00:11:54.676
in human history

00:11:54.676 --> 00:11:56.849
than when we first left our world

00:11:56.849 --> 00:11:58.740
to set foot on another.

00:11:58.740 --> 00:12:00.961
So what came after the moon?

00:12:00.961 --> 00:12:03.769
One is tempted to say that today's pantheon

00:12:03.769 --> 00:12:05.430
is the Internet,

00:12:05.430 --> 00:12:07.899
but I actually think that's quite wrong,

00:12:07.899 --> 00:12:10.754
or at least it's only part of the story.

00:12:10.754 --> 00:12:13.270
The Internet isn't a Pantheon.

00:12:13.270 --> 00:12:15.861
It's more like the invention of concrete:

00:12:15.861 --> 00:12:18.436
important, absolutely necessary

00:12:18.436 --> 00:12:19.876
to build the Pantheon,

00:12:19.876 --> 00:12:21.232
and enduring,

00:12:21.232 --> 00:12:24.423
but entirely insufficient by itself.

00:12:24.423 --> 00:12:27.355
However, just as the technology of concrete

00:12:27.355 --> 00:12:30.942
was critical in realization of the Pantheon,

00:12:30.942 --> 00:12:34.157
new designers will use the
technologies of the Internet

00:12:34.157 --> 00:12:37.355
to create novel concepts that will endure.

00:12:37.355 --> 00:12:39.413
The smartphone is a perfect example.

00:12:39.413 --> 00:12:41.158
Soon the majority of people on the planet

00:12:41.158 --> 00:12:42.492
will have one,

00:12:42.492 --> 00:12:44.893
and the idea of connecting everyone

00:12:44.893 --> 00:12:48.143
to both knowledge and each other will endure.

00:12:48.143 --> 00:12:49.451
So what's next?

00:12:49.451 --> 00:12:52.857
What imminent advance will be
the equivalent of the Pantheon?

00:12:52.857 --> 00:12:54.292
Thinking about this,

00:12:54.292 --> 00:12:56.839
I rejected many very plausible

00:12:56.839 --> 00:12:58.735
and dramatic breakthroughs to come,

00:12:58.735 --> 00:13:00.752
such as curing cancer.

00:13:00.752 --> 00:13:04.090
Why? Because Pantheons are anchored

00:13:04.090 --> 00:13:07.025
in designed physical objects,

00:13:07.025 --> 00:13:09.347
ones that inspire by simply seeing

00:13:09.347 --> 00:13:10.767
and experiencing them,

00:13:10.767 --> 00:13:13.649
and will continue to do so indefinitely.

00:13:13.649 --> 00:13:18.222
It is a different kind of language, like art.

00:13:18.222 --> 00:13:20.994
These other vital contributions that extend life

00:13:20.994 --> 00:13:23.687
and relieve suffering are, of course, critical,

00:13:23.687 --> 00:13:25.374
and fantastic,

00:13:25.374 --> 00:13:27.167
but they're part of the continuum of

00:13:27.167 --> 00:13:29.679
our overall knowledge and technology,

00:13:29.679 --> 00:13:32.203
like the Internet.

00:13:32.203 --> 00:13:34.547
So what is next?

00:13:34.547 --> 00:13:36.266
Perhaps counterintuitively,

00:13:36.266 --> 00:13:38.578
I'm guessing it's a visionary idea

00:13:38.578 --> 00:13:40.432
from the late 1930s

00:13:40.432 --> 00:13:43.592
that's been revived every decade since:

00:13:43.592 --> 00:13:45.606
autonomous vehicles.

00:13:45.606 --> 00:13:47.344
Now you're thinking, give me a break.

00:13:47.344 --> 00:13:50.862
How can a fancy version of cruise control

00:13:50.862 --> 00:13:52.562
be profound?

00:13:52.562 --> 00:13:54.686
Look, much of our world

00:13:54.686 --> 00:13:58.169
has been designed around 
roads and transportation.

00:13:58.169 --> 00:14:00.044
These were as essential to the success

00:14:00.044 --> 00:14:01.542
of the Roman Empire

00:14:01.542 --> 00:14:03.527
as the interstate highway system

00:14:03.527 --> 00:14:05.321
to the prosperity and development

00:14:05.321 --> 00:14:07.531
of the United States.

00:14:07.531 --> 00:14:10.565
Today, these roads that interconnect our world

00:14:10.565 --> 00:14:12.663
are dominated by cars and trucks

00:14:12.663 --> 00:14:14.531
that have remained largely unchanged

00:14:14.531 --> 00:14:17.102
for 100 years.

00:14:17.102 --> 00:14:20.361
Although perhaps not obvious today,

00:14:20.361 --> 00:14:24.946
autonomous vehicles will be the key technology

00:14:24.946 --> 00:14:28.044
that enables us to redesign our cities

00:14:28.044 --> 00:14:30.263
and, by extension, civilization.

00:14:30.263 --> 00:14:31.865
Here's why:

00:14:31.865 --> 00:14:33.618
Once they become ubiquitous,

00:14:33.618 --> 00:14:36.155
each year, these vehicles will save

00:14:36.155 --> 00:14:39.263
tens of thousands of lives in the United States alone

00:14:39.263 --> 00:14:42.390
and a million globally.

00:14:42.390 --> 00:14:45.289
Automotive energy consumption and air pollution

00:14:45.289 --> 00:14:47.662
will be cut dramatically.

00:14:47.662 --> 00:14:49.067
Much of the road congestion

00:14:49.067 --> 00:14:52.877
in and out of our cities will disappear.

00:14:52.877 --> 00:14:55.564
They will enable compelling new concepts

00:14:55.564 --> 00:14:58.033
in how we design cities, work,

00:14:58.033 --> 00:14:59.970
and the way we live.

00:14:59.970 --> 00:15:02.516
We will get where we're going faster

00:15:02.516 --> 00:15:05.514
and society will recapture vast amounts

00:15:05.514 --> 00:15:06.805
of lost productivity

00:15:06.805 --> 00:15:10.446
now spent sitting in traffic basically polluting.

00:15:10.446 --> 00:15:13.719
But why now? Why do we think this is ready?

00:15:13.719 --> 00:15:15.913
Because over the last 30 years,

00:15:15.913 --> 00:15:17.961
people from outside the automotive industry

00:15:17.961 --> 00:15:20.069
have spent countless billions

00:15:20.069 --> 00:15:21.804
creating the needed miracles,

00:15:21.804 --> 00:15:24.676
but for entirely different purposes.

00:15:24.676 --> 00:15:27.304
It took folks like DARPA, universities,

00:15:27.304 --> 00:15:30.468
and companies completely
outside of the automotive industry

00:15:30.468 --> 00:15:32.769
to notice that if you were clever about it,

00:15:32.769 --> 00:15:35.299
autonomy could be done now.

00:15:35.299 --> 00:15:38.682
So what are the five miracles
needed for autonomous vehicles?

00:15:38.682 --> 00:15:40.325
One, you need to know

00:15:40.325 --> 00:15:43.059
where you are and exactly what time it is.

00:15:43.059 --> 00:15:45.467
This was solved neatly by the GPS system,

00:15:45.467 --> 00:15:46.779
Global Positioning System,

00:15:46.779 --> 00:15:49.445
that the U.S. Government put in place.

00:15:49.445 --> 00:15:51.968
You need to know where all the roads are,

00:15:51.968 --> 00:15:54.871
what the rules are, and where you're going.

00:15:54.871 --> 00:15:57.454
The various needs of personal navigation systems,

00:15:57.454 --> 00:15:59.209
in-car navigation systems,

00:15:59.209 --> 00:16:02.242
and web-based maps address this.

00:16:02.242 --> 00:16:04.869
You must have near-continuous communication

00:16:04.869 --> 00:16:06.762
with high-performance computing networks

00:16:06.762 --> 00:16:08.432
and with others nearby

00:16:08.432 --> 00:16:11.747
to understand their intent.

00:16:11.747 --> 00:16:14.855
The wireless technologies
developed for mobile devices,

00:16:14.855 --> 00:16:16.648
with some minor modifications,

00:16:16.648 --> 00:16:19.607
are completely suitable to solve this.

00:16:19.607 --> 00:16:22.097
You'll probably want some restricted roadways

00:16:22.097 --> 00:16:23.287
to get started

00:16:23.287 --> 00:16:25.765
that both society and its lawyers

00:16:25.765 --> 00:16:27.637
agree are safe to use for this.

00:16:27.637 --> 00:16:29.486
This will start with the HOV lanes

00:16:29.486 --> 00:16:31.619
and move from there.

00:16:31.619 --> 00:16:34.170
But finally, you need to recognize

00:16:34.170 --> 00:16:36.273
people, signs and objects.

00:16:36.273 --> 00:16:39.327
Machine vision, special sensors,
and high-performance computing

00:16:39.327 --> 00:16:40.899
can do a lot of this,

00:16:40.899 --> 00:16:43.457
but it turns out a lot is not good enough

00:16:43.457 --> 00:16:45.398
when your family is on board.

00:16:45.398 --> 00:16:48.919
Occasionally, humans will 
need to do sense-making.

00:16:48.919 --> 00:16:52.531
For this, you might actually have to wake up

00:16:52.531 --> 00:16:54.627
your passenger and ask them what the hell

00:16:54.627 --> 00:16:57.429
that big lump is in the middle of the road.

00:16:57.445 --> 00:16:59.789
Not so bad, and it will give us a sense of purpose

00:16:59.789 --> 00:17:01.642
in this new world.

00:17:01.642 --> 00:17:04.382
Besides, once the first drivers explain

00:17:04.382 --> 00:17:05.708
to their confused car

00:17:05.708 --> 00:17:08.374
that the giant chicken at the fork in the road

00:17:08.374 --> 00:17:09.917
is actually a restaurant,

00:17:09.917 --> 00:17:12.221
and it's okay to keep driving,

00:17:12.221 --> 00:17:15.641
every other car on the surface of the Earth

00:17:15.641 --> 00:17:18.563
will know that from that point on.

00:17:18.563 --> 00:17:20.826
Five miracles, mostly delivered,

00:17:20.826 --> 00:17:22.704
and now you just need a clear vision

00:17:22.704 --> 00:17:25.541
of a better world filled with autonomous vehicles

00:17:25.541 --> 00:17:29.154
with seductively beautiful 
and new functional designs

00:17:29.154 --> 00:17:31.608
plus a lot of money and hard work

00:17:31.608 --> 00:17:33.204
to bring it home.

00:17:33.204 --> 00:17:36.226
The beginning is now only a handful of years away,

00:17:36.226 --> 00:17:38.094
and I predict that autonomous vehicles

00:17:38.094 --> 00:17:40.165
will permanently change our world

00:17:40.165 --> 00:17:44.349
over the next several decades.

00:17:44.349 --> 00:17:47.001
In conclusion, I've come to believe

00:17:47.001 --> 00:17:49.239
that the ingredients for the next Pantheons

00:17:49.239 --> 00:17:50.626
are all around us,

00:17:50.626 --> 00:17:52.813
just waiting for visionary people

00:17:52.813 --> 00:17:54.547
with the broad knowledge,

00:17:54.547 --> 00:17:56.157
multidisciplinary skills,

00:17:56.157 --> 00:17:58.025
and intense passion

00:17:58.025 --> 00:18:03.111
to harness them to make their dreams a reality.

00:18:03.111 --> 00:18:05.607
But these people don't spontaneously

00:18:05.607 --> 00:18:06.946
pop into existence.

00:18:06.946 --> 00:18:08.785
They need to be nurtured and encouraged

00:18:08.785 --> 00:18:10.564
from when they're little kids.

00:18:10.564 --> 00:18:12.424
We need to love them and help them

00:18:12.424 --> 00:18:14.143
discover their passions.

00:18:14.143 --> 00:18:16.357
We need to encourage them to work hard

00:18:16.357 --> 00:18:18.794
and help them understand that failure

00:18:18.794 --> 00:18:21.665
is a necessary ingredient for success,

00:18:21.665 --> 00:18:23.846
as is perseverance.

00:18:23.846 --> 00:18:26.944
We need to help them to find their own role models,

00:18:26.944 --> 00:18:29.616
and give them the confidence
to believe in themselves

00:18:29.616 --> 00:18:32.393
and to believe that anything is possible,

00:18:32.393 --> 00:18:35.902
and just as my grandpa did when
he took me shopping for surplus,

00:18:35.902 --> 00:18:37.685
and just as my parents did

00:18:37.685 --> 00:18:39.707
when they took me to science museums,

00:18:39.707 --> 00:18:42.988
we need to encourage them to find their own path,

00:18:42.988 --> 00:18:45.645
even if it's very different from our own.

00:18:45.645 --> 00:18:47.053
But a cautionary note:

00:18:47.053 --> 00:18:49.487
We also need to periodically pry them away

00:18:49.487 --> 00:18:50.956
from their modern miracles,

00:18:50.956 --> 00:18:52.927
the computers, phones, tablets,

00:18:52.927 --> 00:18:54.521
game machines and TVs,

00:18:54.521 --> 00:18:56.765
take them out into the sunlight

00:18:56.765 --> 00:18:58.894
so they can experience both the natural

00:18:58.894 --> 00:19:01.791
and design wonders of our world,

00:19:01.791 --> 00:19:04.033
our planet and our civilization.

00:19:04.033 --> 00:19:06.960
If we don't, they won't understand

00:19:06.960 --> 00:19:08.842
what these precious things are

00:19:08.842 --> 00:19:11.437
that someday they will be resopnsible

00:19:11.437 --> 00:19:13.719
for protecting and improving.

00:19:13.719 --> 00:19:15.362
We also need them to understand

00:19:15.362 --> 00:19:18.391
something that doesn't seem adequately appreciated

00:19:18.391 --> 00:19:20.854
in our increasingly tech-dependent world,

00:19:20.854 --> 00:19:22.537
that art and design

00:19:22.537 --> 00:19:24.450
are not luxuries,

00:19:24.450 --> 00:19:26.276
nor somehow incompatible

00:19:26.276 --> 00:19:28.145
with science and engineering.

00:19:28.145 --> 00:19:33.720
They are in fact essential to what makes us special.

00:19:33.720 --> 00:19:36.235
Someday, if you get the chance,

00:19:36.235 --> 00:19:37.772
perhaps you can take your kids

00:19:37.772 --> 00:19:39.543
to the actual Pantheon,

00:19:39.543 --> 00:19:42.203
as we will our daughter Kira,

00:19:42.203 --> 00:19:44.281
to experience firsthand

00:19:44.281 --> 00:19:48.538
the power of that astonishing design,

00:19:48.538 --> 00:19:52.282
which on one otherwise unremarkable day in Rome,

00:19:52.282 --> 00:19:55.309
reached 2,000 years into the future

00:19:55.309 --> 00:19:57.967
to set the course for my life.

00:19:57.967 --> 00:20:00.098
Thank you.

00:20:00.098 --> 00:20:04.406
(Applause)

title: Zombie roaches and other parasite tales
transcript: A herd of wildebeests, a shoal of fish, a flock of birds. Many animals gather in large groups that are among the most wonderful spectacles in the natural world. But why do these groups form? The common answers include things like seeking safety in numbers or hunting in packs or gathering to mate or breed, and all of these explanations, while often true, make a huge assumption about animal behavior, that the animals are in control of their own actions, that they are in charge of their bodies. And that is often not the case.This is Artemia, a brine shrimp. You probably know it better as a sea monkey. It's small, and it typically lives alone, but it can gather in these large red swarms that span for meters, and these form because of a parasite. These shrimp are infected with a tapeworm. A tapeworm is effectively a long, living gut with genitals at one end and a hooked mouth at the other. As a freelance journalist, I sympathize. (Laughter) The tapeworm drains nutrients from Artemia's body, but it also does other things. It castrates them, it changes their color from transparent to bright red, it makes them live longer, and as biologist Nicolas Rode has found, it makes them swim in groups. Why? Because the tapeworm, like many other parasites, has a complicated life cycle involving many different hosts. The shrimp are just one step on its journey. Its ultimate destination is this, the greater flamingo. Only in a flamingo can the tapeworm reproduce, so to get there, it manipulates its shrimp hosts into forming these conspicuous colored swarms that are easier for a flamingo to spot and to devour, and that is the secret of the Artemia swarm. They aren't sociable through their own volition, but because they are being controlled. It's not safety in numbers. It's actually the exact opposite. The tapeworm hijacks their brains and their bodies, turning them into vehicles for getting itself into a flamingo.And here is another example of a parasitic manipulation. This is a suicidal cricket. This cricket swallowed the  larvae of a Gordian worm, or horsehair worm. The worm grew to adult size within it, but it needs to get into water in order to mate, and it does that by releasing proteins that addle the cricket's brain, causing it to behave erratically. When the cricket nears a body of water, such as this swimming pool, it jumps in and drowns, and the worm wriggles out of its suicidal corpse. Crickets are really roomy. Who knew?The tapeworm and the Gordian worm are not alone. They are part of an entire cavalcade of mind-controlling parasites, of fungi, viruses, and worms and insects and more that all specialize in subverting and overriding the wills of their hosts. Now, I first learned about this way of life through David Attenborough's "Trials of Life" about 20 years ago, and then later through a wonderful book called "Parasite Rex" by my friend Carl Zimmer. And I've been writing about these creatures ever since. Few topics in biology enthrall me more. It's like the parasites have subverted my own brain. Because after all, they are always compelling and they are delightfully macabre. When you write about parasites, your lexicon swells with phrases like "devoured alive" and "bursts out of its body." (Laughter)But there's more to it than that. I'm a writer, and fellow writers in the audience will know that we love stories. Parasites invite us to resist the allure of obvious stories. Their world is one of plot twists and unexpected explanations. Why, for example, does this caterpillar start violently thrashing about when another insect gets close to it and those white cocoons that it seems to be standing guard over? Is it maybe protecting its siblings? No. This caterpillar was attacked by a parasitic wasp which laid eggs inside it. The eggs hatched and the young wasps devoured the caterpillar alive before bursting out of its body. See what I mean? Now, the caterpillar didn't die. Some of the wasps seemed to stay behind and controlled it into defending their siblings which are metamorphosing into adults within those cocoons. This caterpillar is a head-banging  zombie bodyguard defending the offspring of the creature that killed it.(Applause)We have a lot to get through.  I only have 13 minutes. (Laughter)Now, some of you are probably just desperately clawing for some solace in the idea that these things are oddities of the natural world, that they are outliers, and that point of view is understandable, because by their nature, parasites are quite small and they spend a lot of their time inside the bodies of other things. They're easy to overlook, but that doesn't mean that they aren't important. A few years back, a man called Kevin Lafferty took a group of scientists into three Californian estuaries and they pretty much weighed and dissected and recorded everything they could find, and what they found were parasites in extreme abundance. Especially common were trematodes, tiny worms that specialize in castrating their hosts like this unfortunate snail. Now, a single trematode is tiny, microscopic, but collectively they weighed as much as all the fish in the estuaries and three to nine times more than all the birds. And remember the Gordian worm that I showed you, the cricket thing? One Japanese scientist called Takuya Sato found that in one stream, these things drive so many crickets and grasshoppers into the water that the drowned insects make up some 60 percent of the diet of local trout. Manipulation is not an oddity. It is a critical and common part of the world around us, and scientists have now found hundreds of examples of such manipulators, and more excitingly, they're starting to understand exactly how these creatures control their hosts.And this is one of my favorite examples. This is Ampulex compressa, the emerald cockroach wasp, and it is a truth universally acknowledged that an emerald cockroach wasp in possession of some fertilized eggs must be in want of a cockroach. When she finds one, she stabs it with a stinger that is also a sense organ. This discovery came out three weeks ago. She stabs it with a stinger that is a sense organ equipped with small sensory bumps that allow her to feel the distinctive texture of a roach's brain. So like a person blindly rooting about in a bag, she finds the brain, and she injects it with venom into two very specific clusters of neurons. Israeli scientists Frederic Libersat and Ram Gal found that the venom is a very specific chemical weapon. It doesn't kill the roach, nor does it sedate it. The roach could walk away or fly or run if it chose to, but it doesn't choose to, because the venom nixes its motivation to walk, and only that. The wasp basically un-checks the escape-from-danger box in the roach's operating system, allowing her to lead her helpless victim back to her lair by its antennae like a person walking a dog. And once there, she lays an egg on it, egg hatches, devoured alive, bursts out of body, yadda yadda yadda, you know the drill. (Laughter) (Applause)Now I would argue that, once stung, the cockroach isn't a roach anymore. It's more of an extension of the wasp, just like the cricket was an extension of the Gordian worm. These hosts won't get to survive or reproduce. They have as much control over their own fates as my car. Once the parasites get in, the hosts don't get a say.Now humans, of course, are no stranger to manipulation. We take drugs to shift the chemistries of our brains and to change our moods, and what are arguments or advertising or big ideas if not an attempt to influence someone else's mind? But our attempts at doing this are crude and blundering compared to the fine-grained specificity of the parasites. Don Draper only wishes he was as elegant and precise as the emerald cockroach wasp. Now, I think this is part of what makes parasites so sinister and so compelling. We place such a premium on our free will and our independence that the prospect of losing those qualities to forces unseen informs many of our deepest societal fears. Orwellian dystopias and shadowy cabals and mind-controlling supervillains — these are tropes that fill our darkest fiction, but in nature, they happen all the time.Which leads me to an obvious and disquieting question: Are there dark, sinister parasites that are influencing our behavior without us knowing about it, besides the NSA? If there are any — (Laughter) (Applause) I've got a red dot on my forehead now, don't I? (Laughter)If there are any, this is a good candidate for them. This is Toxoplasma gondii, or Toxo, for short, because the terrifying creature always deserves a cute nickname. Toxo infects mammals, a wide variety of mammals, but it can only sexually reproduce in a cat. And scientists like Joanne Webster have shown that if Toxo gets into a rat or a mouse, it turns the rodent into a cat-seeking missile. If the infected rat smells the delightful odor of cat piss, it runs towards the source of the smell rather than the more sensible direction of away. The cat eats the rat. Toxo gets to have sex. It's a classic tale of Eat, Prey, Love. (Laughter) (Applause)You're very charitable, generous people. Hi, Elizabeth, I loved your talk.How does the parasite control its host in this way? We don't really know. We know that Toxo releases an enzyme that makes dopamine, a substance involved in reward and motivation. We know it targets certain parts of a rodent's brain, including those involved in sexual arousal. But how those puzzle pieces fit together is not immediately clear. What is clear is that this thing is a single cell. This has no nervous system. It has no consciousness. It doesn't even have a body. But it's manipulating a mammal? We are mammals. We are more intelligent than a mere rat, to be sure, but our brains have the same basic structure, the same types of cells, the same chemicals running through them, and the same parasites. Estimates vary a lot, but some figures suggest that one in three people around the world have Toxo in their brains. Now typically, this doesn't lead to any overt illness. The parasite holds up in a dormant state for a long period of time. But there's some evidence that those people who are carriers score slightly differently on personality questionnaires than other people, that they have a slightly  higher risk of car accidents, and there's some evidence that people with schizophrenia are more likely to be infected. Now, I think this evidence is still inconclusive, and even among Toxo researchers, opinion is divided as to whether the parasite is truly influencing our behavior. But given the widespread nature of such manipulations, it would be completely implausible for humans to be the only species that weren't similarly affected.And I think that this capacity to constantly subvert our way of thinking about the world makes parasites amazing. They're constantly inviting us to look at the natural world sideways, and to ask if the behaviors we're seeing, whether they're simple and obvious or baffling and puzzling, are not the results of individuals acting through their own accord but because they are being bent to the control of something else. And while that idea may be disquieting, and while parasites' habits may be very grisly, I think that ability to surprise us makes them as wonderful and as charismatic as any panda or butterfly or dolphin.At the end of "On the Origin of Species," Charles Darwin writes about the grandeur of life, and of endless forms most beautiful and most wonderful, and I like to think he could easily have been talking about a tapeworm that makes shrimp sociable or a wasp that takes cockroaches for walks.But perhaps, that's just a parasite talking.Thank you.(Applause)
subtitle:
WEBVTT
X-TIMESTAMP-MAP=MPEGTS:900000,LOCAL:00:00:00.000

00:00:12.603 --> 00:00:15.154
A herd of wildebeests, a shoal of fish,

00:00:15.154 --> 00:00:16.783
a flock of birds.

00:00:16.783 --> 00:00:18.851
Many animals gather in large groups

00:00:18.851 --> 00:00:20.837
that are among the most wonderful spectacles

00:00:20.837 --> 00:00:22.555
in the natural world.

00:00:22.555 --> 00:00:25.279
But why do these groups form?

00:00:25.279 --> 00:00:26.916
The common answers include things like

00:00:26.916 --> 00:00:29.882
seeking safety in numbers or hunting in packs

00:00:29.882 --> 00:00:32.378
or gathering to mate or breed,

00:00:32.378 --> 00:00:34.046
and all of these explanations,

00:00:34.046 --> 00:00:35.283
while often true,

00:00:35.283 --> 00:00:38.326
make a huge assumption about animal behavior,

00:00:38.326 --> 00:00:41.503
that the animals are in control of their own actions,

00:00:41.503 --> 00:00:43.754
that they are in charge of their bodies.

00:00:43.754 --> 00:00:47.181
And that is often not the case.

00:00:47.181 --> 00:00:50.105
This is Artemia, a brine shrimp.

00:00:50.105 --> 00:00:52.869
You probably know it better as a sea monkey.

00:00:52.869 --> 00:00:54.864
It's small, and it typically lives alone,

00:00:54.864 --> 00:00:57.941
but it can gather in these large red swarms

00:00:57.941 --> 00:01:00.188
that span for meters,

00:01:00.188 --> 00:01:03.278
and these form because of a parasite.

00:01:03.278 --> 00:01:05.964
These shrimp are infected with a tapeworm.

00:01:05.964 --> 00:01:08.215
A tapeworm is effectively a long, living gut

00:01:08.215 --> 00:01:11.103
with genitals at one end and
a hooked mouth at the other.

00:01:11.103 --> 00:01:13.638
As a freelance journalist, I sympathize.

00:01:13.638 --> 00:01:15.793
(Laughter)

00:01:15.793 --> 00:01:18.701
The tapeworm drains nutrients from Artemia's body,

00:01:18.701 --> 00:01:20.778
but it also does other things.

00:01:20.778 --> 00:01:22.398
It castrates them,

00:01:22.398 --> 00:01:27.116
it changes their color from transparent to bright red,

00:01:27.116 --> 00:01:28.632
it makes them live longer,

00:01:28.632 --> 00:01:30.989
and as biologist Nicolas Rode has found,

00:01:30.989 --> 00:01:34.348
it makes them swim in groups.

00:01:34.348 --> 00:01:37.800
Why? Because the tapeworm,
like many other parasites,

00:01:37.800 --> 00:01:39.381
has a complicated life cycle

00:01:39.381 --> 00:01:41.645
involving many different hosts.

00:01:41.645 --> 00:01:44.049
The shrimp are just one step on its journey.

00:01:44.049 --> 00:01:46.661
Its ultimate destination is this,

00:01:46.661 --> 00:01:48.608
the greater flamingo.

00:01:48.608 --> 00:01:51.633
Only in a flamingo can the tapeworm reproduce,

00:01:51.633 --> 00:01:54.922
so to get there, it manipulates its shrimp hosts

00:01:54.922 --> 00:01:58.013
into forming these conspicuous colored swarms

00:01:58.013 --> 00:02:00.730
that are easier for a flamingo to spot

00:02:00.730 --> 00:02:02.289
and to devour,

00:02:02.289 --> 00:02:05.221
and that is the secret of the Artemia swarm.

00:02:05.221 --> 00:02:07.384
They aren't sociable through their own volition,

00:02:07.384 --> 00:02:09.460
but because they are being controlled.

00:02:09.460 --> 00:02:11.154
It's not safety in numbers.

00:02:11.154 --> 00:02:13.013
It's actually the exact opposite.

00:02:13.013 --> 00:02:16.054
The tapeworm hijacks their brains and their bodies,

00:02:16.054 --> 00:02:17.450
turning them into vehicles

00:02:17.450 --> 00:02:21.417
for getting itself into a flamingo.

00:02:21.417 --> 00:02:22.847
And here is another example

00:02:22.847 --> 00:02:25.373
of a parasitic manipulation.

00:02:25.373 --> 00:02:28.349
This is a suicidal cricket.

00:02:28.349 --> 00:02:31.653
This cricket swallowed the 
larvae of a Gordian worm,

00:02:31.653 --> 00:02:33.546
or horsehair worm.

00:02:33.546 --> 00:02:35.702
The worm grew to adult size within it,

00:02:35.702 --> 00:02:38.740
but it needs to get into water in order to mate,

00:02:38.740 --> 00:02:40.958
and it does that by releasing proteins

00:02:40.958 --> 00:02:43.146
that addle the cricket's brain,

00:02:43.146 --> 00:02:45.310
causing it to behave erratically.

00:02:45.310 --> 00:02:47.265
When the cricket nears a body of water,

00:02:47.265 --> 00:02:48.884
such as this swimming pool,

00:02:48.884 --> 00:02:51.141
it jumps in and drowns,

00:02:51.141 --> 00:02:52.866
and the worm wriggles out

00:02:52.866 --> 00:02:56.722
of its suicidal corpse.

00:02:56.722 --> 00:03:00.325
Crickets are really roomy. Who knew?

00:03:00.325 --> 00:03:03.540
The tapeworm and the Gordian worm are not alone.

00:03:03.540 --> 00:03:05.260
They are part of an entire cavalcade

00:03:05.260 --> 00:03:07.337
of mind-controlling parasites,

00:03:07.337 --> 00:03:11.286
of fungi, viruses, and worms and insects and more

00:03:11.286 --> 00:03:13.859
that all specialize in subverting and overriding

00:03:13.859 --> 00:03:16.068
the wills of their hosts.

00:03:16.068 --> 00:03:17.805
Now, I first learned about this way of life

00:03:17.805 --> 00:03:20.298
through David Attenborough's "Trials of Life"

00:03:20.298 --> 00:03:22.020
about 20 years ago,

00:03:22.020 --> 00:03:23.722
and then later through a wonderful book called

00:03:23.722 --> 00:03:26.396
"Parasite Rex" by my friend Carl Zimmer.

00:03:26.396 --> 00:03:28.539
And I've been writing about
these creatures ever since.

00:03:28.539 --> 00:03:31.350
Few topics in biology enthrall me more.

00:03:31.350 --> 00:03:35.056
It's like the parasites have subverted my own brain.

00:03:35.056 --> 00:03:37.667
Because after all, they are always compelling

00:03:37.667 --> 00:03:38.955
and they are delightfully macabre.

00:03:38.955 --> 00:03:40.347
When you write about parasites,

00:03:40.347 --> 00:03:42.431
your lexicon swells with phrases like

00:03:42.431 --> 00:03:45.477
"devoured alive" and "bursts out of its body."

00:03:45.477 --> 00:03:46.714
(Laughter)

00:03:46.714 --> 00:03:48.254
But there's more to it than that.

00:03:48.254 --> 00:03:50.356
I'm a writer, and fellow writers in the audience

00:03:50.356 --> 00:03:53.065
will know that we love stories.

00:03:53.065 --> 00:03:55.458
Parasites invite us to resist the allure

00:03:55.458 --> 00:03:57.308
of obvious stories.

00:03:57.308 --> 00:03:59.618
Their world is one of plot twists

00:03:59.618 --> 00:04:03.225
and unexpected explanations.

00:04:03.225 --> 00:04:04.721
Why, for example,

00:04:04.721 --> 00:04:06.899
does this caterpillar

00:04:06.899 --> 00:04:08.873
start violently thrashing about

00:04:08.873 --> 00:04:10.541
when another insect gets close to it

00:04:10.541 --> 00:04:12.798
and those white cocoons that it seems

00:04:12.798 --> 00:04:14.236
to be standing guard over?

00:04:14.236 --> 00:04:17.332
Is it maybe protecting its siblings?

00:04:17.332 --> 00:04:18.781
No.

00:04:18.781 --> 00:04:20.238
This caterpillar was attacked

00:04:20.238 --> 00:04:23.457
by a parasitic wasp which laid eggs inside it.

00:04:23.457 --> 00:04:24.891
The eggs hatched and the young wasps

00:04:24.891 --> 00:04:26.205
devoured the caterpillar alive

00:04:26.205 --> 00:04:27.876
before bursting out of its body.

00:04:27.876 --> 00:04:30.151
See what I mean?

00:04:30.151 --> 00:04:32.989
Now, the caterpillar didn't die.

00:04:32.989 --> 00:04:35.574
Some of the wasps seemed to stay behind

00:04:35.574 --> 00:04:38.911
and controlled it into defending their siblings

00:04:38.911 --> 00:04:40.545
which are metamorphosing

00:04:40.545 --> 00:04:42.565
into adults within those cocoons.

00:04:42.565 --> 00:04:46.104
This caterpillar is a head-banging 
zombie bodyguard

00:04:46.104 --> 00:04:47.405
defending the offspring

00:04:47.405 --> 00:04:49.627
of the creature that killed it.

00:04:49.627 --> 00:04:53.493
(Applause)

00:04:53.493 --> 00:04:57.788
We have a lot to get through. 
I only have 13 minutes. (Laughter)

00:04:57.788 --> 00:04:59.599
Now, some of you are probably just

00:04:59.599 --> 00:05:01.817
desperately clawing for some solace

00:05:01.817 --> 00:05:04.077
in the idea that these things are oddities

00:05:04.077 --> 00:05:06.008
of the natural world, that they are outliers,

00:05:06.008 --> 00:05:07.828
and that point of view is understandable,

00:05:07.828 --> 00:05:10.206
because by their nature, parasites are quite small

00:05:10.206 --> 00:05:11.546
and they spend a lot of their time

00:05:11.546 --> 00:05:14.500
inside the bodies of other things.

00:05:14.500 --> 00:05:16.271
They're easy to overlook,

00:05:16.271 --> 00:05:18.856
but that doesn't mean that they aren't important.

00:05:18.856 --> 00:05:21.061
A few years back, a man called Kevin Lafferty

00:05:21.061 --> 00:05:24.430
took a group of scientists
into three Californian estuaries

00:05:24.430 --> 00:05:26.178
and they pretty much weighed and dissected

00:05:26.178 --> 00:05:28.173
and recorded everything they could find,

00:05:28.173 --> 00:05:29.401
and what they found

00:05:29.401 --> 00:05:32.617
were parasites in extreme abundance.

00:05:32.617 --> 00:05:34.661
Especially common were trematodes,

00:05:34.661 --> 00:05:37.311
tiny worms that specialize in castrating their hosts

00:05:37.311 --> 00:05:39.857
like this unfortunate snail.

00:05:39.857 --> 00:05:42.746
Now, a single trematode is tiny, microscopic,

00:05:42.746 --> 00:05:44.545
but collectively they weighed as much

00:05:44.545 --> 00:05:46.731
as all the fish in the estuaries

00:05:46.731 --> 00:05:50.438
and three to nine times more than all the birds.

00:05:50.438 --> 00:05:52.432
And remember the Gordian worm that I showed you,

00:05:52.432 --> 00:05:53.820
the cricket thing?

00:05:53.820 --> 00:05:56.373
One Japanese scientist called Takuya Sato

00:05:56.373 --> 00:05:58.069
found that in one stream,

00:05:58.069 --> 00:06:00.040
these things drive so many crickets

00:06:00.040 --> 00:06:01.339
and grasshoppers into the water

00:06:01.339 --> 00:06:02.648
that the drowned insects

00:06:02.648 --> 00:06:06.952
make up some 60 percent of the diet of local trout.

00:06:06.952 --> 00:06:09.886
Manipulation is not an oddity.

00:06:09.886 --> 00:06:12.006
It is a critical and common part

00:06:12.006 --> 00:06:13.897
of the world around us,

00:06:13.897 --> 00:06:15.418
and scientists have now found

00:06:15.418 --> 00:06:17.900
hundreds of examples of such manipulators,

00:06:17.900 --> 00:06:20.337
and more excitingly, they're starting to understand

00:06:20.337 --> 00:06:24.395
exactly how these creatures control their hosts.

00:06:24.395 --> 00:06:26.919
And this is one of my favorite examples.

00:06:26.919 --> 00:06:29.376
This is Ampulex compressa,

00:06:29.376 --> 00:06:31.600
the emerald cockroach wasp,

00:06:31.600 --> 00:06:33.894
and it is a truth universally acknowledged

00:06:33.894 --> 00:06:35.537
that an emerald cockroach wasp in possession

00:06:35.537 --> 00:06:37.333
of some fertilized eggs

00:06:37.333 --> 00:06:39.799
must be in want of a cockroach.

00:06:39.799 --> 00:06:40.999
When she finds one,

00:06:40.999 --> 00:06:43.210
she stabs it with a stinger

00:06:43.210 --> 00:06:44.659
that is also a sense organ.

00:06:44.659 --> 00:06:47.330
This discovery came out three weeks ago.

00:06:47.330 --> 00:06:49.635
She stabs it with a stinger that is a sense organ

00:06:49.635 --> 00:06:51.429
equipped with small sensory bumps

00:06:51.429 --> 00:06:53.984
that allow her to feel the distinctive texture

00:06:53.984 --> 00:06:56.091
of a roach's brain.

00:06:56.091 --> 00:06:59.132
So like a person blindly rooting about in a bag,

00:06:59.132 --> 00:07:01.609
she finds the brain, and she injects it with venom

00:07:01.609 --> 00:07:05.810
into two very specific clusters of neurons.

00:07:05.810 --> 00:07:08.893
Israeli scientists Frederic Libersat and Ram Gal

00:07:08.893 --> 00:07:12.618
found that the venom is a
very specific chemical weapon.

00:07:12.618 --> 00:07:15.162
It doesn't kill the roach, nor does it sedate it.

00:07:15.162 --> 00:07:17.289
The roach could walk away

00:07:17.289 --> 00:07:20.314
or fly or run if it chose to,

00:07:20.314 --> 00:07:22.189
but it doesn't choose to,

00:07:22.189 --> 00:07:25.569
because the venom nixes its motivation to walk,

00:07:25.569 --> 00:07:26.683
and only that.

00:07:26.683 --> 00:07:30.389
The wasp basically un-checks
the escape-from-danger box

00:07:30.389 --> 00:07:32.229
in the roach's operating system,

00:07:32.229 --> 00:07:35.462
allowing her to lead her helpless victim

00:07:35.462 --> 00:07:37.573
back to her lair by its antennae

00:07:37.573 --> 00:07:40.212
like a person walking a dog.

00:07:40.212 --> 00:07:41.889
And once there, she lays an egg on it,

00:07:41.889 --> 00:07:44.165
egg hatches, devoured alive, bursts out of body,

00:07:44.165 --> 00:07:46.354
yadda yadda yadda, you know the drill.

00:07:46.354 --> 00:07:49.584
(Laughter) (Applause)

00:07:49.584 --> 00:07:52.464
Now I would argue that, once stung,

00:07:52.464 --> 00:07:54.469
the cockroach isn't a roach anymore.

00:07:54.469 --> 00:07:56.819
It's more of an extension of the wasp,

00:07:56.819 --> 00:07:59.662
just like the cricket was an
extension of the Gordian worm.

00:07:59.677 --> 00:08:02.477
These hosts won't get to survive or reproduce.

00:08:02.477 --> 00:08:04.276
They have as much control over their own fates

00:08:04.276 --> 00:08:06.060
as my car.

00:08:06.060 --> 00:08:07.560
Once the parasites get in,

00:08:07.560 --> 00:08:10.125
the hosts don't get a say.

00:08:10.125 --> 00:08:11.439
Now humans, of course,

00:08:11.439 --> 00:08:13.471
are no stranger to manipulation.

00:08:13.471 --> 00:08:15.831
We take drugs to shift the chemistries of our brains

00:08:15.831 --> 00:08:16.962
and to change our moods,

00:08:16.962 --> 00:08:20.982
and what are arguments or advertising or big ideas

00:08:20.982 --> 00:08:24.685
if not an attempt to influence someone else's mind?

00:08:24.685 --> 00:08:26.212
But our attempts at doing this

00:08:26.212 --> 00:08:27.990
are crude and blundering compared

00:08:27.990 --> 00:08:31.085
to the fine-grained specificity of the parasites.

00:08:31.085 --> 00:08:33.477
Don Draper only wishes he was as elegant

00:08:33.477 --> 00:08:38.437
and precise as the emerald cockroach wasp.

00:08:38.437 --> 00:08:42.177
Now, I think this is part of what makes parasites

00:08:42.177 --> 00:08:44.963
so sinister and so compelling.

00:08:44.963 --> 00:08:47.585
We place such a premium on our free will

00:08:47.585 --> 00:08:48.846
and our independence

00:08:48.846 --> 00:08:50.427
that the prospect of losing those qualities

00:08:50.427 --> 00:08:51.705
to forces unseen

00:08:51.705 --> 00:08:54.873
informs many of our deepest societal fears.

00:08:54.873 --> 00:08:57.326
Orwellian dystopias and shadowy cabals

00:08:57.326 --> 00:08:59.180
and mind-controlling supervillains --

00:08:59.180 --> 00:09:02.208
these are tropes that fill our darkest fiction,

00:09:02.208 --> 00:09:07.006
but in nature, they happen all the time.

00:09:07.006 --> 00:09:09.638
Which leads me to an obvious

00:09:09.638 --> 00:09:11.938
and disquieting question:

00:09:11.938 --> 00:09:13.661
Are there dark, sinister parasites

00:09:13.661 --> 00:09:15.617
that are influencing our behavior

00:09:15.617 --> 00:09:17.192
without us knowing about it,

00:09:17.192 --> 00:09:20.011
besides the NSA?

00:09:20.011 --> 00:09:21.318
If there are any —

00:09:21.318 --> 00:09:25.284
(Laughter) (Applause)

00:09:25.284 --> 00:09:27.606
I've got a red dot on my forehead now, don't I?

00:09:27.606 --> 00:09:30.133
(Laughter)

00:09:30.133 --> 00:09:33.087
If there are any, this is a good candidate for them.

00:09:33.087 --> 00:09:36.365
This is Toxoplasma gondii, or Toxo, for short,

00:09:36.365 --> 00:09:37.954
because the terrifying creature

00:09:37.954 --> 00:09:40.164
always deserves a cute nickname.

00:09:40.164 --> 00:09:42.446
Toxo infects mammals,

00:09:42.446 --> 00:09:43.924
a wide variety of mammals,

00:09:43.924 --> 00:09:47.005
but it can only sexually reproduce in a cat.

00:09:47.005 --> 00:09:49.766
And scientists like Joanne Webster have shown that

00:09:49.766 --> 00:09:51.959
if Toxo gets into a rat or a mouse,

00:09:51.959 --> 00:09:55.431
it turns the rodent into a cat-seeking missile.

00:09:55.431 --> 00:09:58.507
If the infected rat smells the delightful odor

00:09:58.507 --> 00:09:59.731
of cat piss,

00:09:59.731 --> 00:10:02.451
it runs towards the source of the smell

00:10:02.451 --> 00:10:06.370
rather than the more sensible direction of away.

00:10:06.370 --> 00:10:08.905
The cat eats the rat. Toxo gets to have sex.

00:10:08.905 --> 00:10:11.777
It's a classic tale of Eat, Prey, Love.

00:10:11.777 --> 00:10:16.445
(Laughter) (Applause)

00:10:19.470 --> 00:10:22.672
You're very charitable, generous people.

00:10:22.672 --> 00:10:25.257
Hi, Elizabeth, I loved your talk.

00:10:25.257 --> 00:10:28.625
How does the parasite control its host

00:10:28.625 --> 00:10:29.829
in this way?

00:10:29.829 --> 00:10:31.155
We don't really know.

00:10:31.155 --> 00:10:32.843
We know that Toxo releases an enzyme

00:10:32.843 --> 00:10:34.835
that makes dopamine, a substance involved

00:10:34.835 --> 00:10:36.648
in reward and motivation.

00:10:36.648 --> 00:10:39.079
We know it targets certain parts of a rodent's brain,

00:10:39.079 --> 00:10:41.544
including those involved in sexual arousal.

00:10:41.544 --> 00:10:43.745
But how those puzzle pieces fit together

00:10:43.745 --> 00:10:45.589
is not immediately clear.

00:10:45.589 --> 00:10:47.885
What is clear is that this thing

00:10:47.885 --> 00:10:49.277
is a single cell.

00:10:49.277 --> 00:10:50.647
This has no nervous system.

00:10:50.647 --> 00:10:51.779
It has no consciousness.

00:10:51.779 --> 00:10:53.080
It doesn't even have a body.

00:10:53.080 --> 00:10:55.704
But it's manipulating a mammal?

00:10:55.704 --> 00:10:57.130
We are mammals.

00:10:57.130 --> 00:10:59.564
We are more intelligent than a mere rat, to be sure,

00:10:59.564 --> 00:11:02.088
but our brains have the same basic structure,

00:11:02.088 --> 00:11:03.481
the same types of cells,

00:11:03.481 --> 00:11:05.069
the same chemicals running through them,

00:11:05.069 --> 00:11:07.388
and the same parasites.

00:11:07.388 --> 00:11:09.736
Estimates vary a lot, but some figures suggest

00:11:09.736 --> 00:11:12.096
that one in three people around the world

00:11:12.096 --> 00:11:13.809
have Toxo in their brains.

00:11:13.809 --> 00:11:17.297
Now typically, this doesn't lead to any overt illness.

00:11:17.297 --> 00:11:19.175
The parasite holds up in a dormant state

00:11:19.175 --> 00:11:21.358
for a long period of time.

00:11:21.358 --> 00:11:23.397
But there's some evidence that those people

00:11:23.397 --> 00:11:26.431
who are carriers score slightly differently

00:11:26.431 --> 00:11:29.160
on personality questionnaires than other people,

00:11:29.160 --> 00:11:31.644
that they have a slightly 
higher risk of car accidents,

00:11:31.644 --> 00:11:34.247
and there's some evidence
that people with schizophrenia

00:11:34.247 --> 00:11:36.793
are more likely to be infected.

00:11:36.793 --> 00:11:38.976
Now, I think this evidence is still inconclusive,

00:11:38.976 --> 00:11:40.887
and even among Toxo researchers,

00:11:40.887 --> 00:11:43.327
opinion is divided as to whether the parasite

00:11:43.327 --> 00:11:45.712
is truly influencing our behavior.

00:11:45.712 --> 00:11:48.371
But given the widespread
nature of such manipulations,

00:11:48.371 --> 00:11:50.216
it would be completely implausible

00:11:50.216 --> 00:11:51.865
for humans to be the only species

00:11:51.865 --> 00:11:54.811
that weren't similarly affected.

00:11:54.811 --> 00:11:59.204
And I think that this capacity to constantly

00:11:59.204 --> 00:12:02.071
subvert our way of thinking about the world

00:12:02.071 --> 00:12:03.618
makes parasites amazing.

00:12:03.618 --> 00:12:06.827
They're constantly inviting us to
look at the natural world sideways,

00:12:06.827 --> 00:12:08.998
and to ask if the behaviors we're seeing,

00:12:08.998 --> 00:12:10.485
whether they're simple and obvious

00:12:10.485 --> 00:12:12.018
or baffling and puzzling,

00:12:12.018 --> 00:12:14.104
are not the results of individuals

00:12:14.104 --> 00:12:15.957
acting through their own accord

00:12:15.957 --> 00:12:17.766
but because they are being bent

00:12:17.766 --> 00:12:20.436
to the control of something else.

00:12:20.436 --> 00:12:22.476
And while that idea may be disquieting,

00:12:22.476 --> 00:12:25.399
and while parasites' habits may be very grisly,

00:12:25.399 --> 00:12:27.191
I think that ability to surprise us

00:12:27.191 --> 00:12:30.366
makes them as wonderful and as charismatic

00:12:30.366 --> 00:12:33.730
as any panda or butterfly or dolphin.

00:12:33.730 --> 00:12:35.949
At the end of "On the Origin of Species,"

00:12:35.949 --> 00:12:38.938
Charles Darwin writes about the grandeur of life,

00:12:38.938 --> 00:12:41.591
and of endless forms most beautiful

00:12:41.591 --> 00:12:43.023
and most wonderful,

00:12:43.023 --> 00:12:45.602
and I like to think he could easily have been talking

00:12:45.602 --> 00:12:48.782
about a tapeworm that makes shrimp sociable

00:12:48.782 --> 00:12:52.031
or a wasp that takes cockroaches for walks.

00:12:52.031 --> 00:12:55.180
But perhaps, that's just a parasite talking.

00:12:55.180 --> 00:12:56.911
Thank you.

00:12:56.911 --> 00:13:00.911
(Applause)

title: Protecting Twitter users (sometimes from themselves)
transcript: My job at Twitter is to ensure user trust, protect user rights and keep users safe, both from each other and, at times, from themselves. Let's talk about what scale looks like at Twitter. Back in January 2009, we saw more than two million new tweets each day on the platform. January 2014, more than 500 million. We were seeing two million tweets in less than six minutes. That's a 24,900-percent increase.Now, the vast majority of activity on Twitter puts no one in harm's way. There's no risk involved. My job is to root out and prevent activity that might. Sounds straightforward, right? You might even think it'd be easy, given that I just said the vast majority of activity on Twitter puts no one in harm's way. Why spend so much time searching for potential calamities in innocuous activities? Given the scale that Twitter is at, a one-in-a-million chance happens 500 times a day. It's the same for other companies dealing at this sort of scale. For us, edge cases, those rare situations that are unlikely to occur, are more like norms. Say 99.999 percent of tweets pose no risk to anyone. There's no threat involved. Maybe people are documenting travel landmarks like Australia's Heart Reef, or tweeting about a concert they're attending, or sharing pictures of cute baby animals. After you take out that 99.999 percent, that tiny percentage of tweets remaining works out to roughly 150,000 per month. The sheer scale of what we're dealing with makes for a challenge.You know what else makes my role particularly challenging? People do weird things. (Laughter) And I have to figure out what they're doing, why, and whether or not there's risk involved, often without much in terms of context or background. I'm going to show you some examples that I've run into during my time at Twitter — these are all real examples — of situations that at first seemed cut and dried, but the truth of the matter was something altogether different. The details have been changed to protect the innocent and sometimes the guilty. We'll start off easy.["Yo bitch"]If you saw a Tweet that only said this, you might think to yourself, "That looks like abuse." After all, why would you want to receive the message, "Yo, bitch." Now, I try to stay relatively hip to the latest trends and memes, so I knew that "yo, bitch" was also often a common greeting between friends, as well as being a popular "Breaking Bad" reference. I will admit that I did not expect to encounter a fourth use case. It turns out it is also used on Twitter when people are role-playing as dogs. (Laughter) And in fact, in that case, it's not only not abusive, it's technically just an accurate greeting. (Laughter)So okay, determining whether or not something is abusive without context, definitely hard.Let's look at spam. Here's an example of an account engaged in classic spammer behavior, sending the exact same message to thousands of people. While this is a mockup I put together using my account, we see accounts doing this all the time. Seems pretty straightforward. We should just automatically suspend accounts engaging in this kind of behavior. Turns out there's some exceptions to that rule. Turns out that that message could also be a notification you signed up for that the International Space Station is passing overhead because you wanted to go outside and see if you could see it. You're not going to get that chance if we mistakenly suspend the account thinking it's spam.Okay. Let's make the stakes higher. Back to my account, again exhibiting classic behavior. This time it's sending the same message and link. This is often indicative of  something called phishing, somebody trying to steal another person's account information by directing them to another website. That's pretty clearly not a good thing. We want to, and do, suspend accounts engaging in that kind of behavior. So why are the stakes higher for this? Well, this could also be a bystander at a rally who managed to record a video of a police officer beating a non-violent protester who's trying to let the world know what's happening. We don't want to gamble on potentially silencing that crucial speech by classifying it as spam and suspending it. That means we evaluate hundreds of parameters when looking at account behaviors, and even then, we can still get it wrong and have to reevaluate.Now, given the sorts of challenges I'm up against, it's crucial that I not only predict but also design protections for the unexpected. And that's not just an issue for me, or for Twitter, it's an issue for you. It's an issue for anybody who's building or creating something that you think is going to be amazing and will let people do awesome things. So what do I do? I pause and I think, how could all of this go horribly wrong? I visualize catastrophe. And that's hard. There's a sort of inherent cognitive dissonance in doing that, like when you're writing your wedding vows at the same time as your prenuptial agreement. (Laughter) But you still have to do it, particularly if you're marrying  500 million tweets per day. What do I mean by "visualize catastrophe?" I try to think of how something as benign and innocuous as a picture of a cat could lead to death, and what to do to prevent that. Which happens to be my next example. This is my cat, Eli. We wanted to give users the ability to add photos to their tweets. A picture is worth a thousand words. You only get 140 characters. You add a photo to your tweet, look at how much more content you've got now. There's all sorts of great things you can do by adding a photo to a tweet. My job isn't to think of those. It's to think of what could go wrong.How could this picture lead to my death? Well, here's one possibility. There's more in that picture than just a cat. There's geodata. When you take a picture with your smartphone or digital camera, there's a lot of additional information saved along in that image. In fact, this image also contains the equivalent of this, more specifically, this. Sure, it's not likely that someone's going to try to track me down and do me harm based upon image data associated with a picture I took of my cat, but I start by assuming the worst will happen. That's why, when we launched photos on Twitter, we made the decision to strip that geodata out. (Applause) If I start by assuming the worst and work backwards, I can make sure that the protections we build work for both expected and unexpected use cases.Given that I spend my days and nights imagining the worst that could happen, it wouldn't be surprising if  my worldview was gloomy. (Laughter) It's not. The vast majority of interactions I see — and I see a lot, believe me — are positive, people reaching out to help or to connect or share information with each other. It's just that for those of us dealing with scale, for those of us tasked with keeping people safe, we have to assume the worst will happen, because for us, a one-in-a-million chance is pretty good odds.Thank you.(Applause)
