title: Why giving away our wealth has been the most satisfying thing we've done
transcript: Chris Anderson: So, this is an interview with a difference. On the basis that a picture is worth a thousand words, what I did was, I asked Bill and Melinda to dig out from their archive some images that would help explain some of what they've done, and do a few things that way.So, we're going to start here. Melinda, when and where was this, and who is that handsome man next to you?Melinda Gates: With those big glasses, huh? This is in Africa, our very first trip, the first time either of us had ever been to Africa, in the fall of 1993. We were already engaged to be married. We married a few months later, and this was the trip where we really went to see the animals and to see the savanna. It was incredible. Bill had never taken that much time off from work. But what really touched us, actually, were the people, and the extreme poverty. We started asking ourselves questions. Does it have to be like this? And at the end of the trip, we went out to Zanzibar, and took some time to walk on the beach, which is something we had done a lot while we were dating. And we'd already been talking about during that time that the wealth that had come from Microsoft would be given back to society, but it was really on that beach walk that we started to talk about, well, what might we do and how might we go about it?CA: So, given that this vacation led to the creation of the world's biggest private foundation, it's pretty expensive as vacations go. (Laughter)MG: I guess so. We enjoyed it.CA: Which of you was the key instigator here, or was it symmetrical? Bill Gates: Well, I think we were excited that there'd be a phase of our life where we'd get to work together and figure out how to give this money back. At this stage, we were talking about the poorest, and could you have a big impact on them? Were there things that weren't being done? There was a lot we didn't know. Our naïveté is pretty incredible, when we look back on it. But we had a certain enthusiasm that that would be the phase, the post-Microsoft phase would be our philanthropy.MG: Which Bill always thought was going to come after he was 60, so he hasn't quite hit 60 yet, so some things change along the way.CA: So it started there, but it got accelerated. So that was '93, and it was '97, really, before the foundation itself started.MA: Yeah, in '97, we read an article about diarrheal diseases killing so many kids around the world, and we kept saying to ourselves, "Well that can't be. In the U.S., you just go down to the drug store." And so we started gathering scientists and started learning about population, learning about vaccines, learning about what had worked and what had failed, and that's really when we got going, was in late 1998, 1999.CA: So, you've got a big pot of money and a world full of so many different issues. How on Earth do you decide what to focus on?BG: Well, we decided that we'd pick two causes, whatever the biggest inequity was globally, and there we looked at children dying, children not having enough nutrition to ever develop, and countries that were really stuck, because with that level of death, and parents would have so many kids that they'd get huge population growth, and that the kids were so sick that they really couldn't be educated and lift themselves up. So that was our global thing, and then in the U.S., both of us have had amazing educations, and we saw that as the way that the U.S. could live up to its promise of equal opportunity is by having a phenomenal education system, and the more we learned, the more we realized we're not really fulfilling that promise. And so we picked those two things, and everything the foundation does is focused there.CA: So, I asked each of you to pick an image that you like that illustrates your work, and Melinda, this is what you picked. What's this about?MG: So I, one of the things I love to do when I travel is to go out to the rural areas and talk to the women, whether it's Bangladesh, India, lots of countries in Africa, and I go in as a Western woman without a name. I don't tell them who I am. Pair of khakis. And I kept hearing from women, over and over and over, the more I traveled, "I want to be able to use this shot." I would be there to talk to them about childhood vaccines, and they would bring the conversation around to "But what about the shot I get?" which is an injection they were getting called Depo-Provera, which is a contraceptive. And I would come back and talk to global health experts, and they'd say, "Oh no, contraceptives are stocked in in the developing world." Well, you had to dig deeper into the reports, and this is what the team came to me with, which is, to have the number one thing that women tell you in Africa they want to use stocked out more than 200 days a year explains why women were saying to me, "I walked 10 kilometers without my husband knowing it, and I got to the clinic, and there was nothing there." And so condoms were stocked in in Africa because of all the AIDS work that the U.S. and others supported. But women will tell you over and over again, "I can't negotiate a condom with my husband. I'm either suggesting he has AIDS or I have AIDS, and I need that tool because then I can space the births of my children, and I can feed them and have a chance of educating them."CA: Melinda, you're Roman Catholic, and you've often been embroiled in controversy over this issue, and on the abortion question, on both sides, really. How do you navigate that?MG: Yeah, so I think that's a really important point, which is, we had backed away from contraceptives as a global community. We knew that 210 million women were saying they wanted access to contraceptives, even the contraceptives we have here in the United States, and we weren't providing them because of the political controversy in our country, and to me that was just a crime, and I kept looking around trying to find the person that would get this back on the global stage, and I finally realized I just had to do it. And even though I'm Catholic, I believe in contraceptives just like most of the Catholic women in the United States who report using contraceptives, and I shouldn't let that controversy be the thing that holds us back. We used to have consensus in the United States around contraceptives, and so we got back to that global consensus, and actually raised 2.6 billion dollars around exactly this issue for women. (Applause)CA: Bill, this is your graph. What's this about?BG: Well, my graph has numbers on it. (Laughter) I really like this graph. This is the number of children who die before the age of five every year. And what you find is really a phenomenal success story which is not widely known, that we are making incredible progress. We go from 20 million not long after I was born to now we're down to about six million. So this is a story largely of vaccines. Smallpox was killing a couple million kids a year. That was eradicated, so that got down to zero. Measles was killing a couple million a year. That's down to a few hundred thousand. Anyway, this is a chart where you want to get that number to continue, and it's going to be possible, using the science of new vaccines, getting the vaccines out to kids. We can actually accelerate the progress. The last decade, that number has dropped faster than ever in history, and so I just love the fact that you can say, okay, if we can invent new vaccines, we can get them out there, use the very latest understanding of these things, and get the delivery right, that we can perform a miracle.CA: I mean, you do the math on this, and it works out, I think, literally to thousands of kids' lives saved every day compared to the prior year. It's not reported. An airliner with 200-plus deaths is a far, far bigger story than that. Does that drive you crazy?BG: Yeah, because it's a silent thing going on. It's a kid, one kid at a time. Ninety-eight percent of this has nothing to do with natural disasters, and yet, people's charity, when they see a natural disaster, are wonderful. It's incredible how people think, okay, that could be me, and the money flows. These causes have been a bit invisible. Now that the Millennium Development Goals and various things are getting out there, we are seeing some increased generosity, so the goal is to get this well below a million, which should be possible in our lifetime.CA: Maybe it needed someone who is turned on by numbers and graphs rather than just the big, sad face to get engaged. I mean, you've used it in your letter this year, you used basically this argument to say that aid, contrary to the current meme that aid is kind of worthless and broken, that actually it has been effective.BG: Yeah, well people can take, there is some aid that was well-meaning and didn't go well. There's some venture capital investments that were well-meaning and didn't go well. You shouldn't just say, okay, because of that, because we don't have a perfect record, this is a bad endeavor. You should look at, what was your goal? How are you trying to uplift nutrition and survival and literacy so these countries can take care of themselves, and say wow, this is going well, and be smarter. We can spend aid smarter. It is not all a panacea. We can do better than venture capital, I think, including big hits like this.CA: Traditional wisdom is that it's pretty hard for married couples to work together. How have you guys managed it? MG: Yeah, I've had a lot of women say to me, "I really don't think I could work with my husband. That just wouldn't work out." You know, we enjoy it, and we don't — this foundation has been a coming to for both of us in its continuous learning journey, and we don't travel together as much for the foundation, actually, as we used to when Bill was working at Microsoft. We have more trips where we're traveling separately, but I always know when I come home, Bill's going to be interested in what I learned, whether it's about women or girls or something new about the vaccine delivery chain, or this person that is a great leader. He's going to listen and be really interested. And he knows when he comes home, even if it's to talk about the speech he did or the data or what he's learned, I'm really interested, and I think we have a really collaborative relationship. But we don't every minute together, that's for sure. (Laughter)CA: But now you are, and we're very happy that you are. Melinda, early on, you were basically largely running the show. Six years ago, I guess, Bill came on full time, so moved from Microsoft and became full time. That must have been hard, adjusting to that. No?MG: Yeah. I think actually, for the foundation employees, there was way more angst for them than there was for me about Bill coming. I was actually really excited. I mean, Bill made this decision even obviously before it got announced in 2006, and it was really his decision, but again, it was a beach vacation where we were walking on the beach and he was starting to think of this idea. And for me, the excitement of Bill putting his brain and his heart against these huge global problems, these inequities, to me that was exciting. Yes, the foundation employees had angst about that. (Applause)CA: That's cool.MG: But that went away within three months, once he was there.BG: Including some of the employees.MG: That's what I said, the employees, it went away for them three months after you were there.BG: No, I'm kidding. MG: Oh, you mean, the employees didn't go away.BG: A few of them did, but — (Laughter)CA: So what do you guys argue about? Sunday, 11 o'clock, you're away from work, what comes up? What's the argument?BG: Because we built this thing together from the beginning, it's this great partnership. I had that with Paul Allen in the early days of Microsoft. I had it with Steve Ballmer as Microsoft got bigger, and now Melinda, and in even stronger, equal ways, is the partner, so we talk a lot about which things should we give more to, which groups are working well? She's got a lot of insight. She'll sit down with the employees a lot. We'll take the different trips she described. So there's a lot of collaboration. I can't think of anything where one of us had a super strong opinion about one thing or another?CA: How about you, Melinda,  though? Can you? (Laughter) You never know.MG: Well, here's the thing. We come at things from different angles, and I actually think that's really good. So Bill can look at the big data and say, "I want to act based on these global statistics." For me, I come at it from intuition. I meet with lots of people on the ground and Bill's taught me to take that and read up to the global data and see if they match, and I think what I've taught him is to take that data and meet with people on the ground to understand, can you actually deliver that vaccine? Can you get a woman to accept those polio drops in her child's mouth? Because the delivery piece is every bit as important as the science. So I think it's been more a coming to over time towards each other's point of view, and quite frankly, the work is better because of it.CA: So, in vaccines and polio and so forth, you've had some amazing successes. What about failure, though? Can you talk about a failure and maybe what you've learned from it?BG: Yeah. Fortunately, we can afford a few failures, because we've certainly had them. We do a lot of drug work or vaccine work that you know you're going to have different failures. Like, we put out, one that got a lot of publicity was asking for a better condom. Well, we got hundreds of ideas. Maybe a few of those will work out. We were very naïve, certainly I was, about a drug for a disease in India, visceral leishmaniasis, that I thought, once I got this drug, we can just go wipe out the disease. Well, turns out it took an injection every day for 10 days. It took three more years to get it than we expected, and then there was no way it was going to get out there. Fortunately, we found out that if you go kill the sand flies, you probably can have success there, but we spent five years, you could say wasted five years, and about 60 million, on a path that turned out to have very modest benefit when we got there.CA: You're spending, like, a billion dollars a year in education, I think, something like that. Is anything, the story of what's gone right there is quite a long and complex one. Are there any failures that you can talk about?MG: Well, I would say a huge lesson for us out of the early work is we thought that these small schools were the answer, and small schools definitely help. They bring down the dropout rate. They have less violence and crime in those schools. But the thing that we learned from that work, and what turned out to be the fundamental key, is a great teacher in front of the classroom. If you don't have an effective teacher in the front of the classroom, I don't care how big or small the building is, you're not going to change the trajectory of whether that student will be ready for college. (Applause)CA: So Melinda, this is you and your eldest daughter, Jenn. And just taken about three weeks ago, I think, three or four weeks ago. Where was this?MG: So we went to Tanzania. Jenn's been to Tanzania. All our kids have been to Africa quite a bit, actually. And we did something very different, which is, we decided to go spend two nights and three days with a family. Anna and Sanare are the parents. They invited us to come and stay in their boma. Actually, the goats had been there, I think, living in that particular little hut on their little compound before we got there. And we stayed with their family, and we really, really learned what life is like in rural Tanzania. And the difference between just going and visiting for half a day or three quarters of a day versus staying overnight was profound, and so let me just give you one explanation of that. They had six children, and as I talked to Anna in the kitchen, we cooked for about five hours in the cooking hut that day, and as I talked to her, she had absolutely planned and spaced with her husband the births of their children. It was a very loving relationship. This was a Maasai warrior and his wife, but they had decided to get married, they clearly had respect and love in the relationship. Their children, their six children, the two in the middle were twins, 13, a boy, and a girl named Grace. And when we'd go out to chop wood and do all the things that Grace and her mother would do, Grace was not a child, she was an adolescent, but she wasn't an adult. She was very, very shy. So she kept wanting to talk to me and Jenn. We kept trying to engage her, but she was shy. And at night, though, when all the lights went out in rural Tanzania, and there was no moon that night, the first night, and no stars, and Jenn came out of our hut with her REI little headlamp on, Grace went immediately, and got the translator, came straight up to my Jenn and said, "When you go home, can I have your headlamp so I can study at night?"CA: Oh, wow.MG: And her dad had told me how afraid he was that unlike the son, who had passed his secondary exams, because of her chores, she'd not done so well and wasn't in the government school yet. He said, "I don't know how I'm going to pay for her education. I can't pay for private school, and she may end up on this farm like my wife." So they know the difference that an education can make in a huge, profound way.CA: I mean, this is another pic of your other two kids, Rory and Phoebe, along with Paul Farmer. Bringing up three children when you're the world's richest family seems like a social experiment without much prior art. How have you managed it? What's been your approach?BG: Well, I'd say overall the kids get a great education, but you've got to make sure they have a sense of their own ability and what they're going to go and do, and our philosophy has been to be very clear with them — most of the money's going to the foundation — and help them find something they're excited about. We want to strike a balance where they have the freedom to do anything but not a lot of money showered on them so they could go out and do nothing. And so far, they're fairly diligent, excited to pick their own direction.CA: You've obviously guarded their  privacy carefully for obvious reasons. I'm curious why you've given me permission to show this picture now here at TED. MG: Well, it's interesting. As they get older, they so know that our family belief is about responsibility, that we are in an unbelievable situation just to live in the United States and have a great education, and we have a responsibility to give back to the world. And so as they get older and we are teaching them — they have been to so many countries around the world — they're saying, we do want people to know that we believe in what you're doing, Mom and Dad, and it is okay to show us more. So we have their permission to show this picture, and I think Paul Farmer is probably going to put it eventually in some of his work. But they really care deeply about the mission of the foundation, too.CA: You've easily got enough money despite your vast contributions to the foundation to make them all billionaires. Is that your plan for them?BG: Nope. No. They won't have anything like that. They need to have a sense that their own work is meaningful and important. We read an article long, actually, before we got married, where Warren Buffett talked about that, and we're quite convinced that it wasn't a favor either to society or to the kids.CA: Well, speaking of Warren Buffett, something really amazing happened in 2006, when somehow your only real rival for richest person in America suddenly turned around and agreed to give 80 percent of his fortune to your foundation. How on Earth did that happen? I guess there's a long version and a short version of that. We've got time for the short version.BG: All right. Well, Warren was a close friend, and he was going to have his wife Suzie give it all away. Tragically, she passed away before he did, and he's big on delegation, and — (Laughter) — he said —CA: Tweet that.BG: If he's got somebody who is doing something well, and is willing to do it at no charge, maybe that's okay. But we were stunned. MG: Totally stunned. BG: We had never expected it, and it has been unbelievable. It's allowed us to increase our ambition in what the foundation can do quite dramatically. Half the resources we have come from Warren's mind-blowing generosity.CA: And I think you've pledged that by the time you're done, more than, or 95 percent of your wealth, will be given to the foundation.BG: Yes.CA: And since this relationship, it's amazing— (Applause) And recently, you and Warren have been going around trying to persuade other billionaires and successful people to pledge to give, what, more than half of their assets for philanthropy. How is that going? BG: Well, we've got about 120 people who have now taken this giving pledge. The thing that's great is that we get together yearly and talk about, okay, do you hire staff, what do you give to them? We're not trying to homogenize it. I mean, the beauty of philanthropy is this mind-blowing diversity. People give to some things. We look and go, "Wow." But that's great. That's the role of philanthropy is to pick different approaches, including even in one space, like education. We need more experimentation. But it's been wonderful, meeting those people, sharing their journey to philanthropy, how they involve their kids, where they're doing it differently, and it's been way more successful than we expected. Now it looks like it'll just keep growing in size in the years ahead.MG: And having people see that other people are making change with philanthropy, I mean, these are people who have created their own businesses, put their own ingenuity behind incredible ideas. If they put their ideas and their brain behind philanthropy, they can change the world. And they start to see others doing it, and saying, "Wow, I want to do that with my own money." To me, that's the piece that's incredible.CA: It seems to me, it's actually really hard for some people to figure out even how to remotely spend that much money on something else. There are probably some billionaires in the room and certainly some successful people. I'm curious, can you make the pitch? What's the pitch?BG: Well, it's the most fulfilling thing we've ever done, and you can't take it with you, and if it's not good for your kids, let's get together and brainstorm about what we can be done. The world is a far better place because of the philanthropists of the past, and the U.S. tradition here, which is the strongest, is the envy of the world. And part of the reason I'm so optimistic is because I do think philanthropy is going to grow and take some of these things government's not just good at working on and discovering and shine some light in the right direction.CA: The world's got this terrible inequality, growing inequality problem that seems structural. It does seem to me that if more of your peers took the approach that you two have made, it would make a dent both in that problem and certainly in the perception of that problem. Is that a fair comment?BG: Oh yeah. If you take from the most wealthy and give to the least wealthy, it's good. It tries to balance out, and that's just.MG: But you change systems. In the U.S., we're trying to change the education system so it's just for everybody and it works for all students. That, to me, really changes the inequality balance.BG: That's the most important. (Applause)CA: Well, I really think that most people here and many millions around the world are just in awe of the trajectory your lives have taken and the spectacular degree to which you have shaped the future. Thank you so much for coming to TED and for sharing with us and for all you do.BG: Thank you. MG: Thank you. (Applause)BG: Thank you. MG: Thank you very much. BG: All right, good job. (Applause)
subtitle:
WEBVTT
X-TIMESTAMP-MAP=MPEGTS:900000,LOCAL:00:00:00.000

00:00:13.298 --> 00:00:16.905
Chris Anderson: So, this is an
interview with a difference.

00:00:16.905 --> 00:00:20.973
On the basis that a picture
is worth a thousand words,

00:00:20.973 --> 00:00:23.869
what I did was, I asked Bill and Melinda

00:00:23.869 --> 00:00:26.076
to dig out from their archive

00:00:26.076 --> 00:00:28.174
some images that would help explain

00:00:28.174 --> 00:00:29.610
some of what they've done,

00:00:29.610 --> 00:00:32.207
and do a few things that way.

00:00:32.207 --> 00:00:35.938
So, we're going to start here.

00:00:35.938 --> 00:00:38.141
Melinda, when and where was this,

00:00:38.141 --> 00:00:40.175
and who is that handsome man next to you?

00:00:40.175 --> 00:00:42.184
Melinda Gates: With those big glasses, huh?

00:00:42.184 --> 00:00:44.223
This is in Africa, our very first trip,

00:00:44.223 --> 00:00:46.128
the first time either of us had ever been to Africa,

00:00:46.128 --> 00:00:47.738
in the fall of 1993.

00:00:47.738 --> 00:00:49.726
We were already engaged to be married.

00:00:49.726 --> 00:00:51.432
We married a few months later,

00:00:51.432 --> 00:00:53.649
and this was the trip where we really went to see

00:00:53.649 --> 00:00:55.541
the animals and to see the savanna.

00:00:55.541 --> 00:00:57.529
It was incredible. Bill had never taken that much time

00:00:57.529 --> 00:00:58.941
off from work.

00:00:58.941 --> 00:01:03.568
But what really touched us, actually, were the people,

00:01:03.568 --> 00:01:06.176
and the extreme poverty.

00:01:06.176 --> 00:01:07.749
We started asking ourselves questions.

00:01:07.749 --> 00:01:09.553
Does it have to be like this?

00:01:09.553 --> 00:01:10.504
And at the end of the trip,

00:01:10.504 --> 00:01:11.604
we went out to Zanzibar,

00:01:11.604 --> 00:01:13.092
and took some time to walk on the beach,

00:01:13.092 --> 00:01:14.458
which is something we had done a lot

00:01:14.458 --> 00:01:15.776
while we were dating.

00:01:15.776 --> 00:01:18.749
And we'd already been talking about during that time

00:01:18.749 --> 00:01:20.606
that the wealth that had come from Microsoft

00:01:20.606 --> 00:01:21.881
would be given back to society,

00:01:21.881 --> 00:01:23.455
but it was really on that beach walk

00:01:23.455 --> 00:01:25.027
that we started to talk about, well,

00:01:25.027 --> 00:01:28.560
what might we do and how might we go about it?

00:01:28.560 --> 00:01:31.292
CA: So, given that this vacation

00:01:31.292 --> 00:01:33.484
led to the creation of

00:01:33.484 --> 00:01:36.300
the world's biggest private foundation,

00:01:36.300 --> 00:01:39.432
it's pretty expensive as vacations go. (Laughter)

00:01:39.432 --> 00:01:41.900
MG: I guess so. We enjoyed it.

00:01:41.900 --> 00:01:44.798
CA: Which of you was the key instigator here,

00:01:44.798 --> 00:01:47.751
or was it symmetrical?

00:01:47.751 --> 00:01:50.144
Bill Gates: Well, I think we were excited

00:01:50.144 --> 00:01:51.611
that there'd be a phase of our life

00:01:51.611 --> 00:01:53.672
where we'd get to work together

00:01:53.672 --> 00:02:00.283
and figure out how to give this money back.

00:02:00.283 --> 00:02:03.432
At this stage, we were talking about the poorest,

00:02:03.432 --> 00:02:05.834
and could you have a big impact on them?

00:02:05.834 --> 00:02:07.759
Were there things that weren't being done?

00:02:07.759 --> 00:02:09.659
There was a lot we didn't know.

00:02:09.659 --> 00:02:11.747
Our naïveté is pretty incredible,

00:02:11.747 --> 00:02:12.839
when we look back on it.

00:02:12.839 --> 00:02:14.395
But we had a certain enthusiasm

00:02:14.395 --> 00:02:17.392
that that would be the phase,

00:02:17.392 --> 00:02:20.118
the post-Microsoft phase

00:02:20.118 --> 00:02:22.346
would be our philanthropy.

00:02:22.346 --> 00:02:24.492
MG: Which Bill always thought was going to come

00:02:24.492 --> 00:02:25.628
after he was 60,

00:02:25.628 --> 00:02:27.290
so he hasn't quite hit 60 yet,

00:02:27.290 --> 00:02:30.483
so some things change along the way.

00:02:30.483 --> 00:02:32.927
CA: So it started there, but it got accelerated.

00:02:32.927 --> 00:02:35.447
So that was '93, and it was '97, really,

00:02:35.447 --> 00:02:37.185
before the foundation itself started.

00:02:37.185 --> 00:02:39.490
MA: Yeah, in '97, we read an article

00:02:39.490 --> 00:02:42.904
about diarrheal diseases killing
so many kids around the world,

00:02:42.904 --> 00:02:44.518
and we kept saying to ourselves,

00:02:44.518 --> 00:02:45.758
"Well that can't be.

00:02:45.758 --> 00:02:47.512
In the U.S., you just go down to the drug store."

00:02:47.512 --> 00:02:49.677
And so we started gathering scientists

00:02:49.677 --> 00:02:52.143
and started learning about population,

00:02:52.143 --> 00:02:53.503
learning about vaccines,

00:02:53.503 --> 00:02:55.890
learning about what had worked and what had failed,

00:02:55.890 --> 00:02:57.796
and that's really when we got going,

00:02:57.796 --> 00:03:02.173
was in late 1998, 1999.

00:03:02.173 --> 00:03:04.924
CA: So, you've got a big pot of money

00:03:04.924 --> 00:03:07.251
and a world full of so many different issues.

00:03:07.251 --> 00:03:11.473
How on Earth do you decide what to focus on?

00:03:11.473 --> 00:03:14.018
BG: Well, we decided that we'd pick two causes,

00:03:14.018 --> 00:03:16.878
whatever the biggest inequity was globally,

00:03:16.878 --> 00:03:19.138
and there we looked at children dying,

00:03:19.138 --> 00:03:21.878
children not having enough nutrition to ever develop,

00:03:21.878 --> 00:03:23.377
and countries that were really stuck,

00:03:23.377 --> 00:03:25.637
because with that level of death,

00:03:25.637 --> 00:03:27.605
and parents would have so many kids

00:03:27.605 --> 00:03:29.123
that they'd get huge population growth,

00:03:29.123 --> 00:03:32.249
and that the kids were so sick

00:03:32.249 --> 00:03:34.895
that they really couldn't be educated

00:03:34.895 --> 00:03:36.767
and lift themselves up.

00:03:36.767 --> 00:03:37.875
So that was our global thing,

00:03:37.875 --> 00:03:40.595
and then in the U.S.,

00:03:40.595 --> 00:03:43.369
both of us have had amazing educations,

00:03:43.369 --> 00:03:46.418
and we saw that as the way that the U.S.

00:03:46.418 --> 00:03:49.430
could live up to its promise of equal opportunity

00:03:49.430 --> 00:03:52.015
is by having a phenomenal education system,

00:03:52.015 --> 00:03:54.643
and the more we learned, the more we realized

00:03:54.643 --> 00:03:57.071
we're not really fulfilling that promise.

00:03:57.071 --> 00:03:58.908
And so we picked those two things,

00:03:58.908 --> 00:04:00.560
and everything the foundation does

00:04:00.560 --> 00:04:03.574
is focused there.

00:04:03.574 --> 00:04:05.910
CA: So, I asked each of you to pick an image

00:04:05.910 --> 00:04:08.342
that you like that illustrates your work,

00:04:08.342 --> 00:04:11.410
and Melinda, this is what you picked.

00:04:11.410 --> 00:04:12.877
What's this about?

00:04:12.877 --> 00:04:15.908
MG: So I, one of the things I love to do when I travel

00:04:15.908 --> 00:04:19.018
is to go out to the rural areas and talk to the women,

00:04:19.018 --> 00:04:21.616
whether it's Bangladesh, India,
lots of countries in Africa,

00:04:21.616 --> 00:04:24.024
and I go in as a Western woman without a name.

00:04:24.024 --> 00:04:27.433
I don't tell them who I am. Pair of khakis.

00:04:27.433 --> 00:04:28.937
And I kept hearing from women,

00:04:28.937 --> 00:04:31.820
over and over and over, the more I traveled,

00:04:31.820 --> 00:04:34.229
"I want to be able to use this shot."

00:04:34.229 --> 00:04:36.798
I would be there to talk to them
about childhood vaccines,

00:04:36.798 --> 00:04:39.198
and they would bring the conversation around to

00:04:39.198 --> 00:04:41.179
"But what about the shot I get?"

00:04:41.179 --> 00:04:43.631
which is an injection they were
getting called Depo-Provera,

00:04:43.631 --> 00:04:45.612
which is a contraceptive.

00:04:45.612 --> 00:04:47.944
And I would come back and
talk to global health experts,

00:04:47.944 --> 00:04:49.497
and they'd say, "Oh no, contraceptives

00:04:49.497 --> 00:04:51.889
are stocked in in the developing world."

00:04:51.889 --> 00:04:53.879
Well, you had to dig deeper into the reports,

00:04:53.879 --> 00:04:55.655
and this is what the team came to me with,

00:04:55.655 --> 00:04:57.801
which is, to have the number one thing

00:04:57.801 --> 00:05:00.939
that women tell you in Africa they want to use

00:05:00.939 --> 00:05:03.556
stocked out more than 200 days a year

00:05:03.556 --> 00:05:05.460
explains why women were saying to me,

00:05:05.460 --> 00:05:09.012
"I walked 10 kilometers without
my husband knowing it,

00:05:09.012 --> 00:05:12.321
and I got to the clinic, and there was nothing there."

00:05:12.321 --> 00:05:15.128
And so condoms were stocked in in Africa

00:05:15.128 --> 00:05:17.405
because of all the AIDS work that the U.S.

00:05:17.405 --> 00:05:18.809
and others supported.

00:05:18.809 --> 00:05:20.480
But women will tell you over and over again,

00:05:20.480 --> 00:05:23.090
"I can't negotiate a condom with my husband.

00:05:23.090 --> 00:05:27.298
I'm either suggesting he has AIDS or I have AIDS,

00:05:27.298 --> 00:05:30.058
and I need that tool because then I can space

00:05:30.058 --> 00:05:32.475
the births of my children, and I can feed them

00:05:32.475 --> 00:05:35.013
and have a chance of educating them."

00:05:35.013 --> 00:05:37.063
CA: Melinda, you're Roman Catholic,

00:05:37.063 --> 00:05:40.632
and you've often been embroiled

00:05:40.632 --> 00:05:42.586
in controversy over this issue,

00:05:42.586 --> 00:05:44.835
and on the abortion question,

00:05:44.835 --> 00:05:46.290
on both sides, really.

00:05:46.290 --> 00:05:47.981
How do you navigate that?

00:05:47.981 --> 00:05:51.091
MG: Yeah, so I think that's a really important point,

00:05:51.091 --> 00:05:54.174
which is, we had backed away from contraceptives

00:05:54.174 --> 00:05:55.341
as a global community.

00:05:55.341 --> 00:05:58.635
We knew that 210 million women

00:05:58.635 --> 00:06:00.894
were saying they wanted access to contraceptives,

00:06:00.894 --> 00:06:03.534
even the contraceptives we have
here in the United States,

00:06:03.534 --> 00:06:05.839
and we weren't providing them

00:06:05.839 --> 00:06:09.590
because of the political controversy in our country,

00:06:09.590 --> 00:06:11.767
and to me that was just a crime,

00:06:11.767 --> 00:06:14.532
and I kept looking around trying to find the person

00:06:14.532 --> 00:06:16.882
that would get this back on the global stage,

00:06:16.882 --> 00:06:18.888
and I finally realized I just had to do it.

00:06:18.888 --> 00:06:20.559
And even though I'm Catholic,

00:06:20.559 --> 00:06:22.000
I believe in contraceptives

00:06:22.000 --> 00:06:24.296
just like most of the Catholic
women in the United States

00:06:24.296 --> 00:06:26.127
who report using contraceptives,

00:06:26.127 --> 00:06:28.412
and I shouldn't let that controversy

00:06:28.412 --> 00:06:30.227
be the thing that holds us back.

00:06:30.227 --> 00:06:32.185
We used to have consensus in the United States

00:06:32.185 --> 00:06:33.450
around contraceptives,

00:06:33.450 --> 00:06:35.930
and so we got back to that global consensus,

00:06:35.930 --> 00:06:38.574
and actually raised 2.6 billion dollars

00:06:38.574 --> 00:06:41.107
around exactly this issue for women.

00:06:41.107 --> 00:06:46.574
(Applause)

00:06:49.207 --> 00:06:53.063
CA: Bill, this is your graph. What's this about?

00:06:53.063 --> 00:06:55.048
BG: Well, my graph has numbers on it.

00:06:55.048 --> 00:06:57.166
(Laughter)

00:06:57.166 --> 00:06:58.983
I really like this graph.

00:06:58.983 --> 00:07:01.958
This is the number of children

00:07:01.958 --> 00:07:04.520
who die before the age of five every year.

00:07:04.540 --> 00:07:06.363
And what you find is really

00:07:06.363 --> 00:07:08.313
a phenomenal success story

00:07:08.313 --> 00:07:10.467
which is not widely known,

00:07:10.467 --> 00:07:13.142
that we are making incredible progress.

00:07:13.142 --> 00:07:15.520
We go from 20 million

00:07:15.520 --> 00:07:17.224
not long after I was born

00:07:17.224 --> 00:07:20.910
to now we're down to about six million.

00:07:20.910 --> 00:07:23.047
So this is a story

00:07:23.047 --> 00:07:24.714
largely of vaccines.

00:07:24.714 --> 00:07:27.838
Smallpox was killing a couple million kids a year.

00:07:27.838 --> 00:07:30.028
That was eradicated, so that got down to zero.

00:07:30.028 --> 00:07:31.868
Measles was killing a couple million a year.

00:07:31.868 --> 00:07:33.571
That's down to a few hundred thousand.

00:07:33.571 --> 00:07:35.479
Anyway, this is a chart

00:07:35.479 --> 00:07:39.666
where you want to get that number to continue,

00:07:39.666 --> 00:07:41.406
and it's going to be possible,

00:07:41.406 --> 00:07:43.082
using the science of new vaccines,

00:07:43.082 --> 00:07:44.974
getting the vaccines out to kids.

00:07:44.974 --> 00:07:46.698
We can actually accelerate the progress.

00:07:46.698 --> 00:07:48.261
The last decade,

00:07:48.261 --> 00:07:50.073
that number has dropped faster

00:07:50.073 --> 00:07:52.351
than ever in history,

00:07:52.351 --> 00:07:55.074
and so I just love the fact that

00:07:55.074 --> 00:07:57.339
you can say, okay, if we can invent new vaccines,

00:07:57.339 --> 00:07:58.847
we can get them out there,

00:07:58.847 --> 00:08:01.332
use the very latest understanding of these things,

00:08:01.332 --> 00:08:05.943
and get the delivery right, that
we can perform a miracle.

00:08:05.943 --> 00:08:07.101
CA: I mean, you do the math on this,

00:08:07.101 --> 00:08:08.975
and it works out, I think, literally

00:08:08.975 --> 00:08:11.101
to thousands of kids' lives saved every day

00:08:11.101 --> 00:08:13.155
compared to the prior year.

00:08:13.155 --> 00:08:15.002
It's not reported.

00:08:15.002 --> 00:08:18.248
An airliner with 200-plus deaths

00:08:18.248 --> 00:08:20.458
is a far, far bigger story than that.

00:08:20.458 --> 00:08:22.007
Does that drive you crazy?

00:08:22.007 --> 00:08:24.998
BG: Yeah, because it's a silent thing going on.

00:08:24.998 --> 00:08:27.668
It's a kid, one kid at a time.

00:08:27.668 --> 00:08:29.131
Ninety-eight percent of this

00:08:29.131 --> 00:08:31.008
has nothing to do with natural disasters,

00:08:31.008 --> 00:08:32.485
and yet, people's charity,

00:08:32.485 --> 00:08:34.008
when they see a natural disaster, are wonderful.

00:08:34.008 --> 00:08:36.244
It's incredible how people think, okay,

00:08:36.244 --> 00:08:39.020
that could be me, and the money flows.

00:08:39.020 --> 00:08:42.426
These causes have been a bit invisible.

00:08:42.426 --> 00:08:44.637
Now that the Millennium Development Goals

00:08:44.637 --> 00:08:46.187
and various things are getting out there,

00:08:46.187 --> 00:08:49.031
we are seeing some increased generosity,

00:08:49.031 --> 00:08:52.302
so the goal is to get this well below a million,

00:08:52.302 --> 00:08:54.720
which should be possible in our lifetime.

00:08:54.720 --> 00:08:55.900
CA: Maybe it needed someone

00:08:55.900 --> 00:08:57.996
who is turned on by numbers and graphs

00:08:57.996 --> 00:09:00.410
rather than just the big, sad face

00:09:00.410 --> 00:09:02.065
to get engaged.

00:09:02.065 --> 00:09:03.788
I mean, you've used it in your letter this year,

00:09:03.788 --> 00:09:07.239
you used basically this argument to say that aid,

00:09:07.239 --> 00:09:08.910
contrary to the current meme

00:09:08.910 --> 00:09:11.993
that aid is kind of worthless and broken,

00:09:11.993 --> 00:09:13.946
that actually it has been effective.

00:09:13.946 --> 00:09:15.926
BG: Yeah, well people can take,

00:09:15.926 --> 00:09:19.106
there is some aid that was well-meaning

00:09:19.106 --> 00:09:21.029
and didn't go well.

00:09:21.029 --> 00:09:22.962
There's some venture capital investments

00:09:22.962 --> 00:09:25.862
that were well-meaning and didn't go well.

00:09:25.862 --> 00:09:28.701
You shouldn't just say, okay, because of that,

00:09:28.701 --> 00:09:31.819
because we don't have a perfect record,

00:09:31.819 --> 00:09:33.351
this is a bad endeavor.

00:09:33.351 --> 00:09:35.221
You should look at, what was your goal?

00:09:35.221 --> 00:09:37.829
How are you trying to uplift nutrition

00:09:37.829 --> 00:09:41.233
and survival and literacy

00:09:41.233 --> 00:09:42.868
so these countries can take care of themselves,

00:09:42.868 --> 00:09:44.872
and say wow, this is going well,

00:09:44.872 --> 00:09:46.144
and be smarter.

00:09:46.144 --> 00:09:47.984
We can spend aid smarter.

00:09:47.984 --> 00:09:51.396
It is not all a panacea.

00:09:51.396 --> 00:09:54.328
We can do better than venture capital, I think,

00:09:54.328 --> 00:09:57.115
including big hits like this.

00:09:57.115 --> 00:09:59.858
CA: Traditional wisdom is that

00:09:59.858 --> 00:10:03.906
it's pretty hard for married couples to work together.

00:10:03.906 --> 00:10:05.522
How have you guys managed it?

00:10:05.522 --> 00:10:07.192
MG: Yeah, I've had a lot of women say to me,

00:10:07.192 --> 00:10:09.051
"I really don't think I could work with my husband.

00:10:09.051 --> 00:10:11.198
That just wouldn't work out."

00:10:11.198 --> 00:10:14.787
You know, we enjoy it, and we don't --

00:10:14.787 --> 00:10:17.273
this foundation has been a coming to for both of us

00:10:17.273 --> 00:10:20.101
in its continuous learning journey,

00:10:20.101 --> 00:10:22.860
and we don't travel together as much

00:10:22.860 --> 00:10:24.788
for the foundation, actually, as we used to

00:10:24.788 --> 00:10:26.244
when Bill was working at Microsoft.

00:10:26.244 --> 00:10:28.467
We have more trips where
we're traveling separately,

00:10:28.467 --> 00:10:30.609
but I always know when I come home,

00:10:30.609 --> 00:10:32.748
Bill's going to be interested in what I learned,

00:10:32.748 --> 00:10:34.491
whether it's about women or girls

00:10:34.491 --> 00:10:37.177
or something new about the vaccine delivery chain,

00:10:37.177 --> 00:10:39.413
or this person that is a great leader.

00:10:39.413 --> 00:10:41.880
He's going to listen and be really interested.

00:10:41.880 --> 00:10:43.483
And he knows when he comes home,

00:10:43.483 --> 00:10:45.316
even if it's to talk about the speech he did

00:10:45.316 --> 00:10:47.058
or the data or what he's learned,

00:10:47.058 --> 00:10:48.300
I'm really interested,

00:10:48.300 --> 00:10:51.200
and I think we have a really
collaborative relationship.

00:10:51.200 --> 00:10:53.874
But we don't every minute together, that's for sure.

00:10:53.874 --> 00:10:58.049
(Laughter)

00:10:58.049 --> 00:11:00.544
CA: But now you are, and we're very happy that you are.

00:11:00.544 --> 00:11:04.130
Melinda, early on, you were basically

00:11:04.130 --> 00:11:06.131
largely running the show.

00:11:06.131 --> 00:11:07.343
Six years ago, I guess,

00:11:07.343 --> 00:11:09.926
Bill came on full time, so moved from Microsoft

00:11:09.926 --> 00:11:11.037
and became full time.

00:11:11.037 --> 00:11:12.016
That must have been hard,

00:11:12.016 --> 00:11:14.052
adjusting to that. No?

00:11:14.052 --> 00:11:17.106
MG: Yeah. I think actually,

00:11:17.106 --> 00:11:19.095
for the foundation employees,

00:11:19.095 --> 00:11:21.642
there was way more angst for them

00:11:21.642 --> 00:11:23.008
than there was for me about Bill coming.

00:11:23.008 --> 00:11:24.214
I was actually really excited.

00:11:24.214 --> 00:11:25.833
I mean, Bill made this decision

00:11:25.833 --> 00:11:28.516
even obviously before it got announced in 2006,

00:11:28.516 --> 00:11:30.218
and it was really his decision,

00:11:30.218 --> 00:11:32.104
but again, it was a beach vacation

00:11:32.104 --> 00:11:33.408
where we were walking on the beach

00:11:33.408 --> 00:11:35.672
and he was starting to think of this idea.

00:11:35.672 --> 00:11:38.284
And for me, the excitement of Bill

00:11:38.284 --> 00:11:40.993
putting his brain and his heart

00:11:40.993 --> 00:11:43.340
against these huge global problems,

00:11:43.340 --> 00:11:45.668
these inequities, to me that was exciting.

00:11:45.668 --> 00:11:49.402
Yes, the foundation employees had angst about that.

00:11:49.402 --> 00:11:51.077
(Applause)

00:11:51.077 --> 00:11:53.193
CA: That's cool.

00:11:53.193 --> 00:11:54.877
MG: But that went away within three months,

00:11:54.877 --> 00:11:55.804
once he was there.

00:11:55.804 --> 00:11:57.469
BG: Including some of the employees.

00:11:57.469 --> 00:11:58.742
MG: That's what I said, the employees,

00:11:58.742 --> 00:12:00.864
it went away for them three
months after you were there.

00:12:00.864 --> 00:12:03.184
BG: No, I'm kidding.
MG: Oh, you mean, the employees didn't go away.

00:12:03.184 --> 00:12:05.085
BG: A few of them did, but —

00:12:05.085 --> 00:12:06.918
(Laughter)

00:12:06.918 --> 00:12:08.861
CA: So what do you guys argue about?

00:12:08.861 --> 00:12:11.518
Sunday, 11 o'clock,

00:12:11.518 --> 00:12:12.939
you're away from work,

00:12:12.939 --> 00:12:15.452
what comes up? What's the argument?

00:12:15.452 --> 00:12:17.097
BG: Because we built this thing

00:12:17.097 --> 00:12:20.216
together from the beginning,

00:12:20.216 --> 00:12:21.862
it's this great partnership.

00:12:21.862 --> 00:12:23.716
I had that with Paul Allen

00:12:23.716 --> 00:12:25.627
in the early days of Microsoft.

00:12:25.627 --> 00:12:28.439
I had it with Steve Ballmer as Microsoft got bigger,

00:12:28.439 --> 00:12:31.443
and now Melinda, and in even stronger,

00:12:31.443 --> 00:12:33.329
equal ways, is the partner,

00:12:33.329 --> 00:12:35.086
so we talk a lot about

00:12:35.086 --> 00:12:37.214
which things should we give more to,

00:12:37.214 --> 00:12:39.758
which groups are working well?

00:12:39.758 --> 00:12:41.011
She's got a lot of insight.

00:12:41.011 --> 00:12:42.658
She'll sit down with the employees a lot.

00:12:42.658 --> 00:12:44.774
We'll take the different trips she described.

00:12:44.774 --> 00:12:48.391
So there's a lot of collaboration.

00:12:48.391 --> 00:12:50.367
I can't think of anything where one of us

00:12:50.367 --> 00:12:53.637
had a super strong opinion

00:12:53.637 --> 00:12:55.473
about one thing or another?

00:12:55.473 --> 00:12:58.275
CA: How about you, Melinda, 
though? Can you? (Laughter)

00:12:58.275 --> 00:12:59.491
You never know.

00:12:59.491 --> 00:13:01.017
MG: Well, here's the thing.

00:13:01.017 --> 00:13:02.756
We come at things from different angles,

00:13:02.756 --> 00:13:04.688
and I actually think that's really good.

00:13:04.688 --> 00:13:06.696
So Bill can look at the big data

00:13:06.696 --> 00:13:09.708
and say, "I want to act based
on these global statistics."

00:13:09.708 --> 00:13:11.574
For me, I come at it from intuition.

00:13:11.574 --> 00:13:13.507
I meet with lots of people on the ground

00:13:13.507 --> 00:13:15.487
and Bill's taught me to take that

00:13:15.487 --> 00:13:18.110
and read up to the global data and see if they match,

00:13:18.110 --> 00:13:19.199
and I think what I've taught him

00:13:19.199 --> 00:13:20.627
is to take that data

00:13:20.627 --> 00:13:22.241
and meet with people on the ground to understand,

00:13:22.241 --> 00:13:24.625
can you actually deliver that vaccine?

00:13:24.625 --> 00:13:27.826
Can you get a woman to accept those polio drops

00:13:27.826 --> 00:13:29.156
in her child's mouth?

00:13:29.156 --> 00:13:30.714
Because the delivery piece

00:13:30.714 --> 00:13:32.917
is every bit as important as the science.

00:13:32.917 --> 00:13:35.439
So I think it's been more a coming to over time

00:13:35.439 --> 00:13:36.734
towards each other's point of view,

00:13:36.734 --> 00:13:40.004
and quite frankly, the work is better because of it.

00:13:40.004 --> 00:13:42.277
CA: So, in vaccines and polio and so forth,

00:13:42.277 --> 00:13:46.076
you've had some amazing successes.

00:13:46.076 --> 00:13:47.308
What about failure, though?

00:13:47.308 --> 00:13:48.999
Can you talk about a failure

00:13:48.999 --> 00:13:51.095
and maybe what you've learned from it?

00:13:51.095 --> 00:13:53.663
BG: Yeah. Fortunately, we can afford a few failures,

00:13:53.663 --> 00:13:55.800
because we've certainly had them.

00:13:55.800 --> 00:14:00.174
We do a lot of drug work or vaccine work

00:14:00.174 --> 00:14:03.450
that you know you're going to have different failures.

00:14:03.450 --> 00:14:05.677
Like, we put out, one that got a lot of publicity

00:14:05.677 --> 00:14:06.978
was asking for a better condom.

00:14:06.978 --> 00:14:08.472
Well, we got hundreds of ideas.

00:14:08.472 --> 00:14:11.666
Maybe a few of those will work out.

00:14:11.666 --> 00:14:15.045
We were very naïve, certainly I was, about a drug

00:14:15.045 --> 00:14:17.661
for a disease in India, visceral leishmaniasis,

00:14:17.661 --> 00:14:19.312
that I thought, once I got this drug,

00:14:19.312 --> 00:14:20.668
we can just go wipe out the disease.

00:14:20.668 --> 00:14:23.248
Well, turns out it took an injection

00:14:23.248 --> 00:14:24.884
every day for 10 days.

00:14:24.884 --> 00:14:27.271
It took three more years to get it than we expected,

00:14:27.271 --> 00:14:28.729
and then there was no way

00:14:28.729 --> 00:14:31.097
it was going to get out there.

00:14:31.097 --> 00:14:32.316
Fortunately, we found out

00:14:32.316 --> 00:14:35.478
that if you go kill the sand flies,

00:14:35.478 --> 00:14:37.600
you probably can have success there,

00:14:37.600 --> 00:14:39.455
but we spent five years,

00:14:39.455 --> 00:14:40.833
you could say wasted five years,

00:14:40.833 --> 00:14:42.840
and about 60 million,

00:14:42.840 --> 00:14:44.180
on a path that turned out to have

00:14:44.180 --> 00:14:48.345
very modest benefit when we got there.

00:14:48.345 --> 00:14:51.789
CA: You're spending, like, a billion dollars a year

00:14:51.789 --> 00:14:53.724
in education, I think, something like that.

00:14:53.724 --> 00:14:57.748
Is anything, the story of what's gone right there

00:14:57.748 --> 00:15:00.204
is quite a long and complex one.

00:15:00.204 --> 00:15:04.126
Are there any failures that you can talk about?

00:15:04.126 --> 00:15:05.916
MG: Well, I would say a huge lesson for us

00:15:05.916 --> 00:15:07.164
out of the early work is we thought

00:15:07.164 --> 00:15:09.697
that these small schools were the answer,

00:15:09.697 --> 00:15:11.167
and small schools definitely help.

00:15:11.167 --> 00:15:12.691
They bring down the dropout rate.

00:15:12.691 --> 00:15:15.291
They have less violence and crime in those schools.

00:15:15.291 --> 00:15:17.437
But the thing that we learned from that work,

00:15:17.437 --> 00:15:19.971
and what turned out to be the fundamental key,

00:15:19.971 --> 00:15:22.035
is a great teacher in front of the classroom.

00:15:22.035 --> 00:15:23.642
If you don't have an effective teacher

00:15:23.642 --> 00:15:24.708
in the front of the classroom,

00:15:24.708 --> 00:15:26.864
I don't care how big or small the building is,

00:15:26.864 --> 00:15:28.518
you're not going to change the trajectory

00:15:28.518 --> 00:15:30.471
of whether that student will be ready for college.

00:15:30.471 --> 00:15:35.066
(Applause)

00:15:35.066 --> 00:15:37.376
CA: So Melinda, this is you and

00:15:37.376 --> 00:15:40.930
your eldest daughter, Jenn.

00:15:40.930 --> 00:15:42.829
And just taken about three weeks ago, I think,

00:15:42.829 --> 00:15:44.413
three or four weeks ago. Where was this?

00:15:44.413 --> 00:15:46.169
MG: So we went to Tanzania.

00:15:46.169 --> 00:15:47.011
Jenn's been to Tanzania.

00:15:47.011 --> 00:15:49.714
All our kids have been to Africa quite a bit, actually.

00:15:49.714 --> 00:15:51.929
And we did something very different,

00:15:51.929 --> 00:15:53.756
which is, we decided to go spend

00:15:53.756 --> 00:15:56.175
two nights and three days with a family.

00:15:56.175 --> 00:15:59.276
Anna and Sanare are the parents.

00:15:59.276 --> 00:16:02.310
They invited us to come and stay in their boma.

00:16:02.310 --> 00:16:03.809
Actually, the goats had been there, I think,

00:16:03.809 --> 00:16:05.208
living in that particular little hut

00:16:05.208 --> 00:16:07.879
on their little compound before we got there.

00:16:07.879 --> 00:16:09.377
And we stayed with their family,

00:16:09.377 --> 00:16:11.311
and we really, really learned

00:16:11.311 --> 00:16:13.164
what life is like in rural Tanzania.

00:16:13.164 --> 00:16:14.778
And the difference between just going

00:16:14.778 --> 00:16:16.497
and visiting for half a day

00:16:16.497 --> 00:16:17.959
or three quarters of a day

00:16:17.959 --> 00:16:20.357
versus staying overnight was profound,

00:16:20.357 --> 00:16:23.848
and so let me just give you one explanation of that.

00:16:23.848 --> 00:16:25.977
They had six children, and as I talked to Anna

00:16:25.977 --> 00:16:27.752
in the kitchen, we cooked for about five hours

00:16:27.752 --> 00:16:29.395
in the cooking hut that day,

00:16:29.395 --> 00:16:31.206
and as I talked to her, she had absolutely planned

00:16:31.206 --> 00:16:32.676
and spaced with her husband

00:16:32.676 --> 00:16:34.113
the births of their children.

00:16:34.113 --> 00:16:35.768
It was a very loving relationship.

00:16:35.768 --> 00:16:38.071
This was a Maasai warrior and his wife,

00:16:38.071 --> 00:16:39.980
but they had decided to get married,

00:16:39.980 --> 00:16:43.315
they clearly had respect and love in the relationship.

00:16:43.315 --> 00:16:44.926
Their children, their six children,

00:16:44.926 --> 00:16:47.445
the two in the middle were twins, 13,

00:16:47.445 --> 00:16:49.698
a boy, and a girl named Grace.

00:16:49.698 --> 00:16:51.271
And when we'd go out to chop wood

00:16:51.271 --> 00:16:53.706
and do all the things that Grace
and her mother would do,

00:16:53.706 --> 00:16:56.298
Grace was not a child, she was an adolescent,

00:16:56.298 --> 00:16:57.775
but she wasn't an adult.

00:16:57.775 --> 00:16:59.526
She was very, very shy.

00:16:59.526 --> 00:17:01.287
So she kept wanting to talk to me and Jenn.

00:17:01.287 --> 00:17:04.122
We kept trying to engage her, but she was shy.

00:17:04.122 --> 00:17:05.728
And at night, though,

00:17:05.728 --> 00:17:08.535
when all the lights went out in rural Tanzania,

00:17:08.535 --> 00:17:10.039
and there was no moon that night,

00:17:10.039 --> 00:17:11.761
the first night, and no stars,

00:17:11.761 --> 00:17:13.587
and Jenn came out of our hut

00:17:13.587 --> 00:17:16.404
with her REI little headlamp on,

00:17:16.404 --> 00:17:18.542
Grace went immediately,

00:17:18.542 --> 00:17:19.898
and got the translator,

00:17:19.898 --> 00:17:21.988
came straight up to my Jenn and said,

00:17:21.988 --> 00:17:23.221
"When you go home,

00:17:23.221 --> 00:17:24.396
can I have your headlamp

00:17:24.396 --> 00:17:26.126
so I can study at night?"

00:17:26.126 --> 00:17:27.208
CA: Oh, wow.

00:17:27.208 --> 00:17:28.692
MG: And her dad had told me

00:17:28.692 --> 00:17:30.779
how afraid he was that unlike the son,

00:17:30.779 --> 00:17:32.441
who had passed his secondary exams,

00:17:32.441 --> 00:17:33.971
because of her chores,

00:17:33.971 --> 00:17:35.409
she'd not done so well

00:17:35.409 --> 00:17:37.213
and wasn't in the government school yet.

00:17:37.213 --> 00:17:39.748
He said, "I don't know how I'm
going to pay for her education.

00:17:39.748 --> 00:17:41.574
I can't pay for private school,

00:17:41.574 --> 00:17:44.153
and she may end up on this farm like my wife."

00:17:44.153 --> 00:17:45.282
So they know the difference

00:17:45.282 --> 00:17:46.307
that an education can make

00:17:46.307 --> 00:17:49.304
in a huge, profound way.

00:17:49.304 --> 00:17:50.725
CA: I mean, this is another pic

00:17:50.725 --> 00:17:54.131
of your other two kids, Rory and Phoebe,

00:17:54.131 --> 00:17:58.269
along with Paul Farmer.

00:17:58.269 --> 00:17:59.883
Bringing up three children

00:17:59.883 --> 00:18:02.885
when you're the world's richest family

00:18:02.885 --> 00:18:05.181
seems like a social experiment

00:18:05.181 --> 00:18:08.753
without much prior art.

00:18:08.753 --> 00:18:10.288
How have you managed it?

00:18:10.288 --> 00:18:12.503
What's been your approach?

00:18:12.503 --> 00:18:15.136
BG: Well, I'd say overall

00:18:15.136 --> 00:18:16.898
the kids get a great education,

00:18:16.898 --> 00:18:17.796
but you've got to make sure

00:18:17.796 --> 00:18:19.498
they have a sense of their own ability

00:18:19.498 --> 00:18:21.487
and what they're going to go and do,

00:18:21.487 --> 00:18:23.860
and our philosophy has been

00:18:23.860 --> 00:18:25.082
to be very clear with them --

00:18:25.082 --> 00:18:26.627
most of the money's going to the foundation --

00:18:26.627 --> 00:18:30.968
and help them find something they're excited about.

00:18:30.968 --> 00:18:32.363
We want to strike a balance where they have

00:18:32.363 --> 00:18:34.156
the freedom to do anything

00:18:34.156 --> 00:18:37.496
but not a lot of money showered on them

00:18:37.496 --> 00:18:40.625
so they could go out and do nothing.

00:18:40.625 --> 00:18:43.603
And so far, they're fairly diligent,

00:18:43.603 --> 00:18:46.811
excited to pick their own direction.

00:18:46.811 --> 00:18:52.379
CA: You've obviously guarded their 
privacy carefully for obvious reasons.

00:18:52.379 --> 00:18:54.573
I'm curious why you've given me permission

00:18:54.573 --> 00:18:56.198
to show this picture now here at TED.

00:18:56.198 --> 00:18:57.335
MG: Well, it's interesting.

00:18:57.335 --> 00:18:59.176
As they get older, they so know

00:18:59.176 --> 00:19:02.185
that our family belief is about responsibility,

00:19:02.185 --> 00:19:04.300
that we are in an unbelievable situation

00:19:04.300 --> 00:19:05.918
just to live in the United States

00:19:05.918 --> 00:19:07.609
and have a great education,

00:19:07.609 --> 00:19:09.657
and we have a responsibility
to give back to the world.

00:19:09.657 --> 00:19:10.710
And so as they get older

00:19:10.710 --> 00:19:11.730
and we are teaching them --

00:19:11.730 --> 00:19:14.090
they have been to so many
countries around the world —

00:19:14.090 --> 00:19:15.222
they're saying,

00:19:15.222 --> 00:19:16.974
we do want people to know that we believe

00:19:16.974 --> 00:19:18.475
in what you're doing, Mom and Dad,

00:19:18.475 --> 00:19:20.436
and it is okay to show us more.

00:19:20.436 --> 00:19:23.088
So we have their permission to show this picture,

00:19:23.088 --> 00:19:24.803
and I think Paul Farmer is probably going to put it

00:19:24.803 --> 00:19:27.258
eventually in some of his work.

00:19:27.258 --> 00:19:28.860
But they really care deeply

00:19:28.860 --> 00:19:31.285
about the mission of the foundation, too.

00:19:31.285 --> 00:19:33.207
CA: You've easily got enough money

00:19:33.207 --> 00:19:35.798
despite your vast contributions to the foundation

00:19:35.798 --> 00:19:37.432
to make them all billionaires.

00:19:37.432 --> 00:19:38.949
Is that your plan for them?

00:19:38.949 --> 00:19:41.285
BG: Nope. No. They won't have anything like that.

00:19:41.285 --> 00:19:43.220
They need to have a sense

00:19:43.220 --> 00:19:49.756
that their own work is meaningful and important.

00:19:49.756 --> 00:19:53.228
We read an article long, actually,
before we got married,

00:19:53.228 --> 00:19:55.873
where Warren Buffett talked about that,

00:19:55.873 --> 00:19:58.122
and we're quite convinced that it wasn't a favor

00:19:58.122 --> 00:20:01.376
either to society or to the kids.

00:20:01.376 --> 00:20:03.444
CA: Well, speaking of Warren Buffett,

00:20:03.444 --> 00:20:06.108
something really amazing happened in 2006,

00:20:06.108 --> 00:20:09.068
when somehow your only real rival

00:20:09.068 --> 00:20:10.620
for richest person in America

00:20:10.620 --> 00:20:11.990
suddenly turned around and agreed to give

00:20:11.990 --> 00:20:14.583
80 percent of his fortune

00:20:14.583 --> 00:20:16.300
to your foundation.

00:20:16.300 --> 00:20:18.036
How on Earth did that happen?

00:20:18.036 --> 00:20:20.014
I guess there's a long version
and a short version of that.

00:20:20.014 --> 00:20:21.396
We've got time for the short version.

00:20:21.396 --> 00:20:25.151
BG: All right. Well, Warren was a close friend,

00:20:25.151 --> 00:20:29.808
and he was going to have his wife Suzie

00:20:29.808 --> 00:20:31.363
give it all away.

00:20:31.363 --> 00:20:34.804
Tragically, she passed away before he did,

00:20:34.804 --> 00:20:38.402
and he's big on delegation, and

00:20:38.402 --> 00:20:40.560
— (Laughter) —

00:20:40.560 --> 00:20:41.971
he said —

00:20:41.971 --> 00:20:42.826
CA: Tweet that.

00:20:42.826 --> 00:20:45.987
BG: If he's got somebody
who is doing something well,

00:20:45.987 --> 00:20:50.444
and is willing to do it at no charge,

00:20:50.444 --> 00:20:52.822
maybe that's okay. But we were stunned.

00:20:52.822 --> 00:20:54.918
MG: Totally stunned.
BG: We had never expected it,

00:20:54.918 --> 00:20:56.483
and it has been unbelievable.

00:20:56.483 --> 00:20:59.623
It's allowed us to increase our ambition

00:20:59.623 --> 00:21:03.240
in what the foundation can do quite dramatically.

00:21:03.240 --> 00:21:04.744
Half the resources we have

00:21:04.744 --> 00:21:07.628
come from Warren's mind-blowing generosity.

00:21:07.628 --> 00:21:08.512
CA: And I think you've pledged that

00:21:08.512 --> 00:21:10.302
by the time you're done,

00:21:10.302 --> 00:21:12.180
more than, or 95 percent of your wealth,

00:21:12.180 --> 00:21:14.075
will be given to the foundation.

00:21:14.075 --> 00:21:15.229
BG: Yes.

00:21:15.229 --> 00:21:18.978
CA: And since this relationship, it's amazing—

00:21:18.978 --> 00:21:22.344
(Applause)

00:21:22.344 --> 00:21:24.981
And recently, you and Warren

00:21:24.981 --> 00:21:26.861
have been going around trying to persuade

00:21:26.861 --> 00:21:28.837
other billionaires and successful people

00:21:28.837 --> 00:21:30.360
to pledge to give, what,

00:21:30.360 --> 00:21:36.118
more than half of their assets for philanthropy.

00:21:36.118 --> 00:21:38.533
How is that going?

00:21:38.533 --> 00:21:41.705
BG: Well, we've got about 120 people

00:21:41.705 --> 00:21:44.143
who have now taken this giving pledge.

00:21:44.143 --> 00:21:46.749
The thing that's great is that we get together

00:21:46.749 --> 00:21:48.858
yearly and talk about, okay,

00:21:48.858 --> 00:21:50.823
do you hire staff, what do you give to them?

00:21:50.823 --> 00:21:52.050
We're not trying to homogenize it.

00:21:52.050 --> 00:21:53.098
I mean, the beauty of philanthropy

00:21:53.098 --> 00:21:55.105
is this mind-blowing diversity.

00:21:55.105 --> 00:21:56.268
People give to some things.

00:21:56.268 --> 00:21:58.947
We look and go, "Wow."

00:21:58.947 --> 00:22:00.055
But that's great.

00:22:00.055 --> 00:22:01.184
That's the role of philanthropy

00:22:01.184 --> 00:22:03.671
is to pick different approaches,

00:22:03.671 --> 00:22:05.663
including even in one space, like education.

00:22:05.663 --> 00:22:08.034
We need more experimentation.

00:22:08.034 --> 00:22:10.938
But it's been wonderful, meeting those people,

00:22:10.938 --> 00:22:13.170
sharing their journey to philanthropy,

00:22:13.170 --> 00:22:14.274
how they involve their kids,

00:22:14.274 --> 00:22:16.108
where they're doing it differently,

00:22:16.108 --> 00:22:18.814
and it's been way more successful than we expected.

00:22:18.814 --> 00:22:21.509
Now it looks like it'll just keep growing in size

00:22:21.509 --> 00:22:24.072
in the years ahead.

00:22:24.072 --> 00:22:27.584
MG: And having people see that other people

00:22:27.584 --> 00:22:29.288
are making change with philanthropy,

00:22:29.288 --> 00:22:31.624
I mean, these are people who have

00:22:31.624 --> 00:22:32.669
created their own businesses,

00:22:32.669 --> 00:22:35.317
put their own ingenuity behind incredible ideas.

00:22:35.317 --> 00:22:37.543
If they put their ideas and their brain

00:22:37.543 --> 00:22:40.076
behind philanthropy, they can change the world.

00:22:40.076 --> 00:22:42.367
And they start to see others doing it, and saying,

00:22:42.367 --> 00:22:44.407
"Wow, I want to do that with my own money."

00:22:44.407 --> 00:22:46.451
To me, that's the piece that's incredible.

00:22:46.451 --> 00:22:49.369
CA: It seems to me, it's actually really hard

00:22:49.369 --> 00:22:50.615
for some people to figure out

00:22:50.615 --> 00:22:53.298
even how to remotely spend that much money

00:22:53.298 --> 00:22:55.471
on something else.

00:22:55.471 --> 00:22:57.564
There are probably some billionaires in the room

00:22:57.564 --> 00:22:59.673
and certainly some successful people.

00:22:59.673 --> 00:23:01.733
I'm curious, can you make the pitch?

00:23:01.733 --> 00:23:02.967
What's the pitch?

00:23:02.967 --> 00:23:04.348
BG: Well, it's the most fulfilling thing

00:23:04.348 --> 00:23:05.830
we've ever done,

00:23:05.830 --> 00:23:08.800
and you can't take it with you,

00:23:08.800 --> 00:23:11.982
and if it's not good for your kids,

00:23:11.982 --> 00:23:13.271
let's get together and brainstorm

00:23:13.271 --> 00:23:15.958
about what we can be done.

00:23:15.958 --> 00:23:18.148
The world is a far better place

00:23:18.148 --> 00:23:20.786
because of the philanthropists of the past,

00:23:20.786 --> 00:23:23.819
and the U.S. tradition here, which is the strongest,

00:23:23.819 --> 00:23:25.170
is the envy of the world.

00:23:25.170 --> 00:23:27.088
And part of the reason I'm so optimistic

00:23:27.088 --> 00:23:29.032
is because I do think philanthropy

00:23:29.032 --> 00:23:30.646
is going to grow

00:23:30.646 --> 00:23:31.765
and take some of these things

00:23:31.765 --> 00:23:34.664
government's not just good at
working on and discovering

00:23:34.664 --> 00:23:38.134
and shine some light in the right direction.

00:23:38.134 --> 00:23:41.076
CA: The world's got this terrible inequality,

00:23:41.076 --> 00:23:42.237
growing inequality problem

00:23:42.237 --> 00:23:43.698
that seems structural.

00:23:43.698 --> 00:23:46.564
It does seem to me that if more of your peers

00:23:46.564 --> 00:23:48.940
took the approach that you two have made,

00:23:48.940 --> 00:23:50.532
it would make a dent

00:23:50.532 --> 00:23:51.798
both in that problem and certainly

00:23:51.798 --> 00:23:53.398
in the perception of that problem.

00:23:53.398 --> 00:23:54.802
Is that a fair comment?

00:23:54.802 --> 00:23:56.460
BG: Oh yeah. If you take from the most wealthy

00:23:56.460 --> 00:23:59.792
and give to the least wealthy, it's good.

00:23:59.792 --> 00:24:01.924
It tries to balance out, and that's just.

00:24:01.924 --> 00:24:03.680
MG: But you change systems.

00:24:03.680 --> 00:24:06.293
In the U.S., we're trying to
change the education system

00:24:06.293 --> 00:24:08.361
so it's just for everybody

00:24:08.361 --> 00:24:09.918
and it works for all students.

00:24:09.918 --> 00:24:11.808
That, to me, really changes

00:24:11.808 --> 00:24:12.965
the inequality balance.

00:24:12.965 --> 00:24:14.547
BG: That's the most important.

00:24:14.547 --> 00:24:18.095
(Applause)

00:24:18.095 --> 00:24:21.510
CA: Well, I really think that most people here

00:24:21.510 --> 00:24:23.255
and many millions around the world

00:24:23.255 --> 00:24:25.804
are just in awe of the trajectory

00:24:25.804 --> 00:24:27.112
your lives have taken

00:24:27.112 --> 00:24:30.843
and the spectacular degree to which

00:24:30.843 --> 00:24:32.958
you have shaped the future.

00:24:32.958 --> 00:24:34.298
Thank you so much for coming to TED

00:24:34.298 --> 00:24:35.759
and for sharing with us and for all you do.

00:24:35.759 --> 00:24:37.695
BG: Thank you.
MG: Thank you.

00:24:37.695 --> 00:24:40.482
(Applause)

00:24:46.473 --> 00:24:50.868
BG: Thank you.
MG: Thank you very much.

00:24:50.868 --> 00:24:55.039
BG: All right, good job. (Applause)

title: Your social media "likes" expose more than you think
transcript: If you remember that first decade of the web, it was really a static place. You could go online, you could look at pages, and they were put up either by organizations who had teams to do it or by individuals who were really tech-savvy for the time. And with the rise of social media and social networks in the early 2000s, the web was completely changed to a place where now the vast majority of content we interact with is put up by average users, either in YouTube videos or blog posts or product reviews or social media postings. And it's also become a much more interactive place, where people are interacting with others, they're commenting, they're sharing, they're not just reading.So Facebook is not the only place you can do this, but it's the biggest, and it serves to illustrate the numbers. Facebook has 1.2 billion users per month. So half the Earth's Internet population is using Facebook. They are a site, along with others, that has allowed people to create an online persona with very little technical skill, and people responded by putting huge amounts of personal data online. So the result is that we have behavioral, preference, demographic data for hundreds of millions of people, which is unprecedented in history. And as a computer scientist,  what this means is that I've been able to build models that can predict all sorts of hidden attributes for all of you that you don't even know you're sharing information about. As scientists, we use that to help the way people interact online, but there's less altruistic applications, and there's a problem in that users don't really understand these techniques and how they work, and even if they did, they don't have a lot of control over it. So what I want to talk to you about today is some of these things that we're able to do, and then give us some ideas of how we might go forward to move some control back into the hands of users.So this is Target, the company. I didn't just put that logo on this poor, pregnant woman's belly. You may have seen this anecdote that was printed in Forbes magazine where Target sent a flyer to this 15-year-old girl with advertisements and coupons for baby bottles and diapers and cribs two weeks before she told her parents that she was pregnant. Yeah, the dad was really upset. He said, "How did Target figure out that this high school girl was pregnant before she told her parents?" It turns out that they have the purchase history for hundreds of thousands of customers and they compute what they  call a pregnancy score, which is not just whether or  not a woman's pregnant, but what her due date is. And they compute that not by looking at the obvious things, like, she's buying a crib or baby clothes, but things like, she bought more vitamins than she normally had, or she bought a handbag that's big enough to hold diapers. And by themselves, those purchases don't seem like they might reveal a lot, but it's a pattern of behavior that, when you take it in the context  of thousands of other people, starts to actually reveal some insights. So that's the kind of thing that we do when we're predicting stuff about you on social media. We're looking for little patterns of behavior that, when you detect them among millions of people, lets us find out all kinds of things.So in my lab and with colleagues, we've developed mechanisms where we can quite accurately predict things like your political preference, your personality score, gender, sexual orientation, religion, age, intelligence, along with things like how much you trust the people you know and how strong those relationships are. We can do all of this really well. And again, it doesn't come from what you might think of as obvious information.So my favorite example is from this study that was published this year in the Proceedings of the National Academies. If you Google this, you'll find it. It's four pages, easy to read. And they looked at just people's Facebook likes, so just the things you like on Facebook, and used that to predict all these attributes, along with some other ones. And in their paper they listed the five likes that were most indicative of high intelligence. And among those was liking a page for curly fries. (Laughter) Curly fries are delicious, but liking them does not necessarily mean that you're smarter than the average person. So how is it that one of the strongest indicators of your intelligence is liking this page when the content is totally irrelevant to the attribute that's being predicted? And it turns out that we have to look at a whole bunch of underlying theories to see why we're able to do this. One of them is a sociological theory called homophily, which basically says people are friends with people like them. So if you're smart, you tend to be friends with smart people, and if you're young, you tend to be friends with young people, and this is well established for hundreds of years. We also know a lot about how information spreads through networks. It turns out things like viral videos or Facebook likes or other information spreads in exactly the same way that diseases spread through social networks. So this is something we've studied for a long time. We have good models of it. And so you can put those things together and start seeing why things like this happen. So if I were to give you a hypothesis, it would be that a smart guy started this page, or maybe one of the first people who liked it would have scored high on that test. And they liked it, and their friends saw it, and by homophily, we know that he probably had smart friends, and so it spread to them,  and some of them liked it, and they had smart friends, and so it spread to them, and so it propagated through the network to a host of smart people, so that by the end, the action of liking the curly fries page is indicative of high intelligence, not because of the content, but because the actual action of liking reflects back the common attributes of other people who have done it.So this is pretty complicated stuff, right? It's a hard thing to sit down and explain to an average user, and even if you do, what can the average user do about it? How do you know that  you've liked something that indicates a trait for you that's totally irrelevant to the content of what you've liked? There's a lot of power that users don't have to control how this data is used. And I see that as a real  problem going forward.So I think there's a couple paths that we want to look at if we want to give users some control over how this data is used, because it's not always going to be used for their benefit. An example I often give is that, if I ever get bored being a professor, I'm going to go start a company that predicts all of these attributes and things like how well you work in teams and if you're a drug user, if you're an alcoholic. We know how to predict all that. And I'm going to sell reports to H.R. companies and big businesses that want to hire you. We totally can do that now. I could start that business tomorrow, and you would have absolutely no control over me using your data like that. That seems to me to be a problem.So one of the paths we can go down is the policy and law path. And in some respects, I think that that would be most effective, but the problem is we'd actually have to do it. Observing our political process in action makes me think it's highly unlikely that we're going to get a bunch of representatives to sit down, learn about this, and then enact sweeping changes to intellectual property law in the U.S. so users control their data.We could go the policy route, where social media companies say, you know what? You own your data. You have total control over how it's used. The problem is that the revenue models for most social media companies rely on sharing or exploiting  users' data in some way. It's sometimes said of Facebook that the users aren't the customer, they're the product. And so how do you get a company to cede control of their main asset back to the users? It's possible, but I don't think it's something that we're going to see change quickly.So I think the other path that we can go down that's going to be more effective is one of more science. It's doing science that allowed us to develop all these mechanisms for computing this personal data in the first place. And it's actually very similar research that we'd have to do if we want to develop mechanisms that can say to a user, "Here's the risk of that action you just took." By liking that Facebook page, or by sharing this piece of personal information, you've now improved my ability to predict whether or not you're using drugs or whether or not you get along well in the workplace. And that, I think, can affect whether or not people want to share something, keep it private, or just keep it offline altogether. We can also look at things like allowing people to encrypt data that they upload, so it's kind of invisible and worthless to sites like Facebook or third party services that access it, but that select users who the person who posted it want to see it have access to see it. This is all super exciting research from an intellectual perspective, and so scientists are going to be willing to do it. So that gives us an advantage over the law side.One of the problems that people bring up when I talk about this is, they say, you know, if people start keeping all this data private, all those methods that you've been developing to predict their traits are going to fail. And I say, absolutely, and for me, that's success, because as a scientist, my goal is not to infer information about users, it's to improve the way people interact online. And sometimes that involves inferring things about them, but if users don't want me to use that data, I think they should have the right to do that. I want users to be informed and consenting users of the tools that we develop.And so I think encouraging this kind of science and supporting researchers who want to cede some of that control back to users and away from the social media companies means that going forward, as these tools evolve and advance, means that we're going to have an educated and empowered user base, and I think all of us can agree that that's a pretty ideal way to go forward.Thank you.(Applause)
