but things like, she bought more vitamins

00:02:49.727 --> 00:02:51.444
than she normally had,

00:02:51.444 --> 00:02:52.908
or she bought a handbag

00:02:52.908 --> 00:02:54.619
that's big enough to hold diapers.

00:02:54.619 --> 00:02:56.529
And by themselves, those purchases don't seem

00:02:56.529 --> 00:02:58.998
like they might reveal a lot,

00:02:58.998 --> 00:03:00.976
but it's a pattern of behavior that,

00:03:00.976 --> 00:03:04.093
when you take it in the context 
of thousands of other people,

00:03:04.093 --> 00:03:06.850
starts to actually reveal some insights.

00:03:06.850 --> 00:03:08.643
So that's the kind of thing that we do

00:03:08.643 --> 00:03:11.210
when we're predicting stuff
about you on social media.

00:03:11.210 --> 00:03:14.006
We're looking for little
patterns of behavior that,

00:03:14.006 --> 00:03:16.688
when you detect them among millions of people,

00:03:16.688 --> 00:03:19.394
lets us find out all kinds of things.

00:03:19.394 --> 00:03:21.141
So in my lab and with colleagues,

00:03:21.141 --> 00:03:22.918
we've developed mechanisms where we can

00:03:22.918 --> 00:03:24.478
quite accurately predict things

00:03:24.478 --> 00:03:26.203
like your political preference,

00:03:26.203 --> 00:03:29.955
your personality score, gender, sexual orientation,

00:03:29.955 --> 00:03:32.828
religion, age, intelligence,

00:03:32.828 --> 00:03:34.222
along with things like

00:03:34.222 --> 00:03:36.159
how much you trust the people you know

00:03:36.159 --> 00:03:37.963
and how strong those relationships are.

00:03:37.963 --> 00:03:39.748
We can do all of this really well.

00:03:39.748 --> 00:03:41.945
And again, it doesn't come from what you might

00:03:41.945 --> 00:03:44.047
think of as obvious information.

00:03:44.047 --> 00:03:46.328
So my favorite example is from this study

00:03:46.328 --> 00:03:47.568
that was published this year

00:03:47.568 --> 00:03:49.363
in the Proceedings of the National Academies.

00:03:49.363 --> 00:03:50.648
If you Google this, you'll find it.

00:03:50.648 --> 00:03:52.520
It's four pages, easy to read.

00:03:52.520 --> 00:03:55.523
And they looked at just people's Facebook likes,

00:03:55.523 --> 00:03:57.443
so just the things you like on Facebook,

00:03:57.443 --> 00:03:59.581
and used that to predict all these attributes,

00:03:59.581 --> 00:04:01.226
along with some other ones.

00:04:01.226 --> 00:04:04.187
And in their paper they listed the five likes

00:04:04.187 --> 00:04:06.974
that were most indicative of high intelligence.

00:04:06.974 --> 00:04:09.298
And among those was liking a page

00:04:09.298 --> 00:04:11.203
for curly fries. (Laughter)

00:04:11.203 --> 00:04:13.296
Curly fries are delicious,

00:04:13.296 --> 00:04:15.826
but liking them does not necessarily mean

00:04:15.826 --> 00:04:17.906
that you're smarter than the average person.

00:04:17.906 --> 00:04:21.113
So how is it that one of the strongest indicators

00:04:21.113 --> 00:04:22.683
of your intelligence

00:04:22.683 --> 00:04:24.130
is liking this page

00:04:24.130 --> 00:04:26.382
when the content is totally irrelevant

00:04:26.382 --> 00:04:28.909
to the attribute that's being predicted?

00:04:28.909 --> 00:04:30.493
And it turns out that we have to look at

00:04:30.493 --> 00:04:32.111
a whole bunch of underlying theories

00:04:32.111 --> 00:04:34.680
to see why we're able to do this.

00:04:34.680 --> 00:04:37.593
One of them is a sociological
theory called homophily,

00:04:37.593 --> 00:04:40.685
which basically says people are
friends with people like them.

00:04:40.685 --> 00:04:42.699
So if you're smart, you tend to
be friends with smart people,

00:04:42.699 --> 00:04:45.329
and if you're young, you tend
to be friends with young people,

00:04:45.329 --> 00:04:46.956
and this is well established

00:04:46.956 --> 00:04:48.701
for hundreds of years.

00:04:48.701 --> 00:04:49.933
We also know a lot

00:04:49.933 --> 00:04:52.483
about how information spreads through networks.

00:04:52.483 --> 00:04:54.237
It turns out things like viral videos

00:04:54.237 --> 00:04:56.643
or Facebook likes or other information

00:04:56.643 --> 00:04:58.531
spreads in exactly the same way

00:04:58.531 --> 00:05:00.985
that diseases spread through social networks.

00:05:00.985 --> 00:05:02.776
So this is something we've studied for a long time.

00:05:02.776 --> 00:05:04.352
We have good models of it.

00:05:04.352 --> 00:05:06.509
And so you can put those things together

00:05:06.509 --> 00:05:09.597
and start seeing why things like this happen.

00:05:09.597 --> 00:05:11.411
So if I were to give you a hypothesis,

00:05:11.411 --> 00:05:14.638
it would be that a smart guy started this page,

00:05:14.638 --> 00:05:16.577
or maybe one of the first people who liked it

00:05:16.577 --> 00:05:18.313
would have scored high on that test.

00:05:18.313 --> 00:05:20.601
And they liked it, and their friends saw it,

00:05:20.601 --> 00:05:23.723
and by homophily, we know that
he probably had smart friends,

00:05:23.723 --> 00:05:26.779
and so it spread to them, 
and some of them liked it,

00:05:26.779 --> 00:05:27.968
and they had smart friends,

00:05:27.968 --> 00:05:28.775
and so it spread to them,

00:05:28.775 --> 00:05:30.748
and so it propagated through the network

00:05:30.748 --> 00:05:33.317
to a host of smart people,

00:05:33.317 --> 00:05:35.373
so that by the end, the action

00:05:35.373 --> 00:05:37.917
of liking the curly fries page

00:05:37.917 --> 00:05:39.532
is indicative of high intelligence,

00:05:39.532 --> 00:05:41.335
not because of the content,

00:05:41.335 --> 00:05:43.857
but because the actual action of liking

00:05:43.857 --> 00:05:45.757
reflects back the common attributes

00:05:45.757 --> 00:05:48.225
of other people who have done it.

00:05:48.225 --> 00:05:51.122
So this is pretty complicated stuff, right?

00:05:51.122 --> 00:05:53.321
It's a hard thing to sit down and explain

00:05:53.321 --> 00:05:56.169
to an average user, and even if you do,

00:05:56.169 --> 00:05:58.357
what can the average user do about it?

00:05:58.357 --> 00:06:00.405
How do you know that 
you've liked something

00:06:00.405 --> 00:06:01.897
that indicates a trait for you

00:06:01.897 --> 00:06:05.442
that's totally irrelevant to the
content of what you've liked?

00:06:05.442 --> 00:06:07.988
There's a lot of power that users don't have

00:06:07.988 --> 00:06:10.218
to control how this data is used.

00:06:10.218 --> 00:06:13.330
And I see that as a real 
problem going forward.

00:06:13.330 --> 00:06:15.307
So I think there's a couple paths

00:06:15.307 --> 00:06:16.308
that we want to look at

00:06:16.308 --> 00:06:18.218
if we want to give users some control

00:06:18.218 --> 00:06:19.958
over how this data is used,

00:06:19.958 --> 00:06:21.898
because it's not always going to be used

00:06:21.898 --> 00:06:23.279
for their benefit.

00:06:23.279 --> 00:06:24.701
An example I often give is that,

00:06:24.701 --> 00:06:26.347
if I ever get bored being a professor,

00:06:26.347 --> 00:06:28.000
I'm going to go start a company

00:06:28.000 --> 00:06:29.454
that predicts all of these attributes

00:06:29.454 --> 00:06:31.056
and things like how well you work in teams

00:06:31.056 --> 00:06:33.727
and if you're a drug user, if you're an alcoholic.

00:06:33.727 --> 00:06:35.167
We know how to predict all that.

00:06:35.167 --> 00:06:36.928
And I'm going to sell reports

00:06:36.928 --> 00:06:39.028
to H.R. companies and big businesses

00:06:39.028 --> 00:06:41.301
that want to hire you.

00:06:41.301 --> 00:06:42.478
We totally can do that now.

00:06:42.478 --> 00:06:44.266
I could start that business tomorrow,

00:06:44.266 --> 00:06:46.318
and you would have
absolutely no control

00:06:46.318 --> 00:06:48.456
over me using your data like that.

00:06:48.456 --> 00:06:50.748
That seems to me to be a problem.

00:06:50.748 --> 00:06:52.658
So one of the paths we can go down

00:06:52.658 --> 00:06:54.690
is the policy and law path.

00:06:54.690 --> 00:06:57.736
And in some respects, I think
that that would be most effective,

00:06:57.736 --> 00:07:00.492
but the problem is we'd
actually have to do it.

00:07:00.492 --> 00:07:03.272
Observing our political process in action

00:07:03.272 --> 00:07:05.651
makes me think it's highly unlikely

00:07:05.651 --> 00:07:07.248
that we're going to get a bunch of representatives

00:07:07.248 --> 00:07:09.234
to sit down, learn about this,

00:07:09.234 --> 00:07:11.340
and then enact sweeping changes

00:07:11.340 --> 00:07:13.497
to intellectual property law in the U.S.

00:07:13.497 --> 00:07:15.958
so users control their data.

00:07:15.958 --> 00:07:17.262
We could go the policy route,

00:07:17.262 --> 00:07:18.741
where social media companies say,

00:07:18.741 --> 00:07:20.143
you know what? You own your data.

00:07:20.143 --> 00:07:22.632
You have total control over how it's used.

00:07:22.632 --> 00:07:24.480
The problem is that the revenue models

00:07:24.480 --> 00:07:26.204
for most social media companies

00:07:26.204 --> 00:07:30.235
rely on sharing or exploiting 
users' data in some way.

00:07:30.235 --> 00:07:32.068
It's sometimes said of Facebook that the users

00:07:32.068 --> 00:07:34.596
aren't the customer, they're the product.

00:07:34.596 --> 00:07:37.310
And so how do you get a company

00:07:37.310 --> 00:07:39.868
to cede control of their main asset

00:07:39.868 --> 00:07:41.117
back to the users?

00:07:41.117 --> 00:07:42.818
It's possible, but I don't think it's something

00:07:42.818 --> 00:07:45.138
that we're going to see change quickly.

00:07:45.138 --> 00:07:46.638
So I think the other path

00:07:46.638 --> 00:07:48.926
that we can go down that's
going to be more effective

00:07:48.926 --> 00:07:50.434
is one of more science.

00:07:50.434 --> 00:07:52.944
It's doing science that allowed us to develop

00:07:52.944 --> 00:07:54.694
all these mechanisms for computing

00:07:54.694 --> 00:07:56.746
this personal data in the first place.

00:07:56.746 --> 00:07:58.852
And it's actually very similar research

00:07:58.852 --> 00:08:00.290
that we'd have to do

00:08:00.290 --> 00:08:02.676
if we want to develop mechanisms

00:08:02.676 --> 00:08:04.097
that can say to a user,

00:08:04.097 --> 00:08:06.326
"Here's the risk of that action you just took."

00:08:06.326 --> 00:08:08.406
By liking that Facebook page,

00:08:08.406 --> 00:08:10.941
or by sharing this piece of personal information,

00:08:10.941 --> 00:08:12.443
you've now improved my ability

00:08:12.443 --> 00:08:14.529
to predict whether or not you're using drugs

00:08:14.529 --> 00:08:17.391
or whether or not you get
along well in the workplace.

00:08:17.391 --> 00:08:19.239
And that, I think, can affect whether or not

00:08:19.239 --> 00:08:20.749
people want to share something,

00:08:20.749 --> 00:08:23.988
keep it private, or just keep it offline altogether.

00:08:23.988 --> 00:08:25.551
We can also look at things like

00:08:25.551 --> 00:08:28.279
allowing people to encrypt data that they upload,

00:08:28.279 --> 00:08:30.134
so it's kind of invisible and worthless

00:08:30.134 --> 00:08:31.565
to sites like Facebook

00:08:31.565 --> 00:08:34.194
or third party services that access it,

00:08:34.194 --> 00:08:37.441
but that select users who the person who posted it

00:08:37.441 --> 00:08:40.111
want to see it have access to see it.

00:08:40.111 --> 00:08:42.277
This is all super exciting research

00:08:42.277 --> 00:08:43.897
from an intellectual perspective,

00:08:43.897 --> 00:08:45.756
and so scientists are going to be willing to do it.

00:08:45.756 --> 00:08:49.366
So that gives us an advantage over the law side.

00:08:49.366 --> 00:08:51.091
One of the problems that people bring up

00:08:51.091 --> 00:08:52.686
when I talk about this is, they say,

00:08:52.686 --> 00:08:55.332
you know, if people start
keeping all this data private,

00:08:55.332 --> 00:08:57.445
all those methods that you've been developing

00:08:57.445 --> 00:09:00.098
to predict their traits are going to fail.

00:09:00.098 --> 00:09:03.618
And I say, absolutely, and for me, that's success,

00:09:03.618 --> 00:09:05.404
because as a scientist,

00:09:05.404 --> 00:09:09.092
my goal is not to infer information about users,

00:09:09.092 --> 00:09:11.859
it's to improve the way people interact online.

00:09:11.859 --> 00:09:15.077
And sometimes that involves
inferring things about them,

00:09:15.077 --> 00:09:18.099
but if users don't want me to use that data,

00:09:18.099 --> 00:09:20.137
I think they should have the right to do that.

00:09:20.137 --> 00:09:22.788
I want users to be informed and consenting

00:09:22.788 --> 00:09:24.900
users of the tools that we develop.

00:09:24.900 --> 00:09:27.852
And so I think encouraging this kind of science

00:09:27.852 --> 00:09:29.198
and supporting researchers

00:09:29.198 --> 00:09:32.221
who want to cede some of that control back to users

00:09:32.221 --> 00:09:34.532
and away from the social media companies

00:09:34.532 --> 00:09:37.203
means that going forward, as these tools evolve

00:09:37.203 --> 00:09:38.679
and advance,

00:09:38.679 --> 00:09:40.093
means that we're going to have an educated

00:09:40.093 --> 00:09:41.787
and empowered user base,

00:09:41.787 --> 00:09:42.887
and I think all of us can agree

00:09:42.887 --> 00:09:45.451
that that's a pretty ideal way to go forward.

00:09:45.451 --> 00:09:47.635
Thank you.

00:09:47.635 --> 00:09:50.715
(Applause)

title: The unstoppable walk to political reform
transcript: So a chip, a poet and a boy.It's just about 20 years ago, June 1994, when Intel announced that there was a flaw at the core of their Pentium chip. Deep in the code of the SRT algorithm to calculate intermediate quotients necessary for iterative floating points of divisions — I don't know what that means, but  it's what it says on Wikipedia — there was a flaw and an error that meant that there was a certain probability that the result of the calculation would be an error, and the probability was one out of every 360 billion calculations. So Intel said your average spreadsheet would be flawed once every 27,000 years. They didn't think it was significant, but there was an outrage in the community. The community, the techies, said, this flaw has to be addressed. They were not going to stand by quietly as Intel gave them these chips. So there was a revolution across the world. People marched to demand — okay, not really exactly like that — but they rose up and they demanded that Intel fix the flaw. And Intel set aside 475 million dollars to fund the replacement of millions of chips to fix the flaw. So billions of dollars in our society was spent to address a problem which would come once out of every 360 billion calculations.Number two, a poet. This is Martin Niemöller. You're familiar with his poetry. Around the height of the Nazi period, he started repeating the verse, "First they came for the communists, and I did nothing, did not speak out because I was not a communist. Then they came for the socialists. Then they came for the trade unions. Then they came for the Jews. And then they came for me. But there was no one left to speak for me." Now, Niemöller is offering a certain kind of insight. This is an insight at the core of intelligence. We could call it cluefulness. It's a certain kind of test: Can you recognize an underlying threat and respond? Can you save yourself or save your kind? Turns out ants are pretty good at this. Cows, not so much. So can you see the pattern? Can you see a pattern and then recognize and do something about it? Number two. Number three, a boy. This is my friend Aaron Swartz. He's Tim's friend. He's friends of many of you in this audience, and seven years ago, Aaron came to me with a question. It was just before I was going to give my first TED Talk. I was so proud. I was telling him about my talk, "Laws that choke creativity." And Aaron looked at me and was a little impatient, and he said, "So how are you ever going to solve the problems you're talking about? Copyright policy, Internet policy, how are you ever going to address those problems so long as there's this fundamental corruption in the way our government works?"So I was a little put off by this. He wasn't sharing in my celebration. And I said to him, "You know, Aaron, it's not my field, not my field."He said, "You mean as an academic, it's not your field?"I said, "Yeah, as an academic, it's not my field."He said, "What about as a citizen? As a citizen."Now, this is the way Aaron was. He didn't tell. He asked questions. But his questions spoke as clearly as my four-year-old's hug. He was saying to me, "You've got to get a clue. You have got to get a clue, because there is a flaw at the core of the operating system of this democracy, and it's not a flaw every one out of 360 billion times our democracy tries to make a decision. It is every time, every single important issue. We've got to end the bovinity of this political society. We've got to adopt, it turns out, the word is fourmi-formatic attitude — that's what the Internet tells me the word is — the ant's appreciative attitude that gets us to recognize this flaw, save our kind and save our demos.Now if you know Aaron Swartz, you know that we lost him just over a year ago. It was about six weeks before I gave my TED Talk, and I was so grateful to Chris that he asked me to give this TED Talk, not because I had the chance to talk to you, although that was great, but because it pulled me out of an extraordinary depression. I couldn't begin to describe the sadness. Because I had to focus. I had to focus on, what was I going to say to you? It saved me.But after the buzz, the excitement, the power that comes from this community, I began to yearn for a less sterile, less academic way to address these issues, the issues that I was talking about. We'd begun to focus on New Hampshire as a target for this political movement, because the primary in New Hampshire is so incredibly important. It was a group called the New Hampshire Rebellion that was beginning to talk about, how would we make this issue of this corruption central in 2016? But it was another soul that caught my imagination, a woman named Doris Haddock, aka Granny D. On January 1, 1999, 15 years ago, at the age of 88, Granny D started a walk. She started in Los Angeles and began to walk to Washington, D.C. with a single sign on her chest that said, "campaign finance reform." Eighteen months later, at the age of 90, she arrived in Washington with hundreds following her, including many congressmen who had gotten in a car and driven out about a mile outside of the city to walk in with her. (Laughter)Now, I don't have 13 months to walk across the country. I've got three kids who hate to walk, and a wife who, it turns out, still hates when I'm not there for mysterious reasons, so this was not an option, but the question I asked, could we remix Granny D a bit? What about a walk not of 3,200 miles but of 185 miles across New Hampshire in January?So on January 11, the anniversary of Aaron's death, we began a walk that ended on January 24th, the day that Granny D was born. A total of 200 people joined us across this walk, as we went from the very top to the very bottom of New Hampshire talking about this issue. And what was astonishing to me, something I completely did not expect to find, was the passion and anger that there was among everyone that we talked to about this issue. We had found in a poll that 96 percent of Americans believe it important to reduce the influence of money in politics. Now politicians and pundits tell you, there's nothing we can do about this issue, Americans don't care about it, but the reason for that is that 91 percent of Americans think there's nothing that can be done about this issue. And it's this gap between 96 and 91 that explains our politics of resignation. I mean, after all, at least 96 percent of us wish we could fly like Superman, but because at least 91 percent of us believe we can't, we don't leap off of tall buildings every time we have that urge. That's because we accept our limits, and so too with this reform. But when you give people the sense of hope, you begin to thaw that absolute sense of impossibility. As Harvey Milk said, if you give 'em hope, you give 'em a chance, a way to think about how this change is possible. Hope. And hope is the one thing that we, Aaron's friends, failed him with, because we let him lose that sense of hope. I loved that boy like I love my son. But we failed him. And I love my country, and I'm not going to fail that. I'm not going to fail that. That sense of hope, we're going to hold, and we're going to fight for, however impossible this battle looks.What's next? Well, we started with this march with 200 people, and next year, there will be 1,000 on different routes that march in the month of January and meet in Concord to celebrate this cause, and then in 2016, before the primary, there will be 10,000 who march across that state, meeting in Concord to celebrate this cause. And as we have marched, people around the country have begun to say, "Can we do the same thing in our state?" So we've started a platform called G.D. Walkers, that is, Granny D walkers, and Granny D walkers across the country will be marching for this reform. Number one. Number two, on this march, one of the founders of Thunderclap, David Cascino, was with us, and he said, "Well what can we do?" And so they developed a platform, which we are announcing today, that allows us to pull together voters who are committed to this idea of reform. Regardless of where you are, in New Hampshire or outside of New Hampshire, you can sign up and directly be informed where the candidates are on this issue so you can decide who to vote for as a function of which is going to make this possibility real. And then finally number three, the hardest. We're in the age of the Super PAC. Indeed yesterday, Merriam announced that Merriam-Webster will have Super PAC as a word. It is now an official word in the dictionary. So on May 1, aka May Day, we're going to try an experiment. We're going to try a launching of what we can think of as a Super PAC to end all Super PACs. And the basic way this works is this. For the last year, we have been working with analysts and political experts to calculate, how much would it cost to win enough votes in the United States Congress to make fundamental reform possible? What is that number? Half a billion? A billion? What is that number? And then whatever that number is, we are going to kickstart, sort of, because you can't use KickStarter for political work, but anyway, kickstart, sort of, first a bottom-up campaign where people will make small dollar commitments contingent on reaching very ambitious goals, and when those goals have been reached, we will turn to the large dollar contributors, to get them to contribute to make it possible for us to run the kind of Super PAC necessary to win this issue, to change the way money influences politics, so that on November 8, which I discovered yesterday is the day that Aaron would have been 30 years old, on November 8, we will celebrate 218 representatives in the House and 60 Senators in the United States Senate who have committed to this idea of fundamental reform.So last night, we heard about wishes. Here's my wish. May one. May the ideals of one boy unite one nation behind one critical idea that we are one people, we are the people who were promised a government, a government that was promised to be dependent upon the people alone, the people, who, as Madison told us, meant not the rich more than the poor. May one. And then may you, may you join this movement, not because you're a politician, not because you're an expert, not because this is your field, but because if you are, you are a citizen. Aaron asked me that. Now I've asked you.Thank you very much.(Applause)

00:00:28.777 --> 00:00:31.158
Deep in the code of the SRT algorithm

00:00:31.158 --> 00:00:33.409
to calculate intermediate quotients necessary

00:00:33.409 --> 00:00:35.243
for iterative floating points of divisions --

00:00:35.243 --> 00:00:38.342
I don't know what that means, but 
it's what it says on Wikipedia —

00:00:38.342 --> 00:00:41.221
there was a flaw and an error

00:00:41.221 --> 00:00:43.437
that meant that there was a certain probability

00:00:43.437 --> 00:00:46.445
that the result of the calculation would be an error,

00:00:46.445 --> 00:00:49.038
and the probability was one out of every

00:00:49.038 --> 00:00:52.575
360 billion calculations.

00:00:52.575 --> 00:00:54.569
So Intel said your average spreadsheet

00:00:54.569 --> 00:00:59.075
would be flawed once every 27,000 years.

00:00:59.075 --> 00:01:00.369
They didn't think it was significant,

00:01:00.369 --> 00:01:03.595
but there was an outrage in the community.

00:01:03.595 --> 00:01:05.945
The community, the techies, said, this flaw

00:01:05.945 --> 00:01:07.026
has to be addressed.

00:01:07.026 --> 00:01:09.027
They were not going to stand by quietly

00:01:09.027 --> 00:01:10.975
as Intel gave them these chips.

00:01:10.975 --> 00:01:13.021
So there was a revolution across the world.

00:01:13.021 --> 00:01:16.051
People marched to demand --

00:01:16.051 --> 00:01:18.160
okay, not really exactly like that —

00:01:18.160 --> 00:01:20.901
but they rose up and they demanded

00:01:20.901 --> 00:01:23.893
that Intel fix the flaw.

00:01:23.893 --> 00:01:29.745
And Intel set aside 475 million dollars

00:01:29.745 --> 00:01:31.987
to fund the replacement of millions of chips

00:01:31.987 --> 00:01:33.078
to fix the flaw.

00:01:33.078 --> 00:01:35.290
So billions of dollars in our society

00:01:35.290 --> 00:01:37.474
was spent to address a problem

00:01:37.474 --> 00:01:41.565
which would come once out of every 360 billion

00:01:41.565 --> 00:01:43.652
calculations.

00:01:43.652 --> 00:01:46.255
Number two, a poet.

00:01:46.255 --> 00:01:48.535
This is Martin Niemöller.

00:01:48.535 --> 00:01:50.068
You're familiar with his poetry.

00:01:50.068 --> 00:01:51.844
Around the height of the Nazi period,

00:01:51.844 --> 00:01:54.116
he started repeating the verse,

00:01:54.116 --> 00:01:55.851
"First they came for the communists,

00:01:55.851 --> 00:01:57.382
and I did nothing,

00:01:57.382 --> 00:01:59.632
did not speak out because I was not a communist.

00:01:59.632 --> 00:02:00.686
Then they came for the socialists.

00:02:00.686 --> 00:02:02.648
Then they came for the trade unions.

00:02:02.648 --> 00:02:03.894
Then they came for the Jews.

00:02:03.894 --> 00:02:06.796
And then they came for me.

00:02:06.796 --> 00:02:11.467
But there was no one left to speak for me."

00:02:11.467 --> 00:02:14.596
Now, Niemöller is offering a certain kind of insight.

00:02:14.596 --> 00:02:17.928
This is an insight at the core of intelligence.

00:02:17.928 --> 00:02:20.642
We could call it cluefulness.

00:02:20.642 --> 00:02:23.203
It's a certain kind of test:

00:02:23.203 --> 00:02:24.995
Can you recognize

00:02:24.995 --> 00:02:27.499
an underlying threat and respond?

00:02:27.499 --> 00:02:30.989
Can you save yourself or save your kind?

00:02:30.989 --> 00:02:32.728
Turns out ants are pretty good at this.

00:02:32.728 --> 00:02:34.811
Cows, not so much.

00:02:34.811 --> 00:02:37.241
So can you see the pattern?

00:02:37.241 --> 00:02:39.588
Can you see a pattern and then recognize

00:02:39.588 --> 00:02:43.640
and do something about it? Number two.

00:02:43.640 --> 00:02:45.567
Number three, a boy.

00:02:45.567 --> 00:02:47.868
This is my friend Aaron Swartz.

00:02:47.868 --> 00:02:49.299
He's Tim's friend.

00:02:49.299 --> 00:02:51.331
He's friends of many of you in this audience,

00:02:51.331 --> 00:02:52.756
and seven years ago,

00:02:52.756 --> 00:02:55.742
Aaron came to me with a question.

00:02:55.742 --> 00:02:58.325
It was just before I was going
to give my first TED Talk.

00:02:58.325 --> 00:03:00.748
I was so proud. I was telling him about my talk,

00:03:00.748 --> 00:03:03.255
"Laws that choke creativity."

00:03:03.255 --> 00:03:04.864
And Aaron looked at me

00:03:04.864 --> 00:03:06.815
and was a little impatient, and he said,

00:03:06.815 --> 00:03:10.908
"So how are you ever

00:03:10.908 --> 00:03:12.948
going to solve the problems you're talking about?

00:03:12.948 --> 00:03:14.750
Copyright policy, Internet policy,

00:03:14.750 --> 00:03:17.940
how are you ever going to address those problems

00:03:17.940 --> 00:03:21.173
so long as there's this fundamental corruption

00:03:21.173 --> 00:03:24.018
in the way our government works?"

00:03:24.018 --> 00:03:26.623
So I was a little put off by this.

00:03:26.623 --> 00:03:28.608
He wasn't sharing in my celebration.

00:03:28.608 --> 00:03:29.775
And I said to him, "You know, Aaron,

00:03:29.775 --> 00:03:32.869
it's not my field, not my field."

00:03:32.869 --> 00:03:35.425
He said, "You mean as an
academic, it's not your field?"

00:03:35.425 --> 00:03:38.019
I said, "Yeah, as an academic, it's not my field."

00:03:38.019 --> 00:03:41.350
He said, "What about as a citizen?

00:03:41.350 --> 00:03:44.777
As a citizen."

00:03:44.777 --> 00:03:46.373
Now, this is the way Aaron was.

00:03:46.373 --> 00:03:51.434
He didn't tell. He asked questions.

00:03:51.434 --> 00:03:53.184
But his questions spoke as clearly

00:03:53.184 --> 00:03:55.872
as my four-year-old's hug.

00:03:55.872 --> 00:03:57.288
He was saying to me,

00:03:57.288 --> 00:03:59.220
"You've got to get a clue.

00:03:59.220 --> 00:04:00.896
You have got to get a clue, because there is

00:04:00.896 --> 00:04:03.958
a flaw at the core of the operating system

00:04:03.958 --> 00:04:05.465
of this democracy,

00:04:05.465 --> 00:04:09.763
and it's not a flaw every one out of 360 billion times

00:04:09.763 --> 00:04:11.555
our democracy tries to make a decision.

00:04:11.555 --> 00:04:13.376
It is every time,

00:04:13.376 --> 00:04:15.772
every single important issue.

00:04:15.772 --> 00:04:20.305
We've got to end the bovinity of this political society.

00:04:20.305 --> 00:04:21.948
We've got to adopt, it turns out,

00:04:21.948 --> 00:04:24.720
the word is fourmi-formatic attitude --

00:04:24.720 --> 00:04:26.490
that's what the Internet tells me the word is --

00:04:26.490 --> 00:04:28.562
the ant's appreciative attitude

00:04:28.562 --> 00:04:31.200
that gets us to recognize this flaw,

00:04:31.200 --> 00:04:37.013
save our kind and save our demos.

00:04:37.013 --> 00:04:38.491
Now if you know Aaron Swartz,

00:04:38.491 --> 00:04:42.129
you know that we lost him

00:04:42.129 --> 00:04:44.461
just over a year ago.

00:04:44.461 --> 00:04:45.997
It was about six weeks

00:04:45.997 --> 00:04:47.877
before I gave my TED Talk,

00:04:47.877 --> 00:04:49.772
and I was so grateful to Chris

00:04:49.772 --> 00:04:51.203
that he asked me to give this TED Talk,

00:04:51.203 --> 00:04:53.403
not because I had the chance to talk to you,

00:04:53.403 --> 00:04:55.687
although that was great,

00:04:55.687 --> 00:04:59.120
but because it pulled me out
of an extraordinary depression.

00:04:59.120 --> 00:05:03.629
I couldn't begin to describe the sadness.

00:05:03.629 --> 00:05:04.909
Because I had to focus.

00:05:04.909 --> 00:05:09.224
I had to focus on, what was I going to say to you?

00:05:09.224 --> 00:05:11.426
It saved me.

00:05:11.426 --> 00:05:13.375
But after the buzz, the excitement,

00:05:13.375 --> 00:05:17.850
the power that comes from this community,

00:05:17.850 --> 00:05:20.401
I began to yearn for a less sterile,

00:05:20.401 --> 00:05:22.918
less academic way to address these issues,

00:05:22.918 --> 00:05:26.707
the issues that I was talking about.

00:05:26.707 --> 00:05:28.563
We'd begun to focus on New Hampshire

00:05:28.563 --> 00:05:31.231
as a target for this political movement,

00:05:31.231 --> 00:05:33.768
because the primary in New Hampshire

00:05:33.768 --> 00:05:35.558
is so incredibly important.

00:05:35.558 --> 00:05:38.159
It was a group called the New Hampshire Rebellion

00:05:38.159 --> 00:05:40.477
that was beginning to talk about, how would we make

00:05:40.477 --> 00:05:43.727
this issue of this corruption central in 2016?

00:05:43.727 --> 00:05:47.168
But it was another soul that caught my imagination,

00:05:47.168 --> 00:05:52.505
a woman named Doris Haddock, aka Granny D.

00:05:52.505 --> 00:05:55.867
On January 1, 1999, 15 years ago,

00:05:55.867 --> 00:06:00.696
at the age of 88, Granny D started a walk.

00:06:00.696 --> 00:06:03.966
She started in Los Angeles

00:06:03.966 --> 00:06:06.928
and began to walk to Washington, D.C.

00:06:06.928 --> 00:06:09.656
with a single sign on her chest that said,

00:06:09.656 --> 00:06:12.240
"campaign finance reform."

00:06:12.240 --> 00:06:14.968
Eighteen months later,

00:06:14.968 --> 00:06:16.778
at the age of 90,

00:06:16.778 --> 00:06:19.304
she arrived in Washington
with hundreds following her,

00:06:19.304 --> 00:06:21.622
including many congressmen
who had gotten in a car

00:06:21.622 --> 00:06:24.530
and driven out about a mile outside of the city

00:06:24.530 --> 00:06:26.418
to walk in with her.

00:06:26.418 --> 00:06:28.560
(Laughter)

00:06:28.560 --> 00:06:31.850
Now, I don't have 13 months

00:06:31.850 --> 00:06:33.492
to walk across the country.

00:06:33.492 --> 00:06:36.134
I've got three kids who hate to walk,

00:06:36.134 --> 00:06:37.536
and a wife who, it turns out,

00:06:37.536 --> 00:06:39.434
still hates when I'm not there

00:06:39.434 --> 00:06:40.603
for mysterious reasons,

00:06:40.603 --> 00:06:41.908
so this was not an option,

00:06:41.908 --> 00:06:43.068
but the question I asked,

00:06:43.068 --> 00:06:45.616
could we remix Granny D a bit?

00:06:45.616 --> 00:06:47.748
What about a walk not of 3,200 miles

00:06:47.748 --> 00:06:51.668
but of 185 miles across New Hampshire

00:06:51.668 --> 00:06:55.272
in January?

00:06:55.272 --> 00:06:57.498
So on January 11,

00:06:57.498 --> 00:07:00.384
the anniversary of Aaron's death,

00:07:00.384 --> 00:07:04.127
we began a walk that ended on January 24th,

00:07:04.127 --> 00:07:08.473
the day that Granny D was born.

00:07:08.473 --> 00:07:13.053
A total of 200 people joined us across this walk,

00:07:13.053 --> 00:07:16.827
as we went from the very top to the
very bottom of New Hampshire

00:07:16.827 --> 00:07:19.223
talking about this issue.

00:07:19.223 --> 00:07:20.823
And what was astonishing to me,

00:07:20.823 --> 00:07:23.384
something I completely did not expect to find,

00:07:23.384 --> 00:07:25.979
was the passion and anger

00:07:25.979 --> 00:07:31.454
that there was among everyone
that we talked to about this issue.

00:07:31.454 --> 00:07:36.560
We had found in a poll that 96 percent of Americans

00:07:36.560 --> 00:07:38.399
believe it important to reduce the influence

00:07:38.399 --> 00:07:40.645
of money in politics.

00:07:40.645 --> 00:07:42.661
Now politicians and pundits tell you,

00:07:42.661 --> 00:07:44.481
there's nothing we can do about this issue,

00:07:44.481 --> 00:07:45.817
Americans don't care about it,

00:07:45.817 --> 00:07:48.113
but the reason for that is

00:07:48.113 --> 00:07:49.967
that 91 percent of Americans

00:07:49.967 --> 00:07:54.489
think there's nothing that can
be done about this issue.

00:07:54.489 --> 00:07:57.311
And it's this gap between 96 and 91

00:07:57.311 --> 00:07:59.788
that explains our politics of resignation.

00:07:59.788 --> 00:08:01.871
I mean, after all, at least 96 percent of us

00:08:01.871 --> 00:08:03.733
wish we could fly like Superman,

00:08:03.733 --> 00:08:06.897
but because at least 91 percent
of us believe we can't,

00:08:06.897 --> 00:08:09.563
we don't leap off of tall buildings every time

00:08:09.563 --> 00:08:10.873
we have that urge.

00:08:10.873 --> 00:08:12.879
That's because we accept our limits,

00:08:12.879 --> 00:08:15.638
and so too with this reform.

00:08:15.638 --> 00:08:19.931
But when you give people the sense of hope,

00:08:19.931 --> 00:08:26.648
you begin to thaw that
absolute sense of impossibility.

00:08:26.648 --> 00:08:30.263
As Harvey Milk said, if you give 'em hope,

00:08:30.263 --> 00:08:32.978
you give 'em a chance, a way to think

00:08:32.978 --> 00:08:35.067
about how this change is possible.

00:08:35.067 --> 00:08:37.918
Hope.

00:08:37.918 --> 00:08:41.488
And hope is the one thing that we, Aaron's friends,

00:08:41.488 --> 00:08:44.485
failed him with, because we let him

00:08:44.485 --> 00:08:50.085
lose that sense of hope.

00:08:50.085 --> 00:08:54.037
I loved that boy like I love my son.

00:08:58.191 --> 00:09:02.160
But we failed him.

00:09:02.160 --> 00:09:05.748
And I love my country,

00:09:05.748 --> 00:09:08.102
and I'm not going to fail that.

00:09:08.102 --> 00:09:09.274
I'm not going to fail that.

00:09:09.274 --> 00:09:12.967
That sense of hope, we're going to hold,

00:09:12.967 --> 00:09:14.433
and we're going to fight for,

00:09:14.433 --> 00:09:19.133
however impossible this battle looks.

00:09:19.133 --> 00:09:20.427
What's next?

00:09:20.427 --> 00:09:23.588
Well, we started with this march with 200 people,

00:09:23.588 --> 00:09:26.990
and next year, there will be 1,000

00:09:26.990 --> 00:09:28.629
on different routes

00:09:28.629 --> 00:09:31.139
that march in the month of January

00:09:31.139 --> 00:09:34.967
and meet in Concord to celebrate this cause,

00:09:34.967 --> 00:09:37.527
and then in 2016, before the primary,

00:09:37.527 --> 00:09:40.488
there will be 10,000 who march across that state,

00:09:40.488 --> 00:09:43.552
meeting in Concord to celebrate this cause.

00:09:43.552 --> 00:09:46.323
And as we have marched, people around the country

00:09:46.323 --> 00:09:48.181
have begun to say, "Can we do the same thing

00:09:48.181 --> 00:09:49.298
in our state?"

00:09:49.298 --> 00:09:51.677
So we've started a platform called G.D. Walkers,

00:09:51.677 --> 00:09:53.668
that is, Granny D walkers,

00:09:53.668 --> 00:09:55.795
and Granny D walkers across the country

00:09:55.795 --> 00:09:58.897
will be marching for this reform. Number one.

00:09:58.897 --> 00:10:01.177
Number two, on this march,

00:10:01.177 --> 00:10:03.969
one of the founders of Thunderclap, David Cascino,

00:10:03.969 --> 00:10:05.588
was with us,

00:10:05.588 --> 00:10:07.446
and he said, "Well what can we do?"

00:10:07.446 --> 00:10:09.775
And so they developed a platform,

00:10:09.775 --> 00:10:11.697
which we are announcing today,

00:10:11.697 --> 00:10:14.163
that allows us to pull together voters

00:10:14.163 --> 00:10:16.841
who are committed to this idea of reform.

00:10:16.841 --> 00:10:17.987
Regardless of where you are,

00:10:17.987 --> 00:10:20.639
in New Hampshire or outside of New Hampshire,

00:10:20.639 --> 00:10:22.549
you can sign up and directly be informed

00:10:22.549 --> 00:10:25.537
where the candidates are on this issue

00:10:25.537 --> 00:10:27.177
so you can decide who to vote for

00:10:27.177 --> 00:10:30.095
as a function of which is going

00:10:30.095 --> 00:10:34.563
to make this possibility real.

00:10:34.563 --> 00:10:38.635
And then finally number three, the hardest.

00:10:38.635 --> 00:10:40.458
We're in the age of the Super PAC.

00:10:40.458 --> 00:10:42.567
Indeed yesterday, Merriam announced

00:10:42.567 --> 00:10:46.817
that Merriam-Webster will have Super PAC as a word.

00:10:46.817 --> 00:10:50.457
It is now an official word in the dictionary.

00:10:50.457 --> 00:10:55.852
So on May 1, aka May Day,

00:10:55.852 --> 00:10:58.639
we're going to try an experiment.

00:10:58.639 --> 00:11:00.456
We're going to try a launching

00:11:00.456 --> 00:11:02.754
of what we can think of as a Super PAC

00:11:02.754 --> 00:11:06.018
to end all Super PACs.

00:11:06.018 --> 00:11:07.818
And the basic way this works is this.

00:11:07.818 --> 00:11:09.590
For the last year, we have been working

00:11:09.590 --> 00:11:13.310
with analysts and political experts

00:11:13.310 --> 00:11:16.642
to calculate, how much would it cost

00:11:16.642 --> 00:11:19.064
to win enough votes in the United States Congress

00:11:19.064 --> 00:11:20.884
to make fundamental reform possible?

00:11:20.884 --> 00:11:23.686
What is that number? Half a billion? A billion?

00:11:23.686 --> 00:11:25.526
What is that number?

00:11:25.526 --> 00:11:28.291
And then whatever that number is,

00:11:28.291 --> 00:11:30.396
we are going to kickstart, sort of,

00:11:30.396 --> 00:11:32.327
because you can't use KickStarter for political work,

00:11:32.327 --> 00:11:35.098
but anyway, kickstart, sort of,

00:11:35.098 --> 00:11:37.454
first a bottom-up campaign

00:11:37.454 --> 00:11:40.434
where people will make small dollar commitments

00:11:40.434 --> 00:11:43.396
contingent on reaching very ambitious goals,

00:11:43.396 --> 00:11:45.396
and when those goals have been reached,

00:11:45.396 --> 00:11:49.535
we will turn to the large dollar contributors,

00:11:49.535 --> 00:11:52.917
to get them to contribute to make it possible

00:11:52.917 --> 00:11:56.440
for us to run the kind of Super PAC necessary

00:11:56.440 --> 00:11:57.782
to win this issue,

00:11:57.782 --> 00:12:00.676
to change the way money influences politics,

00:12:00.676 --> 00:12:04.447
so that on November 8,

00:12:04.447 --> 00:12:06.775
which I discovered yesterday is the day

00:12:06.775 --> 00:12:10.466
that Aaron would have been 30 years old,

00:12:10.466 --> 00:12:13.158
on November 8,

00:12:13.158 --> 00:12:16.697
we will celebrate 218 representatives

00:12:16.697 --> 00:12:18.784
in the House and 60 Senators

00:12:18.784 --> 00:12:20.805
in the United States Senate

00:12:20.805 --> 00:12:23.098
who have committed to this idea

00:12:23.098 --> 00:12:24.964
of fundamental reform.

00:12:24.964 --> 00:12:28.726
So last night, we heard about wishes.

00:12:28.726 --> 00:12:30.814
Here's my wish.

00:12:30.814 --> 00:12:34.058
May one.

00:12:34.058 --> 00:12:37.441
May the ideals of one boy

00:12:37.441 --> 00:12:41.922
unite one nation behind one critical idea

00:12:41.922 --> 00:12:44.383
that we are one people,

00:12:44.383 --> 00:12:47.860
we are the people who were promised a government,

00:12:47.860 --> 00:12:49.989
a government that was promised to be

00:12:49.989 --> 00:12:54.710
dependent upon the people alone, the people,

00:12:54.710 --> 00:12:57.559
who, as Madison told us,

00:12:57.559 --> 00:13:01.136
meant not the rich more than the poor.

00:13:01.136 --> 00:13:03.282
May one.

00:13:03.282 --> 00:13:07.461
And then may you, may you join this movement,

00:13:07.461 --> 00:13:09.469
not because you're a politician,

00:13:09.469 --> 00:13:11.085
not because you're an expert,

00:13:11.085 --> 00:13:14.377
not because this is your field,

00:13:14.377 --> 00:13:16.057
but because if you are,

00:13:16.057 --> 00:13:19.728
you are a citizen.

00:13:19.728 --> 00:13:22.765
Aaron asked me that.

00:13:22.765 --> 00:13:25.620
Now I've asked you.

00:13:25.620 --> 00:13:27.298
Thank you very much.

00:13:27.298 --> 00:13:35.343
(Applause)

title: How public spaces make cities work
transcript: When people think about cities, they tend to think of certain things. They think of buildings and streets and skyscrapers, noisy cabs. But when I think about cities, I think about people. Cities are fundamentally about people, and where people go and where people meet are at the core of what makes a city work. So even more important than buildings in a city are the public spaces in between them. And today, some of the most transformative changes in cities are happening in these public spaces.So I believe that lively, enjoyable public spaces are the key to planning a great city. They are what makes it come alive. But what makes a public space work? What attracts people to successful public spaces, and what is it about unsuccessful places that keeps people away? I thought, if I could answer those questions, I could make a huge contribution to my city. But one of the more wonky things about me is that I am an animal behaviorist, and I use those skills not to study animal behavior but to study how people in cities use city public spaces.One of the first spaces that I studied was this little vest pocket park called Paley Park in midtown Manhattan. This little space became a small phenomenon, and because it had such a profound impact on New Yorkers, it made an enormous impression on me. I studied this park very early on in my career because it happened to have been built by my stepfather, so I knew that places like Paley Park didn't happen by accident. I saw firsthand that they required incredible dedication and enormous attention to detail. But what was it about this space that made it special and drew people to it? Well, I would sit in the park and watch very carefully, and first among other things were the comfortable, movable chairs. People would come in, find their own seat, move it a bit, actually, and then stay a while, and then interestingly, people themselves attracted other people, and ironically, I felt more peaceful if there were other people around. And it was green. This little park provided what New Yorkers crave: comfort and greenery. But my question was, why weren't there more places with greenery and places to sit in the middle of the city where you didn't feel alone, or like a trespasser? Unfortunately, that's not how cities were being designed.So here you see a familiar sight. This is how plazas have been designed for generations. They have that stylish, Spartan look that we often associate with modern architecture, but it's not surprising that people avoid spaces like this. They not only look desolate, they feel downright dangerous. I mean, where would you sit here? What would you do here? But architects love them. They are plinths for their creations. They might tolerate a sculpture or two, but that's about it. And for developers, they are ideal. There's nothing to water, nothing to maintain, and no undesirable people to worry about. But don't you think this is a waste? For me, becoming a city planner meant being able to truly change the city that I lived in and loved. I wanted to be able to create places that would give you the feeling that you got in Paley Park, and not allow developers to build bleak plazas like this. But over the many years, I have learned how hard it is to create successful, meaningful, enjoyable public spaces. As I learned from my stepfather, they certainly do not happen by accident, especially in a city like New York, where public space has to be fought for to begin with, and then for them to be successful, somebody has to think very hard about every detail.Now, open spaces in cities are opportunities. Yes, they are opportunities for commercial investment, but they are also opportunities for the common good of the city, and those two goals are often not aligned with one another, and therein lies the conflict.The first opportunity I had to fight for a great public open space was in the early 1980s, when I was leading a team of planners at a gigantic landfill called Battery Park City in lower Manhattan on the Hudson River. And this sandy wasteland had lain barren for 10 years, and we were told, unless we found a developer in six months, it would go bankrupt. So we came up with a radical, almost insane idea. Instead of building a park as a complement to future development, why don't we reverse that equation and build a small but very high-quality public open space first, and see if that made a difference. So we only could afford to build a two-block section of what would become a mile-long esplanade, so whatever we built had to be perfect. So just to make sure, I insisted that we build a mock-up in wood, at scale, of the railing and the sea wall. And when I sat down on that test bench with sand still swirling all around me, the railing hit exactly at eye level, blocking my view and ruining my experience at the water's edge.So you see, details really do make a difference. But design is not just how something looks, it's how your body feels on that seat in that space, and I believe that successful design always depends on that very individual experience. In this photo, everything looks very finished, but that granite edge, those lights, the back on that bench, the trees in planting, and the many different kinds of places to sit were all little battles that turned this project into a place that people wanted to be.Now, this proved very valuable 20 years later when Michael Bloomberg asked me to be his planning commissioner and put me in charge of shaping the entire city of New York. And he said to me on that very day, he said that New York was projected to grow from eight to nine million people. And he asked me, "So where are you going to put one million additional New Yorkers?"Well, I didn't have any idea. Now, you know that New York does place a high value on attracting immigrants, so we were excited about the prospect of growth, but honestly, where were we going to grow in a city that was already built out to its edges and surrounded by water? How were we going to find housing for that many new New Yorkers? And if we couldn't spread out, which was probably a good thing, where could new housing go? And what about cars? Our city couldn't possibly handle any more cars.So what were we going to do? If we couldn't spread out, we had to go up. And if we had to go up, we had to go up in places where you wouldn't need to own a car. So that meant using one of our greatest assets: our transit system. But we had never before thought of how we could make the most of it. So here was the answer to our puzzle. If we were to channel and redirect all new development around transit, we could actually handle that population increase, we thought. And so here was the plan, what we really needed to do: We needed to redo our zoning — and zoning is the city planner's regulatory tool — and basically reshape the entire city, targeting where new development could go and prohibiting any development at all in our car-oriented, suburban-style neighborhoods. Well, this was an unbelievably ambitious idea, ambitious because communities had to approve those plans.So how was I going to get this done? By listening. So I began listening, in fact, thousands of hours of listening just to establish trust. You know, communities can tell whether or not you understand their neighborhoods. It's not something you can just fake. And so I began walking. I can't tell you how many blocks I walked, in sweltering summers, in freezing winters, year after year, just so I could get to understand the DNA of each neighborhood and know what each street felt like. I became an incredibly geeky zoning expert, finding ways that zoning could address communities' concerns. So little by little, neighborhood by neighborhood, block by block, we began to set height limits so that all new development would be predictable and near transit. Over the course of 12 years, we were able to rezone 124 neighborhoods, 40 percent of the city, 12,500 blocks, so that now, 90 percent of all new development of New York is within a 10-minute walk of a subway. In other words, nobody in those new buildings needs to own a car.Well, those rezonings were exhausting and enervating and important, but rezoning was never my mission. You can't see zoning and you can't feel zoning. My mission was always to create great public spaces. So in the areas where we zoned for significant development, I was determined to create places that would make a difference in people's lives. Here you see what was two miles of abandoned, degraded waterfront in the neighborhoods of Greenpoint and Williamsburg in Brooklyn, impossible to get to and impossible to use. Now the zoning here was massive, so I felt an obligation to create magnificent parks on these waterfronts, and I spent an incredible amount of time on every square inch of these plans. I wanted to make sure that there were tree-lined paths from the upland to the water, that there were trees and plantings everywhere, and, of course, lots and lots of places to sit. Honestly, I had no idea how it would turn out. I had to have faith. But I put everything that I had studied and learned into those plans.And then it opened, and I have to tell you, it was incredible. People came from all over the city to be in these parks. I know they changed the lives of the people who live there, but they also changed New Yorkers' whole image of their city. I often come down and watch people get on this little ferry that now runs between the boroughs, and I can't tell you why, but I'm completely moved by the fact that people are using it as if it had always been there.And here is a new park in lower Manhattan. Now, the water's edge in lower Manhattan was a complete mess before 9/11. Wall Street was essentially landlocked because you couldn't get anywhere near this edge. And after 9/11, the city had very little control. But I thought if we went to the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation and got money to reclaim this two miles of degraded waterfront that it would have an enormous effect on the rebuilding of lower Manhattan. And it did. Lower Manhattan finally has a public waterfront on all three sides.I really love this park. You know, railings have to be higher now, so we put bar seating at the edge, and you can get so close to the water you're practically on it. And see how the railing widens and flattens out so you can lay down your lunch or your laptop. And I love when people come there and look up and they say, "Wow, there's Brooklyn, and it's so close."So what's the trick? How do you turn a park into a place that people want to be? Well, it's up to you, not as a city planner but as a human being. You don't tap into your design expertise. You tap into your humanity. I mean, would you want to go there? Would you want to stay there? Can you see into it and out of it? Are there other people there? Does it seem green and friendly? Can you find your very own seat?Well now, all over New York City, there are places where you can find your very own seat. Where there used to be parking spaces, there are now pop-up cafes. Where Broadway traffic used to run, there are now tables and chairs. Where 12 years ago, sidewalk cafes were not allowed, they are now everywhere. But claiming these spaces for public use was not simple, and it's even harder to keep them that way.So now I'm going to tell you a story about a very unusual park called the High Line. The High Line was an elevated railway. (Applause) The High Line was an elevated railway that ran through three neighborhoods on Manhattan's West Side, and when the train stopped running, it became a self-seeded landscape, a kind of a garden in the sky. And when I saw it the first time, honestly, when I went up on that old viaduct, I fell in love the way you fall in love with a person, honestly. And when I was appointed, saving the first two sections of the High Line from demolition became my first priority and my most important project. I knew if there was a day that I didn't worry about the High Line, it would come down. And the High Line, even though it is widely known now and phenomenally popular, it is the most contested public space in the city. You might see a beautiful park, but not everyone does. You know, it's true, commercial interests will always battle against public space. You might say, "How wonderful it is that more than four million people come from all over the world to visit the High Line." Well, a developer sees just one thing: customers. Hey, why not take out those plantings and have shops all along the High Line? Wouldn't that be terrific and won't it mean a lot more money for the city? Well no, it would not be terrific. It would be a mall, and not a park. (Applause) And you know what, it might mean more money for the city, but a city has to take the long view, the view for the common good. And they came to me and proposed that they "temporarily disassemble" that third and final section. Perhaps the High Line didn't fit in with their image of a gleaming city of skyscrapers on a hill. Perhaps it was just in their way. But in any case, it took nine months of nonstop daily negotiation to finally get the signed agreement to prohibit its demolition, and that was only two years ago.So you see, no matter how popular and successful a public space may be, it can never be taken for granted. Public spaces always — this is it saved — public spaces always need vigilant champions, not only to claim them at the outset for public use, but to design them for the people that use them, then to maintain them to ensure that they are for everyone, that they are not violated, invaded, abandoned or ignored. If there is any one lesson that I have learned in my life as a city planner, it is that public spaces have power. It's not just the number of people using them, it's the even greater number of people who feel better about their city just knowing that they are there. Public space can change how you live in a city, how you feel about a city, whether you choose one city over another, and public space is one of the most important reasons why you stay in a city.I believe that a successful city is like a fabulous party. People stay because they are having a great time.Thank you.(Applause) Thank you. (Applause)

But we had never before thought

00:08:17.947 --> 00:08:20.183
of how we could make the most of it.

00:08:20.183 --> 00:08:23.396
So here was the answer to our puzzle.

00:08:23.396 --> 00:08:27.027
If we were to channel and redirect

00:08:27.027 --> 00:08:29.321
all new development around transit,

00:08:29.321 --> 00:08:32.948
we could actually handle that population increase,

00:08:32.948 --> 00:08:34.222
we thought.

00:08:34.222 --> 00:08:36.780
And so here was the plan,

00:08:36.780 --> 00:08:38.428
what we really needed to do:

00:08:38.428 --> 00:08:41.276
We needed to redo our zoning --

00:08:41.276 --> 00:08:44.627
and zoning is the city planner's regulatory tool --

00:08:44.627 --> 00:08:47.938
and basically reshape the entire city,

00:08:47.938 --> 00:08:50.083
targeting where new development could go

00:08:50.083 --> 00:08:52.274
and prohibiting any development at all

00:08:52.274 --> 00:08:53.988
in our car-oriented,

00:08:53.988 --> 00:08:56.150
suburban-style neighborhoods.

00:08:56.150 --> 00:08:59.882
Well, this was an unbelievably ambitious idea,

00:08:59.882 --> 00:09:02.458
ambitious because communities

00:09:02.458 --> 00:09:06.073
had to approve those plans.

00:09:06.073 --> 00:09:09.092
So how was I going to get this done?

00:09:09.092 --> 00:09:12.000
By listening. So I began listening,

00:09:12.000 --> 00:09:15.354
in fact, thousands of hours of listening

00:09:15.354 --> 00:09:17.172
just to establish trust.

00:09:17.172 --> 00:09:19.261
You know, communities can tell

00:09:19.261 --> 00:09:21.413
whether or not you understand their neighborhoods.

00:09:21.413 --> 00:09:24.509
It's not something you can just fake.

00:09:24.509 --> 00:09:27.215
And so I began walking.

00:09:27.215 --> 00:09:29.535
I can't tell you how many blocks I walked,

00:09:29.535 --> 00:09:32.944
in sweltering summers, in freezing winters,

00:09:32.944 --> 00:09:34.774
year after year,

00:09:34.774 --> 00:09:36.862
just so I could get to understand

00:09:36.862 --> 00:09:38.889
the DNA of each neighborhood

00:09:38.889 --> 00:09:41.464
and know what each street felt like.

00:09:41.464 --> 00:09:44.959
I became an incredibly geeky zoning expert,

00:09:44.959 --> 00:09:47.028
finding ways that zoning could address

00:09:47.028 --> 00:09:49.090
communities' concerns.

00:09:49.090 --> 00:09:51.662
So little by little, neighborhood by neighborhood,

00:09:51.662 --> 00:09:53.097
block by block,

00:09:53.097 --> 00:09:54.970
we began to set height limits

00:09:54.970 --> 00:09:56.702
so that all new development

00:09:56.702 --> 00:10:00.319
would be predictable and near transit.

00:10:00.319 --> 00:10:02.100
Over the course of 12 years,

00:10:02.100 --> 00:10:04.569
we were able to rezone

00:10:04.569 --> 00:10:07.138
124 neighborhoods,

00:10:07.138 --> 00:10:09.917
40 percent of the city,

00:10:09.917 --> 00:10:14.456
12,500 blocks, so that now,

00:10:14.456 --> 00:10:17.693
90 percent of all new development of New York

00:10:17.693 --> 00:10:20.341
is within a 10-minute walk of a subway.

00:10:20.341 --> 00:10:22.991
In other words, nobody in those new buildings

00:10:22.991 --> 00:10:24.867
needs to own a car.

00:10:24.867 --> 00:10:28.960
Well, those rezonings were exhausting

00:10:28.960 --> 00:10:31.998
and enervating and important,

00:10:31.998 --> 00:10:34.548
but rezoning was never my mission.

00:10:34.548 --> 00:10:38.039
You can't see zoning and you can't feel zoning.

00:10:38.039 --> 00:10:40.127
My mission was always to create

00:10:40.127 --> 00:10:42.051
great public spaces.

00:10:42.051 --> 00:10:45.943
So in the areas where we zoned
for significant development,

00:10:45.943 --> 00:10:48.134
I was determined to create places

00:10:48.134 --> 00:10:50.828
that would make a difference in people's lives.

00:10:50.828 --> 00:10:52.914
Here you see what was

00:10:52.914 --> 00:10:55.338
two miles of abandoned, degraded waterfront

00:10:55.338 --> 00:10:57.105
in the neighborhoods of Greenpoint

00:10:57.105 --> 00:10:58.887
and Williamsburg in Brooklyn,

00:10:58.887 --> 00:11:02.447
impossible to get to and impossible to use.

00:11:02.447 --> 00:11:04.941
Now the zoning here was massive,

00:11:04.941 --> 00:11:07.963
so I felt an obligation to create

00:11:07.963 --> 00:11:10.988
magnificent parks on these waterfronts,

00:11:10.988 --> 00:11:13.728
and I spent an incredible amount of time

00:11:13.728 --> 00:11:16.833
on every square inch of these plans.

00:11:16.833 --> 00:11:18.898
I wanted to make sure that there were

00:11:18.898 --> 00:11:21.437
tree-lined paths from the upland to the water,

00:11:21.437 --> 00:11:23.848
that there were trees and plantings everywhere,

00:11:23.848 --> 00:11:28.036
and, of course, lots and lots of places to sit.

00:11:28.036 --> 00:11:31.406
Honestly, I had no idea how it would turn out.

00:11:31.406 --> 00:11:33.031
I had to have faith.

00:11:33.031 --> 00:11:35.994
But I put everything that I had studied and learned

00:11:35.994 --> 00:11:37.728
into those plans.

00:11:37.728 --> 00:11:39.388
And then it opened,

00:11:39.388 --> 00:11:42.675
and I have to tell you, it was incredible.

00:11:42.675 --> 00:11:44.760
People came from all over the city

00:11:44.760 --> 00:11:46.417
to be in these parks.

00:11:46.417 --> 00:11:49.837
I know they changed the lives
of the people who live there,

00:11:49.837 --> 00:11:52.332
but they also changed New Yorkers' whole image

00:11:52.332 --> 00:11:54.108
of their city.

00:11:54.108 --> 00:11:55.687
I often come down and watch people

00:11:55.687 --> 00:11:57.203
get on this little ferry

00:11:57.203 --> 00:11:59.181
that now runs between the boroughs,

00:11:59.181 --> 00:12:00.668
and I can't tell you why,

00:12:00.668 --> 00:12:02.240
but I'm completely moved

00:12:02.240 --> 00:12:04.387
by the fact that people are using it

00:12:04.387 --> 00:12:06.569
as if it had always been there.

00:12:06.569 --> 00:12:09.842
And here is a new park in lower Manhattan.

00:12:09.842 --> 00:12:12.599
Now, the water's edge in lower Manhattan

00:12:12.599 --> 00:12:15.532
was a complete mess before 9/11.

00:12:15.532 --> 00:12:17.447
Wall Street was essentially landlocked

00:12:17.447 --> 00:12:20.033
because you couldn't get anywhere near this edge.

00:12:20.033 --> 00:12:23.867
And after 9/11, the city had very little control.

00:12:23.867 --> 00:12:25.412
But I thought if we went

00:12:25.412 --> 00:12:27.557
to the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation

00:12:27.557 --> 00:12:30.518
and got money to reclaim this two miles

00:12:30.518 --> 00:12:32.314
of degraded waterfront

00:12:32.314 --> 00:12:34.165
that it would have an enormous effect

00:12:34.165 --> 00:12:36.626
on the rebuilding of lower Manhattan.

00:12:36.626 --> 00:12:37.806
And it did.

00:12:37.806 --> 00:12:41.197
Lower Manhattan finally has a public waterfront

00:12:41.197 --> 00:12:43.311
on all three sides.

00:12:43.311 --> 00:12:45.695
I really love this park.

00:12:45.695 --> 00:12:47.920
You know, railings have to be higher now,

00:12:47.920 --> 00:12:50.464
so we put bar seating at the edge,

00:12:50.464 --> 00:12:52.576
and you can get so close to the water

00:12:52.576 --> 00:12:54.304
you're practically on it.

00:12:54.304 --> 00:12:56.173
And see how the railing widens

00:12:56.173 --> 00:12:57.589
and flattens out so you can lay down

00:12:57.589 --> 00:12:59.471
your lunch or your laptop.

00:12:59.471 --> 00:13:01.451
And I love when people come there

00:13:01.451 --> 00:13:03.311
and look up and they say,

00:13:03.311 --> 00:13:07.338
"Wow, there's Brooklyn, and it's so close."

00:13:07.338 --> 00:13:09.690
So what's the trick?

00:13:09.690 --> 00:13:11.499
How do you turn a park

00:13:11.499 --> 00:13:14.665
into a place that people want to be?

00:13:14.665 --> 00:13:17.508
Well, it's up to you,

00:13:17.508 --> 00:13:20.873
not as a city planner but as a human being.

00:13:20.873 --> 00:13:24.273
You don't tap into your design expertise.

00:13:24.273 --> 00:13:27.788
You tap into your humanity.

00:13:27.788 --> 00:13:31.114
I mean, would you want to go there?

00:13:31.114 --> 00:13:33.097
Would you want to stay there?

00:13:33.097 --> 00:13:35.235
Can you see into it and out of it?

00:13:35.235 --> 00:13:37.487
Are there other people there?

00:13:37.487 --> 00:13:40.134
Does it seem green and friendly?

00:13:40.134 --> 00:13:43.372
Can you find your very own seat?

00:13:43.372 --> 00:13:46.401
Well now, all over New York City,

00:13:46.401 --> 00:13:47.905
there are places where you can

00:13:47.905 --> 00:13:49.759
find your very own seat.

00:13:49.759 --> 00:13:52.281
Where there used to be parking spaces,

00:13:52.281 --> 00:13:54.574
there are now pop-up cafes.

00:13:54.574 --> 00:13:56.552
Where Broadway traffic used to run,

00:13:56.552 --> 00:13:58.516
there are now tables and chairs.

00:13:58.516 --> 00:14:02.070
Where 12 years ago, sidewalk
cafes were not allowed,

00:14:02.070 --> 00:14:04.043
they are now everywhere.

00:14:04.043 --> 00:14:07.038
But claiming these spaces for public use

00:14:07.038 --> 00:14:08.177
was not simple,

00:14:08.177 --> 00:14:10.839
and it's even harder to keep them that way.

00:14:10.839 --> 00:14:12.528
So now I'm going to tell you a story

00:14:12.528 --> 00:14:16.808
about a very unusual park called the High Line.

00:14:16.808 --> 00:14:18.862
The High Line was an elevated railway.

00:14:18.862 --> 00:14:25.493
(Applause)

00:14:25.493 --> 00:14:27.769
The High Line was an elevated railway

00:14:27.769 --> 00:14:29.581
that ran through three neighborhoods

00:14:29.581 --> 00:14:31.451
on Manhattan's West Side,

00:14:31.451 --> 00:14:33.196
and when the train stopped running,

00:14:33.196 --> 00:14:35.352
it became a self-seeded landscape,

00:14:35.352 --> 00:14:37.959
a kind of a garden in the sky.

00:14:37.959 --> 00:14:40.108
And when I saw it the first time,

00:14:40.108 --> 00:14:42.754
honestly, when I went up on that old viaduct,

00:14:42.754 --> 00:14:45.570
I fell in love the way you fall in love with a person,

00:14:45.570 --> 00:14:46.797
honestly.

00:14:46.797 --> 00:14:48.918
And when I was appointed,

00:14:48.918 --> 00:14:50.994
saving the first two sections of the High Line

00:14:50.994 --> 00:14:54.366
from demolition became my first priority

00:14:54.366 --> 00:14:57.038
and my most important project.

00:14:57.038 --> 00:15:00.306
I knew if there was a day that I didn't

00:15:00.306 --> 00:15:03.909
worry about the High Line, it would come down.

00:15:03.909 --> 00:15:05.898
And the High Line,

00:15:05.898 --> 00:15:08.358
even though it is widely known now

00:15:08.358 --> 00:15:10.177
and phenomenally popular,

00:15:10.177 --> 00:15:14.081
it is the most contested public space in the city.

00:15:14.081 --> 00:15:16.956
You might see a beautiful park,

00:15:16.956 --> 00:15:19.403
but not everyone does.

00:15:19.403 --> 00:15:22.040
You know, it's true, commercial interests

00:15:22.040 --> 00:15:25.257
will always battle against public space.

00:15:25.257 --> 00:15:27.081
You might say,

00:15:27.081 --> 00:15:28.651
"How wonderful it is that more than

00:15:28.651 --> 00:15:31.082
four million people come from all over the world

00:15:31.082 --> 00:15:32.729
to visit the High Line."

00:15:32.729 --> 00:15:37.345
Well, a developer sees just one thing: customers.

00:15:37.345 --> 00:15:40.070
Hey, why not take out those plantings

00:15:40.070 --> 00:15:42.078
and have shops all along the High Line?

00:15:42.078 --> 00:15:43.575
Wouldn't that be terrific

00:15:43.575 --> 00:15:46.110
and won't it mean a lot more money for the city?

00:15:46.110 --> 00:15:48.602
Well no, it would not be terrific.

00:15:48.602 --> 00:15:51.901
It would be a mall, and not a park.

00:15:51.901 --> 00:15:59.280
(Applause)

00:15:59.280 --> 00:16:00.788
And you know what, it might mean

00:16:00.788 --> 00:16:02.998
more money for the city,

00:16:02.998 --> 00:16:07.047
but a city has to take the long view,

00:16:07.047 --> 00:16:09.983
the view for the common good.

00:16:09.983 --> 00:16:13.698
Most recently, the last section of the High Line,

00:16:13.698 --> 00:16:15.314
the third section of the High Line,

00:16:15.314 --> 00:16:16.884
the final section of the High Line,

00:16:16.884 --> 00:16:19.686
has been pitted against development interests,

00:16:19.686 --> 00:16:21.986
where some of the city's leading developers

00:16:21.986 --> 00:16:24.668
are building more than 17 million square feet

00:16:24.668 --> 00:16:26.968
at the Hudson Yards.

00:16:26.968 --> 00:16:28.929
And they came to me and proposed

00:16:28.929 --> 00:16:31.488
that they "temporarily disassemble"

00:16:31.488 --> 00:16:34.218
that third and final section.

00:16:34.218 --> 00:16:36.681
Perhaps the High Line didn't fit in

00:16:36.681 --> 00:16:39.568
with their image of a gleaming city of skyscrapers

00:16:39.568 --> 00:16:41.031
on a hill.

00:16:41.031 --> 00:16:43.755
Perhaps it was just in their way.

00:16:43.755 --> 00:16:46.243
But in any case, it took nine months

00:16:46.243 --> 00:16:48.717
of nonstop daily negotiation

00:16:48.717 --> 00:16:50.730
to finally get the signed agreement

00:16:50.730 --> 00:16:52.754
to prohibit its demolition,

00:16:52.754 --> 00:16:56.563
and that was only two years ago.

00:16:56.563 --> 00:16:59.021
So you see, no matter how popular

00:16:59.021 --> 00:17:01.857
and successful a public space may be,

00:17:01.857 --> 00:17:04.273
it can never be taken for granted.

00:17:04.273 --> 00:17:06.854
Public spaces always -- this is it saved --

00:17:06.854 --> 00:17:10.566
public spaces always need vigilant champions,

00:17:10.566 --> 00:17:14.266
not only to claim them at the outset for public use,

00:17:14.266 --> 00:17:17.797
but to design them for the people that use them,

00:17:17.797 --> 00:17:19.828
then to maintain them to ensure

00:17:19.828 --> 00:17:21.798
that they are for everyone,

00:17:21.798 --> 00:17:24.211
that they are not violated, invaded,

00:17:24.211 --> 00:17:26.848
abandoned or ignored.

00:17:26.848 --> 00:17:28.492
If there is any one lesson

00:17:28.492 --> 00:17:31.644
that I have learned in my life as a city planner,

00:17:31.644 --> 00:17:35.404
it is that public spaces have power.

00:17:35.404 --> 00:17:38.473
It's not just the number of people using them,

00:17:38.473 --> 00:17:40.427
it's the even greater number of people

00:17:40.427 --> 00:17:42.546
who feel better about their city

00:17:42.546 --> 00:17:45.778
just knowing that they are there.

00:17:45.778 --> 00:17:49.250
Public space can change how you live in a city,

00:17:49.250 --> 00:17:51.420
how you feel about a city,

00:17:51.420 --> 00:17:54.708
whether you choose one city over another,

00:17:54.708 --> 00:17:57.479
and public space is one of
the most important reasons

00:17:57.479 --> 00:18:00.600
why you stay in a city.

00:18:00.600 --> 00:18:03.065
I believe that a successful city

00:18:03.065 --> 00:18:05.686
is like a fabulous party.

00:18:05.686 --> 00:18:09.591
People stay because they are having a great time.

00:18:09.591 --> 00:18:11.534
Thank you.

00:18:11.534 --> 00:18:17.487
(Applause)

00:18:17.487 --> 00:18:22.117
Thank you. (Applause)

title: Teach teachers how to create magic
transcript: Right now there is an aspiring teacher who is working on a 60-page paper based on some age-old education theory developed by some dead education professor wondering to herself what this task that she's engaging in has to do with what she wants to do with her life, which is be an educator, change lives, and spark magic. Right now there is an aspiring teacher in a graduate school of education who is watching a professor babble on and on about engagement in the most disengaging way possible. Right now there's a first-year teacher at home who is pouring through lesson plans trying to make sense of standards, who is trying to make sense of how to grade students appropriately, while at the same time saying to herself over and over again, "Don't smile till November," because that's what she was taught in her teacher education program. Right now there's a student who is coming up with a way to convince his mom or dad that he's very, very sick and can't make it to school tomorrow. On the other hand, right now there are amazing educators that are sharing information, information that is shared in such a beautiful way that the students are sitting at the edge of their seats just waiting for a bead of sweat to drop off the face of this person so they can soak up all that knowledge. Right now there is also a person who has an entire audience rapt with attention, a person that is weaving a powerful narrative about a world that the people who are listening have never imagined or seen before, but if they close their eyes tightly enough, they can envision that world because the storytelling is so compelling. Right now there's a person who can tell an audience to put their hands up in the air and they will stay there till he says, "Put them down." Right now.So people will then say, "Well, Chris, you describe the guy who is going through some awful training but you're also describing these powerful educators. If you're thinking about the world of education or urban education in particular, these guys will probably cancel each other out, and then we'll be okay."The reality is, the folks I described as the master teachers, the master narrative builders, the master storytellers are far removed from classrooms. The folks who know the skills about how to teach and engage an audience don't even know what teacher certification means. They may not even have the degrees to be able to have anything to call an education. And that to me is sad. It's sad because the people who I described, they were very disinterested in the learning process, want to be effective teachers, but they have no models. I'm going to paraphrase Mark Twain. Mark Twain says that proper preparation, or teaching, is so powerful that it can turn bad morals to good, it can turn awful practices into powerful ones, it can change men and transform them into angels.The folks who I described earlier got proper preparation in teaching, not in any college or university, but by virtue of just being in the same spaces of those who engage. Guess where those places are? Barber shops, rap concerts, and most importantly, in the black church. And I've been framing this idea called Pentecostal pedagogy. Who here has been to a black church? We got a couple of hands. You go to a black church, their preacher starts off and he realizes that he has to engage the audience, so he starts off with this sort of wordplay in the beginning oftentimes, and then he takes a pause, and he says, "Oh my gosh, they're not quite paying attention." So he says, "Can I get an amen?"Audience: Amen.Chris Emdin: So I can I get an amen? Audience: Amen.CE: And all of a sudden, everybody's reawoken. That preacher bangs on the pulpit for attention. He drops his voice at a very, very low volume when he wants people to key into him, and those things are the skills that we need for the most engaging teachers. So why does teacher education only give you theory and theory and tell you about standards and tell you about all of these things that have nothing to do with the basic skills, that magic that you need to engage an audience, to engage a student? So I make the argument that we reframe teacher education, that we could focus on content, and that's fine, and we could focus on theories, and that's fine, but content and theories with the absence of the magic of teaching and learning means nothing.Now people oftentimes say, "Well, magic is just magic." There are teachers who, despite all their challenges, who have those skills, get into those schools and are  able to engage an audience, and the administrator walks by and says, "Wow, he's so good, I wish all my teachers could be that good." And when they try to describe what that is, they just say, "He has that magic."But I'm here to tell you that magic can be taught. Magic can be taught. Magic can be taught. Now, how do you teach it? You teach it by allowing people to go into those spaces where the magic is happening. If you want to be an aspiring teacher in urban education, you've got to leave the confines of that university and go into the hood. You've got to go in there and hang out at the barbershop, you've got to attend that black church, and you've got to view those folks that have the power to engage and just take notes on what they do. At our teacher education classes at my university, I've started a project where every single student that comes in there sits and watches rap concerts. They watch the way that the rappers move and talk with their hands. They study the way that he walks proudly across that stage. They listen to his metaphors and analogies, and they start learning these little things that if they practice enough becomes the key to magic. They learn that if you just stare at a student and raise your eyebrow about a quarter of an inch, you don't have to say a word because they know that that means that you want more. And if we could transform teacher education to focus on teaching teachers how to create that magic then poof! we could make dead classes come alive, we could reignite imaginations, and we can change education.Thank you.(Applause)
