there's a first-year teacher at home

00:01:03.072 --> 00:01:05.624
who is pouring through lesson plans

00:01:05.624 --> 00:01:07.954
trying to make sense of standards,

00:01:07.954 --> 00:01:11.144
who is trying to make sense of how
to grade students appropriately,

00:01:11.144 --> 00:01:12.783
while at the same time saying to herself

00:01:12.783 --> 00:01:14.997
over and over again,

00:01:14.997 --> 00:01:16.955
"Don't smile till November,"

00:01:16.955 --> 00:01:19.038
because that's what she was taught

00:01:19.038 --> 00:01:22.060
in her teacher education program.

00:01:22.060 --> 00:01:24.916
Right now there's a student

00:01:24.916 --> 00:01:26.600
who is coming up with a way

00:01:26.600 --> 00:01:29.088
to convince his mom or dad

00:01:29.088 --> 00:01:30.596
that he's very, very sick

00:01:30.596 --> 00:01:34.469
and can't make it to school tomorrow.

00:01:34.469 --> 00:01:37.366
On the other hand, right now

00:01:37.366 --> 00:01:39.716
there are amazing educators

00:01:39.716 --> 00:01:41.490
that are sharing information,

00:01:41.490 --> 00:01:44.137
information that is shared in such a beautiful way

00:01:44.137 --> 00:01:46.528
that the students are sitting
at the edge of their seats

00:01:46.528 --> 00:01:48.640
just waiting for a bead of sweat

00:01:48.640 --> 00:01:51.225
to drop off the face of this person

00:01:51.225 --> 00:01:54.270
so they can soak up all that knowledge.

00:01:54.270 --> 00:01:57.988
Right now there is also a person

00:01:57.988 --> 00:02:01.349
who has an entire audience rapt with attention,

00:02:01.349 --> 00:02:04.241
a person that is weaving a powerful narrative

00:02:04.241 --> 00:02:05.917
about a world

00:02:05.917 --> 00:02:07.472
that the people who are listening

00:02:07.472 --> 00:02:09.838
have never imagined or seen before,

00:02:09.838 --> 00:02:12.356
but if they close their eyes tightly enough,

00:02:12.356 --> 00:02:13.995
they can envision that world

00:02:13.995 --> 00:02:17.990
because the storytelling is so compelling.

00:02:17.990 --> 00:02:21.129
Right now there's a person who can tell an audience

00:02:21.129 --> 00:02:23.032
to put their hands up in the air

00:02:23.032 --> 00:02:24.682
and they will stay there till he says,

00:02:24.682 --> 00:02:26.426
"Put them down."

00:02:26.426 --> 00:02:28.094
Right now.

00:02:28.094 --> 00:02:29.498
So people will then say,

00:02:29.498 --> 00:02:32.361
"Well, Chris, you describe the guy

00:02:32.361 --> 00:02:34.385
who is going through some awful training

00:02:34.385 --> 00:02:36.918
but you're also describing these powerful educators.

00:02:36.918 --> 00:02:38.452
If you're thinking about the world of education

00:02:38.452 --> 00:02:40.050
or urban education in particular,

00:02:40.050 --> 00:02:42.096
these guys will probably cancel each other out,

00:02:42.096 --> 00:02:44.342
and then we'll be okay."

00:02:44.342 --> 00:02:46.844
The reality is, the folks I described

00:02:46.844 --> 00:02:48.560
as the master teachers,

00:02:48.560 --> 00:02:50.897
the master narrative builders,

00:02:50.897 --> 00:02:52.848
the master storytellers

00:02:52.848 --> 00:02:56.446
are far removed from classrooms.

00:02:56.446 --> 00:02:58.828
The folks who know the skills about how to teach

00:02:58.828 --> 00:03:00.150
and engage an audience

00:03:00.150 --> 00:03:03.070
don't even know what teacher certification means.

00:03:03.070 --> 00:03:05.132
They may not even have the degrees

00:03:05.132 --> 00:03:08.393
to be able to have anything

00:03:08.393 --> 00:03:10.697
to call an education.

00:03:10.697 --> 00:03:12.429
And that to me is sad.

00:03:12.429 --> 00:03:15.428
It's sad because the people who I described,

00:03:15.428 --> 00:03:18.195
they were very disinterested in the learning process,

00:03:18.195 --> 00:03:20.053
want to be effective teachers,

00:03:20.053 --> 00:03:21.405
but they have no models.

00:03:21.405 --> 00:03:23.150
I'm going to paraphrase Mark Twain.

00:03:23.150 --> 00:03:25.680
Mark Twain says that proper preparation,

00:03:25.680 --> 00:03:27.080
or teaching,

00:03:27.080 --> 00:03:30.696
is so powerful that it can turn bad morals to good,

00:03:30.696 --> 00:03:33.368
it can turn awful practices into powerful ones,

00:03:33.368 --> 00:03:35.952
it can change men and transform them

00:03:35.952 --> 00:03:38.553
into angels.

00:03:38.553 --> 00:03:40.856
The folks who I described earlier

00:03:40.856 --> 00:03:42.846
got proper preparation in teaching,

00:03:42.846 --> 00:03:44.930
not in any college or university,

00:03:44.930 --> 00:03:48.925
but by virtue of just being in the
same spaces of those who engage.

00:03:48.925 --> 00:03:51.168
Guess where those places are?

00:03:51.168 --> 00:03:53.234
Barber shops,

00:03:53.234 --> 00:03:56.422
rap concerts, and most importantly,

00:03:56.422 --> 00:03:58.070
in the black church.

00:03:58.070 --> 00:04:00.989
And I've been framing this idea
called Pentecostal pedagogy.

00:04:00.989 --> 00:04:03.299
Who here has been to a black church?

00:04:03.299 --> 00:04:05.608
We got a couple of hands.

00:04:05.608 --> 00:04:06.971
You go to a black church,

00:04:06.971 --> 00:04:08.582
their preacher starts off

00:04:08.582 --> 00:04:11.468
and he realizes that he has to engage the audience,

00:04:11.468 --> 00:04:13.314
so he starts off with this sort of wordplay

00:04:13.314 --> 00:04:14.998
in the beginning oftentimes,

00:04:14.998 --> 00:04:16.816
and then he takes a pause,

00:04:16.816 --> 00:04:18.997
and he says, "Oh my gosh, they're
not quite paying attention."

00:04:18.997 --> 00:04:20.598
So he says, "Can I get an amen?"

00:04:20.598 --> 00:04:21.584
Audience: Amen.

00:04:21.584 --> 00:04:23.883
Chris Emdin: So I can I get an amen?
Audience: Amen.

00:04:23.883 --> 00:04:27.215
CE: And all of a sudden, everybody's reawoken.

00:04:27.215 --> 00:04:29.276
That preacher bangs on the pulpit for attention.

00:04:29.276 --> 00:04:31.936
He drops his voice at a very, very low volume

00:04:31.936 --> 00:04:33.810
when he wants people to key into him,

00:04:33.810 --> 00:04:36.066
and those things are the skills that we need

00:04:36.066 --> 00:04:38.141
for the most engaging teachers.

00:04:38.141 --> 00:04:39.579
So why does teacher education

00:04:39.579 --> 00:04:41.652
only give you theory and theory

00:04:41.652 --> 00:04:43.888
and tell you about standards and tell you about

00:04:43.888 --> 00:04:45.832
all of these things that have nothing to do

00:04:45.832 --> 00:04:49.148
with the basic skills, that magic that you need

00:04:49.148 --> 00:04:52.117
to engage an audience, to engage a student?

00:04:52.117 --> 00:04:55.135
So I make the argument that
we reframe teacher education,

00:04:55.135 --> 00:04:57.920
that we could focus on content, and that's fine,

00:04:57.920 --> 00:05:00.226
and we could focus on theories, and that's fine,

00:05:00.226 --> 00:05:01.797
but content and theories

00:05:01.797 --> 00:05:04.401
with the absence of the magic

00:05:04.401 --> 00:05:07.312
of teaching and learning means nothing.

00:05:07.312 --> 00:05:10.067
Now people oftentimes say,
"Well, magic is just magic."

00:05:10.067 --> 00:05:11.448
There are teachers who,

00:05:11.448 --> 00:05:13.912
despite all their challenges, who have those skills,

00:05:13.912 --> 00:05:16.633
get into those schools and are 
able to engage an audience,

00:05:16.633 --> 00:05:17.927
and the administrator walks by and says,

00:05:17.927 --> 00:05:20.855
"Wow, he's so good, I wish all
my teachers could be that good."

00:05:20.855 --> 00:05:22.898
And when they try to describe what that is,

00:05:22.898 --> 00:05:25.128
they just say, "He has that magic."

00:05:25.128 --> 00:05:26.390
But I'm here to tell you

00:05:26.390 --> 00:05:28.848
that magic can be taught.

00:05:28.848 --> 00:05:31.195
Magic can be taught.

00:05:31.195 --> 00:05:34.007
Magic can be taught.

00:05:34.007 --> 00:05:35.538
Now, how do you teach it?

00:05:35.538 --> 00:05:37.209
You teach it by allowing people

00:05:37.209 --> 00:05:38.614
to go into those spaces

00:05:38.614 --> 00:05:40.216
where the magic is happening.

00:05:40.216 --> 00:05:42.948
If you want to be an aspiring
teacher in urban education,

00:05:42.948 --> 00:05:45.230
you've got to leave the confines of that university

00:05:45.230 --> 00:05:46.988
and go into the hood.

00:05:46.988 --> 00:05:49.098
You've got to go in there and
hang out at the barbershop,

00:05:49.098 --> 00:05:50.480
you've got to attend that black church,

00:05:50.480 --> 00:05:51.935
and you've got to view those folks

00:05:51.935 --> 00:05:53.738
that have the power to engage

00:05:53.738 --> 00:05:55.518
and just take notes on what they do.

00:05:55.518 --> 00:05:58.518
At our teacher education classes at my university,

00:05:58.518 --> 00:06:00.912
I've started a project where every single student

00:06:00.912 --> 00:06:05.504
that comes in there sits and watches rap concerts.

00:06:05.504 --> 00:06:07.727
They watch the way that the rappers move

00:06:07.727 --> 00:06:09.260
and talk with their hands.

00:06:09.260 --> 00:06:12.240
They study the way that he
walks proudly across that stage.

00:06:12.240 --> 00:06:14.446
They listen to his metaphors and analogies,

00:06:14.446 --> 00:06:16.058
and they start learning these little things

00:06:16.058 --> 00:06:17.858
that if they practice enough

00:06:17.858 --> 00:06:19.547
becomes the key to magic.

00:06:19.547 --> 00:06:21.808
They learn that if you just stare at a student

00:06:21.808 --> 00:06:24.311
and raise your eyebrow about a quarter of an inch,

00:06:24.311 --> 00:06:25.778
you don't have to say a word

00:06:25.778 --> 00:06:29.351
because they know that that
means that you want more.

00:06:29.351 --> 00:06:31.806
And if we could transform teacher education

00:06:31.806 --> 00:06:34.068
to focus on teaching teachers

00:06:34.068 --> 00:06:36.021
how to create that magic

00:06:36.021 --> 00:06:39.818
then poof! we could make dead classes come alive,

00:06:39.818 --> 00:06:41.532
we could reignite imaginations,

00:06:41.532 --> 00:06:43.248
and we can change education.

00:06:43.248 --> 00:06:46.342
Thank you.

00:06:46.342 --> 00:06:49.181
(Applause)

title: Hidden miracles of the natural world
transcript: What is the intersection between technology, art and science? Curiosity and wonder, because it drives us to explore, because we're surrounded by things we can't see. And I love to use film to take us on a journey through portals of time and space, to make the invisible visible, because what that does, it expands our horizons, it transforms our perception, it opens our minds and it touches our heart. So here are some scenes from my 3D IMAX film, "Mysteries of the Unseen World."(Music)There is movement which is too slow for our eyes to detect, and time lapse makes us discover and broaden our perspective of life. We can see how organisms emerge and grow, how a vine survives by creeping from the forest floor to look at the sunlight. And at the grand scale, time lapse allows us to see our planet in motion. We can view not only the vast sweep of nature, but the restless movement of humanity. Each streaking dot represents a passenger plane, and by turning air traffic data into time-lapse imagery, we can see something that's above us constantly but invisible: the vast network of air travel over the United States. We can do the same thing with ships at sea. We can turn data into a time-lapse view of a global economy in motion. And decades of data give us the view of our entire planet as a single organism sustained by currents circulating throughout the oceans and by clouds swirling through the atmosphere, pulsing with lightning, crowned by the aurora Borealis. It may be the ultimate time-lapse image: the anatomy of Earth brought to life.At the other extreme, there are things that move too fast for our eyes, but we have technology that can look into that world as well. With high-speed cameras, we can do the opposite of time lapse. We can shoot images that are thousands of times faster than our vision. And we can see how nature's ingenious devices work, and perhaps we can even imitate them. When a dragonfly flutters by, you may not realize, but it's the greatest flier in nature. It can hover, fly backwards, even upside down. And by tracking markers on an insect's wings, we can visualize the air flow that they produce. Nobody knew the secret, but high speed shows that a dragonfly can move all four wings in different directions at the same time. And what we learn can lead us to new kinds of robotic flyers that can expand our vision of important and remote places.We're giants, and we're unaware of things that are too small for us to see. The electron microscope fires electrons which creates images which can magnify things by as much as a million times. This is the egg of a butterfly. And there are unseen creatures living all over your body, including mites that spend their entire lives dwelling on your eyelashes, crawling over your skin at night. Can you guess what this is? Shark skin. A caterpillar's mouth. The eye of a fruit fly. An eggshell. A flea. A snail's tongue. We think we know most of the animal kingdom, but there may be millions of tiny species waiting to be discovered.A spider also has great secrets, because spiders' silk thread is pound for pound stronger than steel but completely elastic. This journey will take us all the way down to the nano world. The silk is 100 times thinner than human hair. On there is bacteria, and near that bacteria, 10 times smaller, a virus. Inside of that, 10 times smaller, three strands of DNA. And nearing the limit of our most powerful microscopes, single carbon atoms.With the tip of a powerful microscope, we can actually move atoms and begin to create amazing nano devices. Some could one day patrol our body for all kinds of diseases and clean out clogged arteries along the way. Tiny chemical machines of the future can one day, perhaps, repair DNA. We are on the threshold of extraordinary advances, born of our drive to unveil the mysteries of life.So under an endless rain of cosmic dust, the air is full of pollen, micro-diamonds and jewels from other planets and supernova explosions. People go about their lives surrounded by the unseeable. Knowing that there's so much around us we can't see forever changes our understanding of the world, and by looking at unseen worlds, we recognize that we exist in the living universe, and this new perspective creates wonder and inspires us to become explorers in our own backyards.Who knows what awaits to be seen and what new wonders will transform our lives.We'll just have to see.(Applause)Thank you.(Applause)

00:06:12.512 --> 00:06:15.416
So under an endless rain of cosmic dust,

00:06:15.440 --> 00:06:17.533
the air is full of pollen,

00:06:17.557 --> 00:06:19.193
micro-diamonds and jewels

00:06:19.217 --> 00:06:22.800
from other planets
and supernova explosions.

00:06:23.531 --> 00:06:27.662
People go about their lives
surrounded by the unseeable.

00:06:30.548 --> 00:06:33.596
Knowing that there's so much
around us we can't see

00:06:33.620 --> 00:06:36.750
forever changes
our understanding of the world,

00:06:36.774 --> 00:06:38.590
and by looking at unseen worlds,

00:06:38.614 --> 00:06:41.366
we recognize that we exist
in the living universe,

00:06:41.390 --> 00:06:44.246
and this new perspective creates wonder

00:06:44.270 --> 00:06:46.849
and inspires us to become explorers

00:06:46.873 --> 00:06:48.171
in our own backyards.

00:06:50.560 --> 00:06:52.970
Who knows what awaits to be seen

00:06:52.994 --> 00:06:55.541
and what new wonders
will transform our lives.

00:06:56.685 --> 00:06:58.130
We'll just have to see.

00:07:01.632 --> 00:07:06.385
(Applause)

00:07:06.409 --> 00:07:07.583
Thank you.

00:07:07.607 --> 00:07:10.678
(Applause)
